Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
306 PM EDT Sat Sep 7 2019

.SHORT TERM (Tonight through Monday)...A somewhat flat H5 high
pressure ridge will continue to produce unseasonably warm
temperatures for the next couple of days, with rain chances too 
low to mention. Because of the unusually dry conditions down by 
the Chattanooga area in recent weeks, temps Monday may jump into 
the mid 90s. Dewpoints across east TN will be creeping upward as 
the week begins, although the most humid conditions will hold off 
until Tuesday in the extended period.

.LONG TERM (Monday Night through Saturday)...Overall, the main 
weather concern through the extended will be the hot conditions. 
Tuesday should be the hottest day with temperatures approaching 
but for the most part expected to stay just below record levels. 
The weather pattern responsible for the heat will be a ridge of 
high pressure strengthening over the region Monday night and 
Tuesday. Southerly flow will continue to pull warm air into the 
region and this flow will also increase low level moisture. The 
result will be a hot Tuesday afternoon with highs generally in the
90s across most valley locations...heat indices could approach 
the 100 degree mark around the CHA area. The increased low level 
moisture will also aid the development of afternoon diurnal 
convection. Due to strong subsidence...thunderstorm activity 
should mainly be confined to higher elevations. 

On Wednesday...the strong ridge will remain the main weather feature 
but it will be slowly shifting east. Therefore...expect highs to be 
not quite as hot but still expect many to reach into the 90s.  With 
the strong daytime heating combined with a weak short wave moving 
through and a slight weakening of the substance...expect diurnal 
convection to develop across the area with the best chance...as 
usual...over higher terrain. Thursday and Friday more of the same as 
the ridge slowly shifts eastward. Temperatures will still be hot for 
this time of year but overall slightly lower than previous days. 
Strong diurnal heating will continue and added to that will be a 
short wave riding through the upper flow.  As a result...afternoon 
isolated to scattered convection is expected. Models indicate a 
frontal boundary will be approaching the area on Saturday.  This 
should continue the minor cooling trend and increase the chance of 
thunderstorm development across the entire area.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
338 AM EDT Sat Sep 7 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Partly to mostly cloudy skies early this morning ahead of a weak 
front that is moving across the forecast area at this time and 
should be through the region by or shortly after 12Z. No rain 
showers have shown up on radar although there could be a few as 
the front moves over the eastern mountains during the early 
morning hours. Temperatures are a few degrees warmer due to the 
cloud cover this morning as compared to yesterday, mostly mid 60s 
to lower 70s at 300 AM. As front exits this morning skies will 
begin to clear and winds will be from the north to northwest which
will bring drier air into the region and lower dew points to the 
mid 50s to lower 60s and keep relative humidity values down into 
the mid 30s south to the mid 40s north. Heat index values will 
again not be that high and close to the actual highs in the mid 
80s to lower 90s. High pressure builds southeast from the Ohio 
Valley to the Tennessee Valley today and tonight. Also upper level
ridging begins to rebuild over the Southeast states as upper 
troughing along east coast shifts east. Lows tonight will be 
comfortable again in the mid 50s to the mid 60s with the drier air
mass continuing.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Friday)...
The extended forecast period kicks off on Sunday morning amidst 
zonal H5 flow across the eastern CONUS as upper ridging builds 
across the Deep South, all while a series of weak northern stream 
H5 shortwaves pass through the central/northern plains states. At 
the surface, weak high pressure centered over the OH valley will 
favor a relatively dry PBL with light nly flow expected, 
eventually breaking down in favor of stronger anticyclonic flow 
beneath the building southeast upper ridge Monday night into 
Tuesday. The pattern through the remainder of the work week will 
remain highlighted by the closed H5 ridge centered nearly overhead
initially, before slowly elongating and shifting westward by 
week's end. As for precipitation, not expecting anything organized
as diurnal convection will dominate each day, especially over the
mountains. Coverage doesn't look all that great as deep layer 
subsidence will prevail for the most part, therefore will keep 
pops capped in the chance range at best. All said, the primary 
weather headline through the period will be the return to well 
above normal temperatures through the week. Currently, guidance 
favors the warmest days being Monday/Tuesday as the ridge 
strengthens overhead, with daily highs surging toward record 
levels and heat indices approaching the century mark on Tuesday 
as moisture slowly advects back into the region thanks to 
developing sly flow. Temperatures will slowly drop a few degrees 
by Thursday/Friday as the ridge migrates west.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Saturday)...

Dew points have finally fallen into the mid/upper 50's this 
afternoon as the flow has been able to back to more northwesterly to 
advect in drier air. Mainly clear skies continuing this evening and 
winds dropping to light and variable beneath the surface high will 
work together with this drier airmass and lead to a quick drop in 
temperatures early tonight. However, most locations will cap off in 
the low/mid 60's due to increaing high level clouds from north to 
south tonight. These clouds are associated with a mid level short 
wave and weak surface cold front that will dive into the region in 
the NW flow aloft. Soundings indicate that this feature will be 
moisture starved, so will mention increasing clouds after Midnight 
but only a slight chance pop in northeast TN, southwest VA, the 
northern Plateau, and eastern mountains.

The weak cool front will move southeast through the region by mid 
morning scouring out any isolated showers. Kept slight chance pops 
through 15Z then dry the rest of the day. Skies will become mostly 
sunny again, and highs Saturday behind this front will actually be 
slightly warmer than today with generally mid/upper 80's in 
southwest VA and northeast TN and upper 80's/low 90's from the 
middle valley and points south.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday night through Friday)...

Saturday night and Sunday...flow aloft becomes fairly zonal with 
high pressure at the surface. This should continue the warm and 
dry conditions through the rest of the weekend. On Monday...there 
will be a weak short wave riding along the upper flow. Moisture 
and lift limited and for the most part expect mainly an increase 
in clouds generally over northern locations though an isolated 
shower or thunderstorm can not be ruled out over higher terrain of
the northeast part of the CWA. 

Tuesday through the end of the extended...a strong of ridge of high 
pressure builds in over the eastern U.S.  This should keep 
temperatures a bit above normal through the period.  Circulation 
around the high will bring in warm...moist air and strong daytime 
heating could potentially aid the development of afternoon diurnal 
convection.  Additionally...a series of fairly weak short waves will 
push through Tuesday through Friday.  As a result...expect to see 
occasional isolated to scattered convection...especially over higher 
elevations.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Forecast area sees another warm late summer day after some patchy 
fog and some higher clouds along the edge of Dorian over the 
northern half of the area early this morning. Early morning 
temperatures are in the 60s to near 70 at 300 AM. Hurricane Dorian
east of Wilmington is moving faster to the northeast tonight with
the outer clouds just brushing the northeast part of the forecast
area. High pressure over the Mississippi Valley and western Ohio 
and Tennessee Valleys will move overhead today with lighter north 
to northwest winds than Thursday. Mostly sunny skies and dew 
points dropping into the mid to upper 50s late today will keep 
heat index values down. Highs today will be similar to Thursday 
but a couple degrees cooler, in the mid 80s north to around 90 in 
the southern valley. Tonight a weak front moves into the Ohio 
Valley then approaches the northwest part of the area by 12Z 
Saturday. Only affect will be some increase in clouds overnight 
and Saturday morning and a slight chance of showers northeast 
half. Lows tonight about 60 northeast to about 70 at Chattanooga.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Friday)...
The extended range forecast period kicks off on Saturday morning as 
TC Dorian gets swept up by a northern stream trough digging through 
Ontario, allowing for quasizonal nwly flow aloft across the Southern 
Appalachian region atop broad ridging centered over TX.  At the 
surface, high pressure looks to advect southeast across the Central 
Plains beneath confluent H5 flow.

Pattern evolution through the period will feature dry air advection 
amongst the aforementioned surface high and associated zonal H5 
flow, which should keep the region dry through the weekend with 
near/above normal temperatures featured.  Moving into the start of 
the work week, guidance favors the TX ridge sliding east and 
strengthening atop the Deep South with the surface high sliding 
east, effectively opening the region back up to sly waa on Monday 
into Tuesday.  While the northern stream remains active through the 
rest of the week featuring an upper wave and consequent surface 
cyclogenesis tracking across the Great Lakes region, the southern 
stream looks stagnant as the now subtropical anticyclone holds. This 
pattern would suggest increased chances for diurnal convection by 
mid/late week, with temperatures remaining above normal levels.

FXUS64 KMRX 051923

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
323 PM EDT Thu Sep 5 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Friday)...

The southern Appalachian region remains between surface high 
pressure centered over the mid Mississippi Valley and Hurricane 
Dorian churning off of the coast of the Carolinas. The tighter 
pressure gradient between these two features has allowed for 15-20 
knot northerly to northeasterly surface winds this afternoon. These 
gusts will quickly subside after 00Z as boundary layer mixing begins 
to wane, but a light northerly flow of 5-10 knots will continue 
through the night as Dorian slowly moves toward the mid Atlantic 
coast. The rain shield with Dorian will stay well to our east, but a 
cirrus shield will continue to stream into southwest VA and far east 
TN through tonight. This will continue to keep a fairly sharp 
gradient in cloud cover from east-west across the county warning 
area. Kept lows tonight slightly above guidance over southwest VA 
and northeast TN due to these clouds and the wind staying up.

Friday will be a picture perfect day as Dorian accelerates to the 
northeast and the surface high slides southeastward over the TN 
Valley. A few lingering clouds in northeast areas will diminish by 
15Z yielding mostly sunny skies areawide. Broad upper troughing 
persisting over the eastern U.S. combined with this surface high 
will continue a light northwesterly flow pattern, and this will 
finally draw lower dew points down into the region. Highs will still 
be slightly above seasonal normals (mid/upper 80's), but the lower 
humidity will make it feel much more comfortable.

.LONG TERM...(Friday night through Thursday)...

Not a whole lot of excitement going on during the long term. The 
biggest story will be the heat due to a building ridge of high 
pressure. 

To start the period, Dorian will be well off to our east with a cold 
front dropping down out of the Ohio River Valley. The airmass still 
looks pretty dry but there may be a few light showers around 
Saturday morning as the front moves through. The front should be to 
our south by Saturday afternoon with drier and cooler air moving in. 
Enjoy Saturday's weather because it will be the nicest day of the 
forecast period. Highs will be in the low to mid 80s for most with 
RH values ranging from the mid 40s to mid 50s. Saturday night will 
also be very nice with lows in the upper 50s to low 60s. 

The ridge slowly starts to build in on Sunday and continues through 
the Tuesday. Highs on Sunday will be in the upper 80s to low 90s. 
The hottest two days will be on Monday and Tuesday with highs 
ranging from the upper 80s to mid 90s. On Tuesday precip chances 
start to tick upwards as the high to our east starts to bring in 
moisture from the south but POPs are still only in the slight chance 
to low-end chance category. The ridge breaks down some for Wednesday 
and Thursday so it won't be as hot and POP chances and coverage will 
be a little higher across the area due to the lowering heights. 
Highs will be in the upper 80s to low 90s for both Wednesday and 
Thursday.

mountains, so will include a slight chance PoP for this afternoon in 
those areas. Slightly cooler air will be filtering in, so today 
should not be quite as hot as recent days although max temperatures 
will still be a bit above normal in most locations.

.LONG TERM...(Friday through Wednesday)...Warm temperatures that 
are near normal to above normal will prevail through the extended 
forecast period. Hurricane Dorian will be exiting to the northeast
affecting coastal North Carolina Friday with some lower clouds 
over the northeast sections early in the day. Otherwise weak high 
pressure behind todays front that will be centered to the west and
the surface low from Dorian will keep a north to northwest flow 
over the east Tennessee Valley Friday. Late Friday, Friday night 
and early Saturday low pressure and weak front moves across the 
region from the Ohio Valley. Air mass will be rather dry but a few
sprinkles or showers possible late Friday night and early 
Saturday. Expect temperatures Friday will be similar to todays 
lower to mid 80s northeast and central to upper 80s to around 90 
southeast. Early Saturday slightly cooler lows in the upper 50s to
mid 60s. Saturday possibly a degree warmer as upper ridge to the 
west begins to move east as Dorian moves farther northeast. 
Surface high pressure will be centered over the Great Lakes and 
Ohio Valley. Sunday the upper level ridge will be re- centered 
over the southeast and Tennessee Valley beginning a warming trend 
in temperatures up to the upper 80s to lower 90s and then mostly 
lower to mid 90s Monday through Wednesday lower elevations. Lows 
will stay slightly above normal in the 60s to near 70. Monday the 
surface high will have shifted far enough east for a return 
southerly flow to increase moisture and allow for isolated showers
and thunderstorms in higher elevations to the east. Tuesday into 
Wednesday increasing shower and thunderstorm chances and spreading
to all areas Wednesday. Heat index values will also reach the mid
to upper 90s central and southern valleys Monday through 
Wednesday with higher humidities.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
324 PM EDT Wed Sep 4 2019

.SHORT TERM (Today through Tomorrow)...
Another warm, sunny day today across the area as Dorian continues to 
spin to our southeast and a weak cool front approaches from the 
northwest. With the weak, and mostly dry, frontal boundary expected 
to move through the area today/tonight some of the high resolution 
models are trying to generate some very light showers along the 
Cumberland Plateau. Soundings show that there's a pretty decent cap 
over the area and not a lot of forcing along the front. Will keep 
about a 10% chance of rain for this afternoon into tonight. 

Front will knock back temperatures a few degrees, but still expect 
to see highs in the upper 80's to low 90's across the valley 
locations tomorrow. At the same time the outer band of Dorian could 
wrap around and bring some light precipitation into the Southern 
Appalachian Mountains tomorrow. QPf amounts should remain light and 
am not expecting any impacts west of the mountains from this storm.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday night through Wednesday)...
The main focus on the long term period will be unseasonably warm 
temperatures. Thursday night into Friday, Dorian will be lifting 
north along the coat of the Carolinas finally pulling away from 
Virginia by Friday evening. A shortwave dropping through the Great 
Lakes will help Dorian off to the northeast and will usher another 
front into the region late Friday and into Saturday. However, with 
limited moisture and a building upper ridge over the region rain 
chances will be negligible.

Speaking of an upper ridge, there is some disagreement by early next 
week with respect to  how strong or how high an amplitude upper 
ridge builds over the southeast Sunday into next week. Regardless, 
most model guidance shows afternoon highs rising from the upper 80s 
to low 90s on Friday to the low and mid 90s by Monday and Tuesday 
afternoons. This is some 7 to 10 degrees above normal for this time 
of year. 

Did keep some rain chances in the forecast for Monday and Tuesday 
afternoons, mainly over the higher terrain. If the ECMWF is correct 
in showing a stronger and higher amplitude upper ridge over the 
southeast United States, then rainfall chances will likely be over 
done. But there's enough uncertainty in that regard that keeping 
some rain in the forecast seems reasonable at this time.

behind exiting Dorian will suppress any chance of convection. 

For Saturday and Sunday, upper ridge moves east and builds into the 
southern Appalachains and southeast United States suppressing 
convection and producing hot conditions. High temperatures in the 
lower and middle 90s will be common in the valley which is 7-10 
degrees above normal.

feature over the area producing hot conditions, but enough moisture 
pulling back into the southern Appalachains to possibly produce some 
orographic convection in the afternoon.

side over our area. NAM soundings show more significant convective
energy today, but appear to be suffering from an overmoistening 
of the boundary layer as is often the case in these types of 
persistent patterns. However, it does appear that there may be 
enough instability for some isolated convection mainly across the 
north, so will include a slight chance of showers and perhaps even
some thunder across the northern Plateau, northeast TN and 
southwest VA. Tonight should be dry and mostly clear. High 
temperatures today should be similar to Sunday's highs.

.LONG TERM...(Monday through Sunday)...Overall...it should be a 
rather quiet extended period though there will be a couple of 
features to note.  On Tuesday...we will still be under the influence 
of surface high pressure and will therefore see another day of 
warm...dry conditions.  A weakening cool front will be pushing 
across the region on Wednesday/Wednesday night.  There is minimal 
lift and little moisture to work with.  Could see a pocket or two of 
sprinkles to a stray isolated shower...but confidence low there will 
be enough moisture available.  So...for now...will leave things dry 
on Wednesday but will add low PoPs over higher elevations Wednesday 
night due to the added upslope lift as the front pushes into the 
mountains.  By Thursday...the frontal boundary should be to our east 
and Dorian should be over the Carolinas. Models continue to keep 
Dorian east of the Appalachians and current thinking is that the 
main influence we will see will be an increase in cloud cover. 
However...an outer band of convection could affect the East TN 
Mountains and part of southwest VA and will continue low PoPs in 
these areas on Thursday. Weak ridging develops over the area into 
Friday for another dry day. Models in poor agreement by the weekend 
with the ECMWF maintaining the upper ridge and the GFS wanting to 
bring in weakening frontal boundary. This boundary current shows 
little energy or moisture...so for now...will keep things dry for 
the weekend.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Monday)...
A shortwave trough and cold front in the lower OH Valley region
will be moving across our area tonight and tomorrow. The
environment ahead of this trough/front is still quite dry,
although we will see a sliow rise in dewpoints and low level
moisture through the night. However, there won't be much moisture
for the system to work with as it moves through. A slight chance
PoP will be mentioned tomorrow afternoon as the frontal passage 
provides a little shallow lift and convergence that could spark
some convection. This is a bit lower than MOS guidance due to the
dry conditions we have seen lately. Will also have high temps 
tomorrow a bit above guidance, in the upper 80s to lower 90s. 

.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Sunday)...
Quiet weather is expected to continue through the first part of 
September as we're under a relatively dry atmosphere and quasi-
zonal to weak troughing pattern in the mid-levels. A few weather 
systems of note for the long term portion of the forecast. First, 
is a frontal boundary expected to move in on Wednesday/Thursday 
from the northwest. This system will have almost no moisture to 
work with and most of the rain associated with it should end 
before it makes it into the Eastern Tennesee Valley. It should, 
however, knock temperatures down several degrees for the second 
half of the work week.

The eye of Hurricane Dorian is still forecasted to remain close to 
the East Coast of the U.S. leaving us in the drier air to the 
northwest/west of the storm. Depending on the exact track of the 
storms we have a slight chance for some light precipitation along 
the Southern Appalachian Mountains, but most likely the biggest 
impact in our area will be increased cloud coverage in Northeast 
Tennessee and Southwest Virginia. 

One more weak front will try and push through over the weekend, but 
this one also looks to have very little moisture to work with, so 
will continue with a sunny and dry forecast into the upcoming 
weekend for most places.

most spots. 

.LONG TERM...(Sunday night through Saturday)...
By 00Z Monday, much of the eastern two-thirds of the country will
be underneath low amplitude troughing with a weak front draped 
across the Ohio valley. Ridging to the west will begin to build as
a weak shortwave moves through the Ohio valley. Isolated 
thunderstorms are possible across SW VA, and the mountains of East
Tennessee Monday but most locations should stay dry as winds out 
of the north promote advection of a drier airmass. High pressure 
at the surface quickly builds in from the west early to mid week 
bringing dry weather conditions and near to slightly above 
temperatures. 

Wednesday, a shortwave trough will move south out of Canada and 
weaken the ridge. At the surface, this shortwave will drag a rather 
potent cold front through much of the Ohio and Tennessee valley. At 
the same time, Dorian will be moving north near the coast. This 
track will mean limited if any effects on our surface weather with 
the exception of increased winds, and possibly increased cloud 
cover. Not expecting a great deal of precipitation with the incoming 
front as the subsidence on the western side of Dorian will be 
strong. Dorian moves off to the east late in the period, with a 
surface high beginning to move directly overhead the region with a 
much drier airmass. Subsidence due to high pressure will bring dry 
weather conditions. Temperatures during this time will be near 
average.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday night through Friday)...

off. A broad but pretty weak trough over the eastern U.S. will have

precipitation should stay north and out of the area closer to the 
Great Lakes region. During most of next week this pattern will lead 
to mostly sunny skies each day, and with plenty of sunshine daytime 
temperatures will reach the upper 80's into the lower 90's across 
the valley locations, a few degrees above normal for this time of 
year.

work it's way southward across the Ohio Valley. Extended models are 
in disagreement with how far south this system will make it and how 
much moisture will be available to work with. Will keep low end 
precipitation chances in case the front is able to make it into the 
Eastern Tennessee Valley. Also worth keeping an eye on is the track 
of Hurricane Dorian as it is forecasted to move up the East Coast. 
Current models are all showing that it should stay along the coast 
keeping us in the western/northwestern portions of the storm. This 
would keep us mostly dry, and maybe only seeing some increased 
clouds west of the Southern Appalachian Mountains. Again, will keep 
an eye on it, but at this time the impacts in our area from the 
hurricane are forecasted to be minimal.

457 
FXUS64 KMRX 291848
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
248 PM EDT Thu Aug 29 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Friday)...

Plenty of subsidence and dry air remain in place this afternoon with 
surface high pressure centered just to the northeast of the southern 
appalachians and northwesterly mid to upper level flow. This 
continues to bring cool Canadian air deep into the Tennessee 
Valley, so only isolated afternoon cumulus have developed. Winds 
will quickly go mainly calm after sunset as the high settles 
overhead, so excellent radiational cooling conditions will develop. 
Stayed close to the cooler MET guidance with widespread mid/upper 
50's expected. Forecast soundings at the TRI Cities show saturation 
below the low-level inversion in the 09-12Z timeframe as temps fall 
close to dew points, so patchy fog will again develop in protected 
valleys of northeast TN and southwest VA. 

Any fog will quickly burn off after 13Z Friday as the boundary layer 
warms. The upper level trough will lift northeast through the day 
allowing heights to rebound. At the same time, the surface high will 
slide a bit farther east. This will begin a WAA process, so high 
temps will be a solid 5 degrees warmer than today with skies 
remaining mostly sunny. Dew points will be slow to rise and will 
remain at comfortable levels to continue the beautiful stretch of 
late summer weather.

.LONG TERM...(Friday night through Thursday)...

The extended range forecast period kicks off on Friday evening 
amidst ridging across much of the southeast CONUS thanks to a 
broad/flat subtropical high.  A series of weak upper impulses look 
to pass through the mean northern stream flow across the Midwest 
into the OH valley, but most if not all activity in association will 
pass by to the north through at least early Sunday.  By that point 
the extended period becomes more complicated and thus uncertain as 
TC Dorian's influence moves into the picture.  Before that though, 
am expecting dry weather with highs near or slightly above normal 
levels.

By Sunday morning, high pressure will have shifted eastward across 
New England, with flow around the approaching TC favoring slight ely 
veering across the Southern Appalachians.  With that, Atlantic 
moisture advection will commence, all while Dorian passes in the 
vicinity of the Bahamas and takes aim at Florida.  Meanwhile, a 
deeper shortwave will pass through the northern stream, eventually 
sweeping into the northeast CONUS effectively forcing the old 
surface high out to sea.  By this point forecast confidence is low 
as the eventual weather across east TN and southwest VA/NC will 
depend on Dorian's track.  Currently, operational guidance suggests 
the cyclone moving over the east coast of Florida through early 
week, riding along the southeast coastline before turning slightly 
inland to sweep through the Carolinas into mid/late week.  If the 
center of the circulation stays east of the Appalachians, impacts 
across the TN Valley will lower as increasing nly flow advects drier 
air into the region.  However, if the cyclone tracks nearly overhead 
of the spine of the Appalachians (or further west), increased 
impacts from moderate to heavy rainfall and wind will be on the 
table.  For now, the extended fcst will feature low rain chances 
westward through the week, with slightly higher chances eastward 
over the mtns in closer proximity to the current fcst track. 
Temperatures are expected to remain near normal levels.

will be low (20 to 30 PoP) and generally confined to the higher 
elevations. Monday will see more of the same with continued strong
diurnal heating and an approaching system. The area with the best
chance of convection will expand over southern locations and 
possible over the northeast.

track and strengthen of the remnants of Dorian.  Models continue to 
have poor agreement with the handling of Dorian.  The GFS is 
bringing the system into GA Monday night and Tuesday then lifting it 
northwestward across western NC and potentially into East TN mid to 
late week.  The ECMWF is slower and generally moves it into the gulf 
by midweek.  With all of this...confidence quite low so for now... 
will maintain fairly low PoPs Tuesday and Wednesday...expecting 
mainly diurnal convection with minimal influence from Dorian for now.

FXUS64 KMRX 270702
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
302 AM EDT Tue Aug 27 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

A strong upper trough was present over the northern plains and up
into the central Canadian provinces this morning. Associated 
surface low pressure was situated over western Ontario, with a 
weaker surface low positioned over the Great Lakes as well. The 
much talked about cold front stretched south from the Great Lakes 
into Indiana and southwestward into Missouri and Oklahoma. 
Further southeast into eastern Tennessee, the remnant influence of
a warm front can be seen thanks to a weak CAD setup east of the 
Appalachians and northerly surface flow down the TN valley.

Radar imagery shows that shower activity from earlier tonight has
pretty much subsided. However a weak impulse will move east 
across the region as we approach daybreak. Increased lift across 
the remnant warm frontal boundary will likely cause another uptick
in shower activity, albeit with only light rain expected. Another
break in rainfall is expected from mid morning onward until 
convection along the front makes its way into the forecast area 
this evening and into the overnight hours. Tried to time in these 
breaks in the rainfall as best I could. I imagine that much of the
day today will be dry, and for most people. Did leave at least 
some chance PoPs lingering in the mountains throughout the day. 
Moist upslope flow is likely to generate some light rain from time
to time there. Elsewhere though, it should be mostly dry today.

Temperatures today should be notably warmer than yesterday. While
cloud cover will be plentiful this morning, some sun breaks could
occur this afternoon. Couple this with a lack of rain and we 
should see highs in the low 80s in many areas. As mentioned, 
convection along the cold front arrives over the plateau during 
the evening hours. By shortly after midnight the front should be 
moving into the mountains, which is where rainfall should be 
mostly confined to by that time. 

Despite a frontal passage tonight, the arrival of drier air and
complete end of rain chances hold off until we get into the long 
term period.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday through Monday)...

A few lingering showers/thunderstorms will be slowly exiting the 
area Wednesday morning as a cold front pulls away from the area. 
High pressure builds in behind the front...allowing a drier and 
cooler air mass to filter in. As a result...highs mid week will 
average in the low to mid 80s across most valley locations and 
lows should drop into the mid 50s to mid 60s. Temperatures will 
slowly warm towards the end of the work week but high pressure and
dry conditions should continue to dominate through weeks end. The
next chance of showers/thunderstorms will be around the Sunday 
and Monday time frame as an upper trough and a couple of weak 
short waves transition through the area.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
327 PM EDT Mon Aug 26 2019

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Tuesday)...A weak short wave will
continue to press slowly northeast across the region tonight.
Tried to have higher pops on the major terrain features with a
lower probability of precip in the valley; especially Northeast
Tennessee where a downsloping and drying flow should continue
through much of the short term period. Model solutions not all on
the same page for Tuesday with indication of weak lift with an
impulse prior to the approach of the main upper trough and cool
front toward evening. Stayed close to guidance temperatures in the
mid to upper 60s tonight and lower to middle 80s on Tuesday. 

.LONG TERM (Tuesday night through Monday)...By 00Z Wednesday, a 
trough will be situated across Ontario and into the Midwest. 
Further west, ridging will extend across the four corners into the
Pacific northwest. This trough will bring a cold front through 
the Tennessee and Ohio valley Tuesday night into Wednesday. As a 
result, large scale forcing for ascent will overspread much of the
region with precipitation expected along and ahead of the frontal
boundary. However, the front will likely be in the process of 
washing out as the low pressure quickly evacuates northward. 
Expect precipitation to wane as the front moves through the area 
on Wednesday. Overall instability is meager at best, although a 
couple of hundred joules of MLCAPE should support chances of 
thunder across much of the forecast area. 

High pressure quickly moves in from the west Wednesday and Wednesday 
night with boundary layer winds quickly turning toward the northwest. 
This will result in a much drier airmass with dewpoints in the low 
to mid 50s area wide. The period of dry weather will persist through 
much of the rest of this week with quasi-zonal flow aloft, and high 
pressure at the surface. Temperatures should continue to be below 
average through this period with highs in the 80s and lows in the 
upper 50s to low 60s. The next chance of rainfall will occur late 
this weekend, as a shortwave trough begins to move into the 
Tennessee valley on Sunday. This will push the surface high 
northeast and begin to turn winds to the south and advect an 
increased theta-e airmass northward. Rain chances will begin to 
increase on Sunday with slight chance to chance PoPs. Flow aloft 
begins to transition to northwest flow by Monday as surface high 
pressure continues to move well to the east. Will maintain slight 
chance to chance PoPs Monday afternoon where diurnal convection will 
be possible. Otherwise, temperatures should begin to increase as the 
ridge of high pressure across the plains moves eastward increasing 
low to mid level thickness values.

382 
FXUS64 KMRX 260716
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
316 AM EDT Mon Aug 26 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

Long wave troughing is in place across the central and northern
plains this morning, with a shortwave trough stretching from the
midwest down through the mid Mississippi Valley. This shortwave
will shift east across Tennessee through the day, lifting north
back into the Ohio River Valley by this evening. At the surface, a
stationary front is positioned well to our south across the
Florida panhandle, stretching northwestward towards the Memphis 
area and further west into the central plains.

Locally, isentropic ascent ahead of the shortwave trough will 
lead to plenty of cloud cover today, as well as generating 
scattered showers across the forecast area. The greatest chances 
will initially be west of I-75. Further east towards the NC 
border, models show easterly downslope flow developing ahead of 
the incoming trough. This should help stave off rainfall until 
later in the day for areas nearer the mountains, but expect those 
areas to eventually see rainfall as well. 

The shortwave trough shifts northeast of the region late this 
evening, but the northern plains trough will deepen tonight as the
next disturbance drops south out of Canada. Strengthening
southerly flow in response to low pressure north of the Great
Lakes will bring the aforementioned stationary front back to the
north as a warm front late tonight and into Tuesday morning. 
Models differ on how much of a chance there is for additional 
rainfall tonight and early Tuesday morning, but given the lack of 
notable upper or mid level ridging behind the lead shortwave 
moving through today, and weak ascent with moistening low levels, 
think it's reasonable to keep some slight to low-end chance PoPs 
in the forecast through the night. The best chances would be in 
the south, nearer the approaching warm front.

As for temperatures, the touch of downslope flow today should 
keep temperatures in areas near the foothills and north of I-40 
warmer, with highs likely near 80. Elsewhere 70s appear more
likely. Regardless, temperatures should be well below normal today
due to all the cloud cover and potential rainfall.


.LONG TERM...(Monday through Sunday)...

Main players during the first half of the long term portion of 
the forecast will be a upper trough that drags a frontal boundary 
through the area. On Tuesday the front will be knocking on the 
door, moving in from the northwest. In response we should see 
increasing shower and thunderstorm activity. With temperatures 
expected to only reach into the mid 80's and continuing cloud 
coverage am not expecting much destabilization of the atmosphere, 
so severe weather looks unlikely at this time. Front will make it 
into the Cumberland Plateau around Tuesday evening, and this will 
be the best chance for precipitation across the region. Front will
continue to move through the area during the overnight hours and 
rain chances will taper off during this time.

Behind the front cooler and drier air will be the main weather story 
through the rest of the work week. Weak flow, generally out of the 
north/northwest will keep skies mostly sunny and temperatures a few 
degrees below normal. It should be a very pleasant second half of 
the work week.

Towards the end of the weekend a weak front will try and move into 
the area and along with it southerly/southeasterly flow will allow 
moisture to increase. Shower and thunderstorm chances begin to 
increase with the presence of this additional moisture and the 
frontal boundary. Since the front looks to be pretty weak and 5+ 
days out the models are in some disagreement with strength and 
movement of this system. Will begin to increase precipitation 
chances, but should hopefully be able to trim them down to a 
narrower time frame with later model runs.

basically the same with an amplifying Eastern U.S. upper trough

surface features. The good news for outdoor activity planning is

Saturday into Sunday. The southerly flow should bring enough 
moisture into the Southern Appalachian region for the development 
of a few showers and thunderstorms ahead of the front on Sunday.

period to account for this possibility. Temperatures will be 
seasonably pleasant during much of the long term behind the first 
front; holding near or even a couple degrees below normal. By the

the arrival of the early week cool front.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
255 AM EDT Sun Aug 25 2019

.SHORT TERM (Today through Tomorrow)...
Just a few lingering showers in far Southeast Tennessee early this 
morning, expect them to continue to decrease in coverage. With the 
front to our south and winds blowing from the south over the front 
we should see continued cloudy conditions today. This will keep 
temperatures near or cooler than what we saw yesterday with high 
temperatures expected to be in the low 80's across much of the 
Eastern Tennessee Valley. 

Expect another round of afternoon showers and thunderstorms, with 
the highest chances being in southeast Tennessee closer to the 
front. PWAT values are still very high across much of the area, so 
there still remains the threat of heavy downpours with late day 
convection. Expect coverage to be pretty isolated which will 
hopefully mean that any flooding threat also remains isolated.

Cloudy weather will continue into the overnight hours leading to 
mild temperatures as we head into tomorrow.

.LONG TERM...(Sunday through Saturday)...
Upper troughing will take hold across the north central and eastern 
United States during the long term, with a couple of notable 
disturbances affecting the southern Appalachian region during that 
time. The first will be a shortwave trough moving east through 
Tennessee on Monday, followed by another affecting our area Tuesday 
night into Wednesday. Showers and thunderstorms will accompany both 
disturbances, but the one on Wednesday will feature a stronger cold 
front that will bring some relief from the heat in the form of 
cooler temperatures and notably drier air.

Infrared satellite imagery shows an area of disturbed weather just 
off the east Texas and Louisiana coastline this morning. This is the 
far southern extent of the trough that will swing through eastern 
Tennessee on Monday. Expect fairly widespread showers on Monday as 
this gets pulled north out of the Gulf and across the southern 
Appalachian region. May be a bit of a break in the rain chances on 
Tuesday as the forecast area lies between the departing trough and 
the incoming front for late Tuesday night into Wednesday. Did leave 
some chance PoPs in the forecast but would not be surprised to see 
Tuesday be dry for most areas. The cold front arrives early 
Wednesday, with rain chances declining quickly during the afternoon 
hours. Behind the front, dry and cooler weather is expected to 
finish out the week and first part of the weekend.

Temperatures on Monday may wind up being the coolest of the week due 
to the widespread rain and cloud cover expected. Guidance suggests 
highs in the 70s most everywhere, with perhaps the northern valley 
breaking into the 80s before the rain arrives in earnest. Some 
models say low 70s in the south, which would be well below normal. 
Trended the forecast in this direction, but am still warmer than 
guidance especially in the southern valley locations. Temps rebound 
back into the 80s for the remainder of the week, but with the caveat 
that it will be notably drier and thus much more comfortable. 
Overnight lows in the 50s to low 60s are expected Wednesday night 
onward.

.LONG TERM...(Sunday through Friday)...

in a couple of disturbances embedded in a larger, deepening trough
over the northern plains and upper midwest. The last of these 
short waves will swing through the Ohio River Valley late Tuesday 
night into Wednesday, ushering a strong cold front into the region
along with cooler and notably drier air.

On Sunday, surface high pressure will extend from New England into 
the southern Appalachians, helping to keep a cold front situated 
just to our south. Despite the front being south of the area, lift 
ahead of the approaching upper trough will begin to spread showers 
into the forecast area from the southwest beginning Sunday 
afternoon. Low level flow across the mountains will likely produce 
some downsloping conditions to counter the onset of rain for much of 
the area north of I-40 on Sunday, but rain will eventually spread 
across much of the area by Monday. Diurnal trends should lead to a 
lull in convective activity Monday night, but another round of 
showers is expected Tuesday into Tuesday night as a cold front 
sweeps through.

Drop rain chances quickly Wednesday afternoon and evening coincident 
with the cold front passage. Behind the front, temperatures will 
drop to slightly below normal values with highs ranging from the low 
80s up north to mid/upper 80s in the south. Dewpoints will also drop 
into the 50s to low 60s so it will feel pleasant outside on Thursday 
and Friday.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
313 AM EDT Fri Aug 23 2019

.SHORT TERM (Today and tonight)...
Front currently slowly making it's way southward across Kentucky 
early this morning and along it a shortwave will move across from 
west to east through the day today. Further up in the atmosphere 
we will see divergence aloft towards the right rear of a upper 
level jet leading to convergence near the surface. These will all 
combine to help showers and thunderstorms continue through most of
the day today. We could see some patchy fog this morning, but so 
far cloud coverage has been keeping fog at bay.

Expect coverage to remain relatively scattered early this morning 
into the afternoon, and eventually increasing storm coverage later 
in the day when the shortwave is over the area.

CAPE values around 1000-1500 J/kg and shear values around 10 knots 
mean that storms will struggle to become strong/severe, but it can't 
be entirely ruled out for a storm to cause brief strong winds. The 
bigger threat remains flooding with the storms expected today. Most 
of East TN/Southwest VA has seen rain over the past 24 hours with 
isolated locations seeing close to 2 inches of rain. The efficient 
rainfall producing storms will continue today with PWAT values over 
the area expected to be around 1.5-2.0 inches. The 90th percentile 
for PWAT value this time of year is around 1.85 inches meaning that 
we are in an abnormally moist atmosphere. 

With the additional rainfall and clouds in the area expect 
temperatures to several degrees cooler today compared to yesterday. 
But relative humidity values will remain elevated meaning that it 
will still be muggy out there.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Thursday)...

The long term period will begin with the upper levels resembling 
somewhat of an omega block pattern, with broad troughing over the
northwestern parts of the CONUS and a sharper/deeper trough over 
the eastern Great Lakes and New England parts of the country. 
Meanwhile, high amplitude upper ridging will be in place across 
the upper midwest between the two areas of troughing. At the 
surface, the aforementioned front will be well to our south but 
the mid level reflection of that boundary will be pretty firmly 
entrenched in the vicinity or just south of the I-40 corridor 
across the eastern half of Tennessee and the southern Appalachian 
chain. With time the western trough will deepen over the plains
and mid Mississippi Valley as the quasi-omega block shifts east,
allowing for southerly flow in the mid levels to spread back over
the region by late Sunday afternoon and evening. This continues
through mid week before the trough finally kicks east of the Great
Lakes and pushes another front through the region by late week.

What does this mean locally? Rain chances will remain high 
through the weekend with the presence of the mid level front 
providing a focus for shower and thunderstorm development both 
Saturday and Sunday. For early next week more broad brushed chance
PoPs are in the forecast with the approach of upper level 
troughing and increase moisture levels in general. The forecast 
reflects higher chances to the south of the I-40 corridor this 
weekend however, as that is where the mid level front is most 
likely to reside. Kept at least some slight chances of showers and
thunderstorms in the north as well though, especially in the 
mountainous terrain where differential heating effects will yield 
typical summertime afternoon shower development. Temperature wise,
northerly flow and the likelihood of scattered to widespread 
showers and associated cloud cover should keep temperatures around
normal levels. Expect a return of above normal afternoon highs by
Tuesday though as southerly flow returns.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Wednesday)...

frontal boundary southward into the area by Friday. Ripple of energy 
will zip across the front on Friday bringing another round of 
widespread showers and thunderstorms in the afternoon. Around 1000-
1500 J/kg of CAPE and PWAT values of around 2 inches will mean that 
a good portion of the area should have thunderstorm activity in the 
vicinity. Expect storms to be moving generally parallel with the 
front so the threat for training storms exists, meaning the main 
hazard continues to be flooding. Biggest threat areas for flooding 
looks to be north of Interstate 40 where multiple days of widespread 
heavy rainfalls looks more likely Thursday/Friday.

On Saturday the higher chances of rain shift further south as 
moisture pools along the boundary. On Sunday the front begins to 
move back to the north, keeping higher chances of precipitation 
south of Interstate 40. Dew points and moisture in the area will 
remain somewhat elevated so will keep precipitation chances for more 
diurnally driven storms as we start the work week. Next system will 
be a frontal boundary moving in from the west riding along a trough 
moving across the North Central Plains of the US. Models are in a 
little better agreement, but still differ slightly on timing and 
orientation of the front.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

Current water vapor and RAP upper air analysis indicate a few 
upper level features of note. The first is the ridge that is 
centered across NE TX into OK. A weak shortwave trough is 
rotating around the periphery of the ridge to the north near 
IA. There is also another shortwave trough to the southeast 
across GA/SC. Closer to home, anticyclonic flow continues aloft 
with the ridge to the southwest. IR satellite imagery indicates 
mostly clear skies across the forecast area. Dewpoints are a 
bit higher than the past few morning and there could be some 
patchy fog, especially near area lakes and rivers.

The ridge will continue to be the main influence today. Upper
level heights will be similar to yesterday with 500mb heights in
the 590-592 dm range. Due to this, sided with the warmer side of
guidance again. Expect highs today will be in the mid to upper 90s
for most locations with heat indices near 100 in the southern
valley. PW values today will start out in the 1.4-1.6 inch range.
These values are around the 50th-75th percentile for late August.
Overall, expect a similar coverage to yesterday with not much
forcing. The shortwave trough currently over IA does move into the
Ohio River Valley later this evening. Models indicate a MCS
developing with this system and show a pronounced weakening trend
before it reaches the forecast area. A few models actually show it
dissipating all together. For now, expect a few strong to
marginally severe storms may be possible this afternoon similar to
yesterday. Gusty winds and small hail will be the main threats.
Any ongoing convection should come to an end near sunset with the
loss of daytime heating. Overnight lows will range from the mid
60s to low 70s for most locations. 

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Monday)...

Broad ridging over the Central/Western US, with mild troughing over 
the East Coast will be in place on Wednesday. The low driving the 
trough will slide eastward across Canada, and try to push a frontal 
boundary into the region. Precipitable Water values will increase as 
winds begin to turn more southerly as the frontal boundary 
approaches. While the frontal boundary looks to remain north of the 
area, temperatures should get warm enough on Wednesday to see 
another round of shower and thunderstorm activity.

Front continues to attempt a further push to the south, but with 
very little forcing it will move pretty slow as it gets into 
Kentucky/Tennessee. As usual in these scenarios the models differ 
with how far the front pushes south during the second half of the 
week. Should lead to continuing chances of more widespread showers 
and thunderstorms as we head towards the weekend. Biggest weather 
concerns during the long term portion of the forecast will be the 
potential for several days worth of storms leading to isolated 
flooding in locations that receive multiple rounds of heavy rain.

Over the weekend the trough over the eastern half of the US finally 
moves off to the east leading to a quasi-zonal flow over the area. 
Will still have the possibilty of diurnally driven storms over the 
weekend and into next week, but expect the coverage to be lower than 
Wed-Fri.

National Weather Service Morristown TN
251 PM EDT Mon Aug 19 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Tuesday)...Mid/upper level ridging 
to our west will continue to extend into our area for the short term 
period, with the air mass over our region undergoing little change. 
Ongoing convection is expected to wane quickly toward sunset, 
with a mostly clear sky over much of the area tonight. Model 
soundings for tomorrow look similar to today. Expect convection to
fire first in the higher terrain around noon, and outflow 
boundaries moving into the valley may trigger isolated convection 
there as well as the afternoon progresses. MAV temps look too low 
for max temperatures Tuesday as has been the case recently, so 
will go higher than guidance again. Heat index values should top 
out from the mid 90s to around 100 across most of the valley. 

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday night through Monday)...We begin Tuesday 
night with a distinct shortwave moving from IL/IN into southern 
Ohio as the strong ridge in the southern Plains begins to slowly 
retreat. A few CAMS are showing an MCS moving ESE into parts of 
northeast TN and southwest VA between 03 and 05Z. Deep layer shear
is substantially weaker over our region compared to farther 
north, but there will be lingering instability well into the night
with MLCAPES progged at 1000-1500 J/Kg. If the convective complex
has a strong enough cold pool, think it's feasible that 
showers/storms will impact at least the northern valley and 
southwest VA between 03 and 06Z. The SPC has put the entire region
in a marginal risk Tuesday night, so have increased pops to 
higher chance category the first half of the night. The main 
threat would be damaging winds. 

The deep layer ridge over the south central U.S. will further 
retreat to the western U.S. Wednesday allowing a longwave trough to 
begin developing in the Great Lakes and Ohio Valley. This will force 
a cold front slowly southward. Before this front gets here, 
southwesterly WAA and lingering ridging aloft will maintain very hot 
and humid weather Wednesday. Heat indices in the low 100's will 
continue across parts of the southern valley. Diurnal convection 
will be more widespread Wednesday afternoon with projected soundings 
showing increasing moisture and instability along with limited 
capping. PWATs will range from 1.60 to 1.90 inches with MLCAPE of 
1500-2000 J/Kg. At this time, will go with chance pops for scattered 
convection Wednesday since the forcing will still be well to the 
north. 

The mid level trough will continue deepening Wednesday night and 
Thursday pushing the cold front into KY, and perhaps into the TN 
valley by Thursday afternoon. The GFS remains faster with this front 
compared to the ECMWF. Due to the strong ridge and August 
climatology, am leaning toward the slower ECMWF. Nevertheless, the 
increasing large scale forcing for ascent, deep moisture, and 
instability will cause showers/storms to be on the increase. 
Maintained chance pops Wednesday night increasing to likely 
Thursday. The boundary still looks to struggle to completely push 
through our region Thursday night and Friday, so its exact placement 
remains uncertain. Since the boundary will be oriented E-W somewhere 
in our vicinity and the mid/upper flow will be WNW allowing weak 
disturbances to ripple through, we will continue to see fairly 
widespread coverage of thunderstorms during peak heat with lingering 
showers at night. Kept chance pops Thursday night with likely pops 
central/southern areas Friday. The high moisture environment and 
multiple rounds of convection could lead to localized flooding in a 
few spots, but recent dry weather should keep this isolated. Went a 
little below NBM numbers for temps Thursday and Friday due to 
increased clouds.

The upper trough will slowly pull away Saturday and Sunday with a 
weak overall flow regime returning to the TN valley and southern 
Appalachians as the northern stream jet returns more zonal. The old 
frontal boundary will either wash out or retreat back north, so have 
chance pops for mainly diurnal convection and temps near normal late 
August values. Further height rises Monday and deepening 
southwesterly flow will allow for temps warming above normal
again.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

Current water vapor and RAP upper air analysis indicates an upper 
level shortwave to the north across the Great Lakes. There is a 
weaker shortwave trough that is currently moving into the Ohio and 
Tennessee River Valleys. IR satellite imagery indicates widespread 
cloud cover from the Great lakes southward into the Tennessee River 
Valley. There are a few showers/storms further to the north in 
OH/KY. Further to the southwest, there is an upper level ridge 
centered over Texas. PW values across the area are around 1.4-1.6 
inches. These values are near the 50th-75th percentiles for mid-
August. Some patchy fog will be possible early this morning, 
especially near area lakes and rivers but do not anticipate any 
widespread issues. 

For today, expect the shortwave trough will exit to the east of the 
area by this afternoon. With the trough axis moving through this 
morning, do not anticipate anything outside a couple of isolated 
showers/storms due to the lack of heating and instability. By this 
afternoon, the ridge to the southwest will expand to the northeast 
with 500mb heights in the 590-592 dm range. High temperatures 
yesterday were in the mid to upper 90s for most locations and do not 
see any reason why this would not be the case today. Due to 
forecasting higher temperatures, went with slightly lower dewpoints 
this afternoon generally in the mid 60s. This will result in heat 
indices being a couple of degrees warmer than the actual air 
temperature. Heat indices will be near 100 degrees across most of 
the southern valley this afternoon. There could be a few isolated to 
scattered showers/storms this afternoon with similar coverage to 
yesterday. Best chances will be in the higher elevations with 
chances in the valley around 10-20%. Any ongoing convection should 
come to an end around sunset with the lose of daytime heating. 
Overnight lows will range from the mid 60s to low 70s.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Monday)...

After several days of dry and hot weather, models are in 
agreement with a gradual pattern change that will feature a little
more active weather. An upper trough will press its way into the 
Eastern states through the week, squeezing the protective ridge 
out of the way. As the upper trough moves toward the Southern 
Appalachian region, the gradual increase in moisture and 
instability on slightly deeper southwesterly flow will be more 
conducive to the development of showers and thunderstorms. 
Convection will still be more regionally limited to the higher 
terrain features on Tuesday. However, a much more active period 
for showers and thunderstorms will be seen Wednesday through 
Friday as the moist and unstable air present over the region will 
be lifted ahead of a an associated slow moving cool frontal 
boundary. Perhaps the highest chance for storms will be Thursday 
through Friday when the front will be making southward progress 
through the forecast area. Probability of precipitation should 
decrease from north to south over the weekend, as synoptic lift 
follows the boundary into the Deep South. The good news is there 
will be some relief from the mini heat wave we have experienced 
during the last several days, as longer periods of cloud cover and
convective precipitation should cap off the above normal warmth. 
By next weekend, a weak northerly flow should help to maintain 
temperatures a little closer to normal for late August.

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Sunday)...
High pressure will keep control over the area through Sunday,

Ohio Valley and a southern branch along the Carolina coast. There
could be a small increase in convective coverage over our higher 
terrain Sunday in comparison to today. Mountain convection could 
cross our state line as moisture increases on the NC side, and 
isolated convection could fire up into the higher terrain of SW 
VA. A couple of models suggest a little bit of activity over the 
Cumberland Plateau of TN as well Sunday, so I added low slgt-chc 
pops there for Sun afternoon. Meanwhile, the heat will increase a 
degree or two as temps will be in the low to mid 90s in the 
Valley, with heat indices from the mid to upper 90s. So while it 
will be a good weather day, be prepared to keep hydrated if 
outdoors.

.LONG TERM (Sunday Night through Saturday)... 
At the beginning of this period, Sunday evening, we will be in 
between a few weather features, with an upper ridge along the Gulf
Coast and a predominant zonal flow to our north, leaving us on 
the north edge of the ridge. At the surface there will a frontal 
system well to our west and northwest, stretching from Michigan to
Colorado, a strong surface ridge out in the Atlantic, although we
will have a weak surface ridge near us, that is slowing the 
return flow from the Gulf. This pattern slowly changes during the 
week with us getting into an upper NW Flow by Thursday, with an 
increasing southwesterly return flow, and the cold front sagging 
closer to the area. For Friday and Saturday, there is less 
agreement in the models, varying from an unsettled pattern with 
the moist axis hanging in the area to a weak ridge building with 
less lift and moisture. What is agreed upon is that we will 
generally be staying in a warmer airmass with the cooler Canadian 
air staying to the north through this period. As a matter of fact,
Heat Index values will likely be over 90 degrees at most valley 
locations through the duration of this extended forecast, with 
95-100 degrees in the southern valley through Wednesday, the 
lowering a few degrees as the moist axis and clouds and rains get 
closer by Thursday.

stalling out Friday. Due to this, lowered PoPs on Friday to account

amount of uncertainty with this still being towards the end of the

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
311 AM EDT Fri Aug 16 2019

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...This period of the forecast should 
be another quiet one in terms of active weather. Drier and more 
stable air continues to build into the Southern Appalachian region. 
A study of forecast soundings supports this quiet scenario with 
precipitable water less than an inch, some capping and negligible 
cape in the beautiful northerly flow regime. Insolation in this 
environment will be in abundant supply but max temperatures should 
still be a degree or two below Thursday's highs due to that 
northerly component. Additionally, dewpoints should drop to the 
lower 60s again this afternoon, keeping the upper 80 to lower 90 
degree heat slightly more tolerable than earlier in the week. 
Another mostly clear night tonight and lower dewpoints should allow 
temperatures to drop to the lower and middle 60s over much of the 
region, with a few spots in the upper 60s to near 70 degrees.


.LONG TERM (Saturday through Friday)...The period of dry weather 
will extend into the beginning of the long- term period with 
rather zonal flow aloft. PW values on Saturday will be around 
1.2-1.3 inches, which are slightly below the median for mid- 
August. Sunday will be a transition day as moisture begins to 
increase across the southern Appalachians. In the low levels, the 
Bermuda high will expand to the west with light southerly flow in 
the low levels. Best chances for afternoon showers and storms will
be over the higher elevations of east Tennessee. Highs 
temperatures on both Saturday and Sunday will be in the upper 80s 
to mid 90s for most locations. 

By Monday, a ridge to the east and west will amplify with slightly 
lower heights over the Southeastern U.S. A ridge to the west will 
amplify over Texas and to the east over the Atlantic. Moisture will 
be elevated by this time with dewpoints returning into the upper 60s 
to low 70s for most of the area. With a typical summer pattern, 
diurnally driven showers/storms are expected each afternoon next 
week. Temperatures will be near climatological normals for mid-
August with highs in the mid 80s to low 90s for most locations. Heat 
indices will be near 100 degrees for the central and southern valley 
Monday-Wednesday. 

The GFS and ECMWF both indicate a front that will slide southward 
out of the Midwest into the Ohio River Valley late in the week. 
Latest runs seem to slow and stall this boundary just to the north 
or stall it out across northern portions of the forecast area. Given 
the time of the year, it makes sense that the boundary would stay to 
the north of the area keeping PoPs elevated into the extended 
portion of the long-term forecast period.

that saw rain yesterday are the most likely to see fog tonight, 
along with some of the area waterways.

As high pressure to our west pushes further east tomorrow the 
flow becomes more zonal. A weak wave of energy will move across 
the Ohio River Valley tomorrow afternoon but shouldn't affect our
weather. Expect mostly sunny skies with highs ranging from the 
mid 80s to near 90. Dewpoints will again be in the low to mid 60s.

.LONG TERM...(Friday night through Thursday)...

The extended begins with a continuation of the dry weather already 
in place. A broad and flat H5 ridge will keep the storm path to our 
north over the Ohio Valley this weekend, although a resumption of SE 
low level flow over the Carolinas will push moisture to the spine of 
the Appalachians on Sunday and trigger afternoon convection there. 
However, the H5 ridge will strengthen in two centers, over the 
desert SW and over the Atlantic, leaving our region in a weak low 
pressure trough that will draw up tropical Gulf moisture and promote 
mostly diurnal scattered showers and tstms for much of the work 
week. A vigorous shortwave will sweep across the Great Lakes 
Wednesday and help shove our weak trough to the east, dropping down 
an associated cold front...but the models disagree on the timing. 
GFS is earliest with fropa late Wednesday, while Canadian and ECMWF 
have a Thursday timing. Thus we may see drier weather late in the 
period.

GFS and ECMWF are suggesting a Bay of Campeche tropical system will 
work its way into south TX around day 9...we will see.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Morning fog will be a concern in parts of the area this morning.
As of 230 AM, it seems fairly isolated but it should expand in the

Advisory or SPS is needed, mainly in the eastern half where rain
showers were more numerous yesterday.

Today, a weak surface low will be tracking east across the upper
OH Valley to the central Appalachians. Forecast soundings show a 
capping inversion at CHA and TYS that should suppress any 
development in the central and southern portions. At TRI, this cap
is weaker, and the hi-res models hint at some afternoon 
development in NE TN/SW VA. So a slight chance PoP will be 
included for that area. Through the day as the low moves east,
high pressure over the MO Valley region will be building in, and
the dry NW flow aloft will continue. This should give high temps
similar to yesterday, mainly upper 80s to around 90, but with
comfortable humidity levels as dewpoints will be in the low to 
mid 60s this afternoon.

.LONG TERM...(Friday through Wednesday)... 
The Tennessee Valley and southern Appalachians will still reside 
at the base of a broad mid to upper level trough to the north 
Friday with a surface high overhead. This subsidence and WNW flow 
aloft will allow for a beautiful end to the week with highs near 
or just below seasonal averages and tolerable humidity levels. 
Higher heat and moisture will begin to return Saturday as the 
surface high slides a bit farther east and heights rise aloft. 
Soundings will still be quite dry, so will stick with a dry 
forecast all areas and temps rising back into the low 90's in most
of the region. Sunday will bring the first chance for isolated 
diurnal convection as a weak mid level shortwave approaches from 
the west helping to strengthen the WAA. Have slight chance pops 
Sunday afternoon and evening in the higher terrain of the Plateau 
and eastern mountains where differential heating will trigger a 
few storms. Expect quick dissipation after sunset. Hot and humid 
conditions will continue with highs in the low 90's in most areas 
and a few mid 90's in the southern valley. Low temps this weekend 
will become increasingly uncomfortable struggling to fall below 
the 70's.

Uncertainty increases Monday through Wednesday. The Tennessee Valley 
and deep South will get stuck in a weakness between strengthening 
mid level ridges over the desert southwest and near Bermuda. This 
will yield weak flow aloft with an elongated mid level trough 
overhead. These patterns are favorable for tropical moisture to 
stream northward with widespread diurnal convection and locally 
heavy downpours, and all model guidance suggests this trend, 
however, the latest ECMWF shows a distinct tropical low drifting 
north through the Carolinas and southern Appalachians early next 
week, while the GFS and Canadian have no such low. At this time, 
will keep consistent with high end chance pops during the daytime 
hours Monday through Wednesday and slight chance to chance at night. 
This tropical airmass will be very humid, but clouds and precip will 
keep highs mainly in the 80's, so will undercut NBM guidance by a 
few degrees.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
328 PM EDT Wed Aug 14 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Thursday)...

Showers and a few storms are ongoing along a weak front that is 
slowly drifting across the area. The front is stretched from 
southwest to northeast generally along and east of the I-75/I-81 
corridor. Showers and any storms dissipate with loss of daytime 
heating and as the front pushes further east out of our area. For 
the rest of this afternoon, a few storms could approach SPS 
criteria as there is still some weak instability and shear across 
the area. With only 500 to 1000 J/kg of MLCAPE though, don't 
expect any strong updrafts which is why there is little lightning 
activity with the current storms. Nonetheless, will keep an eye on
things just in case anything briefly pulses up. Overnight lows 
will be in the mid to upper 60s for most. 

Overnight, drier air slowly tries to work in from the northwest but 
low-level moisture will have a hard time eroding as it gets pooled 
up against the eastern terrain. This will promote cloud cover 
hanging around tonight. Fog is probable for some areas but not too 
confident in coverage. The uncertainty in amount of cloud cover, 
winds, and drier air make for a difficult fog forecast. Conditions 
further improve tomorrow as the drier air makes a bigger push into 
the area. Expect sunshine and highs in the mid to upper 80s with 
dewpoints in the low to mid 60s.

 


.LONG TERM...(Thursday night through Wednesday)...

he long term will being with broad upper troughing over the eastern 
United States, mainly over/north of Tennessee, but will attempt to 
transition to a more zonal flow across the northern tier states by 
late in the weekend as upper ridging strengthens over the desert 
southwest, and also to our east towards Bermuda. Dry conditions are 
forecast across the forecast area for Thursday night through 
Saturday with weak WNW flow in place overhead and drier air 
filtering into the region. Some clouds may be build up over the 
mountains but that would be about the extent of it.

Moisture levels will be on the increase by Sunday as surface high 
pressure moves to our east and at least some degree of warm 
southerly flow returns to the region, even if just above the 
surface. Expect to see some afternoon showers and thunderstorms make 
an appearance once again on Sunday as a result. The best chances 
will be in the mountains mainly, but will carry some chance PoPs 
into the lower elevations as well.

For Sunday onward, the forecast is a bit uncertain. Did not make any 
significant or wholesale changes to the forecast, and kept with the 
trend of higher rain chances for Monday onward. Models show upper 
ridging over the southwest CONUS, and also a typical summertime 
Bermuda high. This leaves the southern Appalachian region in a 
weakness between the two ridges, with subtle/weak height falls noted 
in the H5 fields and increased chances for convection Sunday night 
through Tuesday. The uncertainty lies in how widespread rainfall 
will be and whether there will be any kind of system move north from 
the eastern GOMEX during the first half of next week. Models hint at 
some development, though not necessarily tropical, off the Florida 
panhandle late Sunday into Monday before pulling it back north 
across the region. This seems plausible given the pattern, so 
continued with PoPs close to what the previous shift had.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
258 AM EDT Wed Aug 14 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Most showers have pushed well to the east and south of our area in
association with a shortwave trough, but a diffuse front remains
to our north across KY. The mid and upper levels have dried
considerably behind the initial trough, but abundant low level
moisture remains for low clouds and fog to form this morning.
Another shortwave trough will be approaching today, and will help
push the surface front through the area. This will keep a chance
of showers and thunderstorms going today, mainly in northern
sections. Overcast cloud cover this morning will become broken
this afternoon, which should hold temperatures back in the 80s for
most spots today. The passage of the 850-700 mb shortwave trough
and the weak surface front should bring an end to any precip 
chances by midnight.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Tuesday)... 
Not much change in the long-term as the Tennessee Valley and 
southern Appalachians region will reside at the base of broad 
troughing Thursday and Friday. This will result in a WNW flow 
pattern bringing relief from the recent heat and humidity. High 
temps will actually be slightly below the mid August averages with
most areas seeing 84-87 Thursday and 85-90 Friday along with 
refreshing lows in the low/mid 60's. The southern valley will run 
a couple of degrees warmer for both highs and lows. Dew points 
will fall into the low/mid 60's during this period, so it will 
feel a little bit more comfortable outside. Cannot rule out an 
isolated shower or thunderstorm in the higher terrain of the east 
TN mountains and southwest VA Thursday afternoon/evening, but this
will only be a slight chance pop since soundings project rapid 
drying aloft. Friday will stay dry in all areas as surface high 
pressure in the central Appalachians takes firm control. 

Temps and dew points will slowly trend back upward this weekend as 
the surface high slowly moves farther east and mid to upper level 
ridging tries to redevelop across the Southeast U.S. Soundings still 
look pretty dry Saturday, and there are no real forcing mechanisms, 
but increasing heat and humidity combined with differential heating 
boundaries over the higher terrain warrant slight chance pops for 
afternoon/evening thunderstorms over far east TN and southwest VA. 
Any activity will quickly dissipate after sunset. Afternoon 
convection will become a little more widespread Sunday as warm and 
moist southwest flow deepens ahead of a shortwave trough moving into 
the West TN valley and Delta, so have slight chance to chance pops 
across most of the area.

The above mentioned shortwave will move into our region Sunday night 
then separate from the northern stream. This will result in a very 
slow moving, broad mid level low over much of the South and 
Southeast U.S. Monday and Tuesday. Cloud cover and precip should 
cool highs to slightly below normal values during this period, but 
continued southwest flow will keep the airmass very muggy. The 
greatest coverage of showers/thunderstorms will occur during peak 
heating, but with a moist profile in place (PWATs of 1.60-2.00 
inches, warm cloud depth, and WBZ heights close to 14,000 ft), 
scattered showers could also occur at night. Have high chance pops 
during the day Monday and Tuesday and lower end chance during the 
overnight periods.
