Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
407 PM EDT Tue Aug 13 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Thursday night)...
Latest surface analysis and HREF ensemble show an outflow boundary
across the Plateau and southeast Tennessee. Air mass along and
south of the boundary is quite unstable with MLCAPEs of 2500-3500
J/Kg. Pressure falls across Kentucky will help maintain
southwesterly flow into this boundary through this evening. 

A complex of storms have developed over middle Tennessee latest
CAMS show these thunderstorms moving across the Plateu and east
Tennessee. Like this morning, the following are the concerns:

1) Wind Damage...Soundings show a vertical profile with dry air 
aloft producing DCAPE of 1200-1400 J/Kg with Delta theta-e 
difference of over 35. Wind Damage index of over 1. Overall,
damaging winds will be the main concern.

2) Hail...Even though MLCAPEs are sizeable and Hail CAPES will be
500-700 J/Kg, WBZ heights are fairly high, generally at or above
12kft. There is a potential of marginal severe hail with the
strongest storms.

3) Tornadoes...The 0-6km shear is marginal at best with values of
25-30kts and 0-1km between 5-15kts. Supercell Composite 
Parameters of 2-4 so some isolated supercell characteristics 
possible. Significant Tornado Parameter will be less than 0.5. 
Overall, the threat is very low.

4) Flash Flood...PWs along and south of the boundary is between
1.9 and 2.1 inches. Any training along the boundary could produce
localized flash flooding.

5) Confidence...High for potential of severe storms and moderate 
to high on timing.

For Tonight, convection will diminish by late evening but 
scattered showers will remain possible. Patchy fog possible.

For Thursday and Thursday night, an inverted trough will be across
the far eastern sections of the area with scattered showers and
afternoon storm possible. Drier air will advect into the region
limiting instability. Convection dissipates soon after sunset.
Patchy fog again possible.

.Long Term (Friday through Tuesday night)...By 12Z Friday the region 
will be under cyclonic flow aloft while at the surface high pressure 
remains anchored. The surface high pressure will bring mainly dry 
weather through much of the weekend. Aloft, several perturbations 
will travel through the region likely leading to an increase in 
cloud cover. Overall moisture in the column should remain limited to 
keep PoPs fairly low with slight chance PoPs in the higher terrain. 
A more significant wave will approach the area Sunday night and 
stall out Monday and Monday night turning low to mid level flow 
towards the south and west advective moisture and instability. At 
the surface, a weak boundary will sink into the Ohio valley but 
should remain far enough north to remain a insignificant source of 
focus for convection. This means that with weak focus for 
convection, better PoPs will likely reside across the higher terrain 
where differential heating could aid in development of convection. 
The upper level low over the Tennessee valley will begin to open up 
into more of a shear axis. As a result, will keep chance PoPs going 
through the rest of the extended period. Temperatures through the 
extended should remain near average with possibly a degree or two 
below average for early next week.

depictions from the hi-res models. A slight chance PoP will be kept 
in the grids in northern sections in case this activity is able to 
persist as it crosses KY. 

The current Heat Advisory for the central and southern TN Valley 
continues to appear on track, with high temps in the mid to upper 
90s and dewpoints in the lower 70s will give heat index values in 
the 100-105 range. One slight adjustment will be to add Sevier, 
Jefferson, and Cocke counties into the Advisory. 

Convection is expected to ignite this afternoon along a E-W boundary 
across KY, and track SE across our area during the late afternoon 
and evening hours. Given the high CAPE environment that these storms 
will be encountering (MLCAPE > 3000 J/kg), there will be a risk of 
severe storms with damaging winds being the primary threat. There 
remains some timing uncertainties as the hi-res models are not in 
complete agreeement, but based on the HREF mean, the most likely 
window for strong to severe storms is 21-03Z. Will use this timing 
as a basis for the PoP/Wx grids, which is a little faster than what 
the NAM is showing. Cold pool propagation usually results in faster 
timing being correct. QPF amounts are expected to average around a 
half inch across the area. 

.Long Term (Wednesday through Monday)...
An upper level trough will have made enough progress into the 
Eastern U.S. by 12z Wednesday to push a cool frontal boundary into
the eastern and southern reaches of the forecast area. 
Additionally, models hint at a trailing weak upper wave riding 
east through the Upper Ohio Valley which may spark a shower or 
thunderstorm across parts of Southwest Virginia and Northeast 
Tennessee. Therefore, keep some slight and smaller chance pops for
some convection going in these areas on Wednesday with decreasing
pops from west to east later in the day with almost no pop across
the forecast area by Wednesday evening. 

A most pleasant, and drier mean west to northwest flow brings 
relief to the mini heat wave experienced over the last few days as
well as a noticeable lack of convection for the last half of the 
week. Surface high pressure and the dry air should keep 
thunderstorm development to a minimum until about Sunday and 
Monday when a return southerly flow behind the departed low level 
ridge brings a little bit more moist and unstable air back to the 
Southern Appalachian Region. Despite the slightly more improved 
air mass for convection, there doesn't appear to be any major 
focus present other than aid from orographic lifting. Therefore, 
tried to place the slightly higher chance pops on the major 
terrain features for this late portion of the forecast. The good 
news in this extended forecast is the relief from the brief heat 
wave which should end up with about two to three days of 
temperatures back to a few degrees below the typical 85 to 90 
degree warmth. Temperatures will gradually return to about two to 
three degrees ahead of mid August norms over the weekend.

FXUS64 KMRX 121943
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
343 PM EDT Mon Aug 12 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Tuesday night)...
Heat and strong/severe storms are the main topics for the short 
term period. In the upper levels, a ridge of high pressure was 
located across much of the southern plains and southeast United 
States. Further north a wave was located across the midwest and 
is moving towards the east. At the surface, high pressure 
continues to move east while low pressure develops across the 
plains. Water vapor imagery this afternoon shows a large plume of 
moisture associated with a weakening MCS traveling through the 
Ohio valley. Some of this moisture and cloud cover has been able 
to move into portions of the forecast area and has kept
temperatures a degree or two below forecast. Most of the area 
should remain dry today and tonight with the exception of the 
mountains where differential heating would allow isolated to 
scattered thunderstorms to develop. Otherwise it should be a hot 
and humid afternoon with highs in the low to mid 90s. Not 
anticipating needed any heat advisories today. Tonight into 
Tuesday morning, a shortwave trough will move into the Ohio valley
flattening the ridge out further south. The result on the lower 
troposphere will be to turn 850mb winds to the south. This will 
promote the advection of moisture tonight and on Tuesday with very
warm temperatures expected. 925mb temperatures are progged to 
warm to 28-30C by Tuesday afternoon and guidance suggests highs to
reach the low to mid 90s with the highest temperatures in the 
southern valley. As previously mentioned, moisture will increase 
and as a result, dewpoints will increase to the low to mid 70s. 
This will produce heat index values in the 105-110F range across 
portions of the southern valley, and central valley. Decided to 
issue a heat advisory from 16Z to 00Z Tuesday given the forecast 
heat index values. 

The other topic is the chances for strong to severe thunderstorms.
Convection is expected to increase along and ahead of a cold front
dropping out of the Ohio valley. The environment ahead of this
front will be characterized by surface based CAPEs near 2000-3000
j/kg and lifted index values near -5 to -8 C. However, lapse 
rates should be fairly weak only near 5.5 to 6.0 c/km. Given the 
relatively modest flow aloft, would expect a multicellular 
convective mode with the chance of strong/gusty winds being the
main threat. Not anticipating much in the way of hail as freezing
level heights will be fairly high. Boundary level flow oriented 
parallel to the boundary does promote the chance of isolated flash
flooding although the quick nature of the boundary should keep 
the chances limited. Both the heat advisory, and the strong/severe
storm potential will be highlighted in the HWO. Otherwise, 
frontal forcing and DCVA should be sufficient for chance PoPs 
continuing through the night with likely PoPs across the higher 
terrain. 

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday through Monday)... At the beginning of 
this period--Wednesday morning--the cold front and upper short 
wave will be exiting the area during the morning NW-SE, with 
precip chances ending in the valley and lingering in the eastern 
mountains. Previous Blend runs have lingered POPs all day for most
of the forecast area, but with surface focus and upper lift 
leaving and moisture lowering, it's looking more and more like 
Wednesday will be drying NW-SE more quickly, and the thick, steamy
air will be exiting as well. 

High Pressure builds into the area through Friday, then a surface 
return flow starts Saturday that will start to bring low level 
moisture back into the area.  By Sunday models diverge between 
solutions of keeping us in the warm moist air versus pushing a weak 
cold front through the area with better chances of showers and 
storms. For now, will just go with marginal Blend POPs and will look 
for convergence of a solution as it gets closer for Sunday and 
Monday.

931 
FXUS64 KMRX 120729
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
329 AM EDT Mon Aug 12 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
The surface high pressure area that brought lower dewpoints to 
the area yesterday will be shifting east to the Atlantic coast 
today. This will give a prevailing southerly flow from the surface
through 850 mb, advecting low level moisture into the area. A NW 
flow will remain in the mid and upper levels, which will limit 
convective coverage today to just the mountains along the TN/NC 
border. The prevailing NW flow aloft should prevent any storms 
that develop from entering the Valley. With the rising dewpoints 
and high temps expected to be similar to yesterday, we will have 
heat index values near 100 in Chattanooga this afternoon, with mid
90s in Knoxville.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Monday)...
Tuesday is expected to be our most complex and impactful weather 
day during the next week with the potential for dangerous heat 
prior to evening thunderstorms which may produce severe weather.

At the beginning of the extended, a large ridge will continue to be 
centered over the Southern Great Plains and extend across much of 
the Lower Mississippi and Tennessee Valleys. A small shortwave 
trough across the Ohio Valley will be moving eastward with an 
associated weak surface low. A weak cold front will extend 
southwestward from this surface low across central KY, West TN, and 
through Red River Valley of Texas. As this front moves slowly 
southeast on Tuesday afternoon, convection is expected to initiate 
along this boundary in a highly unstable environment. We'll go into 
some more detail regarding thunderstorm impacts in a moment, but 
first, we'll take a closer look at the heat.

With the area still on the eastern edge of the upper ridge, 
temperatures will continue to be about 7 to 10 degrees above 
average. As moisture increases ahead of the approaching front on 
Tuesday afternoon, dew points will rise into the low, and possibly 
mid, 70s. Based on the current forecast, this would lead to 
widespread heat index values in excess of 105 degrees, Heat Advisory 
criteria, across the southern valley south of Knoxville and near 
Chattanooga. There are some factors that increase uncertainty for 
Tuesday. First, will cloud cover ahead of the front limit max 
temperatures or will subsidence be strong enough to maintain a 
mostly clear sky with the exception of afternoon sct cu? Second, 
what will be the exact timing of afternoon convection that could 
limit overall max temperatures? Third, how much moisture return will 
be realized in the boundary layer and what will be exact dew point 
values? Only a small difference of a degree or two could mean the 
difference in realizing advisory heat index values. Because of the 
inherent uncertainty 36 hours in advance of the potential heat 
impacts, will not issue an advisory this forecast package, but will 
continue to highlight the heat hazard in the HWO. If confidence 
increases, future shifts may need to explore coordinating an 
advisory for portions of the area.

Next, we'll take a look at the severe thunderstorm risk. As the 
shortwave trough and surface low track east across the Ohio Valley 
toward the Mid-Atlantic on Tuesday afternoon, the surface cold front 
will move southeast toward the forecast area. MLCAPE across the 
forecast area will range from 1500 to 2500 J/Kg and effective bulk 
shear will range from 15 to 25 kt. DCAPE is forecast by the NAM to 
be between 900 and 1200 J/Kg. Forecast soundings indicate a weak 
isothermal layer near 800mb, especially across southern portions of 
the forecast area, that may limit convective coverage ahead of the 
front. Because of this, expect a line of thunderstorms to develop 
along the cold front or prefrontal trough in SE KY late Tuesday 
afternoon and move southeastward into the forecast area between 6PM 
and Midnight Tuesday night; however, still have low confidence on 
exact timing 36-48 hours from the potential convective event. With 
the thermodynamic and kinematic environment in place across the 
forecast area, a multicell line of thunderstorms is most likely with 
damaging winds the primary hazard. In addition, with PW values 
increasing to between 2.0 and 2.2 inches ahead of the front, heavy 
rain rates are likely with thunderstorms resulting in the potential 
for isolated flash flooding. For any additional details, please see 
the SPC Day 2 CWO and WPC Day 2 ERO.

As this front moves east, surface high pressure builds in mid to 
late week with slightly cooler temperatures and drier air with dew 
points in the 60s. However, by the weekend, the GFS and ECMWF show 
upper ridging building back across the Southeast CONUS and an 850-
700mb ridge centered over the Lower Mississippi Valley. This would 
result in max temperatures climbing above normal and generally dry 
conditions.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Surface high pressure will continue to build into the area today
with northerly surface flow bringing drier air to the region. With
the weak frontal boundary across far southeastern portions of the
forecast area, expect an isolated rain shower will be possible 
across the mountain peaks of SE TN and portions of SW NC, but 
overall, most everyone should enjoy a mostly sunny and warm Sunday
with dry conditions. Upper ridging across the South-Central CONUS
will continue to slowly expand eastward with strong subsidence 
aloft. With the increased ridging, drier boundary layer air, and 
max temperatures already in the low to mid 90s, expect 
temperatures to be 0 to 3 degrees warmer on Sunday across the 
forecast area, about 5 to 8 degrees above normal. With dry air at 
the surface, this will limit max heat index values to the upper 
90s near 100 across the southern valley in the vicinity of 
Chattanooga.

Dry conditions forecast tonight with high pressure across the 
region. May have some patchy fog in river valleys, but dry 
conditions should mitigate widespread issues. With the dry air 
resulting in lower dew points, expect temperatures to be near 
normal.


.Long Term (Monday through Saturday)...
A large mid/upper ridge over the southern Plains will maintain a dry 
NW flow aloft across our area on Monday. Forecast soundings show a 
weak cap that should suppress convection for most of the area, with 
the possible exception being the mountains along the NC border. 
Tuesday looks much the same but with a slightly stronger 
southwesterly low level flow that will strengthen warm/moist 
advection. The result of this will be high temps in the mid 90s and 
dewpoints in the lower/mid 70s for the central and southern TN 
Valley, giving a heat index in the 100-105 range. With confidence 
rising regarding Tuesday's heat, it will be added to the HWO. 

On Tuesday a cold front and a shortwave midlevel trough will be 
moving SE across the OH Valley. Some scattered to isolated 
convective development will be possible Tuesday afternoon ahead of 
this system, but stronger forcing to overcome the capping inversion 
will likely not arrive until Tuesday night. Despite the overnight 
timing, there will still be adequate instability when the 
stronger forcing arrives to give a potential for some strong 
thunderstorms. PoPs will be decreasing through the day on 
Wednesday as the front crosses the area. 

The rest of the week will feature the resurgence of a high pressure 
ridge over the Plains, which will keep our area mostly dry for 
Thursday through Saturday. However, there is some general model 
agreement that a tropical low pressure system will develop near the 
Gulf Coast and drift NE across the Southeast states next weekend. 
Details on the position of this low are too uncertain at this time 
to carry high PoPs in the forecast, but it will bear watching.

will remain dry...and warm. By Monday afternoon some afternoon 
showers and thunderstorms could develop mainly in the higher terrain

Muggy conditions with afternoon heat index values approaching 105 
degrees for many areas across East Tennessee and perhaps, as far 
north as southwest Virginia. There is a chance of late afternoon 
thunderstorms bringing some relief in the form of rain cooled air 
and cloud cover to mitigate the dangerous heat. Residual storms will 
likely proceed into Tuesday evening in association with a shortwave 
trough. 

The trough will remain across the eastern U.S. through Wednesday 
night. Until then a chance of showers will persist. Another high 
builds across the Southern Plains for much of the remainder of the 
week. This means there will be low chances of showers and 
thunderstorms developing mainly over the higher terrain during this 
time through the end of the forecast period.

Valley. The convective potential rises as well with scattered 
showers and thunderstorms expected Tuesday afternoon, then PoPs rise 
to likely Tuesday night as a shortwave trough axis crosses the area.

and slightly cooler air (highs 85 to 90) building into the area on

through Tuesday. Warmest day is expected to be on Tuesday as the dew 
point values continue to climb along with the temperatures ahead of 
our next system. If forecast models verify we could see heat index 
values of around 100 at Knoxville and areas further south, with 
Chattanooga climbing above 105.

boundary should push into the area from the north. Extended range

middle of next week, but are at odds with each other with respect to

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
338 AM EDT Thu Aug 8 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
The upper pattern this morning is highlighted by longwave troughing 
across the east coast of the CONUS while broad ridging prevails out 
west, all setting up deep wly/nwly flow across the OH/TN Valley.  At 
the surface, a weak/diffuse surface cold front remains draped across 
the TN Valley and Southern Appalachians, while drier high pressure 
noses in from the north.  Currently across the region, partly/mostly 
cloudy skies prevail, with the most dense sky cover along/south of 
I40 in association with frontal moisture and debris clouds that have 
advect in from upstream.  Am starting to see patchy fog in the river 
valleys across northeast TN and southwest VA, which should continue 
(perhaps expand) given modest radiational cooling.  

Moving on, the aforementioned weak front doesn't look to migrate all 
that much, therefore keeping at least portions of the lower 
valley/plateau in the modestly unstable warm sector therefore 
favoring slight chance pops.  While coverage in these areas should 
remain limited, there looks to be enough instability for deep 
convection, thus won't rule out a strong storm/two with damaging 
winds and hail being the primary threats.  Elsewhere, drier air 
should prevail keeping the remainder of the area precipitation free 
with no pops mentioned.  Temperatures today will once again top out 
a few degrees above normal.  Late in the period guidance suggests 
ridge riding MCS development across lower MO and west TN/KY, 
eventually moving into middle/east TN late in the morning given it's 
survival.

.LONG TERM...(Friday through Thursday)...
There is overall good guidance agreement through the extended. 
Longwave troughing remains across the Eastern CONUS on Friday with a 
strong shortwave moving eastward from the Great Lakes to the 
Northeast with a surface low across Quebec. This will bring a 
surface cold front slowly southward across the Ohio Valley and 
approach the Tennessee Valley by Friday night. There is considerable 
disagreement in the mesoscale details on Friday afternoon as the NAM 
has 1000 to 2000 J/Kg of MLCAPE across the forecast area and the GFS 
has limited 100 to 500 J/Kg MLCAPE. Effective bulk shear is forecast 
to be between 20 and 30 kt, so if instability is closer to output 
from the NAM, could have a few stronger organized thunderstorms in 
the afternoon with downburst winds being the primary hazard. 
However, there is a mitigating factor of low-level ridging across 
the Gulf Coast that will limit boundary layer moisture advection 
into the area ahead of the cold front, and this will act to limit 
some convection and excessive rainfall potential. Still, PWs will be 
high, near 1.9 to 2.0 inches, across the southern valley and 
southern plateau near Chattanooga, so localized heavy downpours and 
flooding issues could occur in favored urban and flood prone 
locations.

As the surface low across Quebec becomes further occluded and the 
forward motion of the surface front slows, it will remain across 
southern portions of the forecast area on Saturday. Drier air and 
subsidence aloft should limit precipitation chances, but may still 
have an isolated rain shower or thunderstorm across SE TN and SW NC. 
We should remain dry Sunday with surface high pressure and upper 
ridging.

Early next week, SW flow returns on Monday afternoon and ridging 
begins to build eastward from the Southern Plains to the Lower 
Mississippi Valley. This will bring upper 500mb heights close to 594 
dam by Tuesday near Chattanooga, and this would result in anomalous 
warmth across the Tennessee Valley. Current forecast brings max 
temperatures on Tuesday into the mid 90s around Chattanooga which is 
near blends and a couple degrees higher than MEX guidance. This 
would result in a heat index of around 105 degrees at Chattanooga on 
Tuesday. There is still some uncertainty of convective coverage 
Tuesday afternoon which would limit overall max temperatures, but 
the trend is for above normal temperatures early next week.

Global models are in good agreement for Day 7 with another shortwave 
moving southeast from the Northern Plains to the Great Lakes next 
Wednesday with an associated surface cold front moving southeastward 
toward the Tennessee Valley. This would bring additional scattered 
convection and cooler temperatures by late next week.

FXUS64 KMRX 070747

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
347 AM EDT Wed Aug 7 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
The pattern this morning is highlighted by an amplified H5 longwave 
trough across the eastern CONUS with an embedded shortwave moving 
through the mean flow across the OH Valley, all while broad ridging 
prevails out west setting up nwly flow across the MS Valley. 
Otherwise, the remnants of an earlier MCS continue to diminish 
across east TN this morning (aided by upper divergence tied to the 
left exit region of an H3 jetmax) while a weak/diffuse surface cold 
front sags southward out of KY into middle/east TN. Pattern 
evolution through the day will feature the passage of the weak H5 
impulse across the region promoting at least some minimal synoptic 
scale lift atop the TN Valley and Southern Appalachians.  With that, 
there seems to be two distinct convective features of note moving 
forward in the short term.

The first convective complex to note would be the broken line of 
showers and thunderstorms ahead of the front across KY.  CAM 
guidance tends to not handle this very well, as least regarding a 
consensus.  The HRRR takes this convection east into WV with no 
southern expansion into TN.  However, the HiRes ARW/NMMB and the 
NamNest build convection along the southern flank into northeast TN 
and southwest VA.  Looking at the latest SPC Mesoanalysis MUCAPE 
fields, there isn't all that much to work with across southeast KY. 
Therefore, will lean toward the HRRR, however given some credence to 
the other aforementioned mentioned CAMS by way of featuring mid/high 
chance pops toward daybreak for portions of northeast TN and 
southwest VA.  Nevertheless, not expecting deep convection with any 
of this potential activity, just general thunder (perhaps just 
showers).

Moving on, the second convective potential of the day will lie 
across portions of southeast TN and southwest NC where instability 
will maximize amongst the prefrontal warm sector.  As usual, the NAM 
seems to be the outlier in this regard as it favors nearly 4k j/kg 
MUCAPE generally along/south of I40 this afternoon given deep dry 
air aloft in its fcst profiles.  Tend to think this is a little 
overdone given the NAMs fcst dewpoints being a little high, thus 
opted to rely moreso on HREF ensemble output which suggest mean CAPE 
exceeding 2-2.5k j/kg.  Regardless, those same NAM profiles do favor 
WBZ heights around 10kft or less, which could present an elevated 
hail threat for taller/deeper convection.  All said, the fcst will 
feature chance pops regionwide this afternoon, lowest across the 
northern plateau, elevated to mid/high chance levels southward as 
well as across the high terrain.  As for threats, primarily would 
expect any deeper convection south of I40 being capable of large 
hail, damaging winds, and frequent lightning. 

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Tuesday)...
Persistent upper pattern through the extended period with 
troughing over the east coast of the nation and ridging across the
central and southern Plains. This will produce northwest upper 
flow with a series of short- waves ejecting across the mid-west 
southeast into the Ohio valley/central Appalachians. These waves 
will pull frontal boundaries into the region.

For Thursday, drier air over the region with a 800-700mb capping 
inversion and surface ridging will produce a mostly dry day.

For Thursday night and Friday, a short-wave will move across the 
Ohio/Tennessee valleys producing high chance/likely chances of 
convection. Marginal CAPE values of 1500-2000 J/kg and slight above 
normal PWAT will produce locally heavy rains.

For Friday night through Sunday, wave will move east of the area 
with drier air and surface ridging moving back into the southern 
Appalachians. A mostly dry forecast anticipated.

For Monday and Tuesday, another wave will move across the 
Ohio/Tennessee valleys with increasing moisture and instability. 
Increasing chances of showers and thunderstorms expected.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Wednesday)...

Seeing a couple of isolated showers early this afternoon across 
portions of northeast Tennessee and southwest Virginia. Current 
water vapor imagery and RAP upper air analysis indicates a weak 
shortwave trough that stretches from southwest Ohio into northern 
middle Tennessee. This approaching trough is leading to a few of 
these isolated showers but the atmosphere is fairly dry with PW 
values in the 1.2-1.4 inch range. These values are near the 25th-
50th percentile for early August. Mid and upper level flow is from 
the northwest and could also see a few showers/storms in the 
mountain as well this afternoon and evening. Highs this afternoon 
will be near climatological normals with temperatures in the mid 80s 
to low 90s for most locations. 

The best chance for showers/storms will come during the overnight 
period into early Wednesday morning. A surface boundary currently 
stretches from near Michigan to the southwest into Kansas. In the 
upper levels, there is a trough currently located across 
Iowa/Missouri/Illinois. IR satellite imagery indicates some 
convection already blossoming in eastern Missouri near St. Louis. Hi-
res models indicate that this convection will continue to develop 
and form an MCS that will track to the southeast with the mean flow. 
Models are struggling with the timing but highest chances for 
precipitation appear to be somewhere in the 09-15z timeframe. Due to 
the overnight nature of the convection, instability will be limited 
and do not expect any strong or severe storms. The best chance for 
any stronger storms will be on Wednesday afternoon for locations 
generally east of I-75 and south of I-40. There is some uncertainty 
about how far south and east the front will make it and how much 
lingering cloud cover continues into the afternoon from 
precipitation early in the day. A decent shortwave trough will move 
through the southern Appalachians during the afternoon and should 
lead to another round of convection if there are some breaks in the 
cloud cover and the front remains to the northwest. If the morning 
round of showers/storms pushes through quickly and the front remains 
to the northwest would expect a higher chance for a few strong to 
potentially severe storms but still too much uncertainty to 
mention more than strong storms in the HWO. 

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday night through Tuesday)...

Longwave upper troughing continues through the extended with NW flow 
across the forecast area. By Wednesday night, 500mb shortwave will 
be to the east of the mountains with shortwave ridging providing 
some subsidence and drying conditions across the area. This may lead 
to some areas of fog if clouds clear across areas that received 
rainfall. Thursday should remain mostly dry with subsidence and a 
capping inversion near 700-800mb.

A strong shortwave will move southeastward on Friday across the 
Great Lakes into the Northeast states with an associated occluding 
surface low across Quebec. This will bring a cold front 
southeastward across the Great Lakes and Ohio Valley with a slowing 
forward motion as it approaches the Tennessee Valley. As this front 
moves across the forecast area on Friday afternoon, expect scattered 
showers and thunderstorms. Severe weather risk is still uncertain on 
Friday, but NAM guidance is showing the potential of MLCAPE between 
1000 and 2000 J/kg. Most dynamics should remain well northeast of 
our forecast area, so expect any severe risk to be small, dependent 
on available instability, and localized at this time. Low-level 
ridging across the Gulf Coast should prevent good moisture return 
across the area limiting the overall coverage of precipitation.

The big question this weekend is where this cold front stalls. The 
ECMWF brings the front through our forecast area and takes it south 
into AL and GA. The 12z GFS is trending further south which would 
favor a drier pattern this weekend. By early next week, ridging 
shifts east with southerly flow and additional moisture returning to 
the region. This will lead to an increase in diurnal thunderstorm 
development mainly across the higher elevations. Temperature should 
remain within 5 degrees of normal through the extended.

the TN Valley.  Conditions early this morning remain rather 
uneventful as only a few low remnant cu persist beneath sct high 
clouds.  Am starting to see a little valley fog developing at this 
time, however given slightly lower dewpoints than previous nights, 
think widespread fog is unlikely and thus should remain confined to 
said valleys.  Nevertheless, patchy fog was mentioned for those 
valley locations.

Moving on, looks like a rather nice Tuesday ahead as partly cloudy 
skies prevail for most areas amidst modest heating favoring highs 
slightly above normal.  Guidance does continue to favor iso/sct 
showers and thunderstorms across the mtns, which was featured by way 
of slight/chance pops maximized during peak heating.  At that point 
the focus of the fcst period shifts northward over the Midwest as a 
weak upper impulse moves southeast along the mean H5 flow atop a 
region of modest instability.  HighRes guidance along with the 
operational NAM continue to suggest MCS development by mid afternoon 
across central IL/IN, which will then move southeast into the OH 
Valley by late day.  Guidance favors said MCS tracking further 
southeast into the evening/overnight hours, most likely weakening as 
it encounters a more stable environment across eastern KY, eastern

pops through the evening/overnight generally along/north of I40 
where low likely to high end chances reside, with slight to low 
chance levels featured south of I40.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday through Monday)...
The main weather feature through the extended period will remain 
northwest flow aloft with a series of short-waves riding 
southeast. These waves will bring frontal boundaries enhancing 
convection.

First short-wave will move across the Ohio/Tennessee valleys 
Wednesday. Models are in general agreement with convection moving 
into the area during the morning with additional scattered storms in 
the afternoon. HREF ensemble mean CAPE is between 2000-2500 J/Kg. 
Plenty of dry air aloft and mid-level lapse rates near 6.5 degree C 
may produce some strong and gusty winds. Main limiting factor for 
convection will be best short-wave forcing will be east of the 
Appalachians and too much dry air. Believe coverage will be 30-40 
percent at best in the afternoon and generally along and east of 
interstate 75.

For Wednesday night and most of Thursday, dry air, mid-level capping 
inversion, and surface ridging will produce dry conditions.

For late Thursday night and Friday, increasing moisture will pull 
back into the region. A frontal boundary will move toward the area 
with scattered showers and thunderstorms anticipated. 

For Friday night through Sunday, frontal boundary will be south and 
west of the area with surface ridging producing mostly dry 
conditions.

evening/night. So confidence for this time period is low as of now. 

Thursday looks mostly dry but slight chance and low-end chance POPs

until late Thursday night/Friday morning. More showers and storms in 
store for Friday and Saturday as another front drops down into the 
area. GFS is trending more toward the ECMWF solution and drops the 
front south through our area by Saturday afternoon where it has 
previously been hanging it up across the area. So as of now, things 
are looking drier for the second half of Saturday. The theme 
continues for Sunday and Monday as yet two more disturbances drop 
down though the continued northwest flow and bring more chances for 
showers and storms.

region, while drier air advects across Middle TN per latest WV loop. 
With that, given clearing skies and a moist/decoupled PBL, already 
starting to see some patchy fog across the Plateau.  Would expect

toward daybreak, thus did include patchy fog in the fcst. Otherwise, 
am expecting a rather uneventful and partly cloudy Monday morning. 

Moving on into the remainder of the day, the deeper moisture axis 
will remain tied to the aforementioned trough axis as it advects 
east.  Therefore did included chance/likely pops across the higher 
terrain this afternoon, tapering down sharply into the evening as 
moisture advects out.  Also included slight/chance pops along the

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Sunday)...

dominant feature. A series of short-waves moving southeast across

into/across the Tennessee valley and southern Appalachians.

the central/southern Appalachians. Models show a fairly strong 300mb 
jet (70-80kts) moving toward the area. Strongest forcing with this 
jet seems to be over southwest Virginia into northern/central 
sections of the Tennessee valley. Decent MLCAPEs of 2000-2500 J/Kg 
with increased 850mb jet to 25kts providing some weak shear 
producing some organization to the storms. Biggest concern will be 
the dry air aloft providing enough thermodynamics for wet microburst 
potential. Also, fairly decent mid-level lapse rates of 6.5 degree C 
enhancing Hail CAPES. Hail CAPES along with favorable WBZ heights 
will allow for the stronger storms to produce marginal severe hail.

Will highlight this potential in the HWO. There is some question of 
timing of the storms. NAM has more storms late Tuesday night/early 
Wednesday, while the GFS and ECMWF are later.

For Thursday, drier air pulls into the area behind the wave with 
most locations remaining dry.

For Thursday night and Friday, another frontal boundary pulls south 
into the area. The GFS tends to hang up the front over the area 
while the ECMWF is more progressive and pulls frontal boundary south 
of the area.

For next weekend, depends on which model is correct. Confidence is 
low for Saturday and Sunday.

National Weather Service Morristown TN
303 PM EDT Sat Aug 3 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Sunday)...

Seeing a few isolated showers early this afternoon on radar imagery, 
mainly over the higher elevations. Current water vapor imagery 
indicates an expansive area of mid to upper level dry air across the 
southern Appalachians. At the surface, there is an E-W oriented 
stationary boundary along the Gulf Coast states. PW values are near 
the 50th percentile for early August. In the upper levels, there is 
a broad trough across the Great Lakes stretching southward into the 
northern Gulf of Mexico. Overall, expect isolated to scattered 
showers and storms will continue this afternoon with best chances 
(40-50%)in the higher elevations and lower (20-30%) chances in the 
valley. Overall, instability values are lower today as well with 
SBCAPE values in the 750-1500 J/Kg range and removed the mention of 
strong/severe storms from the HWO. So far, have not seen any 
lightning with any of the ongoing activity. Convection will decrease 
in coverage and intensity near sunset with the loss of daytime 
heating. Fog formation will be possible again tonight and have 
patchy fog in the forecast. Do not expect fog to be as widespread as 
last night with the limited coverage of precipitation anticipated 
this afternoon and evening. Overnight lows will be near 
climatological normals in the mid 60s to low 70s.

The upper level trough deepens some on Sunday as a shortwave trough 
dives southeastward out of the Midwest into the Tennessee River 
Valley. PW values will recover into the 1.5-1.7 inch range. These 
values are closer to the 75th percentile for early August. 
Additionally, there will be an E-W stationary boundary to the south 
across the Gulf Coast states. Better moisture and slightly better 
lift should lead to a wider coverage of shower/storms Sunday 
afternoon. For now, have highest chances around 60-70 percent across 
southern portions of the forecast area and lowest chances around 20-
30 percent across southwest Virginia where moisture values will be 
lower. Slow storm motion and heavy rainfall will lead to the 
possibility of localized flooding. Best chances for flooding will be 
south of I-40 where the best chances of precipitation will be. Went 
a bit lower with highs on Sunday, due to the increased moisture and 
cloud cover with most locations climbing into the upper 70s to mid 
80s. 

.LONG TERM...(Sunday night through Saturday)...

Overall, the period is characterized by a troughing pattern with 
several waves of energy diving down through the trough.

A few showers and storms will likely be ongoing to start the period 
as a weak frontal boundary is moving south and east through the 
area. These showers and storms should decrease in coverage as we 
lose heating. However, most areas will keep slight chance POPs 
through the night as the front should provide enough forcing to keep 
a few showers going. 

The dominate high to our west helps to force the front to our east 
on Monday but it's so weak it's hard to pick out. It looks like it 
should be centered along the spine of the Appalachians early on then 
progresses eastward into the Carolinas as the day goes on. The 
highest POPs on Monday will therefore be along and east of the I-75/I-
81 corridor, which is closest the frontal location. No POPs in place 
by Monday night as the front is further east. Clearing will occur 
overnight as some, brief, drier air works its way into the area in 
between systems. 

Tuesday looks mostly dry as we are behind the front. Did include 
some slight chance POPs across the elevated areas to account for the 
typical diurnal activity. Tuesday night into Wednesday another weak 
front drops down into the flow and brings another chance for showers 
and storms. The front moves out Wednesday night into Thursday and 
more, brief, drying occurs. 

A stronger front approaches in the Fri/Sat timeframe but models 
disagree on the timing and evolution. The GFS brings the front in 
during the day Friday and hangs it up across our area into the day 
on Saturday which would keep showers and storms around. The trough 
in the ECMWF is much deeper and takes the front well to our south by 
Saturday afternoon which would give us a blast of cool and dry air. 
This far out it's hard to say which model is correct. Temperatures 
will remain near normal through the period.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
341 AM EDT Sat Aug 3 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...Satellite imagery this 
morning shows mostly clear skies with a few areas of upper lvl
clouds still passing through. Area observations along with GOES 
Night Fog product is beginning to show areas of patchy fog 
developing. Surface analysis places a weak inverted surface trough
through western Tennessee/Kentucky with weak pressure troughing 
across the southern Appalachians. High pressure is located to the 
north across the Great Lakes. In the upper levels, a 594dam 
anticyclone was located across the desert southwest, while 
troughing sits across much of the eastern US. Water vapor imagery 
this morning depicts a weak shortwave trough moving out of the 
northern plains, while southern stream energy has been 
intensifying across the northern GoM. GOES 6.95 and differential 
water vapor imagery shows an area of dry air just to the north of 
the forecast area which will likely play a large role in 
convective coverage today. The rest of the night is expected to be
quiet with mostly clear skies, and light winds producing ideal 
radiational cooling conditions for fog development.

The trend has been for lowering PoPs on Saturday and this seems 
to be the case with this forecast package. Northerly winds will 
help to advect drier air into parts of the area which will likely 
limit areal coverage of convection. This can be seen in time 
heights at TRI where the column should be dry from ~800mb and up.
However, further south across CHA, the column remains moist and as
a result would expect the highest coverage across southern 
portions of the forecast area. A strong or severe storm is 
possible during the afternoon as CAPE values increase to 1500-2500
j/kg, with damaging winds being the main threat. Heavy 
rainfall/localized flash flooding is also possible given the 
convective nature of the precipitation expected as forecast 
soundings depict a very moist column with PW values near 1.80 
inches across southern portions of the forecast area. Also, cloud 
bearing winds will remain weak, thus storm motions will likely be 
slow. Otherwise, convection will begin to wane Saturday evening 
with the loss of daytime heating. Saturday night should remain 
quiet with mostly clear skies and light winds. Fog is possible in 
areas that receive rainfall. Temperatures Saturday will be near 
climatology. 

.LONG TERM...(Sunday through Saturday)...

The extended forecast period kicks off Sunday morning amidst H5 
ridging over the western Atlantic as well as across the Four 
Corners, while a low amplitude trough (with an embedded shortwave) 
extends southward across the OH/TN and MS valleys from a parent 
cyclone over eastern Canada. At the surface, high pressure will 
advect southeast across the Corn Belt as a weak frontal axis 
(preceding said high pressure) slides into the OH valley early on 
Sunday, eventually pushing further south into the TN valley and 
Southern Appalachians late in the day as the aforementioned H5 
shortwave advects through. With that, pops will maximize along/south 
of I40 where the most instability will reside ahead of the front. As 
for any threats, think the primary concern would be the potential 
for heavy rainfall and isolated flash flooding given pwats in the 
1.8-2.0 inch range, not to mention slow storm motions oriented 
parallel to the front which could promote training. 

Further pattern evolution on Monday will feature a slight eastward 
shift of the overall synoptic longwave with the axis setting up east 
of the Appalachians and the surface front sliding southward into the 
I20 corridor.  This change will promote slightly drier conditions 
given NVA aloft and dry advection in the low levels, thus pops 
will lower across the board with slight chances westward 
increasing to high chances over the mtns, all mainly on a diurnal 
trend. Tuesday looks relatively dry as flow remains fairly 
flattened at the base of the trough while weak waa prevails, thus 
below climo pops are featured. Beyond that, the pattern will 
continue to feature broad troughing across the eastern CONUS 
through the remainder of the week. During this timeframe guidance 
favors a series of amplifications consequent of a deep H5 cyclone 
over central Ontario, first on Wednesday then again Thursday night
into Friday. Each of these waves could feature weak surface 
frontal intrusions into a relatively moist and conditionally 
unstable airmass (depending on eventual fropa timing). Therefore, 
pops will comply with high chances featured on Wednesday, lower on
Thursday, slightly elevated again on Friday.

Temperatures through the period will kick off nearly a category 
below normal levels on Sunday, before a gradual warming trend 
prevails through the remainder of the week.  Temperatures should 
return to near/above normal levels by midweek.

anticyclone and subtropical ridges hold, while the eastern CONUS 
longwave trough amplifies slightly.  The primary weather focus 
through the period will be the slow intrusion of the aforementioned 
cold front on Saturday into Sunday, possibly stalling nearby or 
overhead. Either way, the parent surface ridge looks to anchor over 
the Corn Belt region through the weekend and into the start of the 
new work week before slowly shifting east and weakening into 
midweek.  By mid/late week another cold front looks to slide 
southeast across the Upper Midwest and into the OH/TN valley region 
Wednesday into Thursday.  All in all, this rather stagnant upper 
pattern and minimal surface features will result in mostly diurnally 
favored convection each afternoon, with chances looking highest on 
Sunday given the introduction of the front.  Temperatures will kick 
off near or slightly below normal levels through the weekend, with a 
gradual warming trend favored through the remainder of the period to 
slightly above normal levels.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Friday)...
Longwave upper-level troughing will continue tonight and Friday 
across the region with a similar pattern in place. As showers and 
thunderstorms decrease in coverage this evening with the loss of 
daytime heating, we will have a clearing sky. Areas that received 
rain this evening and river valleys are likely to experience some
fog by Friday morning. Overnight lows should be near seasonal 
normals.

Morning fog will dissipate midmorning with increasing convective 
mixing and cumulus development along the higher elevations by 
midday. Once again, highest PoPs will be along the higher
elevations of the mountains and the Cumberland Plateau. MLCAPE
should be near 1000 J/kg and effective bulk shear will be
approximately 10 to 20 kt. This will again favor mostly pulse
convection with a few localized downbursts possible. Moisture will
be increasing with PW values near 1.7 inch, so a few heavy
downpours will be possible. Temperatures are expected to be within
a few degrees of normal.

.LONG TERM...(Friday night through Thursday)...
A blocking pattern with strong ridges over the desert SW and the 
western Atlantic will maintain a broad trough over the eastern 
Conus through the weekend. The pattern that we have seen for the 
past few days of scattered afternoon showers and t'storms mainly 
initiating in the Plateau and mountains will continue into 
Saturday. 

A slight change to the pattern is expected to arrive Saturday night 
when a shortwave trough drops southeast from the MO Valley to AR. A 
midlevel deformation zone develops over the TN Valley/Srn 
Appalachians that will enhance lift as a southerly low-to-midlevel 
flow strengthens. PW values rise to near 2 inches by Sunday morning, 
so heavy rainfall may be possible at times. The slow movement of the 
trough suggests this heavy rain potential may continue all day on 
Sunday. However, there is still uncertainty with this system as 
models are not all in agreement. The NAM and GFS agree on the wet 
scenario, while the ECMWF and SREF are much drier, showing a less 
amplified trough that keeps deep moisture to our south. For this 
package, will raise PoPs to likely for most of the area, except SW 
VA, and will add a mention of heavy rain/localized flooding 
potential to the HWO. 

The broad trough begins to make some eastward progress on Monday, 
which will begin a start of lowering rain chances through the rest 
of the forecast. PoPs will remain in the chance range on Monday with 
the trough axis overhead, but lower to a slight chance Tuesday as it 
moves east of the Appalachians. Through Wednesday and Thursday, we 
will have a NW flow aloft that should result in little if any rain 
chances both days and near normal temperatures.

National Weather Service Morristown TN
308 AM EDT Thu Aug 1 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...The upper level trough over the 
region will move little during the short term period. Model 
soundings indicate CAPE values will reach 1500 to 2000 J/Kg across 
much of the area this afternoon, and expect another round of showers 
and thunderstorms which will likely initiate over the higher terrain 
first before spreading into valley areas. While shear will be weak, 
DCAPE values in the 750 to 1000+ range are favorable for some strong 
storms once again with strong gusty winds, and will keep mention of 
this in the HWO along with the potential for localized flooding. 
Expect the convection to wane this evening as we lose solar heating, 
with the latter part of the night forecast to be precip free. 
Temperatures will be near normal for this time of year.

.LONG TERM...(Friday through Thursday)...Not many changes from 
the previous forecast in the longterm. The area will be dominated 
by large scale troughing as ridging sits across the southwest and 
the western Atlantic. This blocking pattern will hold through the 
extended period before the eastern US trough finally moves 
eastward in response to rising heights from the west. Diurnal 
convection can be expected this weekend with the best chances 
across far east Tennessee, SW NC, and SW VA. While organized 
severe weather is not expected, any strong storms could transfer 
enough mass to cause strong/gusty winds. Also, efficient warm rain
process with deep warm cloud layers, and weak 850-300mb winds 
means that heavy rain and localized flash flooding could occur 
with any storm that moves slowly over areas that have received 
recent rains.

On Sunday, southern stream energy in the base of the longwave trough 
will move northward into the southern Appalachians increasing 
forcing for ascent. This will ultimately mean an increase in coverage 
of precipitation can be expected mainly in the afternoon and evening 
hours. Temperatures on Sunday may be a few degrees cooler given the 
increased cloud cover and precipitation and as a result did decrease 
max T's a couple of degrees which was still above MEX guidance.

Next week, the trough will still be situated across the southern 
Appalachians, and Tennessee valley. High pressure to the northwest 
will slowly nudge south as lower pressure remains well to the east. 
Afternoon convection will again be possible Monday through Wednesday 
with the better chances in far eastern TN, SW NC, and SW NC. Chances 
will be less further north and west due to subsidence from high 
pressure. Closer to the end of the extended, the upper level pattern 
becomes less amplified as the ridge flattens out, and shortwave 
energy moves out of Canada into the Great Lakes. This will push the 
eastern US trough east which should lead to decreased chances of 
precipitation. Temperatures should be near normal.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
309 PM EDT Wed Jul 31 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Thursday)...
Upper and mid-level trough axis remains across the area tonight 
and Thursday with some ridging and subsidence building in on the 
west side of this axis. Expect convective activity to decrease 
quickly after sunset with the loss of daytime heating. Areas that 
receive rainfall this evening and have a clearing sky will likely 
see some areas of fog late tonight and Thursday morning. This 
seems most likely across western portions of the forecast area and
the Sequatchie Valley where mid-level subsidence and drying will 
be most pronounced. Further east, questions exist about the extent
of a mid-level cloud deck late tonight and early Thursday which 
could inhibit fog like the past few mornings.

Longwave troughing remains across the forecast area on Thursday. 
The GFS, NAM, and ECMWF all show a small shortwave dropping 
southeastward through the upper-level NW flow toward the region 
Thursday afternoon. This should allow for an increase in afternoon
thunderstorms along and east of the trough axis across much of 
the area. Lower PoPs are expected across the far NW portions of 
the forecast area where subsidence will be stronger; however, will
keep chance PoPs for these areas due to the uncertainty of exact 
placement of the trough axis and because of higher elevations 
aiding thunderstorms coverage along the northern Cumberland 
Plateau. HREF places MLCAPE between 1500 and 2000 J/Kg across the 
valley and eastern mountains with lower values near 1000 J/Kg 
across the northern Cumberland Plateau. Deep layer shear remains 
weak near 10 to 20 kt which will favor primarily ordinary pulse 
convection. Localized severe downburst winds appear probable with 
DCAPE of 1100 to 1300 J/Kg across much of the forecast area. PW 
values of 1.3 to 1.6 inches are not anomalous for this time of 
year, so any excessive rain threat appears low. Any localized 
flash flood risk would be primarily across regions with low FFG 
near urban areas and would be aided by slow movement of 
thunderstorms. Thunderstorm activity should quickly diminish after
sunset as instability decreases with the loss of daytime heating 
and weak subsidence in the wake of the departing shortwave trough.


.LONG TERM...(Thursday night through Wednesday)...
There will be little change in the large scale pattern across the
country through the long term period as a large high pressure 
ridge over the Southwest and another ridge over the western 
Atlantic will result in a blocking pattern and a broad trough over
the eastern US. The clockwise flow around the Atlantic ridge will
supply deep moisture to the Carolinas and Southern Appalachians, 
with our area on the western edge. With this pattern we can expect
to see mainly scattered diurnal showers and thunderstorms each 
day, with the highest chances in the mountains along the NC border
and the lowest chances along the Plateau. One period of enhanced 
rain chances appears to be on Sunday afternoon as a shortwave 
trough moves through the larger trough, providing a little better 
synoptic lift and drawing the deep moisture farther north and 
west. Some slight eastward progression of the longwave trough may 
occur on Tuesday and Wednesday, and with the models showing the 
trough axis to our east, PoPs will be lowered to slight chances 
those days.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Wednesday)...
The afternoon saw partly to mostly cloudy skies across the
forecast area. Only a few showers had developed in the morning but
scattered showers and storms developed early in the afternoon
especially across extreme southern Tennessee Valley and southwest
North Carolina with high winds in the Chattanooga area at 2 pm.
The storms developed ahead of a weak cold front now located 
across extreme west Tennessee and western Kentucky. This front 
will move slowly east southeast tonight in association with an 
upper trough and by late Wednesday possibly make it into the 
eastern Tennessee Valley. The showers and storms late today and 
tonight could still become strong and produce locally gusty winds 
and isolated flooding due to high precipitable water values and 
slow movements. Expect skies to clear during the evening with 
patchy fog forming that might become dense in places where heavy 
rain fell. Wednesday conditions will be similar to today with a 
few strong to severe storms in the afternoon and locally heavy 
rainfall causing local flooding problems. Highs Wednesday should 
be similar to today, although slightly cooler in northeast 
sections where there should be more storm coverage earlier in the 
day.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday night through Tuesday)...
The extended will be characterized by a persistent upper trough 
across the Eastern CONUS with the trough axis located near or across 
our region. Near the base of this trough, an area of low pressure 
may attempt to develop along the northern Gulf Coast near LA/MS/AL. 
A surface front will be near the TN/NC border with drier air and 
subsidence to the W/NW of this front.

There is considerable disagreement in numerical guidance for this 
weekend and into early next week with regard to the position of this 
front and the development and track of the low pressure across the 
Gulf Coast. For these reasons, forecast uncertainty is higher than 
normal for the weekend through early next week. Precipitation 
chances will greatly depend on the exact placement of the surface 
front and trough axis. While the GFS and ECMWF place the trough axis 
near or west of our forecast area, the Canadian places it across 
western NC. The common agreement is that highest moisture, 
instability, and PoPs are expected to be across far E TN/SW VA/SW NC 
with lower PoPs to the W/NW where subsidence is stronger. Some 
patchy fog will be possible in the normal spots that received 
precipitation the previous day or are near river valleys each night. 
Temperatures are expected to be within a few degrees of normal for 
this time of year as the weak trough remains across the area.

temperatures.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday through Tuesday)...By 12Z Wednesday, the 
synoptic configuration will consist of ridging across the 
southwest, troughing from Quebec southward into the Tennessee 
valley, and subtropical ridging across the western Atlantic. At 
the surface, a boundary will be aligned just to the east of the 
spine of the Appalachians with surface ridging across the Great 
Lakes. This pattern will persist through much of the extended. 
Diurnally driven convection can be expected each day in the 
extended period with the best chances along the higher terrain 
where differential heating becomes maximized. Flow will be weak so
do not expect much in the way of organized storms but damaging 
winds are possible with any stronger thunderstorms. Some minor 
differences become apparent in NWP after the weekend in regards to
how amplified the pattern becomes as well as the movement of the 
southern stream component in the eastern US trough. The GFS brings
this southern stream component northward into the southern 
Appalachians while the ECMWF keeps a weaker regime with its 
southern component further south across the GoM. Would expect to 
see an increase in coverage of precipitation early next week as 
low to mid layer moisture begins to increase and the forecast 
reflects this. Temperatures should stay near to slightly below 
average through the extended period.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
310 PM EDT Sun Jul 28 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Monday)...

Isolated diurnal convection has been developing this afternoon along 
the higher terrain of the plateau and eastern mountains. This 
activity will peak in the 20-23Z timeframe. The surface high remains 
just east of the Appalachians with flat riding aloft. This is 
resulting in a very weak flow regime where the convective cells are 
nearly stationary. Brief downpours will occur under any 
thunderstorms this afternoon due to the increasingly moist profile, 
but there will not be any severe weather since there is no shear.
 
Any remaining showers will dissipate by 03Z with loss of heating, 
and expect another clear night as high pressure surface and aloft 
stays in control. Similar to the past few nights, patchy fog will 
develop in protected river valleys. Soundings suggest that this will 
most likely begin after 06Z when temp and dew point spreads begin to 
decrease below the low-level inversion. Patchy fog is also possible 
in areas that saw rain Sunday evening. Once again used the slightly 
cooler MET guidance for lows which will bring low/mid 60's from the 
central and northern valley through northeast TN and southwest VA 
and mid to upper 60's along the plateau and southern valley.

The surface high finally moves off the mid Atlantic coast Monday 
with mid level shortwave ridging steepening over the Tennessee 
Valley in response to a mid level shortwave trough and weak cold 
front moving through the Mississippi Valley. This will yield deeper 
southerly flow with dew points finally increasing to 65-70 in many 
areas. Plenty of sunshine continuing along with this stronger warm 
air advection will cause an uncomfortably hot and humid day with low 
90's more widespread. A moderately unstable atmosphere characterized 
by MUCAPE of 1500-2200 J/Kg, surface based LI's of -4 to -6, and a 
lack of capping will allow for decent coverage of diurnal convection 
in the afternoon and evening. Have chance to slight chance pops from 
late morning through the evening with the highest pops on the 
plateau and eastern mountains. PWATs will be increasing to close to 
1.50 inches, so locally heavy downpours will occur. Once again, 
there will be very little shear, so severe weather is not expected. 
However, cannot rule out an isolated strong wind gust since DCAPES 
will be 600-1000 J/Kg.

.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Sunday)...

Another round of isolated afternoon convection is expected on 
Tuesday as the upper level trough and cold front continues to 
approach the area. Highest chances for rain this forecast will come 
on Tuesday/Wednesday as the front moves into the area before 
eventually stalling out. Forecast models are currently indicating 
that the from will stall out somewhere near the TN/KY borders. 
Forecast soundings show that there will be limited instability and 
shear to work with, so at this time severe weather threat looks 
pretty low. Can't rule out a brief storm pulsing up to be strong, 
and causing gusty winds and brief heavy rainfall, but widespread 
severe weather is not expected at this time.

The front will slowly wash out over the area leading to more spotty 
coverage of afternoon showers and thunderstorms. Will continue to 
have relatively moist air over us as Gulf moisture is brought up on 
the West side of the ridge. Models begin to diverge as we head 
through the weekend with the ECMWF wanting to dive a upper level low 
out of the Mid west towards the forecast area while the GFS 
maintains a weaker and broader trough. Will keep an eye on this 
system as it looks to be the next best chance of rain outside of 
Tuesday/Wednesday.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

If you paid attention to yesterday's weather, you can pretty much 
expect a repeat for today. High pressure remains in control and is 
still centered over the southern Appalachians/southeastern U.S. 
Highs for today will again top out in the mid to upper 80s, which is 
near normal for this time of year. A few afternoon showers along 
with a storm or two possible across the high terrain of the 
Cumberland Plateau and eastern mountains but most areas will remain 
dry.

Any shower or storm quickly falls apart during the evening as we 
lose heating. Clouds will clear and overnight lows will dip down 
into the low to mid 60s, which is still a degree or two below 
normal. Some patchy river fog across our northern areas is expected 
once again.

.LONG TERM...(Monday through Sunday)...

Models are in decent agreement with the overall pattern, although
there are some differences in the details. Forecast confidence 
level is about average for this time of year. Surface high 
pressure will be over the region to start but the low amplitude 
upper level ridge will be weakening. Model soundings look rather 
dry for much of the valley, but some mainly isolated convection 
will likely form, mainly over the higher terrain and south. By 
Tuesday an upper level tough will be moving into the region, and a
weak cold front will be approaching from the north/northwest. 
This upper trough will linger over the eastern US for the 
remainder of the period, but will be weakening. The cold front 
will stall over or near our northern border, and it will then 
weaken as well. 

Best chances for convection are expected to be Tuesday and Wednesday 
as this trough and front approach and move into the the region, and 
then will keep chances of convection going for the remainder of the 
period as no significant drying is expected and what remains of the 
frontal boundary will be nearby.  As always with thunderstorms, some 
may produce at least brief torrential rainfall. However, at this 
time the risk of significant flooding looks low. In addition, the 
flow is expected to be weak with weak shear and convective energy 
generally looks moderate at best, so the risk of severe storms looks 
relatively low as well for the period.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Sunday)...

A few diurnal showers have developed this afternoon on the higher 
terrain of the Cumberland Plateau in response to slowly increasing 
dew points and weak upslope flow since the surface high has moved a 
little east of the Appalachians. Soundings are still fairly dry 
which is helping to keep the activity isolated, and not currently 
detecting any lightning in these showers. These will quickly fade 
away this evening as daytime heating decreases, so expect all areas 
to be dry by 01Z.

The surface high will remain just east of the southern Appalachian 
region tonight allowing for clear skies and another decent 
radiational cooling night as winds go mostly calm. The slightly 
higher dew points will keep temps a few degrees warmer than last 
night, but still went with the cooler MET guidance for lows. This 
yields low/mid 60's from the plateau and central valley through 
northeast TN and southwest VA with mid/upper 60's in the southern 
valley. Projected soundings once again show low level saturation 
below the inversion in the pre dawn hours as temps fall close to dew 
points, mainly from the central and northern valley through 
northeast TN and southwest VA, so added patchy fog in these areas 
between 06 and 13Z.

Expect a rapid rise in temps Sunday under mainly sunny skies and 
somewhat deeper southerly flow as the surface high moves toward the 
mid Atlantic coast and heights rise aloft. This will continue the 
trend of slowly rising dew points, so afternoon showers/storms will 
be a little more numerous in the higher elevations of the plateau 
and eastern mountains. Soundings certainly suggest this as a better 
moisture profile looks to be in place with PWAT values increasing to 
1.30-1.35 inches and afternoon MUCAPE of 1500-2500 J/Kg. Have chance 
to slight chance pops in the higher terrain areas starting at 17Z. 
Highs will be near the seasonal averages for late July of upper 
80's/low 90's.

.LONG TERM...(Sunday night through Saturday)...

Weak or flat ridge that extends west into the desert southwest 
strengthens even more Sunday night and Monday which induces a NW 
flow to develop over the region late Monday. Surface high pressure 
still in control over the southeast states Sunday night into Monday 
night will keep the area in a mostly sunny to partly cloudy pattern 
with only isolated to widely scattered showers and thunderstorms 
across the eastern part of the forecast area. Monday with the NW 
flow pattern developing a new upper trough will move into the 
Mississippi Valley Monday and drag a cold front towards the eastern 
Tennessee Valley Tuesday. Rain chances increase from NW to SE 
Tuesday ahead of this front. The cold front gets hung up over or 
just north of the southern Appalachians Wednesday through Friday as 
the western ridge and a strengthening Bermuda high to the east keep 
it in place. The highest rain chances will be Tuesday western 
sections and Wednesday and Thursday eastern sections. Friday and 
Saturday it will be hard to pick out the front but the weak upper 
trough will still lie over the forecast area with daily mainly 
diurnal chances for afternoon and early evening showers and 
thunderstorms. Temperatures will be near normal for this time of 
year. No significant rainfall expected until Tuesday afternoon. Late 
Tuesday through Wednesday there may be brief periods of heavy 
rainfall but not expected to cause any flooding problems at this 
time.

heavy precip. By midweek, the strength of the Four Corners high

Wed-Fri.

little more numerous over the higher elevations but no convection.
Tonight will be another mostly clear night will some patchy fog
late. Expect less coverage than this morning. High pressure over
the Ohio Valley and extending south to the eastern Tennessee
Valley will shift to the mid Atlantic by tomorrow. With light
winds tonight temperatures will drop down into the mid 50s to
lower 60s, a degree or two warmer than todays lows. Friday with a
slight southerly flow developing across southern and western
sections temperatures warm a degree or two. The slight increase in
moisture and dew points will help to trigger a little more
instability and develop a few showers and storms in the higher
elevations along the border with North Carolina. 

.LONG TERM...(Friday night through Thursday)...
A warming trend will be taking place this weekend as 500 mb 
heights rise to around 590 dam over the southern appalachians, but
the core of the significant mid level ridging (heat dome) will 
remain over the four corners region of the desert Southwest. This 
will keep our region in WNW flow aloft, so the warmer temps will 
be at seasonable levels with only a slow rise in dew points. 
Consensus of model guidance suggests spotty afternoon showers 
Saturday in the far east TN mountains and southwest VA. Soundings 
continue to look quite dry due to the surface high still nearby, 
so limited pops to slight chance with most areas staying mostly 
sunny. A slightly better opportunity to see a shower or 
thunderstorm will come Sunday afternoon as a very weak shortwave 
drops through the WNW mid to upper level flow. Soundings show a 
slight increase in mid level moisture associated with this 
feature, and stronger southerly surface flow will be developing as
the surface high moves off of the East coast leading to better 
low level moisture return and instability. Have slight chance to 
chance pops for the afternoon and evening, but any activity will 
quickly dissipate after sunset.

Southerly flow and warm air advection will really ramp up Monday 
ahead of a deepening upper trough and cold front to the NW, and this 
is when the upper 60's to low 70's surface dew points will finally 
return to the southern Appalachian region. Have chance pops for 
diurnally driven afternoon/evening convection, but the coverage will 
be much higher compared to the weekend. Scattered showers and 
thunderstorms will continue Monday night as the cold front slowly 
approaches from the west bringing increased forcing for ascent. This 
front will be very slow to cross east TN, southwest VA, and 
southwest NC Tuesday, so the greatest coverage of clouds, showers, 
and thunderstorms will occur at this time. It will remain very humid 
Tuesday, but high temps will be cooler than Monday due to the clouds 
and precipitation. Increased pops to high chance and likely for 
Tuesday. Early estimates project 1500-2000 J/Kg MUCAPE, decently 
high freezing levels, and PWAT values around 1.70 inches, so locally

The cold front will be essentially washing out and stalling near or

chance pops with temps staying seasonable. The upper trough to the

air, so reduced pops to slight chance Thursday afternoon.

southwest Virginia to as warm as upper 80s southeast Tennessee 
Valley.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday night through Wednesday)...
The long-term forecast period will be rather quiet with a slow 
return to a more typical summer pattern by early next week.

An upper and mid-level trough axis will stretch across the 
Appalachians to end the work week with a ridge across the Western 
CONUS and out over the Western Atlantic. The trough will weaken and 
there will be some slight height rises over the weekend. However, PW 
values will remain around the 25th percentile for late July and have 
featured a dry forecast throughout the weekend. Some of the models 
want to indicate a few afternoon showers/storms across the higher 
elevations but the profiles appear to be too dry for any 
precipitation. Temperatures will slowly creep up over the weekend 
but will still be slightly below normal. 

A more typical summer time pattern will return by early next week. 
Low level high pressure will become established across the Carolinas 
with a cold front well to the north of the area. This will lead to 
light low-level southerly flow across the area. Due to this, 
dewpoints will slowly increase with the atmosphere becoming more 
saturated. Introduced PoPs to the forecast on Monday afternoon 
increasing each afternoon throughout the forecast period. High 
temperatures will also return to near normal with mid to upper 80s 
for most locations.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

Surface high pressure was anchored over northern Missouri this 
morning, with northerly surface flow around the eastern periphery of 
this high extending into the Tennessee valley. Water vapor satellite 
imagery shows a high amplitude upper pattern in place this morning, 
with deep and unseasonably strong upper troughing across the eastern 
half of the lower 48 this morning, and strong ridging out west. This 
pattern will continue through the short term period, with the 
surface high progressing east into the central Great Lakes and Ohio 
River Valley regions late tonight.

The increasing influence of surface high pressure combined with 
clear skies through the night, has lead to some patchy fog 
development across the forecast area. Fog product and nighttime 
microphysics imagery from GOES 16 shows this fog very well. It is 
mainly confined to river valleys at the moment and that should be 
the trend through daybreak and shortly thereafter. Any fog should 
dissipate by an hour or two after sunrise though, so it will be a 
short-lived issue. From a forecast perspective, thus far models seem 
to have been largely too aggressive in how low they took 
temperatures and dewpoints during the overnight period. Thus it 
seems reasonable that this could allow highs to be a degree or two 
higher than previously forecast, and overnight guidance lends 
credence to this. Adjusted afternoon temperatures up a tad as a 
result. 

Another largely cloud free night is forecast for tonight, with 
temperatures in the 50s to low 60s forecast for most low elevation 
locales. Once again, patchy fog to some extent seems a given due to 
wet soil and prime radiational conditions. Have this primarily 
limited to low elevation spots north of I-40 where temperatures will 
be the coolest.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Wednesday)...

The extended period remains quiet overall, with increasing POP 
chances toward the end of the period as our next front rolls 
through.

Thursday through Friday the upper trough at 500 to 300 mb, though 
very weak, is still lingering across the spine of the Appalachians as 
it is sandwiched between high pressure across the desert southwest 
and high pressure over Bermuda. High pressure is in place in the 
lower and mid levels. This pattern keeps us dry with slightly below 
normal highs and lows. Highs on Thursday will range from the low to 
mid 80s with overnight lows around 60. Friday will be slightly 
warmer with highs in the lower to upper 80s and lows in the low to 
mid 60s. 

Saturday and Sunday look to remain mostly dry with a weak 
unorganized flow in place. On Saturday there will be a slight chance 
POP in for some of the elevated terrain. Slight chance POPs in for 
Sunday afternoon as well, but expect most areas to be dry on both 
days. Highs will generally be in the mid to upper 80s with lows in 
the mid to upper 60s. 

Weak southwesterly flow sets up for Monday out ahead of Tuesday's 
weak upper trough. The southwest flow increases moisture and 
therefore allows for expanded slight chance POP coverage across the 
area with low-end chance POPs in the high terrain. Tuesday will 
feature the highest POPs with chance POPs in for most areas as the 
trough and associated front pass through. The trough looks to be 
pretty weak and shallow so don't expect any real push of cooler and 
drier air behind it beyond the extended period.

also will move into the southeast on the weekend. Southerly flow and

to scattered plateau and eastern mountain convection continues. On

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

VAD wind profile data from the KMRX radar as well as some surface
