the surface front has now cleared the forecast area and likely 
rests just east of the Appalachians early this morning. Scattered 
to numerous showers continue across the CWA however, and will
likely do so through daybreak or shortly thereafter as the mid
level front will not clear the area until the mid morning time
frame. There was some concern that development along a low level
jet overnight would fuel fairly high rainfall rates, especially in
the mountainous terrain, and yield additional flash flooding
concerns. Radar trends have not bore this out for the most part,
with only some occasional small areas of rainfall rates
approaching or exceeding 1" per hour. Much of this activity has
either shifted east of the forecast area (moderate along the
Georgia and North Carolina lines), or has died down in intensity
(an area of moderate rainfall shifting from the Clinch Mountains 
area towards the Tri Cities). Thus I believe the threat for any
additional flash flooding is beginning the wind down
substantially. Have dropped the flash flood watch for areas west
of the I-81 and I-75 corridors to that end. Will keep the rest of
it going for now, mainly to cover the aforementioned areas of 
moderate rainfall completely clearing the CWA, and monitor whether
an update will be necessary to pull the rest of the watch by the
12z expiration time.

Otherwise, the short term will be relatively calm. Clouds will be
slow to clear today, but will gradually do so through this evening
as the front continues to push east of the area. Substantially
cooler and drier air will move into the region behind the front
tonight and into the long term period. It will be a wonderful
evening and overnight period tonight, with lows dropping into the
50s tonight. Hard to beat that in July.


.LONG TERM...(Wednesday through Tuesday)...

The extended can mostly be characterized by dry and quiet 
weather, sunny skies, with slight chance POPs returning toward the
end of the period.

The period starts off with dry and cool weather on Wednesday as high 
pressure is building in from the west and the upper trough is 
exiting to the northeast. Highs will be in the upper 70s to low 80s 
with dewpoints in the mid to upper 50s. Overnight lows will be in 
the mid 50s to near 60 for most. These values are roughly 8 to 10 
degrees below normal for this time of year. Elevations above 
4000/5000 feet will dip down into the mid and upper 40s! High 
pressure in control Thursday through Friday will allow for dry 
weather and sunny skies. Temperatures will slowly climb but will 
still be a few degrees below normal.

Saturday through the Monday the high shifts eastward which brings 
the return of southerly flow to the area. Saturday should be mostly 
dry but Sunday and Monday will feature some slight chance and low-
end chance POPs as moisture and temps climb due to the increasing 
southerly flow. We can also expect temperatures to be back to normal 
during the time. Overall, a quiet period in store.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Tuesday)...
The pattern today is highlighted by deep H5 troughing across the 
eastern CONUS, with a series of shortwave impulses passing through 
the mean flow aloft.  At the surface, weakening high pressure 
continues to retreat as a cold front approaches out of the OH 
Valley.  The headline of the day continues to be deep/moist swly 
flow running nearly parallel to the approaching front amidst 
marginal instability and upper divergence associated the rear 
entrance region of an upper jetmax over the Great Lakes.  All these 
factors combine with pwats near 2 inches to favor numerous showers 
and thunderstorms regionwide today ahead of the front, as well as a 
second round associated with the fropa overnight.  The primary 
threat continues to be heavy rainfall given the above noted moisture 
, slow storm motions, and training which will all favor increased 
potential for Flash Flooding, especially for areas along/north of 
I40 where FFGs are lowest.  Latest CAMQPF suggests a few rounds of 
heavier precipitation to fall slightly southward of the original 
Flash Flood Watch, thus did opt to expand it slightly southward as 
well as extending through 12z tomorrow morning, although some 
western zones could be cancelled earlier than that.  All in all the 
fcst for tonight and through the overnight will feature likely/cat 
pops with nearly 1-2 inches of QPF (locally higher amounts possible) 
expected. While general thunderstorms will dominate, cannot rule out 
a few strong storms, especially later along the front when deep 
shear is maximized in the 35-45kts range.

Otherwise, the front should sweep through the region by around 
daybreak Tuesday with light precipitation to accompany the boundary 
by that point, thus pops will be tapering down with likely levels 
over the high terrain and chances westward.  Beyond that, pops lower 
further as drier air advects into the area from the west with nearly 
a dry fcst favored by periods end.  Temperatures on Tuesday will be 
nearly a category below normal levels. 

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday night through Monday)...
The main story of the extended will be the cooler and drier air 
across the region midweek. For Tuesday night and Wednesday, longwave 
trough will be across the Eastern CONUS with surface high pressure 
building in from our west across the mid-Mississippi Valley. Surface 
cold front will be to the east of the Appalachian chain with N/NE 
flow advecting boundary layer cold air across the forecast area. PW 
values will be very dry for this time of year between 0.5 and 0.8 
inch, and dew points will be in the 50s. This dry air is near the 
minimum for this time of year according to NAEFS forecast data. 
Additional shortwaves moving south through the upper flow will act 
to amplify the longwave trough through Wednesday afternoon, but dry 
boundary layer air and surface high pressure should limit any 
precipitation chances. With 850mb temperatures between 10C and 13C 
across the forecast area, this will be near the 1st percentile of 
climatology. This is a strong signal for below normal temperatures 
and an early fall-like feel. For this reason, temperatures midweek 
are expected to be 10 to 15 degrees below normal for this time of 
year with a mostly clear sky.

The cool and dry airmass is expected to continue into the weekend 
with temperatures approaching seasonal normals by Friday and 
Saturday as the airmass moderates and ridging begins to increase. 
Surface high pressure shifts east on Saturday with a return of low-
level southerly flow and an increase in boundary layer moisture. The 
increasing temperatures and moisture will result in some slight 
chance isolated convection across mainly the higher elevations of 
southeast Tennessee this weekend and into early next week.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
339 AM EDT Mon Jul 22 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

A frontal boundary was situated well to our northwest this
morning, lying from roughly central Ohio, southwestward through
Paducah and into the Ozarks of southern Missouri. This will
eventually shift through the Tennessee Valley later tonight. Ahead
of this front, widespread showers and thunderstorms will affect
the region.

Some of this activity was ongoing early this morning. Areas of 
showers and thunderstorms developed over many areas along/north 
of the I-40 corridor early this morning. Some overnight runs of 
the HRRR and also the RAP did catch this, and have trended the 
forecast through mid morning largely in that direction. These show
the ongoing convection shifting north of the forecast area and 
dissipating by shortly after daybreak. This lull in convective 
activity would be short lived as widespread showers and 
thunderstorms are advertised to blossom across most of the CWA by 
midday. In that regard, didn't make any notable changes to what 
previous shifts had in the forecast for midday through tonight. 
Categorical PoPs seem warranted by just about every piece of 
guidance at my disposal, which is reflected in the forecast.
Convective parameters do not support much of a chance of severe
storms really. Some meager instability will be present, but CAPE
profiles through the column do not favor a threat of any
significant hail. Perhaps some gusty winds could occur from precip
laden downdrafts, but think the more pressing issue really is
going to be the possibility of heavy rains and flash flooding.

As mentioned several times over the last few days, precipitable 
water values are very high. Forecast PWAT values will be right 
around the 2" mark for most of today, which is well above the 90th
percentile mark. Combine this with widespread convection and slow
storm movements, and the possibility of some flash flooding will 
certainly exist as the day wears on. To account for this, a flash
flood watch has been hoisted for areas near/north of the I-40
corridor beginning at 8am and lasting through late tonight. 

.LONG TERM...(Monday through Sunday)...

Cooler and drier air will bring relief to the forecast area 
during this period. However, Tuesday the cold front progged to be 
moving across forecast area will have showers along and ahead of 
it. The good news is that it will be moving fairly quickly 
east/southeast taking the precipitation with it by Tuesday evening
things will begin drying out. 

The upper trough will dig deep across the eastern U.S. for this time 
of year providing some relief to the recent heat and humidity for 
most of this week. Some temperatures by Wednesday morning will dip 
into the lower 50s! Dry conditions will persist until the surface 
high shifts from the Midwest to the northeast by Thursday evening. 
The upper flow becomes rather weak and dare I say sort of ridges 
over us again for the weekend. Low level south/southeasterly flow 
will bring back the moisture and associated showers back to the area 
Saturday and Sunday.

For this period temperatures will start off well below seasonal 
normals and gradually warm up through the week back to near
normal.

FXUS64 KMRX 211913
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
313 PM EDT Sun Jul 21 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Monday)...
The synoptic pattern today is highlighted by broad H5 troughing 
across the northern CONUS, while weak southern stream H5 ridging 
prevails across both the Four Corners region and the Western 
Atlantic.  At the surface, weak high pressure holds atop the 
southeast CONUS, while a surface trough/front extends southward 
across the Mid MS Valley from it's parent surface wave centered over 
northern IL.  With that, a conditionally unstable airmass dominates 
across the TN Valley and Southern Appalachian region favoring 
diurnal convection, which is already underway across the higher 
terrain.  Given weak flow, would expect gradual northern movement 
throughout the afternoon, possibly with a few cells in the valley. 
Therefore the fcst will feature chance pops in the valley with high 
chances to likely levels across the mtns/plateau.  Given abundant 
sky cover, think max temps will be a few degrees cooler than 
yesterday. Although sky cover will be increasing through late 
morning, did favor patchy fog as well (which could be dense at 
times) given the abundance of moisture in the BL. 

Moving on, convection should diminish gradually into the late 
evening hours as much thermo forcing is lost.  At that point, the 
fcst focus will shift to the aforementioned surface trough/front 
beneath a weak H5 wave, and it's eventual surge southeastward.  CAM 
solutions suggest a late evening (nocturnal) MCS firing across the 
OH Valley tonight, eventually sliding east into Middle TN as it 
decays toward Monday morning.  Guidance also suggests re-initiation 
by mid/late morning across the TN Valley amidst falling heights 
aloft, the intruding sfc trough, and perhaps along a remnant 
outflow. Meanwhile the surface front itself looks to lag behind, 
likely moving into the region beyond this fcst cycle.  As for pops 
on Monday, given moist profiles (pwats in excess of 2.1 inches, 
which is above the 90th percentile according to sounding climo) and 
the aforementioned boundary/forcing, opted to carry 
likely/categorical pops into the afternoon hours. As for threats, 
the better jet dynamics (and thus shear) will be well north of the 
region, however guidance does suggest 20-30kts deep shear amidst 2K 
j/kg CAPE, therefore cannot rule out a few strong/severe storms on 
Monday afternoon with the primary hazards being damaging winds. High 
temperatures on Monday will once again be below normal.  

.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Sunday)...
A big pattern change is in the forecast for Tuesday as a cold front 
brings a fall-like feel to the region. At 0z Tuesday, a shortwave 
trough will be moving through the Tennessee Valley with height falls 
and a prefrontal surface trough across the region. Expect widespread 
scattered convection with this feature and the potential for some 
heavy rainfall rates. GFS, NAM, ECMWF, and Canadian guidance are all 
in good agreement with PW values being between 2.0 and 2.2 inches 
ahead of the cold front, and this would be near the 97th percentile. 
This is a good signal for heavy rainfall and some isolated flash 
flooding potential. In the wake of this first shortwave, another 
stronger shortwave will be moving southeastward toward the Southern 
Appalachians amplifying the upper trough. The associated cold front 
ahead of this trough will approach and begin to move through the 
forecast area between 06z and 12z Tuesday. The heavy rainfall rates 
will be possible ahead of this cold front.

The GFS, ECMWF, and Canadian quickly bring the cold front through 
the area with the trough axis shifting east of our area by 21z 
Tuesday with subsidence and drying aloft. The NAM is slower with the 
trough and develops a stronger meso-low at the surface which 
continues more widespread precipitation coverage through Tuesday 
afternoon. However, the NAM is currently the outlier solution and 
GFS ensembles support the global model consensus, thus, will 
continue to align the forecast with the GFS and ECMWF solutions 
which bring drying conditions to the area Tuesday afternoon.

Surface high pressure continues to build in on Tuesday night and 
Wednesday with weak shortwaves maintaining the trough across the 
Eastern CONUS. This very cold air, 850mb temperatures of 11C to 13C 
on Wednesday, will be in the 0.5 to 1st percentile for this time of 
year, and this is a strong signal for below normal temperatures. 
Overall, expect temperatures to be 10 to 15 degrees below normal. In 
addition, PW values will decrease to 0.5 to 0.7 inch on Wednesday, 
near the 1st percentile for this time of year, which illustrates the 
anomalous nature of this cold and dry airmass for July. Because of 
this dry airmass, northerly flow, and high pressure, dry weather and 
an early fall-like feel is expected mid to late week.

As high pressure shifts east, southerly flow begins to return next 
weekend with slight chance diurnal PoPs across the southern portions 
of the CWA and the higher elevations. Temperatures will return to 
normal by the weekend as ridging increases across the region.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Another warm, muggy night reflected in the temperatures across the
area early this morning. Most locations are in the lower to mid
70s and dewpoints are nearly identical. Patchy fog has developed
possibly with a few areas with locally dense fog reducing
visibilities, however, the fog is not widespread.

Some early morning convection is likely with current regional
radar showing a lone storm developing just south of Roanoke, VA
and a few light reflectivities showing up across the southern TN

hours and persist into the morning and gradually increase in
coverage through the afternoon. Cloud cover from the showers will

days. As such, don't expect heat index values to be nearly as hot.

Storms that develop today will have the capability of producing
locally heavy rainfall and gusty winds. Steering flow is weak so
storms will move slowly with lots of low level moisture to work
with. 

Tonight, shower activity should slowly diminish by late evening
with another surge of developing showers possible towards sunrise. 


.LONG TERM...(Sunday through Saturday)...
The bottom line of the extended period will continue to be the big 
pattern change early week with much below normal temperatures for 
mid to late week. Weak mid to upper level trough axis (what is 
currently assisting in thunderstorm development this afternoon) is 
expected to be oriented SW/NE across the region Sunday night into 
Monday morning which may enhance a few showers and thunderstorms. As 
a stronger shortwave dives southeast across the upper Mississippi 
Valley, this will result in height falls across the Ohio Valley and 
Southern Appalachians. A seasonably anomalous surface cold front 
will move southeast with this trough and enhance boundary layer 
forcing and precipitation coverage. Guidance is in good agreement in 
indicating a prefrontal trough moving west to east across the region 
on Monday afternoon with widespread scattered convection likely. 
Instability will be marginal at 500 to 1500 J/Kg of MLCAPE late 
Monday and early Tuesday evening with effective deep layer shear 
approaching 20 kt. A few thunderstorms could be strong with gusty 
winds if instability is on the higher end of guidance, but the main 
risk of severe weather will remain to our north where shear and 
instability is expected to be maximized.

The surface cold front is expected to be across western Kentucky 
near the Ohio River by 0z Tuesday and this will move into our area 
by late Monday night or early Tuesday morning with additional 
periods of rain and thunderstorms along and ahead of this front. PW 
values will be between 1.9 and 2.2 inches late Monday and Monday 
night, so heavy rain rates will be a possibility with the stronger 
thunderstorms and result in localized flash flooding.

The front moves east of the area on Tuesday with decreasing PoPs 
from west to east. A few rain showers may linger across the 
mountains on Tuesday afternoon with some weak orographic enhancement 
and shallow post frontal moisture. Drier air and high pressure moves 
in Tuesday night and Wednesday with dry weather dominating through 
the end of the week. NAEFS forecast anomalies show 850mb 
temperatures being around the 1st percentile of climatology on 
Wednesday which is a strong signal for below normal temperatures. 
For this reason, expect temperatures to be near 10 to 15 degrees 
below normal on Wednesday. Overnight temperatures will also be about 
10 to 15 degrees below normal with the dry airmass in place. 
Temperatures rebound closer to normal by the end of the week as the 
airmass begins to moderate and upper ridging increases across the 
south/central parts of the country.

from weakening ridge to unseasonably deep upper trough over the 
eastern third of the nation. The GFS and ECMWF remain in good 
agreement.

southern Appalachians as a significant short-wave trough moves 
across the northern Plains toward the Great Lakes/Ohio valley. 
Increasing coverage of convection is expected. CAPEs of 1500-2000 
J/Kg with fairly high PWs of 1.7 to 2 inches will produce heavy 
rains and strong/gusty winds.

For Monday, upper trough will continue to dive toward the southern 
Appalachians with associated cool front moving toward the Tennessee 
valley in the afternoon and evening. Widespread convection will move 
into the area ahead of the frontal boundary and continue into Monday 
night. CAPEs of 1000-2000 J/Kg and high PWs along with some synoptic 
forcing from including upper trough/frontal boundary will set the 
stage for isolated strong to possibly severe storms. Main concern 
being strong/gusty winds and heavy rains.

For Tuesday, frontal boundary will be moving south across the 
southern half of the area in the morning with drier air advecting 
in. Will transition to lower PoPs as the day progress.

For Wednesday through Friday, surface ridging and trough axis east 
of the area will produce much more pleasant humidity levels with 
cooler temperatures. Generally dry conditions anticipated.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Saturday)...
Main weather story for the short term period will be the hot and humid 
conditions through Saturday. Currently across the area, skies

depicts an area of showers and thunderstorms mainly west of I-75 
and south of I-40. Water vapor imagery is indicating drier air 
aloft advecting from the north that has likely kept most areas 
dry today. The upper levels feature ridging aloft through much of 
the region which is helping to keep conditions warm. With highs 
expected in the upper 80s to low 90s and dewpoints near the low 
70s, this will create very humid conditions with heat indices in 
the upper 90s to near 100. Not anticipating needing any heat 
advisories for this afternoon as most locations should stay below 
advisory criteria. 

The current convection should dissipate after sunset as the boundary 
layer begins to stabilize. Warm and humid conditions will persist
into tonight as the ridge holds over the area. Lows tonight 
should bottom out into the low to mid 70s. Saturday should 
continue to be warm and humid as temperatures quickly increase 
under ridging aloft. Guidance suggests most locations will reach 
or surpass the 90 degree mark, especially across the valley. This
seems plausible as 925mb temperatures increase upwards of 28-30 
degree C.This combined with a moist airmass with dewpoints near 
70-75 degrees will produce heat index values into the upper 90s 
to low 100s. Decided to hold off on issuing any heat advisories 
for Saturday as confidence on how much of the area reaches 
advisory criteria remains low. Nonetheless, the dangerous heat 
index values will persist and should continue to be monitored. 
Instability will increase on Saturday with CAPE values in the 
2,000-3,000 j/kg range. As a result, convection is expected 
mainly during the afternoon hours. Coverage is expected to be 
greater than today as there are some indications that the ridge 
begins to break down. DCAPEs of 800-1200 j/kg means that any of 
the stronger storms could produce strong/gusty winds. PW values 
near 2.0 inches suggest that locally heavy rainfall will also be 
possible. 

.LONG TERM...(Saturday night through Friday)...
Guidance continues to be in good agreement through the extended with 
the main story being a significant pattern change across the region 
early this upcoming week.

The extended begins with a shortwave trough diving southeastward 
across the northern Great Plains and upper Mississippi Valley late 
Sunday into Sunday night. This will bring height falls across the 
region with increasing PoPs for scattered convection on Sunday and 
Monday. MLCAPE each afternoon will be in the 1000 to 2000 J/Kg range 
across the area with effective deep layer shear generally between 10 
to 20 kt and increasing to 20 to 25 kt late Monday as stronger 
dynamics associated with the upper trough approaches the region. 
While widespread severe weather is not forecast with this system, 
the setup favors the potential for a few strong to possibly severe 
thunderstorms, especially later Monday as the front approaches and 
mid-level lapse rates increase with PVA across the area.

The shortwave will amplify longwave troughing across the Eastern 
CONUS Monday night with an associated surface cold front moving 
through the region. Likely widespread convection will be associated 
with this front, and with strong boundary layer forcing and PW 
between 1.8 and 2.0 inches, expect some heavy rainfall at times.

The cold front shifts east on Tuesday with a few lingering showers 
or isolated thunderstorms across the far eastern mountains closer to 
the front and where some weak orographic lift may enhance showery 
coverage. However, expect orographic lift to be minimal with winds 
from the N/NNE behind the front which is not normal to the average 
terrain axis. Surface high pressure builds in with much lower 
dewpoint in the mid 50s to lower 60s by Wednesday morning. In fact, 
both NAEFS and ECMWF output show 850mb temperatures being between 
the 3rd and 10th percentile compared to climatology. In addition, 
CIPS analog data shows high probabilities of below normal 
temperatures with surface temperatures being about 10 degrees below 
normal. This anomalous cold and dry airmass will result in much 
cooler temperatures with an almost fall-like feel mid to late week 
with very low to no chances of precipitation in the forecast.

Tennessee Valley and southwest North Carolina. Some patchy fog was 
noted as well in the usual places near bodies of water/southern 
portions of I-75. 

Rain-free conditions will persist through at least 11 am. 
However, temperatures will be climbing as will the heat index. 
Drier mid- level air should make its way across southwest Virginia
and perhaps as far south as Knoxville. This should limit 
shower/thunderstorm potential this afternoon. 

Farther south enough moisture will be present to produce showers and 
thunderstorms between 11 am and 7 pm ET. PW values will be over 2 
inches therefore the thunderstorms will be capable of producing very 
heavy rainfall in a short period of time. Additionally, some storms 
could produce strong wind gusts but the heavy rainfall will likely
be the most impactful weather aspect. Showers and thunderstorms 
will diminish close to sunset.

Tonight look for gradually clearing skies/thinning clouds along with 
another warm, muggy night. Patchy fog will also likely develop 
shortly after midnight. 

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Friday)...
Models remain in good agreement through the extend period with a 
pattern change from ridging over the Ohio and Tennessee valleys to a 
unseasonably strong upper trough over the eastern third of the 
nation for Monday through Wednesday.

For Saturday, upper ridge remains with very warm and muggy 
conditions. Heat indices in the upper 90s to 103 degrees can be 
anticipated in the afternoon over much of the valley. A few areas 
may reach near 105 degrees which is at Heat Advisory criteria. A 
moist and unstable air with HREF showing ensemble mean CAPEs of 2500-
3000 J/Kg. DCAPEs of 800-1200 J/Kg which will produce strong/gusty 
winds with the stronger storms. PWs of 1.7 to near 2 inches will 
produce heavy rains with steering flow weak, so localized flash 
flooding a concern. 

For Sunday, upper ridge begins to weaken with still very warm and 
muggy conditions but heat indices mainly in the 90s across the 
valley. Greater coverage of convection with isolated strong storms 
continuing with strong/gusty winds and heavy rains.

For Monday, upper trough deepens with a frontal boundary approaching 
the area. Widespread convection and not as hot conditions. Heavy 
rains will be the main concern along with localized flash flooding 
possible.

For Monday night and Tuesday morning, frontal boundary moves through 
with showers and storms. Coverage of storms moves south with drier 
air slowly advecting into the northern areas during the afternoon.

For Tuesday night and Wednesday, upper trough is established over
the region with frontal boundary south. May see some convection 
along the Tennessee/North Carolina Mountains, otherwise dry, less 
humid, and more pleasant temperatures.

022 
FXUS64 KMRX 170706
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
306 AM EDT Wed Jul 17 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today through Tomorrow)...
The remnants of Barry will finally begin to move through the area 
today, bringing widespread showers and thunderstorms. Currently 
precipitation is occurring over AL/Middle Tennessee and is expected 
to continue moving eastward. It A few scattered showers may form 
ahead of the main bulk of precipitation, but the more widespread 
rain will move into the Cumberland Plateau in the late morning 
hours, and is expected to last into the evening hours. Another weak 
mid/low level trough will move through Wednesday night behind the 
main round of rain during the day. Will continue precipitation 
chances Wednesday night and into Thursday as this secondary, but 
weaker, system moves through.

Biggest concern with the upcoming storms will be the threat of 
flooding. Precipitable water values around 2 inches with a tall 
saturated column will help warm rain processes. Expect some of the 
stronger storms to be able to produce quick heavy rainfall, but they 
will also be moving eastward at a decent clip as well. So while the 
storms will be capable of creating heavy rain, they (hopefully) 
won't be over any one location for very long. SREF models are 
relatively consistent with each other of most places seeing about 
0.5 - 1.0 inches of rain today and tonight and almost all of the 
members showing storm total QPE of less than 1.5 inches. Luckily 
we've been relatively dry across the area for the past few days, so 
hopefully the rivers and low lying areas are able to handle much of 
this rain. With the quick moving storms the threat for widespread 
flooding looks relatively low at this time so at this time have no 
plans to issue any flood related watches... HOWEVER, it is still 
VERY possible that some isolated locations get a few heavier storms 
over them and experience flash flooding. So the main message of the 
day is turn around, don't drown. 

High resolution models are indicating that there may be an area of 
heavier precipitation somewhere in Middle Tennessee towards the 
Cumberland Plateau (with QPF amounts closer to 2 inches). Areas 
along and near higher terrain are more likely to see heavier 
rainfall as these storms move through. 

With the secondary trough moving in later tonight expect there to be 
some additional storms capable of producing brief heavy rain, but 
coverage of storms should be much lower compared to earlier today. 

.LONG TERM (Thursday night through Tuesday)...
Overall, GFS and ECMWF are in good agreement with the extended 
forecast. An upper ridge will develop over the Ohio Valley and 
central/southern Appalachians for Thursday night through Saturday. 
For Sunday, ridging weakens with upper trough becoming established 
for Monday and Tuesday over the eastern third of the nation. A 
frontal boundary moves into the Tennessee valley and southern 
Appalachians early next week. Now for the particulars.

For Friday and Saturday, upper ridge across the region, but moisture 
and instability remains and expect mainly diurnal convection each 
day. Greatest coverage over the higher elevations. Typical summer-
time air-mass with MLCAPEs 1500-2000 J/Kg, PWs of 1.6-1.9 inches 
(highest south), and DCAPEs of 700-1000 J/Kg. These values will 
produce isolated strong storms producing strong/gusty winds, heavy 
rains, and frequent lightning.

For Sunday, upper ridge breaks down allowing for greater coverage of 
convection over the region. Same as Friday/Saturday, isolates strong 
storms likely.

For Monday and Tuesday, upper trough develops over the eastern third 
of the nation pulling a frontal boundary southward into the 
Tennessee valley and southern Appalachians Monday night and Tuesday. 
Again, some strong storms are anticipated for Monday afternoon and 
evening. High pressure will build into the are Tuesday with slowly 
drier air advecting into the northern sections during the day.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Wednesday night)...
Through the rest of the afternoon and evening, shower coverage 
should remain isolated to the Plateau and mountains due to a lack of 
forcing and midlevel entrainment of dry air. Tonight, deep moisture 
and synoptic forcing will increase ahead of a shortwave trough that 
merged with the remains of Barry. The convective line in West TN is 
projected to mostly dissipate before reaching our area, but a few 
remnant showers may reach our Plateau counties before 12Z. 

The main period of showers/storms for the area will come during the 
late morning through the mid afternoon hours, associated with the 
main trough axis and associated QG forcing. PW values during this 
time will be around 2 inches, and efficient warm cloud processes 
(large LCL to freezing level thickness) will produce storms capable 
of producing locally heavy rainfall. Localized flooding will be 
possible, although area-wide averge QPF amounts of just a half to 
3/4 inch are expected as the system will be progressive. Overall,
the potential for widespread flooding problems appears low. The 
bulk of this precip will be exiting to the east from 21-00Z. A 
secondary trough at the 700-500 mb level with a weak surface 
trough will approach from the north Wednesday night, so chance 
PoPs will be maintained through that period.

.LONG TERM (Thursday through Tuesday)...
An exiting upper trough and any lingering remnants of Barry will 
be the main focus for convection on Thursday. Low level moisture 
will remain fairy high with PWs near 2 inches and DCAPE generally 
between 500 and 1000 J/Kg. This should lead to scattered 
thunderstorm development. Though a stray strong storm will be 
possible...the remain concern will continue to be heavy rainfall 
and the potential for flooding/flash flooding. The upper trough 
and what's left of Barry should pull out of the area Thursday 
night with a broad ridge of high pressure building in for Friday. 
Therefore...the focus for Friday will be diurnally driven 
convection centered over higher elevations. Flow aloft become 
rather weak and somewhat zonal for Saturday and diurnal convection
will again be the main concern with coverage slightly increased. 
Sunday...an upper trough will begin to move towards the area. Low 
level moisture will increase with a more southerly flow and the 
air mass becomes a bit more destabilized creating a slightly 
increased chance of showers and thunderstorms. By Monday...a 
weakening frontal boundary will move in for a further increased 
and more organized band of convection. High pressure builds in for
Tuesday which should decrease thunderstorm activity.

to develop along the terrain features.

instability increasing. Main forcing will remain the terrain 
features with scattered mainly diurnal storms developing each day.

rains and strong/gusty wind.

Atlantic states with a frontal boundary approaching late. End 
result, increasing coverage of showers and thunderstorms 
anticipated.

formation. Tuesday the remnants of Barry will get picked up by an
upper level trough moving into the mid Mississippi and lower Ohio
Valleys and stay over western and middle Tennessee so only 
limited convection during the afternoon and early evening like
today. Highs will be a couple degrees warmer mostly lower 90s.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday night through Monday)...
The merger of Barry's remains with a mid-latitude trough over the
MS Valley on Tuesday will result in likely PoPs for our area on 
Wednesday as the system moves east. The main concern that we have 
been watching for the past few days is the heavy rain/flooding 
potential, but the trend over the past few model runs has been 
toward lower QPF. While PW values will be anomalously high, around
2 inches, the trough appears to be progressive enough that any 
flash flooding threat should be isolated to locally heavy rainfall
rates or training cells. Model agreement is good that the timing 
of the highest rain chances will be Wednesday afternoon. PoPs will
be trending down Wednesday night as the trough axis move to our 
east. 

A large high pressure ridge drifting east from the lower OH Valley 
to the central Appalachian region will be the dominant feature 
through the remainder of the forecast period. Above normal 
temperatures can be expected under this ridge through the weekend. 
Moisture and instabilty should be adequate each day to support 
isolated afternoon storms in the TN Valley, with scattered coverage 
in the mountains.

104 
FXUS64 KMRX 150733
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
333 AM EDT Mon Jul 15 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Currently still some mid/high level clouds over the area with the
uptick in moisture being caused by Barry. Expect some of these
clouds to help keep fog away, but in some of the valley locations
we could see some patchy fog as RH values are creeping above 90%
very early this morning. Bulk of the rain associated with Barry is
still located in Western to Middle Tennessee. Expect it to remain
that way through most of the day today as the system continues to
run up against the ridge and begins to wash out. Better chances
for rain in our area will come from diurnally driven storms later
this afternoon. But at this time the CAMs are indicating only
isolated to scattered coverage of storms east of Barry. Expect
temperatures to remain around normal for this time of year unless
a stray shower cools a specific place off this afternoon.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Monday)...
The extended period will begin with the remnants of Barry across the 
Western Ohio Valley as it becomes an open trough and begins to 
interact with midlatitude Westerlies. This will place our region 
under deep southwest flow. With ridging across the region and little 
synoptic forcing, instability will be limited and mesoscale forcing 
for any afternoon convection will be across the higher elevations on 
Tuesday.

Our best chance of widespread convection will be on Wednesday and 
Wednesday night. Formerly Barry, but now an eastward propagating 
shortwave trough, will transit eastward toward our area with height 
falls across the region. Deep moisture associated with the former 
tropical cyclone will also increase across the area with PW values 
between 2.0 and 2.2 inches. This will be near maximum climatological 
values and provide ample moisture for heavy convective rainfall. In 
addition, instability is forecast to be on the lower side on 
Wednesday afternoon and evening with the GFS being on the high side 
of guidance with near 1000 J/Kg of MLCAPE. The NAM is much lower 
with generally 500 J/Kg or less of MLCAPE for much of Wednesday and 
Wednesday night. Regardless of exact values, this results in a very 
moist, skinny CAPE sounding with a deep warm cloud layer. For these 
reasons, periods of heavy rainfall and localized flash flooding will 
be possible on Wednesday afternoon through Wednesday night, 
especially where strongest low-level confluence exists across 
northwest portions of the forecast area. At this time, best timing 
for heavy rainfall appears to be between 21z Wednesday and 06z 
Thursday as the 850mb wind axis and max low level convergence will 
be present during this time period.

Shortwave trough axis shifts east on Thursday with deceasing PoPs 
and increasing forecast uncertainty into the weekend. The GFS and 
ECMWF both indicate an area of vorticity becoming displaced from the 
southern edge of the shortwave trough, but the location and track of 
this feature is very different in global model solutions. The GFS is 
much wetter into the weekend primarily because it keeps this vort 
max near our area with widespread scattered convection during the 
afternoons. Because of the uncertainty with this vort max location 
and track, have limited PoPs and expect most convection to be 
diurnal across the higher terrain. Global model consensus does 
continue to expand the ridge across the Central and Eastern CONUS, 
so expect this to help tamper much widespread convection in the 
absence of some mesoscale feature like the previously mentioned 
vorticity maximum. With an increasing ridge, much of the extended 
period should have above normal temperatures.

High uncertainty continues late weekend into early next week. Global 
models have a stronger shortwave across the Upper Mississippi Valley 
moving southeastward, but there are large differences in timing. The 
GFS is 24-48 hours quicker with the ECMWF and Canadian not weakening 
the ridge until the middle of next week. For this reason, introduced 
higher chance PoPs on Sunday into Monday due to potential height 
falls, but still limited highest PoPs to mainly the higher 
elevations.

like the upper ridge to the west takes over and will help to dry

FXUS64 KMRX 140805
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
405 AM EDT Sun Jul 14 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
The remnants of Barry continue to produce moisture rich southerly
flow across the Tennessee Valley. The stationary front that has
been located across the area for the past couple days is no longer
clearly defined in surface observations. Dew points are in the 
low to mid 70s across much of the area with some remaining upper 
60s across far NE TN and SW VA. WV imagery shows the deformation 
axis and axis of shortwave ridging and associated subsidence has 
shifted northward with relatively deep moisture through the 
atmosphere across the entire area. As instability increases mid- 
morning through the afternoon, expect scattered rain and 
thunderstorms to once again develop. The main development area, 
and likeliest PoPs today, is expected to be along a low-level wind
shift/deformation zone stretching NW-SE from near 
Scott/Anderson/Knox/Blount counties. RAP forecast soundings 
continue to show sufficient instability for convection with 1000 
to 2000 J/Kg of MLCAPE forecast across the area. PW values will 
also remain high, near 1.9 to 2.0 inches, across the central and 
southern valley. This deep, rich moisture may enhance heavy 
rainfall and localized flooding potential, especially in areas
that have already received heavy rain during the past 24 hours and
have lower FFG values. Additionally, with increased moisture 
across NE TN and SW VA and the deformation zone shifted north, 
expect higher chance PoPs across these areas today. However, 
forcing is weaker than Saturday, and some ridging is attempting to
build to our southeast. These factors may limit overall coverage 
of convection compared to Saturday. With scattered convection and 
cloud cover, expect temperatures to be near or slightly below 
normals.

Overnight, weak forcing will limit any widespread precipitation
potential, but may still have a few isolated rain showers. Where
there are cloud breaks, especially across SW VA and NE TN, fog and
low clouds would be expected to develop with weak boundary layer 
winds.


.LONG TERM...(Monday through Sunday)...
Main focus on the long term portion of the forecast will be how 
Barry and the mid/upper level ridge interact and influence the 
weather over the forecast area. On Monday the center of Barry will
likely be over Arkansas with broad ridging over much of the 
United States. Closer to home we will see higher dew points 
continue to be drawn up on the east side of the storm keeping 
moisture in the atmosphere high. Model forecast soundings indicate
that we should see precipitable water values of around 1.6 - 2.0 
inches throughout the upcoming work week, abnormally high for this
time of year. Isolated showers and thunderstorms are possible on 
Monday with temperatures rising a few degrees warmer than Sunday. 
On Tuesday Barry starts to lose it's punch and as it weakens it 
should begin to get caught up in the main steering flow of the 
atmosphere around it. This means that the remaining moisture and 
energy associated with the storm begin to move eastward towards 
us, leading to increased shower and thunderstorm chances as we 
move into the middle of th work week. 

Remnants remain in the general area through the second half of the 
work week before they eventually get shoved to the southeast by an 
approaching front over the weekend. Forecast confidence is somewhat 
low around Wednesday and beyond, mainly due to uncertainty in how 
strong Barry will remain and how quickly it starts to dissipate. All 
models are in good agreement that remnants will eventually impact 
our area, but the strength of the storms and amount of rain they 
will bring is still a bit difficult to pin down at this point. 
Biggest threats with storms for the next week will be mainly heavy 
rainfall, especially if rain occurs over specific areas over the 
course of a few days. Temperatures will remain right around normal 
for the upcoming work week and into next weekend.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Morning observations show localized fog and low clouds in river 
valleys. Fog will decrease in coverage this morning as boundary 
layer mixing increases after sunrise. The stationary front which 
has been aiding diurnal convection for the past couple days is 
also evident in surface observations with an 8 degree dewpoint 
gradient between TRI and MOR. South of the front, dew points are 
in the low to mid 70s; whereas, north of the front, dew points are
in the mid 60s. Recent RAOBS and WV imagery show shortwave 
ridging extending across the Ohio Valley and Central Appalachians 
including northern parts of our forecast area. This is resulting 
in subsidence and an inversion near 700mb across parts of far NE 
TN and SW VA. With drier boundary layer air also present across 
SW VA and far NE TN limiting any potential instability, expect 
very low PoPs today with convection unable to develop and reach 
the LFC. Southward, near and south of the low-level front, expect
widespread scattered convection. Boundary layer convergence along
the low-level deformation zone and RAP forecast soundings 
indicating the potential for MLCAPE of approximately 1500 to 2500
J/Kg will allow for likely scattered convection developing mid- 
morning and continuing through the afternoon. For this reason,
will forecast likely convection across the southern half of the 
forecast area, and in general, expect a majority of convection to 
be near or south of the Interstate 40 corridor. PW values will 
continue to be high near the maximum for this time of year with 
high confidence in 1.9 to 2.1 inch values in the vicinity of 
Knoxville and southward. While the high PW can aid localized heavy
rainfall, believe the overall heavy rain and flash flooding 
potential will be limited across the far southern portions of the 
forecast area near Chattanooga, Cleveland, the southern Cumberland
Plateau, and SW NC. The far southern areas are the only locations
that will have a deep warm cloud depth and sufficient mid-level 
moisture for warm rain processes to aid heavy rainfall. The 
central valley will see likely scattered convection but the 
affects of weak mid-level subsidence will be felt with drier mid-
levels limiting the overall flooding rain threat. However, this 
drier air aloft could aid some strong downburst winds with any 
thunderstorms. Max temperatures today will be dependent on 
coverage and location of showers and thunderstorms during the 
afternoon, but expect temperatures to be near seasonal normals.
Because of the drier boundary layer airmass and limited 
convection, temperatures will be slightly higher than seasonal 
normals across far NE TN and SW VA.

Convection is expected to decrease tonight after the loss of
daytime heating, but a few scattered rain showers will remain
possible near the stationary front. With a clearing sky and calm
wind, expect fog development once again in locations that received
rainfall during the day and in river valleys. Minimum temperatures
will be near normal across NE TN and SW VA and above normal across
the southern half of the forecast area where higher boundary layer
moisture is present and high clouds are more likely.


.LONG TERM...(Sunday through Saturday)...
At the beginning of this period Tropical Storm Barry will be 
moving northward through Louisiana, while we are located under a 
weak upper ridge between Barry and an shortwave in eastern Canada 
and NE US. Looks like we will still have a very weak WNW-ESE low 
level boundary draped across the area Sunday, that will offer very
little in the way of focus, but the deeper moisture tapers off 
quickly northeast of this boundary, and will taper off POPs in our
NE areas as well on Sunday.

The basic scenario of Barry remains consistent, with Barry moving 
northward through Monday, then the remnants of Barry turning east 
and heading our way in general, passing through generally between 
Wednesday and Thursday. The movement of Barry in the models is 
slightly slower to approach the area than model runs 24 hours ago. 
Also, models have Barry weaker and precipitable water values lower 
as Barry moves through, so precip amounts will be lower with this 
forecast.  Still with this being a tropical system, precip rates in 
the heaviest downpours will be higher than our normal summer shower 
or storm.  We should still have some flooding potential mid week. 
Trimmed back higher QPF that was showing up in Monroe TN and 
Cherokee County, NC area--looked like some kind of convective 
feedback bullseye stuck over that area for about 24 hours.

For temps, trimmed back Max Temps across the northern 1/2 to 1/3 of 
the area Wednesday and Thursday as lift, moisture, clouds, filter 
and disperse surface heating.

The weak stationary front that is across the south today lifts 
northward tomorrow as Barry pushes further north. The southerly flow 
from TS Barry causes convergence along the front and provides a 
lifting source through the day tomorrow. The high PWs will again 
allow for more heavy downpours. The highest POPs and heaviest rain
for tomorrow will be centered across the central TN Valley. 
Localized flash flooding will again be a concern. Lighter showers
expected across northeast TN and into SWVA as the deeper moisture
remains south of these locations. 

.LONG TERM...(Saturday night through Friday)...Weak upper level 
ridge NE of Tropical Storm Barry and old boundary that should be 
lifting north or along the northern edge of the forecast area will
be a focus for at least evening showers and thunderstorms 
Saturday night and then Sunday the southeast half of the area 
should have mostly scattered afternoon and early evening showers 
and thunderstorms. As moisture deepens Sunday and Monday storms 
that develop will be capable of producing brief heavy rainfall. 
Considerable clouds in the moist airmass will keep temperatures in
the mid to upper 80s for highs and mainly lower 70s for lows. By 
Tuesday the weakening circulation of Barry moves north into the 
mid Mississippi Valley with increasing rain chances across western
sections. The system will then move east across the Ohio Valley 
Wednesday and into the northeast states by Thursday night and 
Friday. Models are forecasting the system to open up and form an 
upper trough over the Ohio and Tennessee Valleys at mid week which
will enhance rainfall over the forecast area starting Tuesday 
night or Wednesday and continue into Thursday. A few inches of 
rain will likely fall with localized flooding possible. On Friday 
an upper level ridge to the west rebuilds over the southeast and 
Tennessee Valley. This will dry out the region and begin to warm 
temperatures back into the upper 80s to lower 90s. Rain chances 
will still be in the 30 to 40 percent range for mainly late 
afternoon and early evening thunderstorms Friday.

FXUS64 KMRX 120759
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
359 AM EDT Fri Jul 12 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
A few showers and isolated thunderstorms have developed early 
this morning along the frontal boundary as a weak vort max advects
southeast. Generally expect this convection to decrease in 
coverage toward sunrise as shortwave ridging arrives and the
jet streak to our northeast exits the area, but may still have 
some isolated/slight chance PoPs near and south of the surface 
front where low-level convergence is strongest. Current 
observations and satellite imagery show areas of fog, some dense, 
north of the front along the Cumberland Plateau, far northeast 
Tennessee, and southwest Virginia. As daytime mixing increases 
after sunrise, this fog should dissipate with a clearing sky.

The big story today will be likely convection along and south of
the stalled stationary front. The 500mb trough axis will be 
shifting eastward with weak subsidence and drier air aloft across 
the region which is already evident in WV imagery this morning. 
This will lead to weaker mid-level lapse rates and limit overall 
instability. Surface analysis data and short-term models are in 
agreement with the low-level deformation zone extending east to 
west through Tennessee generally along or just south of Interstate
40 enhancing surface convergence and lift. South of this front 
across southeast Tennessee and southwest North Carolina, the 
airmass is very moist with dewpoints in the low to mid 70s and PW 
values near 2.0 inches. This is near the max of climatology, so 
tropical downpours with localized flash flooding potential will be
possible in these areas. However, the extent of flash flooding 
risk is uncertain with the dry air aloft. Highest probabilities of
these heavy downpours will be further south near Chattanooga and 
the Georgia state line where the warm cloud layer is deepest and
upper-level subsidence is weakest. North of the front, the 
airmass is much drier with dewpoints in the mid to upper 60s and 
PW values between 1.0 and 1.3 inches. With the very moist airmass 
south of the front, the atmosphere is still expected to be 
moderately unstable generally along and south of Interstate 40.
RAP forecast soundings indicate MLCAPE between 1500 and 2500 J/Kg for
TYS and CHA. With the dry air aloft, the RAP is showing the 
potential for DCAPE of about 1100 J/Kg near TYS which may result 
in a few thunderstorms having some strong downburst winds. Further
north in the drier airmass, instability will be greatly reduced 
with MLCAPE approximately 400 to 800 J/Kg near TRI with the 
atmosphere becoming much more stable further north of the front. 
For this reason, PoPs will be highest generally along and south of
Interstate 40 today. Temperatures will be highly dependent on 
convective coverage this afternoon, but generally should be near 
seasonal normals.

Convective activity will decrease after sunset, but isolated
showers or a thunderstorm will be possible near the surface front
which will remain stationary across our forecast area. Fog will be
likely again north of the front and across those areas that see
rainfall today. Overnight temperatures will be coolest across the
Cumberland Plateau, northeast Tennessee, and southwest Virginia 
in the drier airmass north of the front.


.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Friday)...
At the beginning of this period, we will be under a weak upper 
ridge with the tropical system Barry close to the Louisiana coast,
moving northward. There may be a very weak east to west surface 
boundary on Saturday that would help be a weak focus for 
convection, and there may be some weak lift moving northward on 
the outer fringes of Barry that pass through the area. By Sunday, 
the boundary should be north of the area, and moisture will be 
deepening from Sunday into the work week, with precipitable water 
values over 1.5 inches on Sunday, increasing to over 2 inches by 
Wednesday over most of the area. There is pretty good agreement 
that Barry will turn eastward early in the week, with some part of
it pass through the area around Wednesday. We can expect tropical
downpours as Barry passes through, then rain rates tapering off 
later in the week after Barry moves away to the east. Right now, 
heaviest rains are focused from Tuesday night through Wednesday 
night, with wettest area on the northern plateau, where forecast 
amounts are 1.5 to 2 inches. Other parts of the area during this 
period are closer to 1 inch. For temps, went close to guidance, 
although bumped down Max temps generally by 1-2 degrees south and 
2-4 degrees north as soupy airmass, cloud cover, and lift should 
slow surface heating.

flooding) will be gusty winds with these storms as they strengthen
and collapse. Expect most storms to stay below severe levels, but
with how saturated the grounds have gotten recently it won't take
nearly as strong winds to cause damage to trees or power outages.

Another round of storms is expected to flare up over the area as
the actual front moves into the area later tonight. Can currently
be seen on satellite/radar across Central/Northern Kentucky. This
front and the associated storms will continue to dive towards the
southeast and move into the Cumberland Plateau tonight. Currently
not expecting these storms to be as wide spread as what we are 
seeing on radar this afternoon, but if storms are able to go over 
the areas that got heavy rain already then it won't take much 
additional rain to quickly cause flooding problems.

Overnight expect fog to form in many locations, especially ones
that got rain during the day today, so it would be a good idea to
allow extra time to get to work tomorrow morning. Rain chances
won't completely go away after the front moves through. Higher
rain chances will continue tomorrow closer to the front and closer
to the moisture being brought in from Tropical Storm Barry. Once
again the main threats with any of these storms will be the
continued chances for flooding.

.LONG TERM...(Friday night through Thursday)...
By 00Z Saturday, upper level troughing will encompass much of the 
eastern seaboard with upper level ridging located across the western 
US and western Atlantic. Much of the uncertainty in the extended 
results from what will become of the current Tropical Storm Barry. 
Guidance has trended closer together and the official advisory 5 
from NHC has this system moving through Louisiana and into the 
Midsouth by early next week. A frontal boundary will be situated 
across the Tennessee valley on Saturday and low to mid layer 
moisture will increase leading to slight chance to chance PoPs. 
Temperatures during this time will likely be near normal values 
during this time.

By Sunday we should start to see a slow increase in coverage of 
showers and thunderstorms as the tropical system continues to move 
into the Mississippi valley. Southerly flow will increase on the 
eastern side of this storm and will continue to transport moisture 
northward. Better chances will occur in southwestern portions of the 
area where better low level convergence will be situated. 

Not much has changed from the previous forecast as the tropical 
system makes its transition to an open wave as it progresses 
northward into the Ohio valley. As with any tropical system, 
uncertainty exists with the track and speed so expect some changes 
to the forecast next week. The degree of moisture spreading 
northward does lead to some concerns of heavy rainfall and localized 
flash flooding. Precipitable water values increase to 1.50 to 2.00 
inches by early to middle next week. Will introduce the possibility 
of heavy rainfall and localized flash flooding for next week into 
the HWO. Temperatures will likely stay a couple of degrees below 
normal given the cloud cover and rainfall.

078 
FXUS64 KMRX 110657
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
257 AM EDT Thu Jul 11 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
A very moist air mass with PW values upwards of 2 inches will be 
over the area today. Early this morning, convection is already 
developing over the Plateau. This appears to be associated with a 
pre-frontal trough, while the main cold front is located across 
IN/srn IL. The hi-res models agree on convection increasing this 
morning along the trough, spreading east and south through the 
afternoon. Given the high moisture content and tall, skinny CAPE 
profiles in forecast soundings, any storms will have the potential 
to dump copious amounts of rain in a short time, and will mention 
locally heavy rain with a potential for flash flooding in the HWO. 
Severe storms appear unlikely due to the lack of shear and the 
aforementioned skinny CAPE profiles. With mostly cloudy skies 
expected and morning precip, high temps should be cooler than the 
past few days, mainly in the mid/upper 80s for most of the Valley. 
PoPs will continue through tonight as the front makes its way into 
the area and stalls, but with the 500 mb trough axis moving off to 
our east and drier air moving in on a NW flow aloft, activity should 
only be scattered to isolated with highest chances in southern
sections.

.LONG TERM...(Friday through Wednesday)... 
Upper troughing will be present across the Eastern CONUS on 
Friday with a surface front becoming stationary from E-W across 
southern Tennessee. North of this boundary will be a drier and 
more stable airmass; whereas, south of the boundary, an unstable 
and moist airmass will persist. There is some uncertainty in the 
exact location of this stationary front on Friday, but guidance is
in good agreement at placing the front, and highest PoPs, 
generally south of Interstate 40. Highest PoPs will be expected 
during the afternoon and evening peak heating hours.

What remains of this front is expected to lift north Friday night 
and Saturday as low-level southerly flow increases on the eastern 
side of current PTC2. Due to the uncertainties of PTC2, forecast 
uncertainty is higher from Saturday through the remainder of the 
extended. Model guidance shows the potential for more convection, 
especially across southern portions of the forecast area, on 
Saturday. However, there are differences in the synoptic setup 
between model guidance that would have significant impacts on our 
weather. Ignoring these differences for the moment, there is 
confidence in additional scattered convection along and south of the 
stationary/warm front on Saturday where instability will be highest. 
For this reason, have likely scattered convection forecast for 
Saturday afternoon across southern portions of the forecast area. 
However, depending upon the strength of the low-level southerly flow 
around PTC2 and its exact track, we could have more widespread 
convection. The GFS is currently one of the most bullish on QPF for 
Saturday, and unsurprisingly, is one of the eastern and generally 
weaker track solutions which brings a broad 850mb jet and strong low-
level convergence into our area. Other guidance continues to place 
the strongest 850mb flow to our west, and this would keep our area 
drier. At this time, tend to lean more toward the ECMWF and Canadian 
which keep the majority of convection to our south and west. While 
uncertainty is high for coverage of convection on Saturday, this 
will need to be watched closely over the next couple of days, 
because if the GFS is correct, some heavy rainfall and flooding 
concerns may be enhanced across SE TN and SW NC.

Similar uncertainty exists on Sunday, but at this time, expect 
mainly diurnal scattered convection with PTC2 as it moves inland 
over the Southern Mississippi Valley. Highest chance PoPs are 
currently across southwestern portions of the forecast area which 
are most likely to be impacted by any outer rainbands enhancing 
convergence and mesoscale convective coverage. Otherwise, SW flow 
aloft and high clouds should keep temperatures a few degrees below 
normal.

Next week, the two big questions will be: 1) The exact track of PTC2 
as it transitions into an open wave; and 2) The magnitude and 
location of the ridge as it builds across the SE CONUS. As for the 
track of PTC2, current model guidance is in agreement with it 
reaching the Ohio Valley and moving eastward as it encounters 
stronger westerly flow. The impact on our weather from this will be 
the tropical airmass associated with the low-level center of this 
system where PW values of 2.0 to 2.4 inches will be present. An 
airmass such as this would bring the potential of localized heavy 
rainfall and flash flooding concerns toward the middle of next week. 
Confidence is still very low on the track of this system and the 
impacts to our weather next week, but it is something that bears 
watching over the coming days. Confidence in temperatures through 
the extended is much lower than normal because of the track and 
associated effects of PTC2.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday night through Wednesday)...
The extended range fcst period kicks off on Thursday night amidst an 
increasingly active pattern across the southeast CONUS thanks to an 
H5 trough moving through the OH Valley, and PTC Two moving through 
the northern GOM.  At the surface, a cold front will be approaching 
the region from the west beneath the aforementioned H5 trough, with 
a modestly unstable warm sector out ahead, thus prefrontal 
scattered/numerous thunderstorms are favored.  Fortunately the bulk 
of the upper dynamic support will remain north of the region, 
however guidance does favor around 20-30kts deep layer shear amidst 
2-3k j/kg sbcape. Thus, won't rule out a few strong/severe 
thunderstorms early on in the period with damaging winds, hail, 
brief heavy rainfall, and cloud to ground lightning being the 
primary threats. With that, SPC has placed the entire region in the 
Marginal Risk.

Moving forward through the remainder of the period, uncertainty in 
prevalent as guidance tends to stall the noted cold front somewhere 
near/along the US 64 corridor, possibly southward into north GA, all 
complicated by the eventual track of PTC Two (which has it's own 
inherent uncertainty).  As for PTC Two, NHC currently has the fcst 
track center making landfall across southwest LA as its driven 
westward by the developing/strengthen Bermuda High on Saturday, 
perhaps as a Hurricane.  Closer to home the airmass will continually 
moisten thanks to increasing flux from the GOM, consequent of PTC 
Two.  Therefore, uncertainty in the forecast beyond Saturday is 
high, with the possibility of heavy rainfall accumulations still up 
in the air.  Thus, favored likely pops across the southern 
valley/plateau and mtns both Friday/Saturday, with chance pops for 
the remainder of the region.  Beyond that, leaned toward WPC pops 
which favor chances southward, slight chances northward.  Given the 
intruding fropa as well as gulf moisture advection, sky cover should 
increase with the ridge centered over the Western Atlantic, thus 
temperatures through the period should return to around or slightly 
below normal levels.

FXUS64 KMRX 100653
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
253 AM EDT Wed Jul 10 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Very little change in the synoptic pattern is expected today across 
the region. A mid/upper level ridge will contine to be located over 
West TN extending NE across KY/OH/PA, with low pressure systems over 
the Great Lakes and the Gulf of Mexico. One feature of note is a 700 
mb deformation zone over the Appalachians, which should make the 
higher elevations the favored area for afternoon convection. In the 
Valley, storms will be possible as outflow boundaires move through 
the low 70s dewpoint air mass, but coverage should be more isolated. 
Any storms will be slow moving in the weak steering flow, and while 
their life cycle should be short lived, locally heavy rain may be 
possible. Most activity will dissipate after sunset but will keep 
slight chance PoPs going through the night as the mid/upper ridge 
weakens and a shortwave trough approaches from the northwest. 

Based on the trends of the past few days, will have high temps
today a little above guidance - lower to mid 90s across the
Valley.

.LONG TERM (Thursday through Wednesday)... 
Confidence is high early in the forecast period with scattered 
likely convection across the area on Thursday afternoon and 
evening. A shortwave diving southeast will amplify troughing 
across the Ohio Valley and Central Appalachians resulting in a 
weakening of the ridge and height falls across the Tennessee 
Valley by Thursday afternoon. An associated surface cold front 
will be moving southeastward and its forward motion will begin to 
slow as the surface low occludes across Quebec. While the main 
surface low and upper dynamics will remain further north of our 
forecast area, the resulting height falls and forcing along the 
surface front will increase probabilities of scattered showers and
thunderstorms late Thursday and Thursday night. Most guidance 
favors decent instability with at least 1000 to 2000 J/Kg MLCAPE. 
Deep layer shear will be weak across the area, but it will be 
strongest across NE TN and SW VA closer to the upper jet. In these
areas, effective deep layer shear of 30 kt is possible which will
favor better thunderstorm organization and the potential of some 
multicell convection. The main risk will be for damaging wind 
gusts with any severe thunderstorms that develop. With a high 
freezing level and WBZ level near 11k ft, do not expect much of a 
risk of severe hail, but some subsevere hail is possible with the 
strongest thunderstorms. Low level moisture is also going to be 
very high ahead of the cold front. Guidance is in good agreement 
showing a 2.0+ inch PW plume along and ahead of the front. This 
will favor some localized heavy rainfall and the potential for 
some localized flooding concerns.

The front is expected to dip south on Friday with the highest PoPs 
across southern sections of the forecast area where scattered 
convection will continue, mainly in the afternoon. North of the 
front, Friday is forecast to be mostly dry. What remains of the 
front may initiate a few thunderstorms on Saturday or Sunday across 
the area, but most convection is expected to be diurnal and 
clustered across the higher elevations. With most areas north of the 
front and a general troughing pattern across the Eastern CONUS, 
temperatures should be near normal.

Late in the weekend and early next week, uncertainty remains high 
and our weather will likely be influenced by the track of the 
potential tropical storm in the Gulf of Mexico. The 0z guidance 
continues to show large spread in track with a clustering showing 
landfall in LA and the center moving north through the Mississippi 
River Valley between a weakness in the ridge. The main result of 
this for our area would be an increase in moist, southerly flow with 
scattered thunderstorms primarily in the afternoon hours. Did not go 
higher than chance PoPs during this time period because of the 
continued uncertainty in the timing and track of this tropical low.

Ridging is expected to increase across the Southeast CONUS early 
next week with the Canadian, GFS, and ECMWF all indicating the 
potential for 500mb heights of 592+ dam by next Tuesday. Isolated 
afternoon thunderstorms would be mainly limited to the higher 
elevations. Based on the stronger ridge, temperatures are expected 
to be above normal.

FXUS64 KMRX 091920
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
320 PM EDT Tue Jul 9 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Wednesday)...

Scattered convection is ongoing this afternoon across mainly the
higher terrain. Chances for storms in the valley will remain low
this afternoon and evening, mainly in the 20-30 percent range.
Some outflow boundaries from higher elevation storms could push
into the valley and help initiate some convection there. However
steering flow is northwesterly today so the more likely scenario
would be storms initiating over the plateau would need to push off
into the valley, and outside of the elevated terrain near Frozen
Head State Park the CU field along the plateau region has looked
rather unimpressive so far today. Again, have some 20-30 PoPs in 
the forecast for lower elevations this evening, but that may be 
optimistic in the end.

Convective trends will take a downturn this evening after sunset,
with no rain chances to speak by late this evening. Lows tonight 
will be similar to the past few nights, with temperatures in the 
upper 60s to around 70. Tomorrow should be much the same as today 
as high pressure remains anchored overhead. Expect scattered 
storms to develop over the mountains by late morning, with again a
chance of a few of them drifting into the valley during the late 
afternoon and evening hours.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday night through Tuesday)...

Another round of diurnally driven convection will likely occur on 
Wednesday with another warm day in store for us. These showers and 
thunderstorms won't really be aided by any significant synoptic 
forcing, so still think the most favorable area for convection will 
be along and near the higher elevations, or any potential outflows 
left behind by previous storms.

More widespread and stronger showers and thunderstorms look more 
likely on Thursday under a more favorable synoptic pattern. Upper 
level trough will be moving across the Ohio Valley on Thursday, 
along with it a surface low will pull across a cold front over the 
Eastern portions of the United States. These will help be the focus 
for showers and thunderstorms on Thursday. Looking more specifically 
over the Eastern Tennessee Valley the atmosphere does look to pose 
the potential for some strong to severe storms. The NAM is the most 
bullish with MLCAPE values generally above 2000 J/kg across the area 
while other models are a little more modest with values closer to 
1000-2000 J/kg. Almost all the models are indicating that there be 
very little shear to work with through any portion of the 
atmosphere. PWAT values on Thursday look to be about 1.5 - 2.0 
inches as well. These parameters are lining up to indicate the 
biggest threats with storms on Thursday will be strong winds and 
heavy rainfall in the strongest storms. 

Forecast models indicate the the front will stall out east of the 
forecast area, but west of the Atlantic. This will help to keep 
temperatures a bit more moderate with generally light northerly to 
westerly flow through the rest of the work week and into the weekend.

Forecast certainty begins to drop as we move through the weekend, 
mostly with respect to how the Tropical Disturbance in the Gulf will 
behave. Long range models are in somewhat general agreement that the 
storm will move towards the TX/LA coast and then begin to move 
northward. The biggest unknown is how strong will this system be and 
how much moisture will it be able to bring in from the Gulf. If it 
continues to strengthen and is able to draw up move moisture on the 
eastern side we may experience periods of heavy rain along the 
Cumberland Plateau down towards Chattanooga at some point next week. 
However, forecast confidence is very low at this time, but the 
tropical system will be worth keeping an eye on over the next 
several days.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
247 AM EDT Tue Jul 9 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
A weak surface low will be located over southern AL today, with an 
inverted trough extending across northern AL through the TN Valley. 
Models indicate that this trough will be a focus for convective 
development this afternoon, but each model has varying degrees of 
coverage. In any case, PoPs will have to be raised from the previous 
forecast, especially in SW NC/SE TN which will have a SE low level 
flow on the eastern side of the trough. There is still dry air in 
the mid/upper levels that storms will have to contend with, so the 
forecast will keep coverage scattered to isolated this afternoon. 
Some activity could persist after sunset with the surface trough and 
outflow boundaries, but most will likely dissipate by midnight. Some 
spots in the southern TN Valley, particularly CHA, could see heat 
indicies briefly reach around 100 this afternoon.

.LONG TERM (Wednesday through Monday)... 
The long term period begins with ridging building across the 
Central CONUS. Ridging will also be in place across the Southeast 
and Eastern CONUS with an amplifying trough across the upper 
Mississippi Valley. With minimal synoptic forcing across our area 
on Wednesday, expect highest diurnal PoPs to be primarily across 
the higher elevations with outflows potentially leading to a few 
showers or thunderstorms across the valley late in the afternoon. 
With strong ridging still in place, temperatures should remain 
several degrees above normal.

Afternoon convective activity will decrease after sunset Wednesday 
night while a shortwave trough across northern Illinois moves 
southeast. This will act to amplify the trough across the Ohio 
Valley with height falls extending into the Tennessee Valley. An 
associated surface low will be across the Great Lakes with a 
trailing cold front moving southeast across the Ohio Valley toward 
our area on Thursday. As the front approaches the area and the ridge 
weakens, PoPs will increase on Thursday afternoon. Effective bulk 
shear remains weak, which is common this time of year, so 
significant organized severe weather is not expected. However, the 
NAM does indicate the potential for MLCAPE of 2000 to 3000 J/Kg on 
Thursday afternoon along with high PW values around 2.0 inches. This 
could lead to a few strong to marginally severe thunderstorms with 
heavy rainfall and downburst winds being the primary hazards. This 
front is expected to stall across southern TN or northern AL/GA by 
Friday with drier weather north of the boundary. Temperatures will 
be closer to normal late week as the ridge weakens. Model consensus 
is in reasonable agreement through Friday.

Beyond Friday, high uncertainty in the forecast exists, and our 
weather may be influenced by the potential tropical system in the 
Gulf of Mexico. The 0z track guidance on the low has significant 
spread, and expect models to have a difficult time with the track 
until the tropical low is better developed and resolved during data 
assimilation. At this time, a majority of guidance increases ridging 
across the area through the weekend with dry weather on Saturday to 
the north of the previously mentioned cold front. PoPs increase on 
Sunday into early next week with a general summer-like diurnal trend 
as low-level moisture increases and NW flow provides a chance for 
convective systems to move southeastward across our region. Because 
of the poor model agreement in the potential track of the tropical 
low, confidence is very low late in the extended.
