Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
254 PM EDT Mon Jul 8 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Tuesday)...
Isolated to scattered convection has been forming this afternoon across
the forecast area. Highest concentration of storms has been from 
the VA/KY border down towards Chattanooga. There appears to be the
slightest of weak temp/wind gradient here (along with some 
orographic influence) that may be aiding in the additional 
convection in this area. Expect showers and thunderstorms to 
continue through this afternoon and eventually dissipate as the 
sun sets and diurnal heating stops. Trend of these storms is for 
them to be pretty short-lived and very little lightning in them so
far. Biggest threat right now would be from a quick downpour 
leading to gusty winds or maybe some isolated flooding. Stronger 
storms have formed further south in GA, so will keep an eye 
towards the southern TN/NC/GA border in case a strong storm is 
able to flare up before the afternoon is done.

Dew point values remain relatively elevated and with these
additional storms as well looks like we're in for another round 
of fog in parts of the area early tomorrow morning, similar to 
what we saw early this morning.

Once the fog is able to burn off we can expect to see another day
of slightly above normal temperatures and possible showers and
thunderstorms in the afternoon.

.LONG TERM (Tuesday Night through Monday)...
The extended will begin in a common summer type pattern with an 
upper ridge over the central U.S. extending into the 
area...placing the Southern Appalachian Region under a relatively 
dry northwesterly flow. This pattern will allow the air mass to 
weakly destabilized with little upper support and minimal shear to
work with. As a result...expect mainly diurnally driven 
convection centered over higher elevations with only a stray storm
moving into the low terrain. Will see a pattern change Wednesday 
night into Thursday as a weakening frontal boundary pushes 
southward and into the area. The front will act as a focus for 
convection as the air mass ahead of the boundary become unstable 
and low level moisture remains in place. This should create a line
of more organized thunderstorm activity across the area. The 
front will eventually settle south across the area before stalling
and becoming even more diffuse just south of the TN border. 

For the rest of the extended...confidence becomes quite low.  This 
is mainly in regards to an area of low pressure developing over the 
Gulf.  This low is expected to deepen and potentially take on some 
tropical characteristics.  Models in poor agreement with the 
position...track...timing and overall handling of the low. The GFS 
wants to have part of energy of the low funneled into the stalled 
front allowing these remnants to track along the boundary Friday 
into the weekend.  The rest or main part of the low then rotates 
around the coast eventually becoming incorporated into the boundary 
and other short waves riding through the flow.  On the other 
hand...the ECMWF trends towards maintaining the low over the Gulf 
through much of the weekend and eventually lifts it northward 
through the Mississippi Valley with the current run tracking it well 
to our west late in the extended period. With such significantly 
different scenarios...will basically keep the current thinking in 
place which focuses more on the old frontal boundary to our south. 
This will mean little to no PoPs north and at least a low to chance 
PoPs south from Friday through the end of the period.

midlevel air will be building in today, and as a result we should

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Sunday)...

Central and Southeast States Tuesday and Wednesday. Expecting only
isolated showers and thunderstorms during the peak heating hours 
in the valleys and chance of showers and thunderstorms eastern

carves a path into the Great Lakes and Ohio Valley and pushes a

characteristics and move northward into the southeast states. 
Thursdays front will likely only make it just into Georgia and the
Carolinas before becoming stationary or moving back north. Chance
pops will continue for the eastern mountains and slight chance

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Monday)...

Not a lot going on in the short term. Scattered convection is

be mainly of the garden variety type, with beneficial rains.
High resolution guidance suggests there is perhaps a chance of an
isolated shower or two continuing into the overnight hours.
However, think that typical diurnal trends will win over and there
will be a significant downturn in convection after sunset this
evening. Temperatures tonight should be similar to those seen in
recent nights, with lows in the upper 60s and low 70s. Did
continue with mention of fog, especially in the north where
rainfall will have been prevalent both yesterday and this
afternoon/evening.

For tomorrow, the region will lie beneath weak northwesterly mid
and upper level flow. Surface winds will be light northerly,
however no change in air mass will have occurred as surface high 
pressure remains anchored to our west. So it will be just as hot
and humid as today. Do expect less coverage of showers and
thunderstorms tomorrow however. Most convection should be held in
the higher terrain thanks to persistent upslope northwesterly flow
in the mid levels.

.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Sunday)...

An upper ridge will continue to expand across the region early in
the extended. This will place the area under a bit drier 
northwesterly flow and put us in a normal summer pattern. This 
means the main concern through Wednesday will be diurnally driven 
convection. The area with the best chance of thunderstorm activity
will be over higher elevations with a few storms occasionally 
dropping into the valley. There will be a pattern chance on 
Thursday as a weakening frontal boundary moves south and into the 
Southern Appalachian Region. This front will be the main focus of 
convection Thursday/Thursday evening with the added lift combined 
with a weakly unstable atmosphere and plenty of low level moisture
in place. As a result...should see chance to likely PoPs for this
time frame. The front will settle southward across the area and 
eventually end up south of the TN/GA border with high pressure 
building in. However...models are indicating a low moving in from 
the gulf. Confidence quite low in regards to position...track and 
timing of the low. With this overall synoptic pattern through the 
end of the period...expect the best chance of thunderstorms over 
higher elevations and along far southern locations Friday though 
the weekend.

Weak frontal system over the Ohio Valley will shift south today 
and tonight as upper trough moves south from the northeast and mid
atlantic states and upper level ridge shifts to the southwest.
This front will be a trigger for showers and thunderstorms to 
develop in the very humid airmass over the region. Temperatures 
are again very warm this morning with lower 70s north and 
northeast to mid and upper 70s south. Raised highs a couple 
degrees south and central valley as temperatures will start out 
warm and convection should not become at least scattered until 
early afternoon. The biggest threat with storms that develop today
will be locally heavy rainfall due to the high moisture content 
and slow movement. Precipitable Water values are about 1.8 to 2.0 
inches and CAPE Values 2000 to 3000 J/KG. With approaching front 
late today and tonight, storms may linger longer in the evening. 
Patchy fog again probable tonight. Rain chances will reach a high 
of about 60 percent late afternoon and then 30 to 50 percent by 
early evening decreasing to slight chance late tonight. Lows will 
stay warm again near 70 to the mid 70s. 

.LONG TERM...(Monday through Saturday)... A large ridge over the 
Plains today will expand eastward for the beginning of the work 
week. This will place the Southern Appalachian Region in a drier 
northwest flow aloft. As a result, we will transition into a more 
diurnally-driven convective pattern. Models indicate that a trough
will be dropping south across the Mid Atlantic region on Monday 
to VA/NC on Tuesday, which will favor our NE TN/SW VA counties for
the highest rain chances both days, but still with just scattered
coverage expected at best. On Wednesday behind this trough and 
with the mid/upper ridge overhead, we should see only isolated 
coverage of showers and thunderstorms, mainly focused on the 
higher terrain areas. 

On Thursday a low pressure system crosses the Great Lakes region, 
bringing a cold front toward our area. This will add a little more 
forcing for better chances of convection Thursday afternoon. Still, 
with a west to northwest midlevel flow ahead of it and the Gulf 
being cut off, PoPs will be held in the chance range. The front 
should move out Thursday night with high pressure building in for 
Friday and Saturday, providing drier, more stable air. Will keep 
most of the area dry both days with slightly above normal 
temperatures, except for a slight chance in the mountains along the 
NC border.

chance of convection over southern areas and across the higher 
elevations.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
404 AM EDT Fri Jul 5 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Convection ended by late evening across the forecast area with
skies partly to mostly cloudy and some added smoke possibly
allowed for more fog formation in areas that saw showers during
the evening. The area that had evening rainfall was the northern 
plateau and parts of the northern Tennessee Valley north of 
Knoxville. Fog was forming by midnight in these areas and was 
locally dense across parts of the northern plateau early this 
morning. Will watch to see how much area has the fog and could put
out special weather statement if conditions worsen. Temperatures 
early today were in the upper 60s to lower 70s at this hour. Most 
of the cloud debris from evening storms was only across northeast 
sections. Expect another day of scattered storms as upper ridge 
holds over the area one more day. Upper trough over the 
Mississippi Valley begins to move east toward the western 
Tennessee Valley during the day today. Precipitable water values 
reach around 1.8 inches with weak deep layer shear and instability
values about the same as Thursdays. Storms will be more numerous 
in the higher elevations with some storms producing locally heavy 
rainfall amounts...however no flooding expected. Temperatures 
will be in the lower 90s around Chattanooga and possibly 
Knoxville and Oak Ridge with heat index values mid to upper 90s. 
Expect showers and storms to decrease by sunset but clouds 
lingering overnight. Where there is clearing and rainfall patchy 
fog forms again.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Friday)...
On Saturday, we will have a weak mid to upper level trough over 
Middle TN/northern AL, with PW values in the neighborhood of 2 
inches, and plentiful CAPE. While forcing with the trough appears 
weak, it will only take a nudge to get storms to develop on 
Saturday, so the forecast of likely PoPs with an emphasis on the 
afternoon hours will be continued. Sunday looks much the same as 
the trough slowly drifts SE to GA, and high moisture content 
remains in place. Any storms that develop both days will be slow 
moving, creating the potential for locally heavy downpours and 
potential for flooding. 

A trend toward drier conditions should begin on Monday as the trough 
moves away and a building ridge over the Plains begins to have a 
greater influence over the TN Valley region. We will be in a 
northwesterly flow regime that will provide a drier air mass for 
Monday through Thursday, lowering rain chances to the low to slight 
chance range. The focus of diurnal convection will likely be over 
the higher terrain areas each day. There may be a possibility of 
upstream convection that develops on the northern periphery of the 
ridge to move into our area, but such details are too uncertain to 
pinpoint this far out.

899 
FXUS64 KMRX 041855
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
255 PM EDT Thu Jul 4 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Friday)...

Seeing the coverage of showers/storms begin to increase early this 
afternoon as anticipated. Temperatures are currently in the 80s 
across most of the area with dewpoints in the upper 60s to low 70s. 
Upper level flow is weak with 300-500 mb winds around 10 kts or so. 
Due to this, 0-6 km bulk shear values are around 10 kts. SBCAPE 
values are around 1500-2000 J/Kg. Current water vapor imagery and 
RAP upper air analysis indicates a small weak shortwave trough 
across the central Appalachians and another to the southwest across 
the lower Mississippi River Valley. At the surface, there is a 
boundary to the east across the Carolinas. Closer to home, not 
seeing much in the way of synoptic or surface lift but as 
temperatures continue to rise and dewpoints in the upper 60s to low 
70s, expect a typical summer afternoon/evening with diurnally driven 
showers/storms. A few of the storms could become strong with gusty 
winds and small hail being the main risks. The coverage of 
showers/storms will effect some outdoor plans this afternoon but do 
not anticipate a washout. Any ongoing convection will begin to 
diminish in intensity and coverage near sunset with the loss of 
daytime heating. Heat indices this afternoon will also approach 100 
degrees in portions of the central and southern valley. Remember to 
practice heat safety at any outdoor activities this afternoon. Highs 
this afternoon will range from upper 80s to low 90s for most 
locations.

Fog development will be possible again tonight but will depend upon 
the coverage of shower/storms this afternoon. Lows overnight will
range from mid 60s to low 70s.

Atmospheric conditions look to remain relatively unchanged going into 
Friday. The shortwave trough currently over the lower Mississippi 
River Valley will move into the Tennessee River Valley on Friday and 
may provide a bit more synoptic lift for slightly better coverage of 
showers/storms. Deep layer shear will still be low with weak flow 
aloft and SBCAPE values will be similar to maybe even slightly lower 
than today. PW values will remain elevated in the 1.8-2.0 inch 
range, so have continued with 30-60% chances for tomorrow afternoon. 
Best chances will be over the higher elevations with the lower 
chances over the valley. Heat indices will once again be high with 
near 100 degree values in the southern valley and mid 90s in the 
central valley. High temperatures will range from the upper 80s to 
low 90s.

.LONG TERM...(Friday night through Thursday)...

The broad upper ridging that has occupied the southeastern U.S. this 
past week will shift south to the Gulf Coast Friday night through 
the weekend with broad upper troughing developing over the OH and TN 
valleys. This will allow a cold front to slowly sag south and 
southwestward through the weekend, and the increasing convergence 
ahead of the front will bring an increase in thunderstorm coverage 
Saturday and Sunday. Chance pops are included all weekend, but the 
highest chances will be in the afternoon and evening hours. MLCAPE 
of 1500-2000 J/kg and 2500-3000 J/kg surface CAPE during the 
afternoons and evenings will combine with steep low-level lapse 
rates of 7.5-8.0 C/km and near 1000 J/kg DCAPE to allow for isolated 
severe storms with damaging downburst winds and small hail, however, 
deep layer shear is almost non existent and mid level lapse rates 
are flat, so any downbursts will be isolated. Individual cores will 
not be able to sustain strong updrafts for long before collapsing in 
this environment. The main impact will be locally heavy rainfall. 
The weak flow aloft will result in slow moving convection, and PWATs 
of 1.50-1.75 inches Saturday and 1.75-2.00+ inches Sunday will cause 
torrential rainfall rates underneath any thunderstorms, so localized 
flash flooding will be possible. Highs will be slightly cooler this 
weekend with the increased cloud cover and convective coverage, so 
stuck close to the cooler MAV guidance. Oppressively humid 
conditions will continue. 

The old front now looks to linger on Monday as the upper trough 
moves into the Northeast U.S. and the upper ridge starts to 
redevelop in the southern Plains putting the southern Appalachians 
in WNW flow. This will keep chance pops for showers/thunderstorms 
with the peak again being during the afternoon and evening. The 
southern Plains ridge will slowly try and build east into the TN 
valley Tuesday and Wednesday allowing highs in the upper 80's to low 
90's to return with lower chances of thunderstorms as the boundary 
gradually pushes back to the northeast and capping increases. A new 
trough developing near the Great Lakes will cause a cold front to 
approach from the north late Thursday, but any increase in 
convection will hold off until after the period.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
340 AM EDT Thu Jul 4 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
The synoptic pattern today features some flattening of the 
prevailing H5 ridge across the TN Valley and Southern Appalachian 
region as the primary axis shifts slightly east.  At the surface, 
still looking at weak/mod high pressure spread about the region, 
while numerous remnant convective outflows settle in.  As for this 
morning, any lingering convection will slowly degrade as instability 
wains further into the predawn hours, with any lower stratocu 
expected to sct as well.  With that, still think patchy dense fog is 
possible this morning (closer to daybreak), especially for areas 
that received earlier rainfall.

Moving on, Independence Day looks like another typical summer-like 
day, albeit with above climo pops/temps.  Given that the ridge is 
flattened to some degree, would expect that subsidence is weakened 
as well, therefore did favor widespread chance pops based on a 
diurnal trend while also including some likely pops over the mtns. 
Profiles are very similar to yesterday featuring weak unidirectional 
winds and thus little/no shear, as well as abundant instability. 
Likewise pwats remain high, generally in the 1.7-1.8 inch range 
thereby favoring efficient rain rates. Overall, think once again 
that general thunderstorms will dominate, however a few 
strong/severe storms cannot be ruled out with damaging winds, small 
hail, frequent lightning, and brief heavy rainfall being the primary 
threats. Generally, temperatures today will be slightly cooler, yet 
still a few degrees above normal levels.

For those firework fans out there, sunset tonight is around 9PM EDT. 
CAM guidance favors decreasing convective coverage in the 8-9PM EDT 
timeframe regionwide, however with perhaps a few residual 
showers/thunderstorms across the mtns as well as the southern 
valley/plateau.

.LONG TERM...(Friday through Wednesday)...
A weak upper trough over the Ohio and Tennessee Valley will 
replace the upper ridge that shifts south to the Gulf Coast by 
Friday. Deeper moisture will move in to the region with southwest 
flow aloft and weak shortwaves ahead of a weak frontal boundary. 
The front will slide across the forecast area by late Sunday. From
northeast to southwest rain chances increase Friday into Saturday
with showers and storms likely Saturday and Sunday. Afternoon and
evening thunderstorms through the weekend may become strong with 
locally heavy rainfall and gusty winds the main threats. No 
organized severe storms expected. The upper ridge then becomes re-
centered farther west across the central states Monday through 
Wednesday. Flow becomes more NW and higher pressure with drier 
airmass moves over the region from the north and northeast early 
next week, especially Tuesday and Wednesday. Rain chances drop to 
chance and then slight chance. Highs will be near normal through 
Sunday, then warm slightly Monday through Wednesday.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
327 PM EDT Wed Jul 3 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Thursday)...

Starting to see some scattered showers/storms across the area early 
this afternoon. The widespread mid to high cloud cover throughout 
much of the day delayed the onset of convection and may limit the 
coverage a bit this afternoon and evening. Despite the cloud cover, 
temperatures currently range from the low 80s to low 90s across most 
locations. Current water vapor imagery and RAP upper air analysis 
indicate a weak shortwave trough moving across the Tennessee River 
Valley. Models indicate a decent 300 mb jet streak across the area 
around 30-50 kts but this jet streak is forecast to weaken 
throughout the evening and overnight hours. Models only indicate 
around 20 kt of 0-6 km bulk shear. SBCAPE values are around 1500-
2000 J/Kg and with lower heights aloft, freezing levels are a bit 
lower than normal. Due to this, not expecting any severe storms but 
do expect a few strong storms will be possible with gusty winds and 
small hail being the main threats. Any ongoing convection should 
come to an end near sunset with the loss of daytime heating. Heat 
indices this afternoon could reach to near 100 for portions of the 
southern and central valley.

Patchy fog will be possible once again tonight but the coverage of 
shower/storms this afternoon/evening will depend on how limited or 
widespread the coverage of fog will be. Lows tonight will generally 
range from the mid 60s to low 70s.

Upper level heights will increase tomorrow as the trough weakens and 
slides to the east. The Bermuda high over the Atlantic becomes more 
established with weak southerly flow across the area. This will lead 
to some upslope flow across western North Carolina and into portions 
of the East Tennessee Mountains. For now, think the best chances for 
showers/storms on Independence Day will be across the higher 
elevations of East Tennessee. PW values and dewpoints remain 
elevated but with the lack of any synoptic or surface lift, have 
decreased PoPs slightly for the valley. High temperatures will top 
out in the upper 80s to low 90s for most locations with heat indices 
in the mid to upper 90s for most of the central and southern
valley.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday night through Wednesday)...

Convection should become a little more widespread across the 
Southern Appalachian region as we move into the weekend. Upper 
level troughing will gradually replace the ridge that has been in 
place through much of the week. Moisture will increase across the 
region on deepening southwest flow. The moisture will be lifted in
the presence of several weak waves of low pressure. Eventually a 
slow moving long wave trough will develop Saturday into Sunday and
the mean west to northwest flow pattern with this feature will 
drag a weak cool front south of the forecast area later Sunday 
evening. Utilized a likely probability for showers and 
thunderstorms over the weekend in this scenario. Atmospheric 
buoyancy will become thermonuclear during this timeframe, but 
shear will be almost non-existent, so the threat for severe 
convection will be limited to isolated downbursts in the most well
developed cells. In the superblend broadbrush scheme, maintained 
a small chance for a continuation of some convection in the heat 
of the day on Monday. The continuation may work out due to the 
possibility that the synoptic front doesn't make it all the way 
south through the forecast area. However, Monday may be drier than
currently forecast. Went ahead and dropped pops for most of the 
area on Tuesday in a drier and more stable environment behind the 
front. Forecast uncertainty required using the possibility of some
thunderstorm development on Wednesday with a hint of an impulse 
dropping into the area out of the Upper Midwest. High temperatures
start out a little above normal on Thursday, but pulled back a 
few degrees over the weekend period due to less insolation and 
greater coverage of thunderstorms.

during the period, am expecting generally only airmass type

exhibit weak capping regionwide, however given ample insolation am 
expecting convective temperatures to be achieved, especially across 
the central/southern valley as well as the plateau.  As for threats,

the valley. By mid week and continuing through the rest of the 
period...a series of short waves tracking through the upper flow 
will slowly begin to flatten or at least dampen the ridge. This 
will translate to slightly cooler temperatures and an increase in 
the chance of convection. Throughout the extended there is little 
synoptic support but with strong diurnal heating...expect the 
afternoon atmosphere to become at least weakly unstable. Low level
shear should be fairly weak through the period but air should 
should remain quite moist. Therefore...expect at least scattered 
convection each day with best chance over higher terrain. Do not 
see any significant organization to the convection and do not see 
the potential for a serous severe weather day but any day could 
see scattered...pulse type storms that could reach strong to 
severe levels.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
335 PM EDT Sun Jun 30 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Monday)...
Late tonight, shortwave passes with the trough axis shifting
eastward. This brings subsidence across northeast portions of the
forecast area, generally north and east of Knoxville and allow 
high clouds to clear with ideal conditions for low clouds and fog 
to develop. Dynamic and statistical guidance is in agreement with 
this, but magnitude of fog should depend on how quickly the 
subsidence and drying aloft occurs. At this time, best clearing 
appears to be after 08-09z. Highest probability for fog will be in
areas that receive afternoon rainfall and near rivers.

On Monday, subsidence results in an inversion between 700-800mb 
across NE TN and SW VA which should act as a cap to convection. 
Still could have an isolated shower or thunderstorm if anything 
manages to break through the cap, but with the synoptic subsidence
and drier boundary layer air, believe most of NE TN and SW VA 
should remain dry. South and west of Knoxville where the cap is 
weak to nonexistent, there will be a higher probability of a few 
localized showers or thunderstorms, but synoptic forcing remains 
weak. NAM and RAP forecast soundings are showing up to 2000-2500 
J/Kg MLCAPE, but with weak flow along the deformation axis, 
effective bulk shear remains weak at approximately 10kt. This 
will support pulse convection capable of some strong downburst 
winds with the strongest thunderstorms across SE TN and SW NC. 
Will also have to monitor convection across the Upper Midwest as 
it rounds the ridge and dives south toward the Tennessee Valley. 
Remnant convection or outflow boundaries could play an important 
role in initiating convection on Monday afternoon. High-res CAMs 
are not in good agreement with the overall coverage and timing of 
convection Monday afternoon, but they do generally show the 
potential for remnant convective complexes or MCVs across the 
Midwest to dive south and potentially enhance our convective 
coverage. Because of the uncertainty of timing and location, will 
remain with slight chance and chance PoPs for SE TN and SW NC. 
Temperatures should be warm once again, especially across the 
southern valley as ridging begin to increase as we continue into 
the middle of the week.


.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Sunday)...
Relatively typical summer time pattern will set up for the first 
part of the extended portion of this forecast. Ridging over the 
Southeastern United States will be the dominant feature, leading 
to warm temperatures and isolated afternoon showers and 
thunderstorms. 

Temperatures will likely be able to climb into the 90's in the 
central/southern portions of the Valley through Thursday with Heat 
Index's climbing into the upper 90's in some locations these days. 
With these warm temperatures and moisture trapped under the ridge we 
should see some isolated showers develop in the afternoon hours. 
There is no major source of synoptic forcing for these storms to 
work with so am currently expecting any storms that develop the 
first half of this week to be the typical diurnally driven summer 
thunderstorms... Can't rule out the possibilty that a stray storm 
gets strong, but at this time widespread severe weather looks 
unlikely. 

Ridge looks to broaden out and weaken a bit as we move into the 
second half of the work week towards the weekend. This looks like it 
may allow a few weak ripples of energy to move near the area 
increasing the chances for more widespread precipitation. This 
weakening  of the ridge will also help to cool temperatures off a 
bit, bringing them closer to normal values over the weekend.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
309 AM EDT Sun Jun 30 2019

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...Any areas of fog that develop late 
tonight should lift by mid morning. The main weather feature for 
the short term will be a weakening and rather diffuse frontal 
boundary settling southward into the area this afternoon. The air 
mass in place will become increasing unstable as the front 
approaches. ML CAPEs should increase to 2000 to 3000 J/Kg with 
DCAPE becoming 1000 to 2000 J/KG and PWs are generally between 1.5
to 2 inches. As the front moves in...weak low level shear will 
develop mainly over northern locations. What all of this should 
translate to is an increased chance of thunderstorms this 
afternoon...they may become a bit more organized along/ahead of 
the boundary though convection will still be rather pulsy. 
Depending on the model...mid levels show some degree of drying. 
The overall threat of the convection will be a slightly greater 
chance of strong winds...the potential for heavy rainfall remains 
a threat and the chance of large hail is limited. The front will 
continue to weaken as it makes it way south through the area. 
Convection should decrease and weaken after sunset but do expect 
the potential for lingering convection to continue through much of
the night mainly over higher elevations.


.LONG TERM (Monday through Saturday)...The biggest issue for this 
forecast period is the heat.  Max Temps each day will be 90s in the 
valley at most locations, and due to high dewpoints (muggy 
conditions), Heat Index values look to be about 5-7 degrees warmer 
than the air temp--near or above 100 degrees over the central and 
southern valley each day.  

At the beginning of this period (Monday morning), the upper ridge 
will still be in place.  Weak surface high pressure will be in place 
as well.  Overall, the upper heights this week look a little higher 
than the models did 24 hours ago.  The ridge almost looks like it 
weakens, but actually it is the weakening of the troughs on either 
side with heights holding or rising in the latter half of the week. 
So even though the center of the ridge works south of us, it looks 
like it will have a strong influence over us all week.  There will 
be chances of shortwaves riding through the area that could promote 
better chances of convection. Toward the end of the period, it looks 
like better chances of shortwaves being able to cut into the upper 
ridge to get better chances of showers and storms. Max temps by then 
also look like they may edge a few degrees lower, but dewpoints 
might be edging a little higher as the return flow from the Gulf 
sluggishly gets more established.  So in a couple of words--hot and 
steamy for this Holiday week.

National Weather Service Morristown TN
308 PM EDT Sat Jun 29 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Sunday)...

Isolated thunderstorm activity is expected to decrease this
evening and overnight as atmospheric stability increases.
Locations that received rainfall this afternoon and sheltered 
river valleys will likely see fog development again with a mostly 
clear sky and calm wind.

Between 09z and 15z Sunday, a weak shortwave is forecast to move
through the area around the Northeast CONUS cyclone. Upper level
winds shift to the NW behind this shortwave with drier air
advection and shortwave ridging for Sunday afternoon. This results
in forecast soundings from the NAM, and a more limited magnitude
from the GFS, being very dry above 700mb. A back door surface cold
front will move southwestward across the Mid-Atlantic and approach
SW VA late Sunday and Sunday night. While the primary area of
surface convergence and instability will be across NE TN and SW
VA, have doubt about overall coverage of precipitation if the
atmosphere is as dry as guidance such as the NAM and RAP 
indicate. However, instability will be relatively high with the 
NAM placing 2000-3000 J/kg ML CAPE across the forecast area during
the afternoon. Additionally, weak effective deep layer shear 
approximately 10kt and plentiful low-level moisture will favor
ordinary pulse convection that does develop. With what isolated 
convection does form, DCAPE will be high and downdrafts would 
likely be the main hazard.


.LONG TERM...(Sunday night through Saturday)...

At the start of the extended, a large portion of the CONUS will be 
dominated by upper level ridging. A shortwave moving off the New 
England coast will allow the ridge axis to build into the Ohio and 
Tennessee valley. At the surface high pressure will be in control 
with light winds. Diurnally driven convection will be possible 
Sunday night and Tuesday but coverage looks isolated to scattered at 
best. Temperatures will be near to above average through this time 
as 850mb temperatures increase to near 20-21 degrees C. The warmest 
days should be Monday and Tuesday with heat index values increasing 
as well. By mid week, upper level low moving southward out of the 
northern Canadian provinces is forecast to flatten the ridge a bit 
with lowering heights across the region. Developing low pressure 
across the plains will veer low level winds to the south and west. 
Obvious differences are still apparent in global models with the 
ECMWF holding the ridge a bit stronger through mid to late week. 
This will ultimately have implications on PoPs but the consensus is 
that chances of showers and thunderstorms will be increasing with 
maximum chances during the diurnally favored times. Widespread 
severe weather looks very low but cannot rule out strong to possibly 
a severe pulse storm or two. The weekend period shows low confidence 
as previous model runs showed differences in the strength of the 
ridge.  A weak shortwave trough is advertised to drop out of the 
Ohio valley during the weekend with increased PoPs associated with 
this feature.

Weak flow continues on Saturday with the upper low over the lower
Mississippi Valley retrograding southwestward and an increasing
thermal ridge as we remain in very weak flow. This should limit
PoPs relative to Friday afternoon with lower instability, weaker
mid-level lapse rates, and continued low shear in this very weak
flow. Ordinary pulse convection would still be the favored mode
with MLCAPE of 1000 to 1500 J/Kg and effective bulk shear of
approximately 10kt. With these values, have the potential of a few
thunderstorms, some strong with gusty winds, primarily across the
higher elevations.


.LONG TERM...(Saturday night through Friday)...
On Saturday we will still be situated between a couple of upper 
level lows. One will be across the Texas coast while the other one 
remains north of the Great Lakes region. We will continue to get 
some moderate moisture inflow from the Gulf of Mexico under this 
regime, combine this with continued warm temperatures we will likely 
see isolated diurnal showers and thunderstorms each day over the 
weekend. Severe parameters don't particularly line up well for long 
lived or wide-spread storms, but can't rule out a few strong to 
severe storms popping up each afternoon.

High pressure will increase as we move into the workweek with 
temperatures expected to climb into the lower 90's and upper 80's 
through out the week. Best chance for more widespread rain may come 
during the middle of the week, depending on which model you believe. 
GFS wants to position the ridge slightly east compared to the ECMWF, 
which will help to bring in more moisture the Tennessee Valley under 
the ridge. This would lead to decent chances for widespread 
precipitation... While the ECWF want to keep the ridge a little 
further to the west meaning that less moisture will be available for 
potential storms to work with. Shower and thunderstorm chances will 
continue each afternoon through the rest of the work week as we 
remain under the influence of the upper level ridge.

more local areas of development are possible along any residual 
outflow boundaries from previous overnight convection. As these 
thunderstorms collapse and produce their own outflow boundaries, 
additional isolated thunderstorm development is possible across
the valley later this afternoon and evening. Severe weather is not
anticipated because of the weak flow and storm mode; however, a
few isolated thunderstorms may become marginally severe with 
strong downburst winds due to the drier air and high DCAPE across
the southern half of the forecast area.

Made some minor adjustments to temperatures by increasing most 
areas a degree or two based on current observations, low-level 
heights, and yesterday's max temperatures. Otherwise, forecast is 
progressing as expected.

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...A stray isolated thunderstorm

southeastern U.S. with surface high pressure dominating the lower
levels. This pattern will continue to bring low level moisture and
warm air into the area. The air mass will destabilize this
afternoon with DCAPE reaching near 1000 J/kg and steepening low-
level lapse rates. All of this will combine to create a weakly
unstable atmosphere. With strong diurnal heating this
afternoon...expect convection to develop across the area. The
initial round of new convection should form over higher
elevations. As boundaries from these storms move into the
valley...they along with any lingering boundaries will add focus
for additional afternoon convection. Coverage should be a bit more
widespread than previous days. With deep low level moisture in
place...the main threat will be heavy rainfall. However...a stray
strong to severe storm can not be ruled out with storms creating
strong winds...frequent lightning and possibly large hail.
Convection will continue into the evening hours...but should
eventually dissipate after sunset and much of Friday night should
be quiet. 

.LONG TERM (Friday through Thursday)...By 12Z Saturday, an upper 
level low will be situated across the northwestern GoM while a 
shortwave trough moves southeast out of Canada and into New 
England. Further upstream, upper level ridging will be located 
across the desert southwest into the northern plains with ridging 
also extending into the western Atlantic. At the surface, high 
pressure will be located across the mid-Atlantic with lower 
pressure located across the northern plains. The region will be in
this upper level regime through the weekend with surface high 
pressure situated across the Tennessee valley. Diurnally driven 
convection will be possible on Saturday and Sunday given the very 
unstable airmass. This will be especially true across southwest 
Virginia as the tail end of a front approaches. While mid level 
lapse rates will be weak given the lack of synoptic scale features
nearby, low level lapse rates will likely be large given the 
degree of near boundary layer heating. A few strong storms cannot 
be ruled out but should remain isolated in nature. 

Upper level ridging intensifies on Monday with generally 
anticyclonic flow through much of the US. This will place the region 
in a northerly to northwest flow aloft. Will carry slight chance 
PoPs through Tuesday to highlight potential of diurnally driven 
convection. Temperatures this weekend and early next week look to 
remain near to slightly above normal. Heat indices will likely 
approach the mid to upper 90s Monday and Tuesday afternoon. 

By the middle of next week, models begin to diverge a bit. The GFS 
indicates the ridge axis to move eastward while an upper level low 
moves out of the southern plains. The ECMWF holds the ridge axis 
over much of the Tennessee valley. Nonetheless, a surface low will 
likely develop lee of the Rockies and move into the midwest and into 
the Ohio valley by Thursday morning. With low pressure to the west, 
and high pressure to the east, southwesterly flow will commence 
Wednesday aiding in moisture advection. This along with at least 
weak synoptic scale forcing should promote chance PoPs Wednesday 
into Wednesday night. Kept chance PoPs in through Friday as a couple 
of upper level disturbances could generate additional SHRA/TSRA 
through the end of the extended period. Temperatures will stay near 
to above average.

rainfall Thursday evening.

an upper trough diving southeastward across the Northeast and Mid-

approach our SW VA and NE TN counties. This will lead to our highest 
chance PoPs across NE TN and SW VA on Sunday afternoon through 
Tuesday as the front lingers in this area. With near normal heights 
and no widespread convection forecast, temperatures should be near 
or slightly above normal through the weekend.

Guidance is in good agreement with ridging building in midweek next 
week, and this is likely to favor above normal temperatures next 
week through the Independence Day holiday. Main forcing for 
developing convection would be afternoon differential heating along 
the higher terrain.

FXUS64 KMRX 260648
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
248 AM EDT Wed Jun 26 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...Surface high pressure and a 
broad mid/upper level ridge building over the region will dominate 
our weather for the short term.  We will see some high clouds around 
especially today, but overall expect a mostly sunny day and a mostly 
clear night tonight.  Temperatures today will be just slightly above 
normal for this time of year, and humidity levels will not be 
oppressive.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Tuesday)...High pressure will be in 
control across the Southern Appalachian Region as the extended 
period begins.  Thursday into Friday this high will slowly shift 
eastward...placing the MRX CWA under southerly flow and allowing low 
level moisture and slightly warmer air to filter in.  This combined 
with strong diurnal heating will generate isolated convection mainly 
over higher elevations on Thursday.  Coverage will slightly increase 
on Friday.  By Saturday....this air mass will be at least weakly 
unstable with increasing moisture in place. This will allow the 
chance of shower and thunderstorm activity to expand across the 
entire area...though the best probability will remain over higher 
terrain.  Around the Sunday/Monday time frame...a weakening frontal 
boundary will settle southward and into the region.  Timing and 
strength of this feature remains in question but this should add a 
little lift across the area allowing for more widespread and a bit 
more organized convection.  By Tuesday... remnants of the boundary 
should be lifting slightly north though potentially a few residual 
outflow boundaries may remain over the region.  As a result...good 
diurnal heating should be sufficient for some additional convective 
develop Tuesday afternoon.  So overall...it should be an unsettled 
extended period.  Temperatures should warm to normal levels if not a 
bit above normal throughout the period.

025 
FXUS64 KMRX 251843
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
243 PM EDT Tue Jun 25 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Wednesday)...
High pressure from the surface through the midlevels will dominate
the weather pattern through the period. With calm wind and clear
skies, fog will be a concern tonight. So far this afternoon, 
dewpoints have not dropped much across the area, holding in the
mid 60s despite boundary layer mixing. This suggests that fog will
be more prevalent than just near rivers and lakes, so will mention
patchy fog everywhere. Dense fog may be isolated to bodies of
water, and confidence in greater coverage is too low to warrant an
advisory at this time, but it will bear watching. Tomorrow will be
mostly sunny and rain-free with highs in the mid 80s to around 
90.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday night through Tuesday)...
A typical early summer pattern will be in place through early 
next week with primarily zonal flow gradually transitioning to 
more ridging and above normal temperatures.

A surface high will be shifting east toward the Mid Atlantic 
Wednesday night and Thursday which will allow return southerly flow 
and WAA to begin. Mid level heights will correspondingly rise to 590-
592 DAM at this time, so expect highs around 90 to return to the 
southern valley Thursday with mid to upper 80's elsewhere. All areas 
will see upper 80's to near 90 Friday. The increasing heat and 
humidity will allow for some diurnal convection Thursday and Friday 
afternoons as MUCAPES look to be in the 2000-3000 J/Kg range, but 
some thermal capping should limit coverage to southeast TN and the 
eastern mountains.  

Similarly hot and humid conditions will continue this weekend, but 
the coverage of afternoon/evening convection will be greater as the 
TN valley becomes squeezed between a sharpening upper ridge in the 
Plains and Midwest and digging upper trough in New England. This 
will cause a weak cold front in the vicinity of the OH valley to 
slowly sag southward toward our region. Any outflow boundaries from 
convection tied to this front will spark an increase in diurnal 
convection across east TN, southwest VA, and southwest NC, and some 
subtle cooling aloft will result in a weaker cap too. Shear 
parameters are very weak, so no organized severe weather is 
expected. Locally heavy rain will occur in any thunderstorm since 
PWAT values will once again be high at 1.30-1.80 inches.

The above mentioned front will remain in tne region Monday with 
chance pops for showers/storms continuing. Both the ECMWF and GFS 
are in good agreement on this. The old front will lift back north 
Tuesday bringing a lower chance of convection as the Midwest upper 
ridge axis builds a bit farther east. Still maintained slight chance 
to chance pops at this time for diurnal convection. Temps will 
continue above normal.

National Weather Service Morristown TN

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Tuesday)...Through the afternoon and 
evening, a line of strong to severe storms will cross from east to
west across the area. With the amount of sunshine that has 
occurred across much of the TN Valley, and with dewpoints in the 
upper 60s to lower 70s, there will be a good amount of instabilty 
in the pre-storm environment. Gusty winds so far indicate a more 
dynamic environment than the past few days as well, and downdrafts
will transport strong winds aloft to the surface. The activity is
expected to exit to the east around 00-01Z. The zone forecast 
will include a late afternoon period to account for this timing. 
Dry air in the mid levels builds in quickly but low level moisture
may linger and allow for some cloudy skies overnight. Winds 
should provide enough mixing to prevent widespread fog. Surface 
high pressure will be building over the area tomorrow, with a dry 
westerly flow aloft that will provide mostly sunny skies and highs
in the mid to upper 80s.

.LONG TERM (Tuesday night through Monday)...Finally, slightly
drier air will build into the Southern Appalachian region in the
wake of a departing upper trough. The sub-tropical high will
slowly build across the region through much of the remainder of
the work week which should help to limit diurnal convection to the
higher terrain features. A weakness will gradually develop in the
ridge pattern over the Lower Mississippi Valley. A light southerly
component to the low level flow may help to moisten the local
Southern Appalachian atmosphere Friday into Saturday allowing for
a little higher chance probability for showers and thunderstorms.
However, the best chance of more widespread convection may occur
toward the end of the extended period Sunday into Sunday night as
a back door frontal boundary slips into the region as an unusually
strong upper trough drops southeast across the Northeastern U.S.
Temperatures will be seasonably warm through the forecast period.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
317 AM EDT Mon Jun 24 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...A short wave will be lifting out 
of the Mississippi Valley and into the Great Lakes Region today, and 
a weak cold front will be pushing through our area late today and 
exiting this evening. Convection is expected to form ahead of this 
frontal boundary and push through our area this afternoon/early 
evening. Models still showing decent lapse rates with MLCAPE values 
in excess of 2000 possible, and 0-6 km shear values in excess of 30 
kts are forecast which will enhace potential storm organization and 
severe potential.  Will continue to have strong to severe storms 
included in the HWO for today with damaging winds and hail the 
primary threats.  There may be some lingering convection especially 
eastern parts of the area early tonight depending on exact timing of 
the front, then drier air will be moving in bringing and end to the 
precipitation.  Winds will be gusty from the southwest across the 
area this afternoon, and temperatures are forecast to be withing a 
few degrees of seasonal normals. 

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Monday)...For Tuesday, surface 
ridging will be over the southern Appalachians with drier air 
across the region.

For Wednesday and Thursday, surface ridging will remain but a weak 
upper trough over the lower Mississippi valley will begin to pull 
moisture back into southeast Tennessee and southwest North Carolina 
producing mainly diurnal (afternoon/evening) convection. Main 
forcing will be terrain features.

For Friday into next weekend, upper ridging develops over the Plains 
with unseasonably deep upper trough over the northeast/mid-Atlantic 
region. Moisture and instability pulls back north into the southern 
Appalachians with increasing coverage and intensity of the showers 
and thunderstorms each day. Again, main forcing for Friday and 
Saturday will be local terrain features with activity spreading into 
the valley during the day.  For Sunday, a back door front may move 
into the region but confidence is low on this feature.

973 
FXUS64 KMRX 231917
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
317 PM EDT Sun Jun 23 2019

.SHORT TERM (Tonight through Monday tonight)...
Ample instability south of a warm frontal boundary that is lifting 
across the area has led to some strong storms developing over the 
southern Plateau. With the boundary well north and little synoptic 
forcing, this activity should dissipate with sunset. Overnight, fog 
may develop again in areas that received rain or near bodies of 
water, but dense fog should remain fairly isolated. 

A shortwave trough with a slight negative tilt will be crossing the 
MS River tomorrow morning, with its attendant cold front moving into 
Middle TN in the afternoon. Convection ahead of this front is 
expected to move into our area in the 18-20Z time frame, according 
to the HREF members. Much like today, MLCAPE will be in the 
neighborhood of 2500 J/kg; however there will be better deep shear 
tomorrow compared to today, around 30 kts in the 0-6 km layer, so 
storms should have better organization and severe potential. With 
the shear being mainly unidirectional, a QLCS or squall line is 
expected to be the main mode of convection, posing a threat of 
damaging winds. This line should be on our eastern border around 
00Z, with the frontal passage soon after bringing an end to all 
precip chances.

.LONG TERM (Tuesday through Sunday)... 
After the anomalously strong Mid America upper trough slips 
northeast through the Eastern Lakes and New England, there won't 
be enough northwesterly flow to dry out the Southeastern U.S. in 
the middle of the work week. Relatively high dewpoint air will 
hang around the Southern Appalachian region with more than enough 
insolation to create some instabilty for the development of widely
scattered convection, mainly on the higher terrain features. 
Maintained the concept of gradually increasing pops Friday into 
Saturday in the presence of a developing weak upper low over the 
Lower Mississippi Valley and associated slight increase in 
moisture off the Gulf of Mexico. Perhaps the highest probability 
for more widespread convection would occur on Sunday with the 
Canadian, European, and American models showing another unusually 
amplified upper trough building south across the northeastern 
quarter of the nation. In this scenario, the strong feature would 
be associated with a healthy backdoor cool front which should be 
more than adequate to lift a broad pattern of showers and 
thunderstorms into existence across the Southern Appalachians. 
Again, the temperature forecast will be near normal through the 
extended period.

FXUS64 KMRX 211933

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
333 PM EDT Fri Jun 21 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Saturday)...
The main weather story tonight and Saturday will be the potential
rounds of strong to severe thunderstorms. Much of the risk 
associated with the Saturday evening severe potential will be 
conditional on the first round tonight through Saturday morning.

For tonight, ridge axis will be to our west across the 
Mississippi Valley with an upper low across the Northeast and 
another upper low across the Rocky Mountains. SW low level flow 
will increase with positive theta-e advection and a warm front 
moving northeastward across the forecast area. In addition, a 
small shortwave and 500mb jet streak will enhance ascent and cool 
mid- levels. This will result in the unique situation where 
instability actually increases overnight from sunset to sunrise. 

An MCS complex currently across southern IL and southeast MO is 
forecast to move ESE/SE toward our area and move along the warm 
front boundary tonight. With increasing instability through the 
night and effective deep layer shear of about 30kt, mesoscale 
conditions will be favorable to maintaining a marginal to slight 
severe wind threat as thunderstorms move into our area, especially
across western portions of the forecast area (generally west of 
Knoxville across the Cumberland Plateau). Timing is still 
uncertain, but currently believe the HRRR has the better solution 
with arrival along the Cumberland Plateau about 03z to 04z. The 
HRRR initialization has done well this morning and has been 
consistent for the past several runs with its timing. Am cautious 
to trust the High-Res NAM since it did not resolve the convection 
and cold pool very well across NE MO at 12z this morning. The GFS 
and NAM are also much slower with PoPs tonight, but this would be 
expected as they may not be resolving the forward propagation and 
quicker movement of the MCS as compared to the mean layer flow. 
Thunderstorms will be moving very quickly southeast, so they are 
expected to move through and exit the area within about 3 hours. 
An additional complex of thunderstorms may develop along the warm 
front behind this original MCS and move southeast toward our area 
and affect us near sunrise on Saturday. A lot of questions still 
exist about the environment behind the first MCS, but there should
be enough elevated instability to support thunderstorms Saturday 
morning. Temperatures should be near or above normal tonight as 
cloud cover and southwest flow increases.

We should see a relative break in convection midday Saturday
before additional thunderstorms are likely on Saturday afternoon.
However, the severe threat Saturday afternoon is conditional on
the environment from convection early Saturday morning and how
much afternoon clearing we are able to receive. The NAM is showing
very high instability across our region with MLCAPE of 4000-5000
J/Kg, very rare for the Southern Appalachians. The GFS has lower
levels of instability on Saturday afternoon with MLCAPE of
1500-2000 J/Kg, but these are still high values for the GFS. An
important reason that the NAM has much higher instability is
because it does not have the expected early morning convection
across the area. An upper shortwave/MCV is expected to move south
from the Ohio Valley Saturday afternoon enhancing ascent and 
supporting additional convection in this unstable environment.
Effective deep layer bulk shear is not very high, only about
20-25kt, but will be sufficient to support multicell convection. Once
again, damaging winds would be the primary hazard with an 
isolated hail threat. Localized flash flooding will be another 
hazard to monitor with increasing PW values near 1.8 inches, 
approximately the 90th percentile. Southwest flow perpendicular to
outflow/cold pools could result in convergence and training 
thunderstorms with heavy rainfall. Afternoon temperatures are 
expected to be near guidance but will be dependent upon convective
debris cloud cover during the day.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday night through Friday)...
A couple of convective complexes are projected in model depiction
to pass southeast along the Southeastern U.S. instability 
gradient across the mrx forecast area. These features will have 
some rather significant cape available for buoyancy however, 0-6km
bulk shear magnitude will be limited to about 15-20 kts. 
Therefore, possibility of severe convection a bit limited, 
therefore severe thunderstorm development appears to be isolated 
at this time. After a brief break in the action, a relatively 
significant upper trough will be driving northeast across the 
Upper Midwest. The probability of showers and thunderstorms cranks
up again Monday into Monday night ahead of the surface cool front
associated with this upper feature. Held onto a slight chance for
convection on Tuesday for possible slower departure of this early
week system. Model uncertainty increases through the last part of
the extended forecast but, it appears there will be little chance
for convection Wednesday and possibly Thursday. Added a small 
chance of a couple showers and thunderstorms on Friday due to the 
possibilty of increasing moisture and instability in association 
with an area of low pressure over the Lower Mississippi Valley. 
Temperatures through the period will be very close to seasonal 
norms for late June.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
329 PM EDT Thu Jun 20 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Friday)...

The main concern for the short term period is convective potential
through the evening hours. SHRA/TSRA ahead of a front has
developed across middle Tennessee in a moist and unstable
environment. LAPS analysis shows SBCAPE values in excess of
2000j/kg with dewpoints in the upper 60s. The HRRR has shown this
coverage well and continues to develop scattered convection this
evening. Further north across southern Kentucky and northern
Tennessee, convection is developing along the front where better 
moisture convergence in occurring. 

Given the convective parameters, and increased shear due to an
upper level jet, strong to severe storms are still possible
through the afternoon and evening. Main threats will be damaging
winds, and hail. With the shortwave trough exiting the area
tonight, convection will exit as well. Drier air filtering in
behind the front should begin to clear skies overnight. Friday, a
surface ridge will bring tranquil weather conditions to the area.
A lifting warm front will move into parts of the area by Friday 
afternoon. As a result high temperatures should be a couple 
degrees warmer with daytime highs in the mid to upper 80s over 
most of the area. 

.LONG TERM...(Friday night through Thursday)...

The extended period kicks off on Friday evening amidst deep ridging 
across the southeast states with the ridge axis centered over the 
MidSouth region, thus favoring weak nwly flow aloft into the TN 
Valley and Southern Appalachians.  Guidance continues to suggest 
multiple rounds of MCS activity firing across the Kentuckiana region 
along the theta-e ridge.  Models (GFS/ECMWF) seem to be in better 
agreement with regard to mean layer flow suggesting one or more of 
these MCSs tracking across KY into east TN, southwest VA, and 
eventually southwest NC.  The first of these MCSs looks to arrive 
mid/late morning Saturday which depending on heating/instability, 
could favor a round of strong/severe convection, which is supported 
by fcst soundings with steep lapse rates and thus large/deep cape 
profiles.  Given this scenario playing out, would expect elevated 
chances for damaging winds and large hail. The second MCS looks to 
move in from the northwest overnight into Sunday morning, which 
based on timing would suggest a less unstable environment for deep 
convection.  That said, confidence is still marginal as the NAM 
continues to suggest abundant subsidence amidst the deep ridge 
keeping the vast majority of any MCS activity generally confined 
across extreme northeast TN and southwest VA, therefore essentially 
just glancing the forecast area.  Because of this, kept pops in the 
mid/high chance range for much of the area on Saturday with only low 
end likely pops featured over the above noted regions.  Into Sunday, 
once again pops are highest across northeast TN and southwest VA 
given the most favorable model MCS forecast tracks, but confined to 
only mid/high chances at best.  

Pops will taper late Sunday into Monday morning as the upper ridge 
axis slides east atop the region, eventually moving over the 
Carolinas by mid/late day.  Meanwhile, a northern stream trough will 
eject from the Rockies into the Plains with cyclogenesis to occur 
beneath, and a surface cold front draped southward across the 
mid/lower MS and OH Valleys.  At this point the operational guidance 
tends to diverge a bit as the GFS favors a more progressive track of 
the upper wave into the Midwest and eventually the Great Lakes into 
Tuesday, thus surging the cold front into the TN Valley Monday 
evening.  This solution would support a fairly wet pattern for 
Monday.  On the other hand, the ECMWF features slower progression of 
the upper trough leading to a delayed fropa (relative to the GFS) 
Tuesday afternoon/evening, thereby favoring only diurnal prefrontal 
convection on Monday.  All said, the start of the work week looks 
somewhat active therefore the fcst will generally feature mid/high 
chance pops.  Beyond that for Wednesday/Thursday, am expecting at 
least 1-2 drier days amidst nwly flow and high pressure. 
Temperatures through the entire period will generally be near a 
category above normal levels, especially by next week.&&

FXUS64 KMRX 200748
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
348 AM EDT Thu Jun 20 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

If I'm honest I don't have a high degree of confidence in the
forecast through midday or so. Currently there's a linear MCS
moving east through middle Tennessee and northern Alabama, with
scattered convection well out ahead of it across parts of the
northern Tennessee Valley and southwest Virginia. Most, if not
all, of the CAM guidance wants to completely dissipate the middle
TN convection and really shove rainfall through the daybreak or 
mid morning hours north to the KY/TN/VA border region. This would 
pose at least some risk of flash flooding as rain rates have been 
pretty good with overnight convection and any training of storms 
would certainly lead to some excessive rainfall in spots. However,
the uncertainty with all of this is that a lot of that same 
guidance is not currently modeling that line of storms well at 
all, and lesser resolution models such as the NAM, have virtually 
no signal of it whatsoever. So, with that said, trended towards 
some earlier runs of the RAP, which had the line weakening while 
moving east through TN (south of I-40) but not completely 
dissipating. Then, through the mid/late morning hours the RAP 
ramped up thunderstorm coverage across the CWA before dissipating 
things in the late afternoon hours. Conceptually, upper level
support favors that northern track for storms/rainfall. But the
current mishandling of that line of storms leads me to believe
there's enough confidence to go higher across the south as well,
thus the trending towards the 03z-05z runs of the RAP model.

Otherwise, convective trends should take a notable downward turn
during the late afternoon hours. An upper trough, currently
crossing the Mississippi river this morning, will rotate through
the area this afternoon and be east of the Appalachians in the
5-8pm range today. Some lingering showers will likely continue in
the wake of this trough, but expect rainfall to rapidly begin to
wind down after 5pm or so. Clearing skies should allow for lows to
fall into the mid or even low 60s tonight.

.LONG TERM...(Friday through Thursday)...

Active weather pattern continues through much of the extended 
forecast with a fairly amplified and progressive upper flow. End 
result will be bouts of convection, some strong to severe. Lets get 
to the particulars.

For Friday, ridging surface and aloft will PWs fairly dry for mid to 
late June. Low level inversion will also help to inhibit convective 
development. A very warm day is in store.

For Friday night into Saturday, models agree with a vigorous MCS 
developing over the mid-west late Friday and Friday night, then 
moving southeast toward the southern Appalachians/east Tennessee 
valley. This MCS and associated MCV will be feed by southwesterly 
boundary layer jet enhancing isentropic lift. Timing of this MCS 
into the region is different between models, however, they agree 
with a moderately unstable airmass as mid-level lapse rates steepen.
Strong gusty winds, potentially damaging, hail up to quarter size 
and torrential rainfall are possible.

A break in the convection is likely in the wake of the storms 
Saturday.

For Saturday night and Sunday, the GFS and ECMWF suggest another MCS 
will develop over the Ohio valley and ridge southeast into the 
region. Models do not show as steep mid-level lapse rates reducing 
the CAPES some, but still heavy rainfall and strong/gusty winds are 
anticipated.

For Monday and Tuesday, an upper trough finally kicks out across the 
Plains to the Great Lakes/Ohio Valley increasing the dynamics over 
the area for Monday night and Tuesday. Frontal boundary moves 
through Tuesday afternoon.

FXUS64 KMRX 191932
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
332 PM EDT Wed Jun 19 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Thursday)...

Two primary topics to discuss in the short term forecast period: 
convection potential, and increasing gradient winds on Thursday.
Large scale troughing will be the main driver of surface weather
tonight through Thursday. Currently, area radars show SHRA/TSRA
beginning to develop likely associated with large scale forcing
for ascent due to shortwave troughing moving out of the central
plains and into the Ohio valley and solar heating in a moist and 
unstable boundary layer. LAPS analysis indicates CAPE values 
approaching 2000 j/kg while surface dewpoints range from the upper
60s to low 70s. The latest CAMs show the current convective 
coverage well, and moves SHRA/TSRA east through the region by this
evening. Limited shear and weak lapse rates should keep potential
of severe weather limited this evening but cannot rule out a 
strong storm or two. 

Convective coverage should begin to decrease as we move into the 
overnight period with the loss of daytime heating. However, by 06Z
tonight, upper level forcing for ascent is forecast to strengthen
as a shortwave propogates into the Ohio and Tennessee valley. At 
the surface, an area of low pressure will be located across 
central Indiana with a trailing cold front extending through 
central Kentucky, western Tennessee, and south central Arkansas. 
The increased synoptic forcing along with increasing moisture 
convergence from a low level jet should allow convective coverage 
to increase toward the west in western/central Tennessee. This 
activity will spread eastward overnight and should begin to move 
into the area by morning. By 21Z Thursday, the cold front will be 
located just to the north of the Tennessee/Kentucky state line and
should help to redevelop convection across the area. Favorable 
parameters for strong to possibly severe storms are depicting in 
model guidance with H7-H5 lapse rates of around 6.0 C/km, 35-45kts
of 0-6km shear, and at least 1500 j/kg of CAPE. Large hail and 
damaging winds would be the main threats with any strong to 
marginally severe thunderstorms. 

The other topic for Thursday are increasing gradient winds due to
an increase in the low level jet. Some of this should be able to 
mix to the surface with gusts upwards of 20-30 mph at times. 
Temperatures should remain near to slightly above normal. 

.LONG TERM...(Thursday night through Wednesday)...

The extended fcst period kicks off on Thursday evening amidst the 
passage of an H5 trough atop the Appalachians, while a surface cold 
front advects into the OH/TN Valleys.  With that, some residual 
shower/thunderstorm activity from earlier in the day is expected to 
continue into the early/mid evening hours before any supportive 
upper dynamics advect east and drier air spills in behind the front. 
Thus, the fcst will feature chance/likely pops early on Thursday 
night, maximized across the high terrain given nwly upsloping, all 
eventually tapering below mentionable levels by Friday morning.
On Friday the guidance favors shortwave ridging amidst nwly flow 
aloft, while llv flows backs southwesterly into the afternoon hours 
as a warm front advects in.  Fcst profiles suggest high cape (>3k 
j/kg) Friday afternoon/evening, however with the aforementioned 
ridging presenting an insurmountable capping inversion.  That said, 
the GFS does favor convection westward across the MidSouth region in 
association with the warm front, which could advect east into this 
highly unstable airmass.  If that occurs, expect deep and 
potentially strong/severe convection.  

Meanwhile shifting focus northward into the OH Valley, a series of 
potent MCSs are progged to develop across Kentuckiana atop the 
strengthening southeast CONUS ridge, advecting into east TN and 
southwest VA first early Saturday morning, with the second to arrive 
later in the afternoon.  Guidance does exhibit some solution 
discontinuity with these systems as the GFS/ECWMF track them right 
into the area, while the NAM favors a stronger and more eastward 
focused ridge axis which tracks the MCS activity more north and 
east.  While uncertainty remains high at this point for Saturday 
morning/afternoon, strong/severe convection is certainly a 
possibility.

Moving into Sunday, the upper ridge axis looks to amplify across the 
TN Valley and Southern Appalachian region thereby favoring diurnally 
focused instability.  Profiles do exhibit steep lapse rates, however 
amidst modest llv capping which could inhibit convection to some 
degree.  The start of the new work week looks highlighted by a 
progressive trough moving east across the Midwest states with a 
surface cold front tracking beneath over the MS/OH and TN Valleys. 
There is notable disagreement relative to the progression of this 
next fropa within the GFS/ECMWF, therefore leaned lighter on pops 
for these later periods.  

Overall, the extended period will feature multiple round of showers 
and thunderstorms with temperatures returning to above normal levels, 
especially into next week.

reveals an area of strengthening, albeit generally weak, ascent 
forecast to lift lift northeast from northern Alabama and Georgia 
across the forecast area this morning. CAM guidance depicts the 
response to this ascent by way of increasing coverage of showers in 
the same general area. This makes sense as the ascent should be able 
to lift parcels into areas of elevated instability through daybreak, 
whereafter surface based convection can become dominant as fcst 
soundings show a largely uncapped environment once again by mid 
morning. Radar imagery from northeast Alabama and northern Georgia 
seem to confirm this, so have trended the forecast in that 
direction, showing higher rain chances lifting northeast through the 
first half of the morning. Behind this initial wave, scattered 
diurnal convection seems likely once again today. Perhaps areas of 
the northeast where the aforementioned wave of ascent and associated 
clouds/showers is last to clear, afternoon convection may be limited 
but that remains to be seen. Elsewhere, severe chances with 
afternoon storms appear limited. Lapse rates aloft are nearly moist 
adiabatic and the only reason instability is as strong as it is, 
generally less than 1,700 J/kg for even MUCAPE, is largely due to 
warmer surface/low level temperatures. However, PWATs will be high 
and shear is low, so pulse type convection with wet downbursts will 
pose a conditional severe threat. In addition to winds, flash 
flooding is a localized concern as well. No strong geographical 
signals stand out so this would be an isolated threat confined to 
areas that received heavy rains yesterday or the day before.

Diurnal trends will takeover this evening with convection quickly 
waning as we approach sunset. However, rain chances will ramp back 
up late tonight as the influence of the next disturbance begins to 
be felt. More on that in the long term period however.

Temperature wise, cloud cover should be a little more scattered 
today than yesterday so expect afternoon highs to be warmer 
somewhere in the 2-5 degree range.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Wednesday)...

The extended pattern will remain active with a series of short-waves 
moving across the Ohio/Tennessee valleys. Main question is timing of 
convective clusters as nocturnal MCSs will occur for late Friday 
night/Saturday morning and again Sunday morning.  Lets get to the 
particulars.

For Thursday, a short-wave will be moving across the Ohio/Tennessee 
valleys in the afternoon. Models suggest a cluster of convection 
will move across the region in the morning, but then redevelop along 
a frontal boundary near the Plateau in the afternoon. CAM Ensemble 
shows CAPEs of 1500-2000 J/Kg and mid-level lapse rates of near 6.5 
degree C with decent speed shear. The 0-6km shear of 30-35kts will 
be supportive of some rotating updrafts.  Some marginal severe 
storms possible with hail up to quarter size and strong/gusty winds.

For Thursday night and Friday, ridging pulls into the area with 
drier conditions and warmer temperatures. Low level capping 
inversion will limit convection development even though airmass 
becomes quite unstable in the afternoon and mid-level lapse rates 
increase to over 7.0+.

For Friday night and Saturday, the GFS and ECMWF suggest a 
convective cluster/MCS will develop over the lower Ohio valley then 
pull southeast into the area. Isentropic lift as ridge moves east 
will help support this area of convection along with diffluent 
flow aloft. Airmass remains moderately unstable with good mid-
level lapse rates support of strong updrafts. Redevelopment during
the afternoon is possible depending on how fast and extensive MCS
becomes. Some strong to possibly severe storms are expected with 
heavy rain, strong/gusty winds, hail (up to quarter size) and 
frequent lightning.

For Saturday night and Sunday, GFS and ECMWF shows almost a repeat 
action as another MCS develops over the Indiana/Ohio then moves 
southeast into the region. Fairly steep mid-level lapse rates will 
produce a moderately unstable airmass with CAPES of 2000 J/Kg+. Some 
strong to possible severe storms are possible.

For Monday and Tuesday of next week, models show another short-wave 
moving toward/across the Tennessee valley and southern Appalachian 
producing showers and storms.
