.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Wednesday)...
Southwesterly flow prevails atop the TN Valley and Southern 
Appalachian region this afternoon, while a weak shortwave advects 
east along the mean H5 flow.  Meanwhile, 20-30kt H85 flow out of the 
south/southwest favors ample moisture advection into the area amidst 
weak sfc ridging.  Latest trends favor sct/num convection moving 
east across the valley into the mtns, while new convection begins to 
initiate over the eastern plateau as expected.  Pops this afternoon 
will favor at least likely levels regionwide with categorical pops 
mentioned across the high terrain, tapering to likely levels 
westward into the valley.  Overall still think the primary threat 
this afternoon is deep/moist convection favoring efficient warm rain 
processes thanks to pwats in excess of 1.6-1.7 inches and warm cloud 
depths approaching 11kft. A review of most recent FFGs would suggest 
the most susceptible areas for potential flash flooding as a 
consequence of recent rainfall would be across portions of the TN 
Foothills, northward into much of southwest VA. Although the latest 
SPC MesoAnalysis indicates sbcape approaching 1.5-2.0k j/kg, am 
expecting updrafts to remain fairly water loaded which should 
inhibit severe convection, although won't rule out a strong wet 
microburst if any updrafts can get tall enough before collapsing.  

Overnight, pops will be allowed to fall off into the slight/chance 
range as the aforementioned H5 wave advects east of the region, 
leaving only minimal elevated nocturnal instability to fuel 
convection.  Given a very moist and decoupled boundary layer, some 
patchy fog is expected tonight, especially if skies sct out a bit. 

As for Wednesday, profiles look to dry out somewhat as the mean 
low/mid level flow veers westerly, thus chances for increased 
updraft height look to elevate.  All said, instability should favor 
diurnal trends on Wednesday with upward of 1-2k j/kg possible, thus 
a few strong/severe storms featuring gusty/damaging winds and hail 
cannot be ruled out.  Highs on Wendesday will be around a category 
warmer than that of today given fewer clouds (especially after 
sunrise) thanks to drier profiles.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday night through Tuesday)...
By 00Z Thursday, the upper levels will feature broad cyclonic flow 
through much the CONUS. A shortwave trough will dive southeast 
through the midwest Wednesday night into Thursday morning. At the 
surface, an area of low pressure underneath increasing diffluent 
flow aloft should move into the Ohio valley by 12Z Thursday. 
Increasing SHRA/TSRA chances are expected Wednesday night through 
Thursday. Point soundings indicate CAPE values quickly increasing 
through the day on Thursday with ML CAPE in excess of 2500 j/kg. 
Increased h50 flow should also help to increase shear with 0-6km 
shear increasing to 30-35 knots. As a result, can't rule out some 
strong to possibly severe storms. 

Increased height rises behind the departing upper level disturbance 
will lead to surface high pressure underneath the descending branch 
of the h50 shortwave. As a result, drier weather can be expected on 
Friday. In fact, Friday may be the driest day of the extended 
period. An upper level ridge will continue to build into the Ohio 
and Tennessee valley through the weekend. Some timing differences 
become apparent between global models on Saturday but increasing 
SHRA/TSRA can be expected Saturday and Saturday night. Temperatures 
should be near to slightly above average through he weekend. 

The ridge begins to slowly break down into early next week as an 
amplifying trough moves into the plains. An area of low pressure at 
the surface will move through the midwest and into the Great Lakes. 
Increased chances of precipitation are expected into Monday night 
ahead of a frontal boundary with thunderstorms likely with 
increasing instability. PoPs begin to lower across most of the area 
on Tuesday as high pressure at the surface begins to move in. 
Temperatures should continue to be near to slightly above normal 
through the end of the extended period.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

Today will be much the same as yesterday with regard to rain
chances. The atmosphere will be largely uncapped, even earlier 
than yesterday (daybreak this go round versus late morning 
yesterday) actually, so widespread showers and thunderstorms are 
expected once again. An initial wave of convection will move north
out of Georgia and western North Carolina around daybreak. This 
should clear the forecast area early enough to allow for continued
destabilization into the afternoon hours with another round of
storms expected. Hard to time all of this with respect to rain 
chances, so have fairly high rain chances through the day. 
Afternoon/early evening PoPs are slightly lower than this morning 
given the possibility that morning convective debris clouds reduce
shower coverage later, but again I do not think this will be a 
concern given the bulk of guidance showing widespread storms 
later.

With respect to severe chances, much like yesterday instability
will be sufficient for some risk of severe storms. Damaging winds
are the most likely hazard type with any strong to severe storms.
Also, flooding is a concern as well given overall slow storm
motions. Forecast PWAT values will be high, so any training of
storms over the same area will need to be watched for flooding
concerns. Do not expect heavy rainfall to be widespread today, so
what does occur will be scattered in nature. Given this, have held
off on issuing any Flash Flood Watch products at this time. Will 
continue to mention the possibilty in the Hazardous Weather 
Outlook and here in the AFD for now.

Otherwise, an upper trough axis shifting through the area today
will wind up east of the Appalachians during the overnight hours.
Between the passing of the trough and typical diurnal trends,
convection will likely markedly decrease around and after midnight
tonight before increasing into the long term period. Left some
chance PoPs in overnight however as there is some hint in some of
the CAM guidance of some nocturnal convection approaching from the
west overnight. 

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday through Tuesday)...

The extended forecast is fairly complex with a series of fairly 
significant short-wave effecting the Tennessee valley and southern 
Appalachians. The strongest waves will be Thursday, and possibly 
Monday.  Lets to the specifics.

For Wednesday, models differ some on the possibly of a weak short-
wave moving through the Tennessee valley, but either way, model 
soundings show plenty of moisture/instability for afternoon and 
evening storms. Heavy rain, marginal hail, and isolated damaging 
winds anticipated.

For late Wednesday night and Thursday, models are in agreement with 
a significant short-wave moving across the Ohio/Tennessee valleys. A 
frontal boundary will move through the area in the afternoon. Upper 
jet forcing will move through Thursday with a 850mb jet of 40kts 
during the day. Air mass will be unstable with MLCAPEs of 1500-2000 
J/Kg with decent mid-level lapse rates of 6.5-7.0 in the mid-levels. 
Strong boundary flow producing 0-6km shear of 30-35kts. Expect some 
supercell characteristics enhancing updraft strength. Main 
concern will be large hail up to quarter-half dollar size with 
damaging winds.

For Thursday night and Friday, ridging will build into the region 
behind exiting short-wave. Enough instability to support low chance 
of convection over the higher terrain of the eastern Tennessee 
Mountains and southwest Virginia in the afternoon, otherwise drier 
conditions.

For late Friday and Saturday, a complicated forecast as a warm 
frontal boundary will pull northeast across the area. GFS suggest a 
strong complex of convection will develop over the lower Ohio valley 
then pull southeast into the region Saturday. Timing of storms is 
crucial. GFS model soundings at 18Z Saturday are fairly unstable 
with MLCAPEs of 1500-2000 J/Kg with decent mid-level lapse rates of 
6.5-7.0. Fairly large hail CAPEs will support potential of large 
hail. Low level lapse rates of 7.0-7.5 will also help to support 
damaging winds. 

For Sunday, frontal boundary hangs up across the area with a good 
chance of showers and thunderstorms with the main concern being 
heavy rainfall.

For Monday, models suggest another short-wave approaching the area 
with stronger storms once again possible.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight Through Tuesday Night)...

The pulse convection will weaken quickly after 01Z as diurnal 
cooling takes place and much of the area becomes convectively 
overturned. Kept chance pops for showers and a few rumbles of 
thunder through tonight as the shortwave approaches from the west, 
with the best chances being over the plateau and central/southern 
valley later tonight. Convergence will slowly be increasing ahead of 
a weak surface frontal boundary, likely reinforced by convective 
outflow, and MLCAPE across the central and southern valley will 
remain above 1000 J/Kg in this moist airmass overnight. Stayed above 
MET and MAV guidance for lows due to increasing clouds tonight on 
top of this muggy airmass.

The above mentioned shortwave will cross east TN, southwest VA, and 
southwest NC during the day Tuesday. A weak surface low will move 
northeast through KY, and the NAM is stronger with this surface low 
than the GFS and ECMWF. Suspect that the NAM solution is due to some 
convective feedback, but either way, a weak frontal boundary looks 
to cross from west to east between 18 and 02Z. Large scale ascent 
from the upper wave and frontal convergence will lead to greater 
convective coverage Tuesday, so have likely pops from mid morning 
through the day. Severe weather potential will be low overall, but 
slightly higher than the past couple of days. SPC has the entire 
region in a marginal risk, and this is reasonable since 1500-2000 
J/Kg of MLCAPE will once again develop along with a few hundred 
joules of DCAPE during the afternoon as low-level lapse rates 
steepen with afternoon heating. The main threat will be damaging 
winds in convective downdrafts. Limiting factors continue to be poor 
mid level lapse rates of only 5-6 C/Km and weak 0-6 Km and effective 
shear values of 15-30 kts. This will keep any strong wind threat 
isolated since strong convective updrafts will have a hard time 
sustaining for a long period of time. An additional limiting factor 
will be morning clouds and showers that will delay stronger surface 
heating. With all of this being said, torrential rainfall and 
localized flash flooding will be the bigger impact from any 
convection since PWATs will continue to be 1.50 to 2.00 inches 
(locally higher) with high freezing levels for warm rain processes. 
Storm motion will also be slow due to the weak deep layer wind 
fields. CAMs offer varying solutions for tomorrow, but thinking is 
that an initial round of showers and some embedded thunderstorms 
will move through between 10 and 16Z followed by some redevelopment 
in the afternoon. Kept a heavy rain mention in the HWO for Tuesday. 
High temps Tuesday will be slightly cooler than today due to the 
clouds and widespread convective activity.

Much of the convection will move east of the region after 00Z 
Wednesday as the shortwave and weak front exit to the east. Have 
chance pops through Tuesday night since we do not see a change of 
airmass and remain on the southern fringe of a convectively active 
quasi-stationary front beneath a fast mid level zonal jet around the 
OH valley. Convective complexes moving along this corridor north of 
our region will occasionally send outflow boundaries into our 
area, which warrants keeping chance pops through the night. Lows 
will remain warm and humid.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday through Monday)...

By 12Z Wednesday, the upper levels will feature a rather low 
amplitude pattern with several disturbances moving through weak 
cyclonic flow. A stronger shortwave trough/PV anomaly will be moving 
through the central plains Wednesday. At the surface, an area of low 
pressure will move through the central plains and into the Ohio 
valley by 12Z Thursday. A subtle PV anomaly moving through the area 
Wednesday afternoon and evening combined with differential heating 
will likely be enough to generate TSRA especially with a moist and 
unstable airmass as CAPE values climb upwards of 1500 j/kg. 
Afternoon convection will decrease in coverage by Wednesday night 
with the loss of solar heating.

The aforementioned shortwave trough will deepen as noted by 
increasing cyclonic flow as it begins to approach from the west. A 
trailing cold front will be aligned NE/SW from the parent low into 
the Arklatex. Increasing forcing for ascent underneath height falls 
along with low level convergence should increase SHRA/TSRA chances 
through Thursday morning. Additional chances of precipitation are 
expected immediately along the front through the day Thursday with 
TSRA expected as CAPE values increase.

The area will see a short break on Friday as increasing heights 
aloft and surface high pressure underneath the descending branch of 
the h50 shortwave lead to increasing subsidence and dry weather. An 
upper level ridge axis will be situated across the GoM northward 
into the Great Lakes over the weekend. Both the GFS and EURO 
indicate the ridge breaking down enough a few disturbances to rotate 
around the ridge axis. Expect increased SHRA/TSRA chances through 
the weekend as a result. Closer to early next week, the upper level 
pattern will feature large scale troughing out west with ridging 
along the east coast. This places the region under southwest flow 
aloft. Increasing moisture along with several upper level 
disturbances will keep chances of SHRA/TSRA in the forecast for 
Sunday through Tuesday. Temperatures through the extended will be 
near to slightly above seasonal averages.

National Weather Service Morristown TN

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

Regional radar imagery shows ongoing convection across eastern 
Kentucky, with some scattered showers stretching back into middle 
Tennessee this morning. This is all situated along the axis of the 
low level jet and best moisture transport. This has clipped parts of 
Scott, Campbell, and even far northern Morgan counties overnight. 
However, do not expect this to shift much more to the east, if at 
all, since the LLJ is about as far east as it will make it before 
daybreak. Have some slight chance PoPs through daybreak over parts 
of the northern plateau to account for this, and that should do
just fine.

For the remainder of the short term, an upper level low/trough over 
Arkansas this morning will continue to shift east through the day 
and into tonight, providing increasing rain chances. Southerly 
surface flow out ahead of this system will make for another warm and 
muggy day. Highs yesterday reached into the upper 80s for many 
place, and expect similar conditions to be seen today. Rain chances 
will quickly ramp up through the day today. Model soundings show 
a virtually uncapped environment by mid to late morning, so expect
the plateau and mountainous areas of southwest Virginia, eastern 
Tennessee, and far western North Carolina to begin to convect 
fairly early today. PoP forecast reflect this trend, showing 
higher values there early on, with lower elevation areas trending 
upwards more significantly during the afternoon. Model soundings 
do show a significant amount of instability today, but shear will 
be lacking. And with an uncapped atmosphere in place convection 
will increase in coverage fairly rapidly, with placement largely 
be driven by outflow boundary interactions as time goes by. A few
severe storms, with mainly a damaging wind threat, seems very 
plausible today given the instability profiles, but don't expect 
widespread severe weather. Heavy downpours will also be a concern
given the slow storm motions and higher PWAT air advecting into 
the region.

Diurnal trends will mean a lull in convection during the first half 
of tonight, but expect coverage to increase late tonight heading 
into the long term period tomorrow as the aforementioned upper low 
draws near.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Sunday)...

The active weather pattern continues during the long term period 
with a couple rather significant short wave features operating in 
a deep moist environment. The first wave presses through the 
region Tuesday into Tuesday night generating a widespread pattern 
of showers and thunderstorms with a bit of a break in the action 
during the day Wednesday. The next wave drives through the 
Southern Appalachian region Wednesday night into Thursday. The 
thermodynamic environment is more than sufficient for convection 
with capes around 1500-2000 J/kg for the passage of each of these 
features. However, as is typical during the Summer season in the 
Mid South, shear won't be terribly impressive, so if severe 
thunderstorms develop, they would be isolated. Some uncertainty 
still exists in the latter part of the extended period, but it 
appears there will be a break in the more active weather on 
Friday. Had to keep a recent trend of increasing pops for 
convection (in the medium chance range) over the weekend with 
model depiction of some short wave energy trying to ride into the 
long wave ridge position over the Eastern U.S.

FXUS64 KMRX 161906

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
306 PM EDT Sun Jun 16 2019

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Monday)...A broken line of convection 
that moved across middle TN this morning has pretty much 
dissipated. However...a few isolated cells are forming...generally 
over the Cumberland Plateau and additional convective activity is
expected across the area this afternoon. The atmosphere has 
become weak to moderately unstable but there is little upper 
support or shear to work with. There will continue to be the 
potential for a short lived strong to severe storm but 
overall...do not expect much significant activity. Later this 
evening with the loss of daytime heating...the convection should 
decrease. However...with southerly flow continuing to bring in 
warm...moist air...a few lingering showers may continue over the 
area tonight. 

Then...a short wave moving through the upper flow late tonight
into Monday will generate another round of convection. The air
mass will again destabilize by the afternoon with CAPE values
1500-2500 J/Kg. Again there will be little shear to work with but
a couple of residual outflow boundaries may help enhance
thunderstorm development. So overall...the potential for strong to
severe storms will be slightly higher on Monday compared to
today...but believe the severe threat is marginal. With the
expected increase in clouds and rainfall...temperatures should end
up near to a degree or so cooler on Monday. 

.LONG TERM (Monday Night Through Sunday)...Seasonably warm and 
humid conditions with daily shower and thunderstorm chances are 
expected for the entire workweek as east TN, southwest VA, and 
southwest NC remain on the southern fringe of zonal west-
southwesterly mid to upper level flow and a quasi- stationary 
frontal boundary across the Midwest and OH valley. Most of the 
convection will be scattered in nature, and mainly occur during 
the afternoon and evening when daytime heating will be maximized, 
but Tuesday and Thursday will offer opportunities for greater 
convective coverage due to well defined mid level shortwave 
troughs and weak surface reflections moving across the region.

All guidance is consistent on bringing the Tuesday shortwave through 
the region during the afternoon and evening. Have likely pops for 
this time as fairly widespread convection will accompany this 
disturbance. Severe weather potential is very low since 0-6 Km shear 
will only be 15-25 kts and unidirectional, and mid level lapse rates 
will only reach 5-6 C/km which will keep MUCAPE on the order of 1000-
1500 J/kg and limit the duration of strong, sustained updrafts. 
However, isolated downburst winds are possible since low-level lapse 
rates will steepen during peak heating with at least several hundred 
joules of DCAPE. The biggest impact from thunderstorms will be 
torrential rainfall since PWATs are progged to be 1.50-2.00 inches 
with high freezing levels to support warm rain processes.

The Thursday shortwave looks to be the strongest of the two. Daily 
convection upstream over the Midwest and Mississippi valley will 
likely influence the precise timing and strength of this feature, 
but Thursday could offer a slightly greater chance of seeing a few 
strong to severe thunderstorms. Have likely pops for this period 
too. Early projections suggest 30-35 kts of deep layer 
unidirectional shear which could help increase strong wind 
potential, but negative factors continue to be poor mid level lapse 
rates resulting in lower than ideal MLCAPE to maintain stronger 
updrafts. For this reason, will not mention severe weather in the 
HWO at this point for Tuesday or Thursday. The bigger impact 
Thursday will once again be heavy rain as PWATs will continue to 
average 1.50-2.00 inches with high freezing levels. Additionally, 
some areas will have likely seen repeated thunderstorms containing 
heavy downpours by the time Thursday comes around, so the potential 
of localized flash flooding will be increasing. WPC introduces a 
marginal risk of excessive rainfall across the entire region on Day 
3. Will mention localized flash flooding in the HWO for the coming 
week.

Guidance continues to differ next weekend with the GFS maintaining 
the zonal pattern and resultant seasonable temps and humidity, while 
the ECMWF continues to amplify the pattern with strong western CONUS 
troughing and southeastern ridging developing. Ensemble forecasts of 
teleconnection indices from the Climate Prediction Center show the 
NAO trending neutral to positive and the PNA going strongly negative 
for the latter half of June. This typically yields a western 
trough/eastern ridge pattern, so will side with the warmer ECMWF 
solution for our region and adjust high temps upward to upper 
80's/low 90's next weekend.

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Sunday)...The Southern Appalachian Region
will transition into a more active weather pattern during the
short term. The surface high that has dominate area weather is
moving east over the Atlantic. Circulation around this high has
shifted winds southerly which in turn will increase low level
moisture and bring in a warmer air mass. Flow aloft will slowly
become southwesterly. There will be a couple of short waves riding
along this upper flow. Through the short term...the main track of
the short waves will stay to our north and west but will see
clouds increase during the upcoming 24 hours and while the main
area of convection should track north...a few scattered showers
and even a stray thunderstorms could move in. The best chance of
showers/thunderstorms will be over northern locations and across
high elevations Sunday afternoon. The air mass may become weakly 
unstable.  Additionally...there is little upper level support. 
So...while a strong storm can not be ruled out...do not anticipate
significant convection. 

.LONG TERM (Sunday night Through Saturday)...The overall pattern 
beginning Sunday night and lasting through the upcoming workweek 
will feature zonal west-southwesterly mid to upper level flow with 
much more humid conditions but seasonable temperatures for the 
official start of summer. This pattern will bring chances of showers 
and thunderstorms each day as fast moving, difficult to time, low 
amplitude shortwaves propagate through the flow and combine with 
daytime heating. At the surface, a quasi-stationary front will be 
draped across the Midwest and Ohio valley placing east Tennessee, 
southwest Virginia, and southwest NC on the southern edge of the 
best forcing mechanisms.

The two strongest shortwave troughs appear to be Tuesday and late 
Wednesday into Thursday. These will bring greater coverage of 
showers and thunderstorms outside of the mainly diurnally driven 
scattered afternoon and evening showers and thunderstorms that will 
occur Sunday through the workweek. Have higher pops for these time 
periods. As mentioned above, the synoptic front should stay to our 
north through the week keeping the main focus for widespread 
excessive rainfall out of our region, but have maintained high 
chance to likely pops across most areas during the day and chance 
pops at night to account for the diurnal cycles as well as potential 
outflow boundaries that could occasionally move down into our area 
and ignite convection. Severe weather potential throughout the week 
will be low, but any stronger multicell clusters that develop could 
produce isolated downburst winds during the afternoon and evening 
hours. Surface CAPE will increase to over 2000 J/Kg each day with 
steep low-level lapse rates and PWATs of 1.70 to 2.00 inches aiding 
in strong downdraft potential, but very weak deep layer shear of 
only 15-25 kts most days and poor mid level lapse rates will prevent 
widespread convective organization. Isolated flash flooding will be 
possible since any thunderstorm will produce torrential rainfall due 
to the high PWATs and freezing levels. 

By next weekend, the zonal pattern will try to amplify as longwave 
western CONUS troughing develops and forces Bermuda ridging over the 
Southeast. The latest ECMWF is most aggressive in building mid level 
heights over 590 DAM across our region next weekend with the GFS 
maintaining flatter flow. For now, have temps rising above normal to 
upper 80's to near 90 at that time along with chance pops for 
continued diurnal convection.

beautiful subsidence producing ridge that continues to slip slowly
east over the Western Atlantic waters will be felt across the 
Southern Appalachian region today with just a few higher clouds 
along with some scattered cumulus development. The cu is a 
reflection of the gradual low level moistening on a little 
stronger southwesterly flow off the Western Gulf of Mexico. The 
cumulus clouds will be mainly across the southern part of the 
forecast area this afternoon and will be held in check by a most 
pleasant warm layer around 750-800 mb. A decent amount of 
insolation and stronger southerly component to the low level flow 
will boost high temperatures about five to six degrees above maxes
that occurred on Friday. A moistening airmass won't allow as much
cooling as we've seen in recent days. Lows tonight will be back 
in the 60s across most of the region.

.LONG TERM...(Sunday through Saturday)...

The long term period remains active in terms of convective
activity. The upper level pattern will feature a quasi-split flow
pattern through the short term, with the polar jet near the
Canadian border, and influence from a weak subtropical jet across
the southern tier states. Embedded in that southern stream will 
be a semi-closed shortwave that will begin over the southern 
plains on Sunday and gradually shift east across Arkansas and 
Tennessee Monday into Tuesday. The passage of this trough late
Tuesday gives way to more broad cyclonic flow aloft over the
eastern half of the US as troughing tries to build south. At the 
surface, persistent southerly flow will keep a steady supply of 
Gulf moisture streaming into the area, along with aiding in 
producing more summer like temperatures than in recent days.


With the passage of the Tuesday shortwave, and broad troughing
attempting to build south across the eastern CONUS, there will be
a continued focus for showers and thunderstorm activity across
the Tennessee Valley. In terms of rain chances, most every period
will feature at least some chance of rain, with the highest 
chances being Monday and Tuesday as the aforementioned shortwave 
approaches from the west. Much of the rain will be diurnally 
driven, but will keep some chances even overnight as most 
guidance continues to show some convective QPF during nighttime 
hours most nights.

flow transports Gulf moisture toward the area, and a upper level

that should act to cap deep convection. But there is enough 
instability and moisture for slight chance PoPs over much of the 
valley, and low chances in the terrain areas. The focus of lift 
and therefore the best rain chances appear to be mainly to our 
north and west on Sunday.

Valley will bring increasing rain chances on Monday, with the trough 
passage briging likely PoPs on Tuesday. Instability will be 
increasing as well with no capping inversion and MLCAPE values 
around 200 J/kg. Shear is weak but a few strong to marginally severe 
storms can't be ruled out these days. 

Wednesday may be a short lull in the higher rain chances as a weak 
mid/upper ridge builds overhead, but some chance PoPs will still be 
kept in the forecast as the exact timing of these shortwave troughs 
is uncertain. The next trough axis swings through on Thursday, and 
may have a little better dynamics and amplification than the first 
as the low pressure center is more well definied as it tracks across 
the OH Valley. Again, some strong storms may be possible depending 
on the timing, which remains unclear. Likely PoPs on Thursday will 
drop back to a low chance on Friday behind the trough.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
336 AM EDT Thu Jun 13 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

A cold front was approaching the Cumberland Plateau as of 3:00am
EDT this morning. Ahead of this front was a line of showers, with
embedded thunderstorms, located over the Tennessee Valley. These
showers should push east of the area by around, or very shortly
after, daybreak with the surface cold front moving through by late
morning. The question with regard to rain chances is, how long 
will showers linger into the late morning or early afternoon 
hours. The upper trough driving all of this is noted on water 
vapor imagery over the mid Mississippi River Valley this morning. 
And while additional jet energy will pivot overhead this 
afternoon behind the upper trough axis, the air mass is forecast 
to dry out rapidly today behind the front. Furthermore, the trough
will largely be situated to our north. Despite the trough axis
passing by this morning, colder air will remain to our north and 
mid level temperatures will actually warm slightly as the day 
wears on. Thus, while some clouds may linger in the higher 
terrain into the afternoon hours, especially in southwest 
Virginia, think that rain chances will come to an end rather 
quickly this morning as the atmosphere dries out significantly and
elevated instability becomes non-existent.

One thing of interest today however will be gusty conditions.
Model soundings show a well mixed, post-frontal air mass in place
today, with breezy conditions beginning by mid morning across
western areas near the plateau. Mixed layer depths extend up to
7-8k ft above the valley floor by this afternoon, which will
extend far enough vertically to tap into some 25-35kt winds aloft.
Couple the mixing down of these winds, and increased surface
pressure gradients across the region and a fairly breezy day is
expected across the forecast area. Would think some gusts into 
the 25-30mph range will be seen this afternoon. Expect the 
stronger winds to be north of the I-40 corridor, though still 
think some gusty winds will be seen as far south as the Georgia 
border also. 

For tonight, winds will relax and clouds will clear out. With
dewpoints in the 40s, a fairly cold night is expected by summer
standards. While record lows don't appear in the offing, lows in
the 40s to low 50s tonight will certainly be in the top 10 
for calendar day low temperatures for June 14th.


.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Wednesday)...

At the start of the period the upper trough will be east of the 
forecast area leaving an area of high pressure in its wake. Much 
cooler and drier air will spread across the region providing 
comfortable conditions for this time of year with max temperatures
on Friday and Saturday in the 70s and 80s. Lows on Saturday 
morning will generally be in the 50s.

As the surface high shifts east later on Saturday, southerly winds 
will gradually advect in warm, moist air. However, the chance of any 
rainfall will hold off until Sunday. A series of shortwaves in 
southwest flow and increasing instability over the forecast area 
will produce showers and thunderstorms by Sunday afternoon. With 
little to no change of airmass and persistent southwest flow - 
relatively high rain chances will continue through the middle of 
next week.

instability. Temperatures remain in the upper 50s to low 60s with 
the cloud cover in place. 

Models showing some showers hanging around NETN and SWVA into 
tomorrow morning as the cold front hasn't completely exited yet. 
There is the potential for a storm or two up that way late 
morning/early afternoon before POPs drop off as the front and trough 
exit. Clearing conditions through the afternoon with highs in the 
upper 60s to mid 70s. Winds will become gusty tomorrow as the 
pressure gradient tightens behind the frontal passage. Winds will 
generally gust from 15 to 25 mph from out of the west.




.LONG TERM...(Thursday night through Wednesday)...A well-amplified
upper trough axis and cold front will be to our east by 00Z 
Friday, with high pressure building in from the northwest. This 
airmass, with origins in central Canada, will be unseasonably cool
and dry, which will allow for temperatures to drop into the upper
40s and lower 50 across much of the TN Valley on Friday morning 
and afternoon highs in the mid to upper 70s. 

The surface high and midlevel ridge axis move to our east on Friday 
night, allowing a more southerly low level flow to develop. Clouds 
will increase Saturday as a shortwave trough moves overhead, but low 
levels remain too dry and stable for any chance of precip with this 
feature. Gradual moistening of the column will occur Sunday ahead of 
a trough and surface low crossing the Great Lakes. The best forcing 
with this system will be to our north, but chance PoPs are warranted 
Sunday/Sunday night, favoring northern sections.

A broad trough will be positioned over the Plains and MS Valley for 
the first half of next week, which will place East TN in the deep SW 
flow with a series of disturbances bringing some lift in a moist 
environment. Timing details are sketchy this far out, but the 
general pattern that the models agree on does favor high chance to 
likely PoPs Monday through Wednesday. There may be some potential 
for heavy rainfall in this period, however that will likely depend 
more on mesoscale dynamics as the synoptic pattern does not look 
ideal, and the details are too uncertain at this point.

289 
FXUS64 KMRX 120754
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
354 AM EDT Wed Jun 12 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

Water vapor satellite imagery shows an upper trough situated over
the southern plains this morning, with another disturbance over
the South Carolina coast. At the surface, high pressure over New
York has created a weak CAD setup along the eastern escarpment of
the southern Appalachians, with an inverted surface trough
situated essentially from the Tennessee Valley southward into
Georgia this morning. Previous thinking was that convergence 
along this inverted trough, along with increasing influence from
the approaching southern plains trough, would be enough to spark
showers and possibly some embedded thunderstorms across a better
part of the forecast area today. And indeed there are some 
ongoing showers drifting northward across northern Georgia this 
morning. However low level moisture will be a limiting factor for
substantial convective coverage today I believe. Dewpoints are in
the upper 40s to low 50s in places as you get as far north as the
I-40 corridor, and certainly north of that. Furthermore, the
latest high resolution guidance, including the 12km NAM, indicate
that much of the shower activity will be along or west of the
Cumberland Plateau today, in line with an axis of higher PWAT
values and low level moisture. Did not completely abandon the rain
chances for today by any stretch, but did trend them downwards 
just a bit overall. Did keep a mention of thunder in there, mainly
after midday when instability will be the highest, but suspect it
will be mostly showers.

Otherwise, below normal temperatures will continue today, with
highs likely topping out just below 80 degrees or roughly 5-7
degrees below normal for this time of year. The upper trough axis
will shift overhead late tonight. A chance for showers will 
continue across mainly the higher terrain of northeast Tennessee 
and southwest Virginia late tonight as this occurs, with rain
chances ending from the southwest with time. With cloud cover
hanging around into the overnight hours, and the trough axis not
shifting east of the forecast area until tomorrow, there is not
likely to be any substantial advection of dry and cool air.
Temperatures will be below normal again tonight, but the cooler
air will hold off until the long term period.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Tuesday)...

An unseasonably deep trough over the eastern U.S. will bring 
another bout of welcomed cooler temperatures to the region 
Thursday and Friday. For Thursday - confidence is low for 
measurable precipitation with models differing quite a bit on QPF 
and extent. However, if the showers materialize it appears they 
will be confined generally along and north of I-40 with the best 
locations over southwest Virginia and Tri-Cities area. 
Additionally, rainfall amounts will likely be no more than one 
quarter inch. Precipitation would end by early evening Thursday 
night as drier air and high pressure build into the area. Friday 
morning some low temperatures will dip into the 40s!

The surface high will gradually build east and return the winds to 
the south. This will usher in warmer temperatures and increasing low 
level moisture by Saturday. Showers and thunderstorms will be on the 
increase by Saturday evening and persist through the remainder of 
this forecast period. The upper flow is generally zonal during this 
time frame. Forecast soundings show PWs near the 90th percentile 
indicate that any storms that develop will be efficient rainfall 
makers. Therefore, potential for heavy downpours and localized 
flooding could become a concern by early next week.

National Weather Service Morristown TN

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight through Wednesday Night)...
Tonight moisture will start to return to the area, starting in the 
west. Clouds will be increasing as well.  Clouds will be slow to 
increase in northeast TN southwest VA, both due to later to get 
return flow, but also due to some downsloping that will continue 
into Wednesday.

On Wednesday, a return flow of moderately warm, moist air will begin 
to move into the area, on the Plateau in the morning, and across the 
rest of the area during the afternoon.  Deep weak to moderate lift 
will be occurring during this period as well as an upper jet moves 
across the area. Also, it looks like there may be a weak N-S surface 
trough moving into the area to give a focus for convection. Overall 
moisture levels will be increasing as Precip Water values rise to 
around 1.25 inches across much of the area.  At peak heating and 
instability, deep convection will be expected somewhere near or west 
of the Plateau, with MLCAPE values up to about 1000 J/kg.  There 
could be some strong to even briefly severe storms in this area in 
the afternoon and into the early evening.  With the steering flow 
being to the northeast, the storms will initially just move along 
the terrain, then in the evening as the whole system moves east, 
there will be better chances of storms across the rest of the area, 
however, instability will be weakening as evening cooling continues. 
Will taper off thunder after midnight to just showers for the last 
few hours Wednesday night.   

.LONG TERM (Thursday through Tuesday)...A long wave trough over the 
Great Lakes will usher cooler and drier air into the region to end 
the week, with isolated to scattered showers diminishing during the 
day Thursday. An autumn-like morning on Friday with many lows 
reaching the upper 40s. Dry weather will hold Thursday night through 
Saturday as surface high pressure traverses our area from west to 
east. Once the surface high reaches the east coast and then 
continues to head toward Bermuda, the Gulf will open and southerly 
winds will bring humid air back into the area. A frontal boundary 
will move into the Ohio Valley and perhaps further southward, and 
this front will be oriented parallel to the steering flow aloft, so 
will be a potential focal point for repeated rounds of rainfall. 
Will the brunt of that weather remain to our north or will the front 
buckle far enough southward to have greater impact on our area? 
Right now our extended models keep the front to our north. 
Regardless, disturbances in the flow aloft will be enough to trigger 
rounds of convection in our forecast from Sunday through Tuesday.

National Weather Service Morristown TN
400 AM EDT Tue Jun 11 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

An area of thicker mid level cloud cover lingers from southwest VA 
through the east TN mountains as of 06Z associated with some 
lingering moisture and northwest upslope flow behind the front. 
These clouds should dissipate by sunrise as drier air continues to 
work in, so have decreasing clouds the rest of the night. Dew points 
will continue to slowly fall.

Surface high pressure gliding eastward across the Ohio and Tennessee 
valleys underneath a broad H5 trough will lead to a mostly sunny but 
cool day today with highs generally in the mid 70's to low 80's. A 
much drier airmass with lower dew points will make it feel more 
comfortable outside. The influence of the surface high and the 
already cool airmass in place will lead to another cool night 
tonight as winds go light and variable, however, used the slightly 
warmer MAV guidance for lows since projected soundings suggest an 
increase in mid level moisture which will cause a high and mid level 
cloud deck to slowly develop throughout the night. Upper 50's to low 
60's for lows are expected across the valley, plateau, and southwest 
NC with low to mid 50's across southwest VA and far northeast TN.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday through Tuesday)...

A long wave trough will be amplifying as it progresses slowly 
east across the Eastern U.S. from Wednesday through Friday. An 
initial wave rides through the base of the trough Wednesday night 
while a weaker short wave follows behind during the day Thursday. 
The initial wave is associated with a fropa early in the day 
Thursday and will have sufficient most unstable cape on the order 
of 1-2k j/kg and rather impressive 1000-500mb bulk shear in the 
neighborhood of 40-50kts Wednesday night. The western half of the 
forecast area will be under a Marginal risk for severe 
thunderstorm development in this environment. Again, a trailing 
piece of energy will move across the Central Appalachians on 
Thursday, keeping the threat for a few more showers and 
thunderstorms going through the day. Thursday night into Friday 
will be a cooler and drier period with surface high pressure 
building into the region. By Saturday, the center of the surface 
ridge will have shifted to the Southeast Atlantic Coast allowing a
gradual return to low level southerly flow off the Gulf of 
Mexico. Forecast confidence decreases to some degree in the latter
part of the extended, however slow moistening along with the 
passage of some weak short wave energy through the Ohio Valley; 
will lead to the possibility of a few showers and thunderstorms 
across the area mainly on Sunday. There appears to be a little 
better chance for more widespread convection in the Southern 
Appalachian region on Monday as a more well developed short wave 
moves encounters moist and unstable air on its eastward trek 
across the Ohio Valley through the day. The first three days of 
the extended period will be several degrees below normal with 
recovery to typical mid June warmth over the weekend into the 
early part of the work week.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Tuesday)...After a few lingering 
showers eastern areas this evening near the exiting cold front, 
the remainder of the short term period will be precip free as 
drier air pushes in. Clouds will be decreasing overnight, with 
plenty of sunshine on Tuesday as surface high pressure builds in. 
Relative humidity values will be low Tuesday afternoon and high 
temperatures will be a bit below seasonal normals.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday night through Monday)...By 00Z Wednesday, 
broad troughing will be situated across the eastern two thirds of 
the CONUS with a leading shortwave exiting New England while 
another shortwave begins to dive southeast out of the Dakotas. At 
the surface, an area of low pressure will be in the process of 
developing under h50 height falls in the midwest. Further south, 
another area of low pressure will be located across the Gulf Coast
and is progged to move northeast Tuesday night. Surface high 
pressure will still have an influence over most of the Ohio 
valley, and Appalachians. This subsidence will favor dry weather 
from Tuesday night into Wednesday. Temperatures will continue to 
be below normal through Wednesday. 

Wednesday, the trough continues its descent to the south veering 
winds in the lower troposphere to the southeast. Moisture return 
will be quick and point forecast soundings confirm the limited 
moisture. Increased large-scale forcing for ascent supports isolated 
to scattered SHRA for most of the area. There are some questions 
involving how much instability that can develop ahead of the upper 
level forcing. However, soundings and 2-D plane views suggest 
increasing elevated MU CAPE values above the boundary layer. The 
upper level jet impinging on the area and a 30-35 knot low level jet 
will increase shear with EBWD near 40 knots. This could support a 
couple of strong storms and the SPC has some of the forecast area in 
a Day-3 marginal risk. Hail would be the main threat given lower 
freezing level heights. Confidence is low but will include this into 
the HWO. SHRA/TSRA will come to an end late Wednesday night into 
early Thursday as the main trough and associated surface low exits 
the area. High pressure underneath the descending branch of the h50 
trough will quickly move in by Thursday with dry weather expected 
through Friday. Temperatures will continue to be below normal.

The upper level pattern begins to flatten out a bit toward the 
weekend. Several disturbances will likely travel through this flow 
aloft. A well established southwest flow in the lower levels will

FXUS64 KMRX 100810
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
410 AM EDT Mon Jun 10 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...The area of low pressure that has 
been responsible for the showers and storms the last several days
finally moves out tonight. An upper level trough swinging through
the Ohio River Valley pushes the low east and an associated cold 
front brings in drier air. However, we still have to deal with one
last day of active weather. 

CAMs show showers and storms firing back up by mid to late morning 
with coverage increasing from late morning through mid/late 
afternoon. CAMs show the bulk of the activity initiating generally 
along I-75 and points eastward so have reflected this in the hourly 
POPs. The main threat with the storms today will once again be 
moderate to heavy rain. WPC day 1 excessive rainfall outlook has our 
extreme eastern areas, foothills up through NETN into SWVA, in a 
slight risk for today. The airmass over these areas hold onto the 
deep moisture the longest with drier air not moving in until 
tonight. Areas west of I-75 will see some showers and storms as well 
but don't expect them to be the main problem areas for today. This 
is due to the drier air moving into these areas first, roughly 
early/mid afternoon. Any areas that see repeated bouts of heavy rain 
have the potential to see localized flash flooding, especially for 
areas that have already seen several inches of rain over the past 
few days. Didn't have enough confidence to issue a flash flood watch 
for our far eastern areas today as the storms should be moving 
quicker but will be watching things closely. Winds will also become 
gusty this afternoon as the front draws closer. Expect gusts in the 
15 to 25 mph rage for most areas from out of the northwest.

Conditions improve tonight as the front moves through. Favored 
upslope areas will hold onto the clouds and light showers the 
longest. Overnight lows will range from the lower to upper 50s.


.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Monday)...The long-term will be 
highlighted by near to below normal temps with shower/storm 
chances every couple of days as west-northwest flow aloft brings 
several disturbances and their associated cold fronts through the 
Tennessee and Ohio valleys. 

A broad H5 trough across the eastern U.S. with surface high pressure 
moving eastward across the Tennessee and Ohio valleys will bring 
beautiful weather Tuesday with lots of sunshine, highs in the mid 
70's/low 80's, and much lower humidity. The surface high just to our 
north Tuesday night with clear skies and nearly calm winds will 
allow for good sleeping weather as lows fall into the 50's across 
most of the region.

Heights will quickly rise across the TN valley Wednesday in response 
to a strong shortwave trough dropping through the N Plains and upper 
Midwest. This will induce weak surface low pressure over Iowa that 
will move into the Great Lakes Wednesday night and Thursday. This 
will allow for slightly warmer temps across our region Wednesday 
with gradually increasing dew points as WAA increases ahead of the 
system. Soundings and model plan view trajectories suggest some 925-
700 mb moisture and theta e advection Wednesday into Wednesday night 
as the above mentioned WAA increases, but it will be short duration 
and result in very limited instability. Nevertheless, large scale 
ascent will increase from Wednesday afternoon through Wednesday 
night ahead of the associated cold front, so have chance pops for 
showers/storms at this time. The surface low will deepen and quickly 
move northeast into eastern Canada Thursday reinforcing a deep 
longwave trough across the eastern U.S. The associated cold front 
should push through east TN, southwest VA, and southwest NC Thursday 
morning with chance pops continuing into the early afternoon as wrap 
around moisture dives through the trough. Temps will be cool once 
again Thursday with highs generally mid/upper 70's.

A surface high dropping into the region on the backside of the 
trough Thursday night and Friday will maintain the cool pattern, but 
mainly clear skies will allow for picture perfect weather for 
outdoor activities.

We should squeeze out one more dry and pleasant day Saturday before 
rain chances return Sunday and Monday. The surface high moving east 
generating return flow and rising H5 heights will cause high temps 
Saturday to moderate to seasonable levels, but another H5 trough 
will be developing across the northern tier of the U.S. A series of 
weak disturbances rotating through this mid/upper level flow pattern 
will result in a frontal boundary gradually sinking south into the 
TN valley Sunday through early next week, so have broad chance pops 
at this time. This front may stall across the region early next 
week, so it could be the beginning of another wet pattern.

.SHORT TERM...(Today through Monday)...

The cut off low pressure system that has brought the wet weather to 
the region the past few days will finally begin to open up today 
into an H5 trough that will be centered from the TN valley to the 
central Gulf coast. However, this will continue to keep diffluent 
southerly upper level flow across the southern Appalachians on the
east side of the trough axis which will continue deep layer lift 
and enhance an 850 mb jet. This low-level jet will continue 
transporting tropical moisture into the region. Winds in the 
925-700 mb layer continue to show high theta e and moisture fluxes
transported right into the area which will keep PWATs as high as 
2 inches as well as continue to keep freezing levels high for warm
rain processes. At the surface, the low will be centered in 
northern AL today with a cold front extending south and a quasi-
stationary front stretching east across north GA and SC. Expect 
the scattered light showers early this morning to expand in 
coverage again during the day as daytime heating takes place. 
Afternoon surface based CAPE of 1500- 2000 j/kg will allow for 
thunderstorms again with locally heavy rainfall rates. Low to mid 
level flow looks more southerly today, likely a result of the more
open wave, which will reduce downsloping and allow for greater 
coverage of showers/storms in the valley compared to yesterday.

A diurnal decrease in rainfall coverage is expected again tonight, 
although chance pops for scattered showers will continue. A strong 
northern stream shortwave trough moving toward the Great Lakes will 
begin to absorb the old southern U.S. H5 trough and surface low 
resulting in more of an elongated trough from the Great Lakes to the 
deep South by Monday afternoon. This will cause a surface cold front 
to slowly move into our region tonight with large scale ascent 
acting as a lifting mechanism for the scattered showers. The cold 
front will slowly move eastward across the southern Appalachians 
Monday with daytime heating generating widespread showers/storms 
ahead of the boundary for one more day. High freezing levels and 
PWATs will once again cause locally heavy rainfall Monday 
afternoon before the front exits the region and finally allows a 
surface high to begin to bring a drier airmass Monday night. Near 
to below normal temps will continue through Monday due to limited 
sunshine.

.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Sunday)...

The period begins with the last hurrah of our ongoing rain event.
The culprit H5 trough axis will move east of the area as a 
shortwave trough moves into the Great Lakes and gives our old 
trough axis a shove out. After Monday evening, rain chances should
drop quickly, with no POPS in the forecast for Tuesday and 
Tuesday night. A stronger piece of energy will then drop into the 
MS Valley Wednesday which will work upon some marginal return 
moisture to produce a round of showers and tstms late Wed and Wed 
night with light scattered showers Thursday. Rapid drying again 
occurs Thurs evening, and Friday looks to be an unseasonably 
comfortable day for mid June with below normal temps and lower 
humidities. Extended models then diverge for late week, with the 
GFS bringing in another system, but the Europeans and Canadians 
favoring a dry pattern. Will toss in some 20 percent POPS for 
Saturday.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Sunday)...
Pattern continues to be rather 
stagnant, with the upper low centered over western TN making only 
slow progress east and northeast. This low will gradually weaken and 
open up during the short term, but will continue to move very 
slowly. We will remain in a very moist environment, with PW values 
running between 1.5 and 2 inches for the most part across the area. 
Pieces of weak short wave energy will eject out of the base of the 
upper low and will help to enhance showers and thunderstorms at 
times. One of these is helping to enhance the current activity, 
although the southeast low level downslope flow is acting to inhibit 
activity across much of the valley. Models are struggling to handle 
timing of these weak impulses as is often the case, but it looks 
like another will affect the area later tonight and/or during 
Sunday. 

The southeast low level flow across the mountains is forecast to 
weaken a bit later tonight into Sunday, so activity in the valley 
should have less downslope flow to inhibit it.  

Given the moist environment and the possibility of training 
showers/storms, along with expected efficient rain processes given 
the high freezing levels/skinny CAPE profiles, the threat of 
localized flooding will continue for the short term. Will continue 
to mention this threat in the HWO, but no flood/flash flood watch at 
this time as the risk of widespread flooding does not look high at 
this time.

.LONG TERM...(Sunday night through Saturday)...Models are in 
fairly good agreement through the extended. By 00Z Monday, an h50 
open wave is progged to be situated through the Tennessee valley 
and southeast while a strong shortwave moves through the northern 
plains. The surface reflection depicts an are of low pressure 
situated across central KY with a trailing frontal boundary 
through central TN and AL. Low level winds will be south to 
southeasterly to start the extended period continuing to transport
moisture northward. Increased forcing for ascent can be expected 
Sunday night into Monday associated with the wave as several mid 
level waves travel through weak mid level flow leading to 
continued SHRA/TSRA.

During the day Monday, the northern shortwave continues to move 
eastward into the Great Lakes and as a result elongates the mid 
level circulation across the Appalachians. This results in a 
weakened shear axis while low pressure develops further north under 
h50 height falls in the Great lakes. Forcing for ascent and 
convergence along the front should be sufficient for scattered to 
numerous SHRA/TSRA through much of the afternoon. Will need to watch 
for areas of heavy rain and flash flooding as PWAT values will still 
be in the 1.5 to 1.75 inch range and combined with high freezing 
level heights means that conditions will be favorable for efficient 
warm rain processes. Temperatures Sunday night through Monday should 
be near to slightly below normal.

The front moves through the region Monday night with high pressure 
at the surface quickly moving in behind it. This results in a brief 
period of dry weather ahead of the next system. Upper level heights 
begin to fall ahead of a developing shortwave trough to the 
northwest. Low pressure at the surface develops in the midwest by 
12Z Wednesday before moving into the Great Lakes and deepening by 
00Z Thursday. SHRA/TSRA are forecast to move back into the region 
Wednesday/Wednesday night ahead of the developing trough and 
associated cold front. The front will pass through the area by 
Thursday with high pressure at the surface developing behind it. Dry 
weather returns for the latter part of next week with temperatures 
near normal and lower relative humidity values.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
402 AM EDT Sat Jun 8 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today through Sunday)...

Coverage of showers has significantly decreased over the past few
hours, and lightning is not currently being detected anywhere in 
east TN, southwest VA, and southwest NC. Mainly chance pops will 
cover the remainder of the night. 

The upper level low currently centered around the west
TN valley will continue to slowly move eastward. Expect showers 
to expand in coverage again from mid morning through the afternoon
as another 300 mb jet streak rotates around the system across the
southern Appalachian region and enhances lift. As daytime heating
takes place, surface based CAPE will increase to 1000-2000 J/Kg, 
so will once again mention thunderstorms embedded within the rain 
showers from late morning into the evening. Locally heavy rainfall
will once again occur underneath the strongest showers and 
thunderstorms since there continues to be high PWAT values of 1.70
to over 2.00 inches and a deep warm cloud layer with freezing 
levels between 12,500 and 14,000 ft. Shear parameters continue to 
be very weak, but there could be an isolated strong to severe 
storm with gusty winds due to a few hundred joules of downdraft 
CAPE this afternoon and heavy precip loading to enhance downdraft 
strength. 

Flooding potential today continues to look localized. Recent
rainfall has eased the dry conditions that had been in place,
however, as the low moves into middle TN, the squeeze between the
low and high pressure over the Northeast U.S. will cause
southeasterly surface flow. This is a downsloping situation for
much of east TN and southwest VA which typically leads to lighter
overall rainfall compared to what is shown by model guidance. The
one exception will be in Cherokee and Clay counties NC where
possible bands of heavier rainfall may have to be monitored later
today. The majority of the heavy rain today should occur on the
east side of the Blue Ridge across NC where upsloping is favored,
so for these reasons, have not issued a Flash Flood Watch for any
of our CWA. We will continue to mention localized flooding/flash 
flooding in the HWO. 

As the jet dynamics shift off to the north tonight and some
diurnal cooling also takes place, coverage of showers/storms will
once again decrease, so lowered pops to reflect the reduced
coverage. The cut off low will not move much heading into Sunday,
so with continued moisture transport, spokes of mid/upper level energy
rotating around it, high PWATs, warm cloud layer, and afternoon 
heating, showers/storms with locally heavy rain will develop again.
This will result in additional localized flooding. Temps will
remain below average this weekend.


.LONG TERM...(Sunday night through Saturday)...

A slowly eastward drifting open H5 trough axis will be roughly 
along the I-75 corridor Sunday night and will move to the TN/NC 
state line by sunset Monday. This means a continuation of humid 
and convective conditions for those periods, and localized heavy 
rains and associated flooding risks will continue through Monday 
in our forecast area. These rains will finally taper off from west
to east Monday night to Tuesday thanks to the passing of the 
trough axis, probably with low POPs lingering near the eastern 
mountains. However, a sharp H5 trough will move through the Plains
into the MS Valley Tuesday night and Wednesday, which will resume
showers and some tstms again across middle and east TN Wednesday 
and Wed evening. The rains that return midweek do not appear to be
as potentially heavy. 

As this second system closes off across the Great Lakes, our winds 
aloft will become westerly and drying will resume, except for light 
precip mainly along and north of I-40 Thursday. This Great Lakes 
system, however, will usher in some unseasonably cool temperatures 
for mid June, with min temps Friday morning in the low to mid 50s 
across the Valley, and sunny highs in the 70s to near 80 on Friday 
afternoon with lower humidity! Warmer temperatures and muggy air 
will return for the weekend.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
253 PM EDT Fri Jun 7 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Saturday)...Pattern will be rather 
stagnant for the short term, with the upper low centered near 
Memphis TN making only slow progress east and northeast.  We will 
remain in a very moist environment, with PW values running between 
1.5 and 2 inches for the most part across the area. Pieces of weak 
short wave energy will eject out of the base of the upper low and 
will help to enhance showers and thunderstorms at times. One of 
these is exiting to the northeast early this afternoon. Models often 
do not handle timing of these weak impulses well, but at this point 
it looks like another weak wave will be affecting our area later 
tonight. Another interesting part of this equation is the 
strengthening of the southeast low level flow across the mountains, 
which should bring some downslope motion to inhibit precipitation at 
least to some extent in the northern and central valley areas later 
tonight and especially Saturday. Will carry lower PoPs in these 
areas.  

Given the moist environment and the possibility of training 
showers/storms, along with expected efficient rain processes given 
the high freezing levels/skinny CAPE profiles, the threat of 
localized flooding will continue for the short term. Will continue 
to mention this threat in the HWO, but no flood/flash flood watch at 
this time as the risk of widespread flooding does not look high at 
this time.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday night through Friday)...By 00Z Sunday, a large closed h50 low will be situated 
across the Ohio/Tennessee valley providing deep forcing for ascent 
with extensive cloud cover and precipitation expected to be ongoing. 
At the surface, an area of low pressure is forecast to be located 
across west/central Tennessee providing a southerly flow across the 
area. Moisture content will be high with precipitable water values 
in excess of 1.75 inches and mean layer RH values greater than 90%. 
The closed low will gradually progress to an open wave through the 
day on Sunday as it interacts with the shortwave moving through the 
northern plains. Upper forcing for ascent along with deep saturated 
profiles will support numerous rain showers through the day. 
Elevated instability supports chances of convection which if this 
does occur then potential flash flooding concern increases. 
Temperatures Sunday will be cooler given the extensive cloud cover 
and rainfall.  

Monday, the upper level wave further weakens with a well defined 
shear axis across the Appalachians. At the surface, a wave should be 
aligned along the spine of the Appalachians.  Upper forcing for 
ascent along with low level frontal convergence will be conducive 
for upward motion and precipitation. Forecast soundings indicate 
near moist adiabatic lapse rates with a nearly saturated column 
leading to efficient precipitation processes. Again will need to 
watch for flash flooding but the quick nature of the boundary and 
cloud layer winds orthogonal to this boundary means training is of 
low concern. The upper level shear axis and associated frontal wave 
become less evident as a potent jet streak to the north quickly 
evacuates northward out of the Great Lakes. West to northwest flow 
fills in behind the frontal passage with surface high pressure 
moving into the region. Increased subsidence associated with this 
feature will begin to dry the area out through Tuesday night. 
Temperatures during this time will be near normal to slightly below 
normal.  

By 18Z Wednesday a shortwave trough/PV anomaly is forecast to drop 
out of the northern plains and Midwest. The surface will feature an 
area of low pressure directly underneath the upper level low. The 
response to lowering pressure to the west will be to veer low level 
winds toward the south. The result will be increased low level 
moisture. Another area of low pressure at the surface will develop 
underneath lower heights across the Florida peninsula. The PV 
anomaly and jet streak rounding the base of the shortwave trough 
will provide large-scale forcing for ascent Wednesday 
afternoon/evening with increased precipitation expected. Marginal 
instability parameters support chances of thunder during this time 
as well. The latter portions of the extended feature fairly good 
model-to-model agreement with a deep layer trough axis extending 
from Hudson Bay southward into the GoM. Increased large-scale 
forcing supports keeping slight chance to chance PoPs through 
Thursday.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
322 AM EDT Fri Jun 7 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today through Saturday)... 
The first wave of showers have gradually lifted north overnight 
toward the KY border and into southwest VA as the warm front and 
isentropic lift along it is lifting north. As the upper low now 
centered near eastern OK and AR slowly moves into the TN valley, a
wet pattern will continue through the short term. A true tropical
airmass will lock in place south of the above mentioned warm 
front with PWAT values increasing to 1.70 to 2.00+ inches from 
late tonight through the weekend as well as a deep warm cloud 
layer with freezing levels of around 13,000 ft at TRI and over 
14,000 ft at TYS and CHA. CAPE values through the period will be 
long and skinny. All of this being said, any showers and 
thunderstorms will produce highly efficient rainfall rates with 
little to no hail contamination expected. 

In terms of rainfall coverage, the two most concentrated periods of 
more widespread, steadier rainfall still look to be late tonight 
through midday Friday then again Saturday. The left exit of a 300 mb 
jet streak shifting over the southern Appalachian region late 
tonight through Friday morning will strengthen the low-level jet 
to 30 kts. This enhanced warm and moist advection should blossom a
solid shield of rain and thunder, and most CAMS suggest rain 
filling in after 08Z then moving north through the region. After 
this jet streak moves away Friday afternoon, rainfall coverage 
will transition to diurnally driven scattered showers and 
thunderstorms in the deep cyclonic flow under the approaching 
upper low. Locally heavy rainfall will continue in the strongest 
cores with 1-2" per hour rates possible at times.

Expect a slight decrease in coverage Friday night before the second 
wave of steadier rain arrives Saturday morning. The surface and 
upper low will be nearly stacked in west/middle TN on Saturday with 
another upper level jet streak rotating across the southern 
Appalachians on the east side of the system. This will once again
enhance the low and mid level moisture transport leading to a 
fairly solid shield of rain and thunder. After collaboration with 
neighboring offices, decided to hold off on a flood watch at this 
time. Much of the area has had below normal rainfall in the past 
month, but would expect reports of localized river, stream, and 
low- lying area flooding to increase Saturday since we will have 
seen multiple rounds of rain by that time to overcome the dry 
antecedent conditions. 

Likely to categorical pops will cover late tonight through midday 
Friday then again Saturday. Likely pops are expected outside of 
these periods. Temps will average below normal due to the cloud 
cover and rain.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday night through Friday)...
A slowly weakening H5 closed low will be sitting over western TN 
Saturday night, keeping east TN and adjacent areas under warm and 
humid conditions. The low will open as a long wave trough during 
Sunday, although still to our west. This barely moving system will
keep rounds of precip impacting the area, with several inches of 
rainfall to be seen by most areas throughout the event. Localized 
flooding risks will probably increase each day as soils moisten 
from antecedent rainfall. Upsloping winds could focus heavier 
rainfall in the mountains of the Carolinas and Georgia this 
weekend, which may result in rises on rivers flowing into TN from 
western NC, like the Pigeon and French Broad and Hiwassee and 
Nolichucky. Experimental probabilistic ensemble river hydrographs 
have yet to show a river forecast point get above flood stage, but
this will be monitored as the event continues to unfold over the 
next few days.

Models suggest precip will push off to the east Tuesday as the long 
wave trough axis finally does as well, but GFS/ECMWF/Canadian all 
agree that precip returns on Wednesday as a clipper reinforces 
troughing over the Mississippi valley and draws moisture back into 
the area. Scattered precip chances will continue into Thursday.

dissipating as expected, and will likely only affect SW VA over the 
next hour or two. Through today, we will continue to have deep Gulf 
moisture feeding into the area on the eastern side of a cutoff low 
over TX/OK. Forcing is generally weak over our area today, but any 
weak residual boundaries or low level convergence will be enough to 
spark a shower in this moist environment. The forecast will 
broadbrush likely PoPs area-wide this afternoon as pinpointing a 
favored location is highly uncertain.  

A shortwave trough rotating around the southern portion 
of the cutoff low this morning will track NE across MS/AL through 
today, and influence our area with the potential for heavy rain 
starting this evening. Strong lift associated with frontogenetic 
forcing in a jet exit region will begin to move into our southern 
sections around midnight. The NAM is most bullish on this forcing, 
placing the nose of a 40-50 kt LLJ with strong low level convergence 
at the TN/GA border. Other models follow this trend but are not as 
agressive with lift and QPF as the NAM - the forecast will follow 
this concensus by mentioning locally heavy rainfall in the southern 
sections tonight with QPF amounts there around 1 inch, which is 
close to the SREF mean. Through tonight, the focus of heavy rainfall 
should be slowly drifting northward as the surface low does the 
same. With fairly dry conditions preceding this rainfall, no 
widespread flooding problems are anticipated, although this round 
will be setting the stage for what is to come this weekend. 

.LONG TERM...(Friday through Thursday)...
The main focus in the long-term continues to be the periods of 
heavy rainfall Friday through early next week. A surface low and 
parent upper level low still look to become stacked in the lower 
Mississippi valley and west TN valley Friday with this system very
slowly moving eastward across the TN valley and deep South this 
weekend due to a strong northern stream ridge setting up across 
the Great Lakes. This is a classic Rex block where the low is "cut
off" underneath the ridge to the north. Guidance suggests that 
the closed low will finally open up by Monday and begin to eject 
toward the eastern seaboard as a long-wave trough develops in the 
upper Midwest and Great Lakes, however, the latest runs of the 
ECMWF and GFS have slowed and now suggest the system lingering 
near the Carolinas and throwing some moisture back into far east 
TN, southwest NC, and southwest VA into Wednesday. Suspect that 
this slower trend is accurate considering that models tend to move
out summertime cut off lows too quickly.

The first round of steadier rain looks to cross much of the region 
Friday morning as the left front quadrant of a diffluent 300 mb 
southwesterly jet moves over the region and strengthens the 850 mb 
jet to 30-40 kts. The NAM is the most aggressive with this strong 
low-level jet early Friday morning as it tries to develop a 
secondary meso low near the southern valley, whereas the GFS and 
ECMWF suggest a more modest low-level jet. Nevertheless, periods of 
moderate to heavy rain will occur as strong 925-700 mb moisture flux 
and theta e advection take place bringing tropical moisture from the 
Gulf into the region. PWATs of 1.60 to 2.00+ inches still look to be 
advected into the area in this tropical airmass with freezing levels 
of 13,000-14,000 feet. A few hundred joules of ML CAPE will allow 
for band of convection within this rain shield leading to periods of 
torrential rainfall. The good news is that the ground has become dry 
in recent weeks, so we can handle a decent amount of rain before 
flooding begins.

After the initial wave Friday morning, scattered areas of convection 
will redevelop in the afternoon as surface CAPE increases under the 
upper system followed by some diurnal decrease in coverage Friday 
night. Again, locally heavy rainfall rates will occur under any 
convective cells with greater than 1 inch per hour rainfall rates 
not out of the question.

The second window of steadier rain looks to come Saturday when 
another enhanced mid and low-level jet crosses the region and 
interacts with the continued deep tropical airmass. Localized 
flooding could begin at this time since there will be repeated 
rounds of rain leading up to it. New WPC guidance places a marginal 
risk of excessive rainfall in southwest VA and much of northeast TN 
with slight risk in the southern valley and southwest NC day 2. The 
entire CWA is in the slight risk for excessive rainfall on day 3, 
and after collaboration with WPC, a moderate risk has been 
introduced from the Chattanooga area to southwest NC. Some decrease 
in coverage will again occur Saturday night.

Timing and coverage of heavier rain is more difficult to discern 
Sunday and Monday. The upper system will be slowly moving east which 
will in turn take the enhanced jet dynamics toward the Carolinas, 
but moderate instability, continued high PWATs, and warm cloud layer 
with high freezing levels underneath the upper system will promote 
diurnal increases in convective coverage each afternoon with swaths 
of heavy rain and localized flooding/flash flooding. 

Chance pops will continue Tuesday and Tuesday night, but the 
heaviest rain threat should be over. Dry weather should finally 
arrive Wednesday and Wednesday night with brief high pressure. Temps 
will average a little below normal Friday through Tuesday followed 
by moderation to near normal Wednesday.

FXUS64 KMRX 051914
