Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
314 PM EDT Wed Jun 5 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Thursday)...

The synoptic outlook begins with a developing surface low over the 
Great Lakes region with an associated mid level wave. Some weak 
ridging in the northern Great Plains states with a developing low 
pressure center over New Mexico that is slowly moving to the east. 
As this low over the American southwest moves lee of the Rockies, it 
will produce plenty of WAA from the Gulf into the southern and mid 
Atlantic states.

The previously mentioned H5 shortwave will produce showers and 
thunderstorms for eastern Tennessee and southwestern Virginia this 
afternoon and evening. The main threats look to be a combination of 
damaging winds and heavy rain. NAM soundings show MLCAPE peaking 
around 2000 J/kg in the south with slightly decreasing values 
further northward. Consistent deep layer shear of around 30 knots 
suggest that some areas of convection could develop into severe 
storms. DCAPE upwards of 650 J/kg and inverted V soundings point to 
potential downbursts and outflows of 60+ mph, while high PW values 
ranging between 1.50in and 2.00in show the possibility of localized 
heavy rainfall with runoff an localized flooding possible from any 
training storms. Hail threat is lower but possible, with some decent 
HCAPE and modest SHIP values between 0.5 and 0.7. Tornado potential 
is also low as LCL heights will be greater than 1000m and low level 
shear is weak.

CAMs are still inconsistent on this event, with the NAM showing the 
initial cells in the northern portion of the CWA dying out as the 
mid level wave continues east with any evening storms staying well 
to the north into Kentucky. The HRRR, while similar to the NAM, 
shows a few isolated cells forming just to the west and moving 
northeast through the CWA. A second round of convection looks 
possible for the northern half of the CWA later tonight due to the 
decrease in cloud cover. Worth noting that both the NAM and GFS 
soundings show a decrease in MLCAPE and 0-6km shear into the 
overnight hours, so any storms that form will have a more difficult 
time produce severe weather.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday night through Wednesday)...

Overall...the Southern Appalachian Region will transition into a 
rather active weather pattern for much of the extended. 
Initially...a frontal boundary will be over the general area as a 
short waves rides along it. This will keep scattered convection 
moving across the area Thursday night. At this time...with lack of
diurnal heating... weakening instabiltiy and limited upper level 
support...expect the threat of strong to severe storms to be 
minimal. 

The main feature to watch during the extended will be an upper low 
currently moving out of the southern plains.  This low will track 
across the Mississippi Valley and eventually push through the 
Southern Appalachian Region.  The low will strengthen over time and 
will become cut off as in moves towards the area.  This 
intensification will slow the movement of the low significantly.  As 
a result...expect it to begin to affect the area on Friday as 
circulation around the low increases low level moisture and begins 
to destabilized the air mass over the area.  The low will struggle 
with its eastward propagation and is currently progged to move 
through late this weekend and eventually open up and slide out of 
the area around the Monday time frame.   From Friday through the 
weekend...the air mass in place will be weak to occasionally 
moderately unstable.  Shear is more directional with limited speed 
shear.  At this point...strong to severe storms can not be ruled 
out...but chances are slight and the main threat will be 
flooding/flash flooding.  Low level moisture will increase 
substantially through the rest of the week.  Recent dry conditions 
will allow for decent rainfall amounts before flooding becomes a 
concern.  However...as the week progresses and we receive rainfall 
each day...by this weekend...this could potentially create localized 
problems with flooding/flash flooding.  

Widespread convection will continue over the region into Monday as a 
front pushes the low out.  Convection chances will decrease 
significantly Tuesday and Wednesday.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
328 AM EDT Wed Jun 5 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
A shortwave trough is currently producing some convection in srn
IL/wrn KY, and this feature will be moving east through the
morning. The general concensus of the short term hi-res models is
that convection with the trough will move into our area this 
morning, affecting mainly the northern half. Residual boundaries
from this morning activity are expected to settle across the
southern half in the afternoon, which may provide a focus for
additional development. With abundant CAPE and adequate shear, 
this will pose a threat of severe storms. An inverted V profile
and high DCAPE in the NAM sounding suggests a damaging wind
threat, and MLCAPE over 2000 J/kg points to a large hail
potential as well. The tornado potential appears low as LCLs are
high and low level helicity, while present, is weak. 

Convection is expected to blossom near the OH Valley this
afternoon, with the activity moving south across ern KY through
the evening. The NAM is bullish on these storms maintaining some
intensity as they enter our area tonight, but other models weaken 
it significantly before it gets this far south. The forecast will 
keep high chance PoPs in northern areas tonight, but expect that 
it will be weakening and should not pose a severe threat.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Wednesday)...
The northern stream trough will begin lifting northeast Thursday 
as a southern stream upper low moves into the southern Plains. 
This upper low will induce a weak surface low with the system 
closing off and becoming virtually stacked in the vicinity of the 
lower Mississippi Valley and west TN valley Friday through the 
weekend. Latest guidance appears slightly slower with the movement
of this cut off low compared to 24 hours ago and is also more in 
agreement that the system will slowly track across the deep south 
instead of moving toward the Ohio Valley. These trends are 
reasonable since a Rex Block develops by the weekend with northern
stream longwave troughing from the Pacific northwest into the 
northern Plains and longwave ridging in the Great Lakes and 
northeast causing the cut off low to be stuck underneath around 
the deep South.

In terms of sensible weather across east TN, southwest VA, and 
southwest NC, this pattern will lead to frequent showers and 
thunderstorms with the greatest coverage of rainfall expected Friday 
through Monday. Chance pops for showers/storms will occur Thursday 
and Thursday night as WAA and weak impulses moving through the flow 
interact with a slowly lifting frontal boundary. By Friday as the 
stacked low slowly moves into the lower Mississippi Valley, strong 
925-700 mb moisture flux and theta e advection will bring 
increasingly tropical air into the region with PWAT values progged 
to range from 1.50 to 2.00+ inches Friday through the weekend. These 
values are above maximum climatology for early June and are partly 
due to the advection of moisture from a weak tropical disturbance in 
the western Gulf into our region. Likely pops for showers and 
thunderstorms will cover most periods Friday through Monday with 
slightly lower pops during overnight hours. While it will not be 
raining all of the time, the high PW airmass combined with a deep 
warm cloud layer with freezing levels above 13,500 ft will lead to 
heavy rainfall rates. The frequency of the showers/storms which will 
contain these efficient downpours will cause localized flooding, 
especially by the weekend after repeated rounds. WPC continues to 
put much of the region in a marginal risk for excessive rainfall 
beginning day 2 and 3.

A few strong storms cannot be ruled out late week through the 
weekend as the proximity of the cut off low leads to some 
directional shear, however, very weak 0-1 and 0-6 Km speed shear and 
weak mid level lapse rates will keep this threat isolated. The main 
threat from a stronger storm would be strong winds since several 
hundred joules of DCAPE will develop each afternoon as low-level 
lapse rates steepen. 

The cut off low will finally open up and eject eastward Monday and 
Tuesday as longwave troughing develops over the eastern CONUS. 
Likely pops continue most areas Monday but will be reduced to mainly 
chance Monday night and Tuesday. Surface high pressure will finally 
bring dry weather by Tuesday night.

Temps early in the period will be seasonable then cooling to a 
little below normal Friday through the weekend due to the rain and 
clouds before slowly moderating early to mid next week.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
312 PM EDT Tue Jun 4 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight through Wednesday Night)...
Deep upper ridging continues to highlight the pattern across the TN 
Valley and Southern Appalachian region this afternoon, thus favoring 
partly/mostly cloudy skies (consequent of upstream convection over 
the Plains).  At the surface, high pressure centered off the Mid-
Atlantic coastline stretches east across much of the Southeast CONUS 
(favoring sly veering surface winds), while a warm front is draped 
from the Gulf Coast across the MS Delta and northward into the 
Ozarks.  Overall, the remainder of the day looks quite pleasant 
across the region as skies slowly fill in given moisture advection, 
with temperatures in low/mid 80s in the northern valley, mid/upper 
80s southward.

Moving into Wednesday, the fcst becomes somewhat complicated 
overnight tonight as the aforementioned warm front slowly lifts 
northward with weak isentropic ascent to possibly favor iso/sct 
showers, with the best chances in closest proximity to the Plateau 
northward into southwest VA.  Into the later portions of the 
morning, a weak upper impulse (with origins over the Mid MS and 
Lower OH Valleys) will advect eastward across the area providing 
upper support atop the diurnally destabilizing warm sector.  With 
that, CAMs continue to favor a broken multi-cellular line of 
convection that will sweep southward across east TN, southwest VA, 
and eventually into southwest NC through the afternoon hours. The 
SPC has expanded their initial Day 2 slight/marginal outlooks 
slightly southward given 12z guidance favoring enhanced deep shear 
(30-40kts) and instability (2.0-2.5k j/kg sbcape).  Thus, the fcst 
will feature likely pops sweeping across the area from the northwest 
(around 10-11AM EDT timeframe) to southeast (through 6-7PM EDT) for 
showers/thunderstorms, some of which could be severe with damaging 
winds and large hail being the primary threats.  Although not ruled 
out completely, llv srh looks rather weak for tornadoes, mainly due 
to unidirectional profiles and thus straight hodographs. Likewise, 
heavy rainfall will also be a threat with some isolated flash 
flooding possible, although that threat will increase moreso later 
in the week as FFGs lower.

Moving on into the overnight hours Wednesday night (early Thursday 
morning), guidance also favors a secondary more nocturnal MCS 
firing across the OH Valley and eventually advecting southeast.  A 
CAM consensus would suggest this line weakening as it enters the fcst 
area out of southeast KY around/after midnight.  Given the 
uncertainty surrounding this potential complex, kept pops capped in 
the chance range. 

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Tuesday)...
The long term synoptic outlook starts with a mid level wave east of 
the Great Lakes with an associated cold front extending southwest 
across the east coast that will continue to suppress the ridge over 
the southeast. A developing closed low moving just lee of the 
Rockies with a low level jet over LA that will advect warm moist air 
up from the Gulf. The persistent southwesterly flow will help to 
advect the subtropical airmass and raise PW values over the end of 
the work week.

NAM soundings show very saturated temperature profiles and high PW 
values reaching up to 2.00 inches by Thursday night for the southern 
counties which will be above the seasonal maximums. A number of 
airmass showers and thunderstorms expected for Thursday night as we 
will be well within the warmer airmass with continued moisture 
advection from the south. Some disagreement in the models however, 
as NAM soundings show MLCAPE around 1700 J/kg during the early 
afternoon with deep layer shear of around 20 knots which suggests 
the potential for a few embedded thunderstorms. The GFS is looking 
far less optimal however, with MLCAPE under 150 J/kg and deep layer 
shear of 15 knots or less. Leaning more towards the NAM at this 
point, but felt the discrepancy was worth mentioning.

The previously mentioned low pressure center will be over the south-
central Great Plains by late Thursday and looks to become quasi-
stationary from a lack of upper level steering flow. With the low 
positioning to our west, we can expect plenty of WAA from the south 
over the weekend with associated showers and potential afternoon 
thunderstorms. The cut off low looks to sit and spin over the 
central Mississippi valley into and over the weekend then slowly 
transition eastward by early next week. A few areas of localized 
flash flooding are possible from the excessive heavy rainfall over 
the weekend. WPC estimates totals around 1.0 to 2.0 inches for the 
northern to central valley areas with southern and higher elevation 
areas receiving from 3.0 to 5.0 inches.

Models are not in great agreement as to when the low will finally be 
pushed out of the area. The GFS and ECMWF both are showing sometime 
on Tuesday next week due to increasing surface high pressure, drier 
air advection from the north, and quasi-zonal flow aloft. Consensus 
is even less in regard to the direction of the surface low, with the 
GFS showing it drifting towards the southeast while the ECMWF 
depicts it moving up towards the northeast.

FXUS64 KMRX 040703
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
303 AM EDT Tue Jun 4 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Surface high pressure to our north will shift to our east today, 
resulting in a more southerly low level flow that will begin to 
advect moisture and warmer temps into our area. Aloft, there is 
quite a bit of cirrus this morning as a jet streak rounds the top of 
a ridge, but the cloud cover should decrease through the day as the 
flow flattens and the jet streak moves east. Highs will be a few 
degrees warmer than yesterday. 

Tonight, isentropic lift will begin to saturate the midlevels after 
midnight, and aided by some elevated instability, it may bring some 
light precip to the area. Low levels are still rather dry in 
forecast soundings so will keep PoPs in the low to slight chance 
range with light QPF, favoring the northern Plateau counties. A 
slight chance of thunder will be mentioned due to the elevated 
instability.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday through Tuesday)...
An increasingly wet pattern continues to take shape in the long-
term. A weak cold front associated with a northern stream short-
wave trough will first cross the region Wednesday into Wednesday 
night resulting in chance pops for scattered showers and 
thunderstorms. As this trough digs into the Great Lakes, a brief 
period of northwest flow aloft will surpress the upper level ridge
over the Gulf of Mexico. At the same time, a southern stream 
upper level low will be moving from the desert southwest into the 
southern Plains, so heights will quickly rebound Thursday and 
Friday as WAA strengthens ahead of the upper low. The moisture 
return ahead of the low late in the week will bring an 
increasingly humid airmass into east TN, southwest VA, and 
southwest NC with 1.30 to 1.60 PWAT values Thursday and Friday 
increasing to around 2.00 inches this weekend. These values will 
be above maximum climatology. Additionally, soundings suggest a 
warming cloud layer late week through the weekend with high 
freezing levels.

Any showers and thunderstorms late week through the weekend will 
produce heavy downpours, but the main question will be coverage on 
Saturday and Sunday when the best potential of heavy rain looks to 
occur. All guidance suggests that the upper low will stay well to 
the west Thursday and Friday, but weak disturbances ejecting out of 
the system through the southern stream flow combined with the WAA 
pattern will keep scattered showers/storms in the forecast, 
especially during afternoon and evening. Bigger differences arise 
this weekend into early next week. The latest GFS continues to 
gradually move the upper low and resultant surface cyclone 
northeastward toward Ohio, while the ECMWF has a much more closed, 
"cut off" system that meanders across the Tennnessee Valley then 
eventually moving off the Southeast coast by mid next week. Either 
solution brings the greatest chances of heavy rainfall Saturday 
through Monday, but the ECMWF would have periods of steadier 
rainfall while the GFS would be a little more scattered. Thinking 
the best approach to the forecast is to run chance pops Thursday and 
Friday gradually increasing to high end chance and likely Saturday 
and Sunday then pulling back to chance Monday and Tuesday. WPC 
continues to keep our area in a marginal risk for excessive rainfall 
beginning late in the week, so we will mention this possibility in 
the HWO. Preliminary 4 day rainfall totals from Friday through 
Monday range from 1 to 3 inches with the highest amounts across the 
plateau, southern valley, and southwest NC.

With the upper low passing nearby the region this weekend and a 
warm, moist environment firmly in place, some of the thunderstorms 
could be strong to severe. Both 0-6 and 0-1 Km shear will be 
elevated, and surface CAPE values will rise to 1000-1500 J/Kg each 
afternoon. At this time, location and timing of any stronger storms 
is low confidence, but trends will continue to be monitored 
throughout the week.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
312 PM EDT Mon Jun 3 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Tuesday)...Clouds finally starting to 
thin out more this afternoon as the drier air works its way into the 
area. Dewpoints will continue to fall overnight and will range from 
near 40 near our VA counties to near 50 across the extreme southern 
TN Valley. Clear skies and lowering dewpoints will allow overnight 
lows to dip down into the upper 40s to mid 50s for most areas. Light 
northerly winds continue into the night as the surface high pressure 
remains to our northeast.

The high drifts east tomorrow which returns us to a southerly flow 
by the afternoon hours. Rising heights and southerly flow allows 
temps to climb into the low to mid 80s for the high. Though 
climbing, dewpoints will still only be in the mid to upper 50s 
tomorrow afternoon so it will still feel quite nice outdoors with RH 
values ranging from the mid 30s to low 40s.


.LONG TERM...(Tuesday night through Monday)...The extended fcst
period kicks off on Tuesday evening amidst quasizonal H5 flow 
across the eastern CONUS atop the southern stream 590dm 
anticyclone centered over the GOM, all while a closed upper low 
deepens over the Desert Southwest and a shortwave works through 
the northern stream into the lower Great Lakes region. At the 
surface, high pressure will have shifted east across the 
Appalachians, eventually setting up offshore of the Mid-Atlantic 
states as a weak waa regime prevails over the Deep South. 
Into/through Wednesday the aforementioned northern stream 
shortwave looks to dive southeast over the OH Valley region 
favoring suppression of the upper ridge and intrusion of weak 
upper dynamic support via PVA, all warranting elevated regional 
pops. Moving into Thursday, the northern stream shortwave will 
eject eastward while out west the closed H5 cyclone advects east 
into the Plains with surface cyclogenesis to initiate. Closer to 
home, guidance does suggest some weak upper wave impulses moving 
through the mean southern stream flow across the TN Valley and 
Southern Appalachians, thus will keep pops elevated based on 
diurnal trends.

By Friday morning the pattern becomes increasingly active as the 
Plains H5 low and subsequent surface cyclone work to increase waa 
across the MidSouth and TN Valley.  Unfortunately it is also at this 
point that guidance tends to diverge in their solutions, thus 
introducing uncertainty. The GFS features an opening upper low as it 
moves northeast across the Ozarks into the mid/upper MS and lower OH 
valleys, approaching the lower Great Lakes.  The ECMWF on the other 
hand keeps the upper cyclone closed off longer as it advects further 
east, never really ejecting northward. Essentially, both solutions 
would suggest a wet pattern across the MidSouth region, however with 
uncertainty increasing eastward into Middle and east TN. Therefore 
it's still to early to iron out the details at the end of the work 
week into the weekend, but increasing precipitation chances are 
expected/fcst.  Likewise, given the possible proximity of the closed 
upper cyclone (especially in the ECMWF), deep shear will be 
elevated, which combined with modest instability thanks to sustained 
waa could present the threat for strong storms.  Given model fcst 
pwats well into the upper quartile (possibly approaching daily 
maxes), combined with the potential for a slowly progressing system, 
wouldn't be suprised to see modest QPF and perhaps an increased 
flooding threat Friday and through the weekend.  In fact, WPC 
already has the TN Valley and Southern Appalachian region 
highlighted in the Marginal risk for excessive rainfall on 
Wednesday/Thursday, would expect that to extend in time as days 
progress.  Otherwise, expect near normal temperatures through the 
period.

produce strong and gusty winds with storms, possiblly damaging winds.
Decent lapse rates and favorable WBZ of 9500-10,000ft could produce 
1/2 to 1 inch size hail with the stronger storms.

Light winds this morning will give way to southwest winds increasing 
to 9-12kts sustain with gusts up to 15-20kts possible this afternoon.

will be in the process of rounding the base of this shortwave 
axis. At the surface, there isn't much reflection but a very weak
boundary will be located through the forecast area moving east. 
The aforementioned shortwave trough will provide large-scale 
forcing for ascent during the day on Friday. CAPE values are 
forecast to be around 1500-2500 j/kg by the afternoon across

further south and west as the better mid lvl cooling will be

the lower MS Valley region will put us in a dry and stable NW flow 
pattern through Tuesday with a warming trend. The ridge breaks down

.DISCUSSION...
Current surface analysis indicates a surface low across the Great
Lakes with a weak cold front trailing southward across the
Mississippi Valley. An associated shortwave is located across the
Upper Mississippi Valley and will move southeast toward our
forecast area through tomorrow.

As this front moves eastward today, it will continue to weaken but
provide some weak surface convergence. With MLCAPE near 1000 to
1250 J/Kg across the central and northern portions of the forecast
area-generally near or north of Interstate 40-and effective shear
near 50 kt, the atmosphere will be favorable for storm
organization and maintenance. The primary marginal risk of severe
weather will be for damaging winds with DCAPE of 800 to 1000 J/Kg
across the northern sections. The stronger shear across these 
areas could support some storm rotation, and any localized 
rotating updrafts could increase the risk of isolated severe 
hail. It is important to note that low-level shear is very weak 
which will limit any tornadic potential. This idea is shown in 
recent CAMs showing convection developing across the Cumberland 
Plateau this evening and tracking ENE across the Tennessee Valley.

As the upper trough tracks toward the region tonight,
chance/slight chance rain showers or isolated thunderstorms will 
continue, but the severe threat should quickly diminish after
about 02z tonight as instability decreases.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
The upper pattern this morning continues to feature a dominant ridge 
across the Deep South, while a longwave trough prevails out west 
with an embedded closed H5 cyclone slowly sliding east across the 
northern Plains.  This pattern continues to promote deep swly flow 
across the MS/OH and TN Valley region, with a series of weak 
impulses embedded in the mean H5 flow to advect northward across the 
MidSouth into the OH Valley today.  At the surface, ridging (albeit 
weaker than day's past) remains across the Southern Appalachian 
region, with weak wave activity expected to traverse northeast 
beneath the aforementioned H5 vort impulses today.  With that, 
guidance continues to suggest these impulses moving in close 
proximity to northeast TN and southwest VA this afternoon, which 
combined with ample instabilty, would suggest increased chances for 
showers/thunderstorms.  Thus, while the remainder of the fcst area 
remains dry today, did add in slight/chance pops across portions of 
extreme northeast TN and southwest VA where recent CAM blends favor 
the most fcst coverage. Given weak flow aloft, and thus weak shear 
through the profile, would expect any convection to remain 
disorganized. That said, profiles do feature steep enough lapse 
rates and sufficient dcape to produce some small hail and perhaps a 
few gusty downbursts. 

Otherwise, temperatures will remain nearly 2 categories above normal 
levels, the warmest of which being furthest south where skies are 
expected to be less cloudy.  Winds today will increase with mixing, 
which could favor a few low end wly gusts. Any pops will taper into 
the evening/overnight with loss of heating and northeastward 
advection of the weak upper impulses, therefore the fcst will dry 
out across the board after midnight.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Wednesday)...
By 12Z Thursday, a positively tilted shortwave trough will be 
located over the midwest while a PV anomaly rounds the base of the 
trough across the four corners region.  This PV anomaly should 
become absorbed into the midwest shortwave as the shortwave drops 
into the Ohio valley Thursday night into Friday. Closer to the MRX 
area, a few weak disturbances moving through southwest flow aloft 
could produce isolated showers during the day Thursday. At the 
surface, the induced surface low located over Illinois will 
gradually weaken as it traverses the Ohio valley while a trailing 
cold front slowly moves through the Midsouth and Tennessee valley. A 
secondary low could develop across the Midsouth under increasing 
height falls aloft and move northeast into Ohio by 21Z Thursday. The 
front, barely noticeable in surface fields, is forecast to move 
through the forecast area Thursday night into Friday morning. At 
least weak surface convergence and low level moisture should be 
enough to keep slight chances of showers and thunderstorms over 
portions of the forecast area through Thursday night.  

The shortwave trough/PV anomaly moving through the Ohio valley will 
begin to approach the area on Friday.  Guidance also hints at a 
strengthening 80-90 knot upper lvl jet streak across the Tennessee 
valley and southern Appalachians with northern portions of the 
forecast area in the left front region of this jet.  This will 
increase synoptic scale lift and combined with some low to mid lvl 
moisture will tend to increase PoPs during the day Friday.  Overall 
instability is weak but should be sufficient for scattered 
thunderstorms.  

The upper level shortwave will depart the area Friday night into 
Saturday leaving quasizonal flow in its wake.  A deepening low 
across SE Canada will promote a northwest flow regime aloft for the 
latter part of the weekend bringing slightly cooler conditions (near 
normal for this time of year) to the area.  Daytime highs Saturday 
and Sunday should reach the mid to upper 80s.  Models do show a 
couple of PV anomalies moving through the flow, but it is difficult 
to tell if these are convective feedback issues or actual 
disturbances aloft. At least slight chance to chance PoPs will be 
left in the forecast for Sunday to account for these latest model 
trends. Models are in pretty good agreement toward the latter 
portions of the extended with the main differences being related to 
how amplified the upper lvls become. The GFS is more amplified than 
the ECMWF however both would keep the area under a northwest flow 
regime and keep temperatures near average for this time of year. 
High pressure at the surface should keep conditions dry through 
Tuesday night.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Wednesday)...

The synoptic forecast begins with the ridge over the southeast

today will be above the seasonal average with some areas near record 
highs despite the increasing cloud cover. The low level 850mb flow

produce some gusting winds with the southwesterly flow.

Both the GFS and ECMWF hint at a slight chance for some 
afternoon/evening showers and storms for the southwestern area of 
the CWA along the plateau due to a subtle shortwave moving through 
the mid levels. NAM soundings show nearly super-adiabatic low level 
lapse rates for this afternoon with an isothermal layer around 700mb 
and very dry air aloft. Storm formation may be difficult because of 
the ridging and any cells that do initiate probably won't last for 
too long. Clearing skies and calm overnight winds will allow for 
potential localized fog formation along the major rivers and low 
valleys for the early morning tomorrow.

Wednesday afternoon will present another chance for showers and 
thunderstorms for the more northern area of the CWA. A mid level 
shortwave moving along the ridge axis looks to drop far enough to 
the south to provide some additional lifting along with diurnal 
heating. Went with slight to chance PoP's for southwestern Virginia 
and northeastern Tennesee as soundings show the isothermal layer 
weakening significantly by the end of the period as the ridge begins 
to break down. With heights similar to Tuesday, expect temperatures 
for Wednesday to remain well above normal.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday night through Tuesday)...

The good news in the extended is that the persistent upper ridge 
will begin to break down late week. Approaching shortwaves will 
result in height falls across the region on Thursday suppressing the 
ridge to our south. The surface cold front will weaken as it moves 
south, but weak convergence will allow a few showers or 
thunderstorms to develop with chance PoPs late Thursday. Front moves 
south of the area by Friday with upper flow becoming quasizonal.

Numerical model guidance is consistent with several shortwaves will 
dive southeast from the Upper Midwest through the weekend amplifying 
the upper trough across the Atlantic Coast. This will place the 
region under NW flow aloft with cooler temperatures expected late 
week through the weekend - closer to normal for this time of year. 
With strongest forcing across NE TN/SW VA have chance PoPs most days 
in these locations.

Next week, guidance indicates upper level NW flow remaining across 
the region with several weak disturbances potentially impacting our 
weather. However, low-level ridging increasing across the region and 
to our south may help to suppress convection and keep us mostly dry.

While we will see a reprieve from the near record heat, rain 
chances remain low across the region through the extended.

FXUS64 KMRX 280806
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
406 AM EDT Tue May 28 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Upper heights continue to rise this morning as an upper ridge 
amplifies across the southeast CONUS, while surface high pressure 
prevails beneath.  With that, deep swly/wly flow will dominate today 
amidst partly cloudy skies.  Highs today will once again be 2-3 
categories above normal levels, which will favor ample/deep mixing 
and perhaps some low end wind gusts in the 15-20mph range.  As for 
any precipitation, some guidance sources favor chances for 
showers/thunderstorms over the Plateau this afternoon with peak 
heating, while others keep things dry given strong 
subsidence/capping. With this uncertainty in mind, did include pops 
for these areas, but kept them at slight chance levels. Otherwise, 
should be fairly nice/hot day.  Overnight, skies should clear out 
allowing for modest radiational cooling, which may lead to some 
river/mtn valley fog.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday through Tuesday)...
The persistent upper level ridging that has dominated most of the 
past week will finally begin to break down later this week allowing 
for northwest flow aloft by the weekend.  The result will bring a 
cooler weather pattern with increasing chances of precipitation.  By 
mid week, the synoptic configuration will consist of deep layer 
ridging across most of the southeast with troughing across the west. 
The surface features high pressure to the south and east with low 
pressure moving across the central plains and midwest. Subsidence 
from ridging aloft should keep most of the area dry on Wednesday and 
Wednesday night with the exception of northern areas where 
thunderstorm activity could occur on the periphery of the ridge. 
Another warm day is expected with highs in the upper 80s to low 90s. 
 The ridge begins to break down and shift east Thursday as the upper 
low across the Rockies begins to become absorbed into the Hudson Bay 
vortex. An area of low pressure at the surface will move into the 
Great Lakes with a trailing cold front tracking through the Midsouth 
and Arklatex.  The frontal boundary should weaken as it approaches 
the area late Thursday night into Friday morning, as is typical for 
this time of year.  However, some low level convergence along with 
deep layer moisture will be sufficient to carry slight chance PoPs 
through this time frame.  

This weekend, the upper level pattern features quasi-zonal flow 
aloft with a shortwave trough moving out of the Ohio valley. The 
ECMWF is a bit stronger with this shortwave and as a result 
generates more lift than the weaker GFS.  Both agree on stronger jet 
dynamics aloft which should promote increased lift for slight chance 
to chance PoPs across northeast Tennessee, and southwest Virginia. 
The Hudson Bay vortex strengthens and a result should encourage 
northwest flow aloft across the area through the end of the weekend 
and into early next week.  Several perturbations could track through 
this northwest flow aloft and would bring increasing chances of 
showers and thunderstorms.  Confidence and timing of these upper 
level features remain limited and as a result the forecast reflects 
the lower confidence. Temperatures during this time should be 
slightly cooler with highs in the mid to upper 80s and overnight 
lows in the low to mid 60s.

the persistent upper ridge to a more west to northwest upper flow. 
The primary synoptic feature early on in the long term outlook will 
be the upper level ridge and mid level anticyclone centered over 
Florida. A closed low will be over the northern Rockies tracking 
towards the east with an associated long wave trough extending off 
the Baja coast. A stationary boundary sits just to our north over 
the Ohio valley with a cold front extending into Texas with multiple 
mid level shortwaves that will move along the stationary boundary in 
an ongoing attempt to break down the ridge. The blocking high still 
looks to hold strong through Thursday with a few diurnally driven 
afternoon storms possible for southwestern Virginia and far 
northeast Tennessee where the subsidence is not as strong.

Through Thursday and Friday, the previously mentioned low pressure 
system will move lee of the Rockies and begin to flatten out the 
ridge while taking on a more positive tilt. The cold front 
originating from the low will make it's way across the CWA by 
Thursday night with relatively weak upper dynamics. Model soundings 
show limited instability with CAPEs of 250 to 500 J/kg so only 
scattered showers with a few embedded thunderstorms are expected. A 
more zonal west to northwest flow pattern will be in place behind 
the front as the trough will finally displace the blocking high with 
the remaining stationary boundary setting up to the south. A few 
minor impulses look to produce some showers and potential afternoon 
storms for next weekend with cooler air from the northwest dropping 
daily highs down to the low 80's.

FXUS64 KMRX 270722
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
322 AM EDT Mon May 27 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
The synoptic pattern this morning continues to be highlighted a 
broad H5 anticyclone centered over the central Gulf Coast, while a 
closed cyclone and deep associated longwave trough prevails out 
west.  At the surface, high pressure dominates over the southeast 
CONUS, while a slow moving cold front slides southward across the 
I64 corridor region of KY/WV.  As for the fcst today, another summer-
like day amidst deep ridging with warm swly flow in the low/mid 
levels keeping profiles capped, for the most part.  That said, the 
aforementioned frontal axis will approach the region, likely 
stalling across southeast KY and southwest VA/WV, before moving back 
northward tonight.  Thus, any weak surface convergence along/north 
of I40 (in closest proximity to the surface boundary) will combine 
with weaker ridge induced subsidence to favor increased precipitation 
chances.  Likewise, TRI fcst soundings exhibit modest mucape upward 
of 2.0-2.5k j/kg (which would suggest deeper updrafts), inverted V 
profiles given vast drier air in the BL favoring dcape in excess of 
1k j/kg, all amidst weak deep layer shear.  Therefore, wouldn't be 
suprised to see a couple upright and slow moving strong/severe 
thunderstorms across extreme northeast TN and southwest VA capable 
of damaging downburst winds and large hail.  Otherwise, high 
temperatures will once again be 2-3 categories above normal levels, 
possibly approaching record levels across the southern valley.  As 
for tonight, think any remnant convection will slowly degrade with 
loss of heating leading into a dry yet partly cloudy night.  Lastly, 
wouldn't rule out some patchy dense fog overnight, especially 
in/around any locales that receive abundant rainfall today. 

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Monday)...
Changes coming during the long term. Tuesday through Thursday 
still feature the ridge as being the dominate factor of our 
weather. However, by Thursday afternoon the ridge has been 
displaced off the coast of Florida. This is due to a broad long 
wave trough moving across the Western US during the Tuesday 
through Thursday time frame. The long wave trough has an 
associated low and cold front that will advance toward our 
region. The low is quite strong over the Plains but weakens as it 
moves up toward the Great Lakes. However, the trailing front will 
drift into our area by Thursday evening providing focus for 
showers and Thunderstorms. The front is quite weak so only expect 
scattered showers and storms at best but for all areas.

By Friday, the high that was off the coast of Florida is all but 
gone as the broad long wave trough moves far enough east to finally 
break it down. By this time though the trough really isn't a trough, 
the flow is pretty much zonal. Zonal flow opens up the door for 
showers and storms from Friday through the weekend as several small 
disturbances zip through the flow and across our area. POPs won't be 
higher than chance though as there is no big forcing mechanism that 
moves through (strong front, etc...). 

High temperatures during this time will drop into the lower to 
upper 80s with lows in the lower to mid 60s.

.SHORT TERM...(This Evening through Memorial Day)...
Near record or possibly record highs this afternoon. CHA is pretty 
close to it's daily record high now.

A MCV is moving across the lower Ohio Valley. Some of that activity 
may move into southwest Virginia and far northeast Tennessee. 
Airmass is marginally unstable with MLCAPEs of 500-1000 J/Kg so not 
expecting any severe storms, but DCAPEs of 1100+ J/Kg could produce 
some strong gusty winds. Will include this potential in the HWO.

Otherwise, upper ridge over the area remains in control with 
subsidence and dry airmass across much of the Tennessee 
Valley/southern Appalachians. An convection will dissipate by 
midnight.

For tonight, another round of patchy fog for mainly area 
streams/lakes developing late tonight. Any precipitation over 
southwest Virginia/northeast Tennessee will increase the coverage 
there.

For Memorial Day, models suggest an outflow boundary may move into 
the northern half of Tennessee/southwest Virginia. Southwest flow 
will pull increasing moisture and instability with PWs up to 1.2-1.3 
inches. MLCAPES of 1000-1500 J/Kg. Will include a low chance of 
mainly afternoon showers and thunderstorms generally north of 
interstate 40. Otherwise, another hot day and a little more muggy.

.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Sunday)...
The long term forecast looks to still be under the influence of the 
persistent upper level ridging through most of the outlook. An 
initial synoptic set up of a surface high pressure anticyclone 
located just off the Gulf coast of Florida with deep troughing that 
exists over the American southwest and a developing low pressure 
center over the Four Corners. A weak boundary is located to the 
north of our CWA across the Ohio valley and Great Lakes region with 
a mid level shortwave that look to move along the ridge axis early 
next week. Paired with diurnal heating this mid level wave will 
provide the best possible chance at any precip on Tuesday 
afternoon but looks to be restricted to mostly southwestern Virginia.

With the continued influence of the ridge, the most prominent 
weather for most of the period continues to be the unseasonably warm 
temperatures. Subsidence aloft will restrict a fair amount of cloud 
formation allowing for lots of daytime surface heating. Paired with 
the consistent south to southwesterly WAA bringing in moist 
subtropical air, hot and humid conditions are expected for most of 
the week. With the continued surface heating, the PBL looks to be 
well mixed through the daytime periods with unstable atmospheric 
profiles held back by a capping inversion. Any storms that do manage 
to form will most likely be short lived with the potential of 
producing gusty outflow winds.

By Wednesday night, the previously mentioned cyclone over the Four 
Corners will have tracked eastward to the lee side of the Rockies 
around western Nebraska and will develop a cold front extending 
into the southern Great Plains. While the low pressure center looks 
to remain somewhat stationary and eventually drift to the north, the 
front itself will be propelled forward by the 300mb jet which will 
elongate the boundary. The trough will take on a positive tilt as it 
attempts to push the blocking high to the south thus weakening the 
front as it moves into eastern Tennessee by late Thursday night 
through Friday morning. With the overnight timing of the front and 
weaker troughing at time of FROPA, mostly showers are expected with 
a few embedded thunderstorms possible.

A more zonal pattern will be in place after the passage of the front 
with cooler and drier air expected as the boundary looks to possibly 
stall to our south. Decreased confidence after FROPA due to 
disagreements in the models. The zonal flow will allow the 
shortwaves to quickly move across the Tennessee and Ohio Valleys but 
timing will be difficult.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
337 AM EDT Sun May 26 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...Overall, big picture doesn't 
change much but a few more things to talk about in the short term 
compared to the past few days. 

Strong ridge still located to our south and will once again allow 
for a hot day. Have CHA at 94 today which would tie a record that 
was set back in 1962. TYS and TRI both look to fall a few degrees 
short of their daily record. 

The difference with today is a shortwave trough moves through the 
Ohio River Valley during the late afternoon/evening. As this trough 
draws near the pressure gradient tightens due to the ridge holding 
strong to the south. This allows an 850 mb jet to develop this 
evening of roughly 35 to 40 kts. So expect breezy winds above 2000 
feet with gusts generally from 15 to 20 mph through the night. Areas 
below 2000 feet will be under the nocturnal inversion and won't be 
near as breezy. 

Showers and storms look to develop across western/central KY later 
this afternoon in response to the shortwave. The best lift remains 
north of our area but SWVA and extreme NETN could see some showers 
and storms late but not too confident as all of the CAMs show this 
activity diminishing as it begins to enter the aforementioned areas. 
Will carry slight chance POPs to account for this. Day 1 SPC outlook 
has slight chance risk just to our north but again where the better 
lift will be. 

Other than that, expect a repeat performance of the weather today. 
Overnight lows will be mild again, with lows in the lower to upper 
60s. 



.LONG TERM...(Monday through Sunday)...The extended range fcst period 
kicks off on Monday morning amidst a persistent pattern that 
features continued deep layer ridging, highlighted by a 591dm 
anticyclone centered over the Gulf Coast while surface high 
pressure prevails over the Southern Appalachians. Pattern 
evolution through midweek will be highlighted by said deep ridging
and a series of weak H5 impulses traversing west/east across the 
Great Lakes and northern OH Valley. With that, the best 
opportunity for any notable precipitation continues to center 
around the peak heating hours, and mainly across northeast TN and 
southwest VA given weaker subsidence as well as any weak upper 
support from the passing aforementioned northern H5 waves (and any
associated MCS activity). 

By Tuesday night the pattern begins to alter as the western CONUS H5 
cyclone ejects eastward into the central/northern Plains, 
effectively suppressing the ridge to the east.  This will result in 
height falls over the TN Valley and Southern Appalachian region, 
which could aid convective initiation on Wednesday into Thursday. 
Meanwhile a secondary southern H5 shortwave will eject over the 
southern Plains into Thursday, eventually phasing with the northern 
stream H5 low, and initiating surface cyclogenesis over the 
Arklatex.  This surface front/low complex will advect east through 
Thursday into Friday morning, favoring increased chances for showers 
and thunderstorms.  Behind the front into the weekend, cooler/drier 
surface high pressure looks to build in from the west beneath 
quasizonal H5 flow.

Overall the primary notable weather hazards this upcoming week 
continue to be well above normal temperatures and heat indices in 
the low/mid 90s.  Also, said abundant heating will translate to 
unstable profiles each afternoon, thus any thunderstorms that do 
materialize could produce gusty downburst winds.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
238 PM EDT Sat May 25 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Sunday)...

The near record breaking heat due to the upper level ridge continues 
to be the main story in the short-term forecast period. As of 
early this afternoon, most locations are in the mid 80s to lower 
90s. Heat indices are in the mid to upper 90s across portions of 
the central and southern valley with dewpoints in the upper 60s to
low 70s. However, the overall atmosphere is relatively dry with 
subsidence thanks to the ridge. PW values are near to slightly 
below the mean for late May. Additionally, model soundings 
indicate a capping inversion in place. There have been a few weak 
returns on radar from time to time this afternoon mainly over the 
higher elevations of E TN and SW VA. Visible satellite imagery 
indicates a decent cu field across the forecast area but not much 
vertical development outside of the higher elevations. Any ongoing
activity should come to an end near sunset. Afternoon highs will 
top out near record highs in the upper 80s to low 90s for most 
locations.

Another mild night is forecast tonight with lows only dropping down 
into the mid 60s to low 70s. With the sparse coverage of 
precipitation this afternoon, do not expect any widespread fog 
formation. There could be some patchy fog near area lakes and 
rivers but do not have enough confidence in this to add it to the 
forecast.

The heat wave will continue into Sunday as the upper level ridge
holds strong. The ridge axis will retrograde to the west and the
winds will become more westerly throughout the atmosphere. This
wind direction will lead to slightly drier air across the region
with PW values falling down into the 25th percentile or so for
late May. Due to this, have not mentioned any precipitation
chances for Sunday. Highs on Sunday will once again be near record
levels in the upper 80s to low 90s.

.LONG TERM...(Sunday night through Saturday)...

The long term synoptic outlook begins with continued strong ridging 
centered over the southeast CONUS with amplified troughing over the 
southwest coast and a developing low pressure center moving into the 
Pacific Northwest. A lingering stationary front will be located over 
the northern Ohio valley and will see a number of shortwaves move 
along the boundary that will work to flatten out the ridge. A few 
periods of afternoon convection are possible for southwestern 
Virginia and northeast Tennessee as the shortwaves track just to the 
north. A number of isolated cells could make it far enough south to 
provide some rainfall, but confidence isn't great.

The most substantial weather for early next week continues to be the 
high temperatures. The combination of steady southwesterly flow from 
the surface high and plentiful moisture advection along with little 
cloud cover from the subsidence of the ridge, will aid in keeping 
daily maximums several degrees higher than the seasonal averages. 
Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday all look to peak in the mid 90's with 
heat indices hovering around the mid 90's as well.

As the previously mention low pressure center moves lee of the 
northern Rockies it will develop a cold front that will extend 
across most of the southern and central Great Plains. As the low 
tracks to the northeast the front looks to elongate along the ridge 
axis as it moves into the Appalachians with the trough pushing the 
blocking high further to the south. The front looks to reach eastern 
Tennessee by late Thursday to early Friday but confidence as to the 
coverage and timing is not high as the consistency between model 
runs and individual models is low.

A more zonal pattern is in store after FROPA with the trailing 
boundary setting up either just over us or to the south. Slightly 
cooler and drier air will be behind the front, although the 
temperatures may not drop by too much and could remain a few degrees 
above average into next weekend dependent on the placement of the 
stationary front.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
308 PM EDT Fri May 24 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Saturday)...

The upper level ridge continues to dominate the weather pattern 
across the southern Appalachians. Temperatures early this afternoon 
are already just a couple of degrees away from record highs. Most 
locations are currently in the mid 80s to low 90s. PW values have 
increased just a bit from yesterday as the ridge slides slowly to 
the east. As this happens, winds throughout the atmosphere are more 
from the southwest Visible satellite imagery indicates a decent 
coverage of cu across southern portions of the forecast area. Radar 
imagery even indicates a few light showers associated with this cu. 
Model soundings indicate a cap around 700 mb and not seeing much 
vertical development in the cu field due to this. Therefore, have 
around 15-20 PoPs across southern portions of the forecast area. 
Further to the north, a shortwave trough will pass to the north and 
east around the periphery of the upper level ridge from the Great 
Lakes into the Mid-Atlantic, due to this, have continued with 15-20 
PoPs this afternoon and evening for most of SW VA. Any ongoing 
activity should dissipate around sunset. 

Another mild night is forecast tonight with lows only dropping down 
into the mid 60s to low 70s. Some model guidance suggests a bit of 
patchy fog overnight but with the limited coverage of precipitation 
and the lack of fog formation last night, did not introduce any fog 
to the forecast at this time. However, would not be surprised to see 
some patchy brief fog near sunrise. The low-level ridge will build a 
bit further to the west on Saturday with low level winds taking on 
more of westerly component. Due to this, PW values will be a bit 
lower than today but still near the average for late-May. However, 
with the lack of any synoptic lift, have only include 15-20 % chance 
for a few isolated showers/storms mainly over the mountains of E TN 
and SW VA. Upper level heights will be similar to today with the 
ridge holding strong and expect highs once again in the upper 80s to 
low 90s near record levels. 

.LONG TERM...(Saturday night through Friday)...

The majority of the long term forecast will be under the influence 
of the persistent high pressure ridge over the southeastern US. 
Troughing over the American southwest looks to form a series of weak 
mid level waves just lee of the Rocky mountains that will move along 
the perimeter of the ridge. A much stronger front looks to develop 
by Wednesday next week as the parent low moves across the mountains 
as the trough begins to progress eastward. A stationary boundary 
looks to set up to our north over the weekend around the central 
Ohio valley, with several shortwaves that will move along the 
boundary in an attempt to break down the ridge. Strong southwesterly 
flow over much of the Great Plains out ahead of the trough and along 
the ridge will aid in increasing temperatures through the advection 
of subtropical moisture.

With the combination of the southwesterly winds, moderate dew 
points, and suppressed cloud formation from the ridge which will 
lead to plentiful daytime surface heating, high temperatures will look 
to be the prominent weather concern. Daytime highs could meet or 
exceed established records over the weekend and into early next 
week. A few slight to chance opportunities for some afternoon 
showers and thunderstorms in southwestern Virginia and far 
northeastern Tennessee as the mid level shortwaves flatten the ridge 
out enough to reach far enough to the south to create some 
additional lift. Greatest chance for this occurring during the most 
opportune time of the afternoon looks to be Monday, but confidence 
isn't too great, as models just don't have good consensus. A few 
areas might see formation of patchy early morning fog over the 
weekend due to the moisture advection from the southwest, clear 
overnight skies, and light winds. Greater chance of fog formation 
exists if any areas see some additional rainfall.

The ridge looks to finally give way on Thursday of next week as the 
previously mentioned cold front develops over the Great Plains and 
moves into the area. Thursday looks to be the day with the highest 
probability for areawide thunderstorms across the CWA as the front 
tracks eastward. However confidence is somewhat low as to the 
timing of the front's arrival at the moment. GFS shows sometime 
between late Wednesday night to Thursday morning, while the ECMWF 
shows a better potential for thunderstorms as the front arrives late 
Thursday afternoon. A much more zonal pattern looks to follow after 
FROPA near the end of next week with the boundary stalling either 
over southern Appalachia or just to our south, with cooler 
temperatures finally arriving as we sit either in the cool sector or 
under the boundary.

shower/thunderstorm could linger over the far northeastern area

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Wednesday)...Long term period 
still features a strong area of high pressure that resides over the 
region with periods of flattening and restrengthening. Ridge finally 
pushes east a little by Wednesday as a shortwave trough moves up 
through the Missouri River Valley and into the Great Lakes.


To start the period the ridge is centered directly to our south. 
This puts our region under a west-to-northwest flow throughout the 
atmospheric profile. A weak impulse moves down through the flow from 
out of KY and into WVA/VA. SWVA and extreme NETN may be close enough 
to the impulse to see a few showers and storms develop. Though low 
level lapse rates are quite steep across this area at roughly 7 deg 
C/km and plenty of CAPE, there is a deep isothermal layer that 
stretches from 800mb up to 600mb. This isothermal layer may prohibit 
convection all together. 

The ridge flattens over the weekend as a frontal boundary moves down 
into the Ohio River Valley and becomes east-to-west oriented. Though 
the front remains well off to our north, the flattening of the ridge 
may help to spark an isolated shower or storm across our high 
terrain and up into SWVA. Sunday night/Monday morning another 
impulse rolls through the west-to-northwest flow and into our area. 
This will again allow for slight chance/chance POPs across the high 
terrain, NETN, and SWVA. Models were previously showing this impulse 
coming through on Monday which gave us our best shot of precip of 
the extended. However, now it looks like it exits by Monday morning 
so most areas stay dry now on Monday. The ridge restrengthens Monday 
afternoon through Tuesday.

Wednesday a shortwave trough and trailing front swing up into the 
Great Lakes Region. This weak trailing front approaches our area 
giving us another shot of slight chance POPs, though this time 
areawide.

boundaries will track through the upper flow...briefly flattening

best chance for the shower/thunderstorms activity. The Monday wave
with the strongest of the series and scattered to isolated 
convection could be possible over much of the area. During the 
rest of the time...the upper ridge will re- strengthen and inhibit
most convection. However...with strong diurnal heating and weak 
orographic lift...afternoon high elevations convection can not be 
totally ruled out. 

The other story with the strong upper ridge in place will be the 
very warm temperatures expected throughout the extended.  Highs will 
average a good 10 degrees above normal each day.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Sunday night)...A summer like

outlook, with a strong upper level ridge over the southeast that 
will stay in place through the week. A deepening low will be 
located lee of the central Rockies that will track to the 
northeast with an associated cold front preceding it. The longwave
trough will elongate by mid week as it begins to move around the 
edge of the ridge with a series of shortwaves moving along the 
boundary. The shortwaves will attempt to break the ridge down, 
with the GFS showing a slight flattening by Thursday morning.

Locally, the high pressure for the week will help to suppress cloud 
formation leading to plenty of surface heating. Along with the near 
constant moisture advection resulting from the south to 
southwesterly flow, temperatures and humidity will remain high with 
some days seeing low to mid 90's in the valley. All this increasing 
instability will lead to a few days seeing some afternoon 
convection, driven by differential surface heating and lift from the 
mountains. Most diurnally driven storms will be short lived and 
restricted to the higher terrain due to the elevated LFC levels for 
most afternoons, but a few cells could drift into the valley. The 
best chance for greater convective coverage looks to be late in the 
week moving into the weekend. The afore mentioned shortwaves could 
create enough lift along the stalling front to cause isolated to 
scattered thunderstorms.

The ridge will build back in by the end of the weekend, drifting 
slightly to the west and centered just off the Gulf coast by Sunday. 
Temperatures look to remain high into next week as a similar 
synoptic pattern looks to play out again early next week with 
another longwave trough setting up over the American southwest.

577 
FXUS64 KMRX 191924
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
324 PM EDT Sun May 19 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Monday)...
Water vapor imagery and upper air analysis places a ridge of high
pressure across the eastern seaboard with a shortwave trough 
sliding into the Great Lakes. Further west, troughing is analyzed
across the west coast. This configuration places the southern 
Appalachians under 30-35 knots of southwesterly flow aloft. The
surface reflects an area of low pressure across southern 
Wisconsin with a trailing cold front extending south into the 
Ozarks and southern plains. Satellite imagery is beginning to show
signs of a developing CU field with vertical development. 
Additionally, recent radar scans are beginning to show isolated 
showers and thunderstorms across mostly northeast areas of the 
forecast area. Steep low level lapse rates on the order of 8.0 to 
8.5 C/km along with strong solar radiative heating has allowed the
atmosphere to become very unstable this afternoon. Latest SPC 
mesoanalysis places nearly 1500 to 2000 J/kg of surface based CAPE
values and LI’s around -2 to -3 . The lack of any appreciable
mid level forcing for ascent means that our source of lift will 
likely be from differential heating and orographic forcing for 
ascent. Further, weak surface troughing analyzed across southwest 
Virginia could also aid in lift for parcels to reach their LFC. 
Increased 500mb flow has allowed effective bulk shear to increase 
this afternoon to near 30 knots. This along with strong 
instability could lead to strong and sustained updrafts this 
afternoon and early evening. Further, hail CAPE values near 300 to
400 J/kg suggest a hail threat will accompany any of the stronger
convection. A damaging wind threat also exists today given the 
large DCAPE values in excess of 1000 J/kg and very dry air aloft 
above 700mb. The most likely locations to experience thunderstorm 
activity today are across extreme northeast Tennessee and 
southwest Virginia. Further west, drier air in the atmospheric 
column will tend to prevent convective development through the 
afternoon and evening. 

Through tonight, the upper level pattern begins to flatten out as
the strong shortwave advects north of the Great Lakes. This 
ultimately means the surface front will weaken further as it 
approaches the area. Moisture does increase along the front and as
a result do expect scattered showers across most of the area late
tonight through Monday morning. The abundance of cloud cover will
keep temperature mild with overnight lows progged in the low to 
mid 60s. Upper level ridging builds behind the weak impulse aloft 
and will advect drier air into the area. Otherwise it will be 
another warm day on Monday with high temperatures in the low to 
mid 80s area wide. 


.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Sunday)...
Main weather story for the extended will be the developing heat 
and humidity by mid to late week as upper ridge strengthens over 
the southeast United States and southern Appalachians.

Persistent upper troughing in the Great Basin area of the west with 
ridging over the southeast United States will keep with the weather 
quiet over the southern Appalachians and Tennessee Valley for 
Tuesday through Thursday.  Some gradual increase in moisture is 
anticipated by late Wednesday and Thursday with isolated to widely 
scattered storms over the far east Tennessee Mountains anticipated.

For Friday into the weekend, a series of short-waves will ride a top 
of the upper ridge over the Ohio Valley.  This will help flatten the 
upper ridge over the ridge some allowing for slightly greater 
convection coverage, especially for the higher terrain. Some of 
these storms could be strong to isolated severe with the main 
concern being downburst damaging winds and hail up to quarter size.
At this time, Saturday and Sunday afternoons seems the best day for 
coverage and intensity.

into the Midwest with surface low pressure developing across the
central plains and ejecting northeast into Iowa by Sunday morning.

aloft move into the Great Lakes. An increasing pressure gradient

.LONG TERM...(Sunday night through Saturday)...

The main headline for the extended will be anomalous ridging 
building in across the region for the middle to late part of next 
week with mostly dry weather and above normal temperatures. There 
will be a large ridge across the Western Atlantic with troughing 
across the Central CONUS on Sunday night. A shortwave trough and

into our region with the highest PoPs across western and southern

stalls near our area on Monday before moving quickly north as a warm 
front on Tuesday. Could have a few lingering slight chance/chance

remain dry.

scattered showers or thunderstorms on Wednesday morning, but 
confidence is low. Even if some develop, slight chance PoPs are all 
that's expected Wednesday. The 500mb heights are expected to be near 
590 to 594 dam Wednesday afternoon through Friday which is near the 
max climatological percentile. This anomalous ridging will keep us 
mainly dry and result in max temperatures about 10 to 15 degrees 
above normal. Expect we will have a few diurnally driven isolated 
showers or thunderstorms across the higher terrain of the mountains, 
but most areas should remain dry and unseasonably warm. It will 
definitely be a summer-like pattern during the majority of the 
extended.

Canadian by trying to flatten the ridge as several shortwaves move 
across the Ohio Valley. However, tend to forecast with persistence 
with such a strong ridge, so will trend closer to the ECMWF and 
Canadian keeping ridging firmly in place.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
319 AM EDT Sat May 18 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

High pressure will continue to increase through the weekend as an 
upper level ridge over the Mississippi river valley advects 
eastward. A positively tilted longwave trough over the southern Great 
Plains states will increase in amplitude as it starts to ride along 
the periphery of the strong blocking high. A weak shortwave impulse 
will move northeastward along the ridge into the CWA Saturday night. 
This mid level wave, paired with strong daytime heating and light 
southerly flow, with the additional lift provided by the southern 
Appalachian mountains, could be enough to form some isolated areas 
of elevated convection in the afternoon. Showers and thunderstorms 
are not a sure thing, however, due to very dry air aloft and
strong suppression from the ridge. Clearing skies tonight will
lend to longer periods of radiational cooling, along with residual
moisture at the surface and light winds will allow decoupling of
the PBL, promoting potential fog formation for the early mornings
this weekend along the major rivers and larger bodies of water.

.LONG TERM...(Sunday through Friday)...

Cold front moving through the MS and OH Valleys Sunday will 
draw up warm and humid air upon southerly winds across our area. The 
front will then bring scattered showers and thunderstorms across the 
area Sunday night into Monday, but the forcing will be weakening 
from what it once was and so precip will not be particularly heavy. 
The frontal boundary will come to rest to our south Monday night and 
then lift northward during Tuesday as sharp troughing occurs over 
the Rockies which will induce warm southerly flow back across our 
area. This sharp western troughing will be matched by strong ridging 
over the southeast US, and temps by midweek will soar to nearly 10+ 
degrees above normal. Expecting only isolated diurnal convection 
during those hot days.

FXUS64 KMRX 171949
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
349 PM EDT Fri May 17 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Saturday)...

Upper level ridging is currently building across the Mississippi 
river valley southward into the southern plains with a weakness in
mid level flow across the southeast and northern GoM. The surface
features high pressure centered across the southeast with weak 
surface flow across much of the area. Further west, low pressure 
is analyzed lee of the Rockies underneath mid level height falls 
associated with a shortwave trough advecting northeast. 
Temperatures this afternoon have warmed into the 80’s to near 90
at CHA underneath increasing heights aloft. Dry air advecting in 
from the west will tend to limit convective chances this afternoon
and evening. Clear skies and calm winds are expected tonight 
associated with the aforementioned surface high pressure. Some 
radiational cooling could promote patchy fog development 
overnight in places that received rainfall this morning.

The ridge intensifies on Saturday leading to another day of 
mostly clear skies. Temperatures will be warm with daytime highs 
in the mid to upper 80’s expected area wide. A well mixed lower 
troposphere will tend to increase low level lapse rates as 
reflected in forecast soundings. This combined with differential
heating along the terrain will lead to chances of isolated to
scattered thunderstorms Saturday afternoon and as a result increased
PoPs across mainly the higher terrain and foothills. The limited 
factors are nearly weak upper level flow, and dry air aloft. 

.LONG TERM...(Saturday night through Friday)...

The big story for the extended will be anomalous ridging building in 
across the region for the middle to late part of next week. On 
Sunday, we will have a large ridge across the Western Atlantic with 
troughing across the Central CONUS. A shortwave trough and closed, 
stacked upper low will be across the Northern Mississippi Valley. 
The surface low will have a trailing cold front which will approach 
our area by Sunday night. However, this low will become occluded 
with the forward progression of the front slowing rapidly. Main 
dynamics remain to our north and west with this system. This will 
lead to weak forcing across our area with quickly diminishing PoPs 
as activity moves eastward toward our region on Sunday night. 
Current thinking is that most areas likely still see some QPF, but 
it will be lighter and more scattered as the front approaches. The 
front stalls near our area on Monday before moving quickly north as 
a warm front on Tuesday morning. Could have a few lingering slight 
chance/chance PoPs on Monday and Tuesday near the frontal boundary, 
but expect most areas remain dry.

Ridging builds in on Wednesday and continues to increase through the 
end of the week. The 500mb heights are expected to be near 590 to 
593 dam Wednesday afternoon through Friday which is near the 99th 
climatological percentile. This anomalous ridging will keep us 
mainly dry and result in max temperatures about 10 to 12 degrees 
above normal. Could have a few diurnally driven isolated showers or 
thunderstorms across the higher terrain of the mountains, but most 
areas should remain dry and unseasonably warm. It will definitely be 
a summer-like pattern during the majority of the extended.

National Weather Service Morristown TN
343 AM EDT Fri May 17 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

A frontal boundary is currently over the southern Ohio Valley along 
the axis of the upper level ridge. A shortwave impulse is moving 
southeast along the boundary that will bring a few early morning 
showers with some additional areas of rain along the mountains for 
Friday. NAM soundings show some decent MLCAPE on Friday, along with 
higher Theta-e which implies a slight chance for a few thunderstorms 
to develop along the mountains. Although due to the increasing 
pressure from the ridge paired with little to no forcing aside from 
orographic lift, little to no chance of any severe storms are 
expected. Ceilings will scatter out by the afternoon as high 
pressure continues to build into the region, pushing the stalled 
front further to the north. Winds will back to the south along the 
pressure gradient through Friday night leading to increased WAA. The 
combination of the moist southerly flow and clearing skies will lead 
to much warmer temperatures proceeding into the weekend.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Friday)...

The general longwave pattern throughout the extended will be H5 
troughing over the Rockies and ridging over the Southeast, with a 
northward pull of Gulf moisture and rain in the Central Plains. This 
means very warm temperatures approaching 10 degrees above normal by 
the middle of next week, and 7 day rainfall totals averaging less 
than an inch across the CWA. 

A weak frontal boundary associated with an H5 trough will bring the 
best chances of rain during Sunday night and into the day Monday. 
Once the trough passes, however, the warm ridge will quickly 
reassert itself, and even stronger. It looks like it will keep the 
storm track mostly to our north, which means SW VA will be the main 
area to experience convection chances Wed Ngt and Thurs after hot 
and dry days Tuesday and Wednesday.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
329 PM EDT Thu May 16 2019

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Friday)...Surface high pressure will
continue to dominate area weather for quiet night. A short wave
riding along the upper will push through the Southern Appalachian
Region late tonight into Friday. This will increase mid and high
level clouds tonight with some initial convection possible towards
morning over far northern areas. The clouds combined with
southerly flow increasing low level moisture will allow for warmer
temperatures tonight. As the main lobe of the short wave moves in
on Friday...isolated convection may develop. There is minimal
upper level support but with an increase in moisture and weak
lift...a few isolated showers and thunderstorms will be possible.
With the aid of orographic lift...the East TN Mountains will see a
better chance of convection. DCAPE values will be around 1000 to
1500 J/kg but with little dynamics to work with...do not
anticipate any strong or severe storms. The warming trend will
continue into Friday with afternoon highs forecast to reach into
the 80s across most valley locations.

.LONG TERM (Friday night through Thursday)...The start of the 
long term period will feature upper level troughing out west with 
ridging across the southeast promoting an increase in 
southwesterly flow aloft transporting moisture northward. At the 
surface, cyclogenesis lee of the Rockies will occur under upper 
level height falls and move east northeast through the weekend 
period dragging a cold front through the central and southern 
plains. A rather potent shortwave trough will eject northeast into
the central and northern plains Saturday night into Sunday which 
should send the aforementioned low pressure quickly northward. 
However, continued height falls lee of the Rockies will promote 
additional cyclogenesis with another surface low. An increase in 
southerly flow will lead to isentropic lifting and with at least 
some moisture present could lead to scattered showers on Saturday 
afternoon and evening. By late Sunday night into Monday morning 
the potent shortwave will advect quickly into the Great Lakes 
region with dry air quickly wrapping around the low. A weak cold 
front will move through the Tennessee and Ohio valley Sunday night
into Monday providing a focus for scattered showers. Forecast 
point soundings and 2-D surfaces show some elevated instability 
present underneath mid-level cooling, and would be sufficient for 
a few rumbles of thunder. Given the increased southerly flow, 
temperatures during this time will be above normal. 

Further west, a stronger shortwave trough will move off the Rockies 
and quickly eject northeast into the Great Lakes while upper level 
ridging builds across the GoM. Upper level height falls lee of the 
Rockies will induce surface cyclogenesis with low pressure moving 
through the central plains and Midwest.  A cold front attendant this 
low will move through the plains and into the Mississippi river 
valley by midweek.  There is some uncertainties in regards to if 
this cold front will be able to make its way into the Tennessee 
valley.  If the ridge builds in too quick, this will ultimately mean 
the cold front will not be able to push through and will remain to 
our north.  As a result chances of widespread frontal precipitation 
seems unlikely at this point, yet there remains the probability of 
scattered thunderstorms given some instability that will be present 
due to increased moisture and heating. However, mid-level 
temperatures will be quite warm leading to weak mid to low level 
lapse rates. This combined with weak wind profiles will limit storm 
organization and chances of strong storms. Precipitable water values 
near 1.25 to 1.5 inches along with deep warm cloud layers could 
promote areas of heavy rainfall especially in any convective 
elements. Model soundings indicate a well mixed boundary layer by 
Wednesday which will allow daytime highs to approach the mid to 
upper 80's across most of the forecast area with 90 degrees 
certainly not out of the realm of possibilities. 

Ridge of high pressure will quickly build in behind this mid week 
system and will produce a summer like pattern with drier weather 
conditions and much warmer conditions with highs in the mid to upper 
80s and lows in the upper 60s.
