Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
415 AM EDT Thu May 16 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

An increasing ridge over the eastern Great Plains will continue to 
build into the area over the next few days. Up north, a cold front 
looks to move into the Great Lakes region and eventually stall out 
at the axis of the ridge with a shortwave impulses that will move 
southward along the boundary. A shortwave looks to move over 
northeastern Tennessee and southwestern Virginia late tonight and 
into Friday morning, bringing a chance for showers and some possible 
thunderstorms. Convection will be elevated in nature and tied to 
orographic lifting, which is why the models show some QPF tied to 
the terrain. Currently, the GFS looks to be over doing the chance 
for precip, while the NAM, RAP, and HRRR are showing drier 
conditions, which looks to be more realistic, so am leaning towards 
the greater consensus.

.LONG TERM...(Friday through Thursday)...

The gist of it is that the main story for the long term period will 
be the notable warm up that will occur, with well above normal 
temperatures continuing through much of next week. Some chances for 
showers and thunderstorms will exist on Friday and Saturday, mainly 
over the higher terrain locales, but any significant chance of 
rainfall holds off until a decaying front attempts to move in from 
the west late Sunday evening or into Sunday night. Then it's back to 
a period of warmer weather as upper ridging builds overhead again.

Going into more detail here, a deep trough will be in place across 
the western CONUS at the start of the period, with northwesterly 
upper flow from the northern plains across the Great Lakes region, 
and upper ridging across the Gulf states, and lower Mississippi 
River Valley regions. Some guidance hints at elevated convection 
forming over the Tennessee and southwest Virginia mountains early 
Friday morning. Not particularly sold on the early morning 
convection part, but with a weak shortwave passing through to our 
north, there may be enough of a weakness in the upper ridge to allow 
for some afternoon storms to fire over the plateau and mountain 
regions. Have some 20-30 PoPs in to account for this but it is a low 
confidence forecast. A similar setup is expected on Saturday, with 
another round of isolated to scattered storms over the plateau and 
mountain areas. The more significant item of note here will be how 
warm temperatures get. As the ridge builds in from the west, highs 
will run near 10 degrees above normal on both Saturday and Sunday, 
with highs in the mid to upper 80s expected in the south on Sunday 
afternoon.

Further west on Saturday and Sunday a strong disturbance will eject 
out of New Mexico and into the plains. This will lead to widespread 
severe storms over the plains, but more importantly it will push a 
cold front our direction. Have rain chances increasing through the 
afternoon and evening hours Sunday, but the best chances for showers 
and thunderstorms will likely hold off until late Sunday night. 
Slowed the timing down a bit from previous forecasts due to better 
agreement in a slower arrival time. This should bring fairly 
widespread rainfall to the forecast area though, before departing on 
Monday morning. It should knock temperatures down a bit too, with 
lower 80s forecast for Monday. However, a strong ridge builds back 
overhead by Monday evening in response to another trough entering 
the southern plains, so expect to see summer like temperatures to 
round out the period. Rainfall with the next system probably holds 
off until just after the long term forecast period.

.LONG TERM (Thursday Night through Wednesday)... Overall pattern 
in the long term will be an strengthening ridge through the rest 
of the week and into the weekend, with a low pressure/front 
expected to swing through at the end of the weekend and into the 
next work week.

Mid-level ridge will continue to build as we wind down the work 
week, and a frontal boundary will get stalled across the Ohio River 
Valley. This will help temperatures to quickly climb into the 80's 
by Friday, with these above normal temperatures expected to continue 
through the rest of the forecast. Not a ton of synoptic forcing 
present across the forecast area with more of the lifting mechanisms 
remaining to our north along the boundary. The warm temperatures may 
be able to spark some convection in the afternoon/evening Thursday 
and Friday. Currently think the GFS is overdoing potential 
convection, so have trended towards the drier NAM/ECMWF with respect 
to PoP chances. 

Better chances for showers and storms come as a frontal boundary 
pushes through at the end of the weekend. This will be the best 
chance for precipitation during the forecast. Timing of the front 
and associated storms will hopefully occur overnight decreasing 
strong to severe storm potential, but will definitely keep an eye 
on this system as it gets closer. Front doesn't really do much to 
temperatures and we should remain mostly in the 80's through the 
first half of next week. Ridging begins to build in behind the 
system leading to drier weather.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
354 AM EDT Wed May 15 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

Nighttime microphysics RGB composite imagery on GOES 16 shows 
nicely where fog has developed overnight, largely sticking to 
river valleys across the area. This should dissipate quickly after
sunrise as a dry air mass promotes quick warming and overturning 
of the boundary layer.

For today, clouds will increase from the northwest as a weak
convective complex that started over Missouri yesterday evening
moves in. Infrared satellite imagery is not overly impressive,
nor is radar imagery from between the Paducah and St. Louis NWS 
offices. In other words, this isn't a significant MCS that will
barrel southeast through the region without dissipating. Rather 
this cluster of storms will likely remain ragged in appearance, 
and not offer up a widespread chance of any significant rainfall 
today. Current timing suggests rainfall associated with this 
feature will arrive close to 18z over the plateau and then shift 
southeast across the forecast area during the afternoon. Have PoPs
limited to 35 percent on the high end to account for the 
likelihood that this precipitation is sparse when it arrives, and
only have a few hundredths of rain in for today as well.

Highs today should be a little warmer than yesterday most
everywhere as cloud cover and any rainfall should hold off in
earnest until roughly peak heating this afternoon. For tonight,
rain chances will diminish significantly by early evening, so will
keep the forecast dry for the most part overnight. Do not think it
will be quite as cool tonight as the past couple of nights so went
a little warmer there. Fog also seems a bit uncertain as
radiational conditions won't be quite as ideal. However, suspect
some patchy fog will develop in areas that receive rainfall. This
should be sparse enough to preclude broad brushing patchy fog
across the area however, so left that out of the forecast for the
time being.


.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Wednesday)...

The synoptic outlook for the long term starts with an upper level 
trough over the central east coast that will continue to move 
offshore as a ridge builds over the central Great Plains. A frontal 
boundary looks to set up to our north over the Great Lakes late in 
the week with several shortwaves that will move along the front on 
the eastern side of the ridge. A second longwave trough will move 
onshore on the west coast with a preceding cold front.

A few showers will be possible for the southern counties of the CWA 
on Thursday evening as the first of the shortwaves move though the 
region. The chance for any strong thunderstorms looks to be 
rather limited during this time due to meager MLCAPE around 350 
J/kg and low PW values of under and inch. Deep layer shear will 
also be modest, of around 20 knots or less. Friday morning will 
see another shortwave from the north that will dip far enough 
south to produce a few showers for eastern Tennessee and 
southwestern Virginia. While models aren't in good agreement as to
the placement of the shortwave, decent southwesterly flow through
the day will lead to increasing WAA while soundings indicate an 
increased risk of a few strong to severe thunderstorms with MLCAPE
around 2500 J/kg but low 0-6km shear in the single digits. While 
SHIP values remain around 0.6 for the afternoon, DCAPE looks to 
reach up to 1000 J/kg, so a few stronger cells could produce some 
damaging winds and large hail.

The previously mentions longwave trough of the west coast will 
continue to track eastward through the week, while increasing in 
amplitude over the Rocky's, eventually forming a closed low over 
Colorado by Saturday night. Model inconsistency becomes very high 
this far into the forecast but the cold front from this upper level 
low looks to move into our area sometime between Monday and Tuesday 
next week. This looks to provide the greatest chance for more 
organized convection.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

Upper troughing will hold on across the eastern US during the short 
term period, with upper ridging over the Rockies. At the surface, 
continental high pressure will build into the area from the west 
today and tonight. 

Clouds clung to the Appalachian mountains north of the Smokies 
through the night, and were also persistent over lower elevation 
areas north of the I-40 corridor. Satellite imagery shows that 
clouds have been eroding more quickly over the last hour or two 
however, and much of the area should see mostly sunny conditions 
by mid morning I expect. General continued cyclonic flow aloft 
will help keep afternoon highs below normal today, with temps 
ranging from the mid 60s to around 70. This flow pattern will also
bring one more weak shortwave across the region this afternoon. 
Would not be surprised to see a scattered, flat afternoon CU 
field develop in response to this disturbance and daytime heating,
but expect whatever afternoon cloud cover is present later today 
will rapidly dissipate after we begin to lose sunlight. Thus, the 
combination of clear skies tonight, along with the advection of 
upstream dewpoints in the low to mid 40s into the forecast area, 
point to a cool night tonight. Have continued to advertise lows in
the low 40s in the north, with perhaps mid or upper 40s south of 
I-40. Also added in some patchy fog for late tonight as well. Prime
radiational conditions combined with wet soils and cool 
temperatures seems to be a solid setup for at least some patchy
development.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday through Tuesday)...

The synoptic pattern at the start of the long term outlook starts 
with an upper level low that continues to move off the northeast 
coast as the longwave trough makes its way offshore. Increased 
ridging over the Rocky mountains will build into the region through 
the week with a surface high currently over the CWA. A minor 
shortwave sits just to the west that will advect over eastern 
Tennessee by Wednesday evening.

Showers associated with the shortwave are expected overnight on 
Wednesday with the greatest chance for precip south of I-40. A few 
lingering showers on Thursday morning before the upper levels dry 
out as high pressure builds into the region as the ridge progresses 
eastward. A second minor shortwave moving along the ridge to the 
north will drop far enough south on Friday for some of the 
northeastern counties to see a few showers and thunderstorms.

An increasing amplitude longwave trough out west will develop a low 
pressure center over the four corners by Saturday that will undergo 
further cyclogenesis as it tracks east across the central Great 
Plains. A greater chance for thunderstorms early next week as a cold 
front originating from the upper level low looks to slow and 
eventually stall of the Appalachians. As the low moves off to the 
northeast, a second upper level low looks to form over the Rocky's 
that will lift the stalled boundary northward. This will lead to 
increased southerly flow before the next cold front moves in near 
the end of the forecast period, bringing another chance for 
convective weather.

should center itself nearly overhead by periods end.   Thus, the

again be below normal levels.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday night through Monday)...

National Weather Service Morristown TN
342 AM EDT Mon May 13 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

Synoptic scale troughing will remain in place across the eastern
US through the short term period. Embedded in the mean trough is a
semi-closed upper low currently seen over the southern 
Indiana/Illinois border this morning on GOES-16 water vapor 
imagery. This feature will rotate eastward through Kentucky in 
the base of the mean trough late this morning. Until it passes 
east of the Appalachians, some light showers could linger in the 
higher terrain of southwest Virginia and northeast Tennessee. 
Radar imagery from KMRX as well as surrounding radars show this 
to be the case, with some weak returns noted in those areas. 
Expect the upper low to shift east of the Appalachians by late 
morning or so, with rain chances coming to an end thereafter.

For today, clouds will be slow to clear across the northern parts
of the forecast area, but should become increasingly scattered in
nature through the morning hours in the south. Cloud cover and
weak cold advection will keep temperatures well below normal this
afternoon. This trend will continue tonight also, with clearing
skies and drier air in place temperatures yielding lows in the low
40s in the northern zones, and only in the upper 40s in the south.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Sunday night)...

Closed low will be situated across the Northeast with NW flow aloft 
across the forecast area on Tuesday. With ridging building in at the 
surface and aloft, expect a mostly clear or partly cloudy day with 
temperatures remaining lower than seasonal normals.

Shortwave energy moving through the NW flow will move southeastward 
toward our forecast area on Wednesday with an associated weak 
surface low. With very little moisture advection ahead of this 
system and minimal synoptic lift, expect any chance/slight chance 
rain shower activity to be light and produce near or less than 0.1" 
QPF. Model guidance is in good agreement with this being a minimally 
impactful system for Wednesday afternoon through early Thursday 
morning.

For Thursday and Friday, ridging begins to build in with surface 
high pressure and ridging aloft. Most areas should remain dry, but 
may have a few diurnally drive showers or thunderstorms mainly 
across the higher elevations. Surface high pressure shifts east by 
the weekend with SW flow bringing in additional low-level moisture 
and increasing chances for diurnally driven thunderstorms, mainly 
across the higher elevations. With the ridging increasing late week 
and into the weekend, expect temperatures to rise through the week 
and be back above normal late week and next weekend.

Late weekend into early next week, guidance is in overall agreement 
for Day 7/8 with an approaching upper level trough and surface low 
bringing additional showers and thunderstorms to the Mississippi 
Valley. The big question will be how far east does this system 
progress or does blocking keep our area mostly dry. The GFS appears 
to be the outlier at this time as the ECMWF and Canadian both keep 
the ridge stronger with strong blocking across the North Atlantic 
and minimize our precipitation chances into early next week. At this 
point, lean toward the ECMWF/Canadian solution keeping us drier 
Sunday night into Monday.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Monday)...
An upper low moving through the Midwest will continue sliding east 
into the Great Lakes region through the period, while a pesky

Currently this front looks to be laid atop portions of east KY and 
Middle TN, expected to advect east through the remainder of the 
day/evening.  With that, ample dry air advection aloft will favor 
steepening lapse rates, which combined with continued moist swly 
flow in the llvs, should promote continued convection this 
afternoon.  Shear will continue to increase as the upper trough and 
associated 60-70kt H5 jetmax approach tonight, however tall/skinny 
cape profiles should yield only a few hundred joules of cape.  Thus, 
think the severe threat is really low at this point, with the 
primary hazard threat tonight being slow moving and possibly 
training convection, which could lead to isolated heavy rainfall 
accumulations and thus increased flash flood threat.  FFGs would 
suggest that the most favorable regions for any flooding concerns 
would be across portions of far east TN and southwest VA/NC given 
recent rainfall.  QPF guidance yields 1-1.5 inches of rainfall for 
some locales in the above noted regions, the highest of those totals 
being across the high terrain, which seems reasonable as pwats 
remain in excess of 1.25 inches (although decreasing). All said, the 
fcst will feature mostly cloudy skies with pops in the slight/chance 
range westward, ramping up to likely/cat levels over the mtns for 
the remainder of the day.

Tonight the front should push east of the mtns allowing for deep 
nwly flow to to prevail, possibly favoring prolonged upslope flow 
induced showers into Monday morning/afternoon along the mtns.  Thus, 
pops will slowly lower from the west overnight (as a few showers 
can't be ruled out behind the front beneath the upper trough axis), 
with only slight/chance pops highlighted by daybreak across the mtns 
of TN/VA. Some patchy fog is expected across the region Monday 
morning given the moist PBL. Beyond that, high pressure will build 
in from the west as the region is consumed by upper level subsidence 
beneath the descending branch of the longwave trough. With that, 
all pops are removed by periods end as skies sct out and 
temperatures remain nearly 6-8 degrees below normal levels. 

.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Sunday)...
The rain will finally exit the Tennessee Valley and Southern 
Appalachians by Monday evening as the slow moving upper level low 
moves into the Northeast and the wrap around showers move into the 
central Appalachians. A cool Northwest flow will replace the wet and 
cloudy conditions from this weekend. Much cooler air mass will allow 
temperatures to fall below normal at night the next couple days with 
lows in the 40s. Tuesday there is good agreement of high pressure at 
the surface and with NW winds and drier air mass cool high 
temperatures in the 60s to lower 70s. From Wednesday on rain chances 
increase. The strong ridge to the west will cause the upper flow 
around it to bring a shortwave rapidly southeast from southern 
Canada Tuesday then into the eastern Tennessee Valley late Wednesday 
into Thursday. ECMWF model moves precipitation out early Thursday 
while GFS keeps moisture in later in the day. Ridging builds in 
again Thursday night and Friday through Saturday but another weak 
system may have enough moisture for showers in the northeast part of 
the area. Sunday a new frontal system will approach from the west. 
Southerly flow out ahead of it to spread showers and a chance of 
storms to parts of the area in the afternoon. Warmer temperatures 
will return Wednesday night through the end of the period with lows 
in the 50s to lower 60s. Highs will be 70s Thursday then lower to 
mid 80s Friday through the Weekend.

FXUS64 KMRX 120724
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
324 AM EDT Sun May 12 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Satellite and sounding observations show an upper-level longwave
trough across the Central CONUS with a 120kt jet streak across the
Ohio Valley and Great Lakes placing strong upper divergence across
the Southern Appalachians. Surface analysis places a surface low
across NE KY with a trailing cold front across Central KY and
Middle TN. This, along with converging low-level flow ahead of 
the front, is resulting in widespread boundary layer convergence 
and numerous rain showers. Expect to see some additional rain 
showers, and potentially a thunderstorm or two, this morning as a 
small shortwave currently near the MS/AL state line continues 
northeast across our area. As this pushes northeast and the 
frontal boundary continues east this afternoon, we may see some 
breaks in the rain mid-morning before more scattered showers, and 
possibly a thunderstorm, develop during the afternoon along and 
east of the front. Instability for thunderstorms is marginal, so 
do not anticipate much of a risk of strong to severe 
thunderstorms. Any thunderstorms that develop could have some 
gusty winds with some downed trees because of the antecedent wet 
conditions. With already saturated ground and a moist airmass 
ahead of the front, expect to have some locally heavy rain and 
localized flooding across eastern parts of the forecast area along
the mountains and in SW NC. By late afternoon and evening, we 
should begin to see a drying trend from west to east as drier, 
post-frontal air advects into the region.

Should have some scattered light rain showers continue overnight 
behind the front as the primary shortwave amplifies the trough 
across the Southern Appalachians. There will also be enough 
boundary layer moisture, along with NW flow orographic lift, to 
continue some light rain across the higher elevations of the 
mountains through the overnight period and early part of Monday.


.LONG TERM...(Monday through Sunday)...
An upper trough/semi-closed low will be moving east across 
northern Ohio and the Great Lakes on Monday. This will leave post-
frontal, northwest flow in place across the forecast area Monday 
into Monday night. Will hold on to some 20- 30 percent rain 
chances across the northern plateau, southwest Virginia, and the 
east Tennessee mountains north of the Smokies early Monday. Rain 
chances will decrease through the day as the upper low continues 
to move off to the east and the atmosphere dries out locally.

This northwest flow regime will lead to well below normal 
temperatures on Monday. Some guidance is holding highs down in the 
low 60s for areas in the northern Tennessee valley and southwest 
Virginia. Sided more towards that end of the guidance spectrum, with 
low to mid 60s instead of upper 60s. Below normal temperatures will 
continue into Tuesday, though a tad warmer than Monday thanks to 
clearing skies and weak high pressure building in from the west. Dry 
weather will be seen Tuesday and for much of Wednesday as well. 
However, rain chances return for late Wednesday into Thursday. A 
strong upper ridge will be in place across the central United States 
by late Tuesday night and early Wednesday morning, with upper 
troughing in place across the east and northwest flow from the upper 
midwest across the southern Appalachians. During the day Wednesday a 
shortwave trough will drop southeast from western Ontario across the 
Great Lakes region. The associated surface low will slide from the 
upper midwest down through the Ohio River Valley at the same time, 
with a warm front stretching into our forecast area by Wednesday 
evening. Isentropic analysis on the 300K surface shows modest ascent 
across this warm front as it moves into the region from the 
northwest, resulting in some light rain showers across the forecast 
area during that time. Given this system will be weakening as it 
arrives, limited rain chances to about 40 percent on Wednesday 
night. It seems likely there will be showers, but confidence in how 
widespread they will be is not high enough to go with anything 
higher than 40 percent or so.

After this system moves through, the strong central US ridge will 
shift east and the southern Appalachian region will likely end up in 
a more typical summertime pattern, with surface high pressure over 
the Carolinas and moist Gulf return flow to our west. Thus mostly 
clear/sunny skies seem on tap, with a notable warm up expected to 
round out the period. In fact, widespread highs in the low 80s seems 
very plausible by Friday, with mid 80s possible on Saturday.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight through Sunday night)... 
A wet pattern continues to highlight the weather across the TN 
Valley and Southern Appalachian region today/tonight as deep swly 
flow prevails, and an old quasistationary surface front slowly 
lifts northward as a warm front. With that, pwats in the 1.5-1.7 
inch range combined with ample convergence along the front will 
promote sct/num showers and thunderstorms in close proximity to 
boundary as it sweeps northward. Likewise, moisture and 
instability in the warm sector south of the front will allow for 
shower/thunderstorm redevelopment later this afternoon or early 
evening (after a period of recovery). Some of these warm sector 
storms could take advantage of steepened lapse rates and thus 
allow for deeper strong convection, while one/two severe storms 
with damaging winds being the primary threats cannot be ruled out.
Through the night, guidance favors additional convective 
development in the warm sector across portions of AL/GA, which 
given swly steering flow, should advect said storms into the 
region. Meanwhile, am also expecting sct convection in closest 
proximity to the front as it moves into southeast KY, northeast 
TN, and southwest VA. All that said, the fcst will feature 
likely/cat pops through the vast majority of the 
evening/overnight. 

On Sunday the pattern will finally evolve such that the closed H5 
low diving southeast across the central/northern Plains will favor 
further height falls across the east CONUS.  With that, the old 
pesky front will finally get driven through the region as a cold 
front, relative to the airmass out ahead that is.  Thus, pops will 
remain elevated in the likely/cat range in the morning ahead of the 
fropa, eventually tapering from west/east throughout the day, 
finally falling below likely levels regionwide by late evening. 

Overall regarding hazardous weather, although a few strong (maybe a 
couple severe) storms cannot be ruled out given sufficient warm 
sector instability and 0-6km shear, think the primary threat is 
heavy rainfall and isolated flash flooding. QPE across the area over 
the last 24 hours has been rather high for some locales, especially 
along the US64 corridor where a few gauges have topped the 4 inch 
mark. An additional 1-2 (locally 3) inches cannot be ruled out for 
some areas, most favorable though over the Plateau and Mountain 
regions.  

.LONG TERM...(Monday through Saturday)...
Cold front will have finally moved to the east of the forecast area 
by Monday morning. Upper level low and deep trough over the Ohio 
Valley and Tennessee Valley Monday morning will bring in a few more 
light showers across the area as it moves east toward the Mid 
Atlantic States. Rainfall amounts fortunately will be very light. 
GFS and ECMWF wetter than NAM for Monday and with NW flow and clouds 
temperatures will be much colder with highs only in the 60s to lower 
70s and only 50s in the higher elevations. Rainfall amounts will be 
light, expecting only a few hundredths. The skies will finally clear 
Monday night and higher pressure with NW flow will allow lows to 
drop into the 40s and upper 30s at the higher elevations. Tuesday 
will be about the same temperatures but with more sun to help dry 
out. Tuesday night and Wednesday staying dry with another cool 
morning and warming temperatures into the 70s as higher pressure 
moves farther east. A weakening system drops southeast with the NW 
flow late Wednesday into Thursday which will force a few showers and 
possible late afternoon and evening storms Wednesday night and 
Thursday before a more significant and warmer ridge of high pressure 
develops over the Tennessee valley Friday and Saturday. Temperatures 
will warm into the upper 70s to lower 80s by next weekend.

National Weather Service Morristown TN
419 AM EDT Sat May 11 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Ridging remains in place across the Western Atlantic and Caribbean
with longwave troughing across the Western and Central CONUS. 
This is placing our area under deep southwest flow aloft. At the 
surface, current observations show a SW-NE oriented stationary 
boundary across northern portions of the forecast area extending 
southwest along the Cumberland Plateau. Numerous to scattered 
convection continues along and ahead of this front enhanced by an
upper-level shortwave disturbance.

As this shortwave moves northeast of the region this morning,
expect to see convection become less numerous and more scattered
in its wake. The boundary layer will remain very moist, so
scattered convection and bkn to ovc clouds will continue through
the day along and south of the front. Saturday afternoon, a 
strong shortwave and closed low will move southeast across the 
Northern Plains amplifying the eastward moving longwave trough. 
This will result in height falls across the forecast area by the 
afternoon hours with an increase in instability. The RAP, NAM, and
GFS all indicate MLCAPE of about 1000-1500 J/Kg during the 
afternoon, primarily south of Interstate 40. Shear will be 
stronger on Saturday than during the past several days. The upper 
jet shifting east and a strengthening LLJ during the afternoon and
evening hours will increase deep layer and low- level shear. RAP 
forecast soundings indicate generally 30 to 35kt of 0-6km shear 
with 0-1km shear between 15 to 20kt. This will support storm 
organization, especially late in the day as shear continues to 
increase, with the main hazard being damaging wind gusts from the 
strongest thunderstorms. Overall, appears to be a marginal day for
a few severe thunderstorms this afternoon across SE TN and SW NC.

As mentioned, the upper-level jet will shift eastward during the
afternoon placing our area in the right-entrance region for
favored upper divergence and lift Saturday evening through the
night. Shortwave energy approaches with continued height falls and
a surface low will strengthen along the stationary front across
Middle TN and Central KY. This will produce strong lift across the
region through Saturday night into Sunday morning with increasing
chances of rain and embedded thunderstorms. With PW values of 1.5
to 1.7 inch Saturday evening and night, periods of heavy rainfall
be likely with localized flooding possible.


.LONG TERM...(Sunday through Saturday)...
On Sunday, deep southwesterly flow will be in place across the 
southeast, with a cutoff low/deep trough positioned over the 
Nebraska/Minnesota border, and a shortwave disturbance set to move
through Tennessee. As the day wears on, the upper low will shift 
southeast towards central or southern Illinois, before more 
quickly shifting east to Pennsylvania over the following 24 hours 
or so. At the surface, a cold front will shift east through the 
forecast area Sunday, providing a focus for shower and 
thunderstorm activity and possibly introducing some flash flooding
concerns. More on that a little later.

Some notable cooling aloft will occur on Monday as the upper 
low/trough passes east through the Ohio River Valley. Northwesterly 
flow behind this feature will keep clouds across the forecast area, 
and possibly some lingering showers in the higher elevations through 
Monday evening. Dry but below normal weather will continue from late 
Monday through Wednesday before the next weak front arrives late 
Wednesday night. This front continues to look like moisture supply 
will be a problem so will stick with PoPs of 30% or less for now.

Circling back to Sunday's forecast, flash flooding could be a 
concern depending on how rainfall goes today. While overall moisture 
content will be higher on Saturday, with PWAT values unseasonably 
high, Sunday will introduce higher instability and better dynamics 
to the equation. With organized, stronger convection in place, flash 
flooding could become a concern. Again, it will largely depend on 
the primer event in today's rainfall, but it is something worth 
keeping an eye on. For now, will hold off on any Flash Flood Watch 
products.

will favor iso/sct showers and thunderstorms this afternoon, 
generally with the highest chances across the mountains and plateau. 
Sounding profiles would suggest favorable lapse rates and mid level 
cape for some small hail with the tallest storms, as well as 
downburst winds given inverted V llv profiles.

Meanwhile, a weak upper vort impulse centered over the Lower MS 
Valley will slide northeast, with a weak surface wave to 
develop/advect northeast along the aforementioned surface front 
tonight.  With that, profiles will moisten substantially with pwats 
approaching 1.6-1.7 inches.  Thus, pops will ramp up from the 
southwest overnight tonight, with likely/cat levels favored across 
much of the area by morning. Moving forward, the weak H5 wave will 
advect northeast through late morning, which should allow for some 
clearing and thus heating. Deep layer shear in the 30-40kt range 
combined with this heating/instability should favor convection into 
the afternoon hours, especially along/south of the boundary which 
should be laid in a southwest to northeast orientation across the TN 
Valley.  Thus, SPC has placed these areas in the marginal risk for 
severe thunderstorms with damaging winds and large hail being the 
primary threats.  Lastly, given the presence of the boundary and 
continually moist profiles, any training of cells could yield 
moderate/heavy rainfall and thus isolated flash flooding concerns 
Saturday. 

.LONG TERM...(Saturday night through Friday)...
A wet pattern will continue Saturday night and Sunday then becoming 
cooler and drier as high pressure builds in. Saturday night a moist 
southwesterly flow will continue as stationary front over or near

to move along the front with showers and a few storms continuing 
along and ahead of the front through the evening then decreasing 
after midnight as the area of low pressure moves northeast toward 
the central Appalachians. The front will move only slowly east and
not get another push until Sunday as an upper trough which may 
close off moves into the Upper Mississippi Valley towards the 
Great Lakes. Mid level winds will increase to 40-50 knots 
enhancing the deep- layer shear per the Storm Prediction Center 
Outlook. The eastern half of the area could see some strong storms
with possible damaging winds just ahead of the cold front. 
Another inch of rain or more is possible Sunday. With Saturdays 
rainfall isolated flooding may occur in the eastern mountains of 
Tennessee where total rainfall amounts of 3 to 4 inches are 
possible from tonight through Sunday. Highs Sunday will stay 
cooler in the upper 60s to mid 70s due to clouds and rainfall. The
upper low then shifts east into the eastern Great Lakes Monday. 
Lingering showers Sunday night and Monday morning before drier air
moves in. Monday and Tuesday high pressure with much cooler 
temperatures as flow becomes northwest. Below normal temperatures 
in the 60s to lower 70s are expected with lows at night in the 
40s. The upper lows influence finally shifts out of the way by 
Wednesday with warming temperatures back to the 70s through 
Friday. A weak little system in NW flow will bring in a few 
showers Thursday.

National Weather Service Morristown TN
359 AM EDT Fri May 10 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Observations show the NE/SW oriented surface cold front currently
located across West TN and Central KY. This front will continue to
move southeast this morning and become stalled out across the
forecast area this afternoon. With winds becoming parallel to the
front this afternoon, the front will have very little movement as
it remains across the region. There is a lot of uncertainty in 
the amount of instability that will be realized this afternoon. 
NAM forecast soundings show some areas of MLCAPE between 1000-1500
J/Kg ahead of the front this afternoon, but the RAP is much lower
with generally 500 J/Kg or less. The main difference appears to 
be the degree of boundary layer moisture that each model is 
indicating with the RAP noticeably drier than the NAM and GFS. 
Current model initializations have the NAM and GFS more closely 
aligned with current observations, and based on the diurnal trend 
in dew points yesterday, lean more toward the NAM and GFS 
instability parameters for Friday afternoon. Still, there will be 
limited widespread lift with primary jet dynamics and the surface
low far to our north across the Great Lakes and Canada. Current 
thinking is that a few scattered thunderstorms could become 
strong to severe based on the forecast instability, but do not 
expect widespread convection. Any strong to severe convection
would have strong wind gusts and up to Quarter size hail as the
primary hazards based on the forecast instability, marginal 0-6km
shear (20 to 30 kt) for storm organization, and poor low-level 
0-1km shear values (less than 10 kt). Most of the day should be 
dry for most locations. Remained near guidance for max 
temperatures, but they could be a couple degrees higher in spots
that see breaks in cloud cover through the day.

Models are in good agreement with bringing a shortwave northeast
across MS, northern AL, and across East TN. This will result in
good PVA and height falls between 0z and 06z. With this increasing
lift, expect to see an increase in rain showers, and possibly a
few thunderstorms, tonight through daybreak Saturday. With PW
values near the 95th percentile, some locally heavy rainfall is
expected with convection.


.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Friday)...
This weekend will be rainy and stormy across the forecast area as
the region lies beneath a persistent southwest flow regime, with 
a good tap on Gulf moisture and a cold front helping to focus 
showers and thunderstorms over the area.

In the upper levels a cutoff low will have established a home off 
the southern California coast by daybreak Saturday morning, with 
another trough diving southeast across the northern plains. By 
Sunday morning the northern plains trough will have also cutoff from 
the polar jet over the upper midwest, while the SoCal cutoff low 
shifts eastward into northern Mexico. Meanwhile at the surface, a 
cold front will have settled into the TN Valley or perhaps as far 
east as the spine of the Appalachians by Saturday morning. With a 
persistent southwesterly flow regime at the mid and upper levels, 
and a quasi-stationary front laid out across the forecast area, rain 
seems inevitable and possibly heavy at that. Models show a nice 
plume of high PWAT air surging northeast into the region on Saturday 
as the first wave of showers and embedded thunderstorms arrive. Will 
have to watch for flooding issues on Saturday as some guidance shows 
PWAT values similar to those you would see in June or July, 
considerably higher than normal values for May. Additionally, model 
sounding show that much of the instability will be located beneath 
the hail growth region, lending itself to more efficient warm rain 
processes and increasing the likelihood of heavy rains. 

The area will likely see a bit of a lull Saturday night before the 
next wave of showers and thunderstorms arrives on Sunday. PWAT 
values are tad lower on Sunday, largely thanks to some mid level 
drying. However instability will be higher and access to Gulf 
moisture doesn't exactly shut off. Thus heavy rains will be possible 
again on Sunday, with the added possibility of a few strong storms. 
Better threats for severe storms will be present east of the 
Appalachians, but would not be surprised to see some strong storms 
in the eastern parts of the CWA.

For Monday onward, the midwest cutoff low will slowly shift east 
with time, finally moving off the northeastern seaboard by Tue 
afternoon. Showers will likely linger in the mountains and southwest 
Virginia until late Monday before moisture becomes scarce enough to 
warrant dismissing rain chances altogether. Monday and Tuesday 
nights will be cool, with lows dipping back into the 40s for most 
locations. Dry weather will also be seen for Tuesday.

Wednesday and Thursday are fairly uncertain at this point, with 
large discrepancies noted between models. Will favor a warming 
trend, with slight chances for rainfall entering the forecast again 
for Wednesday night and Thursday for now.

An amplified upper level pattern is in place across the CONUS with 
a deep trough along the western CONUS and a ridge that extends 
from the Carolina Coast northwards into the eastern Great Lakes. 
This puts the ridge axis to the east of the forecast area with 
southwesterly flow aloft. Several shortwave troughs will rotate 
through the longwave trough. Two of these shortwave troughs will 
impact the forecast area this morning and later this afternoon. 
The first is currently moving into the Tennessee River Valley and 
the second back to the southwest near the ARKLATEX. At the 
surface, high pressure extends along the Atlantic Seaboard with a 
surface low centered near the IA/IL line. A cold front extends 
southward from this low into the southern Plains. 

Despite the low-level jet increasing into the 20-35 kt range, some 
locations in sheltered valleys have gone calm. With the rain 
yesterday along the mountains and foothills, expect there will be 
some patchy fog this morning, especially for areas that received 
rainfall yesterday and near area lakes and rivers. Any fog that 
forms this morning will quickly dissipate as southerly winds in 
the 10-15 mph range become established shortly after sunrise. 

The main shortwave trough and area of showers and storms that will 
affect the area is currently located across the ARKLATEX. Models 
have the shortwave ejecting to the northeast into the Tennessee Valley 
by this afternoon. IR satellite imagery and latest trends suggest
that there will be increasing cloud cover today that will limit 
SBCAPE values. The low level jet will increase into the 30-40 kt 
range but models suggest the 40-50 kt jet axis will pass to the 
north and west. Additionally, as noted above, mid-level lapse 
rates are rather weak and even the usually aggressive NAM only 
indicates around 500 J/Kg of SBCAPE across the Plateau later this 
afternoon. Overall, not impressed with the potential for strong to
severe storms. For now, expect maybe a stronger storm or two with
gusty winds and small hail being the main threats with the best 
chance for a strong storm along the Plateau Temperatures will be a
bit cooler today with lower heights moving in, increasing cloud 
cover and precipitation chances. Highs today will be in the upper 
70s to low 80s.

The cold front approaching from the west will begin to slow tonight 
as it takes on more of a NE to SW orientation as the main upper 
level trough ejects to the northeast into the Great Lakes. A 
decrease in coverage is forecast tonight with no real synoptic lift 
with the trough well to the north. However, cannot rule out a few 
scattered showers and maybe a storm or two with some low level 
convergence ahead of the approaching surface boundary. Another mild 
night is forecast with lows in the low to mid 60s.

FXUS64 KMRX 090728
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
328 AM EDT Thu May 9 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

An amplified upper level pattern is in place across the CONUS with 
a deep trough along the western CONUS and a ridge that extends 
from the Carolina Coast northwards into the eastern Great Lakes. 
This puts the ridge axis to the east of the forecast area with 
southwesterly flow aloft. Several shortwave troughs will rotate 
through the longwave trough. Two of these shortwave troughs will 
impact the forecast area this morning and later this afternoon. 
The first is currently moving into the Tennessee River Valley and 
the second back to the southwest near the ARKLATEX. At the 
surface, high pressure extends along the Atlantic Seaboard with a 
surface low centered near the IA/IL line. A cold front extends 
southward from this low into the southern Plains. 

Despite the low-level jet increasing into the 20-35 kt range, some 
locations in sheltered valleys have gone calm. With the rain 
yesterday along the mountains and foothills, expect there will be 
some patchy fog this morning, especially for areas that received 
rainfall yesterday and near area lakes and rivers. Any fog that 
forms this morning will quickly dissipate as southerly winds in 
the 10-15 mph range become established shortly after sunrise. 

Current radar imagery indicates a line of showers moving to the 
northeast across Middle TN and N AL. Models are really struggling 
with this area of showers with most indicating that the showers 
should have already dissipated. The precipitation is moving into a 
more stable and drier airmass as the showers move further to the 
northeast. The shortwave trough is also quickly exiting to the 
northeast with the combination of these factors expect a weakening 
trend this morning but will introduce some 20-40 PoPs across 
southwestern portions of the forecast area. 

The main shortwave trough and area of showers and storms that will 
affect the area is currently located across the ARKLATEX. Models 
have the shortwave ejecting to the northeast into the Tennessee Valley 
by this afternoon. IR satellite imagery and latest trends suggest
that there will be increasing cloud cover today that will limit 
SBCAPE values. The low level jet will increase into the 30-40 kt 
range but models suggest the 40-50 kt jet axis will pass to the 
north and west. Additionally, as noted above, mid-level lapse 
rates are rather weak and even the usually aggressive NAM only 
indicates around 500 J/Kg of SBCAPE across the Plateau later this 
afternoon. Overall, not impressed with the potential for strong to
severe storms. For now, expect maybe a stronger storm or two with
gusty winds and small hail being the main threats with the best 
chance for a strong storm along the Plateau Temperatures will be a
bit cooler today with lower heights moving in, increasing cloud 
cover and precipitation chances. Highs today will be in the upper 
70s to low 80s.

The cold front approaching from the west will begin to slow tonight 
as it takes on more of a NE to SW orientation as the main upper 
level trough ejects to the northeast into the Great Lakes. A 
decrease in coverage is forecast tonight with no real synoptic lift 
with the trough well to the north. However, cannot rule out a few 
scattered showers and maybe a storm or two with some low level 
convergence ahead of the approaching surface boundary. Another mild 
night is forecast with lows in the low to mid 60s.


.LONG TERM...(Friday through Thursday)...

Agreement continues to favor an active weather pattern for our 
region through the weekend along a stationary boundary. A strong 
shortwave will be moving across the eastern Great Lakes on Friday 
with an occluding surface low across Ontario. The better dynamics, 
including the upper jet and LLJ, will remain far north of our 
forecast area on Friday with flow becoming parallel to the 
approaching cold front as it slows down and begins to stall. This 
SW/NE oriented front is expected to be located across our forecast 
area Friday afternoon during peak heating hours. NAM and GFS 
forecast soundings are both showing MLCAPE approaching 2000 J/Kg, 
steep low-level lapse rates, steepening mid-level lapse rates, and 
dry mid-levels. As mentioned, main dynamics remain to the north, so 
shear is relatively weak, especially in the low-levels with the lack 
of a strong LLJ. This will result in deep layer shear between 20 to 
30kt which will at least support organized convection. Low level 0-
1km shear is very marginal, less than 10 kt, and effective SRH less 
than 50 m2s2. This points to at least a low, marginal risk of severe 
thunderstorms on Friday afternoon along and ahead of the front. 
Based on the synoptic setup and forecast severe parameters, the 
primary hazards would be damaging winds and hail with the strongest 
thunderstorms. However, it is important to realize that this setup 
is based on some breaks in cloud cover and strong daytime heating 
ahead of the cold front. If convective debris from earlier activity 
prevents afternoon instability from reaching the nearly 2000 J/Kg 
that models are indicating at this time, the severe threat would be 
greatly limited. In addition, PW values will be near the 90th 
percentile Friday afternoon, so a few locally heavy downpours with 
convection will be possible.

The front will stall across the region on Saturday with convection 
remaining possible along and south of the boundary. The big question 
will be exactly where it stalls. The 0z GFS and 0z ECMWF are in poor 
agreement for Saturday. The ECMWF is more progressive with the 
trough across the center of the country on Saturday afternoon with a 
developing surface low and strengthening SW flow. This would bring 
the stationary front quickly north as a warm front while the GFS is 
slower and drier. Because of these differences, higher uncertainty 
exists to the coverage and timing of precipitation on Saturday. For 
Saturday night, guidance is in better agreement with a shortwave 
dropping south toward the Ohio Valley with a surface low moving 
northeast from the lower Mississippi Valley through the Tennessee 
Valley. The best synoptic lift is expected with this system from 
late Saturday night and during the day on Sunday. The most 
widespread and heaviest precipitation is forecast on Sunday 
resulting in a wet Mother's Day across the area. PW values of 1.5 to 
1.7 inch will be around the 95th percentile. In addition to 
saturated forecast soundings and a warm cloud layer depth between 
10k to 11k ft, it will be a favorable setup for some locally heavy 
rainfall. 

Front moves east of the region by Sunday night with drier air and 
subsidence moving in during the day on Monday. NW flow and residual 
low-level moisture may produce some light upslope rain showers 
across the mountains, but most locations should remain mostly dry on 
Monday. Surface high pressure builds in on Tuesday and Wednesday 
with dry weather across the region. The ECMWF and Canadian show a 
weak system approaching the area Wednesday night, but there is still 
significant uncertainty with timing of this a week from now. With 
cooler NW flow and troughing across the East Coast, temperatures 
should be near or slightly below normal.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Wednesday)...

The extended continues to appear active through the weekend with a 
frontal boundary across the region. With ridging across the East 
Coast, most of Thursday is expected to be dry and relatively nice 
with an increase in mid to high level cloud cover. Southerly flow 
will provide some downsloping across the foothills with warmer 
temperatures and clearer conditions across these areas and Northeast 
Tennessee for much of Thursday.

On Thursday afternoon, upper-level ridging weakens as PVA from 
shortwaves results in height falls across the Tennessee Valley. A

cold front from this low will move eastward toward our area Thursday

the 90th percentile through the weekend. With warm cloud layer depth 
of near or greater than 10k ft and low CAPE with saturated forecast 
soundings, it continues to look like a good setup for convective 
heavy rainfall and localized flooding concerns. It's not a prolonged 
heavy rain event, but the setup will favor heavy downpours with the 
convection that develops.

Confidence continues to increase in the weekend forecast with good 
agreement among guidance. At this point, Saturday appears to be the 
driest day over the weekend, but will still have some convection 
develop during the afternoon peak heating along and to the south of 
the surface boundary. A strong shortwave moving south from Manitoba 
into the Northern Plains on Saturday will bring a surface low and 
reinforcing cold front toward our area on Sunday. A developing 
surface low will move northeast along the front through the 
Tennessee Valley bringing the chance of heavy rainfall. At this 
time, Sunday continues to look like our wettest day and the day with 
the highest potential for locally heavy rainfall. As the front moves 
southeast of the area on Sunday night and Monday morning, drier air 
and subsidence moves in on Monday afternoon. With troughing across 
the region this weekend as well as abundant cloud cover and 
precipitation, expect temperatures to be mainly near or slightly 
below normal.

FXUS64 KMRX 071909
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
309 PM EDT Tue May 7 2019

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Wednesday)... 

High pressure will continue its grip on the area through 
Wednesday. Only isolated evening convection is expected through 
sundown this evening, but will mostly stay over the NC side of 
the state line. Southerly flow on Wednesday will assist with 
upslope convection over the mountains and maybe the southern 
Plateau during the afternoon.

.LONG TERM (Wednesday Night through Tuesday)... 

Another few periods of mostly quiet weather to begin the long 
term portion of the forecast before a more wet pattern sets up at 
the end of the work week. We'll be on the west side of the ridge 
Wednesday night meaning most locations will remain dry with slight
precipitation along the higher elevations of the mountains. 

Ridge continues to shift to the east on Thursday as shortwave ripple 
rides around the west side of the ridge. This will combine with 
surface low moving across the Great Lakes region and dragging a cold 
front behind it. In addition a strengthening low level jet will 
develop across Western/Middle Tennessee on Thursday. Front will be 
the focus for the best chances of showers and thunderstorms. 
Currently forecast models are holding off the front from moving into 
the Cumberland Plateau until late Thursday afternoon/Thursday 
evening. After the front finally moves into the Eastern Tennessee 
Valley it loses it's driving mechanisms and stalls out in the 
region. This means that it should act as a focus for shower and 
thunderstorm activity through the end of the work week and into the 
weekend. As this system moves through there will be abundant 
moisture to work with forecast PWAT values indicating 1.5+ inches, 
which puts us into the 90th+ percentile, meaning that there will 
likely be abundant rainfall with these storms. MLCAPE of 1000+ J/kg 
on Thursday/Friday means that there will be plenty of energy for 
these storms to tap into. The shear will remain relatively low with 
most locations expected to see less than 30 knots of 0-6km. The 
better severe weather environment will be further to the west closer 
to the stronger low level jet. Can't rule out severe weather either 
of these days, but for now the biggest concern will be heavy rain 
and localized flooding, especially if a certain locations gets 1 or 
2 heavy producing storms to move over the same location.

356 
FXUS64 KMRX 070717
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
317 AM EDT Tue May 7 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

The upper level pattern is characterized by a ridge that stretches 
from the Lower Mississippi River Valley northwestward into the Great 
Plains with a trough across the Desert Southwest. Closer to home, 
the flow is rather zonal across the area. At the surface, high 
pressure is centered across the Mid-Atlantic with an SW to NE 
oriented surface boundary stretching from the southern Plains into 
the eastern Great Lakes. PW values currently run from around 0.6-0.8 
inches. These values are near the 25 th percentile for early May. 
Dewpoints are a few degrees lower than the last few nights and do 
not anticipate any widespread fog formation this morning but there 
could be a few areas of patchy fog, especially near area lakes and 
rivers. 

Upper level heights will continue to increase today as the ridge 
builds in from the west. This will lead to highs around 3-5 degrees 
warmer than yesterday. Highs will be in the upper 70s to mid 80s for 
most locations. Most areas will remain dry today but there is a 
small chance for a few isolated to scattered showers/storms across 
the higher elevations along the TN/NC line. Upslope flow will 
develop with the surface high located across the Mid-Atlantic, the 
focus for this upslope will be on the NC side of the mountains, but 
have included 20-30 PoPs for those locations right along the TN/NC 
line later this afternoon. This activity should be diurnally driven 
with precipitation chances coming to an end around sunset. Lee 
cyclogenesis takes place later today into tonight as the trough to 
the west moves across the Rocky Mountains. Winds at 850mb, will 
shift around to the south with strong warm air advection forecast 
tonight. Lows will be mild in the mid 50s to low 60s.


.LONG TERM...(Wednesday through Tuesday)...

There will be an active weather pattern during the extended with the 
mid-level ridge axis shifting east on Wednesday afternoon and 
southwest flow advecting a warm, moist airmass across the Tennessee 
Valley. Could have a few showers or thunderstorms on Wednesday 
afternoon, mainly across the higher elevations as well as the 
southern valley where moisture will be highest.

On Thursday afternoon, upper-level ridging weakens further as PVA 
from shortwaves results in height falls across the Tennessee Valley. 
A stronger northern shortwave will be moving southeast into the 
Great Lakes with a strengthening upper jet and surface low. The 
trailing cold front from this low will move eastward toward our area 
Thursday night and Friday, but will stall out as the surface low 
becomes occluded over Quebec. This will bring periods of unsettled 
weather across our forecast area through Sunday night. The GFS, 
NAEFS, and ECMWF show PW values ahead of this frontal boundary in 
the 1.6 to 1.8 inch range which is between the 95th and 99th 
percentile. Confidence in periods of heavy rainfall that may lead to 
localized flooding is increasing late week through the weekend. The 
severe weather threat is low, but with 0-6km shear up to about 30kt 
and MLCAPE ranging from 1000 to 2000 J/Kg on Thursday evening and 
Friday evening, expect some organized convection that could produce 
some stronger wind gusts. The lack of a well-defined, strong LLJ 
with the main surface low and upper-jet located far to the north 
will limit low-level shear and helicity values across our area, and 
will likely limit some of the severe weather potential. Overall, the 
primary weather hazard late week through the weekend continues to be 
heavy rainfall and localized flooding.

Confidence has increased in the weekend forecast as the operational 
GFS has come into better agreement with its ensembles and the ECMWF. 
At this point, Saturday appears to be the driest day over the 
weekend, but will still have some convection develop during the 
afternoon peak heating along and to the south of the surface 
boundary. A strong shortwave moving south from Manitoba into the 
Northern Plains on Saturday will bring a surface low and reinforcing 
cold front. This front will continue southeast on Saturday night and 
approach the Tennessee Valley on Sunday. With the approaching trough 
and surface cold front, widespread lift with rain and thunderstorms 
is expected on Sunday. As this front passes southeast of the area 
Sunday night and Monday, a drying trend is expected to begin the 
next work week. With troughing setting up across the region, 
temperatures will be cooler, near or slightly below normal, this 
upcoming weekend into early next week.

FXUS64 KMRX 061920
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
320 PM EDT Mon May 6 2019

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Tuesday)...Overall...expect a rather
quiet and benign short term. Surface high pressure will remain the
dominant weather feature tonight and Tuesday. There will be a
minor short wave riding through the upper flow tonight.
However...as dry air continues to filter in and the influence of
the surface high... the best the wave is expected to do will be so
pull in a scattered band of mid to high level clouds. The lower
dew points will also inhibit fog formation tonight. Any fog that
does develop should be quite localized and patchy. On
Tuesday...weak riding aloft will allow for another dry day with
high temperatures reaching into the lower to mid 80s across many
valley locations. As tonight's weak wave moves east of the
area...models do hint at some isolated convection developing in
the afteroon across higher elevations. However...this activity
appears to be confined to area east of the TN/NC border and and
this time is not expected to affect the local forecast area.

.LONG TERM (Tuesday night through Monday)...
Fairly active pattern Wednesday through Monday with an upper ridge 
over the region for Wednesday with a series of upper troughs moving 
across the eastern half of the nation for Thursday through Monday. 
Models are in fairly good agreement for Thursday and Friday, but 
differ greatly Saturday night and Sunday. The ECMWF has a much 
stronger phasing of northern and southern stream troughs producing a 
stronger system.  Lets get to the particulars.

For Tuesday night and Wednesday, upper ridging will keep most 
location dry except for the higher elevations, such as the far east 
Tennessee Mountains and Plateau. Will continue with a low chance 
afternoon/evening PoPs there. A warm day as southerly winds will be 
increasing as pressure gradients tighten.

For Thursday, upper ridge breaks down with increasing jet dynamics 
and pre-frontal surface trough producing scattered to numerous 
showers and afternoon thunderstorms. Model soundings show increase 
in instability and moisture, but limited threat for severe. Main 
concern will be some locally heavy rains over the southern half of 
the valley where jet dynamics best.

For Friday, frontal boundary will move across the region. High 
chance to likely showers. Instability is limited with mainly showers 
and possibly an embedded thunder.

For Saturday, models begin to differ with the ECMWF hanging front up 
across the Tennessee Valley while the GFS takes the boundary south 
of the area. Will maintain chances of showers and embedded storms.

For Sunday, ECMWF and GFS differ greatly with the ECMWF with a 
stronger phased system. Will continue with high chance to likely 
showers and thunderstorms. Low confidence on how this storm system 
plays out. Drier weather returns for Monday.

169 
FXUS64 KMRX 060730
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
330 AM EDT Mon May 6 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
A mostly clear sky across the forecast area early this morning. 
Some lower clouds remain over the northeast half of the area. 
Temperatures have dropped into the 50s with fog forming this hour 
at several sites across east Tennessee, southwest Virginia and 
southwest North Carolina. High clouds from on-going convection in
eastern OK are streaming from AR into West Tennessee at this hour
and should spread into the forecast area later this morning. This
my reverse fog formation in a few hours but with visibilities 
dropping right now will issue a Special Weather Statement in the 
next hour for patchy dense fog for the next 6 hours or until mid 
morning. High pressure will provide mostly sunny skies after the 
fog burns off but some high cloudiness from convection to the west
may affect the brightness at times today. Warmer temperatures 
will be felt with highs in the upper 70s to lower 80s...about 5 
degrees above normal. Tonight more mostly clear skies as high 
pressure is centered nearly overhead of the southern Appalachians.
Lows tonight should be slightly cooler in the upper 40s to mid 
50s. With drier air mass fog will likely be more localized.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Monday)...
Strong mid-level ridging will keep subsidence and very dry air over 
the forecast area on Tuesday with a mostly clear sky. Some models 
are attempting to develop weak convection across the mountains, but 
believe this would be very limited with the amount of dry air 
entrainment any convective updraft would have to overcome. With the 
ridging and clear skies, temperatures should be warm and near 7-10 
degrees above normal. By Wednesday afternoon, ridging is expected to 
weaken and the ridge axis will shift to our east with moist 
southwesterly flow through the low and mid-levels of the atmosphere. 
With higher moisture, expect at least slight chance/chance PoPs 
during the late afternoon hours, especially across the higher 
elevations.

On Thursday, shortwave energy originating from the longwave trough 
across the Western CONUS will lead to PVA and height falls across 
the forecast area. A surface low will also track northeast from the 
Great Plains to the Great Lakes by Thursday night with a trailing 
cold front. The NAEFS and ECMWF show PW values near 1.5 to 1.7 
inches late Thursday, which is near the 95th percentile. While this 
would seem to favor a heavy rain and localized flooding threat, 
there are a few mitigating factors that could limit overall QPF. 
First, the surface low and best forcing is north of the region. In 
addition, the low will be beginning the occlusion process late 
Thursday night with the cold front forward motion slowing. In this 
more weakly forced environment, widespread heavy convection appears 
less likely. The GFS has been consistent with showing convection to 
our south limiting convection further north across our area, and 
this scenario is definitely possible. Regardless, there will be 
enough moisture in the atmosphere for some heavier downpours and at 
least localized flooding with thunderstorms. Furthermore, with the 
surface low and best dynamics north of the area, the overall severe 
threat appears marginal.

Models continue to diverge into the weekend with the GFS taking the 
cold front southeast of our area and keeping us drier with the ECMWF 
and Canadian favoring a wetter pattern as a surface low develops 
over Texas and tracks northeastward across the Tennessee Valley. 
While the GFS remains dry, the GEFS mean is wetter and is more 
similar to the operational ECMWF and Canadian solutions. For this 
reason, will lean toward the GEFS/ECMWF solution for the weekend. As 
troughing develops over the Eastern CONUS, expect temperatures to be 
near or below normal next weekend into the early part of the next 
work week.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
254 PM EDT Sun May 5 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Monday)...

The short term synoptic outlook for this afternoon begins with a 
surface low off to the northeast that will continue to track 
offshore. Zonal flow aloft will help to speed the low pressure 
centers departure and lead to less active synoptic weather for the 
early week. Pressure will increase as a weak ridge off to the west 
builds into the southern Appalachians helping to clear out the 
lingering rain by late this afternoon. Saturated atmospheric 
profiles, along with northwesterly flow will lead to some persistent 
showers for the eastern Tennessee mountains due to orographic 
lifting.

Mid level dry air will continue to move in later this afternoon 
which will help to slowly clear out the mid level clouds. Still 
mostly scattered to broken skies expected overnight as the lower 
levels will remain saturated. Given plenty of residual moisture in 
the PBL patchy fog formation is expected across the region early 
tomorrow morning. Skies will clear out on Monday high pressure 
continues to build into the region.

.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Sunday)...

The extended will begin 
in a rather quiet weather pattern.  Surface high pressure will be in 
control with a weak ridge building in aloft.  As a result...expect 
dry conditions and warm afternoon highs generally in the 80s for 
Monday and Tuesday.  Wednesday will be a transition day as the 
surface high and upper ridge shift east...allowing the approach of 
the first weather system of the extended.  Ahead of this low 
pressure system...southerly flow will increase low level moisture 
and a minor impulse in the upper flow will produce a chance of 
convection across the region during the Wednesday afternoon/evening 
time frame.  The cold front will push in on Thursday.  At this 
point...deep moisture will be in place and with significant 
additional moisture accompanying the front...expect to see a well 
organized line of thunderstorms capable of producing heavy rainfall. 

Model consistency decreases over the remainder of the extended.  The 
ECMWF has been the more consistent run to run with the idea of 
stalling the frontal boundary over the general area Friday through 
the weekend with a series of short waves riding along the boundary. 
This scenario will keep the MRX CWA in an active weather pattern... 
allowing for at least a chance of convection each day.  The current 
GFS has trended the boundary slightly to our south on Friday then 
brings an area of low pressure into the area for the weekend. 
So...even with the low confidence in details over the last few days 
of the extended...overall the models do trend toward an active 
pattern and will maintain the current forecast idea of basically 
chance to likely convection each period.

National Weather Service Morristown TN
354 AM EDT Sun May 5 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Low pressure along a cold front now over east Tennessee slowly
moves east this morning and afternoon and will shift most of the 
rain to the other side of the Appalachians by this afternoon. The
current rainfall was light to moderate with most amounts 0.1 to
0.3 inches in the past hour and some locations reporting over one
inch across the central valley and northern plateau. No
significant flooding is expected and let flash flood watch go as 
hourly rainfall amounts have been low. However some localized high
water in spots over the central valley tonight, especially where
heavier rains fell during the day Saturday. Temperatures have 
been mild overnight in the lower to mid 60s. Some patchy fog has 
reduced visibilities to around 2 to 4 miles where it is raining. 
Another one half inch or so of rainfall is possible for this 
morning and afternoon before the rain moves out. Clouds will 
linger during the day today with clearing in the southwest 
sections this afternoon. All areas will have clearing trend 
tonight with patchy fog forming after midnight. It may become 
dense in places that had significant rainfall Saturday and 
overnight tonight. Temperatures stay cooler today lower to mid 70s
with clouds and northwest winds. Tonight temperatures cool into 
the lower to mid 50s. 

.LONG TERM...(Monday through Sunday)...
The extended period begins relatively quiet with surface high 
pressure over the region on Monday and Tuesday. Upper-level ridging 
will increase across the Southeast CONUS on Monday with ridging 
firmly in control and centered to our south on Tuesday. One of the 
main changes in this forecast package was decreasing PoPs on Tuesday 
through Wednesday morning as model consensus keeps the upper and mid-
level ridge axis to our west during this time period with strong 
subsidence capping convective activity. Forecast soundings verify 
this thinking with very dry mid-level air and a pronounced inversion 
between 850mb and 700mb across southern and central portions of the 
CWA. The inversion is weakest across northern sections of the area, 
but the boundary layer is forecast to be too dry to support 
convection.

By Wednesday afternoon, ridge axis shifts eastward with southerly 
flow and increasing low-level moisture returning to the forecast 
area. Longwave troughing will be present across the Western CONUS 
with small shortwaves exiting northeastward across the Mississippi 
and Ohio Valleys. This will increase chances of some showers or 
thunderstorms late Wednesday. By Thursday, models are in good 
agreement with a stronger shortwave and associated surface low 
moving northeast across the Great Plains toward the Great Lakes. As 
ridging weakens and multiple rounds of shortwave energy trek across 
the region, will see increasing PoPs during this time period with 
the highest PoPs forecast as the surface front approaches Thursday 
night into Friday. Heavy rainfall will be possible with PW values 
from the NAEFS and EPS near the 95th percentile across the Tennessee 
Valley. The highest severe weather threat appears to remain west and 
northwest of our area closer to the surface low, but there will be 
enough deep layer shear for thunderstorm organization if enough 
instability is present. CIPS Analog Guidance confirms this thinking 
with the potential for some heavy rain and at least a low risk of 
some strong to severe thunderstorms. Given the setup and the 
climatologically favorable period, should at least continue to 
monitor the potential for strong to severe thunderstorms late week.

Models diverge in how they handle the weekend setup. The GFS favors 
the front stalling to our south while the ECMWF and Canadian keep 
the front closer to our area with continued rainfall potential 
through the weekend. At this point, will continue with the blend and 
highlight the high uncertainty on Day 7-8.

towards the northeast along with increasing WAA ahead of the cold 
front.

Mostly showers with a few isolated thunderstorms possible today with 
the greatest potential for severe weather further to the south. 
Still, some decent MLCAPE values for the more southern area of the 
CWA this afternoon and evening along with PW values near the max 
moving average for the region, mean that severe weather is still 
possible. The greatest threats will be from strong winds and heavy 
rain with hail of up to an inch diameter is possible from more 
organized cells. DCAPE values around 800 J/kg could produce 
downburst and outflow boundary winds from deteriorating storms that 
could see gusts up to 60mph. Some localized flooding is also 
possible for any training storms due to the high PW with up to an 
inch of rainfall. Areas of southwestern Virginia in particular could 
see between an inch to two inches of rainfall tonight.

Sunday will see a few lingering showers persisting into the day. 
Veering winds behind the cold front will become predominantly from 
the northwest. A few thunderstorms are possible for the eastern 
mountains in the afternoon due to orographic lifting resulting from 
the aforementioned winds.

.LONG TERM...(Sunday night through Saturday)...

As the extended period begins...a cold front will have recently 
pushed east of the area...surface high pressure will be building 
in and a minor wave will be riding through the upper flow. The air
mass that will be slowly filtering in will be a bit drier and 
cooler and fairly stable. There could potentially be a few 
lingering showers over the far eastern mountains Sunday evening in
response to the exiting front but the short wave moving through 
will have little moisture or lift to work with and its main 
contribution should be a brief increase in clouds. The surface 
high will dominate area weather through Monday...aided but weak 
ridging aloft. By Tuesday the high will be shifting east with the 
ridge aloft dampened down slightly. The GFS continues to indicate 
a short wave moving up through the Carolinas on Tuesday. This 
feature could generate some isolated shower activity over the 
eastern mountains. The rest of the area should remain dry and with
southern flow around the high...warmer air will quickly return. 

Confidence in details becomes quite low through the rest of the 
extended as models continue to diverge.  Overall...we should be 
transitioning into a rather active and unsettle weather pattern for 
the Wednesday through Saturday period.  The GFS appears more 
aggressive and active through the period bringing an area of low 
pressure through late Tuesday night into Wednesday with deep 
moisture and decent lift...then it pulls a cold front through on 
Thursday then additional upper level waves/boundary moves through 
Friday into the weekend.  On the other hand...the ECMWF maintains 
weak ridging over the area on Wednesday then tracks a cold front 
through on Thursday...stalls the boundary over the general area as a 
series of impulses ride through and across the MRX CWA.  So...even 
through confidence is quite low on details as mentioned 
earlier...the overall trend indicates a rather wet pattern and will 
keep a mix of chance and likely POPs in the forecast through the 
later half of the extended.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
