MS moving toward the Tennessee Valley and another larger complex 
along the SE Texas coast moving east along the Gulf Coast. These 
features will impact the southeast states later today and into 
tonight producing scattered to numerous showers and storms by late
this morning and continuing this afternoon and evening just ahead
of the cold front. The risk for severe storms is slightly lower 
today as the best instability, moisture and low level shear will 
be across central AL into north GA and the Carolinas later today. 
The forecast area will be on the northern edge. The southern 
Valley, southeast Tennessee mountains and southwest North Carolina
will have the best chance of seeing isolated strong thunderstorms
with damaging winds and hail possibly up to 1 inch diameter. 
Soundings show Cape values up to about 1400 J/KG during the 
afternoon in the southern valley. Locally heavy rainfall is 
possible late this afternoon and evening across the southern half 
of the area and especially the eastern mountains this evening. 
There may be some localized flooding at that especially if storms 
regenerate in the same areas. Highs today should be several 
degrees cooler as clouds increase this morning. Also behind the 
front lows will drop into the 50s with more rainfall overnight. 

.LONG TERM...(Sunday through Friday)...
The cold front will be to the south and east of the forecast area
to start the long-term forecast period. Models indicate that 
moisture will remain a bit elevated just behind the front early 
Sunday with PW values in the 0.8-1.0 inch range. These values are 
slightly above the 50th percentile for early May and expect a few 
lingering showers/storms early Sunday. Drier air will eventually 
advect into the area late Sunday morning into the afternoon and 
overall expect most of the forecast area will be dry on Sunday. 
The cold advection behind the front is rather weak with forecast 
highs on Sunday in the 70s for most locations.

Another weak shortwave trough is forecast to move through the area 
late Sunday into Monday but by this time, PW values will be down 
near the 25th percentile for early May. Overall, just expect an 
increase in mid to high clouds Sunday night into Monday morning with 
lows in the 50s for most locations.

A ridge begins to setup across the area late Monday into Tuesday 
with the main jet stream well to the north across the Great Lakes. 
Temperatures will warm during this timeframe with increasing upper 
level heights. Highs on Monday will be in the upper 70s to low 80s 
with mid to upper 80s forecast by Tuesday for most valley locations. 

Start to see some model inconsistencies with timing of the mid-week 
system. The GFS is much quicker and stronger with an upper level 
rough moving in from the west. The GFS shows a surface low 
associated with this system and strong low level southerly flow 
advecting in moisture to the region. With this solution, 
precipitation will return on Wednesday. The ECMWF solution is much 
weaker with the trough and not seeing much reflected at the surface. 
Due to this, the ECMWF indicates that Wednesday will be mostly dry 
with a more robust system approaching on Thursday. For now, have 
chance PoPs for most locations to account for the GFS solution. 
Regardless of timing, the mid to late week period will be more 
active as the ridge axis shifts to the east with southwesterly flow 
aloft. Several shortwave troughs are forecast to traverse the area 
with elevated PoPs features throughout much of the extended
forecast.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Showers and thunderstorms ended and moved northeast of the area
around midnight with skies clearing. A MCV moving east across 
western KY and western TN towards middle TN early this morning 
was developing scattered to numerous showers and thunderstorms 
approaching Nashville. This MCV and surface low will approach the
southern plateau around sunrise and then move east into the
northeast sections of the forecast area by afternoon. Clouds and
rain chances increase from southwest to northeast later this
morning and afternoon. Have highest rain chances northeast during
the day today. The air mass will become most unstable across
northeast sections with some sun in the morning there. Mid level 
lapse rates will be around 6.5 to 7.0 C/KM. A few storms may be
strong to severe northeast with isolated damaging winds and a few
with large hail. Temperatures will be slightly cooler with highs
in the mid 70s to lower 80s. Locally heavy rain will accompany the
convection in western sections this morning and then central and
northeast third this afternoon. Do not expect any significant
flooding with rainfall amounts generally a half inch or less in
storms. Tonight the MCV will have moved northeast and there 
should be a marked decrease in showers and storms after sunset. 
The weak cold front to the west and northwest now along the lower 
Ohio and Mississippi Rivers this morning will be moving closer 
with more showers and storms ahead of low pressure moving out of 
Arkansas early Saturday. The convection ahead of it is not 
expected to reach east Tennessee before morning so have kept pops 
low tonight. 

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Friday)...
To start the long-term forecast period a 90-110 kt 300mb jet will 
stretch from the western Great Lakes into the Northeastern U.S. This 
will put the forecast are in the right entrance region of the jet. 
At 500 mb, a shortwave trough is forecast to move out of the Lower 
Mississippi River Valley into the Tennessee River Valley during the 
day Saturday. In response to the jet at 300mb, the 850 mb jet 
will increase across the forecast area into the 25-40 kts 
depending on model solution. At the surface, a cold front will be 
located to the northwest of the forecast area to start the day on 
Saturday and will drift slowly to the southeast throughout the 
day. Model soundings indicate SBCAPE values ranging from around 
750-1500 J/KG with mid level lapse rates around 6-6.5 degrees 
C/km. The NAM is the most aggressive model with SBCAPE values over
2000 J/Kg but for now think there will be too much cloud cover to
realize these values. With the strong jet to the northeast, 0-6 
km deep layer shear will range from around 40-55 kts and there 
could be a few more organized storms. Due to this, there is 
currently a slight risk across the southeastern half of the 
forecast area for Saturday. Low level 0-1 km SRH values are not 
overly high in the 100-150 m2/s2 range and expect the chances for 
any tornadoes would be very low. For now, thinking the SBCAPE 
values will be on the lower end with the continued cloud cover 
during the day and think most hail should stay under severe 
criteria. The main threat with the storms will be isolated 
damaging wind gusts. In addition to the severe potential, PW 
values will be in the 1.3-1.5 inch range. These values are over 
the 90th percentile for early May and there could be some 
localized flash flooding, especially in areas of poor drainage. 
Models are struggling with the timing of the frontal passage and 
have lingered some chances for thunderstorms into the early 
morning hours on Sunday. 

PoPs will decrease from southwest to northeast throughout the day on 
Sunday as the front exits to the south and east. Dry air will advect 
into the area behind the departing boundary. Not seeing much in the 
way of cold advection behind the boundary with zonal flow aloft for 
Sunday. Expect mostly to partly sunny skies by the end of the day 
Sunday with highs in the 70s for most locations. 

The GFS and ECMWF are both in agreement that a ridge is forecast to 
move into the area to start the work week. Temperatures will rise 
throughout this period with highs in the mid 70s to low 80s on 
Monday and 80s across most the region by Tuesday with dry 
conditions. The ridge will begin to breakdown by the middle of the 
week with rain chances returning Tuesday night into Wednesday.

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Friday)...Weather becomes a little more 
active each day as we head into the weekend with a relatively 
energetic mean southwest flow in association with long wave 
troughing across Middle America and an already healthy sub 
tropical high parked over the Western Atlantic. In this flow 
pattern, in the short term, a couple of waves of low pressure are 
making their way east northeast out of the Midwest; initially for 
this afternoon and tonight, and then a more well developed wave 
emerges out of the Lower Mississippi Valley for Friday. Some 
instability is present across the forecast area this afternoon, 
with a bit of capping evident in visible satellite and radar 
imagery over the Southern Appalachian region. Apparently, 
orographic lifting is aiding convection on the Cumberland Plateau.
Outflow from this action along with some fresh lift on the 
southern end the initial wave over the Ohio Valley may allow for 
some scattered to widely scattered convection across the viewing 
area this evening. Decreasing buoyancy later tonight leads to a 
decrease in the action while awaiting the arrival of the second 
wave Friday morning. This feature appears to be the best synoptic 
lifting mechanism than we have seen if a few days. Model forecasts
depict a relatively significant upper wave with a nice surface 
reflection. The surface low associated with the wave rides 
steadily east northeast on a path just northwest of the mrx 
forecast area; beginning late tonight in the Lower Ohio Valley, 
with eventual arrival in the Central Appalachians by early Friday 
evening. In this scenario model depiction brings a nice, deep 
moist axis in a moderately unstable environment with just a bit of
0-6km shear (on the order of 20-25 kts) into the forecast area 
from morning into the early afternoon hours. The severe storms 
forecast center has placed Southwest Virginia in a marginal 
category for the possibility of severe thunderstorm development. 
Therefore, a few storms could produce strong wind gusts. Also, wet
bulb zero heights will be around 9k feet, so there could be a bit
of hail with the strongest updrafts. Model depiction shows the 
offending wave slipping east across the Appalachian spine around 
mid afternoon so active weather would be decreasing from west to 
east through the middle part of the day into the later afternoon. 
The temperature scheme looked on track with somewhat muted, 
although still several degrees above normal maxes highs in the 
lower 80s most spots and mild lows in the upper 50s and lower 60s 
north to the middle 60s plateau and south. 

.LONG TERM (Friday night through Thursday)...Synoptic pattern 
starting for the long term outlook begins with the most prominent 
feature being a longwave trough over the central CONUS with a 
strong Bermuda high still in place out in the Atlantic. The 
trailing end of an old cold front originating from a low pressure 
system over New England will have stalled over the Tennessee 
valley. The upper level ridge will start to break down Saturday as
several shortwaves progress along the edge of the elongated cold 
front this weekend.

SPC outlook currently has east Tennesee, southwest Virginia, and 
southwest North Carolina within the marginal category for severe 
weather on Saturday. Strong southwesterly flow ahead of the incoming 
trough will lead to increased thermal and moisture advection which 
will provide increasing theta-e values. An 850mb jet between 35 to 
40kts will set up ahead of the shortwave on Saturday afternoon. 
Model soundings show a fairly unidirectional flow that will limit 
shear.

MLCAPES values around 1700 J/kg for the southern counties with 
decreased values further up the valley. The low level jet along with 
potential of precip loading could produce localized damaging winds. 
PW values of 1.5in is above the 90% average for this time of year so 
any training storms could produce localized flash flooding. Models 
currently indicate higher precip potential for the Cumberland 
Plateau and the northeastern Tennessee mountains. Along with FFG, a 
greater potential for flooding will exist around southwestern 
Virginia. HCAPE of around 350 to 400 J/kg could lead to some hail 
formation for any developing cells, but not expecting anything 
greater than 1/2" sized. Overall, Strong to severe thunderstorms are 
possible Saturday afternoon with the greatest threat being high 
winds and heavy rains.

The convective potential falls away Saturday night with mostly 
showers and a few possible lingering thunderstorms. Mostly showers 
on Sunday, mainly mountains since the main forcing being orographic 
lift. High pressure comes back into control early next week with 
increased ridging Monday through Wednesday. An upper level low over 
southern California looks to undergo increasing cyclogenesis and 
further develop a trough over the southwest. The synoptic pattern 
for next week will increase in amplitude as the ridge over the mid 
Atlantic states builds.

Outlook becomes lower confidence past Wednesday next week, as models 
don't have consensus on the mid week shortwave. GFS brings some 
showers into eastern Tennessee by early Wednesday morning, while the 
Euro holds it back until the afternoon.

.LONG TERM (Thursday night through Wednesday)...The extended 
range fcst period kicks off on Thursday evening amidst H5 
subtropical ridging over the western Atlantic, while deep nearly 
full latitude troughing consumes much of the remaining CONUS 
promoting deep swly flow across the MS/OH and TN Valleys. At the 
surface, high pressure across the eastern seaboard (consequent of 
the aforementioned Bermuda ridge) will be continually weakened 
thanks to falling H5 heights and an approaching surface wave/front
out of the Plains/Midwest states.

with daytime heating could favor ongoing sct convection across the 
Great Valley and Southern Appalachians, generally airmass type 
thunderstorms.  Likewise and further west, convection tied to the

heating and no sig upper lvl support.  On Friday, guidance favors 
the frontal boundary essentially washing out and stalling somewhere 
across the lower OH valley into the TN Valley region, which combined 
with daytime heating should provide additional focusing for 
convection Friday afternoon.  Meanwhile to the west, a potent 
shortwave looks to work through the mean H5 trough across the 
Southern Plains thereby favoring a region of surface cyclogenesis

associated front will work east/northeast across the TN Valley and 
Southern Appalachian region on Saturday.  Although timing of

instability, profiles are sufficiently unstable and moist for deep 
convection.  

Behind the front, a few residual upslope forced showers are

and upper heights build aloft as another ridge advects in.  By 
Tuesday the pattern should return to more of a summerlike setup with 
deep ridging and perhaps some mtn convection expected.

thunderstorms are favored with small hail, gusty winds, and brief 
heavy rainfall possible.  The best chances for heavy rainfall would

pwats in excess of The extended range fcst period kicks off on Thursday evening amidst

.DISCUSSION...
We remain in a -PNA pattern with longwave troughing across the
western half of the country and ridging over the Eastern CONUS. A
shortwave trough ejecting out of the base of the longwave is 
assisting with deep convective development across the Southern 
and Central Plains this evening, but strong mid-level ridging and 
surface high pressure are keeping us dry.

High pressure to the east will result in low-level southwest flow
and an increase in boundary layer moisture on Wednesday. While
instability will be on the increase during the afternoon, there
will be limited lift as shortwave energy remains to our west. In 
addition, mid-level ridging remains strong through the day with 
RAP and NAM forecast soundings indicating very dry air between 700
and 500 mb which will hinder deep convective updrafts. For these 
reasons, expect any convection to be limited and primarily across 
the higher elevations of Southeast Tennessee where differential 
heating along the terrain may enhance convergence and provide a 
source for increased mesoscale lift. With this in mind, believe 
CAMs are on track with general location and timing of convection 
on Wednesday afternoon but are overdoing coverage and PoPs. With 
low and mid- level heights nearly identical to today, expect 
temperatures to be very similar with max temperatures in the mid 
80s for most locations. The main limiting factor would be cloud 
cover, and for the most part, expect a mostly clear sky with 
cirrus similar to what was observed today which guidance appears 
to be handling for tomorrow.

National Weather Service Morristown TN

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Tuesday)...

A warm front, currently located over the central valley, will have 
lifted north of the CWA by later this evening as low pressure 
strengthens in the plains and a broad southerly flow regime sets up 
across the region locally. With high pressure overhead, expect 
another night of clear skies, save perhaps a few high clouds passing 
by at times. With the surface warm front to our north and higher 
dewpoints in place, some patchy fog could develop tonight. Do not 
believe it will be very widespread at all, likely confined to 
portions of the northern valley and into southwest Virginia where 
temperatures will be cooler and overnight RH the highest.

For tomorrow, another disturbance will be ejecting into the plains 
from the southern Rockies, while upper ridging strengthens overhead 
here in the southeast United States. The result will be a warm, 
summer like pattern, with highs around 5-10 degrees above normal. 
Model soundings for points throughout the forecast area show a 
capped atmosphere tomorrow. Have much of the area rain free, with 
only some scattered afternoon clouds in the forecast. However, 
higher elevation locales will likely be at or just above the 
inversion, so expect to see at the very least some better vertical 
growth to afternoon clouds, but more likely some isolated showers 
and thunderstorm development during the afternoon hours tomorrow. 
Most, if not all, of this will likely remain on the NC side of 
things but would not be surprised if a shower or two is able to 
start on the TN side of the line. Steering flow shows a northeast 
movement so, save some possible outflow boundary development, any 
storms that do form in TN would move into NC fairly quick. Have some 
slight chance PoPs in the forecast from the Smokies to the northeast 
TN mountains tomorrow afternoon, and this should cover it just
fine.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday night through Monday)...

Mid level ridge and and low levels winds wrapping around a high off 
the East Coast will continue Tuesday night through the middle of the 
work week. The predominant impact from this ridge will be the 
continued warm temperatures across the area. Temperatures on 
Wednesday and Thursday will continue to be around 10 degrees above 
normal. These very warm temperatures will try and force afternoon 
convection to initiate, but relatively dry soundings indicate that 
coverage of any storms that do develop Tuesday/Wednesday afternoon 
would be limited. Best chances will be along the terrain of the 
Southern Appalachian Mountains.

Low pressure system will try and make a dent in the ridge over the 
second half of the work week and a surface low will try and drag a 
front through the Southeast U.S. Models seem to be slowing down this 
system just a tad over the past few runs, potentially indicating the 
ridge is stronger than previously forecasted or that the incoming 
weather system won't pack as much of a punch. So best chances of 
precipitation are looking more likely during the daytime on Friday. 

Boundary loses it's forward momentum as we head into the weekend 
with the best dynamics of this system having moved off to the 
northeast. This means it is currently forecasted to stall out 
somewhere around the Tennessee Valley. Precipitation chances remain 
somewhat high Friday through most of the weekend as a few weak 
ripples of energy zip along the boundary. These showers and the 
associated cloud coverage will help cool us off a bit keeping 
temperatures near, but still above normal over the weekend.

Precipitation chances decrease as we head into the new work week, 
but they don't completely go away as southerly winds continue to 
draw up moisture from the Gulf of Mexico. A shortwave looks to push 
through the Southeast U.S. just beyond the end of the 7-day forecast.

National Weather Service Morristown TN
320 PM EDT Sun Apr 28 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Monday)...

The cold front is situated along/east of the I-75/I-81 corridor
this afternoon. It's a weak front, with little in the way of
clouds and only a few locations showing a discernible wind shift.
But there is a notable drop in dewpoints behind the front. The
front should slowly continue to push south and east of our area
tonight as high pressure to our north slides east across the lower
great lakes region.

Skies should clear out tonight as drier air moves in. Winds will
die down as well, and temperatures will respond accordingly. Lows
in the 40s to low 50s are expected tonight. With the influence of
high pressure waning tomorrow, and southerly winds returning
across the region, expect a significant warm up tomorrow. Highs on
Monday should rise into the lower 80s for most areas.

.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Sunday)...
 
Mid level ridging and low level high pressure off the East Coast 
will continue for through the middle of the work week. These will 
lead to well above average temperatures, with a pattern that is more 
comparable to summer than spring. Soundings and model output 
suggests that there will be enough daytime heating that we possibly 
develop some thunderstorms. Chances will be greatest each 
afternoon/evening along the Southern Appalachian Mountains. But 
there will be a pretty stable conditions and a dry atmosphere that 
make it difficult for storms to be able to develop, especially over 
the valley.

Best chances for widespread showers and thunderstorms will come on 
Thursday/Friday as front moves nearer and shortwave zips across the 
Tennessee Valley. Models still differ on how far/fast to move the 
front through the Southeastern states as we head into the weekend 
leading to a decrease in forecast confidence at the end of the work 
week. Definitely expect storms to occur, but certainty on timing of 
the storms is low. 

Once the front moves through then rain chances start to decrease as 
higher PWAT is pushed away. A few ripples of energy look to possibly 
move through at the end of next weekend, so rain chances won't 
completely be eliminated at this time.

and stable soundings will make for difficult conditions for 
afternoon convective development. Only the higher terrain along 
the NC border will have a chance of breaking the cap on Tuesday 
and Wednesday afternoons.

the Plains and the ridge to our east starts to weaken its grip. 
Increasing moisture advection should produce scattered coverage on 
Thursday, although synoptic forcing remains weak. Stronger forcing 
is expected on Friday as a shortwave trough crosses the MS River, so 
PoPs will rise to the likely range. GFS and ECMWF are coming into 
better agreement on this timing, although they differ on the trough 
amplification. With the trough moving to our east, Saturday should 
be dry and cooler with highs in the 70s.

or take an hour or two. Later this evening some isolated to

are already on the increase, and as the low level jet shifts
eastward into the CWA. Do have some slight chance PoPs in to

night/early Sun morning there will be another round of showers
associated with the cold front as it moves through. There isn't
much in the way of moisture to work with here, and forecast PWAT 
values showing values of only about an inch. Behind the front, 
some gusty winds will be seen. They will remain below advisory 
levels, but a few gusts of 15-20 mph may be seen in the Tri-Cities
area especially, with lesser gusts the further south you go.

.LONG TERM...(Sunday night through Saturday)...

Generally zonal flow in the mid/upper levels and southerly flow 
around a high off the East Coast of the United States will combine
to maintain benign/warm weather to end the weekend. The zonal 
flow will transition into a ridging pattern ahead of an 
approaching system. This will help to continue to increase 
temperatures about 10-15 degrees above normal for the first half 
of the work week. Closer to the surface the front that is expected
to stall out around the Southern Tennessee Valley will try and 
push back to the north on Monday. But with no additional influx of
moisture, expect it to remain pretty dry throughout the day. 
Generally a persistent pattern will continue through most of 
Monday/Tuesday.

With these warm temperatures the atmosphere is closer to what we 
typically see in the summer months with scattered convection 
possible on Wednesday. Best chances for precip will be closer to 
the terrain of the Southern Appalachian Mountains, but will 
maintain low end scattered chances throughout the valley. Similar 
situation looks to set up on Thursday, but with more moisture to 
work with and a more unstable environment closer to an approaching
cold front it looks like the coverage of storms will be greater, 
so have bumped up precipitation chances on Thursday evening.

Long range models all indicating that the front from the 
west/northwest will move through sometime around Thursday night 
into Friday. Timing is still a bit different between long term 
models, but right now the highest chances for precipitation look 
to occur during the daytime on Friday. Once the front moves 
through temperatures drop down close to normal.

half of the weekend and into the work week. This will bring along 
with it a surface low tracking across the Ohio River Valley.

generally be confined to a shallow mid/low level layer with dry air

precipitation chances with light QPF amounts in the forecast. Front

the cooler air never gets a chance to make it's way into the eastern 
Tennessee Valley

much of the Valley locations. Rain chances begin to increase 
starting on Thursday as a shortwave zips through the plains states

with this system as the long range models differ on how to handle

FXUS64 KMRX 260724

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
324 AM EDT Fri Apr 26 2019

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...A low pressure system will
continue to push through and then exit the Southern Appalachian
Region today. The air mass has become rather stable and at best
may see a stray rumble of thunder. The rain should slowly push out
and exit from west to east this morning into early afternoon
followed by clouds decreasing during the afternoon. The main
concern today will be increasing winds. A tightening pressure
gradient and a 30 to 40 KT 850MB jet will generate breezy and
gusty winds across the area. Higher elevations of the East TN
Mountains are expected to see winds reach to advisory criteria and
a Wind Advisory has been issue for today for this area.
However...wind are already beginning to increase and so will begin
the Advisory with the morning package. The rest of the area will
see winds increase but expect gusts to reach around 30 MPH and
remain below advisory criteria. However...will monitor the winds
and re-evaluate if they become stronger that anticipated and in
the mean time will issue an SPS for the strong and gusty winds. By
this evening...most areas will be dry with clearing skies...with
only a few lingering isolated showers possible over far
northwestern locations. Winds will decrease this evening as the
low continue to pull away from the area.

.LONG TERM (Saturday through Thursday)...A low pressure system 
will track across IL/IN/OH late Saturday and Saturday evening, 
bringing a cold front across the area Saturday night. With the low
to midlevel flow ahead of this system being mainly westerly and 
the midlevel shortwave trough bring weakly amplified, the front 
will have very little moisture to work with. Forecast soundings 
show moisture confined above 700 mb, with very dry air below until
Sunday morning, then as the low levels moisten with fropa, the 
mid/upper levels quickly dry. The position of the jet stream well 
to the north will also mean that lift will be weak. So only slight
chance PoPs will be mentioned with the frontal passage Saturday 
night and Sunday morning. 

The front settles to our south on Sunday with the flow aloft 
remaining nearly zonal. With a lack of cold advection behind the 
front and mostly sunny skies, high temps Sunday will still be in the 
70s. A building ridge over the western Atlantic and Gulf will push 
the front back to our north on Monday, but no precip is expected 
with this as moisture remains very limited. The building ridge 
across the Southeast coast and the resulting SW flow across the 
Appalachians will bring a warming trend that will push highs into 
the 80s in most spots for Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Superblend 
PoPs appear to high for the pattern and will be undercut these days. 
Models indicate some weakening of the ridge and a Midwest trough 
developing late in the week that may bring a chance of rain to the 
area Thursday, but will keep PoPs in the low chance range as 
confidence is low.

FXUS64 KMRX 251912
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
312 PM EDT Thu Apr 25 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Friday)...

A developing upper level low, currently over the east central Great 
Plains, continues to track to the east northeast with an amplifying 
ridge over the east coast states that is trying to remain in place. 
A shortwave is located over the northern Great Plains moving east 
into the Great Lakes region with an old stalled out frontal boundary 
stuck over the Ohio valley. As the upper low in the south moves to 
the northeast, along with the northern shortwave, they look to begin 
to phase overnight eventually forming a greater amplitude longwave 
trough.

Ongoing southerly winds today will aid in increased WAA ahead of the 
incoming front, leading to more saturated lapse rates later this 
evening and overnight. A few scattered showers expected through the 
rest of the day for the southern areas of the CWA. The bulk of the 
precip will arrive later this evening and persist through most of 
the night. Some thunderstorms are possible this afternoon as MLCAPE 
values will hover around 400-600 J/kg according to the NAM, with 
MUCAPE values up to 1500 J/kg. A decent amount of deep layer shear 
between 30-40 kts, will give any thunderstorms some amount of 
organization with associated localized high winds. PW values up to 
1.25in will lead to some heavier rain showers this evening.

A southwest to northeast oriented low level jet between 40-50kts 
ahead of the front will increase surface winds for tonight, but 
doesn't look to reach advisory criteria with the flow parallel to 
the mountain range. The overnight timing of the front doesn't look 
to be good for maximizing most of the convective parameters.
Upper level divergence looking weaker today as opposed to yesterday, 
along with lowered Theta-e and diminishing CAPE into the overnight 
hours. There is some decent positive omega associated with the 
trough along with continued 30-40kt 0-6km shear so thunderstorms are 
possible for the early overnight hours. The front itself looks to 
move through the area early Friday morning, moving over CHA just 
after midnight and looks to be east of TRI after sunrise. 

Winds will become west to northwest after FROPA with increased CAA 
moving into the region behind the front. A tightening pressure 
gradient after FROPA along with an 850mb jet of 35kts will  produce 
windy conditions area wide Friday. The strengthening northwest flow 
Friday along with a saturated airmass to 700mb will produce good 
upslope conditions. Widespread rain showers will continue in the far 
east Tennessee and southwestern Virginia mountains.

.LONG TERM...(Friday night through Thursday)...

A few light showers will linger early Friday night around far 
northeast TN and southwest VA from wrap around moisture on the 
backside of the departing upper trough. Kept slight chance pops 
through 03Z before high pressure begins to drop down from the 
northwest the rest of the night. Lows will be chilly with widespread 
low/mid 40's. Went slightly above MAV guidance.

The surface high will shift into the Carolinas Saturday with mid and 
upper level heights rebounding. This combined with the southerly 
return flow will allow temps to rebound into the mid 70's across 
much of the area with upper 70's in the southern valley. Trended a 
couple of degrees above MAV guidance for highs.

The only weather maker over the weekend will be a weakening cold 
front Saturday night into Sunday. Guidance continues to trend drier 
since our region will be on the tail end of a weakening shortwave 
trough and surface low moving through the northern OH Valley. 
Soundings show a couple hundred joules of CAPE, but with such 
limited frontogenetic forcing, only expect to see a broken line of 
very light showers. Have slight chance pops for showers with no 
thunder wording from 00Z Sunday through 18Z. There will be no 
airmass change behind the front, so highs will remain in generally 
the low/mid 70's Sunday afternoon. The weak frontal boundary looks 
to stall W-E along the TN, MS, AL, and GA borders Sunday afternoon 
and night. The latest GFS and ECMWF suggest a few scattered showers 
continuing near the boundary the rest of the afternoon, but with dry 
soundings and no real forcing mechanism, decided to keep all areas 
dry after 18Z Sunday through Sunday night.

As upper level troughing develops in the western U.S. early next 
week, an upper ridge will amplify in the Southeast U.S., reaching 
587 dam by Tuesday, with a strong surface high setting up near 
Bermuda. This will cause the stalled front to lift back north across 
the region Monday bringing the warmest temps of the season so far 
through mid week. The increasingly warm, humid, and unstable 
environment could lead to scattered convection as this front lifts 
through Monday, so have slight chance pops. Profiles look fairly 
capped Monday night through Tuesday night, so kept most areas dry, 
although isolated diurnal convection in the east TN mountains is 
possible, so have chance pops in that area during the day Tuesday.

Confidence is low for the Wednesday and Thursday timeframe. The 
ridge will be slowly breaking down allowing a cold front to approach 
from the west, but the timing is in poor agreement among the models. 
Given the moist and unstable environment, this front will be 
convectively active. Due to the uncertainty on timing and potential 
outflow boundaries ahead of the synoptic front, just ran chance pops 
for showers and storms Wednesday and Thursday.

FXUS64 KMRX 250717
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
317 AM EDT Thu Apr 25 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
An amplified upper pattern highlights the synoptic setup this 
morning as a closed H5 cyclone moves eastward atop the ArkLaTex 
region, effectively working to suppress the upper ridge anchored 
over the extreme southeast CONUS, while another northern stream 
shortwave moves eastward across the Northern Plains and Upper 
Midwest states.  At the surface, high pressure beneath the 
aforementioned upper ridge continues to hold across the TN Valley 
and Southern Appalachian region (albeit weakening with time), and an 
old frontal axis remains stalled atop the OH Valley region.  

The forecast today/tonight will be highlighted by the intrusion of 
the upper low and its associated/deepening surface low and front. 
Guidance favors increasing moisture through the profile as deep swly 
waa prevails out ahead of these features, which will inherently 
favor increasing precipitation chances as the period evolves. 
Specifically, am expecting iso/sct showers this morning across the 
western tier of the fcst area given proximity to the deepest 
moisture at present time. However as the entire complex shifts east, 
mid lvl lapse rates will steepen a bit, which combined with daytime 
heating will favor at least modest MUCAPE (1-1.5k j/kg) this 
afternoon. With that, iso/sct showers and thunderstorms will be 
possible this afternoon especially along/north of I40 and along/west 
of I75 given further proximity from the upper ridge and any 
associated CIN. Deep layer shear isn't off the charts, however 
respectable at around 30-40kts, therefore some weak organization of 
a few storms cannot be ruled out, but overall think the primary 
threats will be cloud to ground lightning and brief heavy rainfall.  

Moving into the evening/overnight hours, the focus shifts away from 
any prefrontal convection to that associated with the frontal 
intrusion itself.  CAMs favor the front moving east across Middle TN 
around midnight (give or take a hour) with the surface low and 
prefrontal trough out ahead across the Great Valley. Am expecting an 
overall decreasing trend in coverage ahead of these features, 
however ramping back up as they arrive.  Weak upper divergence and a 
40-50kt llj will accompany this second round of convection, however 
instability will be at a premium given nocturnal timing, and 
elevated at that.  Thus, although llv winds look a little better and 
coverage will be greater, think the lack of instability will be a 
significant detraction from deep/organized frontal convection.  That 
said, did include thunder in the forecast for the overnight period 
with a few strong storms packing gusty winds, brief heavy rainfall, 
and cloud to ground lightning not to be ruled out.  

.LONG TERM...(Friday through Wednesday)...
Expect to see some ongoing shower activity as we move into the 
extended period. An exiting low pressure system responsible for 
the showers will slowly push east and out of the area during the 
morning to possible early afternoon hours on Friday. At this 
point...the air mass will be rather stable and the upper level 
support will be diminishing. As a result... expect little 
potential for thunder. Additionally...the deep moisture associated
with the system will also have decreased and any additional 
rainfall amount should be minimal...generally less than a quarter 
inch. A stray light shower may linger over far northeastern 
locations Friday evening. Otherwise...behind the system...surface 
high pressure builds in for dry conditions for much of Friday 
night and into Saturday. The next system will move in Saturday 
night into Sunday. Models continue to show this as a weakening 
system with minimal moisture or lift associated with it. As 
such...expect a broken...scattered band of mainly light showers 
moving through. By mid day Sunday...surface high pressure builds 
back in for a return to a dry weather pattern. Model consistency 
remains rather poor for the end of the extended period. A rather 
strong upper ridge is expected to build in for dry and warming 
conditions Monday and Tuesday. However...is looks to be a rather 
dirty ridge as a series of weather disturbance ride along the 
upper flow to our north. This may bring increased clouds into at 
least northern areas while current models trends keep associated 
shower activity to our north. Additionally...model are indicating 
the potential for another system to be approaching the region 
around the Wednesday time frame. Confidence quite low on details 
and timing and for now...will continue with a slight chance/chance
of convection in the forecast.

FXUS64 KMRX 241843
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
243 PM EDT Wed Apr 24 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight through Thursday night)...

The overall synoptic outlook today features a low pressure system 
over southeastern Canada that continues to move eastward with a 
trailing cold front that has since stalled over the Ohio Valley. A 
low over the southern Great Plains tracking east northeast and 
strong ridging over our area will lead to increased WAA as winds 
begin veering more towards the south ahead of the approaching low. 
The low over the southern plains will further develop from ongoing 
cyclogenesis as it moves towards our CWA, eventually phasing with 
the stalled boundary to the north and forming a deep trough. Models 
are currently not in complete agreement as to the track of this low. 
The ECMWF show it remaining more south and tracking eastward, while 
the NAM, SREF, and GFS depict the low continuing towards the 
northeast and overtaking the stalled front to the north. Leaning 
away from the Euro at the moment since it is currently the only one 
in disagreement.

Showers and possible thunderstorms ahead of the front on Thursday 
afternoon for the more northern counties of the CWA and progressing 
southward through the rest of the day as the low pulls the stalled 
front to the south and begins to phase. A low level jet ahead of the 
front will produce some gusty winds on Thursday night, but the setup 
and orientation doesn't look to cause a downsloping wind event as
the winds will be mostly parallel to the mountain range. Some of
the higher elevations could see sustained winds of 20 to 22 mph
for a couple hours early Friday morning. Models indicate some
decent upper level divergence from the incoming upper level trough
of the 300mb jet overnight. Modest theta-e from the ongoing WAA
and the 40 to 50 knot low level jet will help form a broken line
of convection ahead of the front. However, the timing of the line
paired with decreasing MLCAPE values around 300, and 0-6km shear
below 30 knots will lead to any convection being rather
disorganized. A few areas of heavy rain are also possible with PW
values for most of the area between 1.25in to 1.50in.

.LONG TERM...(Friday through Wednesday)...

Showers will slowly exit to the east Friday morning as the cold 
front advances east. Timing has slowed compared to past model runs, 
so have likely pops from 12-15Z, then tapering to chance from west 
to east through the rest of the morning and afternoon. Profiles look 
stable, so will leave thunder wording out of the forecast. Highs 
Friday will be 5-10 degrees cooler in the CAA and trough aloft with 
generally low/mid 70's.

The upper level trough will slowly move east Friday night allowing a 
surface ridge to build in from the northwest. Subsidence will lead 
to mainly clear skies, so expect decent radiational cooling with 
widespread low/mid 40's areawide, except low 50's in the southern 
valley. The surface high will shift into the Carolinas Saturday 
allowing heights to rise and return southerly flow. This will bring 
upper 70's back to most of the region with the Chattanooga area

ridge as well.  Tonight, waa will ramp up therefore favoring

activity. Model consistency decreases by the end of the period and
confidence becomes quite low. Models indicate a short wave moving
in around the Tuesday time frame. At the moment this it look 
rather unorganized and for now will keep things in the slight 
chance

FXUS64 KMRX 231847
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
247 PM EDT Tue Apr 23 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Wednesday)...

An upper level low over the eastern Great Lakes region is currently 
tracking towards the east. A trailing cold front originating from 
the low looks to stall out just north of our CWA by tonight. 
Confidence as to where the stalled front will eventually settle is 
moderate since the models are still in slight disagreement.

Current ridging over the region along with strong southwesterly 
flow, scattered clouds, and deep layer mixing today will cause the 
high temperatures to be a few degrees higher than the seasonal 
average. Mid level moisture advection, associate with the 
southwesterly flow, will bring in increased cloud cover this evening 
leading to higher overnight lows than the previous night.

The stalled boundary will drop southward tomorrow morning increasing 
clouds and causing a few possible showers for southwestern Virginia. 
Wednesday afternoon has a slight chance of a few thunderstorms for 
northeast Tennessee and southwestern Virginia, but confidence is on 
the low side due to model soundings showing low amounts of CAPE.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday night through Tuesday)...

Wednesday night into Thursday, a northern stream upper trough will 
dig into the northern Plains as a separate southern stream trough 
moves through Texas and Louisiana. At the surface, a nearly 
stationary front will be stretched out in the vicinity of Kentucky 
and the Ohio valley. Disturbances riding through the split flow 
along this boundary will bring scattered showers and thunderstorms 
to far northern TN and southwest VA. Very limited ML CAPE and only 
30 kts of 0-6 km shear parallel to the boundary will keep any 
thunderstorms mainly disorganized, and suspect the more widespread 
activity will stay to the north across KY. However, PWAT values of 1 
to 1.25 inches will support brief heavy downpours in locations that 
get under a shower or storm. Have chance to slight chance pops in 
the far north Wednesday night slowly expanding southward into the 
remainder of the region Thursday morning into the afternoon.

As we move into late Thursday afternoon and Thursday night, the 
northern and southern stream troughs will attempt to phase while 
moving eastward through the TN and OH valleys, eventually resulting 
in a long-wave trough over the eastern U.S. for the end of the week. 
This will force a cold front southeastward which will overrun the 
old stationary front and slowly cross the region late Thursday into 
Friday. Coverage of showers/storms with this system is lower 
confidence. The latest NAM, ECMWF, and GFS are faster to bring the 
front toward the plateau Thursday afternoon compared to previous 
runs, but there remains disagreement on how much phasing of the two 
troughs will take place, with the NAM notably showing the energy 
staying separate and passing north and south of our region. Thinking 
that a more phased solution will likely be the outcome, so am 
hedging the forecast toward the GFS and ECMWF with likely pops 
reaching the plateau Thursday afternoon then likely pops all areas 
Thursday night. Severe weather is not anticipated, but a couple of 
stronger cells with locally gusty winds could occur. Shear profiles 
will be unidirectional on the order of 35-40 kts 0-6 Km and 15-20 
kts 0-1 Km Thursday evening into the overnight, but CAPE will 
quickly decrease after the strongest shear moves in overnight. Mid 
level lapse rates are flat at only 5-6 C/Km. These factors should 
result in a band of showers and embedded thunder moving west to east 
Thursday evening and overnight with brief heavy downpours given 
PWATS of 1 to 1.50 inches.

Chance pops for showers will linger in the 12-18Z block Friday as 
the cold front slowly exits to the east. Highs will be a solid 10 
degrees cooler with the trough aloft and CAA pattern, but we will 
see sunshine for the afternoon. Surface high pressure and rising 
heights aloft move in Friday night and Saturday to allow for mainly 
clear skies and a warming trend.

A weak and moisture starved cold front looks to cross the region 
sometime Saturday night or Sunday. Timing remains in poor agreement 
among the models, but this front is tied to a fairly shallow 
northern stream upper trough to our north, so forcing across the TN 
valley will be limited resulting in only widely scattered 
showers/storms. Brought in slight chance to chance pops after 00Z 
Sunday and carried that through the 12-18Z block Sunday morning. 

High pressure Sunday afternoon through Monday will bring dry weather 
and continued warmth as heights quickly rise again. The next system 
will approach from the west Monday night and Tuesday. Timing is 
highly uncertain, so just have slight chance to chance pops covering 
this timeframe.

warmest day for the next 7 days with temperatures climbing into 
the 80's in parts of the Tennessee Valley. Temperatures through 
the remainder of this work week and into the weekend will remain 
pretty persistent with daytime highs in the 70's and overnight 
low's in the 50's which is slightly above normal for this time of 
year.

Precipitation chances will enter the forecast for the first time on 
Wednesday as the ridge flattens out from a trough zipping through 
the Great Lakes Region. A frontal boundary will make a run at the 
area during the middle of the week but will lose steam and stall out 
somewhere across the Central Ohio Valley. Depending on where this 
front stalls out we could see some spotty showers during the middle 
of the week.

Better chances for precipitation will have to wait until a low 
pressure system is able to move across the Gulf States during the 
second half of the week. Depending on the track of the low and where 
the remnants of that stalled frontal boundary are, we will likely 
see showers and thunderstorms at some point on Thursday/Friday. 
models are still honing in on the track of the low and the location 
of the frontal boundary, so future forecasts may change the timing 
of the best chances of precipitation.

should provide for the highest probability of precipitation in the

weekend with a pleasant springtime warming trend.

FXUS64 KMRX 210710

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
310 AM EDT Sun Apr 21 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Low pressure system that's been the main driver of the weather over 
the past several days is finally making progress in moving off to 
the northeast. Still some lingering showers on the backside of the 
low with weather stations reporting drizzle or light rain. Expect 
showers like this to continue through much of the overnight hours 
with precipitation finally ending shortly after sunrise. 

Temperatures in the higher elevations are still hovering around 
freezing and we could see some additional light snowfall 
accumulations as showers run into the Southern Appalachian 
Mountains. Still looks like locations above 3500 have the best 
chance for this accumulating snowfall. 

As the low pressure system keeps moving to the northeast skies will 
continue to clear out. Skies around Chattanooga are seeing breaks 
in the cloud coverage and expect that trend to continue to the 
northeast through the rest of the night and into tomorrow. These 
clearing skies may allow temperatures to drop close to the dewpoint 
and allow patchy fog to develop. There may be a few very isolated 
locations that see temperatures drop low enough to see frost 
develop, right now the highest threat for frost looks to be along 
the Cumberland Plateau down into the Sequatchie Valley. Based on 
current observations and expected weather conditions closer to 
sunrise it seems like there's not enough of a widespread threat to 
need to issue a frost advisory at this time. Also we may begin to
see patchy fog develop during the early morning hours, but a lot
of this will depend on how fast clouds are able to move out.

With the clearing skies and mid level ridging we're going to warm up 
pretty quickly once the sun comes out. Temperatures are expected 
rise about 10-20 degrees warmer than what we saw on Saturday. 

Rivers levels across the area are continuing downward trend from 
earlier heavy precipitation. The few rivers that we have still in 
minor flood or action stage are forecasted to drop below action 
stage during the day today.

.LONG TERM...(Sunday through Saturday)...
The extended range forecast period kicks off on Monday morning 
amidst the departure of a closed H5 cyclone into the Western 
Atlantic, while deep ridging builds across the OH/TN Valleys and 
Southern Appalachian region.  Further west, broad southern stream 
troughing will dominate atop the Four Corners states as a northern 
stream shortwave slides eastward across the Upper Midwest.  At the 
surface, high pressure will prevail over the southeast beneath 
confluent flow aloft downstream of the primary H5 ridge, which will 
also drive sly waa into the MS Valley.  Lastly, a weak surface wave 
beneath the H5 northern stream shortwave will usher a cold front 
eastward into the Central Plains and Upper MS Valley.  

Pattern evolution through midweek will feature continued deep 
ridging over the southeast CONUS while the northern stream H5 
shortwave and consequent surface low slide through the Great Lakes 
with the associated cold front laying nearly zonal across the OH 
Valley.  The southern stream Four Corner trough looks to deepen and 
move east into the ArkLaTex initiating surface cyclogenesis over the 
Lower MS Valley.  All in all, a drier and warmer period is favored 
across east TN and southwest NC/VA through early/mid Wednesday, with 
pops increasing slightly along/north of I40 late on Wednesday given 
uncertain proximity of the OH Valley front (which the GFS pushes 
further southward than the ECMWF).  Temperatures through midweek 
will be around 8-10 degrees above normal levels.

Moving forward into late week, the southeast ridge becomes 
suppressed as the primary southern stream H5 cyclone moves through 
the gulf coast states, all while another northern stream shortwave 
moves through the central/northern Plains into the Great Lakes 
region.  At this range the operational guidance does continue to 
exhibit some minor discontinuities regarding the track/depth of the 
southern cyclone, as well as any phasing with the northern stream 
features.  Nevertheless, increased pops for showers/thunderstorms on 
Thursday and through Friday are warranted as the cold fropa occurs 
to round out the period, clearing the way for dry high pressure on 
Saturday.  Late week Temperatures will cool slightly given ridge 
erosion, additional sky cover, precipitation, and finally the cold 
fropa. Expect levels around or slightly above normal.

Heavy rainfall across parts of Eastern Tennessee and Western North 
Carolina have caused rapid rises on some rivers in East Tennessee. 
River gauges are showing that most rivers have crested and forecast 
from the River Forecast Center show that hopefully rivers continue 
to recede through the remainder of the night and into tomorrow.

Coldest day of the forecast will be today with colder air moving in 
from the north/west and mostly cloudy skies keeping todays HIGH 
temperature close to our climatological LOW temperature for this 
time of year. 

These colder temperatures look to drop below freezing in the highest 
elevations of the Southern Appalachian Mountains. Spotty weather 
stations in the higher elevations are showing that temperatures are 
remaining a bit warmer than previously anticipated, which will help 
lower accumulating snowfall totals. Still looks like locations with

snowfall. 

.LONG TERM...(Sunday through Saturday)...
The extended range forecast initializes Sunday morning as the pesky 
upper low responsible for the last few days worth of rainfall finally 
migrates northeast into the Central/Northern Appalachians, and 
ridging builds atop the Plains.  Further west, another upper 
disturbance looks to take shape as broader troughing deepens over 
the Rockies.  At the surface, high pressure will prevail amidst 
rising heights aloft across the southeast states, while a waa regime 
sets up across the Southern Plains and Lower MS Valley.  Moving on, 
overall the pattern will feature deep ridging over East TN and 
Southwest NC/VA through Tuesday into Wednesday.  With that, 
expecting dry conditions for the most part, albeit with the possible 
exception of some mountain top convection on Tuesday (slight 
chances) given modest heating.  Highs will reach nearly two 
categories above normal.

By Wednesday the overall synoptic pattern becomes more interesting 
as split flow surges a northern stream shortwave across the Great 
Lakes and an associated cold front southward toward the OH Valley, 
all while the above noted Rockies upper disturbance deepens to 
nearly a full latitude trough. Although guidance agrees on keeping 
the OH Valley cold front north of the fcst area, there appears to be 
some discontinuities to note.  For example, the ECMWF features 
persistent east coast ridging while the southern stream H5 vortex 
slowly moves east into the Appalachians into/through Friday.  On the 
contrary, the GFS exhibits a less progressive system which could 
possibly phase with the northern stream, all while the southern 
stream upper low remains open as less dynamic across the TN Valley. 
Either way it does look as if the pattern moistens up late in the 
period, before the cold front finally surges into the area Saturday 
morning. Temperatures to round out the period will be slightly 
cooler as the ridge is suppressed, however still nearly 1-2 
categories above normal levels.

combination of a saturated air mass limiting evaporative cooling 
and cloudy overnight skies which will limit longwave emissions the
strong CAA behind the front will be the main driver for the lower
temperatures tonight. Overnight lows could be colder than what is
predicted, but have high enough confidence to leave them as is.
Areas of higher elevation will see temperatures drop below
freezing with the rain changing over to snow early tonight, with 
most areas seeing low temperatures in the low 40's. With all the
rain today, a few areas along the Little Pigeon river and French 
Broad have seen a considerable amount of flooding this evening. 
Rivers are expected to crest tonight and slowly recede tomorrow. 
Areas down stream that these rivers feed into can expect to see 
rising water levels.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
336 AM EDT Fri Apr 19 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today through Tomorrow night)...
Storms continue to roll through the Eastern Tennessee Valley. 
Haven't gotten many wind reports from these storms since it's 
occurring overnight, but have seen some power outages and 
observations are all indicating that storms were able produce up to 
around 55mph winds in a few isolated locations. Storms were never 
able to strengthen due to basically zero instability to work with. 
We have not seen any lightning strikes recorded on satellite data 
throughout the night as these storms have moved through. Once we get 
into tomorrow morning we could see a re-intensification of storms, 
but it looks like the better environment and lifting mechanisms 
will be east of the area into North Carolina/Virginia.

What did occur with these storms, and more importantly the strong 
southerly low level jet, is strong winds in the higher terrain of 
the Southern Appalachian Mountains. Wind observation towers in 
several locations have recorded winds of 65mph overnight. So we will 
definitely continue the high wind warning for the mountainous areas 
through the morning at which point the low level jet should move off 
further to the east and taking the strongest winds with it.

Precipitation chances will continue across the area for about the 
next 48 hours until Saturday night. The QPF amounts will decrease as 
the low moves over us and eventually to the north of us decreasing 
PWAT values, so while the rain chances remain pretty high, the 
rainfall amounts should decrease as we progress towards the weekend. 
There's still the chance that a few locations receive several rounds 
of heavy rain leading to isolated flooding, so we will continue to 
monitor that over the next couple of days.

As the low moves over the area colder air will funnel in and drop 
temperatures through most of the day today. Overnight lows will dip 
below freezing in the highest elevations of the Southern Appalachian 
Mountains and we'll likely see snowfall in the tops of the 
mountains. Didn't change the forecast snowfall amounts very much and 
it still looks like accumulating snowfall will hopefully be confined 
to elevations above 3000 feet.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Friday)...
The extended range period kicks off on Sunday morning amidst a 
departing H5 cyclone across the Central/Northern Appalachians, 
building heights and thus ridging over the Plains, and another west 
coast upper low moving into the Rockies. At the surface, a 1023mb 
ridge looks to strengthen over the northern GOM (thanks to 
confluence aloft) which will favor return waa across the MS Valley 
Sunday morning.  Pattern evolution through the period will be 
highlighted by persistent ridging across the southeast states as the 
aforementioned plains H5 ridge slides east and the consequent 
surface flow moves off the Carolina coast by midweek.  Meanwhile the 
above noted Rockies H5 cyclone will slowly shift east into the Four 
Corners while a northern stream shortwave slides through the Upper 
Midwest driving a cold front southward into the OH Valley by Tuesday 
night.  For Wednesday, the long range guidance looks to push said OH 
Valley front southward across East TN and Southwest VA/NC. At this 
point the timing would favor an afternoon fropa, which combined with 
prior days return flow, could suggest the possibility for showers 
and thunderstorms.  Guidance tends to diverge a bit at this range 
regarding the eventual placement of the front by periods end as the 
ECMWF stalls the boundary atop the region on Thursday, while the GFS 
takes it just south near the I20 corridor.  Overall the fcst looks 
rather uneventful with chance pops featuring thunderstorms on 
Wednesday, with slight/chance pops for the remainder of the period 
given uncertainty of the frontal push.  Temperatures through the 
period will generally be highlighted by a warming trend with levels 
around 1 category above normal.

FXUS64 KMRX 182003

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
403 PM EDT Thu Apr 18 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Friday)...

A lot to discuss in the short term period with elevated fire 
weather potential, high winds across the mountains, strong to 
severe thunderstorms, and locally heavy rainfall. The upper levels
this afternoon feature amplified flow across the United States 
with ridging across the eastern seaboard and western Atlantic, 
troughing across the plains, and ridging across the western United
States. At the surface, an area of low pressure was observed 
across the lower Mississippi valley with a cold front extending 
northward across the Ohio valley and into the Great Lakes. 
Increasing southerly flow ahead of the previously mentioned trough
will continue to aid in gusty winds in the lower levels of the 
troposphere. The rest of the afternoon will feature warm 
temperatures, and mostly clear skies. The warmest temperatures 
will likely be located in the valley and closer to the foothills 
where downslope conditions will be most pronounced. The downslope
conditions will also keep dewpoints and RH values lower. RH 
values in the mid to upper 30's will be possible in NE Tennessee 
and SW Virginia. This combined with gusty southerly winds could 
create some elevated fire danger into the late afternoon. An SPS 
has been issued for mainly northeast Tennessee and southwest 
Virginia through 00Z.

The rather strong shortwave trough evident on water vapor across 
central Texas will move northeast overnight and shows signs of
weakening in model guidance. However, further north a potent mid-
level jet maximum will move southward allowing the trough to dig 
southward. With the increasing amplification, heights will fall 
over the southeast. The surface low underneath these height falls
will move northward into the Ohio valley by 06z-09z Friday. A 
cold front attendant this surface low will progress eastward 
through Mississippi and Alabama into the overnight hours. The 
increasing dynamics will allow the low level jet to strengthen 
tonight. Model guidance is in good agreement that 850mb winds 
increase to 45 to 60 knots late tonight and into Friday morning.  
This combined with a south to south-southeast wind direction gives
higher confidence of a mountain wave induced wind event across 
the mountain zones tonight and Friday morning. The current high 
wind warning seems to be in good shape and will keep that as is. 

The next weather hazard to discuss is the potential for strong to
possibly severe thunderstorms late tonight. It is likely that a 
line of strong to possibly severe thunderstorms will be moving 
through Mississippi, Alabama, and southern Tennessee this evening.
As they approach our area, it will likely be moving into a less 
unstable environment, and should be in a weakening state. However,
at least low to marginal instability parameters as indicated by 
100-300 J/kg of most unstable CAPE and +6.0 C/km mid-level lapse 
rates combined with moderate to strong shear parameters should be 
sufficient to carry the marginal chance of strong to severe storms
mainly across southern portions of the forecast area. The main 
threats continue to be damaging winds but a tornado cannot be 
ruled out. Timing of said convection is medium to high confidence.
High-res guidance indicates the line of thunderstorms moving into
far southwest counties of the MRX CWA as early as 03z to 04z and 
will continue to move east overnight. Localized heavy rainfall is
possible as well given the high PW values and efficient warm rain
processes.  

The cold front will push through the area on Friday with likely 
chance PoPs through the day. Some thunderstorms are also possible 
ahead of the front where at least weak instability is still 
present as mid level temperatures decrease. Again a strong to 
severe storm cannot be ruled out across far eastern section of the
area but overall severe weather threat looks low. Daytime highs 
on Friday should be cooler with the amount of cloud cover and rain
with highs in the low to upper 60s. 

.LONG TERM...(Friday night through Thursday)...

Upper level trough is expected to form a cut off upper low and 
moving over northeast Tennessee into eastern Kentucky Friday night 
and then spin nearly in place to the north of the forecast area 
Saturday and Saturday night. Rain showers will be widespread with 
the upper low. With the cold air aloft freezing levels will drop 
with some accumulating snow in the higher elevations above 4000 feet 
late Friday night and Saturday tapering off Saturday night as the 
system gradually shifts north. Snowfall amounts may reach up to 
about 2 inches at highest elevations. Temperatures will be much 
colder Friday night and Saturday. Lows Saturday in the 40s with 30s 
highest elevations. Saturday highs will be in the upper 40s to lower 
50s. Highest elevations will stay in the 30s. Rainfall amounts will 
be tapering off by Friday evening. Saturday night skies will begin 
to clear from the southwest to northeast with another cold night in 
the upper 30s to the lower 40s.

Sunday as higher pressure builds in behind departing upper level low 
temperatures will warm into the 60s to the lower 70s. Temperatures 
warm more for Monday through Tuesday with highs in the 70s to near 
80. At mid week another trough approaches with a slow moving front. 
A chance of showers and storms each day with increased humidity and 
more cloud cover. An upper low may form behind this system and slow 
its progress for the end of the week.

.SHORT TERM...(Today through Friday)...The mid/upper level ridge

will then slowly progress into our area by Friday. A surface front
will move west to east through our area tonight into Friday. A 
strengthening southerly low level jet will bring increasing 
moisture, and showers will move in tonight and progress across all
of our area by early Friday. Low level shear will increase 
significantly as the precipitation moves in, but right now it 
appears that convective energy will be quite limited. Will include
the possibility of thunder, and given wind fields cannot rule out
some strong to severe storms with damaging winds the primary 
threat. Will continue to mention this threat in the HWO. 

The strong southerly jet (850 winds reach 50 kts or more) will also 
bring the likelihood of mountain wave enhanced winds to the usual 
locations in the TN mountains and foothills.  It appears that 
thermal profiles will be quite favorable for at least several hours 
as well overnight, so Will issue a high wind warning for these areas 
for late today into Friday morning. 

Relative humidity values will dip into the 30s in at least parts of 
the area, especially the northern and perhaps central valley areas 
and up into SW VA. This will combine with gusty winds to increase 
fire danger. Will headline this in the Fire Weather Forecast. 

.LONG TERM...(Friday night through Wednesday)... By Friday night 
the upper level trough will likely have morphed into a cut- off 
low around Middle Tennessee with the surface low expected to be 
around Western Pennsylvania. Precipitation chances will definitely
be present Friday night into Saturday morning but QPF amounts 
should be much lower as PWAT values drop a good bit south and west
of the upper level low. Some of the biggest weather impacts over 
the weekend will be the much cooler temperatures over the weekend.
Friday night and Saturday night low temperatures are expected to 
drop into the low 40's in the Valley and near or below freezing in
the higher elevations of the Southern Appalachian Mountains. With
the lingering precipitation on the backside of the low and the 
sub-freezing temperatures the highest elevations may see 
accumulating snowfall Friday night into Sunday morning. Confidence
is still somewhat low on snowfall amounts, but right now it looks
like snowfall should be generally confined to locations around 
3,000 feet or higher. Depending on how temperatures rebound during
the daytime hours we could see a dusting up to a few of inches of
snow in these higher elevations.

Once the low finally moves off to the northeast and we get out from 
under it's influence skies will clear out and temperatures will warm 
back up above normal starting on Sunday afternoon. Warm weather will 
continue through the remainder of the 7-day forecast. 

Another low/trough will move through the mid-Atlantic around the 
middle of the work week. Models are indicating that this one is a 
bit less powerful, but will still bring widespread rainfall to the 
region. Model differences make the timing of the system difficult at 
this time, but it looks to be a decent chance of rain when it does 
eventually move through.

578 
FXUS64 KMRX 171941
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
341 PM EDT Wed Apr 17 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Thursday)...

The upper level ridge that has been aiding in our above 
average seasonal temperatures for the past few days will continue to 
slowly move to the east over the next few days. A weak low level jet 
of 40 knots will past quickly through the western area of the CWA 
early tonight. Conditions could reach very close to wind advisory 
criteria but is currently thought to remain just below minimums. 
Deep layer mixing tomorrow will work to keep conditions warm and dry 
with increasing winds for most of the CWA. Increasing warm air 
advection from the south on Thursday will lead to increasing 
potential temperatures values but the lifting mechanism of the 
incoming trough won't arrive until the long term forecast period.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday night through Wednesday)...

The long term period will be a very active one. Thursday night an 
upper trough will be approaching from the west, and will eventually 
become a cutoff low over Alabama and Mississippi by Friday afternoon 
before lifting off to the northeast over the weekend. The associated 
cold front will move through the CWA late Thursday night into Friday 
morning and will bring with it widespread showers, with some 
scattered thunderstorms mixed in across the southern zones. In terms 
of severe weather chances, it's unclear to be blunt. Forecast 
soundings show plenty of shear to work with, but are lacking in the 
instability department, especially for central and northern parts of 
the CWA. The area of concern would be down around Chattanooga where 
there is some surface-based instability after midnight when shear 
values all point towards the potential for severe storms. It will 
likely be a linear convective mode by the time it arrives in our 
forecast area, with the threats largely of the straight line wind 
variety. The threat of tornadoes in the southern valley can't be 
ruled out, but straight line winds seem of more concern at this 
point. 

Ahead of the front, winds will be quite breezy, though mainly in the 
elevated areas. Wind directions across the Appalachians aren't ideal 
for mountain waves, and there's no presence of a strong capping 
inversion over/east of the terrain, nor strong cross-barrier 
pressure gradient either. However, with forecast ridgetop winds 
approaching 50kt, or possibly a little higher, it seems that at 
least a few gusts to high wind territory will be seen. Given the 
onset of anything close to High Wind Warning criteria will be 
tomorrow evening, will allow the evening and overnight shift to get 
a look at one more set of guidance before pulling the trigger on 
whether to go for wind advisory or high wind warning.

Once the front passes, and the now-cutoff upper low begins to lift 
from northern AL/MS into eastern Tennessee, post-frontal showers 
will continue through the day Friday and into Friday night. Of note 
here will be how low freezing levels fall beneath this upper low. 
Not overly concerned about snow amounts here as we are talking about 
mid-April here, but the current thinking is that elevations above 
roughly 3,000 feet could see some snow showers Friday night. Don't 
expect much in the way of accumulations at this time, but would not 
be surprised to see some high elevation spots get an inch or so 
Friday night into Saturday morning.

For the remainder of the period, went with persistence. Model 
agreement trails off as you would expect, with some guidance showing 
a more zonal flow pattern for late Sunday into the first half of 
next week while others continue with an active pattern. Did 
introduce some slight chance PoPs back into the forecast area wide 
by Wednesday as it seems like a system will be approaching at that 
time.

FXUS64 KMRX 170645
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
245 AM EDT Wed Apr 17 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...The ridge of high pressure 
aloft over the area will slide to the east during the period, with 
surface high pressure centered to our east and northeast. We will 
see an increase in high clouds, but there will still be quite a bit 
of sunshine today. Temperatures will run above seasonal normals for 
the short term period. 

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Tuesday)...One more warm day on 
Thursday ahead of an approaching system, with temperatures 
expected to be around 10 degrees above normal and similar to what 
we see later today (Wednesday). Things will quickly change as a 
deep trough and and associated front begin to move into the 
Eastern Tennessee Valley Thursday evening/night. 

Ahead of this system we look to get some weak to moderate 
destabilization with a few hundred J/kg of CAPE to work with, but 
shear will likely be more important to storms as a strong 50+ knot 
jet out of the South moves through with this trough. With this type 
of environment, and the fact that the storms will likely be moving 
through during the nighttime, the biggest threat with these storms 
looks to be strong straight-line winds. The better environment for 
stronger to severe storms is further west across Middle TN into 
Alabama, but if these storms are able to maintain their strength and 
momentum as they move towards the Cumberland Plateau and Eastern 
Tennessee Valley we could see some strong to severe storms. Forecast 
soundings indicate the locations with the best environment to see 
the strongest storms in our area will be in Southeast Tennessee and 
along the Cumberland Plateau.

In addition to storms, the low level jet will be blowing pretty 
strong out of the south Thursday night into Friday. Models continue 
to indicate the direction of the jet is generally southerly to 
southeasterly during the time of the strongest winds. And depending 
on which model you like the core of the jet may contain winds of 50-
70 knots across far Eastern Tennessee. So while not a classic 
Mountain Wave event, it still looks likely that there will be strong 
winds in the higher elevations of the Southern Appalachian Mountains.

As this deep trough begins to swing through towards the East Coast 
of the U.S. it will morph into a cut-off low. This will lead to 
additional precipitation as moisture is wrapping around the low on 
the back side. There will be much colder air on the back side of the 
low with overnight lows Friday and Saturday night dropping into the 
low 40's in the Valley. In the higher elevations of the Southern 
Appalachian Mountains low temperatures look to drop below freezing 
for several hours each night. With precipitation expected to 
continue as the upper level low spins over head we could see some 
springtime snow in the higher elevations. Right now it looks like 
locations generally above 3000 feet have the best chance to dip 
below freezing and see snowfall. So any hikers along the Appalachian 
Trail over the weekend may run across some mid-spring snow on the 
ground over the weekend. Current models are doing an incredibly poor 
job with forecasting how much snow may stick to the ground, so 
forecast confidence in snowfall accumulations at this time is very 
low.

Rain looks to have moved off to the northeast by sunrise on Sunday 
and southerly winds at the surface will once again combine with mid 
level ridging to quickly shoot temperatures back up into the 70's on 
Sunday. Pleasant weather will then continue into the upcoming work 
week. Another trough/low looks to move move through during the 
middle to second half of the upcoming week, but long range model 
timing is still a bit all over the place as of now.
