Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
334 PM EDT Tue Apr 16 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Wednesday)...
A ridge of high pressure both surface and aloft will remain across
the southern Appalachians through Wednesday. Return of southerly
winds will continue to warm conditions Wednesday with temperatures
some 5 to 8 degrees above normal.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday night through Tuesday)...
Upper level ridge combined with southerly winds Wednesday night 
will continue to maintain the slightly above seasonal average 
temperatures for mid week. A digging trough over the Great Plains 
will move eastward, aiding in increased moisture and warm air 
advection. Temperatures for Thursday will continue to be a several
degrees above the seasonal averages.

Thursday night will see a cold front associated with the deep trough 
to the west move into the area. Strong upper level divergence from 
the 300mb jet will lead to high winds for the plateau and the 
southern areas of the CWA. High PW and Theta-e values combined with 
positive Omega will lead to heavy rains with some embedded 
thunderstorms. The GFS also shows potential high winds along the 
eastern Smokies and surrounding foothills from a low level 850mb 
jet. This downsloping wind event could see wind gusts up to 50 to 60 
mph.

As the cold front moves through on Friday, the winds will shift from 
predominantly out of the south southeast to the west northwest. 
While most of the convective potential will move to the eastern side 
of the southern Appalachians a stray thunderstorm for northeastern 
Tennessee and southwestern Virgina for the afternoon can't be ruled 
out. Some areas of the valley will see a break in the rain due to a 
rain shadow from the mountains and northerly inflow of cooler air.

The trough will begin to take on a negative tilt Friday night with 
strong divergence aloft before transitioning to a cut off low. A 
TROWAL and deformation zone will develop over the area around the 
newly formed cut off low. The more eastern warm air will be pulled 
around the low and ride up over the wedge of cold air at the surface 
and produce more rain overnight. Combined with the increasing cold 
air advection reducing the temperatures, some areas of higher 
elevation are likely to see snow and higher winds develop for Friday 
night.

The cut off low will persist for much of Saturday with cool, wet, 
windy conditions for most of eastern Tennessee while elevations over 
3000 feet look to remain cold with snow. The main forcing 
mechanism's for the precipitationw will be orographic lift, the 
TROWAL and deformation zone. The Euro shows a break from the rain 
for the more southwestern counties, the GFS and Canadian models 
maintain the precip potential until Saturday night. The low looks 
to finally move off to the northeast by Sunday morning, with 
increased warm air advection from the southwest and higher 
pressure moving in behind it.

FXUS64 KMRX 160709
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
309 AM EDT Tue Apr 16 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...Surface high pressure over the 
area will slide east as the mid/upper level ridge builds over the 
region.  After a chilly start, today will be warmer with plenty of 
sunshine. There will be an increase in high clouds overnight, and 
temperatures will be near or a bit above seasonal normals. Relative 
humidity values will dip to around 30 percent across a good portion 
of the area this afternoon and there will be winds of at least 5 to 
10 mph in many locations, so will include a headline mentioning this 
in the fire weather forecast. 

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday through Monday)... Mid level ridging and 
southerly winds wrapping around surface high pressure just off the
Carolina coasts will help temperatures climb about 10 degrees 
above normal for this time of year on Wednesday and Thursday. Dew 
points will begin to increase as moisture really begins to move 
into the area Wednesday night into Thursday ahead of our next 
system. 

Deep trough across the midwest United States will swing through 
along with the associated cold front that will be attached to a 
surface low moving through the Great Lakes Region. This weather 
system looks to be the main focus for the forecast bringing along 
with it a chance for strong (to possibly severe) storms and gusty 
winds as the main weather hazards. Precipitation ahead of the front 
may begin to pop up along the Eastern Cumberland Plateau Thursday 
afternoon/evening. Forecast model soundings are hinting that there 
may be enough shear/instability for storms that form ahead of the 
main cold front on Thursday afternoon/evening to become strong, but 
the better chances for thunderstorms will come overnight as the main 
line moves through. If the timing of this system remains on track 
and the bulk of the initial storms occurs overnight Thursday into 
Friday morning, this should hopefully limit severe storms across the 
Eastern Tennessee Valley. Instability looks relatively low, but the 
moderate to high shear available with the low level jet over us 
means that the greatest weather threat looks to be strong straight-
line winds.

The other threat with this system looks to be the potential for 
mountain wave winds Thursday night into Friday. The winds will be a 
little more southerly than a classic mountain wave scenario and the 
there isn't a strong inversion to keep strongest winds close to the 
surface...but with the low level jet of 50+ knots the threat for 
strong winds is very real.

As the cold front passes through the area the deep trough is 
forecasted to morph into a cut-off low, meaning that it will stick 
with us for a bit longer. The low will slowly move northeast across 
the Tennessee Valley towards eastern Great Lakes. The moisture that 
gets wrapped up in this system will be able to linger over the area 
for several days. Have kept precipitation chances in the forecast 
into Sunday morning, but forecast models are having a bit of a 
difficult time with how to handle the track of the low once it 
becomes cut-off. So forecast confidence starting around Saturday 
decreases a good bit. 

Once this low moves out of the area then another quick warm up will 
begin as mid level ridging and low level Warm Air Advection once 
again look to bring temperatures about 5-10 degrees above normal by 
Monday.

FXUS64 KMRX 151930
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
330 PM EDT Mon Apr 15 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Tuesday)...
Main concerns are frost potential across southwest Virginia and
northeast Tennessee Tonight and low afternoon Relative Humidity
Tuesday.

A ridge of high pressure both surface and aloft will be the main
weather features through Tuesday. Dry airmass will allow
temperatures to drop into the middle 30s over much of southwest
Virginia and northeast Tennessee, especially sheltered valleys.
Will issue a frost advisory for those areas.

Dry conditions and warming temperatures will produce low afternoon
relative humidity Tuesday.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday night through Monday)...

The upper level ridge axis will begin moving east of the region 
Tuesday night as the surface high sets up over the western Atlantic. 
This will lead to strengthening southwesterly WAA and temps 
returning to much above normal values for the middle of the week. 
The ridging will extend far enough westward into the Tennessee 
valley so that its capping influence keeps our region dry and mostly 
sunny through Wednesday, so warm weather fans will get to enjoy 
spectacular spring weather.

Moisture flux will begin to increase Wednesday night as 
southwesterly 925-700 mb moisture transport winds strengthen. 
Capping at the mid levels will not allow any showers to form, but we 
will see an increase in high to mid level clouds through the night. 
As an upper trough deepens over the middle of the country and its 
parent surface low lifts toward the western Great Lakes during the 
day Thursday, a strong cold front will slowly advance toward our 
region from the west. Strong WAA and moisture transport ahead of 
this system will allow Thursday to be the warmest day of the week 
with highs in the low 80's common, and it will feel humid as dew 
points rise into the low 60's by afternoon, especially in the 
central and southern valley. Forecast soundings show enough capping 
lingering in the mid levels to keep most of the day dry, but as the 
front and height falls move into middle Tennessee late in the 
afternoon, scattered showers and thunderstorms could develop around 
the plateau. Introduced slight chance to chance pops over that area 
after 21Z.

The cold front will slowly cross the region Thursday night with 
widespread showers and thunderstorms expected. Have likely to 
categorical pops in all areas. There continues to be some severe 
weather potential, but the overnight frontal timing should prevent a 
widespread outbreak. The main threat will be damaging straight line 
winds, with the greatest potential in southeast TN and the southern 
plateau. ML CAPES of 150-250 j/kg, strong frontogenetic forcing 
ahead of the front and lifting near the right entrance region of a 
120 kt 300 mb jet streak, 0-6 km shear of 70-85 kts, and 0-1 km 
shear of 30-45 kts should all support a line of thunderstorms with 
strong winds developing around middle TN, then progressing eastward 
across our region during the night. There is a hint of a weak 
surface low or pre-frontal trough around middle TN after 00Z Friday. 
In response to this little feature, forecast soundings do show some 
directional shear with winds in the surface to 925 mb layer backing 
southeasterly in the 00-06Z timeframe with a 60-70 kt southwesterly 
850 mb jet, so supercells embedded in the squall line with isolated 
tornadoes cannot be ruled out around the southern plateau and 
southeast TN. The farther east this squall line propagates, the more 
marginal the severe threat will become as nocturnal cooling 
increases combined with lacking instability, which is why the 
southern plateau and southeast TN have the greatest potential of any 
severe weather.  

The very strong southerly 850 mb winds will create favorable 
conditions for another mountain wave high wind event across the east 
TN mountains and adjacent foothills Thursday night into Friday 
morning.

The cold front will pass east of the region after 12Z Friday with 
the widespread showers exiting during the morning. Have likely pops 
in the morning decreasing to chance for the afternoon. Much cooler 
temps will occur in the CAA. This system will turn into a large cut 
off low in the Ohio valley Friday night and Saturday, so scattered 
showers will continue with below normal temps. Kept chance pops for 
showers Friday night and Saturday with some thunder wording during 
the day Saturday as the cold pocket aloft will result in some 
instability thundershowers developing. Low freezing levels and steep 
lapse rates could cause half inch sized hail with some of the 
showers/storms Saturday afternoon. 

The cut off low should finally move far enough eastward to allow 
ridging to bring dry weather and gradual warming to the region 
Sunday and Monday.

National Weather Service Morristown TN
419 AM EDT Mon Apr 15 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...Cooler and drier air will be 
working into the area today on gusty west to northwest winds as 
surface high pressure builds in from the west and southwest. The 
mid/upper level trough will be gradually replaced by broad ridging 
aloft during the short term period. Clouds will decrease, with 
plenty of sunshine this afternoon followed by a mostly clear night. 
With the cooler and drier air in place and winds becoming light, we 
may see some patches of frost develop mainly across the northeast as 
well as SW NC.  At this point it does not look significant enough to 
issue a frost advisory, but one could be issued later if forecast
temperatures have to be bumped a bit lower. 

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Sunday)...The long term period is 
typically handled similarly for the first few days of the extended
forecast, with divergence of model opinion with progression of 
time. Of course, there are no model problems with the most 
pleasant period of generally dry advection and protective ridging 
on Tuesday and Wednesday. Even Thursday is depicted well with 
increasing warm and moist advection off the Gulf of Mexico in 
advance the approaching and deepening Mid America upper trough. 
Later Thursday night into the weekend, modeling appears to have 
difficulty resolving the deepening upper trough, with differences 
in position and strength of the system's slow moving upper low 
center. The consensus opinion for weather across the Eastern 
United States was to follow the ecmwf with its, slightly more 
northern low position as it lumbers slowly east through the Ohio 
Valley on its way east northeast into the northwestern states by 
late in the weekend. With this scenario in mind, increasing 
moisture ahead of this mid latitude cyclone's cold front, along 
with more buoyant air and a coupled upper jet structure will lead 
to the possibility of strong convection developing across the 
Southern Appalachian region, later Thursday afternoon through 
Thursday night. The cold front moves east of the forecast area 
around 12z Friday, but relatively deep moisture and trailing jet 
energy on the back side of the highly amplified trough will keep 
the chance for some showers Friday and Saturday with a possibility
of some drier and warmer air finally building back into much of 
the region on Sunday.

FXUS64 KMRX 141818

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
218 PM EDT Sun Apr 14 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Monday)...
The threat of severe storms continues for our area. Surface heating 
has allowed for temperatures to rise into the mid 70s in most of the 
Valley, and will reach upper 70s shortly. The partial clearing of 
clouds has allowed winds to pick up quickly and become gusty, which 
will continue through the afternoon (the Wind Advisory and High 
Wind Warning will be continued). Increasing instability from
heating and abundant shear will make for an environment favorable
for thunderstorms with rotating updrafts. Hi-res models continue 
to indicate development around 19-21Z along the I-75 corridor, 
with discrete supercell storms merging into a line as they move 
east across NE TN and SW VA. Damaging winds continue to pose the 
highest threat due to midlevel dry air and strong winds aloft, 
while marginally severe hail will also be possible. The tornado 
threat remains present as well, as STP values are between 2-4, and
0-1km SRH of 200-300 m2/s2. 

Storms are expected to exit the area to the east around 10 pm, with 
only a few isolated to scattered showers lingering underneath the 
mid/upper level trough axis after that time. A brisk westerly wind 
will bring cold advection that will drop lows tonight into the 40s, 
with 30s in the mountains. A few snowflakes can't be ruled out in 
the highest elevations, but with no accumulation. Clouds overnight 
will gradually erdoe tomorrow morning, and we should have clear 
skies by the end of the day, with highs in the mid 50s north to mid 
60s south.

.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Sunday)...
Upper level heights will rise Monday night and Tuesday as a ridge
builds across the SE U.S. in response to surface high pressure 
shifting to the Mid Atlantic coast. The axis of the upper ridge 
will slide to the east by Wednesday as the next trough begins to 
take shape in the Plains. The result will be dry weather Monday 
night through Wednesday with mainly clear skies and temps 
rebounding to above normal values again. Stayed close to MAV 
guidance for temps early in the week since a slightly warmer 
forecast seems reasonable given the strong mid April sun and 
rising heights/WAA. Used Superblend guidance temps for the midweek
period.

The above mentioned trough in the Plains will further dig into the 
Mississippi Valley Thursday and Thursday night with a rapidly 
deepening surface low lifting into the upper Midwest. This system 
will pull a strong cold front through our region sometime Thursday 
night into Friday. Timing of the frontal passage is uncertain as 
model guidance has been slowing this system the past few runs. Have 
chance pops for showers and thunderstorms around the plateau 
Thursday afternoon with chance to likely pops areawide Thursday 
night through at least Friday afternoon. There continues to be 
potential for strong to severe convection ahead of this cold front 
late Thursday into Thursday night. Surface to 6 Km bulk shear 
increasing to 55-80 kts, 0-1 Km bulk shear of 35-45 kts, 0-1 Km SRH 
over 300 m2m2, and ML CAPE expected to be at least 120-250 j/kg will 
support damaging winds with the strongest cells. Isolated tornadoes 
could occur, with the greatest threat for this in the southern 
valley where the largest CAPE and shear will come together. Height 
falls will support lowering freezing levels and wet bulb zero 
heights Thursday night, so hail will also be possible in stronger 
updrafts. The SPC continues to have east TN, southwest VA, and 
southwest NC in a 15% severe weather outlook for Day 5, so we will 
continue to mention severe potential in the HWO.  

The low looks increasingly likely to cut off near the Great Lakes 
behind the cold frontal passage for the end of the week into the 
start of next weekend with an upper level trough digging well into 
the TN Valley. This will drop temps a little below normal for a 
change with scattered showers continuing Friday through Saturday, 
then gradually diminishing Saturday night. Have chance pops Friday 
through Saturday then slight chance Saturday night around the east 
TN mountains and southwest VA. Used Superblend temps this period.

Riding at the surface and aloft will return Sunday with dry weather 
and a warming trend.

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...Very dynamic Spring storm system
will be moving across the forecast area during the period. Model
forecasts not all on the same page with the details of this
system. Generally speaking, the higher resolution models appear to
be handling the complexity of the various components. The nam, 
and to a slightly lesser extent with time, the hrrr look like the
best way to go with a general decreasing strength and timing of
the early day convective episode while capturing a nice look to
the afternoon and evening main event. The initial area of
convection has formed along a pre-frontal trough and is progressing
at a decent pace through the Tennessee Valley of Alabama early 
this morning and will be building onto the Cumberland Plateau 
around 12-14z. While modeling indicates a bit of a weakening trend
with this initial area, there still may be just enough 
instability and some helicity for a weak tornado developing across
This Southern Cumberland Plateau area where there is a tornado 
watch until 9 am cdt. This line may still be associated with some 
rather strong convective wind gusts across Southeast Tennessee 
this morning before weakening with eastward extent into an area of
adiabatic warming and drying across much of the remainder of the 
forecast area. The surface low associated with the Mississippi 
Valley deep upper trough will be driving northeast through the 
Ohio Valley while dragging the powerful cold front through the Mid
south around mid day into the afternoon. This will be where the 
main threat of severe weather will occur with the best likelihood 
of severe thunderstorms impacting Northeast Tennessee and 
Southwest Virginia later this afternoon into the early evening 
hours. Its very interesting because previous model runs (in recent
days) have been showing a high shear but low cape event, but 
looking at the early morning model runs, cape doubles to triples 
in magnitude to a moderate or even high category across Northeast 
Tennessee. Of course, shear will not be a problem with bulk shear 
at around 60-80 kts. Just not convinced capes will rise into the 
1500-2000 j/kg range in this area during the afternoon, 
instability should be more than sufficient as the front moves 
through later today into the evening. The convective line pushes 
east of the forecast area during the mid to late evening hours 
bringing an end to the severe weather threat and heavier rain. 
Some weak trailing upper level energy and relatively deep moisture
build east across mainly the northern half of the forecast area 
behind the front bringing widely scattered showers and even a 
snowflake or two in the higher terrain areas toward daybreak.
Will continue with high wind warning and wind advisory products
for the mountains today.

.LONG TERM...(Monday through Saturday)...Models in decent 
agreement for the overall pattern, although some differences in the 
details.  Forecast confidence is about average for this time of 
year. Drier air will be working in Monday behind the departing 
weekend system, so should see a dry day with decreasing clouds. 
Surface high pressure will drift east across the region and an upper 
ridge will build in and then shift to our east, bringing warm and 
dry conditions for Tuesday and Wednesday. By Thursday a mid/upper 
level low will be digging in to our west, and a cold front will be 
approaching.  We will see showers and thunderstorms moving in 
sometime in the Thursday afternoon/Thursday night time frame, with 
some showers expected to linger into Friday and Saturday behind the 
front as the mid/upper level low/trough moves slowly across the 
region.  It still looks like there is a threat of severe storms in 
the Thursday/Thursday night time frame, so will continue to mention 
this threat in the HWO.

National Weather Service Morristown TN
309 PM EDT Sat Apr 13 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight through Sunday night)...
A low-to-midlevel convergence zone/warm front will continue to lift 
northward across our area through the evening. Precip chances should 
drop to slight chance or nothing once it moves across KY/WV by 
midnight. As the southerly flow picks up after midnight, winds in 
the mountains will increase, and some isolated light showers may be 
possible with the advection of warm/moist air aloft. By 12Z the 850 
mb jet reaches 50 -60 kts, so a High Wind Warning will be issued for 
the mountains. Winds aloft will mix down to the Valley as well after 
12Z, so a Wind Advisory will be issued for all other locations. 

The first wave of storms Sunday morning will essentailly be the 
remains of tonight's convection over LA/MS/AL. As these storms 
enounter a more stable environment and become elevated, they will 
likely show a weakening trend as they approach, but will still be 
capable of transfering winds aloft to the surface. This round will 
move through between 12-18Z. 

Behind the first round, advection of drier/cooler air aloft will 
steepen midlevel lapse rates and may allow for partial clearing and 
thus surface heating. SBCAPE values rise to around 2000 J/kg after 
18Z, with LI values near -6. This destabiliztion is expected to help 
reignite convection in the late afternoon as a strong zone of 
frontogenetic forcing arrives from the west around 21Z. Deep shear 
at this time is very strong, supportive of supercells, but near 
surface winds are not strongly backed for high 0-1 SR helicity. 
However, localized backing of winds from terrain features or 
mesolows could present an isolated tornado threat. Low WBZ levels 
will give a marginal hail threat, but the greatest threat is 
expected to be damaging winds due to the dry air and strong winds 
aloft. Unidirectional shear profiles might result in bow segments 
that produce downbursts. The timing of the second round appears to 
be mainly between 21-03Z. 

.LONG TERM...(Monday through Saturday)... 
The weekend severe system will have waned by sunrise Monday, with
light showers lingering over the northern mountains and SW VA in 
the morning. Meanwhile, the next major system will move onto the 
Pacific NW at the same time, and will dig into the southern 
Rockies by Wednesday morning. This will amplify a ridge over our 
area, thus our early week post-frontal cool down will last only 
from Monday morning through Tuesday morning before warmer 
temperatures resume Tues afternoon. Temps will be 5-10 deg above 
normal midweek, thanks to the the warm, moist draw from the Gulf 
ahead of the southern Rockies system. As that system lifts into 
the Missouri Valley near KC MO Thurs morning, frontal convection 
will be impacting western TN and will gradually move through E TN 
SW VA SW NC during Thursday night. Post frontal temps will be near
seasonal norms to end the week, with scattered showers possible 
associated with the departing but sharp upper trough.

.SHORT TERM...(Today through Sunday night)...
Early this morning, An inverted trough axis over the Tennesse
valley along with isentropic lift are producing scattered showers.
Instability is very limited and elevated so thunderstorms are not
anticipated.

For Today, some warm air aloft will help cap most convection 
through around midnight. Only some orographic forcing could
produce scattered showers or the far northeast sections. A good
deal of mid-level clouds is expected today. Another warm day is on
tap.

For Tonight, increasing low-level jet will move into the Tennessee
Valley, especially after midnight. Windy conditions will likely
develop over the higher elevations. A wind advisory may be needed
across the higher terrain. The high resolution Convection Allowing
Models (CAMs) show a band of shower and storms moving into the
Plateau between 4 and 7 am. Due to the strong winds just off the
surface, these storms will be capable of producing damaging winds
across southeast Tennessee Sunday morning.

For Sunday, morning convection will move east of the area. Strong
upper trough will move toward the Ohio/Tennessee Valleys during
the day. A 300mb jet of 125-130kts will swing northeast across the
Tennessee Valley into the eastern Great Lakes increasing the upper
forcing. Associated low-level jet will remain across the area
ahead of an approaching strong cold front. Frontal-genetic forcing
from the upper jet dynamics will help organize strong convective
development across middle Tennessee/northern Alabama
northeastward.

Tightening pressure gradient Sunday will likely produce windy
conditions across much of the area, especially the mountains.

Airmass shows a strongly sheared environment with 0-1km shear of
30kts and 0-6km shear of 80-85kts with MLCAPEs of 1000-1500 J/kg
ahead of frontal boundary. Expect initial supercell development
that will race northeast with eventual line forming producing
damaging straight line winds. Favorable LCL heights, shear, and
CAPE to produce isolated tornadoes as well. Low freezing/wet bulb
zero heights and enough available Hail CAPEs to produce large hail
as well. Some hail up to half dollar size possible.

Current timing of second round of severe storms is from 4 to 8 pm
ET. 

Coverage of showers and thunderstorms will diminish by mid to late
evening with orographic showers remaining in the Mountains. The
highest elevations of the Smokies could even see the rain mix with
or change to sleet/snow before ending, generally above 5kft. 

.LONG TERM (Monday through Friday)...Model forecast continue to 
indicate a decent swath of deep moisture and trailing short wave 
lift for Monday; mainly during the morning. Therefore, will keep a 
few sprinkles and clouds around for much of the northern half of the 
viewing area with improving weather into the afternoon and evening. 
A nice, quiet ridge pattern builds in for Tuesday and Wednesday with 
the low level ridge slipping further east into the Western Atlantic 
Wednesday into Wednesday night so pleasant warm air advection will 
be increasing through this period. Another, highly amplified upper 
trough with another deepening low pressure system drags a strong 
cold front back into the forecast area on Friday. This will be an 
unsettled period with an increasing chance for showers and 
thunderstorms Thursday into Friday as a corridor of deep moist 
convection swings across the Southern Appalachian region. It appears 
this system could provide another opportunity for the development of 
strong to severe thunderstorms during this late week period with 
strong wind fields and more than adequate cape. Probability of 
precipitation would be decreasing later in the day Friday into 
Friday night in this scenario.

part...the system should be out of the Southern Appalachian Region
for a return to dry conditions on Monday with surface high 
pressure building in. 

Weak ridging into Tuesday will keep us in a quiet and dry weather
pattern for another day. Model consistency lowers by the end of 
the period and confidence lowers as well but generally the pattern
looks rather active. Current trend shows a few showers 
potentially moving in on Wednesday in advance of the approaching 
system. The cold front will move in around the Thursday time frame
with the upper low and associated showers lingering over the area

due to the strong wind field and modest instability associated 
with the deep late weekend upper trough, which moves from the 
Mississippi Valley to the Appalachians by Sunday evening. 
Precipitation tapers off Sunday night with a dry west northwest 
flow bringing a couple of good weather days Monday and Tuesday. 
The ecmwf and gfs have come into a little better agreement for the

there is still some uncertainty with this feature's timing. Stayed
with the superblend concept of a chance pop for showers with the 
possibility of an initial weak impulse on Wednesday followed by 
the main long wave system on Thursday that could produce another 
period of convection ahead of the associated surface cold front.

The strong low-level jet is enhancing the isentropic lift over the

embedded thunderstorms.

FXUS64 KMRX 111846

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
246 PM EDT Thu Apr 11 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Friday)...
The upper pattern this afternoon is rather amplified as an H5 ridge 
axis sits atop the eastern CONUS and a deep H5 cyclone rolls across 
the Central/Northern Plains into the Upper Midwest states. At the 
surface, a closed 990MB surface low is tracking northeast (nearly 
stacked beneath the aforementioned H5 low), while a cold front 
stretches southward into the Ozarks and Arklatex region. Further 
east, high pressure beneath the upper ridge axis is working in 
concert with the MLC to increase PGFs atop much of the mid MS and 
OH/TN Valleys this afternoon.  The combination of enhanced llv winds 
and deep mixing will continue to present elevated chances for gusty 
winds across the region this afternoon, all amidst increasing 
cloudiness thanks to the sustained/improving waa regime. 
Temperatures will top out nearly two/three cats above normal.

Tonight guidance favors a nearly 50-60kt sely/sly H85 jet traversing 
the fcst area ahead of the approaching prefrontal trough. The 
orientation of this flow combined with profiles favoring a llv 
inversion suggests some potential for mountain wave winds, therefore 
portions of the previous wind advisory were upgraded to a warning. 
Likewise, the advisory and the new warning were extended through 
10AM EDT Friday.  As for precipitation, looks like some light shra 
is possible along the TN/NC line tonight given upslope flow on the 
eastern facing slopes in western NC, all while profiles moisten and 
upper heights fall thanks to the approaching trough/front. 
Fortunately the vast majority of the amplified dynamics will pass by 
to the north adjacent to the stacked system as it ejects over the 
Great Lakes, however lapse rates will be sufficient to support sct 
showers and general thunderstorms.  Thus, pops increase through the 
night from the south/southwest as moisture advects in and sct 
prefrontal convection slides east through middle TN.  The front 
itself will slow and eventually stall atop the region late in the day 
Friday as it becomes unphased with the primary cyclone to the north, 
thus did keep chance pops spread about the area through the day 
tomorrow.  Temperatures on Friday will top out about 8-10 degrees 
cooler than today's highs amidst precip and clouds. 

.LONG TERM...(Friday night through Thursday)...
The surface front will become parallel to the midlevel flow and 
stall across our area on Friday night. Late in the night, the 850-
700 mb backs and strengthens, creating a midlevel SW-NE convergence 
zone that will bring rising rain chances for locations north of the 
front through Saturday morning. Will have an area of likely PoPs and 
a slight chance of thunderstorms (due to elevated instability) 
across the northern Plateau and SW VA during this period. 

The convergence zone and the surface front continue to lift 
northward through Saturday as the southerly flow strengthens in 
response to a low pressure system tracking from TX to AR to MO/IL. 
With southerly 850 mb winds approaching 50 kts, another period of 
strong winds in the mountains may be possible Saturday night. Linear 
convection along the system's cold front is expected to move into 
our area from the west on Sunday. While instability appears weak, 
strong deep layer shear, frontogenetic forcing, and 50+ kt winds 
aloft may present a straight-line wind threat on Sunday. Cold 
frontal passage occurs Sunday evening, but with the upper trough 
passage delayed a few hours behind it, will keep a small PoP going 
Sunday night into Monday morning. 

An amplified pattern across the Conus will bring a building ridge 
that will provide dry and cool conditions on Monday (highs in the 
60s), with temperatures rebounding into the 70s for Tuesday as the 
ridge axis moves to our east. Models develop another system over the 
Plains on Wednesday, although there is disagreement on the timing of 
impacts on our area with this system. For now, will keep PoPs in the 
chance range for Wednesday and Thursday. There could be some 
potential for severe storms with this system given the amplification 
of the mid/upper trough.

largely dry short term period as an amplified upper trough and
associated frontal system approach the Southern Appalachian
region. More ridging is expected today with gradually increasing
low level moisture advection. The strengthening pressure gradient
between low level reflection of the ridge over the Middle Atlantic
Coast and the deepening Plains low will result in a gusty
southerly wind across the forecast area today. Insolation will
only have to compete with a broken cirrus layer and with the
strong warm air advection, high temperatures will again reach the
upper 70s and lower 80s. Applied a wind advisory for the higher
terrain along the Tennessee and North Carolina border for tonight
due to the ever tightening gradient in pressure ahead of the deep
Mid America low. A weakening frontal boundary will build toward
the Cumberland Plateau by daybreak Friday and both the gfs and nam
depict increasing moisture convergence ahead of the boundary along
with some weak instability for a few showers and possibly a
thunderstorm toward sunrise. A very mild night is in store due to
increasing moisture with the front and warm air advection through
the overnight hours. 

.LONG TERM (Friday through Thursday)...By Friday morning, a

the northwest during the day Friday but will stall out somewhere 
across eastern Tennessee or northern Alabama/Georgia by Friday 
night as upper support moves off to the northeast past the Great 
Lakes and mid/upper level flow becomes parallel to the surface 
boundary. Gradient flow across the region will be basically at 
it's peak Friday morning, with breezy conditions at the lower 
elevations and likely some advisory level winds still taking place
in the mountains. Pressure gradients will By Friday morning, a

of thunder as model soundings show some elevated instability. But
do not expect any severe weather with this system.

For Saturday the stalled front will be a focus for continued shower 
activity as the next system gains strength in west Texas, and 
resultant isentropic ascent over the frontal increases. There should 
be a lull in rain chances Friday night into Saturday morning, but 
expect at least some scattered coverage during the day Saturday. As 
the Texas system moves east it will have a greater impact for our

possibly a severe threat. Chances look considerably better to the 
southwest of our CWA for severe weather, but there could be a short 
window on Sunday morning where some storms with damaging winds could 
be seen. Will continue to monitor things for now and keep a mention 
of it in the HWO.

sizable drop in temperatures for Monday, with lows in the 40s and

Plains will bring a deep southerly flow regime back to the area by

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
211 PM EDT Wed Apr 10 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Thursday)...
Overall the weather across the TN Valley and Southern Appalachian 
region remains rather nice as H5 heights continue to rise amidst an 
approaching ridge, and cool/dry nly llv flow prevails behind an old 
cold front which is currently laid atop northcentral MS/AL/GA. 
Meanwhile, another weak secondary cold front is slowly shifting 
southward across the OH Valley along the southern periphery of a 
surface anticyclone. Out west, a Four Corners H5 cyclone continues 
to deepen leading to lee cyclogenesis across portions of the 
Southern Plains.  

As for the fcst, wly/nwly flow aloft will favor advection of 
mid/high clouds (downstream of the aforementioned system) across the 
TN Valley and Southern Appalachians through the remains of the day. 
Otherwise, am expecting mostly sunny conditions with light nly flow 
and temperatures around a category above normal.  Overnight any nly 
flow will calm as the above noted surface ridge shifts east beneath 
the H5 ridge axis.  Thus, am expecting partly cloudy skies tonight 
(generally patches of mid/high clouds) amidst above normal lows and 
little (if any) fog given the dryness of the BL. 

On Thursday the overall pattern shifts somewhat as the deep ridging 
slides east of the Appalachians allowing for return sly waa across 
the deep south.  With that, expecting slightly higher humidity with 
increasing low/mid level cloudiness.  As the overall pressure 
gradient increases thanks to the advancing system to the west, llv 
flow will ramp up with gusts across the high terrain Thursday 
afternoon upward of 30-40mph at times.  Likewise, ample mixing 
across the remainder of the region is expected to favor some 20-
30mph gusts.  At this time a wind advisory does not look necessary 
therefore will just highlight in the HWO.  Temperatures on Thursday 
will once again top out nearly two categories above normal.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday night through Wednesday)...
This period will be an active one with several systems tracking 
across the eastern US. The first will be the potent storm system 
that is currently over the Great Plains. This system will be 
tracking slowly NE through the upper MS Valley and into Canada by 
Friday night. The trailing cold front is expected to initiate 
storms in AR/West TN Thursday afternoon, but the lifting of 
dynamic forcing with the system to the Great Lakes and overnight 
timing will result in weakening convection as the front approaches
our area. Ahead of it, southerly low level winds will be quite 
strong in the mountains Thursday night, on the order of 50 kts at 
850 mb. This may necessitate a Wind Advisory with later forecast 
issuances. Although gusts may approach 60 mph at times, confidence
is not high enough to go with a High Wind Watch at this time. 

The front becomes parallel to the SW-NE midlevel flow and becomes 
nearly stationary over our area on Saturday. Forcing and moisture 
advection during this period are weak, but the presence of the front 
and an increasingly backed 850 mb wind may be enough for scattered 
light showers in the area. The next storm system will be positioned 
farther south than the last one, tracking from TX to the Mid MS 
Valley to the Great Lakes over the weekend. This one could have a 
greater impact for our area as the upper trough is more amplified 
and the jet is in a better position to support convection on Sunday 
afternoon, and possibly a severe threat. A mention of this potential 
will be added to the HWO. 

Passage of the cold front and upper trough will bring a sizable 
drop in temperatures for Monday, with lows in the 40s and highs in
the 60s. A building ridge will provide dry weather Monday and 
Tuesday, then another system developing over the Plains will bring
a deep southerly flow and increasing moisture on Wednesday. 
Details are too uncertain this far out for specifics, but the 
amplification and positive tilt of the upper trough as shown by 
the GFS and ECMWF will warrant a close watch of the severe weather
potential over the next few days.

FXUS64 KMRX 100748
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
348 AM EDT Wed Apr 10 2019

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...The forecast area will enjoy a 
benign period of weather today as the early week system fades away
off the Atlantic Coast while a deep, slow moving low pressure 
system develops over the Plains. A ridge will be in place over the
Southern Appalachian region between these two systems providing 
for nearly full sunshine today. Strengthening Spring sunshine will
boost high temperatures to the lower and middle 70s north to the 
upper 70s across the south. Quiet weather continues tonight with a
strengthening pressure gradient ahead of the big Plains low. The 
weak low level mixing in this pattern will keep lows several 
degrees above normal in the middle and upper 50s across much of 
the region with upper 40s to around 50 degrees across Southwest 
Virginia and Northeast Tennessee. 

.LONG TERM (Thursday through Wednesday)...The long term forecast 
period is shaping up to be a busy, and interesting period. We 
start the period with a very strong system deepening over the 
plains, and high pressure along the northeastern seaboard. This 
feature will lift to the north/northeast Thursday into Friday, 
with the associated cold front moving into eastern Tennessee 
during the day Friday. Meanwhile, the next system will dive south 
through Arizona into northern Mexico on Friday before ejecting 
east across Texas Saturday into Sunday.

As mentioned in previous discussions, moisture return for this 
Friday cold front will be fairly limited, with perhaps the better 
return flow coming off the Atlantic near the Carolina coast. East to 
southeasterly flow across the Carolinas and into the southern 
Appalachian Thursday night into Friday will produce some upslope 
precipitation across the southern Appalachians. This is likely to 
put much of our CWA into a rain shield until rainfall associated 
with the incoming cold front arrives during the day Friday. Do have 
some chance PoPs along the TN border, but wouldn't expect much 
outside of that until maybe daybreak Friday. Also of note Thursday 
night will be strengthening gradient flow at the surface and aloft, 
perhaps enough to warrant concern for some mountain wave activity. 
One limiting factor here would be the lack of a strong inversion 
above mountain top levels since, by that time, we will be squarely 
in the warm sector of this storm. However, model soundings from 
Asheville NC indicate there may be enough of a capping inversion 
late Thursday night into Friday morning to produce some good 
downslope winds. Cross section analysis shows decently strong 
downward omega in the western foothills of the Appalachians. 
Additionally, H85 flow will strengthen to around 50-60kt, and will 
be favorably aligned out of the S-SE. If nothing else, suspect the 
higher terrain will see pretty windy conditions Thursday night. 

Models have come into better agreement for how widespread rainfall 
will be on Friday with the cold front. High resolution models like 
the NAM12 indicate that precipitation will be more on the scattered 
side of things than widespread, which makes sense given the overall 
lack of moisture. Still, showers and perhaps some embedded 
thunderstorms will be widespread enough to warrant pretty high PoPs 
for Friday. A tenth to a quarter of an inch of rain seems 
reasonable, with the best QPF residing mainly near the northern 
plateau counties.

For Friday night into Saturday the surface cold front will stall out 
to the south of us. However the mid level front will remain overhead 
as the next system ejects into Texas and southerly low and mid level 
flow strengthen along the central Gulf states and up towards 
Tennessee. Therefore will keep at least some slight chance to chance 
PoPs going through that period as some nocturnal convection along 
the H85 front is likely to occur from middle Tennesee eastward into 
our CWA. There may be a bit of a lull in rain chances late Saturday 
as a warm front lifts north of us and we get back into another warm 
sector. However the next cold front arrives early Sunday so the 
break will be short. Will carry categorical PoPs for the day Sunday, 
with a chance of thunder mentioned as well. I will say that Sunday 
poses an interesting scenario with regard to potential severe 
storms. The threat right now looks to be to our south into the 
Georgia area. However if timing slows, or the track of the surface 
low shifts a little north, then conditions could become favorable 
for some severe storms in the southern valley. Will continue to 
monitor, but at this point in time there's a marginal threat at
best.

FXUS64 KMRX 091900
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
300 PM EDT Tue Apr 9 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Wednesday)...

A southern stream trough will continue to progress eastward this 
afternoon and overnight as upper level ridging develops to the 
west. At the surface, an area of low pressure located across 
southern Alabama will continue to move eastward as high pressure 
moves out of the northern plains. Temperatures this afternoon are 
in the upper 60s to low 70s with partly cloudy skies. Visible 
satellite imagery continues to show mostly diurnally driven 
cumulus across a large portion of the area with better vertical 
development located across the Smoky Mountains and southern 
Tennessee where an axis of low to mid level convergence exists. 
Overall lift seems weak across our area, but an isolated 
thunderstorm or two could be possible across far southeast 
Tennessee, and western North Carolina. Otherwise, high pressure at
the surface will bring drier weather conditions through tonight 
with lows in the mid 40s to low 50s. 

On Wednesday, the upper levels become more amplified as a trough 
digs across the Rockies. This will allow for sharper ridging to 
develop while high pressure at the surface extends across the 
Great Lakes, and Ohio valley. The above features will translate to
tranquil weather conditions and slightly warmer temperatures with
mid to upper 70s area wide and a few 80 degree locations 
possible.


.LONG TERM...(Wednesday night through Tuesday)...


A number of features to discuss for the long term outlook. 
Temperatures look to remain fairly constant through the week and 
over the weekend along a seasonal diurnal curve. The only exception 
will come early next week as cooler and drier air moves in behind 
two back to back low pressure systems that are expected to bring 
showers and a few embedded thunderstorms for Friday and Sunday. With 
the advection of this more continental air mass on Monday, 
temperatures early next week look to be in the low to mid 60's while 
most of this week will stay in the low to mid 70's.

Mostly high pressure for the mid week with increasing ridging for 
late Thursday and into Friday ahead of the next incoming cold front. 
A deep upper level low in the Great Plains will track towards the 
east northeast and into the Great Lakes region by Friday morning. The 
cold front originating from the aforementioned low will impact eastern 
Tennessee by Thursday night with some pre frontal showers and some 
possible embedded thunderstorms. This front will move out by Friday 
night but the GFS and Euro models are currently not in agreement as 
to any residual moisture or orientation of the tail end of the 
front. The Euro shows the trailing edge stalling out and becoming 
more stationary over the Smokey mountains. Current thinking is that 
the southerly warm air advection won't be strong enough to account 
for the amount of moisture shown by the Euro, so am inclined to lean 
more towards the GFS.

A brief period of weak ridging early on Saturday ahead of the next 
low pressure system that will move northeastward out of the American 
southwest. Another difference between the models here as the Euro 
brings in the warm front earlier than the GFS as it shows the 
trailing edge of the previous cold front quickly becoming stationary 
and transitioning to a warm frontal boundary on Saturday. The strong 
southerly flow depicted in the Euro shows widespread showers ahead 
of the warm front Saturday afternoon, while the GFS shows weaker 
warm air advection from the south and holds the front back until 
Saturday night. Am inclined again to lean towards the GFS model in 
this instance as the frontal orientation and the inflow amount of 
moisture from the advection of warm air from the south looks more 
reasonable.

FXUS64 KMRX 090750

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
350 AM EDT Tue Apr 9 2019

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...A northern stream upper trough 
will be making its way east through the day while it drags the 
more active southern stream feature slowly toward the Southeast 
Atlantic Coast. Some deep moisture is available for lifting in 
association with the stacked Southeastern states low pressure 
system and sufficient cape will allow for enough buoyancy for the 
development of a few thunderstorms. Much of the threat for a rain 
shower will have ended across most of the forecast area by early 
afternoon, as the trough axis builds closer to the Appalachian 
spine. The northerly flow developing on the back side of the 
system brings increasingly drier and less buoyant air through the 
afternoon hours across much of the northwestern two thirds of the 
forecast area. Forecast highs are on track to reach the lower and 
middle 70s again today. A drier low level airmass, clearing skies 
aloft, and a light northerly surface flow will result in low 
temperatures mainly in the 40s tonight. 

.LONG TERM (Wednesday through Monday)...The primary concerns for 
the long term period will be a cold front moving through the 
region on Friday, and another system slated to arrive sometime 
late in the weekend.

Regarding the Friday system, slowed the onset of precipitation down 
a bit though possibly not enough. Current forecast has some chance 
pops beginning during the early morning hours on Friday, mainly over 
the mountains and perhaps the southern plateau as return flow begins 
in earnest. Have serious concerns about how quickly precipitation 
will begin in this return flow pattern as the current system along 
the central Gulf coast will shove higher moisture content well out 
into the Gulf Of Mexico. There is a bit of a wedge pattern in place 
Thursday with a surface high just off the New York coastline, which 
would yield easterly flow off the Atlantic and into the Carolinas. 
This may yield some upslope precipitation on the NC/SC side of the 
Appalachians but have to wonder whether that would give any rain on 
our side since we'd be in the rain shadow. Further west, the 
moisture tap for the Friday system will come from the western Gulf 
essentially so that's not exactly ideal for a lot of rain into the 
plateau area either. In any case, the cold front will move into the 
CWA sometime on Friday and will bring with it widespread showers and 
likely some embedded thunderstorms. Hard to go too heavy handed with 
thunder chances given thermal profiles, so just included slight 
chance of thunder with overall higher rain chances.

The cold front will clears the area Friday night, though how far to 
the south is in question. The next system will be ejecting out of 
southern New Mexico and into the southern plains and Texas on 
Saturday. Differences in how quickly this happens, and how strong 
the response is in developing southerly flow off the central Gulf 
states mean the Friday cold front either stalls over the southern 
part of our CWA, or stalls out in Alabama and Georgia. The main 
difference here will be with respect to how quickly rain moves back 
into the region on Saturday or Saturday night. The ECMWF is far 
quicker with the development of additional rain, showing widespread 
showers by midday Saturday whereas the GFS shows a more distinct 
break due to a more southerly stalling of the Friday front. 
Generally favored the GFS solution here as I think the drier 
handling of the Friday system seems more realistic, and thus a more 
pronounced break between the Friday and late weekend systems will be 
seen. As a result, featured a slower onset of showers Saturday 
afternoon, with categorical PoPs for Sunday Day 5. Rain looks to 
push out of the area by the start of the work week.

As far as temperatures go, some relief will be seen at night, 
especially Friday night and Sunday night where a shot of 
significantly cooler/drier continental air will be seen. Daytime 
temperatures will continue to run warm through the weekend before 
cooling off firmly into 60s for early next week.

FXUS64 KMRX 081927

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
327 PM EDT Mon Apr 8 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Tuesday)...

An upper level low and parent southern stream shortwave trough will 
rotate eastward through MS and AL this evening through tonight. A 
cold front associated with a northern stream trough will drop south 
into northern parts of the valley in the 06-12Z timeframe. The most 
organized showers and thunderstorms likely already occurred earlier 
today, but a warm and humid airmass will continue across east TN, 
southwest VA, and southwest NC ahead of this system. Lift associated 
with the upper low and cold front will continue to promote periods 
of showers and isolated thunderstorms through the night. Soundings 
suggest a gradual lowering of the freezing level through the night 
with LI's of -3 to -7 and 500-1200 J/KG of ML CAPE as colder air 
aloft filters into the region. The highest of this instability will 
remain in the central and southern valley where any stronger cells 
could continue to produce locally heavy rain, gusty winds, and small 
hail through at least 03Z, although this will be very isolated. Hi-
Res CAMS show many differences in convective coverage overnight, but 
consensus is that the coverage should be the most widespread before 
06Z, then becoming more isolated the rest of the night. Due to the 
lower confidence in coverage, decided to keep chance pops for 
showers/storms through 08Z then taper to slight chance the rest of 
the night in the north. Clouds and continued warm, humid airmass 
will keep lows above normal tonight with mid 50's to near 60 
expected. Went slightly above the MET/MAV blend for low temps. 

The shortwave trough and upper low will continue to rotate southeast 
Tuesday with the cold front slowly settling further south across the 
region. The cold pool aloft underneath this system will build 
afternoon ML CAPES above 500 J/KG with 1000-1500 J/Kg at the surface 
as daytime heating takes place, so scattered showers and 
thunderstorms should develop again from mid morning through mid 
afternoon. The best potential for this will be from the southern 
valley through southeast NC in closer proximity to the front and 
upper low. Could see small hail with the thunderstorms tomorrow 
with freezing levels down to roughly 10,500 ft. Have carried 
chance pops for showers/storms in the morning and afternoon from 
the southern plateau across the southern valley into southwest 
NC, but keeping the forecast mostly dry farther north as drier, 
more stable air filters in. Another pleasantly warm day is on tap 
with low/mid 70's across much of the region. Stayed close to MET 
guidance for high temps.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday night through Monday)...

The short wave to the east will continue to make it's way out of the 
region at the start of the long term outlook. Conditions look to be 
more calm and dry for most of Tuesday night and Wednesday as an 
upper level ridge moves in behind the trough. The higher pressure 
will lead to warm and pleasant conditions for the mid week.

The next weather system to impact our area will most likely move in 
by late Thursday. A low pressure center over the central Great 
Plains will track to the east northeast into the Great Lakes region 
by late Thursday. An associated cold front originating from the low 
will sweep across eastern Tennessee by Thursday evening with mostly 
showers and a few possible thunderstorms overnight. Strong southerly 
flow ahead of the front will account for a number of prefrontal 
showers. A fair amount of continued warm air advection will aid the 
ongoing showers for most of the day on Friday.

As the front moves eastward and the low pressure center continues to 
track into the Great Lakes, a strong pressure gradient behind the 
front will produce some decent winds across the area for Friday 
night. While winds could have some considerable gusts for the 
eastern mountains, the orientation will be predominantly from the 
southwest, so no downsloping wind event is expected at the moment. A 
brief period of high pressure on Saturday as winds calm and 
temperatures warm from the continued southerly flow before a second 
developing short wave event moves up from the southwest Saturday 
night. This system looks to bring another round of rain with 
possible thunderstorms to the area for most of Sunday and into 
Sunday night.

FXUS64 KMRX 080729

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
329 AM EDT Mon Apr 8 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

A quasi-closed low was located over far northeast Texas early this 
morning, with some connections to a northern stream trough moving 
through the Great Lakes noted in water vapor imagery. This system 
will slowly work east across the Arkansas/Louisiana border today, 
enhancing shower and thunderstorm potential across our forecast area 
as it does so.

Locally, skies were mostly clear early this morning in the wake of 
convection from last evening. Some patchy fog has formed in some 
places as a result of these clear skies, but with more high clouds 
moving in from the southwest ahead of the next round of showers and 
thunderstorms, this should either hold at current areal coverage or 
dissipate.

Speaking of the next round of convection, regional radar imagery 
showed a line of storms arcing from far northeastern Mississippi,
to the south-southeast to between Tuscaloosa and Birmingham, and 
finally down to the far western end of the Florida panhandle as of
07z. High res guidance suggests that the more widespread 
convection on northeast MS and central AL will likely continue to 
shift northeast through middle Tenn and towards the 
Kentucky/Virginia line, following roughly along the axis of the 
low level jet. Some scattered shower activity will likely exist 
further east/southeast into the Cumberland plateau and TN valley 
areas. This initial round of showers should lift north of the CWA 
by mid/late morning, with yet another batch of showers and 
thunderstorms likely moving in late this afternoon and into the 
evening hours once the atmosphere recovers from morning showers 
and cloud cover and destabilizes again. The forecast will reflect 
a lowering in rain chances late this morning and into the early 
afternoon hours, before increasing again later today, but will 
maintain at least some 20-30 percent rain chances at all times due
to uncertainty in areal coverage and timing. Much like yesterday,
clouds should break up quite a bit in the afternoon hours. Places
that see sufficient sunshine will likely warm into the low or 
perhaps mid 70s. Expect the coolest areas will be in the western 
valley and plateau regions where cloud cover is likely to be most 
prevalent. For tonight, with the upper low drawing closer to our 
southern counties, it is difficult to say exactly how much 
convection will dissipate. Diurnal trends will certainly result in
a lessening of coverage, but plenty of guidance indicates there 
will be some nocturnal convection so will keep decent rain chances
going overnight as well.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Monday)...

At the start of the period the shortwave trough axis will be 
bisecting East Tennessee. It will be more progressive than previous 
model runs therefore the rainfall will exit the forecast area rather 
quickly. Showers and thunderstorms are expected mainly during the 
morning hours gradually ending from west to east through the day. By 
Tuesday night dry conditions will prevail as shortwave ridging 
begins to build. The ridge will stay in control bringing pleasant 
temperatures and more dry weather through Wednesday night and most 
of Thursday. 

The strengthening low over the Central Plains will begin to 
translate towards the Great Lakes Region on Thursday. As a result, 
the trailing cold front will march across Tennessee and Thursday 
night and Friday. Strong southerly flow ahead of this front will 
bring warmer temperatures and increasing low level moisture to the 
forecast area. Showers will be on the increase late Thursday 
afternoon through Thursday night. Showers are expected ahead and 
along the frontal boundary which will extend across Middle TN by 
midnight Thursday. The rain will move from west to east again and 
exit the forecast area by Friday night. 

A short lived high centered over Missouri will build into the area. 
Southwest flow aloft and another shortwave ejecting out of Texas 
will cause another fetch of low level moisture to overspread the 
area on Saturday night. As a result several more rounds of showers 
and expected through Sunday.

.Short Term (Tonight through Tuesday)...

Warm frontal boundary is lifting northeast across northeast 
Tennessee and southwest Virginia with airmass along and south of the

southeast Tennessee with Hail CAPEs between 200-400 J/kg. DCAPEs

km around 40kts. 

Main limiting factor is forcing as warm front lifts north of the 
area. Terrain will likely produce widely scattered/scattered storms. 
Also, line of storms over northern Mississippi may lift east 
northeast toward the Plateau and souheast Tennessee this evening. 
The main concern being marginal hail and strong and gusty winds. PWs 
of 1.3+ inches south will also have the potential of locally heavy 
rains.

For tonight and Monday, models are in dis-agreement in jet forcing 
will move into the area. The GFS pulls showers and embedded 
thunderstorms before daybreak Monday while the NAM is little later. 
Will increase chance of storms for Monday morning with CAPES around 
1000 J/kg with PWs increasing to 1.4 to 1.6 inches. Main concern 
with this area of convection will be heavy rains with potential of 
localized flash flooding.

For Monday night, jet dynamics lifts out of the Tennessee Valley 
with decreasing coverage of showers and embedded storms.  For 
Tuesday. upper trough moves across the Gulf Coast states with a 
boundary still hung up across far east Tennessee. Large differences 
in how much low-level moisture remains over the area with the NAM 
with higher dewpoints and instability. Will maintain chance of 
showers and thunderstorms Tuesday but confidence is low due to 
differences in boundary layer moisture availability.

.Long Term (Tuesday night through Sunday)...

Models in better agreement to start the period regarding the 
movement of the low pressure system away from the region. The ECMWF 
and GFS have consistently shown more of an open wave where the 
northern and southern streams better phase allowing a longwave 
trough to lift to the east, and the 12Z NAM has finally caught onto 
this idea. Have opted to keep slight chance pops in southeast TN and 
southwest NC through 03Z Wednesday. The rest of east TN and 
southwest VA will be dry all of Tuesday night. Used MET/MAV blend 
for lows with generally mid 40's/low 50's expected. 

Surface high pressure will finally build in Wednesday. Upper level 
heights will be rebounding quickly, so a beautifully warm day is 
expected with highs reaching the low/mid 70's and lots of sunshine 
by afternoon.  

Models in agreement that large scale ridging will return to the 
eastern U.S. Wednesday night and Thursday as a negatively tilted 500 
mb trough moves into the Plains and induces intense surface 
cyclogenesis that lifts toward the Great Lakes. This will further 
warm our already above normal temps as WAA strengthens across the TN 
valley keeping temps much above normal through the end of the week. 
Maintained a dry forecast Wednesday night and Thursday and went 
slightly above Superblend for temps. 

A strong cold front behind this system will cross late Thursday 
night through Friday morning. Brought in likely pops on the Plateau 
Thursday night with chance pops in the rest of the region. Friday 
will be wet at least through mid day with a steady light to moderate 
rain. Have likely to categorical pops areawide through the morning 
then chance in the afternoon. Not much in the way of instability 
will be drawn into the region with only a couple hundred joules of 
CAPE expected, and the better dynamics rapidly shift to the north, 
so have not included any thunder with this system. Early rainfall 
estimates from WPC indicate anywhere from a few tenths to one half 
inches of rain from this late week system, so heavy rainfall amounts 
are not expected. 

A big surface high will build down from the north Friday night and 
Saturday with much cooler and drier air. Temps will actually be 
below normal at this time.

The next system will move in Saturday night and Sunday with chance 
pops for showers returning.

FXUS64 KMRX 070759
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
359 AM EDT Sun Apr 7 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

Confidence is not high in today's forecast, especially with regard
to how convection during the afternoon and evening hours will 
unfold. But I'll come back to this in a moment.

First, the area will lie beneath weak upper ridging for much of
the day as a southern stream disturbance ejects northeast from
Texas and interacts with a northern stream shortwave trough 
moving through the central plains today. At the surface, a warm
front is currently moving north into the forecast area from the
southwest. This feature should continue to lift north through the
morning hours. Guidance, even high resolution CAMs, continue to
show at least scattered showers and thunderstorms accompanying
this front as it lifts through the CWA this morning. Current radar
imagery does not currently instill a lot of confidence in this, 
however the main focus for rainfall along this warm front would be
from roughly daybreak through mid/late morning, so there is still
time for this to change. The forecast reflects this and also 
shows a lull in precipitation from late morning into the early 
afternoon hours from south to north.

Regarding this afternoon and tonight, there are indicators that 
support either fairly widespread convection, or very little, 
depending on what guidance you look at. Pattern wise, there 
doesn't seem to be much of a trigger for storms today, with upper 
ridging (albeit with some gradual height falls as the trough 
approaches) overhead and synoptic forcing well to our west. Given 
the pattern and also what the latest CAM guidance is showing, 
lowered PoPs for the afternoon and evening to account for the 
likelihood of less convective activity later today. The forecast 
may still be too optimistic with respect to rain chances however. 
All of this being said, regardless of which guidance set you look 
at, instability and shear values all support the idea of low-end 
organized convection. The most likely areas to see stronger storms
would be the plateau areas on the western side of the CWA, with 
hail and perhaps some damaging winds being the primary threat.


.LONG TERM...(Monday through Sunday)...

Uncertainty right off the bat as models have a tough time 
agreeing on a solution in terms of the speed of the northern 
stream trough. The NAM continues with a closed low feature (likely
the remnants of the current convection over northern 
Mexico)centered over Louisiana Monday afternoon. However, the NAM 
keeps the northern stream trough rather progressive - and keeps 
both systems separate. The GFS joins the southern and northern 
stream troughs. Despite which one is correct, showers and 
thunderstorms will occur during the day Monday where marginal 
instability will be over the area. Anticipate the heaviest rain to
occur on Monday afternoon. Chances for showers and thunderstorms 
persist into Monday night as the trough axis shifts south and 
east. 

Tuesday, remnant showers will be possible mainly south of I-40 as 
this system shifts farther east. The total rainfall from Monday 
through Tuesday will range from 1 to 1.5 inches.

Dry conditions prevail as broad high pressure builds over the 
central U.S. through Wednesday night. A powerful storm system will 
eject out of Colorado Wednesday night and track into the Great Lakes 
Region on Thursday. The trailing cold front will march east across 
Tennessee Thursday evening and Friday. Showers will increase from 
west to east Thursday night and through much of Friday. By Friday 
night the front will have moved into the Carolinas taking the 
precipitation with it. In its wake, slightly cooler and drier air 
will be place on Saturday.

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Sunday)...
Nice evening in store, then a warm front will lift northward 
through the area late tonight through Sunday morning, spreading 
scattered showers northward with it. Thinking we will get somewhat
of a break during the day, and then a particularly bouyant air 
mass will ensue with diurnal heating, such that some tstms may be
triggered over the higher elevations. SPC has a marginal risk of 
severe thunderstorms over the Plateau Sunday as a result.

.LONG TERM (Sunday night through Saturday)...
A moist and unstable airmass will be in place to start the 
period. The biggest question is whether there will be any ongoing 
convection. If any storms are ongoing or do develop, the main 
threats will be large hail and isolated damaging wind gusts. Hail 
CAPES remain elevated into the evening hours with plenty of CAPE 
within the hail growth zone. There is a chance that activity 
located back to our west and northwest may produce some outflow 
boundaries that move into the Northern Cumberland Plateau and 
Northern Valley during the evening that initiates some convection.
POPS start increasing late in the night and through the day on 
Monday, as an area of low pressure rotates across MS/AL/GA from 
west to east. The incoming low has another warm front which will 
be located north of the area during the day on Monday. This front 
interacts with a weak, trailing, cold front associated with the 
low up across New England and both boundaries end up in a west-to-
east orientation just to our north. This boundary, plus the 
vicinity of the low, will provide plenty of lift to generate 
showers and storms through the day therefore allowing Monday to be
our highest POP day of the long term.

With the low positioned to our southwest, abundant moisture from the 
Gulf gets advected into our area. Soundings show PW values ranging 
from 1.25 to 1.5 inches by Monday afternoon, which is maxed out for 
this time of year climatologically. This will allow for potentially 
heavy rainfall. WPC is currently highlighting a marginal risk for 
excessive rainfall. Also, there could be a few strong storms, with 
the main threats being small hail and isolated damaging winds.

There is quite a bit of disagreement on the position of the low by 
Tuesday. The GFS has it directly to our south, the ECMWF has it off 
to our southeast, and the NAM shows it still back to our southwest. 
The position of the low will directly affect our POPS through the 
day on Tuesday so not very confident on Tuesday's forecast as of 
now. The good news is that Tuesday night into Wednesday the low 
moves out and brief ridging builds back in through Thursday, which 
is the only dry days of the long term. By Thursday night/Friday a 
cold front is approaching from the west and will bring us another 
shot of rain and storms. The front moves off to our east Friday 
night and Saturday looks dry with zonal flow in place.

Temps through the long term will be above normal for both highs and 
lows, anywhere from 5 to 15 degrees above normal.

across most valley locations.

.LONG TERM (Saturday through Friday)...A fairly active long term 
period with several rounds of thunderstorms/rain chances possible 
along with more clouds than sun. The only silver lining is that 
temperatures will be above average for both highs and lows with highs 
generally in the 70s and lows in the 50s.  

Saturday night a low pressure center is swinging through the Plains 
and toward the Great Lakes Region while an associated warm front 
extends down into the MS/AL/GA. This warm front lifts northward 
through our area overnight into Sunday morning, providing focus for 
some showers and storms. On Sunday we are firmly in the warm sector 
so the biggest question will be where will the forcing come from to 
initiate any thunderstorms. The best forcing is off to our west and 
northwest, back across Western TN/KY. The airmass over our area will 
be quite unstable with 1000 to 1500 J/kg MLCAPE in place and a good 
amount of hail cape. So if storms do develop, the biggest threats 
would be isolated damaging winds and large hail. Shear is weak with 
30kts at 0-3km so don't expect any well organized storms, but more 
organized than garden variety pulse storms. A few severe 
thunderstorms are possible. The SPC is highlighting a slight risk 
just to our west, so we will continue to monitor the evolution of 
this system.

On Sunday night into Monday another area of low pressure is moving 
out of the ARK-LA-TEX region in association with the active southern 
stream jet. This low will bring another warm front through our area 
which will be focus for more showers and storms. Monday through 
Tuesday the low rotates across our area and will give us the best 
chance of POPs through the period. Plenty of lift, moisture, and 
instability will be present during this time so expect on and off 
rounds of showers and thunderstorms.

Conditions dry out Wednesday through Thursday. However, Thursday 
night through Friday another front rolls in and brings another shot 
of showers and storms with clearing conditions by Friday afternoon 
with cooler temperatures behind the front.
