124 
FXUS64 KMRX 050833
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
433 AM EDT Fri Apr 5 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

A shortwave trough is moving east through middle Tennessee early 
this morning, and is forecast to be along the North Carolina 
coastline by the mid to early afternoon hours later today. Showers 
are fairly widespread across the forecast area ahead of this feature 
early this morning. Expect this trend to continue through the 
daybreak time frame, with a gradual lessening in coverage expected 
thereafter. PoPs reflect a downward trend from the plateau eastward 
after daybreak, with the highest chances lingering in the mountains 
through later today. Model soundings show some very weak instability 
in the H85 to roughly H7 layer later this afternoon. Guidance yields 
some spotty QPF in the afternoon as a result. Kept some slight 
chance PoPs in for the valley and plateau areas through the 
afternoon to account for this, but again I expect much of the 
rainfall after midday to be limited mainly to the higher terrain.

Temperatures are forecast to get into the upper 60s to around 70 
today. There will be plenty of low clouds around today so this could 
be a little warm, but it should be close to what occurs.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Friday)...

Warm southerly flow will increase across our region Saturday as mid 
to upper level heights begin to rise and a 1022 mb surface high sets 
up over the western Atlantic. Projected soundings are quite dry 
through the column through the day, so mostly sunny skies are 
expected, and with the WAA pattern, this will lead to very warm 
temps. Expect widespread highs in the mid 70's and even a few spots 
around 80 in the southern valley. Went slightly above MAV guidance 
for Saturday's highs. 

The pattern will amplify Saturday night and Sunday with an upper 
level ridge axis developing over the eastern U.S. as troughing and 
lee cyclogenesis take shape in the Plains and western half of the 
Midwest. This will cause a warm front to lift northeast across the 
region late Saturday night into Sunday morning. Soundings show the 
profile becoming increasingly moist and unstable during this time as 
southwesterly warm and moist advection increases in response to the 
tightening southwesterly gradient flow. At least scattered 
showers will accompany the passage of this warm front, so have 
chance pops Saturday night through Sunday morning. Lows Saturday 
night will be mild with mid 50's in most areas and around 60 in 
the southern valley. Again went slightly above MAV guidance for 
lows.

A lull in the activity will occur from mid morning through early 
afternoon Sunday with increasing sunshine. Expect a quick rise in 
temps with highs reaching the mid 70's to low 80's, and the moist 
southerly flow will result in dew points rising into the low 60's. 
This will lead to building instability through the afternoon with 
scattered areas of convection. Thinking that ML CAPE values will be 
1500-2000 J/Kg on the plateau and southern valley Sunday afternoon 
with less in the remainder of the region. Lapse rates will be steep 
in the afternoon too with 700-500 mb and 850-500 mb LR progged to be 
7.0-7.5 C/Km. Deep layer shear is not particularly strong though 
with 30-35 kt 0-6 Km bulk shear. However, low level shear looks 
better with around 20 kt 0-1 Km shear and helicity values of 120-
150, especially in the southern valley. PWAT values look to be 
around 1.25 inches. With all of this being said, think that 
convection will be in the form of scattered multi-cell clusters. The 
forcing from the synoptic cold front will be well to the west 
Sunday, so the coverage of storms will not be widespread. The best 
chance for convection will be from the Plateau through the southern 
valley and along the far east TN mountains where differential 
heating boundaries often help to initiate some convection. The above 
mentioned steep mid level lapse rates and high PWAT values could 
lead to locally heavy rain and hail in the strongest cores. Pockets 
of damaging wind could also occur. Widespread severe weather is not 
anticipated, but the low level wind shear is just strong enough to 
keep whatever clusters of storms that do develop fairly organized. 
Movement of the convection will be to the northeast, so some cells 
could make their way into the valley. With the southwesterly flow 
pattern, some training could take place as well leading to areas of 
heavy rain. As mentioned, convective coverage will not be 
widespread, and there could be some capping associated with the 
ridge axis, so greatest coverage will likely stay close to the 
Plateau in the afternoon. Have chance pops Sunday afternoon at this 
time for the plateau and southern valley with slight chance 
elsewhere. Staying close to MAV numbers for highs Sunday. 

Coverage of showers will increase Sunday night as height falls 
associated with the approaching trough axis induce better lift. 
Diurnal timing is unfavorable, but enough elevated CAPE will remain 
to keep thunder in the forecast, so have likely pops for 
showers/storms Sunday night. No severe weather is expected. Lows 
will remain mild again. 

The actual trough and associated cold front will cross the region 
the first half of Monday. There will be significant cloud cover, but 
with instability still present, have likely to categorical pops for 
showers and thunderstorms with highs still reaching the lower 70's. 
Used Superblend for Monday's temps. Showers will linger Monday night 
into Tuesday as the trough axis remains overhead and both the ECMWF 
and GFS hint at a secondary low moving northeast through the region. 
Have likely pops for showers Monday night and chance Tuesday. Model 
plan views hold onto some CAPE through Tuesday, so used shower 
wording Monday night then put thunder back in Tuesday in the heating 
of the day. Mild temps will continue with lows in the 50's Monday 
night and highs low/mid 70's for Tuesday, and once again stayed 
close to Superblend.

Dry weather will finally return Tuesday night and Wednesday as the 
trough axis moves east and surface high builds in from the north. 
This will yield a drier and slightly cooler airmass, although the 
main difference will be cooler nights with daytime highs still 
expected to be in the low/mid 70's under a mostly sunny sky.   

Another trough and lee cyclone will develop in the Plains Wednesday 
night with increasingly warm and moist advection into our area. An 
associated fast moving cold front should pass through Thursday or 
Thursday night. The ECMWF is slower and deeper with this system than 
the GFS. At this time, have slight chance pops Thursday and chance 
pops Thursday night into Friday. Warm temps will continue in this 
late week period as there will not be any strong airmass changes.

increased southerly flow. A warm front will begin to lift north

Temperatures have been much milder overnight compared to 24 hours

temps and lows for the rest of the night. 

Much warmer air surging into the region ahead of the above mentioned 
shortwave will yield a very warm day. Mostly sunny skies this 
morning through early afternoon combined with strong WAA will boost 
highs into the low/mid 70's across the entire valley and southwest 
NC with upper 60's to near 70 in southwest VA. Went with the warmer 
MET guidance for highs since the WAA and strengthening April sun 
angle should allow the warmer temps to occur. Clouds will increase 
from west to east by mid afternoon. Isentropic lift will cause 
showers to first develop out towards the plateau around 21Z with the 
coverage increasing through the evening. Hi-Res models and projected 
soundings show nearly non-existent CAPE this afternoon or evening, 
so kept the wording as rain showers, and did not mention any 
thunder. Have chance to slight chance pops around the plateau at 21Z 
with chance to likely on the plateau by 00Z and chance to slight 
chance further east at that time.

The shortwave and associated low pressure system will pass just 
north of the region tonight dragging a weak cold front through in 
the 06-12Z time frame. Have likely to categorical pops expanding 
across the entire region through the night then tapering to chance 
in western areas after 11Z. A couple hundred joules of elevated CAPE 
will develop at CHA tonight, so added a slight chance of thunder for 
the southern valley and southern plateau. The rest of the region 
will remain rain showers. Cloud cover and continued warm airmass in 
place will allow for a mild night tonight with many places remaining 
in the 50's. Again used the warmer MET numbers for tonight's lows.

As this system moves east Friday, showers will slowly exit from west 
to east. Have likely pops continuing in far northeast TN and 
southwest VA through 17Z and chance elsewhere. An inverted trough at 
the surface hanging back west into the region could maintain a few 
showers through the afternoon, so kept chance to slight chance pops. 
This system does not draw in much of an airmass change, so sided 
with warmer MAV guidance bringing highs into the low 70's in many 
areas.

.LONG TERM...(Friday night through Thursday)...

As the minor shortwave begins to move out of the CWA at the start of 
the long range outlook, the region looks to be introduced to a more 
zonal pattern for Friday night with a developing trough over the 
Rockies. This developing system will move eastward quickly and begin 
to influence eastern Tennessee by early Sunday morning. A mid level 
ridge over our area for Friday night and Saturday will help to 
suppress any possible precipitation as soundings show a decent 
capping inversion. A small potential for thunderstorms late 
afternoon on Saturday should the inversion break, even with very 
modest CAPE values.

South westerly surface flow through the weekend will aid in keeping 
temperatures warm and are predicted to be several degrees above the 
seasonal averages for the weekend, further aiding in afternoon 
convection. This warm air advection, along with increased moisture 
surging up from the south will begin to produce widespread rain 
showers ahead of the incoming front on Saturday night.

RAP soundings are showing a fair amount of potential instability for 
Sunday afternoon, although weak 0-6km shear values. This indicates 
that we should mostly see multi-cells of pulse convection with non-
rotating updrafts. That said, CAPE values are high enough, 
particularly in the more southern areas of the CWA, that severe 
storms can't be entirely ruled out at this point.

The period of potential thunderstorms also looks to extend beyond 
the weekend. As the GFS and Euro models are becoming more in 
agreement, they show an area of developing low pressure over the 
Great Plains. This area of cyclogenesis will form a weak semi-
baroclinic low pressure center that will slowly track eastward. The 
slow movement of the deepening low will lead to an extended period 
of showers and thunderstorms for the first few days of next week.

broken to overcast cloud cover and a chance of showers late 
tomorrow. The low level air mass remains fairly dry until tomorrow 
night, so coverage of showers in the 20-00Z time frame should be 
mainly isolated to scattered with light QPF amounts. 

.LONG TERM...(Thursday night through Wednesday)...
Multiple chances of showers and thunderstorms along with continued 
warmer temperatures are expected through the long term period. 
Thursday night, an upper level shortwave will approach the Tennessee 
valley with a south to southwest flow aloft. The reflection at the 
surface will be an area of weak low pressure shifting northeast into 
the Great Lakes region by Friday morning. Southerly low to mid level 
flow will transport moisture northward during this time allowing for 
showers and thunderstorms Thursday night into Friday morning. 
Gradual weakening of this shortwave and increasing heights in its 
wake should lead to an overall decrease in coverage of showers 
during the day on Friday. Winds may become gusty across the mountain 
zones Friday morning as low level flow becomes more south oriented. 
While we are not looking at a mountain wave event, a 30-40 knot low 
level jet with at least a moderately strong pressure gradient 
induced across the mountains supports the mention of stronger winds. 
Temperatures Friday will continue to be warm as warm air advection 
dominates with daytime highs in the upper 60s to low 70s. 

Zonal flow then becomes dominate by Friday night ahead of a 
developing system to the west.  Lows Friday night should continue to 
be mild with low to mid 50's expected area wide.  Low to mid level 
winds begin to back to the southwest considerably over the weekend 
ahead of a deepening shortwave trough across the southern plains. 
Moisture will stream northward along with an increase in warm air 
advection.  Weak to moderate isentropic ascent along the 300K 
surface supports slight chance to chances PoPs of showers during the 
day on Saturday, however widespread precipitation is not expected on 
Saturday.  Temperatures are forecast to rise into the low to upper 
70's across most locations.  The surface fields becomes somewhat 
complex Saturday into Sunday.  Lee cyclogenesis supports an area of 
low pressure to develop across the central plains Saturday before 
two surface lows branch off.  This is supported by both the GFS and 
ECMWF and to a lesser extend the Canadian.  The northern low will 
likely eject north rather quickly associated with a quick moving 
shortwave.  An area of low pressure across the southern plains 
likely supported by the deeper shortwave across the southern plains 
will become the dominate circulation for influence on our sensible 
weather over the end of the weekend and into next week.  

A weak baroclinic zone will extend from the Great Lakes southward 
into the southern plains on Sunday.  A weak warm front lifting north 
Sunday morning will likely support precipitation along this 
boundary.  Point forecast soundings indicate several hundred joules 
of CAPE using a most unstable parcel trace.  This elevated 
instability would indicate chances of thunderstorms to accompany 
this lifting boundary as well.  Once the front lifts, the area will 
become embedded into the warm sector airmass.  After a lull in the 
afternoon, precipitation will move back into the area Sunday 
afternoon and evening.  A lot of questions still remain in regards 
to instability and overall shear, but models have been persistent in 
showing increased instability parameters. While shear looks to 
remain on the weak side, the co-location of instability, and weak 
shear would support chances of multi-cellular convection as well. 
Will carry chance to likely PoPs Sunday afternoon through Sunday 
evening. Temperatures Sunday and Sunday night will continue to be 
above normal values.  

The long range becomes less uncertain in how it handles low level 
features, and the precipitation field.  Chance PoPs will need to be 
carried during this period for now.  Again, near to above normal 
temperatures are expected during this period.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

An upper level shortwave will continue to rotate across the

through early this morning at CHA and TYS, but drier air still

think all rain chances will be done by mid morning. This short 
wave will bring increased mid level cloudiness through mid 
morning, but skies will become mostly sunny by late morning 
through the afternoon as subsidence develops behind the departing 
disturbance. Low temps early this morning will stay several 
degrees warmer than yesterday morning due to the clouds and weak 
WAA ahead of the short wave. Expect upper 30's/low 40's across the
central/southern valley and southwest NC with mid 30's across 
extreme northeast TN into southwest VA. This could yield some 
patchy frost in the northeast, but not widespread enough for any 
advisories this morning.

Upper level heights will begin to rise this afternoon through 
tonight with surface high pressure building in from the west, but NW 
flow continuing aloft will maintain below normal temps. Look for 
highs to remain cool this afternoon with low/mid 50's across 
southwest VA and northeast TN and upper 50's to near 60 from the 
central valley through southwest NC. The surface high will become 
centered over east TN by late tonight. This will lead to mostly 
clear skies. Good radiational cooling tonight will lead to patchy 
frost in parts of northeast TN and southwest VA. Leaned toward the 
MET guidance for temps today and tonight because it is slightly 
cooler which makes sense in the NW flow pattern.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday through Tuesday)...

A moderating temperature trend will feature to start the long-term 
forecast period. Upper level heights will be increasing as an upper 
level trough departs to the northeast. In the low levels, the ridge 
will shift out over the Carolina coast. Southerly flow around this 
high will lead to warm air and moisture advection. Sunny skies with 
PW values in the 0.4-0.6 inch range will also aid in temperatures 
rising quickly on Wednesday. Highs on Wednesday will be closer to 
average ranging from the mid 60s to low 70s. Lee cyclogenesis will 
occur on Wednesday into Wednesday night as the next approaching 
upper level trough moves out of the Inter-Mountain West into the 
Rocky Mountains. Warm advection will continue into Wednesday night 
and Thursday morning with lows much warmer than the last few nights 
with most locations in the 40s. Therefore, do not expect any 
frost/freeze issues in the extended portion of the forecast. 

Clouds will increase across the area from west to east on Thursday 
as the surface low and cold front to the west moves across the Great 
Plains. Despite the cloud cover, temperatures will climb into the 
upper 60s to low 70s for most locations with continued warm air 
advection. The upper level trough moves into the Tennessee River 
Valley late Thursday into early Friday. Models indicate two warm 
fronts one to the north stretching E-W across the Ohio River Valley 
and another to the south stretching E-W across the Gulf Coast 
states. This warm front is forecast to stay to the south of the area 
and precipitation chances will be highest across southern portions 
of the forecast area. PW values will increase into the 0.7-1.1 inch 
range Thursday night into Friday. Some elevated instability will be 
possible across southern portions of the area and have included

upper level trough will move through the area on Friday with a dry 
forecast Friday afternoon into Saturday morning. The cold air 
advection behind the front is not overly impressive/short-lived and 
do not expect much of a temperature changed behind the departing 
surface boundary. An upper level ridge will build over the region 
late Friday into Saturday and have fairly high confidence that this 
period will be dry. Overnight lows Friday night into Saturday 
morning will be mild and will range from the upper 40s to mid 50s 
for most locations. 

Longer range models begin to diverge a good bit over the upcoming 
weekend into early next week. The long range models all indicate 
that the ridge axis will quickly shift to the east. The ridge should 
be the main influence on Saturday with the forecast area transitions 
quickly back into the warm air advection regime. The GFS indicates a 
decent coverage of warm air advection shower/storms with the 
ECMWF/Canadian keeping conditions rather dry. For now, have only 
gone with a slight chance for a few shower/storms but would expect 
most areas stay dry on Saturday with highs in the 70s for most 
locations. 

Later in the weekend and into early next week, both models indicate 
several southwesterly troughs moving across the area. Each of these 
should bring in the chances for widespread showers and storms. PoPs 
remain elevated in the extended portion of the forecast. The GFS is 
much more progressive with a frontal passage on Monday, while the 
ECMWF closes off a low to the west and is much slower with the 
frontal passage more towards Tuesday/Wednesday.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
342 PM EDT Mon Apr 1 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Tuesday)...An approaching mid/upper level 
short wave trough will move across the area later tonight and early 
Tuesday.  Moisture will increase, but lower levels will be slow to 
moisten up and lift is expected to be weak, so while a few patches 
of light precip cannot be ruled out, right now the chance of 
measurable precip looks to be lower than slight chance over most 
of the area. Will just include a slight chance for showers in the 
southwest part of the area for a few hours shortly after midnight.
Temperatures tonight will drop to near freezing across portions 
of the northern valley/SW VA, but with the increasing cloud cover 
do not expect widespread frost so no frost advisory will be issued
for now. However, if cloud cover is delayed there may be a need 
for a frost advisory or even a freeze warning in these areas as it
looks like it will be close. Clouds will decrease Tuesday behind 
the short wave but temperatures will continue to run below 
seasonal normals.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday night through Monday)...With the exit of the
short wave earlier in the week, high pressure looks to move back
into the region. While temperatures will remain somewhat low for 
Tuesday night, most areas of the forecast area will see 
significant warming through the day. Overnight lows for Tuesday 
could reach the freezing point in some areas, perticularly for the
higher elevations. Some areas of the valley could see pooling of 
cooler air that will lead to potential formation of patchy fog for
the early morning hours. Winds on Wednesday will gradually shift 
more towards the south by the evening, bringing in more warm moist
air from the south, further aiding the increasing temperatures.

The next low pressure system will begin to influence the area late 
in the week with building clouds and slightly higher winds. Most of 
the higher winds ahead of the incoming cold front are expected for 
the more southwestern counties of eastern Tennessee with some gusts 
reaching up to 15 mph. An extended period of on and off rain showers 
will linger for the end of the week, but most of the rain should 
clear out by late Friday night. Some clearing skies late on Saturday 
but most of the extended period looks to be remain relatively 
cloudy. Due to the extensive cloud cover and predomenantly southerly 
winds, temperatues should remain warm for most of the forecast.

The next major system will move in quickly afterward with a warm 
front surging north into the area Saturday night. This will lead to 
higher temperatures than the seasonal average for early next week. 
Some of the more southern counties could see temperatures up into 
the high 70's or even 80 is possible. The showers and storms 
assosiated with the next cold front will move into the area by 
Sunday morning with the potential for some thunderstorms for most of 
the day. A transition over to mostly rain is expected overnight on 
Sunday through Monday, but can't rule out the possibility of the 
occasional thunderstorm.

980 
FXUS64 KMRX 010800
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
400 AM EDT Mon Apr 1 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

Already seeing most locations below freezing early this morning with 
a widespread freeze anticipated before sunrise. At 4 AM, 
temperatures range from the mid 20s to mid 30s under mostly clear
skies. Current water vapor imagery and RAP upper air analysis 
indicates a trough across the northeast U.S. with another 
shortwave trough moving out of the Desert Southwest into the 
southern Plains. There is also a shortwave ridge ahead of this 
trough that extends across the Lower and Mid-Mississippi River 
Valley. In the low levels, the surface high is located just to the
north of the forecast area across the Ohio River Valley. Due to 
this, there is still some decent low level cold advection with 
northerly winds currently ranging from around 5-10 mph. Winds 
should continue to subside this morning with the pressure gradient
relaxing give away to more radiational cooling conditions. 
Temperatures this morning will start off in the mid 20s in the low
30s for most locations.

The shortwave ridge will move over the area today with increasing 
heights aloft. Mostly sunny skies are forecast with PW values 
ranging from around 0.2-0.3 inches. These values are around the 10th 
percentile for early April. Therefore, do not expect any 
precipitation today. With the dry atmosphere in place, RH values 
will drop down into the 20-30% range this afternoon. High 
temperatures should be a couple of degrees warmer today with most 
locations in the 50s. The upper level trough to the west will move 
into the Tennessee River Valley later tonight. Model soundings 
indicate an increase of upper level and mid level moisture with this 
system. PW values will climb into the 0.3-0.5 inch range, these 
values are only around the 25th percentile for early April. Models 
indicate that 850mb winds will shift around to the south for a very 
brief period of time ahead of the upper trough. Model soundings 
indicate that the low levels will remain rather dry and have only 
included a slight chance of precipitation tonight across southwest
North Carolina where low-level moisture will be a bit higher. It
could even be cold enough for a few snowflakes to mix in but do
not expect any impacts. Elsewhere, just expect an increase in
cloud cover later tonight. Overnight lows will be colder than
normal again ranging from the low 30s to low 40s. Do not expect
any widespread fog formation tonight with the increasing cloud
cover and large low level dewpoint depressions.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Monday)...

We start the period with a shortwave passing through the southern
stream. Though this system still passes to our south, soundings 
show a moist mid and upper level profile across our area as it 
swings through. However, the lower levels are quite dry and 
therefore not confident on precip reaching the ground. Went ahead 
and removed all POPs for Tuesday but wouldn't be shocked if some 
light drizzle made it's way to the surface across some areas. If 
this occurs it will be short-lived as the system quickly pulls off
to our east by Tuesday afternoon. The biggest impact from this 
system will be clouds but clearing is expected by afternoon. Highs
will be in the low to upper 50s. Some patchy frost possible 
across areas north of I-40 on Tuesday night as lows will be in the
mid to upper 30s.

Wednesday through Thursday still features brief ridging building 
back in, which allows for dry and warming conditions. By Thursday 
highs are back into to the upper 60s to low 70s. Thursday night into 
Friday a shortwave and associated area of low pressure will move 
into the area from out the central Great Plains. By the time the 
system moves into our area the wave is much flatter and open. So as 
it stands, this system doesn't look too impressive. At this point 
the main impacts will be rain showers, along with gusty winds across 
the high terrain due to 30 to 40 kts of southerly 850 mb flow. This 
system exits Friday afternoon and clearing begins. This system isn't 
connected with the northern jet so there won't be a push of cold air 
behind it. In fact, riding quickly build back in and highs for the 
weekend are in the mid to upper 70s, which is around 8 to 12 degrees 
above normal. A potentially stronger system moves in Sunday/Sunday 
night and could bring a few storms to the area.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Monday)...

The previous cold front continues to progress eastward as 
cool, dry air associated with higher pressure moves into the region 
behind it. Gusting winds from the north will lessen by tonight as 
the pressure gradient loosens and moves off the east coast, leading 
to more upper level zonal flow by tomorrow morning. The combination 
of northerly winds and cool, dry air will lead to overnight 
temperatures for tonight that will drop below freezing for most of 
the area. A freeze warning will be in effect overnight until Monday 
morning.

.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Sunday)...

Although the brunt of the opening system will be well south of us
as advertised, models have a bit more of an open shortwave trough
crossing TN from west to east, and that may be able to tap enough
of the moisture field to the south and squeeze out some light 
rain showers in our area. Don't be surprised if light rain occurs 
especially in the southern areas late Monday night. All models 
except GFS end it there, but GFS places patchy light rain over the
northern areas Tuesday afternoon. We will hold off on that right 
now, but some northern mountain precip will be added to Tues to 
match up a bit with GSP. Even with the passage of this system, 
mild temps will continue.

Next system rolls out of the Rockies Wednesday, with a moistening 
Gulf fetch for us. Temps will return to 70s in the Valley, and the 
system will spread showers into our area beginning Thurs afternoon, 
peaking on Thursday night/Friday morning before moving out to the 
east. 

Then ridging resumes, as yet another system heads into west TX 
Saturday. Temps may be flirting with 80 next weekend for the central 
and southern Valley.

.DISCUSSION...
Quick update to issue a wind advisory for the remainder of this

flakes over the higher mountain peaks, but no significant 
accumulation is expected even over the highest elevations.  Winds 
will be gusty from the southwest ahead of the front, then 
transitioning to the northwest/north behind the front. Clouds will 
decrease Sunday giving way to a sunny/mostly sunny sky.

.LONG TERM...(Sunday Night through Saturday)...Other than the Monday 
morning freeze, a quiet pattern greets us as the extended period 
opens. The formerly-known-as Tuesday event will track too far south 
to impact us with precip, so it has been removed. This means that 
midweek ridging will allow us to reach the 70s in parts of the 
Valley from Wednesday through Saturday. But the southerly winds that 
will prompt that warm-up will also draw up Gulf moisture ahead of 
the next worthwhile shortwave trough that will roll past the MS 
Valley Thursday and bring us showery weather from late Thursday 
through Friday night. There will be no post-frontal cool down, 
however, as the next trough moves into the southern plains Saturday, 
quickly ridging us once again. Precip from this second event will 
probably hold off until next Sunday at least.

Looking ahead, the 6-10 day and 8-14 day outlooks are showing decent 
signals for an expectation of warmer than average temperatures.(Sunday

844 
FXUS64 KMRX 300732
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
332 AM EDT Sat Mar 30 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

Current water vapor imagery and RAP upper air analysis indicate a 
weak shortwave trough currently moving into the Tennessee River 
Valley, another trough near the southern Plains, and a third to the 
north near the western Great Lakes. Model forecast soundings 
indicate that the low levels are still rather dry with PW values in 
the 0.6-0.8 inch range. These values are slightly above the 50th 
percentile for late March. For now, do not expect anything more than 
an increase in mid level clouds with this first trough. A mild night 
is currently ongoing with temperatures early this morning in the 50s 
for most areas. At the surface, high pressure extends along the 
eastern Seaboard and a cold front to the north and west. Low level 
warm air and moisture advection continue across the forecast area 
ahead of the cold front. 

The shortwave trough currently across the southern Plains will 
continue eastward into the Mid-Mississippi River Valley later today. 
The cold front will then begin to make some steady progress to the south 
and east. The pressure gradient will increase between the surface
low to the west and the surface high to the east. Southwesterly 
winds will increase later this morning with some gusts up to 
around 25-35 mph possible at times today. A shortwave ridge will 
actually move over the area late this morning into the early 
afternoon as the first trough passes to the east. This could 
produce some periods of mostly sunny to partly cloudy conditions 
and with strong warm air advection, expect high temperatures will 
climb into the low to mid 70s in most locations. 

The front will race into the area later this evening as the 
positively tilted trough continues eastward. PW values will increase 
into the 1.0-1.2 inch range along the front. Widespread precipitation 
is forecast later this evening into early Sunday with the frontal 
passage. Instability will be waining during the evening hours with 
the loss of daytime heating. Deep layer and low-level shear is 
sufficient for some severe storms associated with the frontal 
passage but the lack on instability will be the main limiting 
factor. Expect there could be a few stronger storms possible across 
extreme southwestern portions of the forecast area (for example 
Marion/Sequatchie counties) where instability will be a bit higher 
later this evening. Rainfall will be heavy at times with the 
frontal passage and storm totals will range from around half an 
inch to an inch for most locations.

Noticeably colder air will advect in behind the departing system late 
Saturday night into Sunday morning. In fact, a few snow showers will 
be possible in the higher elevations of the Smoky Mountains early
Sunday morning before the moisture exits but do not anticipate any
accumulations at this time. Lows Sunday morning will be in the mid
30s to low 40s. Strong dry air and cold air advection will lead to
PW values dropping down into the 0.1-0.2 inch range on Sunday.
Despite the mostly sunny skies on Sunday, high temperatures will
only rise into the 50s with the strong cold advection. 

.LONG TERM...(Sunday through Saturday)...

Main focus of the period is the below freezing temperatures that 
are expected across the forecast area Sunday night into Monday 
morning. Sub-freezing temps are due to the northerly cold air 
advection coming in behind the departed cold front. Lows will 
range from the mid 20s to near freezing for most places, which is 
10 to 12 degrees below normal. A freeze watch will likely be 
needed with the next forecast issuance.

Under the influence of high pressure and northerly flow, expect 
plenty of sunshine and below normal temperatures on Monday. Highs 
will be in the low to mid 50s, around 8 to 10 degrees below normal. 
As high pressure migrates to our east the flow becomes southerly by 
Monday night. This will allow temperatures to not be as cold as 
Sunday night. Lows on Monday night will be in the lower to upper 
30s. 

On Tuesday a shortwave trough and associated area of low pressure 
will pass to our south. Model have been trending further south with 
the low track so it looks like our forecast area will see minimal 
impacts. Currently, only have POPs in for the extreme eastern areas, 
right along the foothills and eastern mountains. Clouds and POPs 
decrease by Tuesday afternoon as the low races off the coast of the 
Carolinas. Wednesday through Thursday feature high pressure building 
back into the area with warming temperatures due to southerly flow 
and rising heights. By Thursday afternoon a shortwave trough is 
moving through the central Plains and will bring us our next chance 
of precip from Thursday night through Friday.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Saturday)...
Remnant outflow boundaries and showers from storms last night

air near the surface most likely these showers won't be able to 
produce precipitation at the surface. But these boundaries look

Tennessee Valley. This is causing winds to jump up to around 10 
mph with some weather stations recording gusts up aground 20 mph. 
Direction of the winds is generally westerly to southerly when 
they get breezy, depending on the direction of the boundary 
they're near. Winds should die down as the sun sets this evening. 

Frontal boundary will be pushing into Western Tennessee/Kentucky
tomorrow afternoon. This will cause an increase in the pressure
gradient across the area and winds will increase out of the
southwest in response. Winds look to remain below advisory level,
but it will be a bit of a breezy day on Saturday. Rain may creep
into the eastern Cumberland Plateau Saturday afternoon, but the
bulk of the precipitation will stay out of the eastern Tennessee
Valley until Saturday night.

.Long Term (Saturday Night through Friday)...
Period opens with deep longwave trough over the eastern U.S. 
driving a cold front and accompanying band of showers/isolated 
tstms through the area. Cooler temperatures will be ushered in for
Sunday-Tuesday, with valley highs mostly in the 50s after the 
pleasant 70s tomorrow. 

A shortwave trough will move through TX Monday and begin to spin up 
some cyclogenesis in the northern Gulf. The latest 12Z long range 
models are keeping most of the precip chances with this developing 
system to our south and east, but we will hang on to low pops in our 
southern and eastern areas for now, keeping with surrounding 
offices. By Wednesday, this system will begin racing up the east 
coast offshore while dry ridging resumes over the southern 
Appalachians.

A fast shortwave will move onto the west coast Tuesday and race 
across the Rockies, inducing return flow into the southern Plains on 
wednesday and initiating a late week warm-up for us locally. This 
system will bring us more chances of showers from Thurs night 
through Friday.

National Weather Service Morristown TN
359 AM EDT Fri Mar 29 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

Low level high pressure to the southeast is bringing in 
warm air and moisture advection to the forecast area. In 
the upper levels, flow is rather zonal with a jet streak 
to the north across the Great Lakes. At the surface, there 
is a cold front to the north and west across the Great Lakes 
stretching to the southwest into the southern Plains. The 
atmosphere is rather dry currently with PW values in the 
0.4-0.6 inch range. These values are around the 25th-40th 
percentile for late March. Temperatures will start out in 
the 40s across most of the area this morning with a few 
passing mid to high clouds. 

Continued warm air advection with the low level ridge to the 
southeast and cold front to the northwest will push high 
temperatures this afternoon up into the mid 60s to low 70s.
Moisture will also be on the rise today with PW climbing into the
0.7-1.0 inch range. Flow aloft will also be a bit more
southwesterly today as a ridge amplifies near the Carolina Coast.
Models indicate a few weak shortwaves moving across the region
today. The upper level and mid-level flow will remain parallel to
the surface boundary and do not expect much movement today with
the forecast area staying well in the warm sector. Clouds will
increase this afternoon in association with a few weak mid-level
impulses. Have a very small mention of precipitation for portions
of the northern Cumberland Plateau and southwest Virginia but most
areas will remain dry. A mild night is forecast tonight with
continued low level southerly flow and increasing cloud cover.
Lows will range from the low to mid 50s with dry conditions
overnight.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Friday)...

Positively tilted longwave trough swinging into the area to start
the period. Most of the day should be dry with clouds slowly 
increasing from west to east. The main focus during the daytime 
hours will be gusty winds. Deep mixing and dry air in the lower 
levels, notated by the inverted v soundings, will allow for gusty 
winds down at the surface. 850mb flow is out of the southwest 
through the day. This pattern may result in some downsloping but 
not the classic setup needed. By late afternoon/early evening 
850mb flow ramps up to 30 to 40 kts and remains out of the 
southwest. Saturday night the cold front associated with the 
trough is bearing down on Western/Middle TN and approaching 
quickly. The arrival time of showers, and a few storms, will be 
somewhere between 7 and 10 PM. Soundings show very little 
instability some not too concerned with storms at the moment. The 
main threats will be gusty winds and some moderate rain here and 
there, half an inch up to three quarters of an inch is possible 
with lesser amounts along the foothills of the eastern mountains.

Showers exit quickly Sunday morning as the front exits to our east, 
then clearing conditions ensue. Northwesterly flow behind the front 
will bring colder air with highs on reaching the upper 40s to mid 
50s, which is 10 to 12 degrees below normal. Clearing may be slow 
for areas east of I-75 as northwest flow pools moisture up against 
the foothills. Clouds finally clear and Sunday night will be the 
coldest of the period with lows in the upper 20s to lower 30s, which 
is 8 to 10 degrees below normal. A freeze watch will eventually be 
needed for much of the area, as we get a little closer to the event. 

Monday is clear but on the cool side as we remain under northerly 
flow due to high pressure to our west. Monday night into Tuesday a 
system passes to our south but could bring some clouds and light 
rain into the area, depending on the track of the low. Conditions 
clear quickly though as this feature will be off the coast of the 
Carolinas by Tuesday afternoon/evening. High pressure sets up behind 
this system and keeps us under northerly flow for Wednesday but with 
warmer temps as  heights begin to rise. Highs close to normal by 
Wednesday. High pressure moves to our east by thursday returning us 
to southerly flow and increasing moisture with increasing chances of 
rain late in the day as a shortwave approaches from the west.

.LONG TERM...(Friday night through Thursday)...

ridging combines with southerly flow near the surface to bring 
temperatures about 5-10 degrees above normal for this time of year.

begins on Friday night into Saturday morning as a mid level trough 
over the Great Lakes Region and the associated front begin to move 
across the eastern half of the United States. Surface low along the 
front will slide across the Northern Ohio River Valley Saturday. The 
southerly winds at the surface and orientation of the front will 
keep rain chances confined to the Cumberland Plateau and westward 
Friday into Saturday morning. Front gets an eastward push Saturday 
night into Sunday...There looks to be enough dynamics with this 
system to warrant the mention of thunderstorm chances, with the 
highest chances being along the Cumberland Plateau and western 
Tennessee Valley Saturday night, but the low instability parameters 
suggest that most places will see just rain showers. 

Front will have pushed through the area by Sunday night and 
temperatures will drop about 20 degrees in response. Coldest night 
of the week will be Sunday night as lows drop into the 30's across 
the area and below freezing along the Cumberland Plateau into SW 
Virginia. 

Quiet weather is expected until Tuesday when a shortwave zips across 
the Southeastern United States. models have begun to trend a bit 
further north with this system bringing in more moisture and QPF 
into the Eastern Tennessee Valley the first half of next week. Have 
slightly increased precipitation chances Monday night into Tuesday, 
but confidence is still somewhat low at this time as model run-to-
run consistency isn't quite there yet with this shortwave.

cooler conditions.

differences on the affects from this wave. The best cyclogenesis

will be to our north, and the overnight timing will limit

amplified upper trough, likely PoPs with a slight chance of t'storms 
will continue to be mentioned. A much colder air mass will build in 
behind the front on Sunday, with highs only in the 50s.

their solutions. The GFS shows a split flow with a southern stream 
trough bringing quite a bit of rainfall on Monday and Tuesday, but 
many GEFS members and the ECMWF remain dry. For now, will maintain 
the dry forecast for Monday until models show better agreement.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
330 PM EDT Mon Mar 25 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Tuesday)...
The upper pattern this afternoon is highlighted by an approaching H5 
shortwave embedded within the large longwave placed atop the 
central/eastern CONUS, while a 90-100kt H3 jet rounds the base of 
said trough.  At the surface, a cold front tied to an OH Valley 
surface low is slowly advecting east into the Cumberland Plateau 
this afternoon, with weak/modest convection initiating due to surface 
frontal convergence, as well as the aforementioned upper vort and 
the left exit region of the H3 jetmax enhancing divergence aloft. 
That said, surface obs are indicative of only weak instability as 
the warm front is just now moving into the lower valley/plateau as 
dewpoints remain in the low/mid 50s at best.  Profiles exhibit 
unidirectional flow with little if any speed/directional shearing, 
as well as fairly low fz levels of approx 8-9kft.  Thus, favorable 
multicell convection within a broken line has initiated across the 
lower plateau, and will continue to advect east with time this 
afternoon. Some further destabilization is possible as the Nam 
favors mucapes around 800-900j/kg, which may me a bit of a stretch. 
All said, pops will remain in likely/cat levels through the 
remainder of the day with a few strong storms closer to the US64 
corridor possible.  With any stronger convection, think the primary 
threat would be small hail, brief heavy rainfall, and cloud to 
ground lightning. Otherwise, expecting light/moderate showers with 
perhaps a few rumbles of thunder along/north of I40.

Moving on, the front will sweep through the remainder of the fcst 
area tonight, with some residual moisture banked against the 
Southern Appalachians amidst the developing nwly flow.  With that, 
expecting prolonged light shra along the spine of the mtns, perhaps 
with some changeover to snow at the highest elevations above 4500ft 
or so given caa, no accumulations expected.  As for tomorrow, should 
be a fairly quiet day as cold advective nly/nwly flow prevails. Did 
leave some low confidence pops in for the southern mtns given 
proximity to the slowly departing H5 wave.  Otherwise, expect mostly 
sunny (northward) to partly cloudy (southward) skies and 
temperatures a few degrees below normal.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday night through Monday)...
A quite longterm period with ridging expected to dominate through 
the week before a storm system moves through during the weekend with 
increasing chances of showers and possibly thunderstorms.  A exiting 
shortwave Tuesday night will bring northwest flow aloft through. 
Wednesday. The surface fields show high pressure moving off the 
Great Lakes into the northeast with northerly flow.  This flow will 
usher in much drier air with lower dewpoints.  Wednesdays highs 
should top out in the upper 50's to mid 60's, with lows in the 30's 
to near 40. 

Upper level ridging will dominate toward the late week with much 
drier and warmer weather conditions.  A trough will move onshore the 
Pacific northwest and into the intermountain west with lee 
cyclogenesis developing Thursday.  This lower pressure to the west, 
and high pressure off the New England coast will create a south and 
east flow advecting a warmer and moist airmass.  Highs Thursday and 
Friday will be warmer with highs in the 60's to near 70.  Overnight 
lows Thursday night and Friday night are forecast to be in the 
middle 40's to low 50's.

Upper level pattern becomes less uncertain toward the weekend, but 
confidence is becoming higher that the trough to the west will move 
into the central and northern plains with lowering heights across 
the region.  At the surface, an area of low pressure and associated 
cold front will move east Saturday into Sunday, however confidence 
on timing is still rather low.  Sunday, confidence drops off further 
as models differ on how they handle the trough across the Ohio and 
Tennessee valley, but for now will carry mostly slight chance to 
chance PoPs. Temperatures during this period will likely be near 
normal.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
A closed mid/upper level low over the Mid MS Valley this morning 
will be transitioning to an open wave as it tracks E-SE through the 
OH Valley today. A line of showers currently crossing srn KY and 
Middle TN in an area of warm advection ahead of the system is 
projected to reach our Plateau counties this morning, around 10-12Z. 
It will be moving into a drier and more stable air mass, so the 
current lightning activity should be diminishing as it moves east. 

Later today, mainly after 18Z, we will have strengthening forcing 
aloft as a jet streak across E KY and WV provides upper divergence. 
Instability will be increasing as well but still remain fairly weak, 
with MLCAPE values in the range of only 400-700 J/kg in our southern 
half. The forcing and weak instability should be enough for a chance 
of thunderstorms, but the severe threat looks low. Some small hail 
may be possible due to the low freezing levels around 7-8 kft, but 
shear appears too weak and CAPE profiles too narrow for a large hail 
threat. The surface cold front is rather diffuse but appears to move 
through in the evening, with rain chances dropping off from west to 
east through tonight as winds through the column shift to N-NW and 
usher in dry air aloft.

.LONG TERM...(Monday through Sunday)...
A more tranquil pattern until the weekend. 

For Tuesday...another upper trough will move southeast into the 
Tennessee Valley and Gulf Coast states. This wave will produce an 
inverted surface trough over the spine of the Appalachians. Moisture 
is limited due to previous stronger short-wave, but enough boundary 
layer moisture combined with upslope flow into the western Carolina 
to produce 20-30 percetn coverage of showers near the Carolina 
border.

For Tuesday night through Thursday night...the main weather features 
will be surface ridging into the Appalachians and upper ridging. 
Some increase in high/mid level clouds possible for Thursday, but 
overall, dry with plenty of sunshine with low afternoon relative 
humidity (RHs in the 30s anticipated, possibly 20s). A gradual 
warming trend is also expected.

For Friday...surface ridge moves allowing for return of southerly 
flow and slowly increasing moisture. However, no upper forcing and 
moisture/instability not enough to produce orographic showers.

For Saturday...upper trough moves into the Mississippi Valley late 
in the day with frontal boundary approaching the area. Increasing 
showers and possibly thunderstorms late. Degree of Gulf moisture 
return and instability is a big question.

For Saturday night and Sunday morning, main upper forcing moves 
through along with frontal boundary. Again, confidence is low on 
amount of moisture and instability return.

FXUS64 KMRX 241945
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
345 PM EDT Sun Mar 24 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight through Monday night)...

A mild pattern will continue tonight as WAA persists ahead of an 
upper short wave and surface low approaching from the NW. A few 
initial showers late this afternoon through this evening associated 
with a weak vort max will exit by 03Z. The rest of the night will 
stay dry and mild. Projected soundings show deep layer warm and 
moist advection through the night with a 20-30 kt southwesterly 850-
700 mb jet. The mid levels are quite saturated, so expected skies to 
remain mostly cloudy through the night. The cloud cover combined 
with the WAA will keep lows in the upper 40's/mid 50's with the 
coolest temps confined to far northeast TN and southwest VA.

The above mentioned short wave will cross the region Monday with a 
weak surface low tracking roughly from KY to VA. Models have 
struggled with the exact placement and track of this low the past 
couple of days with the ECMWF being the most consistent. The 
consensus is for the low to mainly track just north of the TN/KY 
line dragging a cold front across our region late morning through 
mid afternoon. The 12Z GFS and NAM are in better agreement on this 
timing and track which is what the ECMWF has suggested the past few 
runs. 

Showers and thunderstorms will accompany this frontal passage. The 
SPC keeps east TN, southwest VA, and southwest NC in general 
thunder, however, a few strong storms cannot be entirely ruled out. 
Soundings are saturated through the morning, so there will be 
significant cloud cover and scattered showers in the warm sector 
holding temps several degrees lower than Sunday. The morning showers 
appear tied to a pre-frontal trough associated with weakening 
upstream convection. If storms can redevelop in the early afternoon, 
0-6 km unidirectional shear of 40-45 kts, 0-1 km shear around 20 
kts, mid level lapse rates above 7 C/km, PWAT values increasing to 
around 1 inch, and low wet bulb zero heights of 7000-8000 ft could 
allow for hail and strong winds with any more organized cells. CAPE 
values will only reach a few hundred j/kg which will limit the 
strength and coverage of the stronger storms, so there may be quite 
a few cells with small, pea sized hail and gusty winds instead of 
severe sized hail. Additionally, the NAM has persistently showed low 
level winds veering to westerly early in the day which will limit 
convergence needed for a widespread line to develop in the afternoon 
behind the morning showers. Added showers and thunderstorms to the 
grids Monday with chance pops in the morning increasing to likely 
after 15Z. 

Overall, we think that there will be fairly widespread
showers with embedded thunder from mid morning through the 
afternoon, but only a few are likely to become stronger with small
hail and wind gusts over 40 mph being the main threats. The
greatest chance for a stronger storm will be along and south of
I-40 in the 17-22Z timeframe.

The cold front will move east of the region Monday night with chance 
pops for scattered showers lingering in eastern areas through 06Z 
Tuesday. Lows Monday night will be much cooler in the CAA pattern as 
another deep trough carves out across the eastern U.S.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Sunday)...

Tuesday the shortwave trough will begin to move off the east coast 
while an additional shortwave moves toward the Tennessee valley.  At 
the surface, high pressure moves out of the Great Lakes into the 
Ohio valley.  Northerly low level flow will keep thermal profiles 
cooler with cold air advection.  Highs on Tuesday will likely stay 
in the 50's which is much cooler then previous daytime highs.  A 
weak pressure trough along the Smokies will likely aid in light 
precipitation along the higher terrain. Otherwise, dry air and 
subsidence should bring partly cloudy skies to the rest of the 
forecast area.  

Wednesday through Friday will be under the influence of upper level 
ridging and height rises.  Surface high pressure will move eastward 
with time and will begin to bring lower tropospheric flow toward the 
southeast.  This will advect a warmer airmass with increasing 
temperatures.  Highs Wednesday through Thursday will likely top out 
in the low to mid 60's, with upper 60's to near 70 by Friday.  Lows 
Wednesday night and thursday night will be in the low to mid 40's.  

The upper level ridge will begin to break down by the weekend with 
an upper level trough diving out of the Rockies.  This will bring 
southwest flow aloft and an increase in mid to upper level moisture. 
 Models begin to diverge with time over the weekend in respect to 
the strength of the trough and surface reflection.  It is likely 
that surface pressure falls, and developing cyclogenesis will occur 
east of the Rockies Thursday into Friday with a frontal boundary 
attendant this low. The latest GFS shows a more progressive front 
which is in better agreement with the EURO. Thus while confidence in 
this period is low, will keep low end PoPs over the weekend. 
Temperatures will likely be near to above average for the weekend.

342 PM EDT Sat Mar 23 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Sunday)...
Dew points have remained very dry this afternoon with many lower 
elevation areas staying in the low to mid 20's. A few AWOS sites 
have had upper teens. Luckily winds have been very light underneath 
the surface high with generally 3 to 8 knot north to northeast flow. 
Subsidence from this high has aided in these lower dew points even 
though the source region upstream had higher dew points this 
morning. 

Heights will begin to rise tonight as an H5 trough develops in the 
Plains with a surface low moving in that vicinity. This system will 
move eastward on Sunday while higher heights hold over the TN valley 
as the surface high settles off the mid Atlantic coast. This pattern 
will yield WAA across east TN, southwest VA, and southwest NC 
beginning tonight and lasting through Sunday.

Expect low temps tonight to average a couple of degrees warmer than 
last night. A 10-20 kt southwesterly 850-700 mb jet will begin to 
transport warmer and more moist air into the region after 06Z, and 
projected soundings from the latest NAM12 show some mid level 
moisening as the night goes on which should result in mid to high 
level clouds increasing. These factors will lead to the milder night 
with no frost concerns. Stayed close to MAV guidance for lows. 

Warm, moist advection will continue Sunday with midlevel RH 
increasing through the day. This will lead to partly sunny to mostly 
cloudy skies, but a warm day is in store with mid to upper 60's in 
much of the valley and some low 70's likely near CHA. A 50+ knot 300 
mb jet streak moving overhead late in the afternoon or early in the 
evening could generate scattered showers well ahead of the synoptic 
cold front, so introduced slight chance pops between 21Z Sunday and 
00Z Monday. Leaned toward the slightly warmer MAV guidance for highs.


.LONG TERM...(Sunday night through Saturday)...
The long range period will feature a disturbance Monday with 
showers and thunderstorms, while the mid to late week features 
increased temperatures and dry weather. Sunday night, a 
disturbance will traverse the area. Models are not in great 
agreement in how this system progress with the NAM indicating the 
lead shortwave across the Ohio valley leading a secondary wave 
moving through the Southeast. The EURO indicates a more phased 
system with one shortwave trough as it moves through the Tennessee
valley. The GFS is aligned more with the EURO with one shortwave.
This will likely have implications on timing of the frontal 
passage and best coverage of showers and thunderstorms on Monday. 
The surface reflection features an area of low pressure across the
Ohio valley that will move into southern Appalachians by Monday 
night. 

A cold front attendant this surface low will move through the area 
on Monday, although as mentioned above, timing is still uncertain. 
This front will likely begin to wash out as it makes its passage 
through the area limiting convergence along the front.  The warm 
sector airmass characterized by moisture and instability, albeit 
weak, will lead to widespread coverage of shower activity early on 
Monday. Isolated to scattered thunderstorms are possible along the 
front where weak instability exists.  A couple of limiting factors 
for widespread coverage of thunderstorms is the mid-level flow 
displaced further south, and weak frontal convergence.  Will be 
watching the Monday system closely for any changes, as some small 
hail could occur in any stronger storms as wetbulb zero heights are 
low, in the 6 to 7 kft range. However confidence is low in organized 
severe weather.

Rain will end from west to east Monday night into Tuesday with the 
exit of the shortwave trough and cold front.  Northwest flow aloft 
should provide at least some lift in the form of orographically 
enhanced flow to provide a focus for continued precipitation chances 
for the higher terrain along the plateau, and Smoky Mountains. 
Surface high pressure will build into the Ohio valley Tuesday 
providing a northerly surface flow.  This should keep conditions 
cooler Monday night and Tuesday with highs on Tuesday in the 50's.
 
The main story for the mid to late week period is the increase in 
temperatures. Upper level heights will be on the rise with high 
pressure located off shore the mid-Atlantic providing a southerly 
fetch near the surface and lower troposphere.  Drier weather with 
highs in the 60's to near 70 degrees are likely with lows in the 40 
to 50's. Another system will begin to approach the area by Friday 
and Saturday. Details are still very uncertain in regards to the 
synoptic pattern but it seems an amplification in the upper levels 
will provide a deep trough across the western US, with ridging 
across the East. For now decided to follow a CMC and EURO blend as 
these seem to be in better agreement. Later forecasts will refine 
these large scale uncertainties.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Winds have stayed up overnight, which has prevented temps from 
falling as expected. Thus the Frost Advisory for the southern TN 
Valley does not appear close to panning out, so it will be 
cancelled.

Surface high pressure and ridging aloft will continue to build over 
the area today, providing sunny skies and lighter winds than 
yesterday. With afternoon highs in the 60s for most locations, we 
will see afternoon RH values in the 20s. With winds expected to be 
less than 10 mph, no Fire Danger Statement is needed but will 
highlight the low RH in the Fire Weather Forecast product. High to 
midlevel cloud cover will begin to increase tonight as the mid/upper 
ridge axis moves to our east.

.LONG TERM...(Sunday through Friday)... 
Main system of interest is a short-wave moving across the Ohio 
and Tennessee Valleys on Monday. Timing of this system and 
position of low pressure are crucial with significant differences 
between models. There is a potential of strong to severe weather 
for Tennessee and southwest North Carolina but most align closer 
to the ECMWF solution. Lets get to the particulars.

For Sunday, surface ridging will be east of the Appalachians with 
return southerly flow beginning to pull moisture back into the 
Tennessee Valley. Some residual showers will move into the area, but 
lift is weak so only widely scattered.

For Sunday night and Monday, increasing jet dynamics and isentropic 
lift will produce an area of showers that will move into the region 
by early Monday morning. This area will move east with a break in 
the convection possible before increasing destabilizion and incoming 
frontal boundary produces another round of showers and thunderstorms.
Again, models differ on the degree on instability but freezing 
heights will once again be low. Will need to monitor Monday 
afternoon for the potential of severe weather.

For Monday night/early Tuesday morning, short-wave will move east of 
the area along with shower activity. The GFS does suggest the 
potential of upslope into the western Carolinas that could produce 
some showers Tuesday but confidence low.

For Wednesday and Thursday, ridging both surface and aloft will 
produce dry conditions with a warming trend. Some return moisture 
for Friday producing a slight chance of showers, but overall dry and 
warm.

FXUS64 KMRX 221949
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
349 PM EDT Fri Mar 22 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Saturday)...
The enhanced fire danger across the southern valley and southwest NC 
will quickly subside early this evening as the 15-25 knot wind gusts 
being seen this afternoon die down and RH values increase. 

Despite temperatures running a little below normal, very nice early 
spring weather is expected in the short term. As an H5 trough in the 
eastern U.S. slowly retreats to the east, surface high pressure of 
Canadian origin will continue to build into east TN, southwest VA, 
and southwest NC from the northwest tonight. This will allow winds 
to diminish rapidly after sunset, and with the subsidence bringing 
clear skies, it will be a good radiational cooling night. Widespread 
lows in the upper 20's are a good bet across the Plateau, northern 
valley, northeast TN, and southwest VA with low to mid 30's across 
the central and southern valley and southwest NC. Leaned toward the 
MET guidance for lows. The frost/freeze program started last weekend 
across the southern valley counties, so issued a Frost Advisory for 
these areas from 07 through 13Z. Added the widespread frost mention 
to the grids for these areas too. 

The surface high will be nearly overhead Saturday, so expect a 
beautiful start to the weekend with mainly sunny skies and light 
winds. The flow aloft will still be NW, but highs will rebound after 
the cold morning into the mid to upper 50's across northeast TN and 
southwest VA with upper 50's to low 60's farther south. The 
increasing late March sun angle combined with nearly full insulation 
will make it feel pleasant outside. Used the slightly cooler MET 
guidance for highs.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday night through Friday)...
The longterm period will feature one system of interest on Monday
with the chance of showers and thunderstorms. Otherwise, a 
warming trend is expected mid to late week. Saturday night, the 
upper level pattern will feature broad troughing across eastern 
Canada and New England while a closed low will be located across 
the central plains. Further upstream, near zonal flow is forecast 
across the Southwest United States. The surface reflection 
features an area of low pressure lee of the Rockies across Kansas 
and Oklahoma, and high pressure across the Ohio valley and mid-
Atlantic. 

Sunday, the 500mb low will begin to become absorbed in the cyclonic 
flow across the Midwest while the upper level flow across the 
southern and central plains flattens.  Upstream, a large cyclone 
will begin to move closer to the Pacific Northwest.  This upper 
level configuration supports west to southwest flow aloft across the 
southeast Sunday into Sunday night.  At the surface, the area of low 
pressure will begin to fill as it progresses eastward into the 
Midwest.  An associated cold front will extend south of this surface 
low through Arkansas, and into eastern Texas.  The surface high will 
continue to move offshore providing a southern trajectory with Gulf 
of Mexico origins.  This will advect a warm and moist airmass into 
the region.  Area point soundings indicate a well mixed atmosphere 
Sunday afternoon with surface temperatures possibly warming into the 
mid to upper 60's.  Lack of forcing, and inversion aloft will keep 
any convection at bay, leading to a dry forecast for Sunday.

By Monday, models begin to diverge in placement of low pressure 
feature, and time of arrival with the frontal zone. However, what is 
in better agreement is the shortwave trough at this point, embedded 
in cyclonic flow, will traverse the Ohio and Tennessee valley Monday 
with the associated low pressure. This low will track just to the 
north of the forecast area. Southerly flow ahead of the front will 
support a warm sector airmass advecting into the area characterized 
by surface dewpoints in the low to mid 50's.  This overall warm air 
advection pattern across the warm sector will result in an increase 
in shower and thunderstorm activity across most of the area. Point 
forecast soundings show limited CAPE profiles with better 
instability south of the forecast area where greater boundary layer 
moisture resides. Overall kinematics and shear look weak at this 
time, with 0-6km shear generally less than 40 knots. Further given 
the westerly wind component, a downstream pressure trough develops 
lee of the Smokies that will inhibit some of the convergence 
associated with the primary frontal boundary. This is common in 
these situations and limits overall severe thunderstorm threat. Went 
with slight chance to chance thunder across most of the forecast 
area to account for the limited instability and lift, but it seems 
that widespread thunderstorms seem unlikely at this time.  Given the 
uncertainties, have left out the mention of strong to severe wording 
in the HWO, but will keep watching over the weekend.  

The cold front shifts eastward by Tuesday with rain ending from west 
to east.  Residual moisture left over along the mountains along with 
orographically induced lift from northwest flow aloft presents 
chances of precipitation into Tuesday before much drier air moves 
in.  Highs Tuesday will reach the mid to upper 50's in a weak cold 
air advection pattern. The coldest night of the extended looks to be 
on Tuesday night with temperatures in the low 30's to near 40 
degrees. The mid week features upper level height rises Tuesday 
night through Friday associated with an amplified pattern with 
stronger troughing across southeast Canada. This results in 
increasing temperatures through the week with drier weather.  Highs 
Wednesday and Thursday will reach the mid to upper 60's while lows 
only in the low 40's to low 50's.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
The primary concerns for the short term are winds and relative
humidity. Winds will be gusty today as high pressure builds in
from the west and a low tracks north along the Mid-Atlantic coast.
In this NW flow regime the strongest winds tend to be to our east
in NC, and winds in the NE TN mountains today are expected to be 
close to but just below Advisory criteria, with sustained winds of
15-25 mph and gusts of 30-40 mph. 

Afternoon min RH values are expected to be in the 30-40% range 
for most of the area, with southern sections dropping to 25-30% as
there will be less cloud cover there. This along with gusty winds
will create some fire weather concerns this afternoon. Will 
coordinate with forestry personel this morning to assess the need 
for a Fire Danger Statement. 

Cloud cover across much of the area will be decreasing through the
morning, mainly from south to north. With mostly sunny skies, the
southern half should be able to reach high temps in the lower to
mid 60s, with broken to overcast clouds in the north hangning in 
until the afternoon, and keeping highs in the 50s. 

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Friday)...
Main system of interest through the extended period is a short-
wave moving across the Ohio/Tennnessee Valleys Sunday night 
through Monday night. The GFS and ECMWF are continuing to align 
with a potential severe weather event, especially for the southern
half of the Tennessee Valley. No for the particulars.

For Saturday and Saturday night, ridging both surface aloft will 
produce dry conditions. Increasing high and mid level clouds by 
early Sunday morning. Main concern will be the continued low 
afternoon relative humidity with readings dropping into the 20s and 
30s.

For Sunday, surface ridge has moved east of the Appalachians with 
some return southerly flow producing isentropic lift maily over the 
Plateau areas. Scattered showers are anticipated. A milder day is on
tap as well. 

For Sunday night and Monday, A short-wave will move into the Ohio 
and Tennessee Valleys with jet dynamics placing the region under 
divergence aloft. The jet structure will enhance fronto-genetic 
forcing along an approaching frontal boundary for Monday. Increasing 
southerly boundary layer jet will pull moisture back into the 
Tennessee valley helping to increase CAPEs to 500-1000 J/Kg. 
Increasing shear ahead of the wave along with the instability could 
set the stage for strong to severe storms. Will continue to 
highlight this potential in the Hazardous Weather Outlook.

For Monday night and Tuesday morning, short-wave and boundary moves 
east and southeast of the area with showers coming to and end.

For Tuesday night through Thursday, strong surface and upper ridging 
will return the dry conditions. Low afternoon relative humidity will 
once again be a concern. Cool mid-week, but warmer temperatures 
expected by the end of the week.

FXUS64 KMRX 211914

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
314 PM EDT Thu Mar 21 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Friday)...Colder air will be pushing in 
overnight as the axis of the short wave upper trough and the cold 
front exit to the east. There will continue to be some showers in 
the cold advection especially in upslope areas, and over the higher 
terrain there will be some snow showers especially first part of 
tonight.  Still looks like some light snow accumulations can be 
expected across the highest terrain, especially at elevations above 
4000 feet.  Will continue the SPS talking about this.  Clouds will 
be decreasing from southwest to northeast during the period, but the 
clearing trend is expected to be slow. Winds will be gusty from the 
west and northwest on Friday, especially in the eastern mountains. 
However, it looks to be borderline for a wind advisory in these 
higher elevation areas so will not issue one at this time. Will 
mention in HWO.

.LONG TERM...(Friday night through Thursday)...The Spring season
is definitely here as temperatures look to be on a roller 
coaster ride for the long-term. We begin Friday night with surface
high pressure sliding down from the northwest as an H5 trough 
lingers over the eastern U.S. downstream of an H5 ridge building 
in the Plains. This will lead to dry but chilly conditions Friday 
night and Saturday with below normal temperatures across our 
entire region. Despite the cool temperatures, subsidence 
underneath the high should lead to mostly sunny skies Saturday, 
and the increasing late March sun angle will make for a pretty 
nice day. The surface high and H5 trough will shift eastward 
Saturday night as the large ridge moves from the Plains into the 
Tennessee and Ohio Valleys. This will set up a WAA pattern, and by
Sunday, the surface high will be over the western Atlantic with 
the H5 ridge over the eastern U.S. and developing H5 trough and 
surface low in the Plains. This will lead to much milder 
conditions on Sunday with temps rising above normal thanks to the 
WAA bringing air up from the Gulf coast region. The cold front 
associated with the system in the Plains and Midwest should remain
to our west on Sunday leading to another mainly dry day except 
for some widely scattered showers. Only have slight chance pops 
Sunday afternoon.

This will be the system of interest in the long-term period. Recent 
runs of the GFS and ECMWF have come into better agreement that this 
system will phase with a vortex in southeast Canada by Monday with 
at least a moderately strong surface low moving across the Ohio 
valley dragging a strong cold front across east TN, southwest VA, 
and southwest NC by Monday night. After this fropa, another deep 
upper level trough will carve out across the eastern U.S. sending 
temps back to below normal.

For the details of this system, the low tracking north and west of 
our region and the entrance region of an upper jet streak close to 
the Tennessee Valley will likely bring enough moisture, instability, 
and lift for convection Monday into Monday night ahead of the cold 
fropa. Severe storms are a possibility, but the details of the 
amount of instability and shear available still need to be worked 
out. The ECMWF and GFS show several hundred j/kg of surface based 
CAPE and 20-30 kts of west to southwesterly 0-1 km AGL shear Monday 
afternoon and evening, so the low level wind field will be strong. A 
30 kt west-southwesterly low level jet should transport 1 to 1.5 
inch PWAT values into our area during this time as well. For now 
just added thunder to the grids Monday into Monday night with chance 
pops Monday morning becoming likely Monday afternoon through the 
first half of the night decreasing to chance or slight chance toward 
Tuesday morning. 

Cooler and drier Tuesday as upper trough and surface high build into 
the region. Could see a snow shower or flurry in the highest
