FXUS64 KMRX 210744
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
344 AM EDT Thu Mar 21 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today through Friday)...

An interesting short-term forecast with two short-waves moving
across the Tennessee Valley and southern Appalachians today and
early Friday. 

First wave is currently over northern Alabama/ 
southern middle Tennessee. This wave does have upper level jet
energy/dynamics producing divergence aloft over the area. Main
limitation is moisture. Surface ridging into the Gulf has greatly
limited moisture return. This short-wave will have little effect
over the region.

More significant short-wave upper trough will move from the
southern Great Lakes into the central/southern Appalachians by
this afternoon and night. Plenty of cold air aloft is associated
with this upper trough with freezing levels dropping to 4kft or
lower. Upper jet will pull into southwest Virginia/northeast
Tennessee this afternoon producing dynamics for scattered to
widespread showers. Greatest coverage will be generally along and
north of interstate 40. Would not be surprised of isolated thunder
as well. Given the low freezing heights and sufficient Hail CAPE,
some pea size hail/graupel is possible with the stronger updrafts.

The tightening pressure gradient associated with the second
short-wave will produce gusty winds this afternoon and evening,
especially near showers.

Temperature profile also support rain changing to snow/sleet over
the highest elevations, generally at or above 4kft. The highest
mountains, such as the Smoky and Roane, could see 1 to 2 inches.
Highway 441 could become snow/ice covered late today and
overnight. Will include in Hazaroudous Weather Outlook and Special
Weather Statement.

Drier air will move back into the region from southwest to
northeast Tonight through Friday allowing for a return of
decreasing clouds. Pressure gradients will remain tight enough
Friday to produce breezy conditions, especially over the far east
Tennessee Mountains.

.LONG TERM...(Friday Night through Wednesday Night)...
The extended fcst period tips off on Friday evening amidst nwly flow 
across the TN Valley and Southern Appalachians, all while H5 heights 
look to rise from the west as a full latitude ridge axis amplifies 
and advects east across the Plains.  At the surface, cold high 
pressure will be diving southward atop the Midwest, eventually into 
the OH/TN Valleys Friday night.  At fcst initialization, any 
previous nw flow induced precipitation should have ceased leading 
into a dry but cool weekend.  A back door cold front looks to surge 
into the region overnight into Saturday ahead of the aforementioned 
sprawling surface high, which anchors itself over the OH Valley by 
midday Saturday.  

Meanwhile, models continue to favor lee cyclogenesis over KS/OK, 
which should induce a zone of baroclinicity over the Lower MS 
Valley.  Further pattern evolution into Sunday will feature a 
transitioning of the OH Valley surface anticyclone atop the 
Appalachians, setting up over the western Atlantic offshore of the 
Carolina coast allowing for a reopening of the GOM and thus waa 
across the southeast states.  From that point forward, the focus 
shifts to the Plains H5 cyclone and it's eventual evolution/track 
across the Central/East CONUS. Guidance has been a bit divergent in 
days past, but things seem to be coming a little more clear as now 
the ECMWF/GFS favor a phasing of this H5 cyclone with the northern 
stream flow around a large upper vortex over Canada.  This vortex 
will deepen and migrate southward, engulfing much of the Eastern 
half of the country in upper troughing to start the work week. The 
00Z runs of the GFS/ECMWF now both favor an open upper low and 
surface wave traversing eastward atop IN/OH Sunday night into Monday 
with a cold fropa sweeping across the TN Valley and into the 
Southern Appalachians mid/late day Monday. These solutions could 
present a convectively active Monday to Monday night period, with 
storm modes and hazards being dependent on further details that 
aren't yet clear.  Stay Tuned!

Otherwise, some residual moisture could be left behind post fropa 
into Tuesday amidst nwly caa, thus a brief period of RA/SN showers 
looks plausible (SN mainly at the highest elevations).  To round out 
the fcst period, another reinforcing cold front is progged to move 
into the region Tuesday into Wednesday, with a sprawling cold/dry 
high pressure airmass to accompany.  This should keep conditions 
cool/dry through midweek next week.  Temperatures through the period 
will be quite variable given a series of cold fropas, generally 
starting out slightly below normal Saturday, warming to above normal 
for Sunday/Monday amidst strengthening waa, then falling back to 
below normal Tuesday and Wednesday behind the primary cold fropa.

details and for now will trend the forecast towards a compromise 
between the two models.  Models continue to diverge for Wednesday. 
The GFS wants to move the system out for generally dry conditions. 
The slower ECMWF bringing the upper low through for a continue 
active pattern on Wednesday. With low confidence...will introduce 
some low POPs over northern areas as a compromise.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
344 AM EDT Wed Mar 20 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today through Thursday Night)...
A ridge of high pressure will remain across the southern
Appalachians and southeast United States producing another dry and
mild day. Main concern will remain the low afternoon relative
humidity. 

For Tonight, A short-wave trough will move into the Ohio and
Tennessee Valleys with upper jet structure enhancing the forcing
over the area. Main limitation will be boundary layer moisture
initially as surface ridging will keep Gulf moisture south of the
area.

For Thursday and Thursday night, upper trough will continue to
deepen over the central and southern Appalachians with freezing
levels dropping to 3-4kft. The strongest upper forcing will be
generally along and north of interstate 40 which is closer to
proximity of the upper low. Enough moisture gets wrapped into the
low with low-level CAPES increasing to 100-300 J/Kg. Enough
instability to produce widespread showers with the threat of pea
size hail with the stronger showers due to the low freezing
heights.

Also, the vertical temperature profile will be cold enough to
include a mixture of snow, sleet, and freezing rain over the
highest elevations of the far east Tennessee and southwest
Virginia Mountains, generally at or above 4kft. Light snow and ice
accumulations are expected, so highway 441 may become slick.

Orographic lift will kick in during the day Thursday and
especially Thursday night/Friday morning. This will keep a wintry
mix going for the favored northwest flow areas.

Even though Spring officially starts today, Thursday through
Friday will feel more like winter, especially over the higher
terrain.

.LONG TERM...(Friday Through Tuesday Night)...
The extended range fcst period kicks off on Friday morning amidst 
moist nwly flow across the Southern Appalachians behind a departing 
trough and associated cold front. Critical thicknesses amongst deep 
caa should favor falling snow levels supportive of light snow/sleet 
across portions of the east TN and southwest VA high terrain, likely 
already ongoing at fcst initialization.  By Friday afternoon/evening 
moisture levels tend to taper, thus any residual precipitation 
should cease.  Not expecting any significant snowfall accums, 
generally less than an inch.

Moving into Saturday, H5 heights will rise as a nearly full latitude 
ridge axis builds across the Plains, and advects east with time.  At 
the surface, cold/dry high pressure will slide southeast through the 
Midwest into the OH/TN Valley, setting up atop the Central 
Appalachians by Saturday evening.  However that will be short lived 
as the ridge continues sliding east over the Carolinas by Sunday 
morning.  Meanwhile, southern stream lee cyclogenesis looks to 
commence/amplify over KS yielding a zone of baroclinicity across the 
Plains and MS Valley, all while a deep northern stream upper vortex 
slides southward across Central Canada.  

Although still with some minor timing differences, guidance tends to 
agree on a wet pattern to start the new work week. Generally it 
looks as if the broad region of surface high pressure will slide 
further east over the western Atlantic allowing for the return of a 
waa regime across the Southeast CONUS.  Meanwhile according to the 
GFS, the two aforementioned cyclones (northern/southern streams) 
phase and drive a cold front across the region Monday into Tuesday. 
On the other hand, the ECMWF doesn't favor any phasing and promotes 
a stronger positively tilted upper trough to sweep through the 
region Tuesday afternoon.  Details such as potential instability and 
shear remain unclear, but think chances for a convectively active 
fropa are modest, especially with the ECMWF solution. Behind the 
fropa into midweek, conditions look cold and dry.

Valleys Wendesday night, while the left exit region of an upper 
jetmax moves along the I10 corridor region of GA/FL promoting 
surface cyclogenesis along the Carolina coastline. By midday 
Thursday, the primary shortwave axis should be crossing the 
Appalachians setting up deep nwly flow atop the region, while the 
East Coast Cyclone races north toward New England.  As for impacts 
associated with this wave across the TN Valley and Southern 
Appalachians, profiles ahead of the system suggest a rather dry 
airmass given minimal preceding return flow. However, the wave 
itself does look to advect modest midlevel moisture into the region 
on Wendesday night, sufficient to support showers.  Likewise, on 
Thursday amidst the developing nwly flow, cannot rule out some 
residual focusing of light precipitation along the favored upslope 
regions, possibly with a few light snow showers at the highest 
elevations of east TN and southwest VA into Friday morning as snow 
levels fall, before all precipitation moves out.  

Beyond that moving into Friday, sharp and nearly full latitude H5 
ridging sets up across the Central CONUS, while the Eastern CONUS 
trough slowly shifts east.  Rising heights into Saturday will be 
accompanied by another region of dry high pressure advecting 
southward across the OH Valley into Central/Southern Appalachians. 
On Sunday the upper ridge begins to deamplify as troughing deepens 
and moves east setting up a zone of baroclinicity over the Plains 
and MS Valley, as well as a return to weak sly waa across the 
southeast. At this range guidance tends to diverge a bit with regard 
to the details, but it looks like a deepening H5 low will initiate 
surface cyclogenesis across the Midsouth in that late Sunday to 
early Monday timeframe, with a potent frontal passage and associated 
convection to traverse across the TN Valley Monday evening into 
Tuesday.

As for temperatures throughout the period, expecting at or below 
normal levels to dominate through the remainder of the work week. As 
the aforementioned upper ridge builds into the region on Saturday 
and weak waa initiates on Sunday, moderation should commence allowing 
temperatures to return to and exceed normal levels by periods end.

afternoon.

By Thursday night light northerly winds will cause another day of 
temperatures generally rising from the 30s to near 40 to the 50s and 
60s as drier air settles back into the forecast area. A high 
amplified pattern sets up quickly as another potent trough digs over 
the Intermountain West. The resulting ridge will help pump up our 
temperatures in strong southerly flow. Consequently, rising low 
level moisture will also increase through Saturday night. While it 
is still at the end of the forecast period, it is worth noting that 
showers and thunderstorms will be possible on Sunday 
afternoon/evening.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Monday)...

In the upper levels, there is a rather broad upper level trough 
across the Eastern CONUS. At the low levels, there is a cold front 
located to the north and west of the forecast area. The atmosphere 
is rather dry with PW values currently around a quarter of an inch 
with mostly sunny skies. Temperatures have warmed rather quickly 
today with the dry atmosphere in place. The cold front will move 
across the forecast area later this evening into the overnight hours 
as a a shortwave trough rotates from the western Great Lakes into 
the Ohio River Valley. The cold air advection behind the front is 
rather impressive with 850 mb temperatures dropping down into the -8 
to -5 degrees Celsius range across northeast Tennessee and southwest 
Virginia. Some of the models indicate enough moisture with the 
trough passing to the north for a few flurries/sprinkles across the 
higher elevations of southwest Virginia and northeast Tennessee. 
Lows tonight will drop below freezing for most of the area except 
for the southern valley. Winds behind the boundary should remain 
elevated enough to prevent any widespread frost formation. Monday 
will be another sunny but cooler day behind the frontal boundary. 
Highs will only top out in the upper 40s to low 50s.

.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Sunday)...

High pressure in place to our west to start the period on Monday 
night. A shortwave will have moved through earlier in the day. 
Behind this wave, some cold air will settle into the area 
overnight. Monday night lows will be the coldest of the period 
with temps down into the upper 20s to lower 30s. If the trends 
hold, a freeze warning may eventually be needed for the southern 
valley areas that have been activated in the frost/freeze program.

High pressure remains in place to our west through Tuesday which 
keeps us in northerly flow. This allows the airmass to stay dry with 
continued below normal temps. Winds will be light during the day 
with RH values in the low to mid 30s. Highs will be in the low to 
mid 50s with clear skies. By Tuesday night a shortwave trough is 
swinging down into the central plains and begins to displace the 
area of high pressure to our west. Wednesday should be mostly dry 
during the day but increasing clouds are expected as the system 
draws closer. Models in decent agreement that precip doesn't arrive 
until the overnight hours and exits through the day on Thursday. 
Highs on Wednesday will be slightly warmer as we transition from a 
weak northerly flow to a more westerly flow in the lower levels. 
Highs will be in the low to upper 50s. 

The negatively tilted trough swings into the region on Wednesday 
night. Moisture isn't abundant but there is plenty of lift to 
produce some light showers as the system swings through. The 
vorticity is quite strong due to the orientation of structure of the 
trough. Strong vorticity combined with the polar and southern stream 
jet phasing together as it swings through will provide good lift. 
Again though, moisture is on the weaker side so showers will be 
light and scattered in nature. The shortwave moves off to our east 
during the afternoon on Thursday but some light showers may remain 
on the backside of the system if there is enough moisture. POPs 
during the Wednesday night through Thursday timeframe will be on the 
low end.

Ridging builds back into the area from the west on Thursday night 
and Friday and conditions improve. Ridging further builds into the 
area through the rest of the period with gradually warming 
temperatures. By the weekend, temps are back closer to normal with 
highs in the low to mid 60s and overnight lows in the low to mid 
40s. Our next system begins to move into the area on Sunday night.

widespread freezing temps.  Then by Wednesday as the high slides 
east, the an anemic return flow sets up with a westerly component

elevated moisture that will warrant "chance" POPs, but very light 
QPF. Also, looks like the timing will not favor any frozen precip 
for this shortwave. Looks like a complete turnaround from the soggy 
patterns of the past many weeks. By late in the period, a shortwave 
ridge is expected to build in, with the warmest temps of the whole 
seven days.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
255 AM EDT Sat Mar 16 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
The upper pattern this morning is highlighted by a passing upper 
trough axis across the Appalachians, while quasizonal flow sets up 
atop the TN Valley between said trough and a broad region of H5 
ridging over the Southern GOM.  At the surface, a dry cold front 
continues to advect through east TN and southwest VA/NC ahead of an 
approaching region of high pressure.  With that, PGFs remain 
somewhat elevated along/behind the boundary, which will promote 
sustained low end gusting of winds through late morning.  Otherwise, 
a jetmax associated with the passing shortwave embedded within the 
longwave trough continues to slide east this morning, which combined 
with enhanced llv moisture has favored development/advection of low 
stratus.  Said sky cover is expected to erode toward daybreak, 
leading into a partly cloudy to mostly sunny day for the region. 
Likewise, abundant insolation will favor modest diurnal warming with 
max temperatures topping out a few degree below normal thanks to the 
cold fropa.  

Mostly clear skies and light/calm winds combined with 
the cool high pressure airmass will set the stage for a cold night 
tonight.  Temperatures across the region will fall into the 
mid/upper 20s over southwest VA and the northern valley/plateau, 
with slightly warmer low/mid 30s favored southward across southwest 
NC and the southern valley/plateau.  As of today the front/freeze 
program has been activated across the southern valley/plateau, thus 
a freeze warning may be needed tonight for these areas.  Given that 
fcst min temperatures are currently borderline, will defer to the 
day shift for any freeze warning issuance.  Otherwise, some patchy 
frost cannot be ruled out for outlying areas as well.

.LONG TERM...(Sunday through Friday night)...
The extended begins with upper-level troughing across the eastern 
half of the country and surface high pressure across the Tennessee 
Valley. A strong shortwave will dive southeast from the Northern 
Plains to the Ohio Valley during the day on Sunday with a 
strengthening W-E oriented upper jet across the Central 
Appalachians. Concurrently, a surface low will move across the Ohio 
Valley toward the Mid-Atlantic with a trailing cold front. Ahead of 
this front, boundary layer winds will shift from the NW to the W 
allowing some neutral or slight WAA Sunday afternoon near 850mb. 
With poor moisture return ahead of this system, expect little, if 
any, precipitation associated with the front on Sunday evening. The 
front will quickly pass through the region early Sunday night with 
winds shifting back to the NW allowing CAA across the Southern 
Appalachians and Tennessee Valley. The NW winds will produce 
orographic lift across the western slopes of the Appalachians and 
may produce some very light precipitation with any remaining 
moisture across higher elevations of northeast Tennessee and 
southwest Virginia. With temperatures forecast to be cold enough to 
support frozen precipitation across the higher elevations, may have 
some light snow showers or flurries. Forecast soundings show the 
post-frontal saturated layer to be between about -3C and -8C, so 
this will limit dendrite potential and lead to some rime ice issues 
across the higher terrain. Overall, with very little moisture to 
work with, expect little to no snow accumulation even across the 
highest peaks. With longwave troughing and mainly neutral or CAA, 
temperatures are expected to be about 5 degrees below normal Sunday.

CAA continues on Monday as dry NW/NNW flow dominates the weather 
pattern. The good news is that clear skies and late March sunshine 
is expected which can help warm things up, or at least counteract 
the strong CAA, this time of year. Temperatures will be near 10 
degrees below normal. Surface high pressure centers over the area on 
Monday night and Tuesday morning with very cold temperatures 
forecast. Expect widespread frost and freeze issues, especially 
where the growing season is near its beginning across the southern 
valley.

Trough shifts east on Tuesday with zonal flow developing across the 
region ahead of the next system. Numerical model guidance continues 
to have difficulties with run to run consistency with how to handle 
the shortwave energy, but are in general agreement with the overall 
pattern. A shortwave trough will drop south from the Northern Plains 
toward the Tennessee Valley with a strengthening upper jet across 
the Tennessee Valley. A surface low and trailing cold front is 
predicted to move across the Mid-Mississippi Valley eastward toward 
the Southern Appalachians on Wednesday afternoon as it becomes 
occluded. As mentioned previously, there are run to run consistency 
issues with guidance, so uncertainty is still high with regard to 
the shortwave strength and phasing which will impact the strength 
and timing of this system. This front moves east on Thursday with 
high pressure moving in from the west. Upper-level ridging is 
forecast to develop across the Central CONUS and build eastward on 
Friday which appears to start a warming trend at the end of the 
period. Overall, the extended period is mainly dry which will help 
the entire area continue to recover from recent anomalous rainfall.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
336 AM EDT Fri Mar 15 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
The upper pattern this morning is highlighted by a sharp ridge over 
the Western Atlantic, while a deep trough with embedded shortwave 
impulses dominates over the Plains and MS/OH Valleys.  At the 
surface, the first of two cold fronts continues to work eastward 
across Middle TN this morning, while a second reinforcing front 
moves through Upper Midwest.  Currently, prefrontal convection 
prevails across east TN and southwest VA/NC in association with a 
region of divergence aloft beneath the rear entrance region of an 
upper jet.  This feature (and the consequent convection) will 
continue advecting east/northeast through morning, thus current pops 
trends favor a maxima of likely/categorical levels moving across the 
high terrain by daybreak, then tapering below mentionable levels. 

Behind the initial front, profiles will dry out as abundant mid 
level moisture advects east, and drier/cooler high pressure attempts 
to nose in from the west.  Thus the fcst through much of the day 
will feature only partly cloudy skies and temperatures generally in 
the upper 50s to lower 60s.  Profiles also support ample mixing 
today, which combined with modest llv flow upward of around 40kts, 
could yield a windy day at the surface with gusts in the 30-35mph 
range possible. These levels are just below advisory criteria, 
therefore no advisory is planned at this time.  Lastly, the 
aforementioned secondary reinforcing front will approach the region 
beneath/behind a shortwave impulse that will pass across the OH 
Valley into the Central Appalachians by late evening.  With that, 
guidance favors a surge of H85 moisture from the northwest, 
therefore the overnight forecast will feature increasing cloudiness 
and falling temperatures as the dry cold front moves through the 
region into Saturday morning. Expect morning lows on Saturday in the 
low/mid 30s, perhaps in the upper 20s across the higher terrain.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Thursday night)...
Behind the departing cold front, CAA continues on Saturday with 
boundary layer winds from the N/NW. Upper-level troughing remains 
over the eastern half of the country through the weekend with high 
pressure shifting east over our area Saturday night. This will 
result in a clear sky and calm winds making Saturday night and 
Sunday morning our coldest night of the weekend with a widespread 
freeze across the area. Based on climate normals, our median last 
freeze for CHA is March 31, for TYS is April 4, and for TRI is April 
19, so it's not abnormal to be dealing with these cold temperatures 
in mid to late March. As high pressure shifts to the east on Sunday, 
some weak WAA will occur during the afternoon with temperatures a 
few degrees warmer than on Saturday. Temperatures will be about 10 
degrees below normal through the weekend with the troughing pattern 
and predominant northerly flow.

A strong shortwave will rotate through the longwave trough on Sunday 
night diving south through the Great Lakes toward the Central 
Appalachians. This will deepen the upper-level trough and bring a 
fast moving surface low southeastward across the Ohio Valley toward 
the Atlantic Coast. A trailing cold front will result in a 
reinforcing shot of cold air as 850mb winds shift to the NW at 15 to 
25 kt behind the front early Monday morning. With flow from the W 
ahead of the front, very little moisture return is expected, so do 
not expect widespread precipitation. Do expect we could have some 
orographically enhanced precipitation across the mountains of 
northeast Tennessee and southwest Virginia as the upslope flow helps 
to maximize any remaining available moisture. It will be cold enough 
to support some light snow showers or flurries in these higher 
elevations Monday morning, but moisture is so limited that little to 
no accumulation would be expected, even across the highest peaks.

Northerly flow continues on Monday and Tuesday with temperatures 
again close to 10 degrees below normal as longwave troughing 
dominates the Eastern CONUS weather pattern. High pressure at the 
surface will keep us dry and will settle over the area on Tuesday 
night into Wednesday morning bringing another clear, calm, and cold 
night. Widespread frost/freeze potential will exist again on both 
Monday night and Tuesday night. CIPS analog guidance shows above a 
90% chance of minimum temperatures below 32 deg F across most of the 
forecast area early next week. Numerical model guidance is in good 
agreement through Tuesday night/Wednesday. 

Model guidance diverges on Thursday in how the GFS and ECMWF handle 
shortwave energy transiting the longwave trough. The ECMWF is much 
more progressive and deeper with the longwave trough compared to the 
GFS, and the Canadian is an outlier with a deep upper low. However, 
both continue to show a weak system affecting the region on 
Wednesday night through Thursday. Ridging across the Central CONUS 
begins to build eastward into our area toward the end of the week.

National Weather Service Morristown TN
251 PM EDT Thu Mar 14 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Friday)...
Storms with supercell structure have been increasing across N AL
and Middle TN over the past hour. The short term models indicate
that the environmental shear and instability will remain 
supportive of supercells, and the RAP shows strengthening 
mesoscale forcing as storms move into our area. 

The period of the greatest severe threat will be between 7 pm and
midnight. Damaging winds with be the main threat with the storms,
and tornadoes will also be possible given the high shear and low 
LCL environment. The Plateau and southern TN Valley will be the 
areas of greatest concern for tornadoes. The eastern half of the 
area will still have a threat of straight line winds but storms 
should generally be weakening after moving past Knoxville, which 
should occur around 10 pm to midnight. 

The eastward progress of the cold front begins to slow late
tonight, and the models show the front hanging up along the
mountains tomorrow morning as the mid/upper flow parallels the
front. Will keep a chance of showers along the eastern border
through the morning, then end all rain chances in the afternoon as
a more amplified upper trough approaches and pushes the front
east. 

The Wind Advisory will be extended to 03Z in the Plateau, and
until 06Z in the Smokies. 

.LONG TERM...(Friday night through Thursday)...
Cooler weather will be in place over the weekend after the front 
has passed through the area. Temperatures will run about 10 
degrees cooler on Saturday compared to Friday. Temperatures will 
remain below average as mid level flow remains zonal to slightly 
"troughy" (that's probably not a real word). 

GFS continues to insist that a weak clipper system will zip across 
north of the Tennessee Valley Monday. Currently it is the only model 
consistently showing this. Will keep an eye out for this, but with 
the GFS being the outlier, and even then with moisture expected to 
be meager and it barely showing QPF in our area, will leave 
mentionable precipitation chances out of the forecast for now. If 
this system did materialize, Northeast Tennessee and Southwest 
Virginia would have the highest chance to see precipitation from it. 

Better chances for precipitation will come during the second half of 
the week, around Thursday. Models are in very poor agreement with 
this system, so confidence is very low at this time. Both GFS and 
ECMWF show a trough swinging through the area, but the GFS kicks 
through a much stronger one while the ECMWF wants to keep a broader 
and weaker one, and keep the Eastern Tennessee Valley Dry. Will have 
low end chances of precipitation in the forecast, but the forecast 
may likely change as models hopefully get into better agreement.

FXUS64 KMRX 140813
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
413 AM EDT Thu Mar 14 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
A large upper trough is located across the Central CONUS this
morning with a stacked, occluded surface low. A cold front 
extends north to south near the Mississippi River. As the 
vertically stacked low shifts NE toward the Great Lakes, the cold 
front will shift slowly eastward during the day. The LLJ will 
strengthen during the day with S/SSW 850mb winds near 50 kt across
the area. As the boundary layer mixes out in the afternoon and 
the warm front shifts northward, expect to see breezy conditions 
across the entire area. Wind Advisory criteria wind gusts above 40
mph will be expected across the higher elevations of the 
mountains and higher elevations of the Cumberland Plateau, so 
expanded the advisory in these areas. Surface winds from the S/SE 
will lead to upslope conditions across the southern Cumberland 
Plateau with increased convergence and showery activity possible 
through the day. In contrast, downslope flow will prevail across 
the foothills and central and northern valley locations which will
keep dry weather, more sunshine, and warmer temperatures across 
these locations. For this reason, bumped up temperatures between 
TYS and TRI to reflect the effects of the downslope flow. Weak PVA
and stronger WAA between the surface and the boundary layer 
during the afternoon will result in upper-level height falls and 
increased instability by evening as the front approaches.

Tonight, the cold front will be the focus for likely convection 
and will approach western portions of the CWA after 0z. We will be
in an area of diffluence aloft associated with a 300mb jet streak
across the Ohio Valley. With the majority of lift focused 
directly along the frontal boundary, expect a narrow band of rain 
and thunderstorms along this axis. Numerical model guidance shows 
increasing surface based instability between 0z and 6z as positive
equivalent potential temperature advection occurs, and this 
places the majority of surface based instability generally along 
and west of a line from Claiborne, Union, Knox, and Sevier 
Counties. NAM and GFS forecast soundings both show 200 to 500 J/kg
of MLCAPE during this time period. In addition, the LLJ remains 
strong with 850mb winds near 50 kt. Deep layer flow above the 
boundary layer is mainly unidirectional from about 240 deg which 
will intersect the frontal boundary at about 30 deg. These factors will
favor primarily QLCS convection. With the strong LLJ, wind shear 
is very strong. Forecast soundings show: 1) effective storm layer 
shear at 50 to 60 kt; 2) effective inflow layer shear of 40 to 50 
kt; 3) 0-1km shear of about 40 kt; and 4) effective SRH of 300 to 
400 m2s2. These values, combined with the QLCS favored storm mode,
mean damaging winds will be the primary threat from strong to 
severe thunderstorms between 0z and 6z Friday. However, because of
the strong low-level shear and surface based instability, cannot 
rule out a tornado or two within the line across the western parts
of the CWA. Because of the weak instability, hail does not appear
to be a main threat. This forecast matches up very closely with 
CIPS analog guidance which shows the potential for damaging winds,
and a much lower chance of tornadoes, across the western and 
southern parts of the forecast area based on similar past events.
The main mitigating factor will be the low instability, and if 
surface based instability does not increase as forecast, the 
severe threat will be much lower. As for the heavy rain potential, PW
values will increase to 1.3 to 1.5 inches ahead of the front with
the moist S/SW flow which is bewteen the 95th to 99th percentile 
of climatology. Because of the limited duration of potential 
heavy rainfall, any flash flood threat is marginal.

As fropa occurs between to 6z-10z, rain chances diminish as we 
approach 12z Friday. Some showers may continue across the eastern 
mountains and foothills before ending Friday morning.

.LONG TERM...(Friday through Thursday)...
A few lingering showers can be expected especially eastern 
portions of the area on Friday with the exiting cold front, then 
drier and colder air will be pushing in as surface high pressure 
builds in from the west and northwest. The remainder of the period
for Saturday through Wednesday looks to be mainly dry with 
temperatures running below seasonal normals for the entire period.
Models, especially the GFS, have been trying to bring the 
possibility of isolated to scattered light showers/snow showers to
the area at some point with some weak short wave energy, but even
the GFS has trended drier so for now will go with a precip free 
forecast for the period other than the aforementioned Friday 
morning showers.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight through Thursday)...
Surface high pressure is now east of us, allowing southerly return 
flow to start.  Deep low pressure in the Plains and its associated 
cold front will be heading eastward, continuing to increase our low 
level southerly flow. Winds might be advisory level on the plateau 
and up through parts of the valley Thursday as southwest winds 
increase, but looks like glancing blow as fastest low level jet goes 
to NNE with its core staying west of us.  Will hold off issuing 
advisory for now. Chances of showers will be increasing as well, 
with chances for storms later on Thursday afternoon for western 
areas.  Best precip chances will be into the next period.  

Dewpoints  slow to recover this afternoon, partly based on the fact 
that return flow is sluggish to get started in the mid and upper 
valley.  Have trimmed back dewpoints for the remainder of the 
afternoon, but they should catch up once winds start up again.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday night through Wednesday)...
Showers and thunderstorms will be knocking on the door of the 
Eastern Tennessee Valley Thursday night. There will be a few weather 
items of note as this system continues to move through the area 
Thursday evening into Friday. Thunderstorms will likely be ongoing 
across Middle Tennessee and try to move into the Valley Thursday 
evening/night. CAPE values will be very meager, but the low level 
jet coming out of the south/southwest along this system will help 
bring in high 0-6km shear values of 40-50+ knots. Timing of this 
system is not very good for strong storm development as it tries to 
come through after the sun has set. But if strong enough storms are 
able to form further west of the area they could remain together 
long enough to pose a marginal risk of damaging winds along the 
Cumberland Plateau and western portions of the Valley. 

Models are still in some disagreement on when the band of 
precipitation along and ahead of the front will move through. NAM is 
the most sluggish with this precip and leaves areas of NE 
Tennessee/SW Virginia pretty dry into Friday morning. Some hints in 
the models that the influence of downsloping winds will be stronger 
than previously forecasted, so have bumped down PoPs a bit in 
locations that typically see the downsloping influence the 
strongest. 

The previously mentioned low level jet will also bring strong winds 
to the higher elevations Thursday into Thursday night. While the 
wind direction is not exactly perpendicular to the Southern 
Appalachian Mountains the strong winds of in the low level jet of 
40+ knots will lead to high winds regardless. Will hold off on a 
high wind watch as the orientation of the winds aren't ideal for a 
high wind warning, but it's very possible that we may see wind 
advisory winds in the higher elevations into the foothills Thursday 
into Thursday night.

After this system exits the area on Friday we'll see dry conditions 
through the rest of the weekend. GFS wants to bring through a ripple 
of moisture/energy Sunday into Monday across NE Tennessee/SW 
Virginia. But it's currently an outlier, so will keep low end PoP 
chances for now, but confidence is low in this for now. 

Quiet weather will continue through the rest of the forecast with 
another low/trough expected to move across the Eastern half of the 
United States during the second half of the work week.

will shift eastward on Wednesday placing our area under southwest

instability aloft this morning providing the mid-level clouds;

deg F warmer on Wednesday. With SE flow near 925 to 850 mb of 
about 10 to 15 kt during the afternoon, also expect some downslope
warming across the foothills and NE TN and SW VA with locally 
higher temperatures.

Southwest winds continue to increase in response to the tightening
pressure gradient tonight. This will continue to advect warmer 
and more moist air across the region. Lift will increase as PVA 
and low-level WAA provide for some weak lift and slight chance 
PoPs across western portions of the forecast area late tonight.

expected to be light. Increasing boundary layer S/SE flow will 
keep much of the foothills and central and northern valley dry 
with downslope winds, but upslope winds along the southern plateau
will increase chances for rain showers and fog as we approach 
Thursday morning.

are some differences in the details, and forecast confidence is 
close to average for this time of year. A cold front will swing

Friday. Models have trended a bit slower with this system, but 
still expect some showers to enter at least western portions of

southerly low level jet strengthens. Confidence not high enough to
issue a high wind watch at this point since wind directions looks
borderline, but definitely will keep mention in the HWO. 

After any lingering showers move out Friday, colder and drier air 
will push in and much of the remainder of the long term period will 
be dry with below normal temperatures. There is a possibility that 
some short wave energy will bring a few showers or snow showers to 
the area at some point although timing is uncertain. Right now 
Sunday night looks the most likely time frame for any precipitation, 
so will include slight chance PoPs to account for this.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
334 PM EDT Tue Mar 12 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight through Wednesday)...
Benign weather will continue the rest of today and through
tomorrow across the area. Increased mid level ridging, light 
southerly winds are both helping to bring temperatures up a few
degrees warmer than yesterday. High level clouds are moving across
the area, but they are pretty shallow so aren't doing much to keep
back the warmer temperatures. 

Conditions won't change much overnight as with the exception for
some additional mid level moisture moving in from the west leading
to a slight increase in mid-level cloud coverage and helping 
temperatures stay warmer than last night and generally above 
freezing across the East Tennessee Valley. 

During the daytime hours tomorrow conditions will continue to
remain persistent. Temperatures will increase a bit as mid level
ridging slightly strengthens and stronger winds move out of the
south ahead of an approaching system. Temperatures are expected to
be a few degrees above normal for this time of year.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday night through Tuesday)...
The main forecast item of note in the long term will be the incoming 
front for Thursday into Friday. Otherwise the long term period is 
shaping up to be a decent one, with cooler than normal temperatures 
but a nice dry period expected to round out the Friday - Monday time 
period. Actually, though beyond the scope of our 7 day forecast, dry 
weather may actually persist through much of next week which would 
be a welcome sight for those still dealing with high water.

Jumping back to Thursday, a cold front will be approaching from the 
west late in the day. Wednesday night and Thursday morning should be 
dry for most everyone, but rain chances will slowly ramp up through 
the the day Thu as the front approaches from the west. By the time 
this feature is moving through middle Tennessee however, upper and 
mid level flow will become parallel to the frontal boundary, leading 
to a slowing forward speed. The significance of this revolves around 
thunderstorm activity along/ahead of the front. This slower speed 
may lead to shower and thunderstorm activity not arriving until 
Thursday night. There will be some elevated instability so will keep 
a slight chance of thunder in the forecast Thursday evening and 
Thursday night. But the later arrival time of convection will likely 
mean that surface-based won't be as much of a concern. Instability 
is limited to begin with so the main concern would be for the ample 
amount of shear available to be utilized in producing damaging 
winds. In any case the main area of concern for any storms will be 
in the south and west, primarily south of areas like Bledsoe over to 
McMinn county. Will stick with the previous shift's wording in the 
HWO regarding the storm potential.

The other item of note with Thursday's front is downsloping winds 
ahead of the system. Temperatures should warm considerably on 
Thursday, with highs likely reaching into the low 70s for many 
valley locations due to this flow. Does not look like a prime 
mountain wave setup due primarily to low level wind fields not being 
quite perpendicular to the terrain, so do not have high winds 
extending down into the foothills area. But enough mixing and 
downslope flow should be present to warm things up nicely in the 
valley, as well as produce some high winds in the elevated terrain. 
Again, will continue with the same wording in the HWO that the 
overnight shift added in.

By Friday morning the front is east of the Appalachians. Clouds will 
be a little slow to clear out as the main trough axis will not swing 
through until Saturday. There may even be a few showers lingering 
around in the mountains into Saturday morning, but overall dry 
weather will be setting in from Friday through the end of the 
period. After a warm Thursday, cooler than normal temperatures will 
be ensue, but still expect highs in the 50s to near 60 by the end of 
the period.

issues in areas of poor drainage.

will arrive Friday afternoon into Saturday. Highs on Friday will

.DISCUSSION...

A much warmer and drier air mass is moving into the forecast area
behind last nights frontal boundary. Strong southwesterly flow 
today will lead to much of the changing weather. Temperatures look

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
412 AM EDT Sun Mar 10 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...The weak cold front moving 
through the region will exit our area to the east today.  May be a 
lingering shower early over eastern areas, but most areas will be 
dry for the entire short term period as surface high pressure to our 
northwest builds in.  The lower clouds will exit, but there will be 
an increase in high clouds during the period.  However, still should 
be considerable sunshine today with above normal temperatures.  The 
high wind warning will be allowed to expire as mountain wave 
enhancement is ending.   

.LONG TERM...(Monday through Saturday)... Quiet pattern to start 
extended forecast period with high pressure moving toward the 
Tennessee Valley and centered to the northwest Monday. Upper level
flow is zonal Monday then ridging aloft ahead of upper level low 
that spins off the southwest US coast brings warmer temperatures 
at mid week. The deep trough associated with this upper low moves 
into the south central states Wednesday. As the system deepens and
the parent deep surface low moves into the northern plains A warm
front is expected to develop across the eastern Tennessee Valley 
bringing up warm moist air from the Gulf of Mexico. A chance of 
thunderstorms Thursday and Thursday night ahead the cold front. 
Temperatures will be much above normal in the upper 60s to lower 
70s. Also a heavy rain threat Thursday night and early Friday 
ahead of the front. Friday and Saturday temperatures will be 
cooler with highs Saturday only in the upper 40s to lower 50s and 
a slight chance of showers.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
600 PM EST Sat Mar 9 2019

.DISCUSSION...Quick update to replace wind advisory across a few
of the mountain zones with a high wind warning. Guidance continues
to suggest that the highest peaks will see gusts in the 60 to 65
mph range as a very strong 850mb jet will be in place this
evening. Also made some updates to hourly POPs to match up with
latest HRRR and RUC trends. Made some adjustments to hourly temps
as well, kept temperatures elevated longer overnight due to the
strong jet in place. Warmed temps along the foothills as current
obs are showing evidence of downsloping winds. GKT came in at 70
degrees with the 5 PM observation. Rest of the forecast still
looks on track. 

Instability gradient remains to our southwest, across northern
Alabama, so any storms approaching our area should weaken as they
draw closer. Having said that, shear is still quite impressive and
a few strong to possibly severe storms aren't out of the question
for areas such as Marion, Sequatchie, and Hamilton county as they
are the closest to the instability gradient. We have already
observed a few strong/severe storms approach the aforementioned
areas from out of the Huntsville area and weaken significantly by
the time they get to the TN/AL/GA line.

101 
FXUS64 KMRX 092017
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
317 PM EST Sat Mar 9 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Sunday)...

A shallow layer of saturated air persists over much of the southern 
region of the forecast area with a dry layer aloft. This is keeping 
the low clouds in place as a wedge of cold air over the eastern 
mountains is preventing the warm front to our south from progressing 
northward. This is also leading to less isentropic lifting over the 
valley than originally thought so rain has been less prevalent 
today. With the cold front out to the west continuing to track 
eastward, a slightly more unstable airmass will move in later this 
afternoon to help lift the ceilings across much of the southern 
counties of the forecast area.

As the frontal boundary moves into eastern Tennessee, the winds will 
pick up a bit in the valley, while a decent downsloping event is 
expected for the Smokey mountains and eastern foothills. While not 
the traditional setup for this kind of event, models are indicating 
overnight wind gusts of up to 55 mph or more. Some areas of the 
Cumberland plateau could also see close to wind advisory criteria, 
although the high wind event will be mostly be restricted to the 
eastern mountains. With the onset of the front, some areas could see 
periods of heavy precipitation and the occasional thunderstorm is 
possible with local rain totals of up to an inch. Current CAPE 
values are too low for any severe thunderstorms and most of the 
severe weather should stay to the west of the Cumberland plateau. 
Temperatures tomorrow will be pleasant despite the passage of the 
cold front due to lack of any decent cold air advection and 
increased INSOLATION from the clearing skies.

.LONG TERM...(Sunday night through Saturday)...

The extended will begin in a rather quiet and tranquil weather 
pattern. Surface high pressure tracking through and centered to 
our north will be the dominant weather feature. Flow aloft will 
begin fairly zonal and slowing shift towards a ridge. This will 
allow Sunday night through Tuesday to remain dry with seasonal to 
a bit above normal high temperatures. Wednesday will be a 
transition day with a warm front approaching the area. Associated 
light showers will move in Wednesday night as low level moisture 
increases and weak lift develops over the region. The cold front 
will push in on Thursday. This will bring of line of convection 
across the Southern Appalachian Region Thursday afternoon and 
evening. The air mass should become at least weakly unstable for a
chance of a few thunderstorms. The frontal boundary will continue
to affect local weather into Friday with continued scattered 
showers. As the system slowly pulls away from the area Friday 
night into Saturday...wrap around light precip could linger over 
far northern locations and over upslope areas of the east TN 
mountains.

National Weather Service Morristown TN
1236 PM EST Sat Mar 9 2019

.AVIATION...

While conditions have stubbornly remained IFR or LIFR for both 
CHA and TYS all morning, the fog is expected to lift over the next
few hours as the warm front to the south moves slightly more 
northward. Confidence is marginal as to the timing of the fog 
lifting, as it was originally thought it would have lifted over an
hour ago. A shallow layer of very saturated air is in place over 
both CHA and TYS with dry air aloft, which is keeping the moisture
locked in place.

With the incoming cold front to the west, we will move a slightly 
more unstable environment by this afternoon with showers moving in
for the early evening. Conditions are expected to become 
predominantly MVFR overnight with a few brief possible periods of 
IFR from any stronger showers on station. A few thunderstorms for 
both CHA and TYS are possible from the initial onset of the front,
although current CAPE values are low enough that no severe storms
are expected.

.DISCUSSION...

Another rainy day today with low ceilings and morning fog for some
areas. While the fog will lift later this morning, the low clouds
will remain in place for most of the day for the more southern and
central regions of the forecast area. Temperatures will rise
throughout the day from the warm air advection as the warm front

for most of the day, with wind speeds picking up later this

downsloping winds for the mountains and foothills in far eastern
Tennessee can be expected later today.

FXUS64 KMRX 090828
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
328 AM EST Sat Mar 9 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...The warm frontal boundary to our 
south will lift north today and early tonight, followed by a cold 
front pushing in from the west late tonight. There will be some 
showers around today, especially southern half, but these should be 
isolated to scattered for the most part.  Later in the day showers 
can be expected to increase ahead of the cold front across western 
areas, with a band of convection moving across the entire area 
overnight.  Enough elevated instability is expected to keep thunder 
in the forecast this afternoon into tonight, although the convective 
energy will be limited. With the strong low level jet, will also 
need to keep the mention of a few strong to severe storms in the HWO 
although the overall threat of severe weather still looks limited. 
There also appears to be potential for some mountain wave 
enhancement to the wind in the usual spots along the usual higher 
elevation/foothills areas of the E TN mountains this afternoon into 
tonight.  While showing some potential, model soundings do not look 
ideal for mountain waves at the moment, so will just go with a wind 
advisory for now. However, minor changes in vertical profiles of 
temp/wind may lead to a need to upgrade at least parts of the wind 
advisory to a warning later. 

.LONG TERM...(Sunday through Friday)... A cold front will be 
moving through the extreme eastern and northeastern section of the
forecast area with showers bringing the last few hours of 
rainfall. The mild temperatures early Sunday...upper 40s to mid 
50s will give the area an early start to warmer temperatures. 
Clouds are expected to decrease rapidly and winds stay southwest 
until late in the day when they switch to the west then northwest 
at night. Bumped highs a couple more degrees up as guidance is 
showing upper 60s northeast to lower to mid 70s in the central and
southern valley. Highs may still be a little cool. Cold air 
advection with this high pressure area does not really affect 
temperatures until Sunday evening. High pressure centered in the 
Plains states will move over the Ohio and Tennessee valleys Sunday
night and continue over this region Monday and Tuesday. Skies 
will be mostly clear to partly cloudy. Lows early Monday through 
Wednesday will stay near normal in the 30s to mid 40s. Highs will 
also stay near to slightly above normal as the upper flow is zonal
for the Monday to tuesday time frame and then slight ridging 
Wednesday. Another strong system develops over the Plains states 
similar to the system departing early Sunday on Wednesday. Winds 
shift to the south and southeast then increase ahead of this 
system. Another couple inches of rain is possible with a chance 
for thunderstorms Thursday and Thursday night. Much warmer lows 
Thursday and Friday with clouds and rain and continued mild highs 
mostly in the 60s.

690 
FXUS64 KMRX 082006
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
306 PM EST Fri Mar 8 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Saturday Night)...

Numerous showers across the southern Appalchians early this 
afternoon with an E-W stationary surface boundary located just to 
the south of the area. In the upper levels, there is a weak trough 
and jet streak moving through the Appalachians currently with a more 
amplified ridge back to the west stretching from the Lower 
Mississippi River Valley northwards into the western Great Lakes. 
Models also indicate a slight surge in the low level jet across the 
area currently with 850 mb winds around 30-35 kts. Low level 
isentropic lift to the north of the boundary is also adding to the 
lift to produce numerous showers across the region. Also have the 
chance for a few rumbles of thunder this afternoon for the southern 
tier of counties or so with MUCAPE values around 250-500 J/Kg. 
Temperatures have slowly warmed today with the blanket of cloud 
cover but with the warm advection, highs are expected to range from 
the low 40s to low 50s later this afternoon. 

For tonight, the axis of rainfall shifts further to the south and 
expect best chances will be south of I-40 closer to the surface 
boundary. Low level isentropic ascent will persist but as the trough 
and jet exit to the east, model soundings indicate that the upper 
level and mid-levels begin to dry out. Expect coverage will begin to 
decrease overnight but with the saturation in low levels have added 
fog and drizzle to the forecast. The upper level ridge will move in 
overnight also leading to lower precip chances with higher heights 
aloft. Temperatures will begin to warm late tonight into early 
Saturday as the upper level ridge axis moves to the east of the area 
and the front lifts northwards. Low temperatures will range from the 
upper 30s to upper 40s. 

On Saturday, a negatively tilted upper level trough moves into the 
Mid-Mississippi River Valley. Southwesterly flow will increase ahead 
of this approaching system as moisture advects northward with PW 
values climbing into the 1.0-1.3 inch range. The best lift and 
moisture looks to arrive later in the day and have cut back PoPs a 
good bit Saturday morning. Surface high pressure to the northeast 
will lead to a wedge on the eastern side of the mountains. This 
wedge will hinder the warm fronts progression to the north and east. 
The evolution of the warm sector will be key to if any strong to 
severe storms develop across the area. Some of the models indicate 
that the warm sector moves into the area late in the afternoon with 
maybe a few strong to marginally severe storms possible late 
tomorrow afternoon into the evening hours. Other models want to keep 
this boundary along and just to the south of the area and pinch off 
the warm sector as the cold front moves in from the west. In this 
scenario, would not expect much in the way of strong to severe 
storms. The timing of the frontal passage is also not overly 
favorable for strong to severe storms. For now, will keep the 
mention in the HWO but regardless, it looks like a low end threat. 
Storm total rainfall amounts will not be too high only around half 
an inch to one and half inches. These values are fairly low but with 
the record rainfall in February, there could be a few areas of 
localized flooding, especially in areas of poor drainage. 

Southerly winds will increase ahead of the approaching system late 
Saturday into Sunday morning and have issued a High Wind Watch for 
the Smoky Mountain. The setup favors a mountain wave type event with 
strong winds across the higher elevations and foothills. May need to 
extend or upgrade the watch during later forecast issuances. 

.LONG TERM...(Sunday through Friday)...

A few showers will linger over the area...especially over eastern
locations...Saturday evening as an ongoing weather system pulls 
out of the area. Surface high pressure builds in on Sunday with 
zonal flow aloft slowly moving into weak ridging early into the 
work week. This will result in a fairly quiet weather pattern with
dry conditions and seasonal to warm temperatures Sunday through 
Tuesday. A warm front will lift through the area on Wednesday. The
main lift and moisture with this feature should stay to our west 
but expect enough over the area for at least isolated showers. The
associated cold front will move in around the Thursday/Friday 
time frame...and bring in our best chance of showers and even a 
few thunderstorms for the extended period.

forecast with increasing probability Wednesday into Thursday, when
another strong frontal system is expected to move across the

but colder air will build back into the area on Monday and 
Tuesday, followed by a nice warming southerly flow as the next 
storm system approaches.

958 
FXUS64 KMRX 070918
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
418 AM EST Thu Mar 7 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today through Friday)...
Another cold morning today across the southern Appalachians and
east Tennessee Valley. Temperatures are in the lower 20s to around
30 across the region. Some high and mid level clouds are spreading
over the area from the northwest early this morning. Surface high
pressure now overhead shifts to the east coast by this evening. 
The cloud cover will gradually thicken and lower as a weak cold 
front approaches late today. Rain will develop late tonight along 
the front with temperatures slowly warming. A little light 
freezing or frozen precipitation possible late tonight before 
temperatures warm above freezing. Friday temperatures should be 
close to todays lower 40s across the higher elevations ...but up 
to lower 50s lower elevations. Rainfall Friday should average 
about 0.5 to 1 inch with the heaviest in southeast Tennessee.

.LONG TERM...(Friday night through Thursday)...
On Friday night the region will lie beneath low amplitude 
cyclonic upper flow, with increasing heights just to our west in 
response to a strong system ejecting from the southern Rockies 
into the plains. Surface features across the eastern US during 
this time will include the center of a roughly 1030mb sfc high 
pressure center exiting the Atlantic coastline somewhere between 
DC and New York, as well as a quasi stationary frontal boundary 
anchored along the leading edge of a wedge front near the southern
end of the Appalachians, likely immediately south of our forecast
area. Despite the relative increase in upper heights nearby, low 
and mid level isentropic ascent across the previously mentioned 
boundary will be in place locally, with fairly high chances for 
widespread rain south of the I-40 corridor where upglide will be 
maximized. Expect a few rumbles of thunder to occur through the 
late Friday evening time frame as well, as model soundings show 
some meager elevated instability. How far north the rain will make
it/linger during the overnight hours Friday night into Saturday 
morning is somewhat uncertain since lift is maximized near the 
Georgia border. Have PoPs generally decreasing across the northern
tier counties to account for this, but will leave in some 20-30 
PoPs overnight into Saturday morning since guidance doesn't signal
a slam dunk dry period up there.

On Saturday the strong southern Rockies disturbance ejects into the 
central to southern plains. Associated cyclogenesis will take place 
over the central plains, with a deepening surface low rapidly 
shifting from central Kansas around daybreak Saturday to the Great 
Lakes region by Sunday morning. Locally the aforementioned 
stationary boundary to our south will be pulled north during the 
afternoon and evening hours. Widespread showers will develop along 
this boundary as it shifts north during the day Saturday but the 
best rain chances will be Saturday evening/night as the cold front 
approaches from the west. The question remains, what if any severe 
threat will exist in our CWA. Instability and diurnal trends look to 
be the limiting factors for any severe threat locally. That being 
said, there is plenty of shear to work with. Should instability be 
stronger than forecast, I could easily see a scenario where storms 
area able to bring to the surface some strong winds aloft. Forecast 
soundings for Chattanooga show 55-60kt within 3k ft AGL by midnight 
Saturday night for instance. The main area of concern would be the 
southern plateau and TN valley areas. There are still some details, 
most notably timing and what the effects of/how widespread daytime 
convection will be, to iron out before getting overly excited about 
any severe storms in eastern TN. One last thing to mention about Sat 
night and early Sun morning would be winds at higher elevations. 
Guidance is insistent on strong low level winds during that time 
frame. Cross-barrier flow no longer looks ideal for mountain wave 
activity, but gusts at higher elevations could easily rise into the 
50-60 mph range. 

Moving on, Sunday looks to be a nice day. We should see the cold 
front push east of the mountains by daybreak or shortly thereafter. 
Some lingering showers may still be present in the southern TN 
mountains or western NC counties. But much of the area looks to be 
dry. Not only will it be dry, but the influx of dry air will lead to 
a substantial mixed layer on Sunday. That and the lack of strong 
cold air advection should allow the forecast area to warm well into 
the 60s. 

For Sunday night onward confidence is low. Models diverge quickly 
after Sunday morning with respect to the evolution of the upper 
level pattern. Indications are that Monday and Tuesday will be dry, 
and do have some chance PoPs to wind out the period on Wednesday. 
But overall confidence is rather low on how things will unfold.

FXUS64 KMRX 061936

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
236 PM EST Wed Mar 6 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Thursday)...
Quite weather will continue today as mid level northwest flow and
surface ridging combine to keep temperatures below normal. One
more night of sub freezing temperatures across the area tonight
with lows expected to dip into the 20's and the teens in the
higher elevation. Increasing moisture from the northwest will
begin to move in overnight into tomorrow causing an increase in
cloud coverage. Most locations will remain mostly sunny tomorrow,
but clouds could limit overnight lows and highs tomorrow
afternoon.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday night through Wednesday)...
The start of the long term period will see zonal upper level flow
across most of the eastern United States, with a weak disturbance
across the northern plains, and midwest. Further upstream, weak 
ridging is forecast across the Rockies. The weak disturbance 
should induce weak lee cyclogenesis east of the Rockies with an 
area of low pressure moving across the south and central plains 
Friday. This will strengthen southerly flow and warm air 
advection. As a result of weak overrunning, showers are likely to 
develop along the low level front. Some of the initial 
precipitation could fall in the form of rain/snow or sleet before 
the low levels warm above freezing. Sufficient moisture in the 
column as indicated by pwats upwards of 1.2 to 1.3 inches, along 
with deep layer theta-e advection will allow for periods of 
precipitation, with some heavy at times. The limiting factor will 
be the lower freezing level heights, which could limit warm rain 
processes. 

The lifting warm front will set up a warm sector air mass across the 
forecast area Saturday evening as upper level heights respond to 
deepening of a trough across the west.  As a result, better 
amplification of upper level heights will bring upper level ridging 
on Friday night and Saturday morning.  However, continuing 
isentropic ascent with reduced condensation pressure deficits should 
at least be sufficient for scattered showers across the area 
saturday morning.  The lead shortwave will begin to deepen and take 
on a negative tilt Saturday morning with strong cyclogenesis taking 
place lee of the Rockies.  This results in increased amplification 
and southerly flow.  The surface low deepens as it progresses 
through the midwest indicative of the strength of thermal advection. 
 A cold front associated with this low will move through the 
Midsouth as early as Saturday afternoon and reach the MRX CWA late 
Saturday night.  Precipitation is expected along this front with 
thunderstorms a good possibility at this time.  Severe weather 
potential is to low to mention at this time.  This mornings guidance 
really shunts the better instability further south as a result of 
the occlusion process, and timing of the front.  However, deep layer 
lift will be quite strong across most of the area which should 
result in at least elevated thunderstorms.  The degree of moisture 
and deep layer ascent should also present chances of heavy rainfall 
as well.  Will highlight these in the HWO, but changes to this period 
of the forecast are possible as conditions further west will have 
large implications on the forecast across this area.  

Another hazard to mention is higher winds across the higher 
elevations.  This will result from a strong low level jet nearing 60 
knots.  There are some model disagreements in wind direction, which 
is common this far out.  The GFS has a better southerly flow 
component with the EURO showing a more parallel mountain flow.  Not 
too confident on mountain waves, however it seems reasonable that 
strong winds could be found across the higher elevations.  This will 
also be highlighted in the HWO. Precipitation will begin to exit the 
area Sunday with a much drier airmass moving in.  Surface high 
pressure drops south into the Great Lakes and Ohio valley Sunday 
into Tuesday with high amplification in upper level heights with 
riding across the east, and deep layer troughing across the west. 
This will result in a much drier air mass. Wednesday, continued 
amplified upper flow could lead to a large disturbance beginning to 
impact the region. For now too many synoptic scale differences exist 
to have much confidence on any one solution.  For now will leave 
chance PoPs in the forecast.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
337 AM EST Wed Mar 6 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
In the near term, an area of scattered snow showers/flurries is
moving across Wise, Lee, and Russell counties of southwest
Virginia. This area of snow is poorly handled by models, but is
due to relatively steep low-level lapse rates (low level
instability) and boundary layer moisture. Snow accumulations of
1/2 to 1 inch are possible, especially across High Knob. Have
issued a SPS to account for expected impacts of snow/ice covered
roadways. This area of snow will move east of the area soon after
daybreak.

Wind chills of 0 to -10 will continue over the higher terrain of
the far east Tennessee Mountains. Will continue advisory through
mid-morning.

For the remainder of Today and Tonight, dry northwest/west flow
and surface ridging will be the main weather features. Dry and
unseasonably cold conditions will remain. Very dry afternoon
relative humdity can be anticipated today and Thursday.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Wednesday)...
Dry conditions will be seen on Thursday as the region lies beneath 
zonal upper flow aloft, weak ridging in the mid levels, and a dry 
high pressure center at the surface. Temperatures will remain below 
normal on Thursday as well thanks largely to another cold night to 
round out the short term period. With only a modest increase in 
cloud cover during the day Thursday, and substantial dry air in 
place, we should drop back down into the 30s most everywhere 
Thursday night. Meanwhile a disturbance will be approaching from the 
west late Thursday night into Friday morning. Model soundings show 
sufficient moistening to support precipitation reaching the ground 
by a few hours after midnight Thu. They also show wetbulb zero 
heights near the surface for a few hours after precip onset, 
suggesting that at least some degree of mixed precip will be seen. 
Will continue to show just a mix of rain/snow for late Thu night 
through around daybreak Fri. Some sleet or freezing rain could occur 
too, but given the uncertainties with whether precipitation will 
arrive soon enough to take advantage of the colder temperatures, and 
the subsequent duration of any mixed precipitation, decided to keep 
it simple. Additionally, it is unlikely any notable accumulations 
will occur so impacts should be minimal in that regard.

Temps rise above freezing quickly on Friday ending any talk of 
frozen precip. Rain also expands on Friday morning, with a chance of 
thunder entering the forecast by mid morning as ascent across a warm 
frontal boundary in the region is enough for parcels to take 
advantage of elevated instability. Per model soundings any thunder 
should mostly be confined to the first half of the day, as PoPs and 
elevated instability both decrease in the afternoon and evening 
hours. Though on a downward trend, do have some PoPs continuing 
during the overnight hours Friday night (mainly in the south). Would 
not be surprised to see a distinct lack of rainfall though as upper 
heights build overhead in response to the strong system entering the 
plains on Saturday. 

A negatively tilted upper trough will shift across the southern 
plains and into the Ozarks during the day Saturday. Convection will 
develop ahead of the associated cold front as it shifts east across 
the southern states during the afternoon and evening hours. Expect 
storms to move in from the west during the evening hours. Low level 
jet influence could provide some degree of downslope winds ahead of 
the convection Saturday evening, though directionally speaking 
conditions won't be ideal. However the combination of strong winds 
at ridge top levels, strong gradient flow across the region, and 
convective mixing with storms, will likely produce windy conditions 
across the CWA Saturday evening and Saturday night. As far as severe 
chances go locally, details are a bit uncertain at this time. There 
appears to be at least a mentionable chance of damaging winds if for 
nothing else than some storms being able to mix down very strong low 
level winds. But beyond that it is difficult to say at this time.

Dry weather with very warm temperatures, highs approaching 70 in 
some cases, will round out the weekend, followed by a return to more 
normal temperatures by Monday.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
308 PM EST Tue Mar 5 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Wednesday)...
An amplified upper trough highlights the synoptic pattern across the 
East/Central CONUS this afternoon, while a shortwave impulse moves 
through the mean flow aloft.  High pressure at the surface continues 
to reinforce cool/dry conditions favoring RH in the 20s/30s. Winds 
remain slightly elevated as well given enhanced PGFs across the 
region. Should be a fairly quiet short term period outside of a few 
minor things.  Am expecting the aforementioned shortwave to cross 
the Central Appalachians tonight bringing along enough moisture to 
increase low/mid clouds, and perhaps a few flurries across the 
higher elevations of TN/VA. Likewise, winds will remain gusty at 
these same higher elevations, which combined with temperatures in 
the teens and single digits will yield wind chill values in the 0 to 
minus 15 range.  Thus the current wind chill advisory will remain as 
is. Otherwise, not much change for Wednesday as the overall pattern 
remains intact.  However, the surface ridge center does look to 
advect eastward to some degree favoring weaker PGFs and thus weaker 
winds.  Temperatures will remain nearly 20 degrees below normal 
amidst sunny skies.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday night through Tuesday)...
Have noticed the models struggling a bit with frontal 
positioning, timing, strength, and location of greatest lift 
during the past seven to ten days as the winter season continues 
to battle with the slowly emerging spring season. Therefore, 
forecast certainty will be a little diminished; mainly later in 
the period. Initially, dry advection and short wave ridging should
be able to hold off any inclement weather for one more day prior 
to the first late week system. This feature will be a rather weak 
and moisture starved upper level wave that will bring a few light 
showers to the region later Thursday night into Friday. There may 
be a few light snow showers mainly in the mountains across 
Southwest Virginia and along much of the Tennessee and North 
Carolina border. Details in terms of how fast warm air advection 
builds in ahead of the Friday feature are limited at this time, 
but as warm and moist air builds in over the top of the below 
freezing near surface air mass, there may be enough moisture for 
the production of around half an inch to possibly one inch of snow
in the highest peaks. The warmer air advances into the region 
quickly Friday morning changing this precipitation into light 
rain. There should be a break in the action Friday night into 
Saturday morning however, a stronger system is expected to build 
into the region later in the day Saturday through Sunday morning. 
The best chance of rain appears to be Saturday evening when there 
may be enough instability for the possibility of the development 
of thunderstorms ahead of the system cold front. The front clears 
the region with drier air moving in from west to east during the 
day Sunday. As previously stated, model uncertainty is at its 
highest in these last couple days of the forecast. Therefore, kept
Monday and Tuesday dry and uneventful while awaiting the possible
arrival of the next upper level wave. Temperatures start off a 
little chilly to start the extended period with highs only in the 
40s and 50s followed by a milder weekend and beginning to the work
week featuring highs in the 50s and 60s.
