799 
FXUS64 KMRX 050835
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
335 AM EST Tue Mar 5 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...Main concern for the short-
term is the very cold wind chills for tonight and Wednesday
morning. Tightening pressure gradients will produce breezy
westerly winds this afternoon into the night. Wind chills between
5 and 15 below zero are expected for the far east Tennessee
Mountains where a wind chill advisory has been issued.

Dry west/northwest flow aloft and ridge of high pressure
continuing to build into the Tennessee Valley and southern
Appalachians will be the main weather features. Currently a weak
system is pulling some high/mid level clouds across the area. This
area of clouds will move east of the region soon after daybreak.

For tonight, a short-wave will move into the east Great
Lakes/central Appalachians. Some cloud cover from this wave will
move into the southwest Virginia, but dry conditions will prevail.
Again, main concern will be tightening pressure gradients,
especially over the mountains, where dangerous wind chills are
expected.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday through Tuesday)...
The upper level pattern during the long term will start off 
highly amplified, with a large upper trough shifting east off the 
eastern seaboard and ridging over the Rockies. Upper flow will 
become more zonal Wednesday night into Thursday as a shortwave 
trough comes ashore over northern California and helps to knock 
down the ridge over the Rockies. Upper flow becomes highly 
amplified again on Friday as another, significantly stronger 
trough comes ashore over southern California. This system will 
eventually eject into the plains Saturday, bringing the potential 
for severe weather to the mid and lower Mississippi River Valley. 
It could even bring some storms to the Tennessee River Valley late
Saturday night depending on which model you believe, but more on 
that later.

Wednesday will be dry, with below normal temperatures as surface 
high pressure is anchored over the lower Miss River Valley. 
Northerly flow should hold temperatures somewhere between 15 to 20 
degrees below normal. Surface high pressure will shift east across 
the area on Thursday, and finally off the coast of the Carolinas by 
Thursday afternoon evening. The aforementioned NorCal trough will 
lead to cyclogenesis over the southern plains Thursday into Friday, 
with a stationary or warm frontal boundary extending to the east 
across northern Miss and Alabama. While much of Thursday will also 
be dry, temperatures will be a tad warmer with southerly flow 
beginning to impinge on the CWA thanks to the surface high shifting 
off the southeast coast. Isentropic lift associated with this trough 
will move east across the CWA late Thursday, and may result in some 
light precipitation Thursday night into Friday. Given the dry air in 
place and sufficiently cold temperatures, it seems very plausible 
that some mixed precipitation types will show up Thursday night into 
Friday morning. Left it with a rain/snow mix for the time being. 
Timing differences in the onset of precipitation, differences in low 
level thermal profiles, and the possibility of a non-diurnal 
temperature curve (temperatures warming during the night due to 
strengthening southerly flow in this case), preclude getting too 
fancy with Ptypes at this time. In any case, no accumulations would 
be expected, and temperatures will quickly warm above freezing 
Friday morning, so impacts would be minimal if at all.

A lull in precip is likely to be seen late Friday into Saturday as 
upper ridging develops over the Ohio and Tenn River Valleys in 
response to the SoCal trough ejecting into the southern plains. 
Temperatures will warm significantly however as southerly flow 
strengthens in advance of this approaching trough. Expect near to 
slightly above normal temperatures by Saturday. 

Saturday night is where things potentially get interesting. Ahead of 
this SoCal trough, a strong low level jet will be seen across the 
southern Appalachians. Cross-Appalachian flow isn't, directionally 
speaking, as ideal as you would want to see for strong downsloping 
winds. However, given how strong this LLJ will be, and the fact that 
there will be a period of decent SSE winds over the mountains, 
expect there will be some good mountain wave activity ahead of any 
incoming storms, even with the slower ECMWF timing. Speaking of 
storms, chances for severe storms will largely depend on the timing. 
The ECMWF is a bit weaker and slower with the overall progression of 
the upper trough. The GFS is predictably stronger/faster. If the 
timing is quicker like the GFS insists on, then some strong to 
possibly severe storms could make it into the southern valley by 
around midnight Saturday night. That is an unfavorable time for 
surface based severe storms, so even in the case of the aggressive 
GFS, the likelihood of severe weather is uncertain. But it bares 
watching as there is a decent signal for strong storms present in 
the GFS. The ECMWF is slower and weaker. It still would favor 
thunderstorms in the forecast Saturday night but not of the 
strong/severe variety. Again, plenty of time for details to change 
but it's worth monitoring at this time.

cold/dry high pressure continues to prevail, centered over the

Southern Appalachians.  With that, WNW flow prevails over much of 
the fcst area today, with moisture trapped in the llvs beneath a 
capping inversion.  Profiles favor continuation of said inversion

tonight leading into a mostly sunny Tuesday.  As the aforementioned 
ridge center shifts east into Tuesday, PGFs will amplify across the 
region leading to increased WNW flow.  Gusts in the 15-20mph range 
will be possible across the lower terrain, nearly 30mph across the 
higher peaks and ridges of the Southern Appalachians.  Temperatures 
Tuesday morning will fall into the 20s (teens at the higher 
elevations) regionwide, which combined with gradually increasing 
winds could yield some bitter windchills at the higher elevations 
before diurnal warming prevails.  Highs on Tuesday will top out in 
the upper 30s to lower 40s in the valley with 20s to lower 30s 
across the higher terrain.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday night through Sunday)...

influence of a trough building in from the west. Overnight lows will 
still be very cold and a moderate increase in winds Tuesday night 
into Wednesday morning will lead to some frigid wind chill values.

short while early Tuesday morning. Anyone unfortunate enough to be 
at the in the highest elevations of the Southern Appalachian 
Mountains may see negative wind chill values.

Valley towards the end of the work week. After the shortwave moves 
through over the weekend a cold front will sweep through Sunday into 
Monday. Still some discrepancies on the timing of these systems, 
which will impact the wintery weather we may experience, but all 
models agree that these systems will be mostly rain across the area. 
Precipitation will move into the Valley Thursday into Friday and 
precipitation chances will continue over the weekend. Overnight lows 
will likely remain above freezing for most locations over the 
weekend, but the higher elevations and Northern Tennessee Valley may 
see some switchover to snowfall during the early morning hours over 
the weekend. Behind the cold front Sunday into Monday we may get 
wrap around moisture that's cold enough to bring more widespread 
snow. 

Current forecast models indicate we may see around 1-2 inches of 
rainfall over the end of the week and through the weekend. An axis 
of heavier precipitation is forecasted to occur over Western/Middle 
Tennessee so if the track of these systems shifts this heavier band 
may shift as well. Confidence in rainfall amounts is still somewhat 
low at this time, but it's possible that this system could re-
aggravate flooding in areas that were hit hard last week.

into the southern Appalachians.

FXUS64 KMRX 022021
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
321 PM EST Sat Mar 2 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Sunday)...

Skies have cleared out this afternoon with temperatures warming 
into the upper 40's to mid 50's area wide. Clouds should begin to 
increase once again this evening as low to mid level moisture 
begins to increase ahead of the next disturbance to the west. 
Current water vapor imagery depicts a southern stream shortwave 
trough moving onshore of central and southern California, with a 
large upper level vortex across southern Canada. A broad southern 
stream jet carries moisture eastward across the Rockies, and into 
the southern plains. To our east, another shortwave trough is 
beginning to exit the New England area with poleward moisture 
transport. The short term forecast will greatly depend on how the 
above features evolve through the next 24 hours. High chances of 
precipitation and heavy rainfall are all hazards to discuss in 
this short term period. The aforementioned Pacific shortwave will 
continue to progress eastward into the Southwest and across the 
Rockies overnight weakening into the zonal flow. The large upper 
level low across Canada will begin to shift east with time, 
setting up a northwest flow regime aloft transporting much colder
air equatward into the northern plains. 

Increased curvature with the lead shortwave across the plains 
will tend to increase isentropic ascent on the 295-305 K surfaces 
as early as 12Z to 15Z Sunday across the region. Further, an 
increased 110-115 knot upper level jet streak will shift across 
the Tennessee Valley with the forecast area becoming placed in the
right entrance region of this jet. Model cross sections depict 
increased deep layer omega in response to the increase in synoptic
scale lift with a nearly upright ageostrophic circulation during 
the Sunday afternoon and evening period. This increase synoptic 
scale lift coincides with an increase in poleward moisture 
associated with a southerly low level jet maximum. Further, the 
increased jet dynamics aloft will lead to an increase in the low 
level thermal gradient across the Ohio and Tennessee valley during
this time which is indicative of a response to the strengthening 
mass field aloft. As a result of the above features, widespread 
precipitation should begin as early as 12Z to 15Z Sunday 
associated with the isentropic lift, and increasing in intensity 
as the upper level dynamics increase. Forecast QPF amounts are 
generally around 1 inch through 12Z Monday. Given the recent heavy
rain event, this amount of rainfall could lead to localized 
flooding in some areas. 

.LONG TERM...(Sunday night through Saturday)...

Low will continue to move off to the east and precipitation will 
gradually begin to end from west to east overnight Sunday night into 
Monday. Temperatures will drop well below freezing overnight, and 
there looks to be a brief crossover of lingering moisture and sub-
freezing temperatures, which will lead to some snowfall. Right now 
the highest chances to see wintery precipitation will be in the 
higher elevations of the Southern Appalachian Mountains and over 
towards the Cumberland Plateau. Forecast currently calls for around 
an inch of snowfall at the mountain peaks and a dusting to half inch 
in the higher elevations of the Valley. We could see a brief round 
of wintry weather in the northern Valley locations, but it currently 
looks like it would have difficulty sticking to the warm ground and 
likely result in no accumulations. 

Broad troughing will continue through the middle of the week leading 
to below average temperatures into the weekend. With overnight 
temperatures expected to be well below freezing for several days 
people need to be mindful of any lingering flood waters freezing and 
leading to patches of black ice on the roads in areas that have poor 
drainage.

Shortwave will move through at the end of the work week and bring 
the next chance of precipitation to the region. Current models 
indicate that we could see additional wintry precipitation in the 
higher elevation, but most of the Valley will stay warm enough to 
see all rain. Even if it does fall as mostly rain across the area, 
will have to be mindful of potential re-aggravation of flooding 
conditions, depending on how much the ground can dry out over the 
upcoming work week. So with multiple effects possible from this next 
weekend system, will want to keep a close eye on this one.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
301 PM EST Fri Mar 1 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Saturday)...
Rain is continuing to clear out of the Eastern Tennessee Valley
this afternoon. Rainfall amounts have generally been about
0.25-0.50 inches, but a few isolated locations have seen a bit
closer to 1 inch of rain. Expect rain to continue to move out of
the area and exit SW Virginia/NE Tennessee by sunset this evening. 

Colder air will continue to funnel in from the northwest and
overnight lows will dip down into the 30/40's across the area. Dry
weather will continue tomorrow and temperatures will rebound to us
seeing high temperatures similar to what we saw today. 

.LONG TERM (Saturday through Thursday)...
On Saturday night, the upper levels will become dominated by 
zonal flow as a strong area of high pressure begins to settle 
southward out of Canada. An area of surface pressure falls across 
the southern plains and western Gulf will lead to a weak area of 
surface low pressure. This surface low will move toward the 
northeast across the southeast states and extreme southern 
Appalachians. Ahead of this surface low, isentropic ascent on the 
290-300K surfaces will begin as early as Sunday morning. Strong 
net isentropic adiabatic omega will occur as a result of the 
strong ascent and with adequate deep layer moisture should lead to
widespread showers across a large portion of the forecast area. 
Precipitable water values are progged to increase upwards of 1.00+
inches with values in excess of 1.25 inches across southern 
Tennessee. This amount of moisture could lead to locally heavy 
rainfall across portions of the area. Already saturated ground 
would mean that this precipitation could create additional flood 
issues. Precipitation should quickly come to an end Monday morning
as the weak area of PVA and area of surface low pressure ejects 
eastward. Residual moisture could lead to light drizzle or 
flurries across portions of the area into Monday morning as a much
colder airmass moves in. Some of this moisture may be able to 
stick around long enough for light snow across the higher terrain 
in the Smokys but am not expecting any impacts. Gusty winds should
follow behind the arctic front with a strong pressure gradient. 
Temperatures Monday will be much cooler with daytime highs only in
the upper 30’s to low 40’s. 

Surface high pressure will remain in control Monday night through 
Thursday with below normal temperatures expected under a northwest 
flow regime aloft. The NAEFS guidance still indicates temperatures 
in the bottom 1-2 percentile range and 850mb temperatures anomalies 
as low as -1.0 to -1.5 sigma.  Further, CIPS analog guidance also 
shows a strong signal of much colder air. Given this, will trend on 
the colder side of guidance.  However, strong subsidence will bring 
mostly clear skies through the extended period.   Models are still 
having issues in regards to the next system to traverse the region 
late in the period.  The main differences are that the ECMWF keeps 
the area under persistent northwest flow aloft, with the GFS showing 
a more active pattern with deep troughing across the central and 
southern plains and a large disturbance.  For now will keep PoPs in 
the 20 to 30 percent range.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
318 AM EST Fri Mar 1 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

At the surface this morning, a cold front is draped lengthwise 
down the Tennessee Valley and into northern Alabama. Cold air 
advection isn't particularly strong at this point in time due to 
zonal upper flow and lack of strong surface high pressure helping 
to drive it south and east, so colder temperatures are displaced 
north and west into middle Tennessee and into Kentucky. Showers 
associated with a shortwave passing to our north are still 
lingering in the far northeast TN mountains and into southwest 
Virginia. Those will dissipate in the next few hours. However 
another shortwave is traversing Oklahoma early this morning and 
will impact our weather through the morning and early afternoon 
hours. Expect to see a wave of surface low pressure develop along 
the front to our southwest, riding the boundary northeast through 
the morning hours after daybreak. Lift from this approaching 
shortwave should cause showers to become fairly widespread from 
around daybreak through midday, progressing from southwest to 
northeast with time. Regional radar imagery supports this, with 
numerous showers developing over the last couple of hours over 
central and northern Alabama. Increased PoPs further to support 
the observational, as well as high res numerical guidance, trends 
of widespread rainfall today. Amounts should be light overall, but
suspect most people will see some measurable rain today.

On the temperature front, went with a standard diurnal trend. The 
shortwave responsible for incoming rain and surface low pressure 
riding north along the boundary will not pass by until this evening. 
So any notable shift in the location of the front, and subsequent 
CAA regime, is not expected until tonight. Expect to see highs in 
the mid and upper 50s for the valley and points east, and perhaps 
some upper 40s to low 50s for mainly the northern plateau. Low 40s 
to upper 30s appear on tap for tonight due to some meager 
strengthening of the CAA regime.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Friday)...

A few showers will be lingering over the Southern Appalachian 
Region early Saturday as the ongoing system pulls out of the area.
At best a hundredth or two is possible over the eastern 
mountains. Otherwise....Saturday should be dry with zonal flow 
aloft. The main system of concern through the extend will begin to
push in late Saturday night/early Sunday morning with the main 
band of showers moving through during the day Sunday and showers 
lingering into Sunday night/early Monday. Models are in poor 
agreement with the amount of rainfall expected. PWs should be 
above an inch and expect the overall average rainfall to be 1 to 2
inches...though some models do want to bring in at least 3 
inches. So...with the disagreement in models...confidence is low 
on details. The main concern with the rainfall is with the recent 
significant rains during the end of February and still a rather 
saturated ground and there does continue to be some ongoing minor 
flood of low lying areas...this additional rainfall could could 
have more of an impact that it normally would. The rest of the 
extended period looks fairly benign with just a couple of weak 
impulses moving through which is generally expected to 
occasionally increase cloud cover. However...we could see a 
isolated showers move in late Thursday in advance of the next 
approaching system.

the short term period with above normal temperatures tonight and 
temperatures near seasonable normals tomorrow.

.LONG TERM...(Friday night through Thursday)...Shortwave trough
exits east of the region on Friday night with some  weak 
subsidence across the region resulting in dry weather and some 
mostly clear to partly cloudy skies through Saturday. With zonal 
flow, expect temperatures near normal. Late Saturday afternoon, 
isentropic lift increases from southwest to northeast with high 
clouds moving in Saturday evening and more widespread 
precipitation late Saturday night and Sunday morning. Model 
guidance is in generally good agreement for Sunday and Monday. A 
northern stream shortwave is expected to phase with a southern 
stream shortwave Sunday afternoon with strengthening surface 
cyclogenesis across the Southern and Central Appalachians along an
arctic front. With southwesterly flow ahead of the front on 
Sunday afternoon, PW values will increase above 1.0 inch with 
values up to 1.4 inch across southwest Tennessee and southwest 
North Carolina. This will favor the potential for some additional 
heavy rainfall on Sunday with 1 to 2 inches of rainfall expected. 
Localized convective activity could increase totals in some spots,
but at this time, the bulk of instability is expected to remain 
southeast of the surface low across portions of Mississippi, 
Alabama, and Georgia.

Much colder air advects into the region as winds veer to the 
northwest behind the cold front on Sunday night. This will lead to 
any remaining moisture mixing with or changing to some light snow 
showers and flurries, especially across northern portions of the 
forecast area and the higher elevations. However, most of the 
moisture is forecast to be gone by the time temperatures drop cold 
enough for frozen precip, so any accumulation is expected to be 
little to none. Still, could have some freezing of moisture on 
surfaces, especially elevated surfaces like bridges, Sunday night as 
temperatures drop into the mid 20s across the northern plateau and 
southwest Virginia.

A northern shortwave trough rotating through the longwave troughing 
pattern will usher in a reinforcing cold front on Tuesday and 
strengthen troughing across the Eastern CONUS. While moisture is 
limited with this second front, anomalously cold air will move 
southward into our area. The NAEFS guidance shows temperatures in 
the bottom 2 or 3 percentiles, which is a very strong signal for 
much below normal temperatures 5 days out. In addition, CIPS analog 
guidance also shows a very strong signal for much below normal 
temperatures from Tuesday through Thursday of next week with a near 
100 percent chance of below normal temperatures and surface 
temperature anomalies of 10 below normal (which is the bottom limit 
of the scale). With this information, went much below normal on 
temperatures next week, and even went several degrees below MOS 
guidance. Although temperatures will be much below normal, do expect 
mostly clear skies on Tuesday afternoon through Thursday morning 
with subsidence in the wake of the strong shortwave. By late week, 
another system is expected to approach from the west with isentropic 
lift increasing once again which will bring slight chance/chance 
PoPs across the area.

.LONG TERM (Friday through Wednesday Night)...Seeing some better
model agreement during the long-term portion of the forecast. 
Model consensus suggests that the surface boundary will stall 
further to the south and east. Drier air will move in behind the 
frontal boundary with dewpoints dropping down into the low to mid 
40s. PW values will drop down into the 0.5-0.7 inch range. These 
values are around to slightly above normal for late February into 
early March. Model soundings indicate that this moisture is 
limited to the low-levels and with the lack of lift, went ahead 
and lowered PoPs for Friday. There is a weak trough that will 
rotate through the region and the area will be in the left exit 
region of an upper level jet. However, with the boundary now 
forecast further south and the lack of moisture, kept most areas 
dry on Friday. Under mostly cloud skies, highs will generally be 
in the 50s. 

The period with the highest uncertainty is Friday night into 
Saturday morning. The NAM indicates another upper level trough 
moving in quickly Friday night into Saturday morning. The front 
nudges further northward. The lift increases and NAM model soundings 
indicate saturation at Chattanooga and Knoxville. The GFS and ECMWF 
indicate that the upper level flow during this timeframe remains 
more zonal with the front remaining further to the south. For now, 
have kept PoPs a bit higher Friday night into Saturday morning to 
account for the NAM solution. PoPs during this frame range from 
around 20-50 %. Regardless, expect cloud cover will continue 
overnight with lows dropping into the low and mid 40s.

850mb ridge will move across the forecast area with zonal flow 
aloft. PW values will be in the 0.4-0.6 inch range. These values are 
around average for early March. Model soundings suggest a bit more 
sunshine on Saturday compared to Friday with highs rising into the 
mid 50s to low 60s. The 850 mb ridge will shift to the east of the 
area Saturday night into Sunday as low level southwesterly flow 
begins to increase. A southern stream trough will move out of the 
Desert Southwest into the southern Plains during this timeframe. The 
surface boundary to the south will begin to surge northwards. PoPs 
will increase from southwest to northeast Saturday night into 
Sunday. PW values will increase into the 1.0-1.3 inch range with the 
strong moisture and warm air advection. These values are over the 
90th percentile for early March. Forecast rainfall amounts will 
range from 1-2 inches late Saturday through Sunday. The event is 
still a few days away but any additional precipitation will lead to 
localized flooding issues due to the widespread historic rainfall 
events throughout February. The track of the surface low is a bit 
better defined between the GFS and ECMWF. The models have come 
closer together with the GFS a bit further north and the ECMWF a bit 
further south. For now, it doesn't appear like the low will track 
far enough north to include thunder in the forecast on Sunday.

Much colder air will advect in behind the departing front Sunday 
night into Monday. Model soundings indicate that the deep moisture 
will exit during this timeframe but there could be enough leftover 
for a few snow shower/flurries late Sunday night into Monday 
morning. The best chances for snow will be across southwest 
Virginia, northeast Tennessee, and the east Tennessee Mountains. For 
now, not forecasting an impactful winter weather event due to the 
limited moisture behind the boundary. Temperatures early next week

30s to low 40s and lows in the teens and 20s.

the high moves farther east and a mid level shortwave and associated 
weak surface low move across Mississippi and Alabama during the day. 
This will result in light rain showers developing from S to N across 
east TN and southwest NC between 12 and 18Z. These showers will hold 
off in far northeast TN and southwest VA until around or just after 
18Z. Brought in slight chance pops around 09Z gradually increasing 
to chance and likely through the morning to reflect this increasing 
rainfall, except for southwest VA where likely pops will hold off 
until early to mid afternoon. The good news is that the rain will be 
light and should not redevelop any flooding. WPC QPF guidance 
generally gives a few hundredths to 0.30 inches between early 
Thursday morning and Thursday evening with the greatest amounts over 
the southern Plateau and southern Valley. Extensive cloud cover will 
be mostly locked in for Thursday, but highs will remain near to 
above normal with a few 60's once again possible in the southern 
valley and southwest NC. This will especially be the case if there 
are breaks in the rain showers. Kept Thursday's highs close to the 
CONSSHORT output but raised temps in northeast TN to account for 
some downsloping effects.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday night through Wednesday)...

Models in fair agreement to start the period on Thursday night. An 
upper level disturbance is moving across to our north and will bring 
a weak frontal boundary through the area Thursday night. Enough lift 
and moisture are present for some scattered showers. As the 
disturbance to our north moves further east POPs decrease through 
the night. If the NAM is correct, the weak boundary stalls across 
the area for Friday which allows for more light and scattered 
showers. The GFS has the boundary to our south and keeps us drier. 
The location of the stalled boundary will be key on who ends up 
seeing the showers. If we do see the showers QPF will be light as 
forcing is weak due to isentropic lift.

The boundary begins to lift northward Friday night into Saturday 
morning. During this time another weak disturbance moves through the 
zonal flow and lift is enhanced over the boundary. Another round of 
mostly light showers expected during this time. An upper level 
trough swinging across the Great Lakes Saturday afternoon helps to 
force the boundary back to our southeast. This will allow us to dry 
out during the afternoon hours. Highs on Friday and Saturday will be 
in the mid to upper 50s for most.

Showers move back in Saturday night and into Sunday. This is in 
response to high pressure setting up to our southeast and a strong 
cold front approaching from the northwest. The northern and southern 
stream jet phase and puts our region under a double jet structure. 
This will enhance lift with the left front quadrant of the southern 
jet and right rear quadrant of the northern jet over the area. This 
double jet, strengthening southwest flow, and stalled boundary will 
allow for likely and categorical POPs on Sunday. How much rain we 
receive depends on how and where the northern and southern stream 
jet phase together. As of now, it looks like we could get anywhere 
from 0.75 inches up to 1 inch of rainfall on Sunday. 

The cold front pushes through Sunday night and colder air rapidly 
moves in. There could be a brief period where lingering moisture on 
the back edge transitions to some light snow showers before the 
moisture finally exits. The rest of the period will be under the 
influence of an upper level trough which will keep us in a dry and 
cool airmass. Highs from Monday through Wednesday will range from 
the lower 30s to near 40 with lows in the upper teens to upper 20s.

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...The surface high has shifted
east of the area with a weak short wave tracking through the upper
flow to our south. The wave will continue to bring bands of clouds
through the area and may generate a stray pocket of light rain or
sprinkle over far southeast locations early this morning. But 
overall...it should be a dry day with zonal flow aloft. Clouds 
will slowly increase and lower late tonight as the next low 
pressure system approaches the area. Associated rain will begin 
pushing in overnight. By late night/early morning...rainfall 
should be scattered and light...with totals generally less than a
tenth of an inch by sunrise. The main band of rain is not 
expected to move in until the long term period. 

.LONG TERM (Thursday through Tuesday Night)...Model uncertainty 
features throughout the long-term forecast period with the timing 
and placement of each upper level trough moving in the zonal flow 
being key to the forecast period. The model discrepancies start at
the beginning of the forecast period. A frontal passage is 
forecast late Wendesday into early Thursday and the boundary will 
stall to the south and east of the area as it takes on more of an 
E-W orientation as the trough to the north lifts out over the 
Atlantic. The models are all fairly consistent with a weak 
shortwave trough move across the southeastern U.S. on Thursday but
differ on the location and strength. The NAM is by far the 
strongest and most bullish with precipitation. The Canadian, GFS, 
and ECMWF both indicate that the front will stall a bit further 
south and will only lift slightly northward with the trough on 
Thursday. This solution keeps best precipitation chances to the 
south and east and have gone closer to this solution for the 
forecast. Thursday night into Friday morning will feature a bit of
a lull in the activity as a weak shortwave ridge passes over the 
area. Highs will range from the upper 50s to low 60s on Thursday 
with lows Thursday night into Friday morning in the 40s.

The next upper level trough moves into the Tennessee River Valley on 
Friday with the surface boundary lingering to the south. The ECMWF 
is the most impressive model with this wave featuring elevated PoPs 
across the area. The Canadian, GFS, and NAM indicate a rather 
similar scenario as Thursday with the upper level trough being to 
weak and the front remaining further to the south and east. For now, 
have gone with chance PoPs around 30-50 %. Most models indicate a 
break Friday night into Saturday morning but the GFS keeps chances 
in the forecast. The GFS solution keeps the forecast area in the 
left exit region of an elongated jet as another weak shortwave 
trough moves into the Tennessee River Valley. Due to this, have 
continued with some mention of PoPs Friday night into Saturday 
morning. Highs on Friday will be in the mid 50s to low 60s with lows 
Saturday morning in the 40s. 

Model solutions continue to diverge into the upcoming weekend. The 
ECMWF and Canadian indicate a rather robust upper level southerly 
stream trough moving through the region On Sunday. The GFS indicates 
best precipitation chances will arrive on Saturday as the front 
lifts northward due to southwesterly low level flow increasing ahead 
of a clipper type system. The ECMWF and Canadian solution suggest 
that Saturday will be dry but have continued with chance PoPs 
throughout much of the weekend to account for the uncertainty. If 
the ECMWF and Canadian solutions are correct, expect there will be 
strong winds across the high terrain on Sunday. A few strong to even 
severe storms could be possible as well as heavy rainfall. This is 
still several days away and still too much uncertainty to add 
anything to the HWO.

The clear part of the extended is that the airmass will change going 
into next week as arctic air moves in behind the departing front. A 
few wrap around snow showers could be possible late Sunday into 
Monday. For now, this does not look to be a very impactful event due 
to the cold air moving in as the moisture exits. Temperatures early 
next week will make it feel more like winter with highs in the mid 
30s and low 40s and lows in the 20s and 30s.

feature to our south. We may see a few mid to high band of clouds
move across the region but the area should remain dry.
However...another wave will move through the upper flow late
tonight. This one will track a bit further north and a few
isolated light showers could push across far southern and eastern
areas toward sunrise. Precip amounts should be minimal. The main
concern through the short continues to be the lingering areal
flooding and high river levels. Some counties continue to have
some flooding issues and a couple of rivers are still above flood
stage. Associated Flood and River Flood Warnings remain in effect.
The areal flooding and river flooding...as well as other local low
lying ponding and higher rivers and creek...will continue to lower
for slowly improving conditions. 

.LONG TERM (Wednesday through Monday Night)...Zonal flow aloft 
will feature throughout the end of the work week. Wednesday will 
feature a warm front moving to the north of the forecast area and 
a cold front approaching from the northwest. The atmosphere will 
stay relatively dry with PW values in the 0.5-0.7 inch range. 
Model soundings also indicate rather limited moisture and with the
lack of any synoptic lift, have removed PoPs for Wednesday. Highs
will warm into the 60s under mostly sunny skies. Warm air 
advection begins to increase Wednesday night ahead of the 
approaching front with low remaining up in the mid 40s to low 50s.
By Thursday, a weak upper level trough will move in with the 
zonal flow aloft. Models differ on the exact track of the surface 
low and how much instability will be available. Regardless, looks 
like instability will be rather low and have included chances for 
a few thunderstorms across southern portions of the forecast area.
Rain chances will increase on Thursday as moisture advection 
increases with PW values rising into the 0.9-1.1 inch range. 
Thursday will feature the best rain chances through the end of the
work week. 

The front will push south of the forecast area on Thursday night but 
will stall due to the zonal flow aloft. Some weak cold air advection 
will drop lows down into the low to mid 40s. With the front 
lingering, chances for showers will continue Thursday night into 
Friday morning. The front will begin to nudge back northward Friday 
night into Saturday with strong low level southwesterly flow ahead 
of another approaching upper level trough. Due to this, some areas 
will reenter the warm sector with a few thunderstorms possible again 
Friday night into Saturday. A more robust upper level trough will 
move into the region late this weekend finally pushing a cold front 
through the area. This front will usher in an airmass change as 
arctic air will feature throughout the extended portion of the long-
term forecast period. Models differ on when this cold air arrives 
with the ECMWF being a bit later than the GFS. The ECMWF lingers 
some moisture behind the boundary Sunday night into Monday morning 
that could result in a few snow showers. WIth the GFS showing a dry 
solution behind the boundary.

Regardless of timing and model solution, it is clear that a pattern 
change is in the works for early next week. Both models indicate 
that the surface boundary will stall along the Gulf Coast early next 
week with several upper level troughs moving through the region. It 
will all depend on the timing and track of these systems but it does 
look like there will be a couple of threats for wintry precipitation 
early next week with temperatures forecast to be below average.

temperatures as heights rise across the area. Highs will be in the

WAA ahead of this system will result in above normal temps Saturday,

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
209 AM EST Mon Feb 25 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

A dry forecast for the short-term period. PW values will remain 
below a quarter of an inch throughout the short-term forecast 
period. These values are around the tenth percentile for late 
February. In the upper levels, the trough is now over New England 
with upper level heights increasing across the forecast area. At the 
surface, the low is now north of the Great Lakes racing 
northeastward into Canada. Surface high pressure is building into 
the area behind the departing system. Winds have remained up a bit 
tonight between the surface low to the northeast and high to the 
northwest. These winds have kept overnight temperatures a bit warmer 
than forecast and have increased temperatures a bit this morning 
with lows in the upper 20s to mid 30s for most locations.

Sunny conditions will feature today as upper level heights continue 
to increase. There will still be some weak cold air advection across 
the area with the low level ridge axis staying to the west of the 
forecast area. High temperatures today will top out in the 50s for 
most locations. Winds will be lighter as the pressure gradient 
relaxes with the surface high approaching. Will see a radiational 
cooling night tonight with light winds and clear skies. Overnight 
lows will range from the mid 20s to low 30s for most locations.

.LONG TERM...(Monday through Sunday)...

Generally zonal flow and near normal weather conditions are expected 
Tuesday. A weak wave of energy will zip through the area Tuesday 
night into Wednesday. Rain chances will be best in the Southern 
Tennessee Valley. QPF amounts look to be pretty light with this 
system, so at this time additional flooding is not expected, even 
though grounds will probably still be pretty wet. 

We take a brief break before another round of precipitation is 
expected to move through Thursday night into Friday. Looks to be a 
bit more moisture and energy associated with this second system, but 
rainfall amounts still look to be relatively moderate. And once 
again quickly behind this system another even stronger system will 
move through. This third system is Low pressure system moving 
through the Great Lakes region and dragging a cold front through the 
eastern half of the United States. This system looks to move through 
the Eastern Tennessee Valley Friday into Saturday. Precipitation 
will likely begin Friday night and continue into mid-day Saturday. 
Current models indicate that we could see rainfall totals of around 
a half inch, with some places possibly getting closer to an inch. 
Timing and strength of this system is still a bit up in the air 
until models come into better agreement, but once this system does 
move through we will drop temperatures to below normal at the start 
of next week.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
258 PM EST Sun Feb 24 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Monday)...
The upper pattern today features quasizonal flow atop the Tennessee 
Valley and Southern Appalachian region, while surface high pressure 
noses in from the west.  PGFs remain high across the region today 
associated with the advecting high pressure airmass, thus winds are 
quite gusty.  The pressure gradient will relax across the lower 
elevations tonight, thus the present wind advisory will be allowed 
to expire for all areas outside of the mtn zones.  For those areas, 
am expecting persistent advisory level winds through 7AM Monday 
morning, which is when the remaining wind advisory expires. 
Otherwise, still looking at high water across much of the area in 
the wake of the past weeks' (and mainly yesterday's) flooding. Thus, 
opted to carry all areal flood warnings through midday tomorrow, 
allowing for ample time Monday morning to call around to local 
officials and discuss conditions on the ground.  If it is deemed 
conditions have improved sufficiently, warnings will at that time be 
allowed to expire.  River levels also remain high with the Pigeon, 
and North Fork Holston Rivers at moderate flood levels, with the 
Clinch expected to rise to moderate as well.  The South Chickamauga, 
Sequatchie, Tennessee, Powell, and French Broad rivers are at (and 
shouldn't exceed) minor flood levels.  All rivers should crest soon 
(if not already), thus yielding some relief for any impacted areas. 
Otherwise, cooler/drier high pressure will overtake the region on 
Monday allowing for mostly sunny skies and temperatures topping out 
near or slightly below normal levels. Winds on Monday should be 
substantially weaker than that of today. 

.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Sunday)...
There is still a little bit of uncertainty in the extended period
with a couple weaker systems moving through the region during the
middle part of the week. We should still be able to enjoy another
dry day on Tuesday but some moisture may be advancing from the 
south as the first weak impulse rides through a nearly zonal flow 
aloft. This feature may bring a little light rain to the southern 
part of the forecast area Tuesday night into Wednesday morning 
with some of this light qpf moving into the northern half later 
Wednesday into the evening hours. There should be a bit of a gap 
in the precipitation later Wednesday evening. However, the next 
wave, which is progged to be slightly more well developed, could 
bring a little better chance for some showers area wide Thursday 
with departure of this feature later Thursday night. While there 
may some timing issues with the final system of the long term 
period, models agree on a well amplified long wave trough dropping
into the Eastern U.S. into the weekend. The chance for showers 
and thunderstorms will increase Friday and Friday night as a 
healthy, negative tilt short wave drives a deep surface low from 
the Mid Mississippi Valley northeast into the Eastern Great Lakes.
While its almost at the end of the extended period, this 
configuration would allow for the possibility of strong 
thunderstorms later Friday or Friday night depending on how much 
instability will be available ahead of the boundary. At this time,
it certainly appears that shear will be sufficiently strong. 
Temperatures will start out a little below normal to start out the
forecast however, much of the remainder of the week appears to be
near to several degrees above normal; especially when the 
stronger southerly flow develops Thursday into Friday. Cooler air 
will be building back into the region over the weekend behind the 
strong cold front.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
306 AM EST Sun Feb 24 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

The cold front is still back to the west of the forecast area but a 
line of showers ahead of the surface boundary is currently moving 
through the area early this morning. This line of showers will bring 
in an additional 0.25-0.75 inches of rain and will continue to 
exacerbate the flooding issues across the area. The good news is that 
this will be the last chance for precipitation over the next several 
days. In the upper levels, the trough is racing northeastward 
into the western Great Lakes. The cold front will eventually move 
through the forecast area later this morning with precipitation 
finally coming to an end. The surface low will continue to deepen 
as the upper level jet across the Appalachians into the 
Northeastern U.S. increases with winds speeds as high as 130-150 
kt at 300 mb. The winds will increase behind the front as the 
pressure gradient tightens as the surface low strengthens. Model 
soundings indicate winds around the mixing height of 30-40 kts 
and expect these will be brought down to the surface. Due to this,
went ahead and extended the wind advisory to the south and west. 
Due to the saturated soils, trees could easily be brought down 
with gusts up to 40 mph and there could even be some sporadic 
power outages. The cold air advection behind the system is not 
overly impressive and highs should remain in the upper 40s to low 
50s throughout much of the day. With the cold and dry air 
advection, expect to see some welcome sun today. The winds will 
subside overnight as the surface low tracks well into Canada as 
high pressure move sin from the west. Extended the wind advisory 
through 12z Monday across the higher elevations where winds will 
remain elevated. Overnight lows will be closer to normal for late 
February ranging from the upper 20s to low 30s for most locations.

.LONG TERM...(Monday through Sunday)...

a quiet weather pattern is forecast to start the work-week with high 
pressure building in with upper level height rises. Temperatures on 
Monday will range from the upper 40s to low 50s with sunny skies. 
Clear skies will allow for radiational cooling Monday night into 
Tuesday morning with lows in the upper 20s to mid 30s. The low 
level ridge will shift to the east of the area by Tuesday with 
warm air advection returning. Highs will run a bit warmer in the 
mid 50s to low 60s. 

Precipitation chances will return by the middle of the week as a 
warm front pushes northward from the Gulf States. The warm air and 
moisture advection will persist throughout the remainder of the week 
keeping precipitation chances elevated in the extended portion of 
the forecast. The GFS and ECMWF are both consistent indicating a 
rather robust upper level trough moving into the region over the 
weekend. The forecast area should be well into the warm sector and
have added thunderstorms to the forecast over the weekend. This 
event is still several days away but could also produce some 
stronger storms depending on the track of the system.

FXUS64 KMRX 240221
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
921 PM EST Sat Feb 23 2019

.DISCUSSION...

The main purpose for the evening update was to increase rainfall
amounts for the overnight hours and address a growing concern with
regard to the flash flood potential tonight.

Numerical guidance shows a fairly high plume of PWAT values moving
into our area from the southwest tonight, along/ahead of the cold
front that will move through by daybreak Sunday. Couple this with
sufficient forcing for convection and there is concern that
significantly higher rainfall rates will be observed overnight
tonight than what was seen earlier today. Duration will be
shorter, and totals will definitely be lower than earlier today.
But the rainfall rates are what concern me at this point. Flash
flood guidance suggests as little as half an inch in a one hour
period would be enough to start causing additional problems.
I think both the short duration rates, as well as expected 
totals, will be enough to surpass that.

Bumped up rainfall totals through the overnight hours to the 0.75
to 1.00" range for the plateau and central/southern TN Valley 
region. Have little doubt there will be some amounts that exceed
an inch or even an inch and a half. By themselves, those totals 
don't sound impressive. Given the soil conditions though, if they
occur in a 1-2 period tonight, especially for central valley
locations, some additional flash flooding would seem to be a 
given. We will continue to closely monitor the situation
overnight.

I'll close on a positive note here. There are some details that 
give hope for a more favorable outcome. Cloud top temperatures on 
infrared satellite imagery are warming and lightning strike counts
seem to be coming down. Additionally the entire precip shield is 
moving along quickly. So it is possible that this event could 
conclude with no increase in flooding issues above the substantial
problems we've already had.

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...

Oak Ridge, TN                       51  56  31  52 /  90  30   0   0

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
310 PM EST Sat Feb 23 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Sunday)...
Well it's been a busy day around these parts.  A slow moving band of 
H85 frontogenetic forcing has allowed for modest training of 
convection across the I40 corridor region of east TN.  With that, 
rainfall upwards of 3-4 inches over the last 6-7 hours are fairly 
common, especially across Roane, Loudon, and Knox counties. Multiple 
road closures continue to prevail across the area, even outside of 
the above noted hardest hit areas.  

As if that wasn't bad enough, we are still looking at a potent cold 
frontal passage tonight, which will have abundant moisture and lift 
for a line of convection across the region. Guidance favors said 
convective line moving out of middle TN late this evening, slowly 
traversing across the Plateau and through the Great Valley after 
midnight.  Current thinking favors the best chances for any stronger 
convection along south of I40 were best overlapping of 
shear/instability occur.  That said, a potent 60-70kt llj will move 
atop the region ahead of the front, which could mix to the surface 
with any strong cells.  If that occurs, given how saturated the 
ground is, am expecting scattered falling/uprooting trees, even with 
winds maxing out in the 40-50mph range.  Aside from any wind 
threats, additional rainfall (perhaps at higher rates) could 
exasperate/prolong any ongoing flooding. Finally, the traversing llj 
combined with elevation will lead to high winds across the Southern 
Appalachians, especially across the Smoky's where the earlier High 
Wind Watch was upgraded to a Warning through tonight.  Likewise, a 
Wind Advisory has also been issued for the remainder of the TN/VA 
high terrain starting tonight running through Sunday.  

Speaking of Sunday, FINALLY the sun will make it's triumphant 
return.  Expecting mostly sunny skies and highs in the mid/upper 50s 
amidst gusty wly/swly winds regionwide. 

.LONG TERM...(Sunday night through Saturday)...
A powerful upper level trough moves east of the region Monday 
into Monday night with a zonal flow developing aloft. This flow 
helps the waterlogged region dry out as the Gulf of Mexico source 
region won't be involved in this flow pattern early in the week. 
The models are still having a difficult time resolving minor 
perturbations in this zonal pattern at mid week. A weak cold 
frontal boundary drops through the Southern Appalachian region in 
this pattern, but moisture will be limited ahead of the front, so 
the chance for a shower will remain slight. Later Thursday into 
Friday, there will be a gradual increase in isentropic lift as a 
weak wave rides east across the Deep South. Perhaps the best 
chance of rain will be in association with a more amplified upper 
level trough and surface frontal system on Saturday. However, kept
pops in a medium to high chance category due to uncertainty 
during this late period of the extended forecast. Temperatures 
will start out a couple of degrees below normal at the beginning 
of the long term with a warming trend bringing max and mins just a
little above normal mid to late week.

FXUS64 KMRX 230738
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
238 AM EST Sat Feb 23 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

Current upper level pattern features a trough moving out of the 
Desert Southwest into the southern Plains with a ridge extending 
from Florida northward into the Great Lakes. Closer to home, 
southwesterly flow continues to bring in plenty of moisture with PW 
values running in the 1.1-1.4 inch range. These values are around 
the maximum values observed for late February. At the surface, an E-
W boundary stretches across MS/AL/GA. High pressure at the surface 
across New England is keeping a wedge to the east of the mountains 
and this will hinder the fronts northern progression but the low 
level jet is forecast to increase later this morning. Current radar 
imagery indicates widespread precipitation across northern Alabama, 
northern Mississippi and west and middle TN. Models indicate strong 
lift to the north of the surface boundary in these regions with a 
120-130 kt jet developing across the Ohio River Valley. Models 
indicate the best lift across the forecast area in the 09-15z 
timeframe with best precipitation coverage across the northern 
Plateau into southwest Virginia. Amounts through the end of the day 
will range from 1-2 inches but could be as high as 3 inches and with 
the already saturated ground all of this will be runoff. Due to this 
and ongoing river flooding, will extend the Flood Watch for the 
entire area through 12z Sunday. This additional rainfall will also 
lead to the possibility of flash flooding and will exacerbate any 
ongoing river flooding. Models indicate the lift weakens going into 
the afternoon and expect to see a decrease in coverage. 

The strength of the low level jet will continue to increase 
overnight and the front will move northward into the forecast as the 
wedge retreats. There are some model difference on how far north 
the warm front makes it. The warm sector becomes pinched off due to 
the wedge to the east and instability is rather limited regardless 
of model solution. Winds at 925 mb will be around 40-50 kts. Model 
soundings indicate some weak instability across southern portions of 
the forecast area later tonight into Sunday morning and any of these 
strong updrafts could bring these winds down to the surface. 
Therefore, will continue the mention of strong to marginally severe 
storms in the HWO. With the saturated ground, any stronger wind 
gusts will have the ability to bring down a few trees. Additional, 
moderate to heavy rainfall along the front will continue to 
exacerbate any ongoing flood issues. Winds in the mountains will 
increase later tonight as the low level jet surges into the area. 
The event is not a typical mountain wave event due to the 
southwesterly winds blowing parallel to the mountains. For now, will 
continue with the High Wind Watch for late tonight into Sunday 
morning.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Friday)...

Drier and slightly cooler weather will begin on Sunday as the 
frontal system has moved off to the east. Breezy conditions will be 
the biggest weather on Sunday as air tries to fill in behind the 
front. Strongest winds will be early Sunday into the daylight hours, 
and will eventually begin to decrease after the sun sets.

Dry weather is then forecasted for several days as we start the next 
work week, and generally zonal flow in the mid levels of the 
atmosphere lead to near normal conditions for this time of year. 
Models then indicate that there may be another weather system to 
move through the area at the end of the week or over the weekend. 
Large differences between the long term models, so will keep low end 
precipitation chances at the end of the week and into the weekend. 
However, hopefully once models come into better agreement the 
duration of the PoP chances can be decreased.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
1040 PM EST Fri Feb 22 2019

.DISCUSSION...

Many updates to the forecast tonight with additional chances of
heavy rainfall. Additionally, high winds across the mountain 
zones Saturday night is beginning to look increasingly likely. 
Overall, temperatures were on track and am not planning any 
updates. Skies remained cloudy tonight while the main axis of 
rainfall, aligned along a zone of enhanced 850mb convergence, 
continues to lift northward. To the south, a warm front analyzed 
across northern Georgia, Alabama, and Mississippi continues its 
northward movement with a poleward transport of low level 
moisture. Area radar shows an area of heavy rainfall forming again
across north Mississippi and west Tennessee along and ahead of 
the front aided by an 850mb jet and associated warm air 
advection. Closer to our CWA, areas of rainfall are starting to 
fill in and will continue to push northward into southern 
Tennessee. Latest short term and hi-res models indicate a band of 
enhanced rainfall along the advancing warm front. The main 
differences in models are where exactly the axis of greater 850mb 
winds will set up. The HRRR is more east with this zone, and as a 
result places the heavier QPF axis further into the MRX CWA. The 
NAM is a bit further west, which keeps the higher QPF totals 
closer to middle Tennessee, although higher totals are still seen 
across the Cumberland Plateau. No matter these differences, it 
seems increasingly likely that heavy rainfall will move back into 
the region in the morning hours with heavy precipitation rates 
given the strength of upper level diffluence and accompanied low 
level convergence along the front. As of this update, 1-3 inches 
of additional rainfall seems possible across the Plateau area. 
While instability looks limited, any elevated convection could 
enhance rainfall rates, and contribute to additional amounts of 
rainfall. These areas have already seen plenty of rainfall, and 
any additional rain could cause flooding. As a result, have 
extended the flood watch timing through Saturday night and added a
couple of additional counties to better match the forecasted QPF 
axis. 

The other item of interest was to issue a high wind watch for the
mountain zones Saturday night. The orientation of 850mb winds is
not favorable for a true mountain wave event, however, enhanced
850mb winds in excess of 50-60 knots in addition to an enhanced
pressure gradient would support high winds across the mountains.
The updated zones have already been published.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
312 PM EST Fri Feb 22 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Saturday)...
The highlight of the short term period continues to be prolonged 
moderate (at times heavy) rainfall oriented across the TN valley in 
association with an old frontal axis, and beneath the entrance 
region of an upper jet.  The H85 front looks to have been much the 
focus this morning/afternoon for areas along/north of I40, 
especially into the northern valley/plateau and southwest VA.  This 
feature looks to continue advecting northward through the day, while 
the surface front and associated frontogentic forcing works 
northward as well out of northern GA/AL.  With that, precipitation 
should become more showery in nature through the evening/overnight 
as it spreads northward, while areas southward in the lower 
valley/plateau gradually dry out behind the front.  Thus the fcst 
features slightly lowering pops northward this afternoon while pops 
increase across the south, with this region of increased pops 
sweeping northward overnight.  Guidance continues to suggest 
enhanced QPF mainly north of I40 through late morning tomorrow as 
the surface warm front slowly meanders northward into WV/KY.  

All in all, given moist profiles and slow moving boundaries 
additional areal flooding cannot be ruled out given poor antecedent 
conditions yielding continued very low FFGs. Likewise, various 
rivers/streams remain in action/flood stages.  Thus, opted to 
segment the Flood Watch which currently ends at 7AM, extending the 
northern (I40 north) segment through noon Saturday.  Otherwise, pops 
taper from the south to north through the day Saturday, possibly 
allowing that big glorious ball of radiation to show itself once 
again!  Of course, that will be temporary as the subsequent cold 
front approaches tomorrow night. 

.LONG TERM...(Saturday night through Friday)...
Deepening, increasingly negatively tilted, upper trough will be 
making its way from the Central Plains region Saturday night 
through the Great Lakes by mid day Sunday. The system will bring a
close to the never ending moist southwest flow regime as a drier 
mean westerly flow finally develops across the Southeastern U.S. 
for at least a couple days. Showers and even a few thunderstorms 
will accompany the frontal passage Saturday night. A few light 
showers may hang around across Southwest Virginia and Northeast 
Tennessee through mid day Sunday behind the boundary however, much
of the rain will be over before daybreak. It looks like we will 
enjoy that dry period on Monday and Tuesday with some uncertainty 
in the remainder of the forecast. Differences in the Canadian, 
American, and European models concerning short wave energy and 
associated surface cold frontal systems dropping southeast out of 
the Central Canadian provinces will be the reason for the forecast
uncertainty. The current forecast keeps a slight chance for rain 
in this mid week period, with a little higher chance pops toward 
the end of the extended with the possibility of the southern 
branch of the jet becoming more active later Thursday into Friday.
Due to the prevailing mean flow remaining generally westerly 
through the period, temperatures will remain near normal for late 
February through the extended forecast.

262 
FXUS64 KMRX 220734
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
234 AM EST Fri Feb 22 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

Current longwave pattern features a trough across the Four Corners 
region with a ridge extending from Florida into the Great Lakes. The 
upper level ridge axis is just to the east of the forecast area with 
southwesterly flow aloft. Several shortwaves troughs are forecast to 
traverse the area throughout the short-term forecast period keeping 
PoPs elevated. At the surface, there is an E-W surface boundary that 
is located across MS/AL/GA into the Carolinas. Radar imagery 
indicates scattered to numerous showers with best coverage currently 
across the northern Cumberland Plateau into southwest Virginia. 
Rainfall rates have been light early this morning with rates of less 
than a tenth of an inch per hour for most locations. Regardless, 
with the saturated ground, any additional rainfall could lead to 
additional areas of flooding.

For today, a 150-160 kt jet will stretch from the Ohio River Valley 
eastward into the northern Atlantic. This will put the forecast area 
in the favored right entrance region for divergence aloft. At 500 
mb, several shortwave troughs will traverse the area today. Models 
indicate the best lift during the day will be around 12-15z as one 
of the stronger shortwaves moves through with decent frontogentical 
forcing. The higher rainfall totals during this timeframe will be 
along and south of I-40. Starting to see some of this enhancement on 
current radar imagery across northern Mississippi and Alabama with 
this expected to move in around or shortly after daybreak. Higher 
rainfall rates associated with this increased lift, will result in 
continued flooding. Models back off a bit on the amount of lift late 
this morning into the afternoon as the upper jet tracks further to 
the east. Regardless, PW values remain elevated in the 1.1-1.3 inch 
range and expect scattered showers will continue for much of the day 
but hard to pinpoint an area of higher precipitation chances or 
rainfall totals during this timeframe. 

The front to the south begins to surge northward tonight as the 
upper level trough moves into the southern Plains. At the surface, 
the wedge to the east of the mountains will impeded the fronts 
northern progress. The focus for forcing and precipitation overnight 
will be across the northern Cumberland Plateau and southwest 
Virginia to the north of the boundary. Overnight, expect an 
additional inch or so of rain will be possible for these areas 
exacerbating ongoing flooding issues. Further to the south, rain 
chances will actually begin to decrease as the front moves 
northward. Overnight temperatures should remain rather steady and 
will even rise slightly across southern portions of the area with 
lows in the upper 40s and low 50s for most locations.

.LONG TERM...(Friday through Thursday)...

Frontal boundary that has been the focus for widespread showers 
should be lifting northward around the TN/KY border. Most of the 
Eastern Tennessee Valley should see a decent break in the rain on 
Saturday afternoon into the evening. However, another round of rain 
will quickly come in from the west as a low moves across the Great 
Lakes region and sweeps a cold front through the area Saturday and 
into Sunday. Ahead of the front a strong southerly/southwesterly low 
level jet will ramp up over the area. Core of the jet will likely 
have winds around 50-60 knots. This will cause gusty conditions, 
especially in the higher terrain near the core of the jet. Even if 
winds at the surface don't get that strong we could see some damage 
to trees due to all the rain saturating the soil.

Another factor to watch with this front will be the possibility for 
thunderstorms Saturday into Sunday. Stronger storms will likely be 
ongoing across Middle Tennessee and will eventually make their way 
into the Eastern Tennessee Valley Saturday night. Severe weather 
parameters don't really line up too well in our area, but if storms 
are able to maintain strength across Middlle Tennessee they could 
tap into the low level jet and bring damaging winds down towards the 
surface. Confidence is relatively low for a severe threat, but will 
want to keep an eye on this aspect of the system.

Once the front finally moves through colder and (FINALLY) drier 
weather will set up for several days. Semi-zonal flow sets up 
through the middle of the week, and precipitation chances stay at 
bay until the second half of the upcoming work week. A weak system 
looks to zip across the area Wednesday/Thursday, but at this time 
QPF amounts look pretty light. Hopefully the second half of the 7-
day forecast gives everyone a chance to dry out.

.DISCUSSION...
Satellite and radar show increasing convection over northern
Mississippi and Alabama. This activity is located along elevated

the right entrance region of the upper jet. SPC Meso-analysis
shows strong moisture transport into this boundary with PWs of 1.4
inches or more south of the boundary. 

High resolution models depict a band of moderate to heavy rain 
with embedded thunder intensifying along the Alabama/Tennessee 
state-line and move east northeast into the southern half of 
Tennessee early Friday morning the moving over the rest of the 
area through Friday. 

Given the high freezing levels, favorable warm rain process is
expected, especially over the southern areas overnight. High
rainfall rates are anticipated. Rainfall in excess of 2 inches 
possible over the southern Plateau and southeast Tennessee which 
will cause significant flash flood concerns there.

864 
FXUS64 KMRX 212034
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
334 PM EST Thu Feb 21 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight through Saturday Morning)...
The upper pattern this afternoon is highlighted by deep troughing
out west, while ridging centered over the western Atlantic 
extends westward across the southeast CONUS. With that, weak 
shortwave impulses continue to eject from the trough base over TX,
eventually sliding northward along/atop a quasistationary frontal
axis laid across the TN valley and southern Appalachians. 
Moisture remains prevalent as regional observed/forecast soundings
continue to favor pwats above the 90th percentile, approaching 
daily maxes. The aforementioned quasistationary surface warm front
looks to slowly slide northward through the overnight into 
Friday, with guidance favoring rather robust QPF along the more 
northern H85 front. QPF totals through Saturday morning will 
ranges from around 1 to 1.5 inches across the central/northern 
mountains and foothills of east Tennessee, with higher amounts 
further west topping out in the 2 to 3 inch range. 

These totals combined with poor antecedent conditions yield rather 
low FFG values regionwide, however especially in the areas noted 
above to receive the most QPF.  Thus, opted for another Flood Watch 
that will start at midnight tonight, running through 7AM Saturday 
morning.  Some additional areal flooding is expected through this 
period, which could result in road closures and even additional 
debris flows (landslides) on steeper slopes. Lastly, area rivers 
continue to rise to bank full levels, with numerous forecast points 
expected to reach/exceed minor flood stage.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Thursday)...
A slowly, northward, lifting frontal boundary will still be in 
place across the area on Saturday morning. Models in decent 
agreement that the boundary should be north of I-40 and centered 
somewhere around the TN/KY state line. This boundary will provide 
focus for moderate to heavy rain until it finally lifts northward 
into KY by late Saturday morning/early afternoon. Areas along the 
state line and up into southwest VA can expect to pick up 0.25 to 
0.5 inches of rainfall Saturday morning before the boundary lifts 
north. Once the boundary does lift north, the rest of the day will
be fairly dry with only chance POPs in place for light scattered 
showers as we will be deeper into the warm sector. Highs will 
climb into the upper 50s to mid 60s as a strong southwest 850 mb 
jet cranks up through the day. This will allow for gusty winds 
across the higher elevations.

The strongest part of the jet comes through around 00z Sunday 
through 09Z Sunday. During this time a 60 to 70kt 850 mb jet will be 
in place. A wind advisory will eventually be needed for the high 
terrain and perhaps a high wind watch. A line of showers and storms 
move into the area ahead of and along the cold front Saturday night 
through early Sunday morning. Storms will be weakening as the enter 
our area from out of middle TN as instability isn't that impressive 
across our area. Though we will have an inversion in place, any 
convection or heavier showers could possibly transport some of the 
higher winds aloft down to the surface. This will be the greatest 
threat Saturday night, isolated damaging wind gusts. The front 
pushes through Sunday morning with clearing conditions by afternoon 
and cooler air moving in.

Drier air in place Sunday through Tuesday with DRY WEATHER expected. 
Moisture increases Tuesday night through Wednesday as a weak wave 
moves across to our south, this will give us another shot of some 
showers but QPF looks light. We dry out on Thursday as the system 
pushes east.

690 
FXUS64 KMRX 210746
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
246 AM EST Thu Feb 21 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Rain continues to be the main focus for the forecast. Currently
the heaviest and most widespread rain is along the frontal
boundary that has stalled out across Northern Georgia into South
Carolina. Depending on where/how this frontal boundary moves, it
will remain the location for the most widespread rain showers.
High resolution models keep the boundary relatively stationary as
of early this morning. But that doesn't mean we won't see rain 
away from the front. Waves of showers will be possible away from 
the front, but chances decrease pretty quickly as you head north 
and west away from the frontal boundary. Instability this 
afternoon looks to be enough, especially near the boundary, that 
we could once again see a few rumbles of thunder.

Rain chances will remain across most of the area, but hopefully
many places get a break from rainfall today, and a brief chance to
dry out.

Shortwave will ride up along the front tonight into tomorrow. This
will mean some of precipitation will move back towards Eastern 
Tennessee Valley. And with little time to dry out from previous 
rain, there is the chance to (once again) see flooding over 
locations that have recently received continuous rainfall over the
past couple of weeks. 

.LONG TERM (Friday through Wednesday)... 
A band of frontogenetic forcing along with PW values around 1.3 
inches will be over the area through the day on Friday, further 
exacerbating the ongoing flooding problems as widespread amounts are 
expected to exceed one inch. A Flood Watch will likely be needed for 
that period, but will hold off on that for now as the day shift will 
have a better feel for how rivers are responding to the relative 
precip lull today, and still have 24 hours of lead time. 

The trend through Saturday will be a northward shift of the greatest 
forcing, mainly across srn KY and SW VA on Friday night, then into 
nrn KY/WV on Saturday. While a very moist air mass will remain, 
Saturday should provide a brief period of lower rain chances and QPF 
amounts. That changes on Saturday night as a low pressure system 
tracks NE from MO to the Great Lakes, pushing a cold front through 
the area. A 50-60 kt LLJ will advect high theta-e air in the 330K 
range, while forcing aloft increases as the jet streak moves into 
the OH Valley. A slight chance of thunderstorms will be mentioned 
this period, and another half to 1 inch of precip is expected. The 
passage of the cold front is expected around 12Z Sunday. 

A much needs dry period with temperatures closer to normal is on 
track for Sunday, Monday, and Tuesday. Model disagreement increases 
after that time, but the general consensus is that a trough and 
upper jet will be moving across southern Canada and the Great Lakes,
