249 
FXUS64 KMRX 202043
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
343 PM EST Wed Feb 20 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Thursday)...

Heavy rainfall is the main topic in the short term period.  
Currently across the forecast area skies were cloudy with 
temperatures in the upper 40’s to mid 50’s.  The warmest areas 
where near the foothills of the Smokys where downslope conditions 
have caused temperatures to warm up quicker than other locations.
Current radar shows a solid band of rainfall from the Southern 
Mississippi valley north through the Tennessee valley. The upper 
levels are characterized by lower heights across the western CONUS
and Plains with higher heights across the eastern CONUS. The main
synoptic feature to note is the potent shortwave trough quickly 
ejecting northeast into the Great Lakes amplifying the upper 
pattern. Closer to the surface, an area of low pressure was 
analyzed across eastern Mississippi with a parent low across the 
Midwest. A cold front extends from the Midsouth low southward 
through the Gulf Coast, with a warm front across southern Alabama
and the Florida panhandle.  

The current band of rainfall has been situated along an zone of 
enhanced 1000-925mb frontogenesis. However, warming cloud tops and
a weakening potential temperature gradient suggests low level 
forcing is beginning to weaken. Further, the dynamic shortwave
trough is quickly ejecting northeast weakening upper level
support. This supports what hires model data suggests, which is a
weakening trend in the coverage of precipitation this afternoon 
and evening. Moisture still remains high with precipitable water 
values in excess of 1.5 and near boundary layer mixing ratio’s 
greater than 8 to 9 g/kg. While synoptic lift remains marginal at 
best, low level frontogenesis and convergence should support 
likely PoPs through the evening and overnight before the boundary 
moves out of the area. Forecast soundings support a marginal 
chance of elevated convection this afternoon with only a few 
hundred joules of CAPE generated by models. Latest lightning data
shows a gradual decrease in convective activity this afternoon 
which matches closely with the latest mesoanalysis MUCAPE with 
better values south and west of the forecast area. However, if 
thunderstorms could develop than this would exacerbate the 
flooding threat with increased rainfall rates in areas that have 
low flash flood guidance. The ongoing flood watch looks to be in 
great shape and no changes will be needed. 

As mentioned in the previous updated forecast discussion, have
extended the high wind warning, and wind advisory through 04Z
tonight. The low level jet should still be positioned in an area
that would support high winds in the higher elevations of the
Smokys. Tomorrow should be mostly dry as a surface high pressure
to the north pushes the low level boundary southward. However,
this high will move back northeast allowing the low level boundary
to begin to push northward by Thursday night. 

.LONG TERM...(Thursday night through Wednesday)...
 

Thursday night a warm front will be lifting northward through the 
area. This is the same boundary that came through earlier in the day 
on Thursday. The warm front advancing back northward is in response 
to the cyclone developing across the Four Corners states and the 
area of high pressure off to our southeast. Models are coming into 
better agreement that this boundary stalls somewhere across the area 
on Friday, providing focus for another round of moderate to possibly 
heavy rainfall. It is very difficult to say exactly where this 
boundary sets up but wherever it does is key to where the heaviest 
precip will occur. It looks like another 1 to 1.5 inches of rainfall 
is possible along the boundary from Thursday night through late 
Friday evening. Areas further away from the boundary will see lesser 
rainfall amounts, around 0.5 to 0.75 inches. We will have to watch 
the boundary location closely as any moderate to heavy rain that 
occurs has the potential to cause additional flooding. If models 
still show the boundary stalled across our area over the next few 
runs a flood watch may be needed during the day on Friday for some 
areas. 


Friday night through Saturday morning there is greater model 
uncertainty regarding the movement of the boundary. The NAM lifts 
the boundary north into KY Friday evening whereas the GFS keeps it 
along the TN/KY state line. At some point from Friday night through 
Saturday morning the boundary does push north and gives us a brief 
break from the moderate to heavy rainfall as we get deeper into the 
warm sector. The break is short-lived though as the aforementioned 
cyclone is moving in from out of the plains along with its 
associated cold front. Southerly winds increase out ahead of the 
front as the 850 mb jet strengthens. Gusty winds likely across the 
high terrain from Saturday through Saturday night. The front pushes 
through Saturday night into Sunday morning bringing another line of 
showers and perhaps a few rumbles of thunder, but not confident 
enough at this point to put thunder in the forecast. Another 0.5 to 
0.75 inches of rain is possible with the precip associated out ahead 
of and along the frontal passage. Storm total rainfall from Thursday 
night Through Saturday night ranges from around 1 inch up to 2.5 
inches.

Sunday through Tuesday looks drier as we are in northwest flow. Late 
Tuesday we return to a southwest flow as high pressure develops to 
our east. Another shot of precip moves in for Tuesday night through 
Wednesday as another cold front pushes through the area.

to 925mb layer. This area of rainfall will need to be watched 
closely for any flooding problems. Along this diffuse boundary, 
moisture remains high with precipitable water values in excess of

convergence along this boundary in combination with upper level 
divergence due to a shortwave trough moving across the Midwest 
should continue to support moderate to heavy rainfall. The best 
chances will likely occur west of I-75. 

Additionally, a strong low level jet has led to strong winds in 
the higher elevations of the Smoky Mountains. Expect these winds 
to continue through this evening before the jet finally moves 
north out of the area by tonight. Based on this, have extended the
current high wind warning and wind advisory through 04Z.

FXUS64 KMRX 200742
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
242 AM EST Wed Feb 20 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
A brief lull in precipitation is occurring early this morning as 
the heavier precipitation shield dissipates and continues to move 
northeastward out of the Tennessee Valley. But during this brief 
break in the rainfall, we won't get to experience much in the way 
of sunshine before the next round begins, so little drying is 
expected to occur meaning the flooding risk will still be
relatively high. That next round of rain will come as a frontal 
boundary moves in from the west this afternoon into the overnight 
hours. 

There is enough instability with this system that
we could see another round of thunderstorms along the frontal
boundary. This second round of rain will also continue the
flooding threat that the area has been dealing with. With the
possibility of thunderstorms comes the possibilty that some 
places could see brief heavy rainfall under a storm... So flash 
flooding will be the primary concern later today into the 
overnight hours. Thus we will continue with the Flood Watch until 
Thursday morning. Precipitation chances will remain the lowest in
the foothills of the mountains where we could see some downsloping
winds keep the rain at bay for a while.

In addition to rainfall a strong low level jet streak will move
across the area today. Strongest winds will be in the higher
elevations, and especially in the foothills of the Southern
Appalachian Mountains where mountain wave winds may bring strong
wind gusts. High wind warnings and wind advisories are in effect
today for the higher elevations of the mountains and the adjacent
foothills that typically see the strongest winds during these
types of events. 

.LONG TERM (Thursday through Tuesday)...
The wet pattern will continue through the end of the week, but there 
is some uncertainty regarding the finer details of the location of 
the heaviest rainfall, as the models are not in agreement. The 
general pattern is that the 850 mb thermal/convergence boundary near 
our southern border on Thursday will push back to the north as the 
Atlantic ridge builds and a trough moves into the Plains. The GFS
favors an axis of highest QPF across our southern tier on 
Thursday through Friday, while the NAM, SREF, and ECMWF favor the 
northern areas. Will lean the forecast toward the latter solution.
Eventually the GFS catches up and takes the strongest QG forcing 
to our north on Saturday. The track of the low pressure system 
across the Upper MS Valley and Great Lakes on Saturday night will 
put us firmly in the warm sector, and with a 50+ kt LLJ and upper
jet streak over the OH Valley, thunderstorms will be a 
possibility. 

These model disagreements lead to a low confidence QPF forecast and 
flooding potential. However, as we have been saying for several 
days, it will not take much rain at all to produce flooding problems 
as any precip will quickly run off. Flooding will likely continue to 
pose a threat through Saturday for at least portions of the area. 

A cold frontal passage on Sunday morning will finally bring a 
period of dry conditions through Monday, with a NW low level flow
and a nearly zonal flow through the mid and upper levels. The 
models hint at a weak shortwave trough passage on Tuesday that 
will warrant a chance PoP returning to the forecast.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
303 PM EST Tue Feb 19 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight through Wednesday night)...

An incoming warm front will continue moving over a low level wedge 
of cold air in the forecast area. The resulting isentropic lifting 
will produce a widespread area of continuous rain over the next few 
days. A number of areas, particularly higher in elevation, will see 
an initial leading edge of sleet from this precip shield, but as the 
air continues to saturate to wetbulb, the sleet will fully 
transition over to rain. A few mountainous areas for some of the 
more northeastern counties could see a small amount of ice 
accumulation overnight.

While the majority of the rain will be light in intensity, we can 
expect a period of moderate rainfall for Tuesday evening as the warm 
front continues to lift towards the north. The second period of 
moderate rain will be early Thursday morning as the rain transitions 
to showers as the cold front moves in from the west. The front will 
be slow to push the rain out of eastern Tennessee, as it transitions 
to more of a stationary boundary and sets up the next round of rain 
that we'll see going into the later half of the week. The current 
system does seem to be setting up more towards the west and north of 
the forecast area. As a result the previous few model runs have been 
trending downward in regard to the total rainfall amounts. The 
potential for flooding still exists for the forecast area, with 
greater rainfall amounts expected for the more southern counties. 
Over running banks of creeks and rivers is possible along with 
ponding of low laying areas and runoff along paved surfaces.

The second major consideration for the short term forecast is the 
high wind threat for the mountains and foothills in eastern 
Tennessee. Strong southeasterly flow will create considerable 
mountain wave and downsloping winds for the eastern counties along 
the Smokey's and southern Appalachian mountains. The winds for these 
areas are expected to increase starting Tuesday night and continue 
through Wednesday finally dying down early Wednesday night as the 
predominant wind direction shifts more towards the south
southwest.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Tuesday)...

A break from the rain is expected for most of the region Thursday as 
the active frontal boundary and associated fronto-genetic forcing 
weakens and shifts off to the south and east. Have held onto higher 
pops across far southeast TN and southwest NC into the afternoon 
where forcing lingers over a longer duration, but these rain showers 
should be on the light side. Temps Thursday will be pleasantly mild 
and could see breaks in the cloud cover, especially along the 
plateau and northern valley through southwest VA. Have used the 
CONSALL for temps.

Showers begin to return Thursday night and Friday as the old frontal 
boundary moves back north and isentropic lift develops associated 
with another surface low forming around LA/AR. Have chance pops 
increasing from S to N Thursday night becoming likely then 
categorical on Friday since the best forcing develops overhead on 
Friday. The NAM pushed this warm front and associated lift north 
into KY Friday night which would give a break from the showers while 
the GFS and ECMWF hold the boundary overhead causing rain to 
continue Friday night. Have kept likely pops as an early estimate. A 
strengthening 850 mb southwesterly jet will lead to PWATs increasing 
to 1.2-1.4 inches during this time, so periods of heavier rainfall 
are certainly possible in any of the showers. 

The above mentioned surface low will deepen rapidly as it moves 
northeast into the Midwest Saturday and Saturday night as the 
longwave trough to the west finally moves eastward and takes on a 
negative tilt. There will likely be a break in the showers Saturday 
as strong WAA pushes the warm front north with temps soring through 
the 60's, but models remain in some disagreement. Have held onto 
likely pops for now. A strong cold front looks to move through 
Saturday night bringing a more concentrated period of rain and 
possibly some thunderstorms with the strong wind field aloft and 
weak instability. 

Ridging finally takes control Sunday and Monday bringing dry and 
cooler conditions. The GFS and ECMWF both show another possible 
system in the Monday night through Tuesday timeframe, but with it 
being day 7 and plenty of time for change, have just introduced 
chance pops.

FXUS64 KMRX 190836
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
336 AM EST Tue Feb 19 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Frontal boundary that will be a major player for the wet week
ahead will move northward into the area throughout the day today.
Precipitation is currently in Northern Georgia/Alabama, but will 
continue northward this morning. Reports from further south/southwest
of the area indicate there may be some light sleet mixed in with 
this early morning precipitation, but as temperatures continue to 
increase after sunrise, we will see predominately rain across the 
area. 

Rainfall rates will generally be light to moderate with scattered
showers today, but due to an abundance of rainfall over the past
couple of weeks we could see some flooding issues over the next 
several days. It's difficult to pinpoint if/when/where flooding 
may occur, but there are likely numerous low lying areas around 
the Eastern Tennessee Valley that may see minor flooding (possibly
as early as today) if a couple of rounds of heavy showers move 
over them. With that being said, there will be a flood watch that 
begins this evening and continues through early Thursday morning.
Flash Flood Guidance values hint that a couple of inches of 
rainfall over a few hours may lead to flooding issues, which again
is possible in isolated locations if they get unlucky enough to be
under a few rounds of storms. Some of these scattered showers 
today may bring with them a rumble of thunder as warmer and more 
unstable air moves in along the front. Instability is relatively 
low, but will mention the chance for thunderstorms in the forecast
for late this afternoon into the evening hours. 

In addition to the rains coming with this system we will see
gusty winds, specifically in the higher elevations of the Southern
Appalachian Mountains tonight into tomorrow. Will continue with a
High Wind Watch for the mountainous areas tonight into tomorrow,
as models are still shifting around the axis of strongest winds
and rainfall with this system. Regardless of whether or not the 
strict criteria for a high wind warning/advisory is met there is 
still a good chance that we see several reports of downed trees 
simply due to how saturated the grounds are, which leads to 
falling trees much more easily.

Finally we could also see a wintry mix of precipitation overnight
tonight into early tomorrow morning in the higher elevations of
far Northeast Tennessee and Southwest Virginia. Warmer 
temperatures with this front will reach these locations last which
means they will remain colder for longer. Model soundings suggest
that a mix of winter precipitation is possible, but also that 
amounts of winter weather remain relatively light. Some locations 
could see a dusting up to a half inch of snowfall and possibly a 
brief period of freezing rain before sunrise.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday through Tuesday)...

The downward trend of lower QPF amounts through the weekend 
continues with the latest model runs, although the threat of 
flooding will remain due to high river levels and saturated soils. 
The timing of the heaviest rain appears to be coming into better 
focus, with Wednesday afternoon/evening, Friday night, and 
Saturday night being the expected periods of highest PoP/QPF. 

Wednesday will open with a warm advection pattern from a strong 
southerly 850 mb LLJ of 50-60 kts. This could produce high winds in 
the mountains and adjacent foothills in the morning hours. The main 
precip axis at this time will be across Middle TN and KY, with 
downslope drying/warming for the central and northern TN Valley. As 
the upper jet and surface cold front approach, we will see a surge 
of higher theta-e air into the area late Wednesday and into the 
night, and PoPs will rise to categorical. Elevated instability and 
upper divergence will warrant a mention of thunderstorms this 
period. With rain amounts on Wednesday night expected to be around 1 
inch (mainly for the southern and central portions of the area), and 
FFG expected to be in that range, the Flood Watch will go to 
12Z to cover that period.

The cold front settles to our south and high pressure builds into 
the area on Thursday, which should result in a dry day for most of 
the area, with the possible exception of the extreme southern tier. 
This does not last very long however, as a low develops in the 
Plains and the Atlantic ridge retrogrades slightly, bringing the 
front and another moisture surge northward on Friday. Isentropic 
lift will produce categorical PoPs on Friday afternoon and night. 
However, rain amounts do not appear particularly heavy as the 
southerly LLJ is not particularly strong. Confidence lowers after 
that time, as the GFS and ECMWF differ in the northward push of the 
boundary, which will affect rain chances and QPF on Saturday. Both 
show a cold frontal passage occurring Saturday night, followed by
dry and air ridging for Sunday and Monday.

FXUS64 KMRX 182027
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
327 PM EST Mon Feb 18 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Tuesday)...

A drier outlook to the short term forecast today with a strong 
inversion in place over the forecast area. Cloud cover is expected 
to become more scattered in the evening, then build back in 
overnight. A few low ceilings are possible for the morning as the 
lower cloud decks continue to build with the approaching warm front 
moving up from the south. The resulting isentropic lift will lead to 
areas of widespread light to moderate rain for Tuesday afternoon. 
Some localized areas of flooding are possible due to the still 
saturated ground, but it looks like the bulk of the rain will stay 
to the west of eastern Tennessee and move north of the forecast area 
into the week.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday night through Monday)...

A very wet but 
overall mild week is still expected with areas of flooding, although 
the flood threat will be less widespread than earlier thought. 
Longwave troughing in the west and ridging off the east coast will 
keep the TN Valley in an active southwesterly deep layer flow 
pattern. This combined with an extremely strong upper level jet will 
lead to enhanced lifting of the copious amounts of moisture being 
transported into our region. The result will be a series of short 
wave troughs and surface lows moving northeastward through the TN 
and OH Valleys along a quasi-stationary front bringing waves of rain 
until a stronger shortwave next weekend finally moves the western 
trough eastward and forces the front to clear our region. Even 
though most of the rain will be light to moderate, the long duration 
will cause at least some flooding of creeks, rivers, streams, low 
lying and poor drainage areas, and basements. The above normal 
precipitation this winter has saturated the soil.

Isentropic lift along a warm front will produce a steady area of 
rain that will lift from S to N across the region Tuesday night. 
Freezing levels near 12 thousand feet, a strengthening LLJ, and PWATs 
around 1.2 inches will lead to periods of heavier rainfall rates, 
but the duration will be short lived as the forcing shifts northward 
rapidly after 06-08Z. Have categorical pops early decreasing to 
chance/likely for the second half of the night. A cold wedge is just 
deep enough for a light mix of sleet and freezing rain in Russell 
and Washington Counties, VA and extreme northeast TN Tuesday night 
before 09Z. A light ice accumulation could occur in these areas. WAA 
Wednesday with the warm front to our north and quasi-stationary cold 
front to the west will lead to mostly dry and pleasantly warm 
conditions much of the day. Have pops in the high end chance range 
until the front to the west and associated fronto-genetic forcing 
brings rain eastward into the region after 21Z. Increased pops to 
categorical for late Wednesday into Wednesday night. The front 
continues to progress faster in latest models, so it now only looks 
like a 6-8 hour window of decent rainfall rates. Have pops tapering 
to chance/likely after 06Z Thursday from W to E. The exception is 
extreme southeast TN and southwest NC where the boundary will stall 
and cause steady rain to persist through Thursday afternoon. QPF 
from Wednesday evening through Thursday afternoon should range from 
0.50 to 1.50 inches in much of southwest VA, the Plateau, and valley 
with some higher amounts around 2 inches across far southeast TN and 
southwest NC. These amounts are significantly lower compared to a 
couple of days ago and are low confidence due to run to run 
inconsistency among the guidance. 

High winds are likely in the peaks and foothills of the Smoky 
Mountains in far east TN Tuesday night through Wednesday. Southerly 
850 mb winds of 50-65 kts across the terrain, strongly negative 
Omega, and a duct function up to 24 C indicate this could be a 
classic mountain wave event. Have issued a High Wind Watch for the 
peaks and foothills of Greene County to Monroe. It is possible that 
an advisory will be needed farther north.

Another wave quickly developing on the active frontal boundary 
Thursday night will bring showers back to the region. Have fairly 
high pops returning to all areas Thursday evening through Friday 
night. The ECMWF and GFS are in decent agreement with this, but 
suspect there will be breaks in the rain during this time as 
isentropic ascent is usually forced northward when a low passes to 
our west.  

After a brief break Saturday, a strong shortwave is still progged to 
induce cyclogenesis in the Plains and Midwest which will move a 
strong, pattern changing cold front across the region. Slight timing 
differences continue among the guidance, but have likely pops 
spreading in Saturday night into Sunday afternoon. A strong LLJ and 
deep moisture ahead of this front, strong fronto-genetic forcing, 
and unseasonably high PWAT values once again will bring the 
potential for a period of heavy rainfall on top of saturated soil.  

Dry and colder weather will finally move in late Sunday through 
Monday.

FXUS64 KMRX 180932

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
432 AM EST Mon Feb 18 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
A cold front is located across the TN Valley along the back edge 
of light to moderate precip. Extrapolation of the front takes it 
to our eastern border around 12Z, after which time all PoPs will 
be removed from the forecast. The difficulty for today's forecast 
will be how quickly low level clouds clear out. Dry air above 850 
mb builds in quickly this morning behind the front, but a strong 
inversion will likely keep clouds in place through the morning. A 
downslope wind off the Plateau complicates the matter, as it may 
cause partial clearing in the Valley. Will have a general trend of
decreasing clouds through the late morning and early afternoon. 
Temps will depend on the rate of cloud dissipation, but will keep 
highs within the bounds of the cooler NAM and the warmer GFS MOS. 
High and midlevel clouds return tonight as the flow aloft 
amplifies, but dry air below 700 mb should prevent precip from 
reaching the ground until after 12Z Tuesday.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Monday)...
Well, we're getting a nice mild mid to late February, complete 
with almost no snow at all, but we're going to pay for it with 
lots of liquid precipitation. The upper level pattern won't move 
too much in the next several days with mean troughing over the 
western states along with the ever present sub-tropical ridge over
the Western Atlantic. A significant short wave trough will drive 
northeast out of the Lower Mississippi Valley through the Upper 
Ohio Valley during the day Wednesday, as a powerful upper level 
jet forms around the periphery of the beloved Bermuda High. While 
the upper levels will be well supplied with Pacific moisture in 
this pattern, a tightening low level height gradient will help 
drag very high precipitable water off the Gulf of Mexico. Strong 
isentropic lifting, along with some thermodynamic instability will
lead to an increasing chance for showers and even a few 
thunderstorms later in the day Tuesday into Wednesday with 
continuation into Thursday morning as the battle front between 
Winter and Spring holds across the Southern Appalachian region. 
This boundary will probably slip just a little south of the 
forecast area Thursday into Thursday night allowing for a small 
break in the action. However, a gradually tightening height 
gradient between that sub-tropical high and another healthy short 
wavelength upper trough appears to pull that moisture lifting 
frontal boundary back across the forecast area later Friday night 
into Saturday, generating another period of moderate to possibly 
heavy rainfall. If all goes well, drier westerly flow behind this 
early weekend system may bring an end to the lengthy period of 
rain. Flooding is still very much a possibility across parts of 
the forecast area with the entire six day precipitation forecast 
indicating the highest totals across southern and western sections
of the forecast area ranging from around four to six inches with 
the "rain shadowed" northern and eastern sections picking up 
around two to three inches of rain. Additional highlights of this 
forecast are a small possibility of a brief period of light sleet 
in the chillier air in the higher terrain across Extreme Northeast
Tennessee and higher terrain across a small part of Southwest 
Virginia later Tuesday night. 

Additionally, at a minimum, advisory level winds are possible across 
the higher terrain later in the day Tuesday into Wednesday as the 
strengthening low level jet builds east across the area with the 
healthy short wave system.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
301 PM EST Sun Feb 17 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Monday night)...

The current rain event looks to persist for the remainder of the
day and into tonight. Due to the isentropic lifting and falling
diurnal temperature for tonight the airmass looks to further
saturate, leading to heavy rainfall overnight. The soundings for
both Chattanooga and Knoxville show some increased convective
forcing tonight, so the chance of an overnight thunderstorm is
possible. Some higher elevation areas in southeastern Tennessee
and southwestern North Carolina could see up to 2 inches of rain
leading to some areas of ponding and runoff possible. The driving
cold front will sweep in tomorrow morning leading to an end to the
current period of rain and rapidly clearing skies. A greater
chance of flooding later in the week due to the increased ground
saturation from the current rain event and more rain predicted
later in the week.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Sunday)...

A very wet but mild week is still expected leading to flooding 
concerns. Longwave troughing in the west and ridging in the east 
will keep the TN Valley in an active southwesterly deep layer flow 
pattern. This combined with an extremely strong southern stream 
upper jet, sampled at greater than 170 kts at 250 mb at Norman, OK 
and Wilmington, OH this morning, will lead to enhanced lifting of 
the copius amounts of moisture being transported into our region. 
The result will be a series of surface lows moving northeastward 
through the TN and OH Valleys along a quasi stationary front 
throughout the week bringing waves of rain until a stronger 
shortwave next weekend finally moves the western trough eastward and 
forces the front to clear our region. These periods of rainfall will 
not always be heavy, but the frequency of the rain through a long 
duration will undoubtably cause flooding of creeks, rivers, streams, 
low lying and poor drainage areas, and basements. Above normal 
rainfall over the past 2 months has completely saturated the soil, 
so all of this rain will be purely runoff with low FFG expected.

Tuesday will start off dry, but a surface low developing around LA 
and MS will bring a warm front and isentropic lift induced showers 
into the area during the afternoon. Have chance pops expanding from 
S to N after 18Z, but have likely to categorical expanding after 
21Z. As the warm front moves into KY Tuesday night and enhanced 
fronto-genesis band sets up over middle TN along the quasi-
stationary boundary, much of east TN, southwest VA, and southwest NC 
will eventually get into a dry slot, so have reduced pops to 
borderline chance/likely late at night through Wednesday morning. 
That boundary and fronto-genesis will slide east later Wednesday 
afternoon allowing steady rain to return to the area. Have 
categorical pops Wednesday afternoon through Wednesday night. A 
strong low-level jet bringing impressive moisture transport, and 
PWAT values in excess of 1.4 inches with freezing levels around 12 
thousand feet on projected soundings from CHA and TYS support some 
heavy rain with warm rain processes at this time. The good news is 
that the fronto-genesis band will be weaker and propagate faster 
across our region Wednesday evening and Wednesday night which will 
lead to lower rainfall rates compared to earlier forecasts. 

A period of high winds could occur in the peaks and foothills of the 
Smoky Mountain chain in far east TN Tuesday night through Wednesday 
morning. Southerly 850 mb winds of 50-65 kts across the terrain, 
strongly negative Omega, and a duct function of greater than 25 C 
indicate this could be a classic mountain wave event.

Not much of a break from the rain is expected Thursday as another 
wave quickly develops on the active frontal boundary with fronto-
genesis, 850 mb low-level jet, and theta e gradient continuing to 
focus rain over our region. At this early juncture, believe keeping 
likely to categorical pops Thursday and Thursday night is the best 
approach.  
  
Differences arise among the ECMWF and GFS for Friday. The previous 
GFS showed a break between waves and temporarily reduced the forcing 
and rainfall coverage Friday, while the ECMWF has shown continuous 
showers. The new GFS is closer to the ECMWF. Have chance to likely 
pops Friday and Friday night for now, but these may be adjusted 
upward later this week. 

There is good overall agreement that the western U.S. trough will 
eject northeastward into the Midwest Saturday inducing strong 
cyclogenesis near MO and IL. This will bring a final wave of forcing 
and strong cold front across the region sometime Saturday into 
Saturday night. Timing will likely change, but have likely to 
categorical pops returning during that period. Gradual drying is 
expected Sunday. Leaned toward the NAM/GFS blend for high and low 
temps early this week and Superblend mid week through the weekend.

FXUS64 KMRX 162042

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
342 PM EST Sat Feb 16 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Sunday)...

The short term period will essentially be part of the primer for 
what will be a long and rainy week to come.

Stratus has been slow to dissipate this afternoon, if at all. The
best erosion of the low cloud deck has actually been in our far
western NC counties where the inversion has had less of a hold on
things. Elsewhere, aside from some erosion due to downslope flow
in southwest Virginia and near the escarpment of the northern
plateau areas, stratus has held tight. Expect to see a slow fall
in temperatures tonight due to this cloud cover.

The main forecast item of concern in the short term is when will 
the rain arrive. The upper pattern tonight and into Sunday is
categorized by relatively zonal flow in the eastern CONUS, with
long wave troughing in the west. A shortwave trough will eject 
into the plains this afternoon, which will be what helps drive
precip forcing late tonight into Sunday morning. The strongest
forcing for ascent arrives just before dawn tomorrow and lasts
into the mid/late morning hours. Guidance suggests the heaviest 
rainfall will be over/west of the Cumberland Plateau region, but 
expect rainfall will be fairly widespread so will go with high
PoPs for this event. As mentioned, this will kind of be the primer
for what's to come over the next 5-7 days. Expect areas along the
plateau and possibly up into southwest Virginia to see rain totals
in the 0.70 - 1.00" range, with lesser amounts the further
south/east you go. Even still, a quarter to a half an inch of rain
can be expected in the mountainous areas.

Going back to the western and more rainy areas for tomorrow,
forecast soundings show just a small amount of positive buoyancy
basically above 850mb. Would not be surprised to hear a rumble of
thunder or two. Not sure it warrants inclusion in the forecast at
this time due to the likely very isolated nature of it.

With the passage of this initial shortwave, expect to see a lull
in precipitation from midday through the end of the period. Rain
showers will surely be present, but they should become much more
scattered in nature as forcing wanes. 


.LONG TERM...(Sunday night through Saturday)...

A very active weather pattern through the extended with deep 
southwest flow due to an upper trough over the southwest United 
States and persistent Bermuda Ridge. Very significant flash flood 
event possible for mid to late next week.

For Sunday night, another jet streak moving across the Ohio Valley 
will place the southern Appalachians under the favored right 
entrance region enhancing lift over the region. This system moves 
out around daybreak Monday with total rainfall around 1 inch or so.

For Monday and Monday night, ridging will build into the Tennessee 
Valley and southern Appalachians producing a period of dry 
conditions.

Main flooding concern starts late Tuesday and Tuesday night. Strong 
upper jet becomes established over the Ohio and Mississippi Valleys 
with strong upper divergence over the area from Tuesday night 
through Wednesday night. The direct circulation around this jet 
enhances the fronto-genetic forcing over the area and intensifies 
the 850mb southerly jet pulling in unseasonably high moisture. PWs 
increase to 1.4 to 1.5 inches which is above the daily climatology 
maximum. Another concern is that freezing heights are quite high 
which are also well above the daily climatology maximum. Layer 
above freezing will be greater than 10kft over much of the area 
helping to produce high rainfall rates.

End result, another round of heavy rainfall over already saturated 
ground/high stream flows will set the stage for the potential of 
serious flash flooding concerns, especially over the Plateau, 
central-southern Tennessee, and southwest North Carolina. Will 
highlight this concern in the Hazardous Weather Outlook and 
Hydrologic Outlook.

The persistent southwest flow continues through the end of the week 
with the potential of additional moderate to locally heavy rains 
for Thursday through Saturday. Overall, a very wet pattern with 
flooding concerns continuing. 

River flooding looks to be a major problem as well from mid to late 
next week, possibly into the next weekend.

.SHORT TERM...(Today through Sunday night)...
The shortwave trough bringing rain to the area this morning marks 
the beginning of an extended period of wet weather that could result 
in significant flooding problems for parts of the area by the middle 
of next week. 

This first system will be moving through fairly quickly as it is 
weakly amplified, with rain expected to exit the area by noon. A
few spots in Wise and Russell counties in SW VA could see a brief
rain/snow mix early this morning, so the SPS will be continued. 
Low level moisture trapped below an inversion will keep cloudy 
skies in place all day. NAM and GFS continue to show a big 
difference in high temps, but the forecast will lean toward the 
cooler NAM given the amount of cloud cover, low level NE flow, and
weak 850 mb cold advection behind the exiting system.

The next system will be associated with a slow-moving closed low 
over the Plains. The surface low tracks from MO to the OH Valley on 
Sunday, lifting a warm front through our area, with the resulting 
isentropic lift producing rain from late tonight through Sunday 
morning. Temps Sunday morning in SW VA and NE TN appear warm enough 
to have all rain in the Wx grids, although cold air damming sets up 
a tight temp gradient along the NC border. As the low tracks up the 
OH Valley, the trailing cold front will move across the area Sunday 
night, bringing enhanced lift that will produce moderate rain 
amounts in the southern sections, particularly SW NC. While 
widespread flooding problems are not expected with this system, the 
0.5 to 1 inch of QPF expected from it will help set up very moist 
ground conditions ahead of the upcoming systems in the long term.

.LONG TERM...(Monday through Friday)...
Predictably better resolution of expected weather is seen in the 
Monday forecast period (where previously we were extending 
precipitation through this period; albeit with some limited 
decrease in pops) where it appears we can go with a drier period 
behind a departing wave. We should continue to see this "better 
model resolution" with individual short waves as we move closer to
the big rain event coming in the new week. 

At this time, model forecasts predict an initial moistening 
southwest flow with another wave of low pressure emerging out of 
the Lower Mississippi Valley into the Southern Appalachian region 
into Wednesday. This is where the atmospheric configuration 
basically stalls out well into Thursday with additional waves of 
lower pressure riding along a stationary frontal boundary situated
over the region. Flooding problems will be the result as the 
deep, moist southwest flow is lifted along the boundary. Tried to 
trim out some qpf in what will likely be an area of at least some 
rain shadowing across the Northern Great Valley into Southwest 
Virginia due to the downsloping regime that would occur in this 
scenario in this region. We will have to wait on future model runs
to better define this event, but it still appears that several 
inches of rain are possible through the entire seven day forecast 
period across the southern and western portions of the forecast 
area with emphasis in the terrain due to orographic lift. Model 
divergence definitely creeps into the latter part of the extended,
but lower probability for precipitation is expected later 
Thursday into Friday with a break in the action before a final 
system moves across the region moving into the weekend. Again, 
temperatures will be too warm for frozen precipitation through 
most of this forecast period.

FXUS64 KMRX 152023

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
323 PM EST Fri Feb 15 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Saturday)...
Atmosphere is moistening up this afternoon ahead of a weak cold 
front that is slowly moving in from the west northwest and 
extends back to the southwest into east Texas. A steady stream of 
moisture is moving across the southern Plains and southeast states
along and north of the front. Lower pressure along the front in 
east Texas and southern Arkansas will travel along the front 
tonight and move east of the Appalachians during the morning 
Saturday. Shortwave energy will increase as well as lift along and
near the front with mostly light to moderate rainfall overnight. 
Heaviest rainfall will be across southeast Tennessee and southwest
North Carolina. Rainfall amounts will be from about one half inch
northeast to one inch southwest. Colder air behind the front will
drop temperatures into the mid 30s along the Tennessee and 
Kentucky border possibly lower in southwest Virginia by Saturday 
sunrise with a small amount of snow or brief freezing rain near 
the border with KY and WV but little to no accumulation. Rain 
chances will be high but drop off early Saturday from the 
southwest to northeast. Low level moisture will stick around 
Saturday and with north to northeast winds prefer to follow closer
to NAM model highs in the 40s to lower 50s.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday night through Friday)...
An exceptionally wet long-term is expected which will come with 
the possibility of significant flooding. An increasingly positive 
NAO combined with a persistently negative PNA will lead to 
western CONUS longwave troughing and eastern CONUS longwave 
ridging over the next week, with a strong subtropical high 
centered in the vicinity of Bermuda. This is a classic pattern for
mild temps and wet weather across the Tennessee and Ohio Valleys,
and local research at our office shows that past heavy rainfall 
events in east TN, southwest VA, and southwest NC have occurred 
from such a pattern as southwesterly deep layer flow transports 
moisture from the Pacific and Gulf into our area. 

The first wave will bring showers late Saturday night through 
Sunday. 925-700 mb theta e advection and moisture flux should 
strengthen in response to a 130-145 kt 300 mb jet streak overhead 
allowing for isentropic lift along a warm front. Have temps slowly 
rising after 06Z. Showers will develop with this lift prior to dawn 
Sunday morning. Most of these should be light. There could be a 
break in the shower coverage mid to late morning before rain fills 
in again ahead of a weak cold front during the afternoon and 
evening. There are some QPF differences among the NAM, GFS, ECMWF, 
SREF, and WPC, but QPF should generally be a few tenths of an inch 
to just under an inch on Sunday with the greatest amounts from the 
southern valley through southwest NC. Have chance pops expanding 
after 06Z Sunday with likely much of Sunday morning into the early 
evening.

Pops will gradually decrease Sunday night as the rain exists 
eastward behind the cold front, and surface high pressure to the 
north will extend just far enough south for a mainly dry and cooler 
day Monday.

Tuesday through Thursday will be the greatest period of concern. The 
longwave trough out west further amplifies during this time with a 
sharpening of the eastern U.S. ridge. This will place our area in 
the right entrance region of a divergent 130-145 kt southwesterly 
300 mb jet for a prolonged period. The result of this strong upper 
level lift will be low to mid level WAA and moisture flux quickly 
returning Monday night and Tuesday with the strongest 850 mb low 
level jet and associated warm/moist advection coming Tuesday night 
into Wednesday. This will occur as strong frontogenetic forcing also 
moves into the area Wednesday from a slowly advancing, nearly 
stationary, cold front. PWAT values during this period will likely 
be 1-1.4 inches further increasing the heavy rain threat. Have 
chance to likely pops expanding from south to north Monday night 
followed by likely to categorical Tuesday through Wednesday evening. 
As an early estimate, storm total QPF from 00Z Tuesday trough 12Z 
Thursday looks to be 1.5-4 inches from southwest VA through the 
northern valley and 3 to 6 inches from the plateau through the 
central and southern valley. Given the persistently wet pattern 
and saturated soil that we have seen most of this month, we will 
continue to highlight a significant flooding potential in the HWO.

A brief southward suppression of the above mentioned active 
frontal boundary will bring a short break from the widespread rain
Thursday, so have reduced to chance pops, before the trough 
amplifies out west again leading to another enhanced 300 mb 
southwesterly jet and resultant low to mid level warm/moist 
advection and lift. For this reason, have likely pops returning 
Thursday night and Friday. It should be noted that the 12Z ECMWF 
does not show much of a break Thursday and keeps steadier rain 
over the area, but it also shows a drier pattern Thursday night 
and Friday, so the pop forecast will be changing for the late week
period.

The only good news about the next 7 days is that temps will be above 
normal from this southwesterly flow pattern, and have leaned toward 
the Superblend for temps.

.SHORT TERM...(Today through Saturday)...
Current obs show that wind gusts in the mountains have dropped 
below Advisory criteria, and that trend is expected to continue 
through the rest of the morning, so the Advisory will be allowed 
to expire at 4 am. Some spotty light showers will be crossing the 
area through the morning, associated with a weak midlevel 
shortwave trough. The trough axis will be to our east by 15Z and 
dry air aloft will bring and end to most of these showers, but a 
southwesterly low level flow will maintain low level moisture and 
cloud cover through the day. A surface cold front behind the 
trough will move into the area from the north in the early 
afternoon, then stall near our southern border with a W-E 
orientation late in the day.

A low pressure system currently over the Plains will track east over 
the Ozarks today and cross TN tonight along the W-E stationary 
front. Increasing isentropic lift over the front will begin to 
spread categorical PoPs from south to north this evening, with peak 
forcing and QPF occurring between 03 and 09Z. Southern sections 
along thr front will likely have the highest precip amounts, which 
could exceed one inch. Rain chances start to decrease Saturday 
morning as the surface low and shortave trough move into western NC. 
However model soundings show a strong inversion trapping moisture 
below that will keep cloud cover in place across the area through 
the day. For this reason, the cooler temps of the NAM are prefered 
over the warmer GFS.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday night through Thursday)...
The battle between the approaching Spring season and Winter will 
be engaged in the vicinity of the Southern Appalachians over the 
long term period as the sub tropical high sets up over the Western
Atlantic around the Tropic of Cancer. Several waves of low 
pressure will ride from southwest to northeast along a quasi-
stationary polar front generating the possibility of more flooding
in our rain soaked region as moderate to sometimes heavy bouts of
rain build across the region with each passing wave. It must be 
stated that there are subtle differences between the Canadian, 
European, and American models with timing and axis of greatest 
lift and deepest moisture. However, it appears the first wave will
be building into the region later Saturday night through Sunday 
night with isentropic lift moisture increasing with the shot at a 
little better qpf across the southern third of the forecast area 
impacting Southeast Tennessee and Southwest North Carolina. This 
wave moves away through the day on Monday allowing for a bit of a 
break in the action. This later part of the extended forecast may 
be the more concerning part in terms of some excessive rainfall as
a long wave trough amplifies across the Western United States 
while the sub tropical high refuses to yield position Tuesday 
through the end of the week. This pattern allows for strengthening
moist southwesterly flow off the Pacific Ocean and in the lower 
levels off the Gulf of Mexico Tuesday into Thursday. This moist 
airmass will be lifted in the presence of a slow moving frontal 
boundary/low level trough with the best likelihood for higher pops
extending from Tuesday into Wednesday night. Some good news is 
that with such a healthy southerly component to the mean flow, 
temperatures are expected to be relatively mild with almost all 
the precipitation being liquid.

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...A low amplitude upper trough 
and weak cold front will be approaching the Southern Appalachian 
region later today and tonight. Winds will be shifting to the 
south and strengthening from mid day through the afternoon, as the
stronger 85h flow mixes down to the surface. Despite increasing 
high level clouds, strengthening late winter insolation and warm 
air advection should help boost temperatures several degrees above
normal and a good five to ten degrees above yesterday's highs. 
Moisture will be limited with this frontal system, but there 
should be enough low level moistening for the possibility of a few
light showers after midnight and mainly on the Cumberland Plateau
before sunrise. Overnight low temperatures will be very mild; 
bottoming out only in the lower and middle 40s north to the middle
and upper 40s south.

.LONG TERM (Friday through Wednesday)...The main focus of this 
part of the forecast will be the precip amounts falling over 
already moist soils. Looks like three waves of precip--Friday/Fri 
night; Sunday; then the big show Monday night through the end of 
the forecast. The first couple of events should each stay below 1 
inch in general, but the big event will likely produce very heavy 
rains over part of the area, and possibly repeatedly for some 
areas. The mid-range ensembles show an axis of heaviest rains over
N GA/N AL/SE TN/W NC/W SC and staying over the same areas, but 
the deterministic GFS/Euro show more active north or south 
movement of the axis over time, so there may well be some lulls in
the precip, but some areas should definitely get some very heavy 
rains and possible flooding. Between now and when this big event 
starts, it will be important to watch for changes in the placement
of this axis and the placement of the associated frontal 
boundary. Looking at the contributing components for heavy rains, 
things are a little more progressive than it might seem at first 
glance--looks like the heaviest rain rates and flash flooding 
threats will generally be confined to one 24-hour period--like 
Tuesday and Tuesday night -or- Tuesday night and Wednesday, etc. 
However, the river (non-flashy) threat probably will continue 
through the end of next week for the places under that heaviest 
precip axis--once again the forecast for this axis may drift north
or south in the coming days--still 5-6 days away. Pretty cool 
airmass over southwest VA some of these nights, but looks like 
almost all precip will be in the form of rain.

FXUS64 KMRX 131958
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
258 PM EST Wed Feb 13 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Thursday night)...

The short term forecast will see our area predominantly under the
influence of a high pressure ridge for the majority of the forecast.
Winds across the area are starting to decrease in magnitude as the
tight pressure gradient resulting from the previous upper level
low continues to track eastward. The incoming area of high 
pressure will bring in a much drier airmass aloft, leading to 
suppressed cloud formation and warming temperatures from the 
increase insolation. An increase in clouds late Thursday will 
signal the approaching influence of another deep upper level low. 
This system, although tracking well to the north, looks to also 
bring a tight pressure gradient over our forecast area. As a 
result, winds over the higher elevations are again expected to 
increase to a considerable degree for a few hours overnight.

.LONG TERM (Friday through Wednesday)...

A mild and wet pattern for the weekend into the middle of next week 
at least. The extended starts out with a cold front moving across 
Tennessee and light rain across the area ahead of the front. Light 
amounts initially Friday. Friday night models show new low pressure 
developing over the lower Mississippi Valley and increased lift with 
a period of moderate rainfall as this slows the fronts progress 
through the forecast area. The surface low will finally shift east 
of Tennessee Saturday. Rainfall amounts expected to be less than one 
inch. After a brief break late Saturday another low develops to the 
west and brings another front through the area Sunday. This system 
could produce another inch of rain from late Saturday night through 
Sunday night. Monday brings another brief break in significant 
weather. Then Monday night and Tuesday the front begins to move back 
north with overrunning and a stronger shortwave with a deepening 
upper trough approaching the area. This will produce some heavy 
rainfall over the southern half of the area. Models show around 3 
inches of rain for the southern third of the area from Monday night 
through Wednesday. This may cause flooding due to the saturated 
ground from recent rainfall.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
359 AM EST Wed Feb 13 2019

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...The upper trough that brought 
the wet weather to the region on Tuesday will be shifting steadily
east with ridging moving in behind the departing feature. Strong 
dry air advection will allow for full insolation and despite the 
cool west northwesterly flow, high temperatures will only fall 
short of typical mid February maximums by a few degrees. The 
pressure gradient between the advancing ridge and the eastward 
moving low will remain tight today, and the strongest winds will 
occur in the higher terrain across Southwest Virginia and in the 
far East Tennessee Mountains. A wind advisory remains in effect in
these areas through the afternoon hours. The low level flow will 
decouple tonight under mostly clear skies allowing low 
temperatures to drop to the middle and upper 20s north to the 
lower 30s south.

.LONG TERM (Thursday through Tuesday)...This period starts out 
with an upper level zonal flow pretty much across the southern 
U.S., with a surface high in the Carolinas and cold front well to 
our west, stretching from Minnesota SSW to Kansas. A return flow 
from the Gulf is just picking up in our area. Thursday night low 
level moisture increases rapidly and upper level lift starts to 
move into the area. By Friday the aforementioned cold front will 
be passing through and with the moisture and upper level lift, 
precip chances increase Friday and into Friday night. Models tend 
to diverge somewhat after this frontal passage, but there is 
agreement that from the weekend and into early next week it will 
be an unsettled pattern with numerous chances for precip. Looks 
like airmass over NE Tenn and SW VA might be cold enough for some 
wintry precip Monday night into Tuesday morning, but when the bulk
of the precip comes in with this system around Tuesday it should 
be all rain as a lot of warm air streams northward. We will need 
to watch this system for another possible round of heavy rains 
early next week.

767 
FXUS64 KMRX 121956
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
256 PM EST Tue Feb 12 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Wednesday)...

Widespread rainfall currently across the forecast area ahead of an 
advancing cold front. The cold front is located from near Toledo, OH 
southward to Nashville, TN to near Houston, TX. In the upper levels, 
there is a 150 kt jet that stretches from the Lower Mississippi 
River Valley into the Great Lakes. This puts the forecast area in 
the favored right entrance region of the jet. PW values are near 
maximum levels observed for mid-February with values in the 1.2-1.4 
inch range. Due to the saturated atmosphere, lapse rates are near 
moist adiabatic and have only seen a couple of lightning strikes 
this afternoon across far southeast Tennessee and southwest North 
Carolina. Radar estimates rain rates of up to half an inch of rain 
an hour with observed storm total rainfall amounts around 0.5-1.5 
inches. Regardless, these amounts are causing some flooding 
issues due to the already saturated ground. The good news is that 
the precipitation is making steady progress to the east and should
come to an end by sunset for most locations and the flood watch 
will expire at 00z. Winds remain elevated in the higher elevations
with latest gusts out of Cove Mountain still above 50 mph and 
will let the high wind warning continue through 4 pm. Winds have 
weakened over the last couple of hours as they take on more of a 
southwest direction. 

Precipitation chances will decrease from west to east later this 
afternoon into the evening hours as cold and dry air advect in 
behind the departing front. Looking upstream, westerly to 
northwesterly winds behind the boundary remain elevated and will 
continue with the wind advisory for the higher elevations through 
Wednesday afternoon. There could be enough moisture leftover later 
tonight as the cold air rushes in for a few snow showers across the 
higher elevations but this shouldn't amount to much more than a 
dusting or so for some of the highest peaks. Temperatures will be 
noticeably colder by tomorrow morning with lows in the mid 20s to 
low 30s with cold air advecting in behind the departing surface 
boundary.

Mostly sunny conditions are forecast on Wednesday as the low level 
ridge moves into the area. Heights will increase as the upper level 
ridge builds to the west. The combination of weak cold advection, 
insolation, and rising heights should lead to a day with highs near 
average for mid-February with most locations topping out in the mid 
40s to low 50s

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday night through Tuesday)...

Models solutions continue to be in flux and model agreement is 
not good, so confidence in the details of the forecast for the 
long term period suffers as a result especially the weekend and 
beyond. We will start out the period dry as we will be under the 
influence of surface high pressure and some low amplitude short 
wave ridging aloft, then a frontal boundary will push through on 
Friday. This system is expected to be moisture starved, so will 
only carry chance PoPs Friday. Beyond that things get complicated,
as the front is forecast to stall and multiple waves of low 
pressure are forecast to affect the region, but timing of these 
waves and how significant they will be is very uncertain. Right 
now, appears best chances for precip will be Friday night into 
Saturday and again Monday night into Tuesday, but while there may 
be a dry period mixed in there for now will keep precip in the 
forecast all periods given timing uncertainties. Much of this 
precip is expected to be rain, although some snow cannot be ruled 
out at times mainly north/higher mountains.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
330 AM EST Tue Feb 12 2019

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...Strong late cold season storm 
system will shift from the Mississippi Valley across the 
Appalachians through the short term period. More moderate to 
occasionally heavy rainfall expected to move across the region and
therefore, the flash flood watch was maintained for the rain 
soaked northern third of the forecast area through early evening. 
Strong southerly flow ahead of the powerful upper trough will 
require a continuation of the high wind warning in the Smokies 
along with a wind advisory in the higher terrain across Southwest 
Virginia and extreme Northeast Tennessee through the afternoon 
hours. Tightening pressure gradient behind the departing frontal 
system will bring a strong northwesterly flow into the higher 
terrain across Southwest Virginia and along the Tennessee and 
North Carolina border. Therefore, will issue a wind advisory in 
these areas Tuesday night through Wednesday Drier air streams in 
behind the surface cold front this evening through the overnight 
hours. Temperatures will be cold enough for a few snow flurries in
the higher terrain tonight before the precipitation ends.

.LONG TERM (Wednesday through Tuesday)...The extended range 
forecast period looks fairly active and kicks off on Wednesday 
morning amidst the passage of an upper level trough axis and 
associated surface cold front, clearing the way the for rising H5 
heights and surface high pressure through Thursday. This will 
favor dry conditions, a return to above normal temperatures, and 
gusty westerly winds across the mountains of TN/VA where a wind 
advisory will be effective through 00Z Thursday. 

Meanwhile closed a H5 cyclone will dive out of Canada across the 
Upper Midwest states favoring surface cyclogenesis over the Great 
Lakes and northern OH Valley.  A cold front will extend from said 
low pressure southward along the mid MS river and lower OH river 
valleys.  Out ahead, moisture advection amidst swly flow across the 
TN valley will dominate, thereby favoring increasing precipitation 
chances on Thursday night and Friday ahead of the fropa.  This front 
looks to push through Friday evening with high pressure attempting 
intrusion, all while an unphased southern stream H5 wave moves 
across the Plains beneath the left exit region of an H3 jet. This 
feature will traverse the TN valley and Southern Appalachian region 
on Saturday, keeping precipitation chances elevated.  At that point 
guidance features another fast moving upper wave and surface cyclone 
across the deep south on/through Sunday. Temperatures through the 
weekend look to return to below normal levels.  

Lastly, both the GFS/ECMWF favor a deepening/closed southern stream 
H5 cyclone across the Desert Southwest to start the new work week, 
which will eventually advect east initiating surface cyclogenesis and 
warm/moist advection across the Deep South by Monday night into 
Tuesday. However discrepancies in timing, duration, and thermal 
fields yield high uncertainty at this range.

First the heavy rain: As WAA increases overnight associated with a

values will increase, peaking as high as 1.4 inches prior to 18Z

frontogenetic forcing, and upper level support from a nice 300 mb 
jet streak will cause a swath of heavy showers and possible 
thunderstorms to spread across the region. Chance to likely pops 
begin in most areas after 00Z, but categorical pops quickly expand
after 11Z as the swath of rain moves through. Categorical pops 
continue through 18Z before tapering off from west to east. Rises 
in creeks and streams will occur, along with ponding of water in 
low lying and poor drainage areas. This will especially be the 
case where heavy rain fell last week. In between waves of showers,
patchy fog will continue through mid morning due to a lingering 
low level inversion and moist conditions. Temps will slowly rise 
later tonight through Tuesday morning, then fall rather sharply 
later Tuesday afternoon behind the cold front. 

Wind potential: As the 850 mb jet ramps up to 50-60 kts after 
06Z, strong winds should begin in the mountains and foothills 
above 3000 feet. The best potential of seeing sustained winds 
above 25 or 30 mph gusting to 55 mph will be in the peaks of Cocke
County down to Monroe. The time period of strongest winds will be
09-16Z due to the proximity of this 850 mb jet. These elevated 
winds will lift slowly out of the region in the afternoon. A stout
inversion below 850 mb should prevent much in the way of strong 
winds below these elevations.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday night through Monday)...
Models in decent agreement early on, but model solutions diverge 
later in the period and run to run consistency is lacking, so 
forecast confidence is degraded as a result. Colder air will be 
pushing in behind the cold front Tuesday night. There may be a few
snow showers especially in the terrain as the precip is ending, 
but any accumulation should be rather light and confined to the 
highest elevations. Surface high pressure and low amplitude 
ridging aloft should provide a couple of dry days Wednesday and 
Thursday, then the next system will bring a chance for precip for 
Friday and Saturday which should be mainly rain with perhaps a few
snow showers on the back side. Models in poor agreement in the 
evolution of this system, as well as how much drying occurs for 
Sunday behind the front. For now will keep Sunday dry. By Monday 
the GFS is showing a potential snow system, while the ECMWF and 
Canadian show differing solutions but indicate more of a rain 
system. Confidence is very low that far out, and a blended 
solution shows mainly rain which is a reasonable forecast for now.

FXUS64 KMRX 102037
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
337 PM EST Sun Feb 10 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Monday)...

Radar imagery across the area shows that the main area of isentropic 
forcing is shifting north as forecast, with rainfall mainly limited 
to areas roughly near and to the north of the I-40 corridor this 
afternoon. Initial shortwave trough responsible for onset of 
rainfall today will begin to lift into the Ohio River Valley region 
later this afternoon. After its passage, an ensuing rise in both H5 
and H85 heights will be seen in response to a western trough digging 
into the desert southwest. This suggests isentropic upglide maxima 
will will be shunted to the north, with the focus for rainfall 
tonight and into Monday morning lying along the TN/VA border before 
beginning to taper off in earnest on Monday. The latest model 
guidance indicates very little in the way of additional rainfall 
will be seen from late Monday morning through Monday evening. 
Trended the forecast in that direction, but did not dry out the 
forecast completely tomorrow.

The other interesting forecast item of note is high temperatures 
tomorrow. Tonight will be much warmer than recent nights, with lows 
firmly in the 40s across all but the far northern parts of our 
southwest Virginia counties. Continued warm southerly flow will
push highs into the 50s to even low 60s for tomorrow. However the
the most interesting aspect of this is how model guidance
continues to show very warm temperatures in the mid slope regions
of the foot hills and mountainous areas tomorrow. Forecast
soundings do show a marked increase in 900-850mb temperatures
tomorrow afternoon, and surface winds are ever so slightly
downsloping as well. Perhaps this will be enough to significantly
increase the mixed layer depth and warm temperatures into the
upper 50s to low 60s like some guidance is forecasting. Between 
these factors, and decreasing rain chances, it will be interesting
to see the temperature traces for those areas tomorrow afternoon.
In any case, even if they do not climb as high as forecast, 50s 
seem like a sure thing before rain moves back in during the long
term period.

.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Sunday)...

The long-term looks very similar to how it looked yesterday with an 
active, progressive pattern across the U.S. giving east TN, 
southwest VA, and southwest NC rounds of precipitation every couple 
of days. This will add to what has already been a wet start to 2019. 
Two distinct mid and upper level troughs will rotate from west to 
east across the U.S. this week inducing surface cyclogenesis in the 
Plains that will each lift into the Midwest and bring moisture 
fluxes and active frontal boundaries across the southern U.S. 

We start with the Monday night into Tuesday system. The upper level 
trough will be rotating toward the Great Lakes while becoming 
negatively tilted. Its parent surface low will deepen to below 995 
mb as it moves into the northern Ohio Valley by Tuesday afternoon. 
This will force a cold front across our region with the frontal 
passage likely occurring from mid morning Tuesday through about 21Z. 
The latest NAM and GFS have slowed the timing of this frontal 
passage and are more in line with the ECMWF, although the ECMWF is 
slightly slower than both of them. PWAT values will increase to over 
1 inch Monday night to as high as 1.4 inches Tuesday morning thanks 
to strong WAA and moisture advection from a southwesterly 40-50 kt 
925-850 mb jet late Monday night into Tuesday. These PWAT values are 
well above the max moving average for Feb 12 of 1.26 inches. Our 
region will be close to the right entrance region of a 120-140 kt 
300 mb jet streak late Monday night into Tuesday, which combined 
with strong frontogenetic forcing, will produce strong lift for a 
period of heavy rain and possible thunder along and ahead of the 
frontal passage. The timing of the front is not ideal for any 
widespread convection, but a small amount of elevated CAPE seen in 
the projected soundings associated with the strong low level jet 
warrants a thunder mention. I have pops quickly increasing to likely 
and categorical after 06Z Tuesday then slowly decreasing to chance 
from west to east after 18Z. In terms of QPF, I have followed WPC 
which has mostly under a half inch between 06 and 12Z Tuesday 
increasing to about 0.50 to 1.10 inches from the valley across the 
Plateau in the 12-18Z timeframe and 0.40 to 0.80 inch from southwest 
VA through the east TN mountains and southwest NC in the 18Z Tue-00Z 
Wed timeframe. Since the swath of rain will move eastward at a 
decent clip, the duration is not long enough for a flood watch at 
this point, however, rises in creeks, streams, and rivers will occur 
along with localized flooding of low lying areas. WPC has our 
plateau in a marginal risk for excessive rainfall Tuesday with a 
slight risk over the rest of the region. Highs and lows for Tuesday 
will be well above normal, and I have blended the Superblend with 
the NAM12 for these temps.  

Gusty winds above 30 mph will occur in the far east TN mountains 
late Monday night into early Tuesday afternoon due to the strong 850 
mb winds ahead of the front, but a low inversion and southwesterly 
direction should prevent a classic mountain wave.

Wrap around moisture will cause chance pops to continue through 
about 12Z Wednesday across southwest VA and extreme east TN, and as 
temps fall through the 30's in the CAA during the night, some snow 
showers could occur in the higher elevations. Any accumulation would 
only be a trace to a few tenths of an inch. Surface high pressure 
combined with the NW flow aloft will lead to a mostly sunny but 
seasonably cool day Wednesday. 

The surface high will move east Thursday with broad upper level 
ridging returning to the Southeast U.S. ahead of the second trough 
and parent surface low moving into the Plains. This will allow WAA 
to begin, so temps will climb back to above normal levels. Moisture 
flux and theta e advection along a warm front will induce showers 
Thursday night, so I have chance to likely pops after 00Z Friday. 
The system's cold front will cross on Friday afternoon with 
additional showers expected, so I have likely to categorical pops. 
The GFS is a few hours faster with this system than the ECMWF, so 
tweaks are likely throughout the week, and I have utilized 
Superblend pops and temps for this system for the time being. Both 
models show wrap around moisture in the CAA behind the frontal 
passage Friday night into Saturday morning, so have chance pops for 
a rain or snow precip type from the east TN mountains through 
southwest VA. A fairly deep upper level trough and surface high 
gradually building in from the west will bring drier but colder 
conditions Saturday afternoon through Sunday with temps below 
normal.

therefore pops initialize this morning at slight chance levels 
before increasing into the mid/high chance range by midday.  Beyond 
that, pops ramp up further to likely/cat levels north of I40 where 
guidance favors some minimal enhancement in the upglide regime 
thanks to a weak llj.  Finally, pops will lower gradually through 
the night into Monday morning, yet still holding at likely levels 
northward, tapering to chances southward. Given waa, temperatures 
Sunday night should remain above critical levels for wintry 
precipitation, thus all rain.  Total QPF through the period ranges 
from approx .20 over the lower valley with an increasing gradient 
northward where close to .60 to .70 is possible closer to the KY/WV 
borders. 

.LONG TERM...(Monday through Saturday)...

night and Fri. Models are more consistent with an expectation of

psbl Fri night, dwindling to slight chances over the northeast
