018 
FXUS64 KMRX 092044
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
344 PM EST Sat Feb 9 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Sunday)...

A +1040mb surface high is anchored over Michigan this afternoon, 
with cold, dry northerly flow stretching down into eastern 
Tennessee. Temperatures are running 5-10 degrees below normal as a 
result. Dry conditions will continue through much of the night, but 
precipitation will begin to spread into the forecast area from the 
west and southwest by daybreak tomorrow morning. The big question is 
will there be any wintry precipitation at the onset?

Out west, a shortwave trough will be ejecting east across Nevada and 
into the four corners region this evening, and moving into the 
central plains by Sunday morning. Ahead of this feature, isentropic 
lift will spread across the CWA by daybreak, leading to some 
widespread light precipitation developing across the area. This 
precipitation will be high-based, with column saturation existing 
mainly above 800mb for much of the day tomorrow. Below this, a very 
deep layer of dry air will exist, allowing for the possibility of 
significant evaporative cooling through a few hours after 
precipitation onset. The uncertainty lies with how cold temperatures 
will be tonight, and what the resulting Ptype will be tomorrow 
morning. Raw model guidance is notably warmer than MOS guidance is, 
especially for areas around and north of the I-40 corridor. Looking 
at IR satellite imagery upstream, there seems to be plenty of high 
clouds set to stream into the area after midnight. Given this, feel 
that MOS guidance is probably too cold, and trended the forecast 
towards the raw model guidance slightly which still yields near, but 
sub-freezing, temperatures for the I-40 corridor northward. This is 
not as simple as surface temperatures however because BUFR soundings 
show a substantial warm nose intruding into the area from the 
southwest as precip moves in. However, given the dry air, wet bulb 
zero heights remain near the surface for much of the morning. All 
things considered, added in a mixed bag of precip for tomorrow 
morning. Think the primary wintry ptype would be either sleet or 
freezing rain given the strength of the warm nose. However wouldn't 
be surprised to see a few flakes mixed in for a brief period at the 
start.

After all of that discussion about Ptype, I get to say that it 
matters very little because temperatures will fairly quickly warm 
above freezing tomorrow. Highs should max out in the low to mid 40s. 
And given the overall low QPF amounts expected, especially during
the period where wintry precipitation would occur, did not carry 
any accumulation of snow, sleet, or snow.

.LONG TERM...(Sunday night through Saturday)...

An active weather pattern will continue in the long-term with more 
unwanted rain and flooding threats. A long wave trough will slowly 
progress from the western U.S. Sunday night into the upper Midwest 
by Tuesday afternoon while deamplifying and becoming positively 
tilted. At the same time, broad ridging will be over the Southeast 
U.S. with the western edge of the ridge slowly eroding from the 
impinging trough. This will set up an active conveyor belt of 
southwesterly warm air advection and moisture flux across the TN 
valley leading to periods of showers Sunday night through Tuesday.

The first wave of showers will be lifting northward Sunday night 
associated with a theta e gradient along a warm front. Theta e in 
the 925-700 mb layer will quickly rise from 306K to about 315K 
Sunday night into Monday morning from south to north. Impressive 925-
700 mb moisture flux is also expected at this time tied to the warm 
front and theta e gradient with values increasing from -9 g/kg/12hr 
to 5 g/kg/12hr. Behind this gradient of theta e and moisture, the 
rain will likely be more scattered with many places seeing periods 
of dry weather. For this reason, I am lifting the likely pops 
northward between 00 and 12Z and expanding chance pops to account 
for this break. Likely pops will continue across the TN/KY border 
through southwest VA. QPF guidance is rather unimpressive Sunday 
night from this first wave with generally 0.10 to 0.30 inches, 
greatest from the northern plateau into southwest VA. Low temps will 
remain mild Sunday night.

Monday will feature the above mentioned warm front well to our north 
in central KY while a cold front develops from MO through AR and 
east TX. This will place east TN, southwest VA, and southwest NC 
into the warm sector with many areas remaining dry and warm as temps 
surge into the 60's. I have kept chance pops in most areas but have 
some likely wording in southwest VA in closer proximity to the warm 
front. At the same time, both the NAM and GFS project PWAT values to 
increase over 1 inch throughout the day, so any showers will contain 
heavy downpours.

As a surface low moves from the Plains into the Great Lakes Monday 
night, the cold front will move through middle TN then into our 
area. The latest NAM and GFS are faster with this front than 
previous runs, so I have likely pops returning to all areas quickly 
Monday night. PWAT values look to be up to 1.5 inches Monday night 
through Tuesday morning which is well above the max moving average 
of 1.26 inches for Feb 12. This will lead to heavy rainfall. QPF 
from the NAM and GFS is generally 1-2 inches Monday night through 
Tuesday with the greatest amounts around the plateau. The SREF is a 
little lighter. I went with a WPC blend which generally brings 0.50 
to 1.25 inches between 00Z and 12Z Tuesday with some additional 
amounts through 18Z. Storm total QPF from 12Z Sunday through 00Z 
Wednesday is about 1 to 2.25 inches. The wild card will be any 
convection that can develop. Diurnal timing of this cold front is 
not very favorable for thunderstorms, but a couple hundred joules of 
CAPE, lift associated with a 120-140 kt 300 mb jet moving near the 
region, strong frontogenesis, high PWATs, and mid level lapse rates 
above 5-6 C/KM will support a thunder mention with periods of heavy 
rain. This would cause localized swaths of heavier QPF. Creaks, 
streams, and rivers could quickly rise in all areas, so I will 
continue to mention the flood threat in the HWO. 

The cold front and associated rain should be moving east of the 
region after 18Z Tuesday, so pops will taper down from west to east 
with falling temps after a warm first half of the day. Dry and 
colder weather is expected across all areas Tuesday night through 
Wednesday as surface high pressure builds in with a NW flow aloft. 
The GFS shows some possible wrap around moisture near southwest VA 
in the colder air that could support a few snow showers late Tuesday 
night into Wednesday morning, but the chance of this occurring and 
confidence level are both too low to warrant any pops at this time. 

A southerly flow of warmer air will begin Thursday ahead of another 
central Plains upper trough and surface low, but we will remain dry 
through the day. The warm front associated with this system and 
moisture advection will spread showers into the region Thursday 
night into Friday morning, followed by additional showers along the 
system's cold front Friday afternoon. Model timing differences 
exist for this system, so I will keep chance pops in the grids for
this extended range. Drier and colder weather will return by 
Saturday.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday night through Friday)...

A sub 1040 mb surface high will begin moving east and northeast of 
the region Saturday night allowing return flow to begin to develop, 
but a cold wedge looks to persist across the far east TN mountains 
into western NC where northeasterly surface flow hangs on longer. 
Another long wave trough developing in the western U.S. will force 
broad downstream ridging and begin a period of deep layer 
southwesterly flow and WAA beginning Sunday. This will cause fairly 
widespread precipitation to break out by mid morning Sunday due to 
isentropic lift. The GFS and NAM are a couple of hours faster with 
the onset than the ECMWF. It is possible that a light mix could

and across the mountains and southern TN valley, but confidence in

temps look to be above freezing by 12Z, so any mixed precipitation 
would be very isolated in sheltered areas. Continued WAA and

pops most areas. The rain on Sunday should remain on the light side 
with QPF generally a few tenths to under a half inch.

region Sunday night, we should see less widespread activity, 
especially in the southeast TN and southwest NC counties, so I have

VA and in the northern valley. 

The main heavy rain threat from this pattern will come Monday and 
Tuesday. The above mentioned long wave trough in the west will 
slowly be shifting east during this period leading to an enhanced 
mid and upper level southwesterly jet between the trough to the west

projected to be 120-140 kts from eastern OK through the western TN 
and OH valleys by Tuesday which will help to produce a long swath of 
lift along a NE to SW oriented frontal boundary. This will also 
enhance the deep layer southwesterly flow and WAA leading to 
unseasonably warm temps and waves of heavy rain. The axis of 
heaviest rain may end up over middle TN skirting the plateau on 
Monday with more showery type rain farther east due to the boundary 
being a little farther west, but the above mentioned jet energy will 
induce strong cyclogenesis over the Plains and upper Midwest Monday 
night into Tuesday. This will push the front into the region as a 
cold front and definitely move a swath of heavy rain through most of 
our CWA Tuesday, so I have likely to categorical pops most of Monday 
night through most of Tuesday. The latest WPC QPF plots as well as 
model forecasted QPF supports this idea by keeping the heaviest rain 
west of Knoxville through the plateau into Middle TN Monday then 
progressing through the rest of the CWA Tuesday. Embedded 
thunderstorms are possible ahead of the cold front Tuesday as 
soundings show at least a little CAPE with PWAT values around 1.5 
inches. I mentioned possible thunder in the forecast grids across 
the valley and plateau. Flash flood guidance from the northern 
Plateau across the northern Valley will probably be the lowest due

far east TN Monday into Tuesday, but wind direction and speed are 
not expected to line up for long enough durations for any distinct 
mountain waves.

Cooler and drier air will quickly filter into the region behind the 
cold front Tuesday night. An upper level trough aloft and surface 
high building into the area will bring mostly sunny and cooler temps 
Wednesday, but still a little above normal for this time of year.

move in Thursday night and Friday bringing the next chance of

reaching minor flood stage around next Tuesday or Wednesday.

increasing, but right now it looks too weak to warrant inserting 
thunder ahead of the front.

FXUS64 KMRX 072023

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
323 PM EST Thu Feb 7 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Friday)...
The wind advisory will expire at 01Z since the gusty southwesterly 
winds will diminish rapidly after sunset. An upper level trough at 
500 mb digging into the Midwest and Great Lakes with a deepening 
surface low moving northeastward will push a strong cold front 
across our region between 03 and 07Z bringing an end to this 
round of unseasonable warmth. Winds will veer to the west and 
northwest behind this frontal passage with temps falling over 20 
degrees from west to east after Midnight. I used a non-diurnal 
temperature trend for tonight's lows to account for this frontal 
passage. 

A band of showers will accompany this front, and some thunder is 
again possible, however, quite a bit of mid level warm air ahead of 
the front will keep CAPE values very limited. Soundings suggest 
little if any CAPE until right along the immediate front, and even 
then, it is minimal. The band of showers will also cross fairly 
rapidly. These factors should prevent widespread heavy, convective 
rainfall, so I do not expect a repeat of last night. I do want to 
point out that one hour flash flood guidance is only 0.8 to 0.9 
inches from about Anderson County eastward through Hamblen, Hawkins, 
and Sullivan Counties. Although QPF will be below these values, any 
rainfall will lead to rises in creeks and streams.  

Surface high pressure building in from the northwest through the day 
Friday combined with the trough aloft and 850 mb temps falling to 
between 0 and -5 deg C will lead to a mostly sunny but cold day. 
A few slight chance pops will remain through about 14Z around the 
east TN mountains and southwest VA, but the rest of the day will 
be dry. Most highs will not rise past the low 40's with northwest 
winds of 10-20 mph making it feel much different compared to 24 
hours earlier.

.LONG TERM...(Friday night through Thursday)...
The weekend looks mostly dry and cool as high pressure at the 
surface begins to move southeast into the Ohio Valley. The upper 
levels will feature southwest flow aloft as troughing develops 
across the Pacific northwest with low amplitude riding across the 
central and eastern CONUS. Temperatures will be cooler during this
period however this will be short lived as the surface high moves
northeast of the forecast area. Low level flow will veer to the 
south in response to this while advecting a warmer airmass atop a 
retreating colder air mass. While isentropic ascent starts as 
early as Saturday night noted by positive pressure advection on 
the 295 to 300K surface, the low levels really do not start to 
saturate until around Sunday afternoon with low condensation 
pressure deficits. By Sunday night, better lift along the boundary
is noted by increasing omega values, along with positive 2-D 
frontogenesis values. As a result, expect rain chances to begin to
increase as early as 18Z to 21Z on Sunday with most of the 
forecast area experiencing rainfall by Sunday night. 

Better dynamics aloft come into play Monday with a shortwave 
ejecting off the Rockies.  Upper level height falls and strong 
diffluence aloft will contribute to upward motion and developing low 
pressure off the Rockies.  This will strengthen the low level flow 
with an increase in baroclinicity across the quasi-stationary 
boundary Monday into Monday night.  A couple of disturbances will 
ride along the quasi-stationary boundary which will aid in low level 
convergence while theta-e advection begins to ramp up south of the 
boundary. Moisture will also be on the increase as the mean mixing 
ratio in the lowest 100mb increase from 4 to 8 g/kg.  All of this 
will contribute to chances of heavier rainfall Monday into Monday 
night.  Models begin to diverge late Monday night leading to much 
less uncertainty in how the latter part of the extended ends up. The 
12Z GFS has come into better agreement with the 00Z ECMWF. The 
aforementioned area of low pressure will move east through the 
central plains.  An associated cold front will extend south of this 
low through the Arklatex Monday night. Forcing along the cold front 
should support additional chances of heavy precipitation with a 
likely already saturated ground.  Do not want to get into too many 
other details at the moment but confidence in another heavy rain 
event is increasing. Generally, a blend of model guidance supports 
upwards of 1 to 3 inches of additional rainfall through the 
extended.  Will go ahead and beef up wording in the HWO to highlight 
the increased potential for heavy rainfall and flooding.  After the 
frontal passage, high pressure at the surface moves in with cooler 
temperatures and drier conditions.

in that area until sometime around 08Z. Generally have likely pops

half of our CWA with chance south half, then taper pops back from
south to north second half of the night. Outside of these 
showers, periods of drizzle may develop from the central valley 
and points north overnight. Projected soundings from the latest 
NAM12 show a decent inversion developing around 850 mb overnight 
with low level saturation, but winds should stay up enough to 
prevent widespread fog. A very mild night is on tap with lows in 
the mid 50's to low 60's, well above normal for early February. I 
went 1-2 degrees above the MAV and MET blend for tonight's lows. 

Lower clouds should break apart rather quickly by mid morning 
Thursday as warm air advection really ramps up ahead of an upper 
level trough and strong cold front moving into the western TN 
Valley. This will lead to gusty southwesterly winds and sufficient
mixing for periods of sunshine. Record highs are in jeopardy with
mid to upper 70's forecasted across the entire region! I 
generally followed the MET and MAV blend with some input from the 
CONSSHORT for Thursday's highs.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday night through Wednesday)...
At the start of the long term period, a potent shortwave will be 
located across the upper Midwest. An associated 100-120 knot 500mb
southwesterly jet will aid in strong upper level forcing across 
the Ohio valley and Midsouth. A surface low will move through the 
Great Lakes in tandem with the trough axis with an associated cold
front extending south through the Midsouth, and lower Mississippi
river valley. The cold front is forecast to move through the area
early Friday morning with widespread precipitation along the 
frontal boundary. With the quickly ejecting shortwave and 
attendant surface low into the Great Lakes, this will push the 
better dynamics northward as well. Further, this will also tend to
occlude the surface cyclone and weaken the baroclinicity. 
However, frontal forcing, and low level convergence along with a 
moist column would support chance to likely PoPs with the frontal 
passage. Thunder still seems unlikely at this point, and have left
this out of the forecast. Not expecting any flooding issues given
the progressive nature of the front, and location of the better 
dynamics. 

Upper flow becomes more zonal over the weekend with a strong area of 
high pressure moving out of the Midwest through the Ohio valley. 
This results in cooler and drier weather conditions through the 
weekend. As the surface high moves into the Mid-atlantic on Sunday, 
low level flow veers toward the south.  A resulting warming trend 
develops Sunday into the beginning of next week.  In the upper 
levels, the pattern becomes more amplified as a shortwave trough 
moves through the western CONUS. The southerly return flow atop a 
retreating cooler air mass will lead to isentropic ascent over a 
boundary as seen in the 290-300K layers.  An increase in cloud cover 
can be expected starting Sunday as the low-levels saturate before an 
increase in chances of rain Sunday night through Tuesday along a 
frontal boundary.  While it is still too early to get into specifics 
, mean flow vectors oriented parallel to the boundary supports 
chances of heavier rain and flood issues. Again, this is still far 
out with changes likely but will continue to mention this in the 
HWO. Models show less consistency later in the extended period 
temporally with the shortwave trough and low pressure moving across 
the central plains and Ohio valley Monday night and Tuesday. The 
ECMWF is much quicker with the system and brings precipitation to an 
end as early as late Tuesday night while the wetter GFS brings the 
FROPA in on Wednesday. Given the differences, have left chance PoPs 
in for this period.

868 
FXUS64 KMRX 052010
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
310 PM EST Tue Feb 5 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Wednesday)...

The short term period will continue to be warm with increasing
rain chances late tonight through Wednesday. The upper levels
feature ridging across the eastern CONUS and troughing across the
western CONUS. As a result, the region remains under southwest
flow aloft. At the surface, a weakening area of high pressure is
situated across the Florida peninsula with a weak baroclinic zone
across the southern plains and Ohio valley. The trough along the 
Intermountain west will begin to dig across the Rockies overnight 
tonight through Wednesday. Increasing divergence aloft across the 
Rockies will support the development of lee cyclogenesis late 
tonight and Wednesday. The aforementioned frontal boundary will 
become draped from central Oklahoma through the Ohio valley before
gradually lifting north Wednesday night as the upper level 
pattern becomes more amplified. An area of enhanced low level 
convergence along the baroclinic zone should support heavier rain 
mainly north of the forecast area. While upper level support 
remains weak, isentropic ascent along the baroclinic zone supports
chances of rainfall across the entire area with likely chances 
mainly north of I-75, and I-81. Given the weak upper level 
support, thunder chances remain low enough to not include this 
into the forecast for Wednesday. Rain chances gradually decrease 
Wednesday night into Thursday as upper level heights increase. 
Above normal temperatures will continue under southerly flow with 
daytime highs on Wednesday in the mid to upper 60s. 

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday night through Tuesday)...

A relatively rainy start to the long term outlook, as a well 
organized frontal system moves into the area at the end of the week. 
Most of the rain will fall overnight on Thursday through Friday 
morning and will be light to moderate in intensity. The Cumberland 
plateau and some of the northern valley counties could see up to an 
inch of rain. The unseasonable high temperatures will drop in the 
wake of the front and we will be looking at temperatures that feel 
more like February rather than April by Friday afternoon. As high 
pressure builds in behind the front, expect the overnight lows to 
drop below freezing for most areas over the weekend.

The next major weather event looks to arrive by late Sunday to early 
Monday. A warm front out ahead of the approaching cold front will 
bring increasing clouds and warming temperatures along with steady 
rain. The event is far enough out that the models aren't in complete 
agreement as to it's timing. The Euro shows it coming in a few hours 
earlier than the GFS and with a little more moisture content. The 
GFS looks to delay the heaviest rain until Monday morning and keeps 
most of it to our west. Both show that with the orientation of the 
front that most of the rain will fall over the plateau. Some areas 
could see over 2 inches of rain from this system. Under the 
influence of the warm air mass, temperatures will remain high enough 
that no snow or ice is expected.

The timing with the exit of the system is another point where the 
models are not in agreement with each other. The Euro looks to have 
everything said and done by Tuesday afternoon, while the GFS holds 
the rain in place until midday on Wednesday, outside the current 
bounds of the forecast period. While the timing will become more 
refined as we continue into the week it leaves the total rainfall in 
question at the moment.

Will carry no higher than chance PoPs.  Temperatures will continue

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Sunday)...Overall, not much change 
with the long term forecast. Above average highs and lows through 
most of the period. Overnight lows will be warmer than our normal 
highs for many of the nights. 

We start the period with a cold front stalled out from west-to-east 
up across the Ohio River Valley while a strong ridge is centered to 
our south in the Gulf of Mexico. A few light showers may be around 
through the day as weak synoptic lift is in place due to an active 
sub-tropical and polar jet just off to our west. Weak lift and 
residual moisture from Monday may be enough for these light showers 
to develop. Any rainfall that occurs will be very light. Highs will 
be in the lower to mid 60s for most as we remain in the warm sector.

Tuesday night through Wednesday southwesterly flow continues to 
strengthen as the pressure gradient tightens due to an incoming 
western trough. Through this time period, the best chances for 
precip will generally be west of I-75, with lesser chances the 
further east of 75 you go. This is due to the placement of the 
active upper jet off to our northwest. Highs on Wednesday will be in 
the upper 60s to near 70. 

The better jet dynamics lift north of our area on Thursday as the 
incoming trough transitions from a negative tilt to a more neutral 
one. Expect most areas to be dry Thursday with only some slight 
chance and low-end chance POPs in place along the Cumberland Plateau 
up through the KY, TN, and VA border counties. A strong 
southwesterly 850 mb jet is in place through the day and soundings 
indicate good mixing will occur. This will allow for gusty winds 
area-wide with gusts generally around 20 mph and some gusts up to 30 
mph. The strong area of high pressure will allow highs to climb into 
the lower 70s. This is around 20 to 25 degrees above normal. 

POPs ramp up Thursday night into Friday morning as the cold front 
sweeps in from the west. The GFS and ECMWF in pretty good agreement 
on the timing. Both models show the front mostly through the area by 
12Z Friday morning. Warmest temps of the day will be during the 
morning hours with temps falling through the day as cold air moves 
in behind the front. 

Storm total rainfall from Wednesday through Friday ranges from a few 
tenths of an inch across our far eastern mountains, to near half an 
inch across the central valley, and around an inch for the 
Cumberland Plateau up through the KY/TN/VA border counties as the 
heaviest rains remain well to our northwest. Southerly flow returns 
on Sunday and precip chances return.

cutoff low out of the way, will start to stall and become more 
stationary.

.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Sunday)...

a wet pattern for us as trough after trough lifts out of the Four 
Corners into the Plains, tapping the Gulf and Tropical Pacific and
streaming that moisture into the SE. Weak systems will keep 
isolated to scattered showers around until Wednesday, when 
coverage then increases over the NW half of the area with some 
moderate rains. But as troughing sharpens over the Plains late 
Wednesday, the frontal boundary focusing the precip buckles 
westward and places us in an unusually warm regime for Thursday, 
when temps in the 70s will abound beneath mostly fair afternoon 
skies. Then the front passes through fairly quickly Thursday 
night/Friday morning, keeping event total rainfalls at bay. Then a
few dry periods will greet us from Friday afternoon through 
Saturday night, before the next round of Gulf-fed rains try to 
come back into the area Sunday.

FXUS64 KMRX 311957

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
257 PM EST Thu Jan 31 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Friday)...

The short term period will be fairly quiet with slight chances of
precipitation on Friday.

The upper levels feature retreating cyclonic flow across the
eastern CONUS, with increasing heights and ridging over the
Western CONUS. A cutoff low is beginning to move onshore across
California. A highly amplified trough was analyzed across the
northeast Pacific. A fetch of moisture associated with this trough
was moving across the ridge and into the upper plains. At the
surface, high pressure was moving across the Ohio Valley, with a
quasi-stationary boundary draped across the central plains and
southeast. 

The rest of today will feature mostly clear to partly cloudy skies
over a large portion of the forecast area as mid to upper level
moisture continues to move southeast. As the upper level trough
across the east begins to move further eastward, more zonal flow 
sets up across the region. The retreating cold air mass will allow
low-level temperatures to increase under a WAA regime as noted on
2-D surfaces, and model soundings. A weak low level jet will 
allow the aforementioned surface boundary to begin to lift 
northward tonight and on Friday. As the low-level boundary 
situates itself across the Mid south and Ohio valley, isentropic 
ascent will strengthen along this boundary. The associated lift 
will allow for light precipitation along the boundary. Expect an 
increase in clouds on Friday with only a slight chance of rain 
showers mainly north of I-40. Model soundings depict a very dry 
sub-cloud layer which would likely keep precipitation very light 
at best. Given some wet-bulbing effects, some light wintry 
precipitation is possible mainly across SW VA on the leading edge
of the precipitation. Given little to no accumulation expected, 
impacts should remain minimal. This is mentioned in the HWO, and 
an SPS may be needed should conditions warrant. 

.LONG TERM...(Friday night through Thursday)...

Warmer pattern in the extended forecast as southerly flow sets up. 
Higher pressure across the Mid Atlantic and southeast States will 
strengthen with weak warm front moving north of the area Friday 
night. Clearing skies from south to north will still bring 
temperatures down into the lower to mid 30s. High pressure will 
bring a pleasant winter day to the region Saturday with highs 
reaching the 50s to lower 60s. Will follow closest to ECMWF solution 
for the Sunday/Monday period. A weak surface low along the Gulf 
Coast Saturday night and a closed upper low just to the south will 
bring moisture north into the southern part of the area with some 
light rain showers late Saturday night and Sunday. Sunday night into 
Monday models are developing a system in the plains and starting to 
bring in more moisture into the eastern Tennessee Valley. Will bring 
slight chance to chance showers over the rest of the area Monday. 
Still low confidence for the timing of next front for Tuesday 
through Thursday as models tending to hold system back with just 
weak impulses approaching the forecast area Tuesday and only light 
rain showers. The system intensifies by Wednesday but gets held back 
as new surface low develops over the southern plains Wednesday. 
Temperatures will stay mild through the period with highs upper 50s 
to lower 60s Sunday and Monday and then mid to upper 60s Tuesday and 
Wednesday. Behind the front Thursday temperatures will show a 10 to 
15 degree temperature drop for highs and much colder temperatures 
after that. Lows will all be above freezing through the extended.

454 
FXUS64 KMRX 310858
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
358 AM EST Thu Jan 31 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...Today is the beginning of our
warming trend as most areas will rise above the freezing mark!
Southwest VA and extreme northeast TN however will stay in the 
upper 20s to lower 30s. 

Warming is due to the flow becoming more zonal today thanks to the
long wave trough lifting off to the northeast. Weak ridging 
begins to develop and fill in behind the departing trough as the
day progresses. As the trough is slowly lifting northeast, a 
small and weak lobe of energy rotates through the trough base and
across our area, allowing for some cloud to spread in. Areas 
greatest affected will be north of I-40, especially into southwest
VA and northeast TN. By the end of the day, weak southwesterly 
flow in place back across west TN as surface high pressure further 
develops to our southeast. 

Not as cold tonight as southwesterly flow continues to slowly 
strengthen. It looks like temps actually rise a few degrees after
midnight and through day break Friday as an 850 mb jet begins to 
nose in from the southwest. Areas influenced the most will be 
north of I-40. Some cloud cover expected overnight as southwest
flow advects in moisture. 

.LONG TERM...(Friday through Thursday)...Arctic high pressure
associated with a deep upper trough over the eastern United 
States the last few days, will shift off the eastern seaboard 
beginning Friday morning. This will set the stage for persistent 
southerly flow into the forecast area for the remainder of the 
long term period, with well above normal temperatures and a few 
chances for rain thanks to an active/progressive upper pattern.

For Friday morning, one last impulse embedded in the departing 
eastern trough will swing through the Ohio River Valley and into 
West Virginia. This clipper system will help to pull the arctic cold 
front, currently to our south, back north through the forecast area 
as a warm front during the pre-dawn hours on Friday morning. Warm 
frontal passage notwithstanding, temperatures will be slow to rise 
above the freezing mark until right around daybreak. Isentropic 
analysis shows that the best forcing for ascent will be located to 
the north and west of our CWA, maximized from roughly the Nashville 
area northeast into Kentucky. Model QPF reflects this, showing a 
band of precipitation along that same axis, gradually shifting east 
with time from before daybreak through mid morning Friday. By mid to 
late morning, the jet streak and upper trough shift far enough east 
that forcing is lost and precip chances wane to negligible values. 
The main question for tomorrow morning is, will precipitation occur 
while temperatures are still cold enough to support a wintry 
variety? At this point, model sounding show marginal support for a 
mixed bag if wintry precipitation, possibly as a mix of snow, sleet, 
and freezing rain, but quickly transitioning to all rain. That 
sounds bad, but it's worth pointing out that this would occur over 
the course of perhaps 2-3 hours at most, and with very low liquid 
equivalent QPF amounts. In other words, snow or ice accumulations 
will be effectively zero. Same goes for impacts.

Wintry precip aside, temps warm into the 40s to perhaps low 50s 
(south) on Friday as the warm advection regime gets established. 
Confidence is high that this warming trend will continue through the 
remainder of the long term, with widespread highs in the upper 50s 
to low 60s expected for Sunday onward. Despite model disagreement on 
the pattern, all guidance is showing these above normal temperatures.

Where confidence is low is with regard to rain chances early next 
week. Model solutions diverge quickly over the weekend with respect 
to how they handle the evolution of the upper pattern across the 
CONUS. Agreement is good that a southern stream disturbance will 
shift east from southern California on Friday, to Georgia by Sunday. 
Further to the west a deep trough will slide south along the Pacific 
Northwest and northern California coast Saturday into Sunday then 
eject east through the four corners region on Sunday. But the speed 
and strength of the western trough as it ejects east into the 
nation's interior is not well agreed upon at all. Subsequently, 
there is considerable spread with regard to how widespread 
precipitation becomes locally as we head into Monday. For now, have 
some low PoPs for showers in the southern zones with the 
approach/passage of the aforementioned southern stream disturbance. 
Have much higher PoPs on Monday for that next system but fear those 
may be far too high given the uncertainties that exist.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Thursday)...

Visible imagery this afternoon shows skies have cleared as a

out of the Midwest is creating strong gradient winds behind the
front with gusty winds. The upper level pattern is characterized 
by deep cyclonic flow across most of the CONUS with several 
perturbations rotating through this flow. Increasing heights are 
noted across the Eastern Pacific, with a cutoff low just off the 
west coast. Water vapor imagery shows a well defined meridional 
deformation zone to the west of this low. Heights begin to 
increase tonight as the flow begins to become less amplified. An 
area of enhanced upper level winds will begin to move through the 
base of the upper cyclonic flow providing weak synoptic scale lift
across the Ohio/Tennessee valley. In response to this increase in
lift, model guidance increase low to mid level moisture. The HRRR
is the only model that develops any QPF with this across Kentucky
before beginning to dry out as it moves into far northern 
counties in the MRX CWA. As a result of this weak lift and a 
strong surface high across the Ohio Valley, only expect an 
increase in cloud cover with maybe some flurries across northeast
Tennessee, and southwest Virginia. Skies clear out on Thursday 
with high pressure, and increasing heights aloft. Warm air 
advection at 850mb will begin on Thursday with warmer daytime 
highs. Southern portions of the forecast area will likely see

Areas across SW Virginia will likely stay much cooler with the 
increased cloud cover.

south to southwest winds aloft will begin to warm temperatures to 
above freezing across plateau and southern valley early Friday 
morning. Have slowed weak impulse moving in Friday slightly so only 
a short period of snow possible before temperatures warm above 
freezing. Expect amounts to be light. With increased cloud cover 
temperatures will slowly warm into the 40s and lower 50s...some 
upper 30s in higher elevations. From saturday on pattern changes as 
cold high shifts east and southwest flow aloft produces strong 
warming trend. Modified airmass Saturday with sunshine will begin 
above normal trend with highs in the 50s to near 60 south valley. 
Moisture increases Saturday night and Sunday with light rain in the 
south and even warmer temperatures in the upper 50s to lower 60s. A 
deepening low over the plains states moves up into the Great Lakes 
Monday. This system will bring up more warm air from the gulf with a 
chance of showers spreading across the entire region. Light to 
moderate rain showers will again occur. This front will slow as high 
pressure remains off the southeast coast. Temperatures will stay 
warm reaching the mid to upper 60s Tuesday and then again Wednesday 
as the front still has not made it through. There is a possibility 
of a few thunderstorms the last 2 days but have not included any in 
the forecast yet. Also with the continued wet pattern...rainfall may 
become heavy at times.

National Weather Service Morristown TN
406 AM EST Wed Jan 30 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
Another reinforcing shot of arctic air headed our direction. 
Current radar returns across central and eastern KY show light 
snow showers along and just ahead of the front. Models in good 
agreement that the frontogentic lift associated with the front 
weakens as it nears our area, thus eventually weakening the 
returns currently seen. Slight chance and low end chance POPs in
place along our TN/KY and VA/KY border counties through around 
noon to account for the snow showers dropping down out of KY.
Though QPF is light and snow showers will be weakening, put in a 
couple tenths of an inch of snow accum across the our VA/KY 
border counties because of how cold temps are. Slight cloud 
increase also expected with the front, but mostly sunny skies
expected overall behind the frontal passage.

Highs today will range from the upper teens lower 20s near the 
TN/KY/VA line to lower 30s down toward Chattanooga. Gusty winds
also expected this afternoon along with drier air. Low RH values
and gusty winds will allow for near red flag conditions for some
areas. Temps start dropping mid/late afternoon across the northern
areas behind the front.

Overnight lows will be in the single digits to lower teens. It
would be even colder if it weren't for some overnight cloud cover
moving in. Wind chill advisory for the mountains continues through
Thursday morning and the one for the VA counties goes into effect
tonight at 7 PM EST and goes through Thursday morning as well. 

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Wednesday)...
On Thursday the arctic air begins to moderate as the large upper 
trough over the eastern CONUS as well as the parent surface high 
pressure center retreats to the northeast. Highs will likely rise to 
near or above freezing for areas south of the Tri Cities. For 
southwest Virginia and also higher elevations in the Tennessee 
mountains, another day of sub-freezing temperatures appear likely.

In the wake of the cold outbreak, a progressive and active pattern 
will setup over the country. One last jet streak will dive into the 
retreating upper trough Thursday night into Friday morning. Forcing 
remains to our north, but with the last vestiges of the arctic front 
lifting back north through the area early Friday there should be 
enough lift to create some light precipitation. The best chances 
will be over the plateau and into eastern Kentucky and southwest 
Virginia. Still, will leave some slight chances eastward into the 
mountains as well early Friday. It will be cold enough Thursday 
night for some ptype concerns on Friday morning. Do have some snow 
or rain/snow mix in the forecast with precipitation onset, but 
amounts should be light so do not expect much in the way of impacts. 
Furthermore there is some indication that warm advection at the 
surface could begin early enough Thursday night to make this a non-
concern to begin with. For now, will stick with a normal diurnal 
trend for hourly temperatures and a northward retreating rain/snow 
mix during the morning hours. By late morning all rain is expected. 
Eventually the boundary will shift to our north by late Friday, 
bringing rain chances to an end. Interestingly though, a westerly 
fetch of 850mb moisture will likely keep cloudy skies in place 
through late Friday night. Could see a few showers lingering in the 
higher terrain late in the day as well given some orographic 
component to winds above roughly 2000 ft. Otherwise rain chances 
will be negligible after midday for most everyone.

By late Thursday a southern stream disturbance will reside over 
southern California, beneath the longwave western upper ridge. This 
rex block pattern will slowly break down as it shifts east Friday 
into Saturday. The resulting downstream surface pattern will be one 
of persistent southerly flow Friday into the weekend locally, 
with temperatures warming into the 50s and perhaps even 60s for 
Saturday and Sunday. Expect mostly dry conditions over the 
weekend, however the aforementioned SoCal disturbance will have 
shifted over northern Alabama and Georgia by Saturday night into 
Sunday morning. Some g guidance indicates chances for rain over 
the southern valley and mountains on Sunday, while others show 
completely dry weather. Have some slight chance PoP in the 
forecast to account for this, but it's not a high confidence 
scenario given significant differences in timing and placement of 
that disturbance by this time.

For Monday and Tuesday, even greater differences exist in the 
evolution of the upper pattern and thus confidence is definitely not 
high. The GFS shows a very vigorous system, with widespread rain 
from the Great Lakes southward through the Ohio River Valley and 
into east Tennessee for Monday. Meanwhile the ECMWF has very little 
rain. Knocked our PoPs down considerably from what we had, but for 
persistence/consistency's sake I kept some chance PoPs in there. But 
that may be stretching it at this point. One thing that does look 
certain though...no snow.

FXUS64 KMRX 292029
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
329 PM EST Tue Jan 29 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Wednesday)...
Snowfall totals today ranged from trace amounts in the southwest 
and west to around 2 to as much as 4 inches in central and eastern
Tennessee Valley locations. Farther north and east the snow 
started later with amounts mostly less than 2 inches across
northeast Tennessee and southwest Virginia. Higher elevations 
reported over 2 inches and reached above 4 inches in a few spots. 
The main precipitation band has just about moved out of the area 
with some possible snow showers and flurries extreme northeast 
Tennessee and southwest Virginia. Now the colder air is rushing 
in. Temperatures at mid afternoon are in the mid 20s to lower 30s 
with the warmest temperatures in the extreme southern valley where
skies have cleared first and also in across southwest North 
Carolina and southwest Virginia where the colder air has just 
moved in. Skies are clearing tonight and with west northwest winds
around 10 to 15 mph...wind chills will drop to single digits 
lower elevations and below zero higher elevations as the actual 
temperatures drop into the teens with single digits highest 
elevations.

A deep cold upper level low has dropped into the Western Great Lakes 
this afternoon bringing the cold arctic airmass into the Tennessee 
Valley. Tonight a weak system will drop through the Northwest flow 
into the Ohio Valley and spread clouds back into the northwest 
sections early Wednesday. A brief few tenths of an inch of snow 
Wednesday morning before skies clear out. Also winds will pick up by 
afternoon behind this system. Highs should reach the 30s south where 
there will be more sun and 20s north but below 20 in the highest 
elevations of east Tennessee and southwest Virginia.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday night through Tuesday)...
We begin with deep arctic air entrenched over our entire county 
warning area Wednesday night. The anomalously deep sub 487 dam 
upper low at 500 mb will be rotating from the central Great Lakes 
toward eastern Ontario and Quebec during this time. This will 
allow the longwave 500 mb trough over the eastern U.S. to begin a 
slow east and northeastward shift with a 1034 mb surface high 
pressure sliding down into Illinois and Indiana. The result will 
be fairly clear skies and light winds over our region. This 
combined with 850 mb temps of -15 to -20 over southwest VA and -8 
to -15 over east TN and southwest NC will result in the coldest 
night of the season so far. The NAM, GFS, and ECMWF as well as MOS
and MET guidance seem too warm Wednesday night based on this 
environment. Recent research at our office showed that the 
Canadian (CMC) handled recent arctic air well, so I am using a 50%
blend of this model to the previous forecast for the lows 
Wednesday night. This will bring lows down into the single digits 
in southwest VA, northeast TN, the Smoky Mountains, and on the 
plateau with low teens in most of the valley. A pocket of mid to 
upper teens should occur across the far southern valley near 
Chattanooga.

In terms of wind chills, soundings for TRI show 25-40 kt winds 
around 850 mb lingering tomorrow night which should allow for 5-10 
mph surface gusts in far northeast TN and southwest VA with some 15 
mph gusts in higher ridges of southwest VA. The SREF is most 
aggressive with these winds, and I feel pretty confident that they 
will occur due to weak short waves and enhanced jet energy rounding 
the base of the trough over that region. For this reason, I have 
expanded the wind chill advisory across Russell, Wise, and 
Washington Counties in southwest Virginia to cover -5 to -10 deg 
wind chill values. This will expire along with the previous advisory 
at 15Z.

The above mentioned surface high shifting eastward into Ohio and 
Pennsylvania Thursday will allow mostly sunny skies and slowly 
rebounding temps across our region. Again, I will use a blend of the 
CMC and previous forecast for highs to cover the retreating upper 
trough and corresponding arctic air. This will yield upper 20's to 
low 30's across northeast TN and southwest VA with low to mid 30's 
across the valley and plateau and possibly around 40 in the southern 
valley. Increasing warm air advection and clouds Thursday night will 
hold lows 10-15 degrees warmer compared to the bitterly cold 
previous night.

Friday's forecast is still a bit challenging. Isentropic lift based 
on pressure advection on a 300K pressure layer should cause light 
precip to develop in the morning, but confidence on timing and 
amounts are low due to continued model differences. The GFS shows 
widespread precip much of the day while the ECMWF is fairly dry. The 
NAM is dry in the morning then moves activity in during the 
afternoon. NAM12 soundings for TRI project faster boundary layer 
warming compared to yesterday's runs, and alot of dry air will be in 
place. However, lingering low level cold in the morning could still 
lead to light mixed precip if anything manages to reach the ground. 
All areas will warm well above freezing for the afternoon. At this 
point, I will continue with chance to slight chance pops and a 
rain/snow mix wording.

The weekend into early next week continues to look warm and 
unsettled. A zonal flow over the eastern U.S. will give way to a 
western trough and eastern ridge. Temps will be above normal, and 
guidance suggests a series of disturbances will lead to a wet 
pattern at times, but timing differences exit. I am keeping the 
Superblend pops for this period.

FXUS64 KMRX 290911

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
411 AM EST Tue Jan 29 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...Let's get straight to the point. 
Snowfall amounts continue to trend downward this morning based on 
all the latest data. Total snowfall amounts are similar to the 
previous evening update but slightly lower with this latest 
forecast. Generally, it looks like most of the central and southern 
valley will see amounts less than one inch, with some areas seeing 
little to no accumulation. Some lower elevation areas across 
northeast TN and into southwest VA could see up to 1 inch, but most 
areas will see less than an inch. The higher terrain areas of 
northeast TN and southwest VA could see 1 to 2 inches. The high 
terrain of the eastern mountains will see amounts from 2 to 4 
inches. Southwest NC will see less than an inch for valley locations 
and 1 to 2 inches across the high terrain.

The cold front is on our doorstep and cold air will move in quickly 
over the next few hours. Temps are still in the mid to upper 40s 
across most of the area with temps in the lower 30s on the 
Cumberland Plateau. The lowered snowfall amounts are due to lack of 
moisture along the front and the slower arrival of the cold air. As 
it stands, there will be a very small window for accumulation to 
occur this morning as we currently have the precip over the area but 
are still waiting on the cold air. Rain will change over to snow as 
cold air rushes into the valley over the next few hours but the 
precip doesn't hang around for long. The changeover from rain to 
snow doesn't occur in the central valley until 6 to 8 AM EST. Our 
narrow band of precip will likely be east of I-75 between 10 AM EST 
and noon. Snow showers will linger across northeast TN and southwest 
VA into the early afternoon. Snow showers will linger across the 
high terrain of the eastern mountains through late afternoon.

Most areas will see sunshine by early/mid afternoon as moisture 
clears out quickly. Once temps drop, temps will remain in the upper 
20s and lower 30s for most of the day. Very cold temps tonight as 
arctic air moves in with lows in the lower to upper teens. 

Broke up the winter weather advisory into two segments. Areas west 
of I-75 will expire at noon and areas east of I-75 will expire at 4 
PM EST. Winter storm warning and wind chill advisory remain 
unchanged. 



.LONG TERM...(Wednesday through Tuesday)...The gist of the long term 
is that the large upper trough responsible for the cold outbreak 
this week, will shift east of the New England coast by Thursday 
evening. This will allow for a more progressive upper pattern for 
the remainder of the long term, along with warmer temperatures and
a few chances of rain.

Going into a bit more detail, Wednesday will start off rather chilly 
with morning lows in the teens for low elevation areas and some 
single digits perhaps in the higher ridges of the mountains. Suspect 
the southern valley will likely rise above freezing by the afternoon 
but for areas closer to, or north of, the I-40 corridor mid to upper 
20s will be about it for highs. The upper low over the Great Lakes 
will still be in place for much of the day Wednesday. Rounding 
the base of this trough during the first half of the day will be a
+140kt jet streak, being roughly centered over the TN/VA border 
by daybreak. This will be positioned atop an arctic front with a 
reinforcing shot of polar air set to spill into the region during 
the day. Models continue to advertise some light precipitation 
along this boundary as it moves in. Will maintain some slight 
chance pops for some light snow showers, but do not expect much in
the way of QPF so do not have any measurable snow accumulations 
for that time frame. Think it more likely that accumulating snow 
will be seen further north where better overall forcing resides.

Also on Wednesday, breezy conditions are expected. As the jet streak 
and arctic front move through, mixing heights should be sufficiently 
deep to tap into some +40kt winds around 800mb. Would not be 
surprised to see wind gusts of 30-40mph at higher elevations near 
the TN/VA border and especially further north into southwest 
Virginia. As the morning wears on and the arctic front continues 
south, these winds will subside however. Clearing skies and an 
arctic air mass Wednesday night should be good radiational 
conditions and sufficient enough for lows to dip into the low teens 
to perhaps single digits for even low elevation areas. Coldest 
temperatures are likely to be in SW Virginia.

Late Wednesday through Thursday night will be dry but an incoming 
system may spread precipitation back in from the southwest by 
daybreak Friday. Do have a rain/snow mix mentioned early Friday but 
uncertainty in the timing of precip is high, and strong warm 
advection will change that over to rain fairly quickly so do not 
expect any notable impacts there. Another dry patch is expected for 
the first half of the weekend, with increasing rain chances for 
Sunday and Monday.

briefly and then end as some light snow from about 13-16z from
west to east. Ceilings should scatter out around mid day into the
afternoon with the exception of tri where it may take a while
longer to break the low ceiling.

119 
FXUS64 KMRX 282038
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
338 PM EST Mon Jan 28 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Tuesday)...
The short term forecast period will be active with the potential
for winter weather, and cold temperatures. Currently, skies were
mostly clear with temperatures in the 50's. An area of low
pressure was analyzed across NE IL at 18Z with a trailing cold
front extending south through the Ozarks, and into the Southern 
Plains. Regional radar depicts a band of precipitation along an 
area of enhanced 925-800mb zone of frontogenesis co-located with 
the baroclinic zone. The 12Z suite of guidance had trouble 
initializing this precipitation and this may cause some issues
with its raw model output relative to the precipitation field.

The synoptic pattern consists of deep mean longwave troughing
across the CONUS with several perturbations rotating through this
cyclonic flow. While the Midwest shortwave ejects northeast into
the mean upper level flow, a Polar low moves southeast with very
deep Arctic airmass. This Arctic airmass shows up well on the 
GOES 16 airmass product. Closer to the surface, an area of low 
pressure will move northeast this evening and overnight with a 
trailing sharp frontal boundary moving through the Ohio/Tennessee 
Valley. 

Precipitation will likely continue to develop along and behind
this frontal boundary as it continues to move east overnight. A
warm subcloud layer will lead to an initial p-type of liquid 
rain. As cold air advects in behind the front, this p-type will 
quickly change over to snow. While the main synoptic scale lift 
will likely be south of the MRX CWA, strong frontogenesis will 
likely allow for at least a narrow band of snow behind the front. 
While confidence remains low, there is at least a small chance 
that some heavier bands could be realized along the steep frontal 
slope. Another item of interest to watch is the development of a 
weak surface low along the baroclinic zone. Should this still 
occur near the CWA, enhanced convergence could increase QPF 
slightly. 

Probably one of the most difficult aspects of the forecast is
snowfall amounts. This will greatly depend on how much
precipitation we see and how quickly the column can cool in time
before the majority of the precipitation can move out. While
previous models were consistent in QPF amounts, the 12Z NAM came
in much drier. This does cast some doubt in the forecast,
although, it may have initialized the precipitation field 
incorrectly. Based on the latest guidance, and WPC, 0.1 to 0.4 
inches of liquid equivalent seems likely. At least half of this 
will likely be rain. Assuming at least 0.1 to 0.2 can fall as snow
still leads to most of the area seeing 1 to 2 inches with locally
higher amounts up to 3. The higher terrain in the Smoky's will 
likely see even greater amounts up to 6 inches. 

Remember that exact amounts are not important. The impacts will
remain the same with any amount of snow we receive. Hazardous
travel could be an issue especially with the timing of the change
over. The airmass behind the front will be very cold. This means,
what snow does fall will not melt on Tuesday or Tuesday night. 

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday night through Monday)...
Drier conditions are expected Tuesday night as the arctic frontal
boundary moves to the east, however, the coldest air of the 
season will pour into the region. Taking a look at 500 mb, an 
anomalously deep trough will carve out across the entire U.S. east
of the Rockies Tuesday night through Thursday night. An 
extraordinarily deep upper level low at 500 mb will be located in 
the center of this trough over the upper Midwest and Great Lakes 
by Tuesday night with heights of 489 dam progged by the ECMWF and 
487 dam progged by the GFS! This upper low, infamously known as 
the polar vortex, is typically in the vicinity of Hudson Bay. The 
feature will slowly rotate eastward into Quebec by Wednesday night
and Thursday. This is all in response to a massive upper level 
ridge of high pressure situated from the west coast all the way up
into Alaska and the arctic circle over the next couple of days, 
which forces cross polar flow and a downstream displacement of the
arctic air. 

In terms of temperatures in east TN, southwest VA, and southwest NC, 
this will lead to well below normal temps with dangerous wind chills 
through early Thursday before moderation begins. Temps at 850 mb 
falling to -10 to -18 deg C by Wednesday will allow for widespread 
lows Tuesday night in the teens, and WSW surface winds of 5-15 kts 
will lead to single digit wind chills in all lower elevations with -
5 to -10 wind chills in the mountains. Highs Wednesday will only 
recover to 25-30 across the valley and southwest NC with mid teens 
to low 20's across southwest VA, the mountains, and plateau. A sub 
1035 mb surface high near Illinois Wednesday night should allow for 
calmer winds and less cloud cover resulting in the coldest night of 
this stretch. Lows in the single digits are likely across the 
plateau, northern valley, and mountains with low teens across the 
southern valley and southwest NC. Below zero lows are not out of the 
question in southwest VA. Wind chills between -5 and -15 should be 
more widespread Wednesday night from the mountains through southwest 
VA. The good news is that the upper trough lifting northeastward 
Thursday will allow highs to recover to above 30 in many areas. 

Snow chances in this arctic airmass look confined to Wednesday. A 
secondary lobe of vorticity rotates through the 500 mb trough during 
the morning and afternoon. The right entrance region of a distinct 
jet streak (120 kts at 500 mb and 150 kts at 300 mb) will produce a 
swath of light snow across the northern valley and southwest VA 
beginning Wednesday morning, so I have included chance pops as of 
now. The NAM holds onto these snow shower chances through Thursday 
morning, while the GFS, ECMWF, and CMC end the activity by Wednesday 
evening, so confidence on timing is still fairly low. Amounts should 
be on the light side with no more than 0.5 inches.

For the remainder of the long-term, retreating cold air and building 
heights aloft combined with a weak surface low west of the Tennessee 
Valley will begin a warm air advection pattern Friday. This will 
result in isentropic lift induced precipitation. Lingering cold air 
near the surface in northeast TN and southwest VA could allow precip 
to start as a mix of snow, sleet, and rain up there. Soundings from 
the GFS show a warm layer around 850 mb with a shallow remaining sub 
freezing layer at TRI Friday morning, but the GFS and ECMWF are in 
disagreement about how much precip there may be with the ECMWF 
running drier. I put chance pops in the grids with a rain/snow mix 
wording. This will be find tuned in the coming days. Heights will 
continue to build this weekend bringing much warmer temps, but the 
pattern will remain unsettled with rain moving into the area by 
Sunday.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
342 AM EST Mon Jan 28 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today)...

A cold arctic air mass is heading our way, but first a very nice 
January day is on tap across the region.

Strong low pressure was situated over central Iowa this morning, 
with a cold front draped southwestward across the central plains and 
a stationary boundary extending southeast through the Tennessee 
Valley and the southern Appalachians. Meanwhile the arctic front was 
just a little further north across Wyoming and South Dakota. The 
aforementioned stationary boundary will surge back to the north as a 
warm front today as the Iowa surface low moves east into Michigan. 
This is all in response to strong energy diving south into a 
persistent and broad upper trough that has been in place across the 
eastern CONUS for the last couple of days. With the warm front to 
our north and us sitting firmly in the warm sector of the 
strengthening mid latitude cyclone, expect to see a very comfortable 
January day. A well mixed low level atmosphere should result in 
partly to mostly cloudy skies, and temperatures in the well into the 
50s for much of the Tenn Valley with a few locations possibly 
approaching 60 degrees this afternoon in the south.

The daytime hours today should be dry. Precipitation, cold air, and 
all the wintry mess arrives in the long term period beginning later 
tonight.

.LONG TERM...(Tonight through Sunday)...
A challenging forecast for tonight and Tuesday. A deep upper
trough move into the Great Lakes with a series of jets increasing
the upward forcing over the Tennessee Valley and southern
Appalachians. In response, an increasing low-level southwest jet
pulls moisture back northward into the area. There are fairly
significant disagreements in how much/fast this moisture gets
pulled north. The previous GFS and current ECMWF and NAM are in
decent agreement, but latest GFS run is drier. Plan on following
the trend with the models and SREF/GEFS plumes to decide snowfall
potential with this system. 

The jet dynamics will enhance the frontogenetic forcing along a
strong arctic front which moves across the area between 06-12Z
Tuesday. Models show a sharp drop in temperatures with frontal
passage. The precipitation will begin as a mixture of rain/snow
then quickly transition to snow with a period of 3 to 4 hours of
decent snowfall. Will call for 2 to 3 inches over most locations,
except for the Smoky Mountains to southeast Monroe County with 3
to 6 inches are anticipated. Thus will upgrade watch to an 
advisory, except warning for the Smokies.

Snow will end by late morning/early afternoon most locations with
sky gradual clearing from west to east.

For Wednesday, a true arctic front will usher in the coldest air
so far this season. A period of light snow is possible, especially
along and north of interstate 40. Dangerous wind chills are likely
for the higher elevations Tuesday night and especially Wednesday
night. Even the lower terrain will see very cold wind chills.

For Thursday, arctic high will build into the area producing dry
conditions but still cold.

For Thursday night and Friday, arctic airmass will quickly lose
it's grip with more seasonal temperatures. There is a chance of
snow or snow/rain mixture for Friday as warmer air (isentropic
lift) produces lift over the area.

For next week, upper ridging becomes established with southerly
winds developing producing milder conditions. Southerly winds will
increase the isentropic lift produce a chance of rain showers.

FXUS64 KMRX 272015
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
315 PM EST Sun Jan 27 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Monday)...
Clouds will continue to exit the region the remainder of the 
afternoon as the cold front and upper level forcing move away from 
the area. This will allow for mostly clear skies tonight as a 
surface high over the Ohio Valley nudges into the Tennessee Valley. 
The clear skies and calm winds should allow for a good radiational 
cooling night, so I am undercutting the MET and MAV blends by a 
couple of degrees for tonight's lows with generally mid 20's from 
southwest VA through northeast TN and upper 20's to low 30's for the 
rest of the area. 

The surface high will quickly shift to the east Monday with the 
pressure gradient and southerly return flow increasing ahead of a 
strong cold front moving through the Midwest. Low and mid level 
warm air advection combined with a mostly sunny sky most of the 
day will result in a pleasantly warm mid winter day across all of 
east TN, southwest VA, and southwest NC. Increasing clouds will 
hold off until after 21Z allowing for maximum surface heating to 
be achieved. Based on this afternoon's high temps that 
overachieved, the warm air advection, and mostly sunny skies, I am
going a few degrees above guidance for highs Monday. I think 
upper 50's in the southern valley and southwest NC, low to mid 
50's in the northern and central valley, and low 50's across far 
northeast TN and southwest VA are likely. The slowly increasing 
sun angle will help to achieve this. Looking at projected 
soundings, decent mixing will allow for 10-20 knot gusts from the 
south and southwest during the afternoon, especially from the 
plateau through the central and southern valley, so it will be a 
breezy and mild day. Enjoy it while you can because the above 
mentioned cold front is of arctic origin associated with a very 
amplified 500 mb trough that will center itself over the upper 
Midwest and Great Lakes for the rest of the week. This will lead 
to bigtime changes after the warm Monday. More on that below.

.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Sunday)...
Active long range with potential winter weather, and low 
temperatures midweek. By 00z Tuesday, a highly amplified mean long
wave trough will situate itself over the CONUS with several 
perturbations traveling through this cyclonic flow aloft. Long 
wave ridging will manifest itself across the eastern Pacific. A 
deep 500mb 490 dam polar low will be located near the southern 
border of Ontario, and Manitoba. Very strong curvature will exist 
aloft across the Midwest into the Mississippi river valley. An 
area of low pressure will move across the Great Lakes between 00z 
and 12z Tuesday. An associated cold front will extend from this 
surface low across the Ohio Valley and Mid south. 

Models depict the air mass will saturate quickly ahead of the strong 
shortwave as it dives south out of the Midwest.  The aforementioned 
strong cold front will traverse the region early Tuesday with 
widespread precipitation along and behind this front.   Upper level 
support will become maximized between 09z to 18z through upper level 
divergence aloft, and strong PVA near 500mb that aids in increasing 
synoptic omega.  Latest trends in the 00z and 12z guidance show the 
better upper level dynamics shifting further south.  This can be 
seen in 24 hour QPF amounts with higher QPF across central Alabama. 
Further models back away from a nearly upright direct lift response, 
however, ageostrophic circulations still support deep tropospheric 
lift. This leads to less confidence in precipitation amounts, and 
therefor snow amounts. While the initial thermal profile supports a 
rain/snow mix at the onset of precipitation, the column will quickly 
cool to below freezing. Forecast model soundings, and cross sections 
depict a rather deep (~100mb) layer of dendrite growth that is 
saturated. Omega should be strong in the saturated DGZ through 18z 
before drier air quickly filter in.  Snow-to-liquid ratios quickly 
increase to nearly 12:1 or 15:1 as the cold air mass pours in behind 
the front. The strong front will be characterized by strong 
frontogenesis from the surface through 700-500mb and just below the 
co-location of max omega and the DGZ. Cross sections also depict 
another secondary area of low-level frontogenesis that is likely due 
to a low-level convergence boundary.  

Now for snowfall amounts...The above supports a couple of inches of 
snowfall through the day on Tuesday. The newest 12z suite of model 
data paints roughly 0.2 to 0.4 of 24 hour QPF across a majority of 
the forecast area. While some of that will be in the form of rain, 
at least half should be snow. Raw model output would suggest a 1-4 
inch snow range. Further, latest 15z SREF has jumped up with a mean 
above 4 inches, although much model spread still exists. KCHA, and 
KTRI have more uncertainty with regards to QPF and snow amounts but 
have both increased with the newest run.  A couple of factors could 
lead to heavier snowfall rates.

 1) Albeit weak, NAM and GFS cross sections do show some elevated 
negative EPV within areas of saturation between 15 and 18z.    This 
weak elevated instability could allow for higher precipitation 
rates.  

 2) Guidance, specifically the NAM and GFS, have been advertising a 
surface low developing along the frontal wave as it passes through 
the area.  Should this indeed occur, surface and low-level 
convergence could increase helping to increase precipitation rates, 
and QPF.  

Needless to say, the snow forecast is low confidence.  The best 
consensus on todays shift would be a 2-4 inches of snow across a 
majority of the forecast area with higher amounts in the higher 
terrain, and SW VA. It is best to remember that the impacts will 
likely remain the same with hazardous travel expected on Tuesday. 
Due to forecasted amounts, and potential impacts to travel, have 
decided to issue a winter storm watch for the entire CWA.  

Bitter cold will follow Wednesday through Thursday as mean long wave 
troughing sets up over the Great Lakes, and Ohio Valley. 490 dam 
500mb heights will move south of the Hudson Bay area and sets up 
near the Great Lakes.  Lows Tuesday night and Wednesday night will 
fall into the teens and single digits.  Wind chills will also be 
bitter with readings in the 5 to -15 degree F range. Cyclonic flow 
remains over the eastern CONUS through midweek with an additional 
true Arctic front moving south through the Ohio/Tennessee valley. 
This front will be moisture starved, yet enough frontogenesis may be 
available to squeeze out some moisture in the form of snow.  Given 
the dynamics involved, this seems to be more showery in nature as 
low-level lapse rates become steep.  Decent microphysics exist 
aloft, with at least a 1-2 kft layer of supersaturation with respect 
to ice in the DGZ.  Confidence is too low to mention any 
accumulations at this point.  A sub-1040mb surface high glides south 
into the Ohio/Tennessee valley by 12z Thursday. There are some minor 
differences spatially in regards to where the center of the surface 
high will be placed at 12z Thursday. However, assuming we can clear 
skies, temperatures are expected to drop into the teens to single 
digits. It is not out of the realm of possibilities to see 
temperatures in the low single digits should we end up with a 
sizable snow pack on the ground with radiational cooling conditions. 
 Thursday through Friday remains below average with long wave 
troughing still over the eastern CONUS.  This weekend remains 
uncertain but seems to be unsettled with a couple of disturbances 
impacting the area.  Temperatures are expected to moderate during 
this time as well.

349 
FXUS64 KMRX 270829
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
329 AM EST Sun Jan 27 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

A shortwave trough axis, embedded in the larger eastern CONUS 
trough, will approach from the west this morning. Low clouds will be 
on the increase over the forecast area in response to this feature, 
however indications are that a dry forecast is in order for most, if 
not all, of the CWA. Most guidance supports this, with the GFS being 
the wet outlier in showing a grand total of five hundredths total QPF 
today in southwest Virginia. Can't say this is totally unreasonable 
given there are some light returns on radar upstream. But certainly 
am not expecting much out of this disturbance. Previous shifts had 
slight chances in southwest Virginia and south into bordering 
Tennessee counties. Decreased PoPs slightly, shifting the focus for 
any precip mainly into southwest Virginia. Temperatures are a bit 
cooler in those same areas than previously forecast thanks mainly to 
a dearth of cloud cover so far tonight over much of the CWA. As 
such, should any precipitation occur it will likely be snow or a 
rain/snow mix for much of the morning before temps warm sufficiently 
to change precip to strictly rain. However, despite having several 
hours of snow or rain/snow mix in the forecast, QPF will be quite 
light and thus do not expect any snow accumulations whatsoever. 

Clouds will clear out this evening, making for a mostly clear 
overnight period with temperatures once again below the freezing 
mark for most areas. Mid to upper 20s will once again be the norm, 
with low 30s expected further south. The warmest places tonight will 
likely be the foothill areas south of I-40 as drainage or even 
slight downslope winds set up. 

.LONG TERM...(Monday through Sunday)...

Main weather feature is baroclinic wave that moves across the 
late Monday night and Tuesday producing widespread precipitation. 
Also, arctic front that moves through the area Wednesday morning.

Best day during the extended period will be Monday. For Monday, 
ridging aloft and increasing southwest winds will produce a dry and 
mild day. Increasing cloudiness is expected as southwest winds pull 
moisture back into the Tennessee Valley. Breezy conditions can be
expected over the ridges and mountains. 

For Monday Night and Tuesday, a depending upper long-wave trough 
will dive into the northern plains and Great Lakes region. This 
will pull the first series of cold fronts into the Tennessee 
Valley and southern Appalachians. Models in reasonable agreement 
in pulling Gulf moisture into the area in response to the dynamic 
upper jet forcing. Strong fronto-genetic forcing is depicted along
the front late Monday night and Tuesday morning. The latest runs 
are pulling the front earlier into the area.

Initially the vertical temperature profile will be too warm for 
snow, except for the highest elevations. The light rain produced by 
the isentropic lift Monday night will be mainly rain, but as the 
strong frontal boundary moves through between 09-15Z, the rain will 
quickly transition to snow. Deep lift is noted for about 3 hours so 
do expect accumulating snows with the greatest snowfall in the 
mountains. 

Currently thinking of around 2 inches (give or take 1/2 inch) over 
most of the area, expect 3 to 6 inches across the higher elevations, 
such as High Knob, Smoky Mountains, and Roane Mountain. Still a 
little early to issue an advisory/watch, but will include into the 
HWO and SPS.

The snow will come to an end by late morning through mid-afternoon 
Tuesday with decreasing clouds. 

For Tuesday night, dry conditions are expected except for the far
east Tennessee Mountains where light snow/flurries are possible. 

For Wednesday, models show a true arctic front moving across the 
area. These type of cold air advection behind the front will squeeze 
out the lift over moisture across the region. Also, northwest flow 
will produce some orographic enhance lift in the Mountains. 
Currently going for low chance PoPs, but would not be surprised if 
we need to call for widespread light snow/flurries for much of 
Wednesday.

Very cold arctic air will be the main concern for mid-week with 
dangerous wind chills, especially for the higher terrain. The snow 
on the ground will also enhance the radiational cooling conditions 
for Wednesday night/Thursday morning.

For Thursday afternoon and Thursday night, a moderation in the 
arctic air is expected. 

For Friday, another system diving southeast from the Plains into the 
Ohio/Tennessee Valley could produce another round of wintry 
precipitation. Confidence is low on the evolution of the system.

For Saturday, upper trough lifts out with milder conditions 
returning for the Tennessee Valley and southern Appalachians.
