853 
FXUS64 KMRX 262010
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
310 PM EST Sat Jan 26 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Sunday)...
The rest of this afternoon into most of tonight is a break between 
systems. Shortwave ridging and weak warm air advection in the 850-
700 mb layer has led to a milder afternoon, and this will also keep 
low temps quite a bit warmer compared to last night with upper 20's 
to near 30 in southwest VA and northeast TN and mainly low 30's 
across the valley and plateau. Increasing clouds after 06Z will also 
aid in the insolation process as a cold front approaches from the 
west. This front is the result of a low pressure system passing from 
Indiana into the lower Great Lakes during the night. According to 
the latest NAM soundings, moisture depth with this front is lacking 
compared to what was shown yesterday. Expect the cold front to cross 
the region between 12 and 16Z, but due to moisture in the 09-18Z 
time frame generally confined to around 850 mb, widespread precip is 
not likely, so slight chance pops will cover this. These pops will 
be confined to the northern Plateau, northern valley, and southwest 
VA between 12 and 18Z. Moisture is deeper near TRI, so the greatest 
pops will be across extreme northeast TN and southwest VA. Any 
showers in this region will be a mix of rain and snow as 850 mb 
temps will be between -2 and -5 degrees C with surface temps 
struggling to get above the mid to upper 30's. Snowfall amounts in 
southwest VA will be a trace to a tenth at most. The precip chances 
should quickly exit the entire region after 18Z with cloud cover 
gradually beginning to thin. The central and southern valley will 
see the greatest rise in temps tomorrow afternoon with mid to upper 
40's still likely.

.LONG TERM...(Sunday night through Saturday)...
The long term period remains active with wintry precipitation and
very cold temperatures. The upper level pattern will remain 
highly amplified with a broad trough situated across the CONUS 
centered along and just south of Hudson Bay. A shortwave will dive
out of Canada late Sunday night which will drive an area of low 
pressure and associated cold front into the Plains, and Ohio 
valley. Another shortwave will traverse the Gulf Coast before 
lifting across the Eastern seaboard. Models are in decent 
agreement with the overall pattern and strength of the synoptic 
features. Monday is forecast to be dry as low-level winds begin to
back toward the southwest and 850mb temperatures begin to climb 
slowly ahead of the shortwave trough that will dig into the 
Midwest. Behind the northern shortwave, a deep upper level low 
will quickly dive south out of Canada and begin to phase this 
shortwave. Some minor differences still exist in regards to the 
depth of this eventual long wave trough. The 00z/12z ECMWF has 
come in much deeper with the jet streak just south of the Gulf 
Coast. The GFS is not as deep with the upper-level jet streak 
across central MS/AL/GA. Nonetheless, the region will be under 
deep cyclonic flow. Closer to the surface, the aforementioned 
surface low will travel through the Great Lakes Monday and 
Tuesday. A trailing cold front will approach from the west Monday 
night into Tuesday. Behind this frontal boundary, deep Arctic air 
will quickly filter in behind with increasing pressure to the 
west. 

As mentioned previously, the upper-level pattern will feature a 
strong jet streak rounding the base of the deep trough axis.  As a 
result, divergence will increase which will aid in lift across the 
region.  Deep moisture will be in place immediately along and behind 
the surface front.  Widespread precipitation will develop as a 
result of the increased divergence and deep moisture.  Model cross 
sections still show deep lift associated with the favorable dynamics 
aloft and strong positive omega values extending through the low and 
mid levels of the atmosphere.  Further, the strong omega values can 
be attributed to the strength of vorticity advection in the mid 
levels.  2-D plane and cross sections show very strong frontogenesis 
values along the Arctic front with a steeply sloped frontal zone 
extending from the surface to 500mb.  It will be a combination of 
upper level dynamics, and low-mid level frontogenesis that will lead 
to widespread and at times, heavy precipitation. Cold air will 
quickly filter in behind the front with strong CAA. 1000-500mb 
thickness values crash to as low as 520-530 dam with 850mb 
temperatures as low as -5 to -15 degree C during the time of the 
precipitation.   Precipitation will likely start out as liquid rain 
as the lower troposphere will likely remain above freezing briefly. 
However, this will not last long as rain will quickly turn to snow 
with very strong CAA in the lower levels of the atmosphere.  

Snow amounts are still difficult to pinpoint this far out with some 
model differences still apparent.  However, with the degree of 
moisture and omega values in the -12 to -18 degree C layer, 
dendritic growth will become maximized between 12 to 18Z Tuesday. 
The strength of dynamics aloft in combination with strong low-level 
frontogenesis forcing supports moderate to heavy precipitation 
falling as well.  The cold air in place will mean that SLR's will 
likely be higher than climatology (12:1 to 15:1).  The limited 
factor is the window of precipitation will be short lived.  Models 
are all in decent agreement in regards to snow amounts.  1-3 inches 
of snowfall looks likely for the majority of the area with higher 
amounts up to 4 inches in the higher terrain.  It is important to 
realize that regardless of specific amounts, impacts will be similar 
with the cold air moving in.  Icy and hazardous travel may become an 
issue across the entire area Tuesday.  

Precipitation will quickly come to an end Tuesday afternoon. 
Temperatures will continue to fall Tuesday night.  With 850mb 
temperatures in -10 to -15 degree C range, minimum temperatures will 
likely fall into the teens to single digits.  If we do end up with 
accumulating snow on the ground, then expect surface temperatures to 
be even colder then what guidance is advertising.  Wind chills could 
be below 0 Tuesday night as high pressure quickly builds to the 
west.  The higher terrain could see wind chills as low as -15 at 
times.  Global models are both suggesting additional chances of snow 
showers Wednesday along the sharp Arctic front.  How far south this 
band of snow ends up is still in question. Temperatures on Wednesday 
and Wednesday night will continue to be below average. Strong high 
pressure will meander through the Ohio valley Thursday before winds 
begin to back toward the southwest ahead of a developing low 
pressure system across the Plains.  A slight warming trend will be 
possible Friday and into the weekend.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

Temperatures were in the 20s across the forecast area early this

cirrus has been streaming overhead much of the night thus far. 
This may prevent morning lows in the teens from being observed, 
but it will be close. After a chilly start, expect to see
temperatures rebound into the 40s for much of the lower elevation
areas, with upper 30s in portions of southwest Virginia.

To our west, regional radar imagery shows some light returns 
stretching from central Kentucky southward into middle Tennessee 
early this morning. Not much is showing on surface observations, 
although there has been some light snow reported around the Bowling 
Green area. This is all associated with shortwave energy that is 
moving through that region at this time. Guidance indicates this 
feature will shift east of the forecast area by shortly after 
daybreak. Would not be totally surprised to see some flurries in 
southwest Virginia this morning, but in large part forcing 
mechanisms favor any precipitation being mostly north of our CWA. As 
such, continued to advertise a dry forecast, with only an increase 
in cloud cover today as this shortwave moves overhead. 

Clouds will shift well east of the area this evening and
overnight. However do not expect temperatures to be quite as cold
as recent nights, with upper 20s to low 30s expected.

.LONG TERM...(Sunday through Saturday)...

The main feature through most of the extended will be a deep 
long-wave upper trough over southern Canada into the eastern 
United States. 

For Saturday night and Sunday morning, a short-wave will dive across 
the Great Lakes and upper Ohio Valley. Most of the precipitation 
from this system will be north of the area as dynamics and moisture 
stays north. 

A much stronger wave will dive southeast from the northern Plains 
toward the Great Lakes/Ohio Valley. Better jet dynamics with this 
system for the Tennessee Valley and southern Appalachians. Also, 
this wave phases better with a southern stream wave and Gulf 
Moisture. The ECMWF and NAM models are close in agreement in timing 
and strength in pulling the brunt of the precipitation in after 12Z 
Tuesday. The GFS is faster and weaker. Will trend toward the ECMWF 
and NAM solution. 

Jet dynamics associated with the right entrance region of the jet 
will enhance the forcing over the area along a strong cold front. As 
the front moves through the area between 12-15Z, precipitation will 
increase in intensity. Vertical temperature profile shows a mixture 
of rain/snow initially, but strength of the cold air advection 
behind the front will quickly change mixture to snow. A period of 
snow between 3 and 6 hours is expected. Looking at the latest GEFS 
plumes and WPC coordination, snowfall around 2 inches will be 
common, but up to 4 inches. Given the cold air advection, do expect 
problems on area roadways for Tuesday.

An arctic cold front will move through the region Wednesday 
producing another round of light snow into Wednesday night. 
Additional light snow accumulation is possible.

For mid to late week, a cold arctic high will build into the 
southern Appalachians with very cold temperatures building into the 
region. Dangerous wind chills will be a concern. Winds chills of -15 
to -20 degrees is possible over the mountains areas with -5 to 5 
degrees possible elsewhere Tuesday night.

normally lead to colder overnight lows, but a weak low pressure 
system approaching the region along with some jet energy in the base 
of the longwave trough will cause cirrus to move in from the west 
overnight. The above mentioned disturbance will pass north of the 
region Saturday. Mid level moisture will briefly increase Saturday 
morning from about 12-18Z, especially across southwest VA and the 
northern valley. Low levels remain fairly dry, so I am not 
introducing pops at this time and feel that this will only result in 
greater cloud cover through mid to late morning. Warmer 850 mb temps 
will lead to a milder day with highs reaching the low to mid 40's 
during the afternoon once the clouds clear out. Southwesterly winds 
will increase during the afternoon as well ahead of another 
disturbance which approaches tomorrow night.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday night through Friday)...
A highly amplified upper level pattern will dominate the long term
period with deep long wave troughing across most of the central 
and eastern CONUS, and ridging across the Pacific Northwest. 
Several disturbances will rotate through the cyclonic flow and 
will bring increasing chances of precipitation. The first 
disturbance moves through the region Sunday. Models are in decent 
agreement with the placement and strength of this disturbance; 
however, differences arise in regards to available moisture. While
widespread precipitation is not anticipated, slight chance to 
chance PoPs seem reasonable at this time.

High pressure develops across the northern Gulf of Mexico on 
Monday, before a deep low pressure system associated with northern 
stream energy dives south out of Canada. Monday will likely be dry 
under zonal flow aloft as low-level winds back toward the southeast. 
Models begin to diverge Monday with the strength of synoptic 
features.  The ECMWF is a much colder solution as the shortwave 
diving out of Canada is much stronger then the GFS is showing.  The 
GFS however has a deeper surface low as it traverses the Great 
Lakes.  A preferred model blend suggests as the surface low moves 
across the Great Lakes, an associated cold front will moves west to 
east and begin to move into the area Monday night into Tuesday. 
Ahead of the cold front, 850mb winds strengthen to near 50 knots. 
This could support high winds across the Smoky Mountains. Even with 
the differences in the overall strength of the system, widespread 
precipitation will accompany the frontal boundary.  This is a result 
of increasing upper level dynamics, as the area is in the left exit 
region of a 150 knot 300mb jet streak rounding the base of the 
trough with strong 500mb PVA. This indirect circulation is easily 
visualized in model cross sections with a nearly vertical 
ageostrophic circulation, and strong omega values in the low to mid 
levels of the troposphere.  In addition, there will be a narrow band 
of isentropic lift in the wake of the low-level frontal passage. 
This overrunning will enhance lift between the 850 to 700mb layer. 
The enhanced low-level lift, in concert with strong upper-level 
dynamics aloft, supports deep lift in the troposphere Tuesday. While 
the ECMWF is stronger with the shortwave, and develops cyclogenesis 
in the Mid-Atlantic, the GFS has a weaker shortwave with limited 
cyclogenesis along the surface wave. Albeit these differences, a 
model blend still supports widespread precipitation and some heavy 
precipitation, especially along and behind the FROPA. The GEFS even 
paints high probabilities of 12 hour 0.1 to 0.3 precipitation 
totals.  

While the thermal profile initially supports liquid rain, strong 
cold air advection immediately behind the front will quickly allow a 
change over to all snow.  Further, the usual 10-1 snow to liquid 
ratio will likely be increased to more like 12-1 or 15-1 given the 
depth of cold air advection.  This system is still several days 
away, and a lot can, and most likely will, change.  However, it 
seems reasonable that a couple inches of snow could fall at most 
locations with higher amounts in the higher terrain.  The region 
will be under the influence of deep troughing Wednesday and 
Thursday.  A vort lobe is progged to push into the area Wednesday 
night.  This could produce additional snow showers during this time. 
Temperatures at 850mb are forecast to drop in the -15 to -20 degree 
C range during this time.  This will translate to very cold surface 
temperatures with many locations several degrees below normal.  If 
snow does indeed fall, it is likely temperatures Wednesday and 
Thursday morning could be several degrees cooler then what models 
currently show.

Models become more uncertain with the late week as the operational 
GFS is much cooler then the ECMWF.  An additional shortwave is 
forecast by both operational models to impact the region by Friday. 
For now, will lean with the Superblend.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
329 AM EST Fri Jan 25 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

Fog product satellite imagery shows a fairly expansive low level 
cloud deck in place across southern Appalachia early this morning. 
Per model soundings and cloud top height products GOES-16 imagery, 
cloud tops should be around 4-5k ft. Assuming numerical guidance was 
absolutely correct, these clouds would not quite extend vertically 
into the dendritic growth zone, falling short by 500 to 1000 ft or 
so. Previous shifts included some very low PoPs for some light 
snow/flurries through mid morning, and given light radar returns 
in eastern Kentucky are beginning to expand southward, I am
inclined to keep that in the forecast for now. Would not be 
surprised at all, especially in our southwest Virginia, to see 
some light snow through shortly after daybreak. In any case, 
little to no accumulations are expected, so impacts should be 
negligible.

For the rest of the short term period, broad upper troughing will 
remain in place across much of the nation, but especially the 
eastern half of the United States. A shortwave trough over Arkansas 
will shift eastward through Tennessee and into the Carolinas by 
midday. This will help clouds clear out by the afternoon, with clear 
skies prevailing through late tonight thereafter. Highs should hold 
in the 30s for lower elevations today, but may warm into the lower 
40s in the south depending on how quick clouds dissipate. Continued 
with undercutting guidance for tonight's lows. With light winds, 
clear skies, and very dry air in place, prime radiational conditions 
should exist. Did bump overnight lows up a degree or two, but 
still think teens (north) to low 20s (south) seems very plausible.
Most guidance is about 3-5 degrees warmer across the board, 
likely banking on increased cloud cover prohibiting temps from 
falling too far. Trended that direction slightly but, as 
mentioned, continued to undercut guidance.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Friday)...

A deep long-wave upper trough over southern Canada into the Great
Lakes/Ohio Valley will be the main feature of interest through 
most of the extended. This pattern will pull periods of very cold 
airmass into the Tennessee Valley and southern Appalachians.

For Saturday, a dry period with near seasonal temperatures as 
southwest flow aloft pulls milder air into the region.

For Sunday and Sunday night, a short-wave will move across the area 
with boundary layer southwest flow producing a period of isentropic 
lift. This lift will produce a chance of rain, possibly mixed with 
snow. Light snow accumulations are possible over the northern 
Plateau into southwest Virginia. Snow accumulations of 1 to 2 inches 
are possible.

The main weather feature of interest will be a stronger short-wave 
moving southeast from the northern Plains into the Great Lakes/lower 
Ohio Valley late Monday through Tuesday. The northern stream wave 
will phase with a southern stream jet over the lower Mississippi 
River Valley pulling moisture northeastward into the Tennessee/Ohio 
Valleys. A strong arctic front will sweep through the region 
sometime Tuesday. The GFS is the fast and pulls the front into the 
area by 12Z, while the ECMWF is slower and more toward 18Z. Either 
way the precipitation will likely begin as rain (rain/snow higher 
terrain), but quickly transition to snow. 

Strong jet dynamics with this short-wave with deep lift for about 6 
hours. Snow accumulations are looking more likely with this system, 
even across the Tennessee Valley. Since this system is several days 
away, snowfall forecast will likely change, but currently 2 to 4 
inches is possible most locations with higher amounts across the 
higher terrain. Additional light snowfall is possible Tuesday night.

For mid to late week, a cold arctic high will build into the 
southern Appalachians with very cold temperatures building into the 
region. Dangerous wind chills will be a concern.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Friday)...
A surge of cold air behind an upper jet and trough will be making 
its way into our area tonight. Clouds that have been over the area 
for most of today are gradually eroding from SW to NE, but satellite 
shows more clodu cover upstream across IL/MO. This moisture is 
fairly shallow but with the very cold air mass, there will be some 
moisture in the dendrite growth zone for some snow showers or 
flurries across northern sections late tonight, mainly in the 06-12Z 
time frame. With very weak forcing, any accumulations should be less 
than a half inch, even in the mountains. Flurries may linger in the 
northern sections into Friday morning due to steep low level lapse 
rates. Clouds will clear through the late morning and early 
afternoon, but cold advection will hold high temps into the 30s in 
most spots. Wind chill values tonight will be in the single digits 
in the mountains, with perhaps a few spots briefly going below
zero.

.LONG TERM...(Friday night through Thursday)...
As we head into the weekend...there will be a couple of short 
waves riding along the upper flow. The first one should track to 
our north Friday night into Saturday. Any associated precip should
stay to our north with the main impact being an increase in 
clouds across at least northern areas of the MRX CWA. The second 
short wave will be a bit stronger and should dip a little further 
south as it move through the area Sunday into Sunday evening. A 
mix of rain and snow could reach into northern locations Saturday 
night. As the system moves in on Sunday...precip should transition
to rain with the exception of a mix of precip over the highest 
elevations. Coverage will be higher over northern locations but a 
few isolated showers could spread into southern locations. We will
be between systems on Monday. The main system of concern through 
the extended will be a strong cold front expected to move in 
around the late Monday night/Tuesday time frame. Accompanying the 
front will be a wide band of showers. The temperature profile with
the initial round should generate mainly rain. However...the 
strong cold advection along and directly behind the front will 
allow for rain to change to snow. Timing of the transition remains
difficult but should see precip change to mostly all snow late 
Tuesday afternoon into Tuesday evening. The snow will linger 
through Tuesday night with weak wrap around precip 
possible...mainly north and across higher terrain...on Wednesday. 
The system should pull out for a return to dry conditions by 
Thursday.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Thursday)...
A strong southerly flow across the Southern Appalachians will 
continue to produce high winds in the East TN mountains through the 
evening. Gusts as high as 85 mph at Camp Creek have been measured 
with reports of downed trees around the area. Most obs over the past

is expected to continue through the evening. One change to the NPW 
will be to extend the Wind Advisory for the eastern half of the area 
until 10 pm. After that time, the models show the strongest winds of 
the LLJ moving to our east. 

Rainfall this evening and tonight will be moderate to locally 
heavy, but widespread flooding issues are not expected, with total
QPF amounts between 1-2 inches. The cold front is expected to 
reach our western border around midnight, and exit to the east 
around 12Z. Cold advection behind it will overlap with adequte 
moisture in the dendritic growth zone, giving a small window for 
snow. But it will be brief as midlevel moisture drops off quickly 
between 09-15Z. Even in the mountains and SW VA, less than one 
inch is expected with perhaps a dusting in the Plateau and no 
accumulation in the Valley. Thursday afternoon will have 
decreasing clouds and cold advection with a NW wind keeping highs
only in the 30s to lower 40s.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday night through Wednesday)...
As a cold front continues to pull away from the Southern 
Appalachian Region Thursday evening...the area will be between 
systems for cool and dry conditions. However...this will be short 
lived as a weak secondary boundary will push through late Thursday
night into Friday morning. This feature will generate a few 
isolated light snow showers over far northern and eastern 
locations and will usher in another surge of cooler air. Then...a 
couple of weak waves will ride through the upper flow during the 
weekend. The main track should keep these waves mainly to our 
north with only the tail end swing south and potentially into the 
MRX CWA. As a result...isolated to scattered showers may 
occasional move through the area mainly around Sunday...with the 
best chance across northern locations. Temperatures will moderate 
a bit during the weekend and therefore...expect any daytime 
showers to generally fall as rain and overnight showers may be a 
rain/snow mix. The main system of concern through the extended 
will be a cold front expected to move in Monday night into 
Tuesday. This system will bring a band of rain and snow to the 
area. Drier and cooler conditions are expected on Wednesday.

454 
FXUS64 KMRX 230839
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
339 AM EST Wed Jan 23 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today through Thursday)...
An active short-term with a strong upper jet over the Great Lakes
into the Ohio/mid-Mississippi Valley. This jet will produce broad
divergence aloft over the Tennessee Valley today into tonight. The
direct circulation around this jet will enhance the fronto-genetic
forcing along a cold front that moves across late today and
overnight. The strong upper jet/forcing has induced a very strong
low-level jet with 850mb winds of 70-75kts over the Tennessee/Ohio
Valleys. The strong boundary layer jet even reaches down to the
925mb level.

This low-level jet will produce a mountain wave high wind event
for the Mountains and Foothills. Winds at Camp Creek are already
gusting near 50 mph early this morning. Since the strong winds
reach down to the 925mb level decided to include the rest of the
area, even the Valley, under a wind advisory. Gusts of 30-40 mph
are possible, especially for the ridge tops.

The downslope southerly winds into the northern and central Valley
will help hold off the rain across much of the eastern areas, but
isentropic lift is already producing showers over the Plateau.

The brunt of the upper jet forcing will move across the area from
late today through early Thursday morning. Widespread rain can be
expected with periods of moderate to heavy rain. Rainfall amounts
of 1 to 1 1/2 inches will be common with localized areas receiving
2-2 1/2 inches. Similar to the last rain event, localized runoff
issues are possible given the saturated ground. Plenty of ponding
of water across low lying areas are likely.

As the cold front moves through overnight the vertical tempeature
profile will turn cold enough to change the rain to snow. The
mountains of southwest Virginia, far east Tennessee, and the
Plateau will likely see light accumulations of 1/2 to 2 inches
over the Smokies and High Knob.

Will include these impacts within the HWO and SPS.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday Night through Tuesday)... 
A less active outlook for the upcoming weekend and following 
week, with only a few notable weather events. As the front moves 
out of the forecast area on Friday, expected temperatures to be 
colder with a chance of seeing a few snow showers. A few counties 
in southwestern Virginia and higher elevations in the Smokey's 
could see a modest amount of accumulation up to around a quarter 
inch or so. Winds along the base of the mountains and foothills of
eastern Tennessee will also gradually decrease moving into the 
weekend.

Temperatures will steadily rise over the weekend following the 
normal diurnal curve with a few snow showers possible on Sunday 
morning. Expect any showers in the valley to transition from snow to 
rain as the temperature climbs during the day on Sunday. Monday 
looks to be fairly pleasant with highs reaching the high 40's to low 
50's for much of the forecast area.

The last event of note will be another low pressure system on 
Tuesday of next week. While the GFS and Euro aren't in particularly 
great agreement on the time of it's arrival or duration at present, 
this system has the potential to produce a fair amount of precip. 
This one looks to be very similar to the one of the previous week, 
so expect rain showers for most of the day Tuesday, with the 
possibility of transitioning to snow later on as the system moves 
through and the cold air behind it sets in.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
300 PM EST Tue Jan 22 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Wednesday)...Moisture will increase 
across the area tonight into Wednesday as a cold front and upper 
trough approach from the west.  A southerly low level jet will 
increase, and while thermal profiles do not look ideal for mountain 
waves, it still appears that mountain wave enhancement of the winds 
will be a threat in the usual locations and given the strength of 
the low level jet, will issue a high wind warning for the mountains 
and foothills that were previously included in the watch.  Expect 
downsloping to hinder the advancement of the rain in the northern 
and central valley locations, so will show a fairly tight gradient 
of PoPs late in the day depicting this. While some spots are 
expected to dip below freezing early tonight, temperatures will 
likely rise later tonight in most areas as clouds increase and the 
warm advection increases, so at this point it looks like any light 
precipitation that makes it into mainly southern/western areas and 
possibly the far eastern mountains areas should be all rain.

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday Night through Tuesday)...The extended 
will begin in an active pattern as a cold front continues it's 
push across the Southern Appalachian Region. This will have 
categorical POPs in place Wednesday evening with the chance of 
precip slowly decreasing through the night and ending from west to
east on Thursday. Another round of cold air will filter in behind
the system and rain will transition to snow at many locations 
Wednesday night and Thursday. Little to no snow accumulation is 
expected over most lower elevations of the TN Valley. 
However...higher terrain of the Cumberland Plateau...Southwest VA 
and especially over the East TN mountains...some minor snow 
accumulations are possible. The highest elevations could see 
around an inch. Additionally...a strong 850MB jet will accompany 
the front and higher elevations of the East TN will have a High 
Wind Warning in effect through 03Z Thursday. The area will see a 
brief break late Thursday/Thursday evening for dry and seasonally 
cool conditions. A secondary frontal boundary will slide through 
the region late Thursday night into Friday morning, This will push
through a band of isolated to scattered light snow ...mainly over
northern areas. Little to no accumulation is expected with this 
feature. A couple of weak short waves will ride through the upper 
flow Friday night through the weekend. The main track should keep 
these moving through to our north and at best may generate a few 
isolated to scattered rain or snow showers. Again no accumulations
are expected. The next main weather system of concern will be a 
cold front progged to move through around the Monday night 
/Tuesday time frame and bring a mix of rain and snow into the 
area.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

Upper ridge will remain across the southern Appalachians today 
keeping conditions dry, but allowing plenty of cirrus/cirrus-
stratus to move into the area. Surface ridge will will located 
east of the Appalachians allowing the boundary layer jet to become
southerly. Southerly winds of 30-40kts is expected in the 
afternoon pulling warmer air back into the Tennessee Valley.

For this evening into tonight, southerly jet will continue to 
increase to 50 to 60kts with another mountain wave high wind event 
developing this evening through Wednesday. We have issued a high 
wind watch for the Mountains and Adjacent Foothills with gusts up to 
65-70 kts possible in the favored areas. 

The southerly winds will also increase the isentropic lift over the 
area with showers moving into southeast Tennessee and southwest 
North Carolina overnight. Downslope winds will help keep the shield 
of rain from moving into the northern and central valley until 
Wednesday.

Lows tonight will likely occur by midnight since increasing clouds 
and advection of warmer 850mb temperatures allowing temperatures to 
warm toward daybreak.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Monday)...

Starting off the long term forecast with a frontal system on
Wednesday. Temperatures during Wednesday will be warm enough that
we will initially only see rain from this weather system. Rainfall
could reach up to 2 total inches with a possibility of localized
flooding. As we get into Wednesday night, the temperature will 
drop low enough for areas of moderate to higher elevation, such as
the plateau and the Smokey's, to start seeing snow. Some minor 
accumulation is possible for these areas of under an inch.

Winds will also be a concern during this weather system. Some
downsloping winds along the mountains and foothills could see 
sustained wind speeds of 40 mph with even higher gusts. The winds 
are expected to calm by Thursday morning as the front moves out of
the forecast area.

Wednesday also looks to have unseasonably high temperatures due 
to the warm front out ahead of the frontal boundary, but it will 
be back to colder weather by the end of the week. The passing cold
front brings in another very cold airmass that will be relatively
short lived as we return to more seasonal temperatures by the 
weekend. Another weather system is expected around midway through 
the weekend, although models are currently not in great agreement 
with it's arrival time.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
330 PM EST Mon Jan 21 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Tuesday)...Surface high pressure 
centered to our north will continue to extend into our area as it 
drifts east. It will be another cold night tonight with some high 
clouds drifting across the area especially north.  Tuesday will 
start be precip free, but moisture will start to increase ahead of 
the next system, bringing increasing clouds in the afternoon 
especially south and west.  Temperatures Tuesday afternoon will be 
close to normal for this time of year.

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday night through Monday)...Tuesday evening
starts out dry as surface high pressure over the Mid Atlantic 
area begins to shift east and deep trough over the Rockies moves 
into the South central states. Once again strong south to 
southwest flow will develop Tuesday night and Wednesday ahead of 
the system which has surface low over the Mid Mississippi Valley 
Tuesday evening then moves up to the Great Lakes early Wednesday 
with front moving across the Ohio and Tennessee Valleys Wednesday.
The strong southerly flow aloft should cause winds to gust to 
over 40 miles per hour in the higher elevations...possibly up to 
60 miles per hour in the preferred high wind areas late Tuesday 
evening through Wednesday. Will need to watch if winds increase 
more for possible High Wind Warning may be needed late Tuesday 
night to Wednesday afternoon. Models also show heavy rainfall will
also accompany the front late Wednesday afternoon and night. 
Rainfall amounts of around 2 inches could fall in Southeast 
Tennessee and southwest North Carolina. Behind the front cold air 
will bring a quick temperature drop with snow developing late 
Wednesday night into Thursday morning before the moisture moves 
out. A couple inches of snow may accumulate by late Thursday in 
the higher elevations of east Tennessee and southwest Virginia. 
Thursday temperatures will be colder...mostly 30s and a few 
degrees colder Friday. A weak impulse will move through Thursday 
night and early Friday and another weak system Saturday into 
Sunday which will bring some more chances for snow or cold rain. 
Not expecting much accumulation with these later systems but the 
eastern states will stay in a long wave trough with temperatures 
staying below normal. Highs will be in the 30s to lower 40s and 
lows mostly 20s.

961 
FXUS64 KMRX 210841
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
341 AM EST Mon Jan 21 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

The coldest airmass of the season is in place with temperatures 
early this morning in the single digits to low 20s. Low temperatures 
around sunrise will range from the single digits and teens. 
Northerly winds remain elevated across the southern Appalchians with 
the surface low currently located off the New England Coast and the 
surface high across the western Great Lakes. Due to this, wind chill 
values are already below zero across the higher elevations with 
single digit wind chills across a good portion of the valley. A wind 
chill advisory continues for the higher elevations of east
Tennessee, southwest Virginia and southwest North Carolina through
10 AM. Regardless, wind chills will be brutally cold this morning
across the entire area.

Upper level heights will rise today as a ridge builds in from the 
west. At the low levels, the ridge axis will move overhead with the 
bulk of the cold air advection shifting further to the east. Another 
cold day is forecast but temperatures will be a bit warmer than 
yesterday with mostly sunny skies, temperatures will warm into the 
mid 20s to mid 30s for most locations. Winds will decrease 
throughout the day as the pressure gradient relaxes with the surface 
high pressure move into the region.

The upper level ridge axis will move over the forecast area tonight. 
The low level ridge axis will shift to the east of the area 
overnight with low level southerly to southeasterly flow returning 
bringing back in warm air and moisture advection to the area. 
Overnight lows will be warmer than the last couple of nights ranging 
from the teens to mid 20s. 

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday through Monday)...

The longterm period will be active with several chances of 
precipitation and below normal temperatures expected much of the 
period.  Model guidance is above average through Thursday before 
much uncertainty exists.  Tuesday will be dry with near normal 
temperatures. This is the result of surface high pressure across the 
Mid-atlantic and surface low pressure developing across the Central 
Plains.  As a result of lower pressure to the west, winds will begin 
to back to the south. An increase in cloud cover can be expected 
Tuesday afternoon and night in weak isentropic ascent.  As the 
surface low ejects northeast into the Great Lakes, cyclogenesis is 
expected across the Midsouth along the low-level boundary Wednesday 
morning. The increase in upper-level dynamics associated with a 140 
knot upper-level jet, and increased low-level convergence, will 
allow the precipitation field to expand.  Precipitation is expected 
to move into the region Wednesday morning ahead of the front.  The 
increase in upper level support further supports locally heavy 
rainfall through Wednesday night. A low-level jet develops Wednesday 
with 50-60 knot southerly flow. This would support strong winds 
across the mountains and wind advisories or a high wind watch may be 
needed in future forecast packages for those areas.  

Surface high pressure builds into the area on Thursday with colder 
air moving in.  Precipitation on the back side of the system could 
turn to a rain-snow mix or all snow.  As is usual with these types 
of systems, the moisture looks to move out quicker then the colder 
air.  As a result, not expecting much if any accumulations. 
Confidence is low Thursday night and into the weekend.  It is clear, 
however, that a much colder airmass will settle into the area under 
a deep trough.  Some disturbances could rotate through this cyclonic 
flow and produce precipitation.  For now, kept PoPs at slight chance 
to chance.

National Weather Service Morristown TN
330 PM EST Sun Jan 20 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Monday)...Very cold air will continue 
to push in tonight. Some weakening and moisture starved mid level 
short wave energy will brush us with some high/mid clouds early 
tonight, but other than that brief interruption the overall 
clearing trend will continue, and Monday should feature plenty of 
sunshine although it will still be quite cold. Have not been 
seeing evidence of wind gusts to advisory criteria over the past 
few hours, and with winds gradually diminishing will cancel the 
wind advisory early. Wind chill advisory still looks to be needed 
for tonight/early Monday as wind chill values will be quite low 
over the higher elevations from the Smokies north.

.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Sunday)...Arctic high pressure
will be hanging on one more night Monday night with temperatures
warmer in the west and southwest than tonight. Expect mostly 
clear skies and lows still in the teens to lower 20s. Southeast 
winds starting Monday evening will keep temperatures warmer. 
Tuesday will start out mostly clear with southerly winds and 
warmer temperatures in the 40s. Moisture begins to increase 
Tuesday afternoon and night with temperatures warmer by morning. 
Rain will spread into western sections by morning then slowly 
spread northeast early Wednesday as deepening surface low moves 
from the plains toward the Great Lakes. Winds will increase with a
wind advisory possible for the higher elevations and the 
foothills with southeast wind flow. Rainfall will increase late 
Wednesday and Wednesday night just ahead of the cold front and may
cause localized flooding. Behind the front temperatures will fall
quickly with some snow late Wednesday night and Thursday. A 
secondary cold front Thursday night will bring in much colder air 
once again Friday through the weekend. On Sunday a surface low 
tracking southeast in the Northwest Flow will bring another chance
of snow and reinforce the cold air over the region.

056 
FXUS64 KMRX 200801
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
301 AM EST Sun Jan 20 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

The cold front is now to the east of the forecast area with strong 
cold air advection pushing into the southern Appalachians. Current 
radar imagery indicates a band of snow across Middle TN moving into 
the Cumberland Plateau. The temperature at Crossville is already 
below freezing with light snow being reported. Temperatures will 
continue to plummet overnight. Radar trends indicate that this band 
of snow is eroding some and models indicate this as well. With 
northwesterly winds, there will be some downsloping as the 
precipitation moves off the plateau into the valley. Then 
reintensify as it moves into western portions of the valley into the 
east Tennessee and southwest Virginia mountains. Models suggest a 
rather classic northwest flow snow event setting up for this morning 
and into the early afternoon. Forecast soundings show rather shallow 
moisture but the moisture does extend up to around -10 degrees 
Celsius on the lower end of the dendritic growth zone and expect 
precipitation will be all snow as the cold air advection moves into 
the area later this morning. The low-level lift begins to weaken 
early this afternoon and snow will come to an end across the higher 
elevations. For now, expect amounts of around 1-4 inches across the 
higher elevations of east Tennessee and southwest Virgina, around 
0.5-1 inch across the northern Cumberland Plateau and lower 
elevations of southwest virginia, and a dusting to around half an 
inch across the central and northern Tennessee Valley. The ongoing 
winter weather products look to be in good shape and have kept those 
the same.

Strong northwesterly surface winds are forecast today ushering in 
the pattern change. These winds will be strong enough for a wind advisory 
across the higher elevations with gusts into the 35-45 mph range 
today. For the lower elevations, expect gusts in the 25-35 mph 
range. High temperatures will remain below freezing in the upper 
20s to low 30s for most valley locations. The combination of winds
and temperatures will lead to wind chills in the mid teens to low
20s for most valley locations with wind chills of -5 to 5 in the 
higher elevations. 

Winds will remain elevated during the overnight hours with continued 
cold advection. Wind chill values in the higher elevations of the 
east Tennessee and southwest Virginia Mountains will drop to as low 
as -10 and a wind chill advisory has been issued. Wind chill 
readings in the valley will drop down into the single digits to low 
teens for most locations. Low temperatures will range from the 
single digits in the higher elevations to mid teens to low 20s for 
most of the valley.

.LONG TERM...(Monday through Sunday)...

A cool weather pattern will start the long term period off as 
surface high pressure settles across the Ohio Valley. In the upper
levels, deep troughing is forecast to exist across New England 
with low amplitude ridging across the Plains. Troughing will also 
exist across the Western CONUS. The surface high pressure and low 
850mb temperatures will keep daytime highs on Monday below 
average. Further, good radiational conditions will produce another
night of cold temperatures for Monday night. Early Tuesday, the 
ridge will build across the Eastern CONUS as troughing moves 
across the Rockies. Lee cyclogenesis will produce a surface low 
across the Central Plains. As a result, low-level winds will begin
to back toward the Southwest. This backing wind, and upper level 
pressure falls, will allow for an increase in moisture and cloud 
cover Tuesday afternoon. 
 
Models are in fairly good agreement with the midweek system.  At 00z 
Wednesday, the surface low is progged to be located across northern 
Missouri with a trailing cold front across the Midsouth and 
Arklatex.  Upper level forcing along this boundary will produce 
numerous showers.  The front will begin to move into the forecast 
area as early as Wednesday morning.  A south to southwest low-level 
flow trajectory will likely produce downsloping across the Smoky 
Mountains which will delay precipitation across northeast Tennessee, 
and southwest Virginia.  Speaking of the low-level winds, models 
project 850mb flow in excess of 45-50 knots on Wednesday with gusty 
winds in the Smokys likely. Models have been consistent in showing 
cyclogenesis along the low-level boundary as it moves through the 
area.  This could produce enhanced convergence along the boundary. 
The enhanced convergence in combination with upper level forcing 
from a 130-150 knot 300mb jet will produce an environment conducive 
for deep lift. Model soundings suggest a moist adiabatic profile 
with precipitable water values greater than 1 inch.  Periods of 
heavy rainfall are possible, especially Wednesday night.  

Cold air will filter into the region behind the front which could 
create a rain/snow mix for areas along the Plateau, and higher 
elevations.   Carried slight chance to chance PoPs Thursday across 
the higher terrain, and in southwest Virginia where upslope snow 
showers are possible.  The region will get a break as surface high 
pressure builds in behind the front.  For the latter portions of the 
period, confidence becomes low as models have shown low run-to-run 
consistencies. However, global models have been showing a few 
disturbances that could impact the area this coming weekend. Given 
the deep cyclonic flow in place, it seems reasonable that systems 
could travel in this flow and impact the area.  Timing of individual 
disturbances this far out is difficult but temperatures will be low 
enough for low end PoPs of snow.

FXUS64 KMRX 190902
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
402 AM EST Sat Jan 19 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today through Sunday)...

A very complicated short-term forecast period with heavy rainfall 
today with the possibility of localized flooding. Strong winds will 
develop across the area ahead of the system today with a high wind 
warning for the mountains. A few thunderstorms will also be possible 
this afternoon with the possibility of a stronger storm or two with 
gusty winds. Then as a cold air rushes in, snow will be possible 
late tonight into Sunday morning with accumulations of 1-3 inches 
across the higher elevations of the east Tennessee and southwest 
Virginia mountains that summarize the short-term forecast period 
for further details see the paragraphs below. 

Upper level trough is currently moving out of the southern Plains 
into the Lower Mississippi River Valley. At the surface, a low is 
currently located along the OK/AR line with a warm front extending 
to the west across MS/AL/GA. Current radar imagery, indicates 
widespread showers with a few embedded thunderstorms ahead of the 
main system in association with the strong warm advection across W 
TN, N MS, and N AL. This activity is forecast to move into 
southwestern portions of the forecast area just before sunrise. Low-
level southerly winds ahead of the approaching system will create a 
mountain wave event with gusts in the high terrain and foothills up 
to 60-70 mph at time today. The wind direction will lead to 
downsloping across portions of NE TN and SW VA and will delay the 
onset of precipitation until later this afternoon for these 
locations. Moisture advection will be impressive with PW values 
soaring into the 0.9-1.2 inch range later today. These values are 
around the 90th- to maximum values observed for mid to late January. 
Storm total rainfall amounts will range from 1-2 inches with some 
locally higher amounts. These values are a bit below the 3 hour 
Flash Flood Guidance values and have held off on a Flood Watch for 
now. Although, do expect some areas of localized flooding. 

The strong low-level temperature and moisture advection will push 
the warm front northward today bringing southern portions of the 
forecast area into warm sector. Model soundings indicate some weak 
instability in these areas with surface dewpoints climbing into the 
mid to upper 50s. Storms that do form in the warm sector could 
dynamically bring down strong winds just above the surface leading to 
locally damaging wind gusts. Although. confidence is rather low with 
this scenario due to the limited instability with the overly 
saturated atmosphere. 

Much colder air will advect in behind the front tonight. Model 
soundings indicate that the upper and mid levels will dry out as the 
main upper level trough lifts out to the northeast. A textbook 
northwesterly flow will setup behind the departing system. 
Saturations will reach up to around -8 to -10 degree Celsius on the 
lower end of the dendritic growth zone and expect the main 
precipitation type will be snow. The best lift, moisture, and cold 
air will be around the 09-15z timeframe on Sunday. Snowfall amounts 
of 1-3 inches will be possible across the higher elevations of the 
east Tennesse and southwest Virginia Mountains with 0.5-1 inch 
across the northern Cumberland Plateau and lower elevations of 
southwest Virginia, and a dusting possible across the central and 
northern Tennessee Valley. In addition to the snow, strong 
northwesterly winds will reduce wind chills below zero across the 
higher elevations and a wind chill advisory may be needed in later 
forecast issuances for the east Tennessee Mountains. In the majority 
of the valley, winds chills will be in the teens. Highs on Sunday 
will be bitterly cold with most locations remaining below freezing 
all day with highs in the mid 20s to low 30s.

.LONG TERM...(Sunday Night through Saturday)...

The longterm period starts off with building surface high 
pressure moving out of the northwest with strong troughing across 
the eastern CONUS. With northwest flow aloft, some light snow 
flurries still remain possible across the higher terrain Sunday 
night into Monday morning. Temperatures Sunday night will likely 
be very cold. With strong arctic high pressure in place, 850mb 
temperatures are progged to drop to around -10 to -20 degrees C. 
This will likely send surface temperatures into the single digits 
to teens across the majority of the area. 

For the beginning of the week, the area will be between systems with 
the next system across the Intermountain west by 00Z Tuesday. Upper 
level ridging will develop across the midsection of the country 
bringing drier and clearer weather to the area. Temperatures Monday 
and Monday night will likely be below average. Winds begin to back 
toward the Southwest Tuesday ahead of a deep positively tilted mid 
to upper level trough that will advect a warmer and wetter airmass. 
Lee cyclogenesis will develop a surface low late Monday night and by 
Tuesday night this low will be located in the Great Lakes.  A cold 
front associated with this surface low will traverse the Midsouth 
Tuesday night before slowing as it approaches the MRX area.  Upper 
level divergence across the Southeast will aid in weak cyclogenesis 
along the boundary Wednesday. Increasing chances of rainfall look 
likely by Tuesday night into Wednesday. Some of the rainfall could 
become heavy as surface convergence increases along the front, and 
with PWAT values in excess of 1.0 inches.  

Models begin to diverge with the exiting system Wednesday night and 
Thursday.  As of the latest 00Z suite of guidance, the GFS places a 
surface low across the Delmarva region by 12z Thursday, while the 
ECMWF has its surface low across the Carolinas.  The 00z GFS is far 
removed from the GFS ensemble mean.  Further, the ECMWF has shown 
low run-to-run consistency.  Given these trends, have used a model 
blend for timing of precipitation ending. It is likely some residual 
moisture will be left over behind the system as the cold air 
arrives.  How much is left is still uncertain. Expect a change over 
from rain to a rain-snow mix with low impacts at this time. Needless 
to say, this is a low confidence forecast with many details yet to 
figure out.  

The region will be under the influence of deep cyclonic flow by the 
end of the week and into next weekend.  Several disturbances 
traveling in this cyclonic flow could impact the area with low end 
chances of rain or snow.  Temperatures during this time look to be 
below average.

and Saturday night. Rainfall of 1 1/2 to 2 inches will be common.

Tennessee and southwest Virginia Mountains.

rain/snow showers may stick around into Friday as well. Precip type 
quite problematic that far out, but right now looks like mainly rain 
until colder air starts pushing in behind the system Thu night. This 
system will bear watching as a shift southeast in the track of the 
surface low could increase our potential for snow.

FXUS64 KMRX 180819

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
319 AM EST Fri Jan 18 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

Current water vapor imagery indicates dry air in the upper and 
mid=levels with a cold front at the surface currently back to the 
west. The cold front currently stretches from near Cleveland, OH to 
the southwest to just to the east of Nashville, TN. Model soundings 
indicate that the saturated low-level layer is limited to around 
1000-800 mb with an inversion and dry air just above 800 mb. There 
is some low-level lift in this layer with increase surface 
convergence ahead of the boundary. Due to this, there is some light 
rain/drizzle currently on radar with the best coverage across NE TN 
and SW VA. Temperatures across the area are above freezing and do 
not expect any issues with any wintry precipitation early this 
morning. Winds are light ahead of the boundary and as the low level 
lift exits near sunrise, expect fog will become more widespread and 
have added fog and drizzle to the near-term forecast. 

Clouds will linger once again today as the front slowly moves across 
the forecast area late this morning. Not seeing much in the way of 
cold air advection as the front stalls across southern portions of 
the forecast area. A weak shortwave ridge does build into the region 
today as the low level lift weakens. Therefore, expect most 
locations will remain dry but it does appear that cloud cover will 
linger. Due to this, went a bit lower with forecast highs in the mid 
40s to low 50s. 

A more robust system will move out of the Southern Plains tonight 
into the Lower MIssissippi River Valley. warm air and moisture 
advection will move into the southern Appalchians with 850 mb winds 
ranging from around 35-45 kts. The warm front will surge northward 
as rain chances increase across southwestern portions of the 
forecast area. PW values will climb to over an inch for southwestern 
portions of the forecast area before sunrise. For overnight lows, 
went with a more raw model blend with temperatures warming overnight 
due to strong southerly flow. With the stronger winds at 850 mb, 
expect gusty winds across the higher elevations and a wind advisory 
may become necessary for locations along the TN/NC line.

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Friday)...


The longterm forecast period will be active with several 
disturbances impacting the region under an active Polar jet.  Heavy 
rainfall, thunderstorms, wintry precipitation, strong winds, and 
cold temperatures are all possible in this long term period.  

Model confidence is average for the weekend system.  The latest runs 
of the ECMWF have trended quicker with the system, and this is in 
consensus with ensemble means.  The 12z and 00z GFS has trended 
notably faster with its trough and this quicker solution is more in 
consensus with the ECMWF. Also, the GFS has trended with a deeper 
trough versus a flatter system in previous runs. This forecast 
utilized a blend of the ECMWF and GFS for placement and timing of 
synoptic features. 

The longterm period starts off with a deep trough across the Central 
Plains and Midwest with lowering heights aloft covering the CWA. 
Further north, northern stream energy was beginning to dive out of 
the Hudson Bay area. Upper level ridging will be building across the 
Rockies.  At the surface, an area of low pressure will develop under 
upper level mass divergence across the Midsouth and travel through 
the Tennessee River valley. Winds will begin to back toward the 
southwest ahead of the approaching upper level system.  This will 
advect deep moisture into the region.  Precipitable water values 
will increase upwards of 1.5 inches with normalized anomalies as 
high as 1.5 to 2.0 standard deviations.   Model soundings show a 
nearly fully saturated column that is moist adiabatic by 18z. 
Further, upper level winds will be unidirectional with vectors 
parallel to the low level boundary. This ultimately means locally 
heavy rainfall is possible.  K-index values are progged to be above 
30 and model soundings and 2-D plane views show some elevated 
instability. Some thunder is possible but widespread thunderstorms 
seem unlikely at this time.  By Sunday morning, the surface low is 
forecast to move through the Mid Atlantic with a neutral tilted 
trough over the Ohio Valley and Southern Appalachians.  As the 
system pulls out, moisture wrapping around the system in combination 
with negative thermal advection could allow precipitation to turn to 
snow on the back side.  GFS model soundings at 12z Sunday show a 
thermal profile that is completely below freezing with a saturated 
layer between 900-650mb. Further, an isothermal layer exists from 
850-750mb.  While most of the upper level support is too far east, 
the residual moisture could become lifted by northwest flow aloft 
and would allow light snow especially for areas in higher 
elevations.  Snow amounts look to remain light with the highest 
terrain in the Smoky Mountains seeing 1-2 inches of snowfall 
possibly.

Strong winds are also possible during the day on Saturday as the low 
level jet cranks up over the area.  A true mountain wave event does 
not look likely, but higher gusts could still occur over the higher 
terrain.  

Upper level ridging will develop by the beginning of next week with 
high pressure diving out of Canada.  850mb temperatures are progged 
to drop to -10 to -20 degrees C which is nearly 10-20 degrees below 
normal.  This will allow surface temperatures to plummet. 
Temperatures in the single digits to teens are likely on Sunday 
night.  In the meantime, another trough will develop off the Rockies 
allowing for lee cyclogenesis Monday night into Tuesday. This low 
will track through the Central Plains and into the Ohio Valley 
through midweek.  Low level flow will strengthen ahead of the trough 
and advect low level moisture back into the area. Precipitation will 
begin as early as Tuesday along the frontal boundary.   Most of the 
precipitation Tuesday through Wednesday night will likely be liquid 
rain.  As colder air filters in, a change over to a rain/snow mix or 
snow could occur on Thursday with chance PoP's.  Confidence on exact 
placement of surface and upper level features is low at this time, 
and this time period bares watching. Surface high pressure builds in 
by the end of the period with below normal temperatures expected.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
336 PM EST Thu Jan 17 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Friday)...The Winter Weather Advisory
for our southwest Virginia counties will expire at 4 PM.
Temperatures remain in the mid 30's in that area which could cause
a light mix of rain and snow to continue. Little to no additional
accumulation is expected. 

Low pressure system will pass east of the area tonight dragging a
weak cold front through the region. The widespread rain and snow 
showers from earlier today will become more scattered through the 
evening. Have likely pops decreasing from west to east this 
evening with generally chance pops after Midnight. The soundings 
are very saturated. Drying begins around 750 mb at 06Z, but the 
profile remains saturated from 850 mb and below through at least 
15Z Friday due to a surface high moving down from the north 
creating an inversion over the wet ground. This will lead to 
periods of drizzle overnight into Friday morning. Patchy fog 
could develop at times overnight, but this is low confidence due 
to winds increasing a bit. The soundings should dry enough by late
morning or early afternoon Friday to allow clouds to gradually 
thin with possibly some sun, but have lowered high temps from 
previous forecast to account for morning drizzle and low clouds. 
Generally expect low/mid 40's in southwest VA, northeast TN, and 
the Plateau with upper 40's/low 50's in the southern valley. 


.LONG TERM...(Friday night through Thursday)...
Strong low pressure system is still expected to move across the mid-
Atlantic region and bring with it a wide range of weather over the 
upcoming weekend. There will be several impacts from this system 
ranging from thunderstorms, wind, rain, snow, and cold 
temperatures... So let's just break it down by impact.

Winds...As this system moves across Central Kentucky the low level 
jet out of the South/Southwest will crank up to over 50+ knots 
Saturday. While this is not a classic mountain wave set up (with 
winds coming out of the southeast) but we could still see strong 
winds in the higher elevation closer to the jet max. Will need to 
watch this for a potential wind advisory if models continue with the 
strong jet trend.


Thunderstorms...Strong divergence aloft will help lead to rising air 
in the warm sector of the low pressure system on Saturday afternoon. 
Even though instability is weak there appears to be enough for some 
thunderstorm activity and with the strong low level jet there's the 
possibilty of transporting the strong winds down towards the 
surface. 

Rain...Decent amount of moisture will be wrapped up in this system. 
Rainfall will begin moving into the Tennesee Valley around Friday 
night and begin to move out by Sunday. Current QPF totals are 
expected to be in the 0.5-1.5" range, with a few locally higher 
amounts under thunderstorms or heavier bands of rain.

Snow...As this system exits the area on Sunday/Monday temperatures 
will drop and lingering moisture could be converted over to 
snowfall. The higher elevations and Northeast Tennessee/Southwest 
Virginia have the highest chance to see accumulating snowfall. We 
could see some accumulating snowfall in the Valley, but with little 
moisture to work with for a relatively short period, would expect 
snow amounts to remain less than 0.5" for most Valley locations. 
Higher elevations could see closer to an inch or more, but certainty 
is still somewhat low due to differences in the models on when the 
cold temperatures and the moisture will actually overlap to bring 
snowfall. 

Cold temperatures...Skies will clear out Sunday night and very cold 
air will continue to funnel in from the northwest. These will help 
lead to temperatures in the teens (and possibly single digits in 
some places) Sunday night/Monday morning. Winds will remain 
relatively light in the Valley, but wind chill values are still 
expected to drop into the single digits early Monday morning.

After this system's influence finally leaves us alone we'll get a 
break for a few days starting on M.L.K. Jr. Day.

Another weather system/frontal boundary will move through the 
forecast area in the second half of the work week. Models are coming 
into better agreement with the system expected to move through on 
Wednesday. It will likely bring mostly rain, but we could see some 
light snowfall as it exits the region.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
349 AM EST Thu Jan 17 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

Active short term forecast period with increasing chances of
rainfall today and tonight. The upper level pattern starts off
with cyclonic flow across New England with troughing across the
central plains. A ridge was analyzed across the intermountain
west. Across the southeast, the upper level flow was more zonal in
nature with slight ridging ahead of the trough. Closer to the 
surface, an area of low pressure was centered across Oklahoma. A 
warm front was aligned NE of the low across central Missouri with 
a portion of that front stalled across Kentucky. 

The rest of tonight should remain quiet with lows in the low to 
mid 30's. Some fog is possible through morning but should remain 
patchy in nature. Isentropic ascent (as viewed on the 290-300K
levels) and warm air advection as noted on point soundings will 
allow moisture to increase during the day with an increase in 
clouds. As of this discussion, light rain was beginning to develop
across the Midsouth in the aforementioned area of warm air 
advection. Short term model guidance and CAM's indicate rainfall 
will begin to move into the area in the late morning to afternoon 
hours. Given that temperatures in the morning are just above 
freezing and thermal profiles are supportive of wintry mix, there 
is the chance that the onset of precipitation could contain a 
mixture of liquid rain, and ice pellets or snow. Confidence on 
this is very low, and will not cause any issues as any mix would 
not last very long at all. As of now, the best timing for rainfall
is between 15-18z for areas along and west of I-75 and I-81. 
Areas east of I-75 would likely see rainfall after 18z. Intensity 
should remain light as the system remains on the weaker side. PoPs
drop off late tonight into Friday morning with only chances of 
precipitation across NE TN, and SW VA. Friday looks to be warmer 
then previous days with highs in the low to mid 50's. 

.LONG TERM...(Friday through Thursday)...
 
A strong low pressure system will be tracking from the Ozarks across 
KY to the Mid-Atlantic region Friday night through Saturday night. 
As we have been following the past few days, there will be several 
concerns with this system. First, a southerly LLJ of 50-60 kts may 
create some potential for high winds and/or mountain waves on 
Saturday. Second, East TN will be in the warm sector Saturday 
afternoon, and although instability is weak, strong divergence aloft 
between diffluent jets will enhance lift and give a chance of 
thunderstorms, likely in the form of a squall line. With the strong 
LLJ, there may be a damaging wind threat Saturday afternoon/evening 
as the line moves through. Third, there will be a chance of light 
snow accumulations behind the cold frontal passage Saturday night. 
Most of this will occur in the mountains and SW VA, and even there, 
only a few inches are expected at this time as deep moisture pulls 
out quickly Sunday morning. Finally, temps will be falling through 
the day Sunday with a brisk NW flow that could create low temps in 
the teens in the Valley and sub-zero wind chill values in the 
mountains Sunday night. 

Ridging over the area should provide a dry and mostly sunny day on 
Monday with below normal temperatures. Another system is expected to 
follow on Tuesday/Wednesday, although there are some model 
differences in the timing of the best precip chances with this 
system. The GFS focuses on Tuesday night, while the ECMWF delays it 
until Wednesday. Will maintain chance PoPs during both of these 
periods.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
333 AM EST Wed Jan 16 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

Across the area, skies remain cloudy with the exception of the 
higher terrain in the Smoky mountains with temperatures in the low
to middle 30's. In the upper levels, broad cyclonic flow exists 
across the eastern CONUS with ridging to the west across the 
Rockies and central plains. A subtropical jet was noted nosing 
into the Gulf Coast and across the GoM with upper level moisture 
as shown on GOES channel 9 imagery. At the surface, high pressure
remained across the southeast with a cold front progressing SE 
out of the Midwest associated with low pressure in Quebec. As 
mentioned above, the area still remains under low level stratus 
with area LAPS soundings showing a low level inversion around 
900mb with shallow moisture trapped beneath it. The NAM has been 
the most pessimistic model showing the low level stratus 
persisting. Given these trends, and the fact that low level flow 
remains orthogonal to the mountains, have trended for stratus not 
deteriorate as quickly as other guidance indicates. In fact, areas
near and north of Knoxville may see mostly cloudy skies through 
the morning and afternoon. Areas across the far southern 
Tennessee counties stand the best chance to scatter out as the low
level inversion begins to weaken, but confidence remains low. 
This will also likely influence high temperatures today. Since the
forecast hangs on to cloud cover longer, have trended max 
temperatures downward in consensus with the NAM especially across 
northern portions of the forecast area.

Otherwise, expect a quiet day weather wise, as surface high 
pressure remains in control. Low level flow begins to back to the 
SW tonight ahead of an approaching weather system to the west.

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Wednesday)...
 
Rain will begin to spread into the area Thursday morning ahead of a 
shortwave trough and a surface low tracking up the OH Valley. This 
should be a fairly light QPF (and all-liquid precip) event as the 
trough is weakly amplified and inflow of Gulf moisture remains cut 
off, but with good model agreement giving high confidence, PoPs will 
be in the categorical range in the afternoon. The mid/upper trough 
outpaces the surface cold front, so chance PoPs will remain in place 
until the fropa Friday morning. 

High pressure at the surface with a near zonal flow aloft will 
briefly be across the area Friday and Friday night before the next 
system starts to approach for the weekend. Models have some timing 
differences with the onset of precip, with the GFS fastest, and the 
NAM being slowest. Will lean the forecast toward the ECMWF, which is 
in the middle of those two, and bring in chance PoPs to the Plateau 
and southern Valley late Friday night. The dynamics with this system 
do not appear quite as impressive as before, as the northern stream 
trough does not amplify as sharply and merge with the southern 
stream as completely as previous runs. Still, heavy rain, gusty 
winds, and thunderstorms will be concerns Saturday afternoon as the 
system crosses the MS Valley. QPF amounts are expected to be in the 
range of 1-2 inches. Cold advection sets in late Saturday 
night/Sunday morning, and there should be enough overlap of moisture 
and cold temps to produce some potential for snow accumulation, 
mainly in the mountains and SW VA but also in the TN Valley. 

Bitterly cold temps and low wind chills will be the concern behind 
this system for Sunday night and Monday, as lows will be in the 
teens to single digits with a brisk NW wind. The GFS is quick to 
bring another deep trough into the Plains with precip spreading into 
our area on Tuesday, but the ECMWF is slower with a cut off upper 
low. With uncertainty this far out, will keep Tuesday dry.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Wednesday)...
The upper pattern today is highlighted broad troughing over the 
eastern seaboard with ridging to the west atop the Rockies which is 
yielding deep nwly flow across the OH/TN valleys.  A weak shortwave 
impulse moving along the mean flow aloft on the tail end of a jet 
streak will sweep through the region today/tonight, however with 
little/no consequence.  The main story of the weather in the short 
term is the persistence of a llv inversion, and the modest llv 
moisture trapped beneath.  Given the inversion, said llv cannot 
escape as long as flow remains orthogonal to the mountains, or the 
inversion erodes. Am expecting H85/H925 flow to back swly with time, 
thus some scattering of low clouds is favored through the remainder 
of the afternoon/evening.  That said, per latest visb sat loop, 
there is an interesting region of downslope drying (in the lee of 
the Black Mountain range in KY) across portions of the northern TN
valley and southwest VA. Otherwise, a fairly quiet short term in 
store as sly high pressure prevails on Wednesday amidst rising 
heights aloft. Thus, am expecting temperatures to moderate nearly 
10 degrees from that of today. 

.LONG TERM...(Wednesday night through Tuesday)...
Shortwave trough will be moving towards the area Wednesday night 
into Thursday and a surface low will race along with it. These will 
combine to bring chances of precipitation with the highest 
likelihood of rain coming Thursday afternoon and night. Rain will 
begin to decrease as we move into Friday from southwest to 
northeast. When everything is said and done this first system will 
probably bring less than 0.25" of rain to most locations.

The second system of the forecast will move in quickly on the heels 
of the first, a southern stream shortwave will interact with a 
trough further to the north and combine over the Eastern United 
States. Strong surface low will move to the northeast on Saturday 
just north of the Tennessee Valley. This will bring in very warm and 
moist air on Saturday. There may be enough  dynamics with this 
system to produce a few rumbles of thunder on Saturday as well. 
Highs on Saturday are currently forecasted to be about 20-25 degrees 
above normal for this time of year. Moderate to heavy rain looks to 
be the main mode of precipitation on Saturday afternoon/night with 
widespread rainfall totals around 1-2" over the weekend looking 
possible.  After this system exits to the north we will see strong 
cold air advection from the northwest at the end of the weekend and 
into next week. 

High temperatures will drop about 25 or more degrees on Sunday 
compared to Saturday. Overnight lows look to drop well below 
freezing into the teens on Sunday night/Monday morning. With some 
lingering winds behind the system we could see wind chill values 
drop into the single digits as well. The final aspect to watch with 
this weekend system will be the potential for some snow showers as 
it exits the region on Sunday. A bit difficult to time the departure 
of the moisture with the drop in temperatures, but can't rule out 
some light snow showers in the Valley on Sunday at this time.

northern stream trough to produce a longwave trough across the

warm sector. Add in some potent dynamics with the upper and low

Saturday afternoon. Will add a chance of thunder to go with with 
categorical showers. Fropa occurs Saturday night, with falling 
temperatures through the day on Sunday. Snow showers will be 
possible during this time as temps aloft will drop sharply and 
create steep lapse rates with a NW upslope flow. At this time, 
accumulations appear to be mainly in the mountains. Highs Sunday 
and Monday will be in the 20s and 30s, with lows Sunday night 
mainly in the teens.

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Monday)...

Winds will shift to be more from the west northwest late tonight
leading to cooler temperatures overnight and into tomorrow. While
a more northwest flow will eventually lead to clearing skies we
can expect Monday to remain relatively cloudy with a few stray
showers overnight. The combination of the overnight precipitation
and lowering temperatures will create the chance for some frozen
precip for areas of higher elevation. Some areas of the Smokey's
and southwestern Virginia could see some accumulation of ice, up
to a few hundreds of an inch. No weather advisory will be issued
due to limited area of expected accumulation of frozen precip, but
will issued an SPS.

.LONG TERM...(Monday night through Sunday)...

A few pockets of light snow and even some freezing drizzle will 
linger over the higher elevations of the East TN Mountains Monday 
evening...before ending overnight. Little to no snow or ice 
accumulation is expected. A ridge of high pressure begins to build
in on Tuesday...ushering in a warming and drying trend. The mild 
and quiet conditions will continue over the Southern Appalachian 
Region through Wednesday night. The area will then transition into
a more active and wet weather pattern for the rest of the 
extended as a series of systems move through. On Thursday/Thursday
night...a weak area of low pressure will track through the upper 
flow and spread scattered showers across the area. Any precip that
moves into the higher elevations early Thursday could see a mix 
of rain and snow...otherwise daytime temperatures will be warm 
enough for all rain. There should a be brief dry period somewhere 
around the Friday time frame when we are between systems. 
However...the break will be short lived and timing of this is 
difficult. This is because the next system...a decently strong 
cold front...will move in quickly late Friday into Friday night 
and continue to affect the area into Saturday. The main band of 
showers will push through ahead of the front. The warm air mass in
place will keep precip as rain. Cooler air will filter in behind 
the cold front late Saturday/Saturday night. Any residual rain 
Saturday night will change over to snow at many locations as the 
front pulls away from the area. The associated upper low will then
wrap low level moisture into the area for Sunday...continuing to 
generate light scattered rain or snow showers...with snow mainly 
over northern locations and especially across favored upslope 
area.

Friday night. Rain spreads through the Tennessee Valley Friday night

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...

Across the region it was mostly clear, slightly cooler, and

today in the wake of the cold front. The wind advisory for the
