Strong northwest flow and an associated shortwave will translate
across southwest Virginia today. This will reinforce cold air
advection into the area. Additionally, shallow moisture will also
be present which could produce a few snow showers into the early
evening. Do not anticipate much, if any, accumulations from this
system. The bigger problem will be the wind chills later today
into tonight particularly for portions of southwest Virginia and
higher elevations of the TN mountains. Will be monitoring for the
possibility of a wind chill advisory for tonight for these areas. 

Temperatures for today and tonight will be well below normal
values. Look for temperatures to drop or remain steady through the
day. 

.LONG TERM...(Thursday through Wednesday)...

The extended range fcst period initializes on Thursday morning 
amidst rising heights aloft and nwly flow as a ridge slides east. At 
the surface, high pressure will be moving across the Midwest and 
into OH/TN valleys, enhancing the pressure gradient across the high 
terrain.  This combined with modest but weakening nwly H85 flow will 
allow for some gusty winds and brisk wind chills at elevations above 
3kft early on Thursday. Otherwise, the aforementioned upper ridge 
will continue to advect east while surface ridging slides beneath 
and atop the central/southern Appalachians, eventually setting up 
CAD conditions east of the mountains by late week.  All in all, the 
remainder of the work week continues to look dry and cool. 

Meanwhile an H5 trough will dig out of the Rockies promoting surface 
cyclogenesis and setting up a zone of baroclinicity over the lower 
MS valley and Midsouth regions by Friday afternoon.  At this point 
the guidance begins to diverge with regard to placement of both the 
upper/surface low tracks, as well as timing of said features. 
Nevertheless, as the entire complex shifts east overnight into 
Saturday isentropic upglide atop the entrenched surface ridge looks 
plausible, which depending on precipitation onset timing could yield 
a brief period of wintry weather early on Saturday morning before 
WAA favors all rain.  Precipitation will increase in 
coverage/intensity with passage of the upper low and any associated 
dynamic forcing through the day on Saturday into Sunday morning when 
the surface low slowly pulls away to the east.  As the upper trough 
swings overhead, profiles will begin to cool from the top down with 
critical thicknesses favoring a change over to snowfall during these 
overnight hours for the higher elevations, with a rain/snow mix in 
the valley.  Diurnal warming on Sunday will favor yet another phase

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
242 PM EST Tue Jan 8 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Wednesday)...

The cold front is still back to the west of the forecast area 
currently. Radar returns have been rather sparse today with little 
in the way of deep moisture across the area. The moisture has been 
confined to below 750 mb and strong low level winds have helped to 
mix out the cloud cover. The shallow moisture coupled with the lack 
of synoptic lift has left the forecast area mostly dry today. Winds 
ahead of the boundary have been rather impressive mixing down to the 
surface with gusts in the 20-25 kt range being reported. Models 
indicate increasing low level convergence and orographic lift as the 
front moves into extreme NE TN and SW VA. Expect to see a moderate 
increase in shower coverage but still only have around a 30-40 
percent chance for extreme NE TN and SW VA. The frontal passage is 
forecast to occur later this evening with strong cold air advection 
behind the boundary late tonight into Wednesday. Temperatures will 
be noticeably colder by Wednesday morning with lows in the upper 20s 
to mid 30s. Winds will remain elevated overnight into Wednesday 
morning with wind chills in the upper teens to mid 20s for most 
locations. Winds are forecast to be high enough for a wind advisory 
for the East Tennessee Mountains. These locations will experience 
wind gusts of up to 45 mph leading to single digit wind chills on 
Wednesday morning in the high terrain.

Cold air advection surges into the area late tonight into early 
Wednesday with northwesterly winds of 20-30 kts at 850 mb. 
Concurrently, a lobe of vorticity at 500mb will swing across the 
central and southern Appalachians. Models indicate some lingering 
shallow low-level moisture during this timeframe with low level lift 
as well. Due to this, there could be a few snow showers across the 
higher elevations of NE TN and SW VA but confidence is not overly 
high with the shallow nature of the moisture. Expect any snowfall 
accumulations would be limited to locations above 4 kft and would be 
less than an inch.

Highs will be much colder on Wednesday with strong cold air 
advection continuing. It will be a rather blustery days with strong 
northwest winds and highs only in the mid 30s to low 40s for most 
locations.

.LONG TERM (Wednesday night through Tuesday)...The weak clipper 
pattern with northwest flow and cold air advection could still 
produce a couple tenths of an inch of snow accumulation in the 
highest reaches of the mountains across extreme Northeast Tennessee 
Wednesday night before moisture and lift exits the region. Despite 
the return of sunshine on Thursday, the prevailing northerly flow 
will limit warming with high temperatures remaining a good ten 
degrees below normal. Short wave ridging builds into the area on 
Friday allowing for a little more warming sunshine after a cold 
start to the day. However, clouds will be spreading back into the 
Southeastern United States ahead of a weekend low pressure system 
that will bring light rain to much of the southern part of the 
forecast area later Friday night into Saturday morning. Winter 
precipitation is possible over northern sections with emphasis in 
the higher terrain as low level east to northeasterly flow should 
produce a temperature profile that keeps sub-freezing air in place 
during this late night period into Saturday morning. At this time, 
the main lift and deepest moisture with this system will arrive 
during an approximate twelve hour period later Saturday afternoon 
into Saturday night.  This would also coincide with the period of 
strongest warm air advection and a changeover to rain in all but the 
highest terrain. On Sunday, a trailing area of lift and moisture 
with a final upper level wave could get some snow showers going 
again in the higher terrain areas; especially across Southwest 
Virginia and Northeast Tennessee. This prevailing northwest flow 
pattern may last into Monday morning in the mountains before ending. 
This event is still five to six days away and several significant 
changes are possible in the system's track and surface low position 
with corresponding temperature structure changes from today's 
modeling depiction. However, a possibility for significant snow 
exists for our mountain locales due to the antecedent cold air that 
will likely be in place above three thousand feet. Drier air finally 
builds back into the forecast area for Monday night and Tuesday with 
high temperatures at least approaching normal for mid January.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
317 PM EST Mon Jan 7 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Tuesday)...

The main forecast challenges for the short term are temperatures, 
wind, and rain chances tonight and tomorrow. In the upper levels,
the eastern CONUS is under the influence of upper level ridging, 
while a trough digs into the upper Mississippi river valley. At 
the surface, high pressure was located over the southeast while an
area of low pressure progresses across the Great Lakes. At the 
same time, a cold front associated with the aforementioned surface
low extended south into Southern Plains. GOES water vapor/airmass
RGB data shows moisture continuing to stream aloft across the 
Southern Plains, and into the Mid South and Ohio Valley out ahead
of this surface front. The front will continue to slowly move 
eastward with time overnight with a slight increase in cloud cover
and precipitation chances. Not expecting heavy rainfall as the 
upper level dynamics remain weak, and overall moisture is limited.
In fact, it will likely take some time to moisten the column 
enough for rainfall to reach the surface as the 12z KOHX sounding
indicated the mid and low levels of the atmosphere to be very 
dry. Model soundings overnight do not really moisten the column 
sufficiently until the 03-06z time frame when low end chance PoP's
are introduced into the forecast. Low temperatures will be tough 
to forecast given the amount of cloud cover, and the fact that the
boundary layer never fully decouples under the WWA regime. Given 
this environment, steered away from any guidance that utilized a 
cooler MOS scenario. 

Tuesday remains cloudy as low level moisture looks to stick around
ahead of a 850mb thermal trough. However, additional mixing ahead
of the approaching front will likely keep maximum temperatures in
the upper 50's to low 60's. Would not be surprised to see drizzle
tomorrow as well given the magnitude of dry air above the
saturated low layer. The pressure gradient begins to tighten ahead
of the approaching frontal boundary tomorrow with an increase in
winds expected. The overnight shift will evaluate the need for a
wind advisory tomorrow.  

.LONG TERM...(Tuesday night through Monday)...

Main story for the long term portion of the forecast will be the 
return of cooler weather behind the cold front. Temperatures will 
drop a bit below normal for this time of year, and look to remain 
that way into next week.

On Tuesday and Wednesday breezy conditions will continue as strong 
850mb winds continue out of the northwest behind the front. Since 
winds will be out of the northwest we're not expecting a mountain 
wave event on the West side of the mountains, but nonetheless winds 
may flirt with advisory criteria in the highest elevations.

As the drier air continues to flow in from the northwest we enter a 
period of benign weather for the remainder of this work week and 
into the weekend. Over the weekend our next weather system will 
begin to impact the region. A trough and associated surface low will 
move across the Eastern half of the United States. Models are still 
waffling on how to handle the track of the low. Right now models are 
depicting the low to move near the Tennessee Valley sometime on 
Saturday into Sunday. Models differ with how much cold air will be 
associated with this system, which leads to a low confidence in 
precipitation type. Will need to keep an eye on this system as it 
could bring a bit of snow to a few of the Valley locations depending 
on the final strength/track.

.SHORT TERM...(Today and Tonight)...
The pattern through the short term will be highlighted by the closed 
upper low atop the ArkLaTex region, and the consequent surface low 
and frontal complex beneath and eastward along the lower MS valley. 
With that, a warm front continues to slowly move northward toward 
the I20 corridor at this time, however with abundant llv upglide 
further north into the lower TN valley.  Light rain continues across 
much of the southern tier of the fcst area, only to spread 
regionwide over the coming hours.  

As the warm front finally moves into the southern Appalachians after 
sunrise, a narrow H85 jet will traverse the region leading to modest 
gusting upward of 45-50mph at elevations greater than 3kft across 
the Smokies. Therefore the current wind advisory looks good with no 
changes planned. Precipitation rates will likely increase along the 
passing warm front as it spreads northward through mid/late morning, 
briefly lowering behind as the upper low and surface cold front 
approach.  Downsloping flow amidst the aforementioned sly llj with 
aid in localized drying closer to the terrain as well into the 
afternoon hours.  

As the cold front and upper low sweep in, the combination of frontal 
forcing and steepened lapse rates aloft will favor at least chances 
for a few thunderstorms, especially along/east of I75.  All in all 
the forecast features widespread likely/categorical pops this 
morning, tapering a bit into the early afternoon hours before 
ramping back up along the front when some thunder is mentioned. As 
for hazards today, other than the above mentioned high elevation 
winds, think most convection will be rather weak.  However, given 
saturated soils across much of the area, any modest thunderstorms 
this afternoon could produce 35-40mph wind gusts which could topple 
a few trees.  Some isolated flash flooding cannot be ruled out as 
well, especially along/north of I40 and along the I81 corridor into 
southwest VA where flash flood guidance is lowest. 

.LONG TERM...(Saturday through Thursday)...
An upper low will be pulling away from the Southern Appalachian 
Region Saturday morning but a few lingering pockets of light rain 
will continue to affect the area...mainly over the eastern half of
the CWA. Higher elevations should be cold enough for 
snow...though little to no additional accumulation is expected. 
High pressure builds in behind the exiting low for dry and 
seasonally warm conditions through the rest of the weekend. The 
mainly system of concern through the extended will be a cold front
progged to move through the area around the Monday/Monday night 
time frame. As the front moves through...expected a broken line of
showers to develop and track through the area. The air mass will 
be fairly stable and do not anticipate any thunder. Also...the 
temperature profile will be warm enough that it should be an all 
rain event. Accompanying the front will be a strong 850MB jet 
which should generate breezy and gusty winds across the higher 
elevations. A few showers may linger into Tuesday as the low pulls
out. Then...we should return to a quiet and dry weather pattern 
for the rest of the extended as high pressure once again builds 
in.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
258 PM EST Thu Jan 3 2019

.SHORT TERM...(Tonight and Friday)...
The closed low pressure system over the Red River Valley today will 
be tracking nearly due east through the period, bringing yet another 
round of moderate rainfall to the area. Isentropic lift in the warm 
sector of the cyclone will begin to spread rain into SE TN this 
evening, mainly between 03-06Z, and gradually spread northward. As 
850 mb winds back in response to the approaching low, the downslope 
component will increase and may delay precip in the northern half 
until late tonight. Frontogenetic forcing in the jet exit region 
will provide stronger lift for heavier precip rates in the 06-12Z 
time frame, and some locally heavy rain will be possible. QPF 
amounts will be highest in southern sections, between 1 and 1.25 
inches total. This is well below flash flood guidance for this area, 
so no flood watch will be necessary at this time, although localized 
minor flooding in the usual places will be possible. 

From 12-18Z tomorrow we will have drying aloft as the upper jet 
moves over the area, decreasing precip amounts and coverage. 
Southeasterly 850 mb winds will peak during this time, which will be 
in the 40-50 kt range, and may necessitate a Wind Advisory on later 
shifts, although it looks marginal at this time. The downslope 
winds may warm temps in the northern Valley and Foothills into the
lower 60s depsite abundant cloud cover. The center of the closed 
low moving directly overhead Friday afternoon will bring 
steepening lapse rates, and a slight chance of thunderstorms will 
be mentioned with this across the northern half of the area. As 
cold advection sets in late in the day, freezing levels will drop 
quickly after 00Z, allowing for a change to snow for higher 
elevations. Model soundings indicate that this will be mainly at 
or above 2500 ft elevation. Up to 1 inch accumulation may be 
possible Friday night for the highest peaks of the Smokies and NE 
TN mountains. Gusty W-NW winds will develop overnight as the 
system exits.

.LONG TERM...(Friday night through Thursday)...
Two main points of focus for this period: 1) Minor focus on any 
residual wintry precip the first few hours of the forecast 
Saturday morning and 2) see if there are any threats associated 
with the frontal passage early next week. 

For Saturday morning, conditions dry out very quickly, so only looks 
like about 2-3 hours of light snow showers in the higher elevations. 
My snow grid shows only a few pixels of 0.1" for Saturday morning. 
So no real further contribution to any early accumulations.

For the Front early next week--it looks to be racing through around 
next Monday night.  Doesn't look like there will be any instability, 
so will not introduce any thunder, and the showers associated with 
the front should sweep through pretty quickly.  Will have POPs 
Monday afternoon, Monday night, and Tuesday, but that is mainly a 
timing issue of when the front will pass through--the actual precip 
time with the front will likely only be an hour or two as the band 
of showers marches through--a little wider band and longer 
precip time north vs. south.

Monday afternoon the pressure gradient will be getting pretty tight, 
inducing a moderate to strong deep southwest flow up the valley. The 
angle is not good for a mountain wave event, but it is good for a 
gusty flow up the valley, and might be as high as advisory level 
Monday afternoon--we'll keep watching.  

Other than these two time periods, it should be drying out somewhat 
with below average precipitation for a change, and looking like 
temperatures will be notably above seasonal averages as well.

FXUS64 KMRX 012015
AFDMRX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
315 PM EST Tue Jan 1 2019

.SHORT TERM (Tonight and Wednesday)...
Moisture stream to our south will stay south overnight, then will
buckle back northward Wednesday as a closed low over the desert 
southwest ejects a disturbance into TX that shifts the southern 
jet northward back toward our area. Rainfall amounts will be light
Wednesday, and temps will remain mild. 

.LONG TERM (Wednesday night through Tuesday)...
On Wednesday night the much talked about southwestern upper low will 
be moving east into Texas. Meanwhile a northern stream trough will 
depart the upper midwest and move east towards New England. Rain 
should be rapidly expanding to the northeast across the forecast 
area during the late evening hours on Wednesday as broad ascent and 
a coupled subtropical and polar jet is in place overhead. Rain 
should taper off during the early morning hours on Thursday however 
as the northern stream trough pulls off the eastern seaboard and jet 
support wanes. Subsequent shortwave ridging will develop to the east 
of the upper low, still over central Texas by this time, to develop 
over the eastern Tennessee region. Expect much of Thursday to be dry 
as a result of this evolution, with rain not likely to spread back 
into the area until early Friday morning when the upper low nears.

Ahead of this feature, some downslope flow over the mountains 
develop. Don't expect winds to get to high wind levels by any 
stretch as H85 flow is sub 50kt at the peak. However wind advisory 
criteria may be reached in the higher terrain. Will watch how this 
progresses to see if any wind headlines will be needed. The more 
significant reason for bringing this up is that the upper low, and 
mid level low, swings through middle Tennessee and then up into 
southwest Virginia Friday into Friday night. This leaves our CWA in 
a downslope pattern, with some rain shadowing becoming a strong 
possibility as a result. Forecast PoPs as well as QPF amounts favor 
a mountain bias, with lesser values over the valley. This entire 
system pulls off to the northeast by late Saturday morning, bringing 
rain chances to an end. Guidance has trended warmer for several 
consecutive runs now with respect to mid level temperatures. Will 
still carry a rain/snow mix for mainly elevated locations Friday 
night. But given the trends, do not expect there to be a lot of snow 
with this.

High pressure and a warming trend will round out the weekend, with 
the chance for another system to impact the area late Monday night 
into Tuesday.

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Morristown TN
257 AM EST Tue Jan 1 2019

.SHORT TERM (Today and Tonight)...A few showers will linger over
the Southern Appalachian Region into the morning hours as frontal
system slowly exits the area. Low level moisture will remain in
place and some low clouds will persist for much of the day.
Otherwise...we will be between systems for the short term and
after the few morning showers exit the area...expect generally dry
conditions for the rest of today and through the night.
Additionally as the system pulls away...winds will continue to
decrease. Temperatures will remain above normal through the short
term with highs today reaching into the 50s and low 60s and lows
tonight mainly in the 30s and low 40s.

.LONG TERM (Wednesday through Monday)...We will continue to be in 
southwest flow aloft to start the period, with a stationary frontal 
boundary to our south. This front will begin advancing as a warm 
front on Wednesday, with an area of isentropic lift moving in from 
the south.  Will see a dry start, but some rain will begin moving in 
from south to north during the day, and will overspread the entire 
area Wed night. There should be lull in the precipitation during 
much of Thursday as somewhat drier air works in, but another round 
of showers can be expected by Thursday night into Friday as a 
mid/upper level low to our west advances east. Models have trended 
warmer with this upper low as it moves across our area Friday night, 
so right now it looks like if there is any snow it will be mainly in 
the higher elevations.  Will continue to mention this snow 
possibility in HWO.  While models not in great agreement yet, there 
is also some potential for mountain wave enhanced winds Friday as 
this system approaches, so will mention wind potential in HWO as 
well.  Once this system moves off to our east Saturday, drier air 
and high pressure look to be in control for the remainder of the 
period. Temperatures will generally be near to above normal during 
the entire period.
